tori paitan.author: Dave S.
tori paitan.review:
I stopped by on a Friday night around 8:30 pm and there were about 20 people in front of me in line. They do not take reservations and the seating inside is limited to about 25-30 and it is also communal seating. Since I came by myself, the server was able to offer me a single seat at the bar after waiting about 30 minutes. The bar seating overlooks the kitchen. 

After being seated the server came over quickly and I went ahead and ordered the Tori Paitan Ramen with a soft boil egg. The service was very efficient and friendly. The ramen was also brought out quickly. The broth was very rich and flavorful and the meat was tender. However, the egg was sweeter than I expected and closer to hard boiled than soft.    

They also charge a mandatory 15% service fee into the bill and they don't have any take out containers but you can bring your own. I would not recommend coming with a large group of friends and be expected to wait no matter when you come.

excerpts: I ordered the Spicy Tori Paitan (chicken soup, pork chashu, menma, spicy jalapeno miso, cabbage, fried burdock and green onion)
$17: I've been looking for a ramen place with thick egg noodles in SF
and I've finally found it!
The ramen was al dente and
the spicy jalapeno miso added just enough kick to it.
The chicken soup was very thick, almost to the point of being viscous, and was very flavorful.
I loved the crunchy fried burdock root and perfectly cooked soft boiled egg.
tori paitan.author: Nette T.
tori paitan.review:
For my 700th review, I'm giving this 4.5 stars. I'm knocking off half a star. Why? The wait. Yelpers said they waited at least 30 minutes to an hour. We waited over an hour and half. And we got there when they opened at 5. I think the best thing is to start queueing up at 4:15, that way you will be the first or second seating. For us we were the third seating and I was pretty tired by the time I got into the restaurant. It's not like Marufuku in Japantown where you can actually go and look at different shops so the time passes by quickly. Lesson learned. 

I came with my friend and thank goodness we were not that hungry because by the time we got seated, we were starving. Inside there are long tables that are meant to be shared.  We ordered Oysters in Shoyu and dare oil as a starter. 

I ordered the Spicy Tori Paitan (chicken soup, pork chashu, menma, spicy jalapeno miso, cabbage, fried burdock and green onion) $17: I've been looking for a ramen place with thick egg noodles in SF and I've finally found it! The ramen was al dente and the spicy jalapeno miso added just enough kick to it. The chicken soup was very thick, almost to the point of being viscous, and was very flavorful. I loved the crunchy fried burdock root and perfectly cooked soft boiled egg. I liked that the pork chasu was not too fatty and was able to eat most of the meat. 

Service was quick and our server moved quickly in between tables and taking orders. 

I'll definitely come back here but now I know to come extra early to be in the first seating of the night.

excerpts: Being our initial visit, the four of us agreed to go with the Tori Paitan ramen noodle soup.
Three of us went with the original, while my hubby had the spicy version.
That was the essence of our Tori Paitan.
Thick ramen noodles and great presentation.
tori paitan.author: Shirley N.
tori paitan.review:
We've been back from Japan about six months now.  Upon our return we stated we planned to try local ramen places.  So far this is just our 2nd place.  But definitely a winner!!!

We knew to come early before the restaurant opened at 5pm to secure first seating.  We arrived around 4:30pm on a Friday night, and already six people in line.  

Being our initial visit, the four of us agreed to go with the Tori Paitan ramen noodle soup.  Three of us went with the original, while my hubby had the spicy version.  We ordered imported Japanese beer to pair with our noodles.

The chicken soup broth was very flavorful.  That was the essence of our Tori Paitan.  Thick ramen noodles and great presentation.  Just the right amount of toppings.

We got the only 4 seats with chair backing.  Else you sit at one of two communal tables on high bar stools.

Service was quick and efficient.  We were in & out within the hour.

We've only been to two ramen shops in six months; however this one will be hard to beat.

excerpts: I ordered the tori paitan while my boyfriend ordered the shoyu.
We also ordered the two appetizers: oysters and enoki chips.
Both were tasty but the oysters were a bit too salty for me

I thought these were quite unique and tasted really good with a little lemon on top or even dipped into the ramen broth.
As for the ramen, I found my tori paitan to be very flavorful
and I loved the thick and toothsome noodles.
While the frothy broth was interesting at first, I feel like this caused the ramen to cool down really quick, making it less tasty.
My favorite part, however, was actually the duck chashu!
Cooked
perfectly-
I wish I ordered more!
The shoyu was quite good as well and I actually preferred the broth of the shoyu to the tori paitan.
tori paitan.author: Janice L.
tori paitan.review:
Finally made it out to Mensho on a Wednesday evening and just missed the first wave to be seated.  The wait after that was about 40 minutes long as the restaurant is quite small. 

I ordered the tori paitan while my boyfriend ordered the shoyu. We also ordered the two appetizers: oysters and enoki chips. Both were tasty but the oysters were a bit too salty for me and so I enjoyed the enoki chips much more. I thought these were quite unique and tasted really good with a little lemon on top or even dipped into the ramen broth. As for the ramen, I found my tori paitan to be very flavorful and I loved the thick and toothsome noodles. While the frothy broth was interesting at first, I feel like this caused the ramen to cool down really quick, making it less tasty. My favorite part, however, was actually the duck chashu! Cooked perfectly- I wish I ordered more! The shoyu was quite good as well and I actually preferred the broth of the shoyu to the tori paitan. 

Overall it was a pretty good meal, a little pricey but not too extravagant. They do have quite a few other options such as vegan tantanmen as well as some soupless noodles that I can't wait to try next time!

tori paitan.author: Lucy Z.
tori paitan.review:
Overall, I'm very whatever about ramen. But that was before I met Mensho. I love Mensho. I don't love the cramped seating but if I'm gonna sweat while I eat, it might as well be over a bowl of Mensho ramen. 

Friends and I came at 5:45 on a Friday night and waited around 30-45 mins. Not too bad and the good company made the wait seem shorter ;) 

We each ordered a different bowl with me being basic and getting the tori paitan and someone getting the matcha. Others ordered the vegan tantanmen and the spicy tori paitan. I added an egg to mine that honestly, you can probably skip. But that's only because I didn't like a cold egg. 

The matcha was weird, not gonna lie. Mine was my favorite but the vegan one was also really really good. I'd just order that for the tantanmen and add chashu because you know, meat. 

All in all, totally worth the wait and I can't wait to revisit.

excerpts: I am just okay with their best seller, Tori Paitan ramen.
tori paitan.author: Shannen B.
tori paitan.review:
Crazy about the Abura Soba here. The richness of the flavor is definitely enhanced by making the noodles "dry". It kind of reminds me of the dry saucy noodles I have back home in Indonesia, called Bakmi Ayam (Chicken Noodle). They give you a bottle of chili oil and a bottle of vinegar so you're able to adjust the amount of chili oil and vinegar for your noodles yourself. The noodles here are thick and chewy, just the way I like them. 

I am just okay with their best seller, Tori Paitan ramen. It's a little too heavy for me, but a lot of people like it. 

The restaurant is pretty tiny, so always expect a line, even on a weekday. The line is worth the wait, but honestly, try coming at around 4.40 to get first seating. They don't have any to-go boxes, so bring your own if you think you're not gonna finish the whole bowl, but honestly, you wouldn't be able to resist finishing the whole thing!

excerpts: After much deliberation and recommendations from our server, I ordered the Tori Paitan Ramen (double chashu) which is what they are known for.
I was given the heads up that this is not "typical" ramen as it has a creamier soup, but I thought I'd try it anyway.

Super tender and packed full of flavour.
I loved it.
The noodles were also done well.
Not too soft, but not too hard, just what I expected.
tori paitan.author: Samantha M.
tori paitan.review:
So, I should preface this by saying I'm a bit of a ramen newbie. As in, prior to this experience, I had never really had ramen other than the individual pouches of Mr. Noodles with those nifty flavour packets.

I wanted my first ramen experience to be amazing, so I did my research and I came across Mensho Tokyo and decided it would be a great addition to my foodie adventures on my San Fran vacay. I was totally pumped and ready to love it.

To start, I went there prepared to wait in line. Reviews advised that the wait would be around 30 minutes, ours was a bit closer to 40 but we did go around 7:00pm, prime dinner time, I guess! Fortunately the wait time gave us time to peruse the menu and decide what to order. I am thankful that the menu is not overwhelmingly long, but there were several interesting options so I had to choose carefully.

Once we got in, we could tell that the space is small, fitting maybe 20-25 people, which does explain the lineup. It has a nice cozy charm to it though, with a type of communal seating, and wall decor. Somehow it made the experience feel more authentic and worth the wait. This might not be ideal for some people looking for an intimate or private meal.

We decided to try the Enoki mushroom chips to start. I have absolutely zero regrets here- they were freakin' delicious! In fact, I would have been perfectly satisfied with a bowl of these for dinner! They're kind of like crispy onion strings you can get on burgers, same texture... but the flavour is just yummy. Disclaimer: I am a bit of a mushroom fanatic, so if you don't like mushrooms, these might not be for you.

After much deliberation and recommendations from our server, I ordered the Tori Paitan Ramen (double chashu) which is what they are known for. I was given the heads up that this is not "typical" ramen as it has a creamier soup, but I thought I'd try it anyway. I'll start by saying- the pork and duck chashu were delicious. Super tender and packed full of flavour. I loved it. The noodles were also done well. Not too soft, but not too hard, just what I expected. Unfortunately that is where my enjoyment ends. 

I won't fault the restaurant for it, but apparently I am not much of a miso fan and maybe I'm just not that into ramen, even though I really wanted to be! I did enjoy the overall experience, and will say that even though there was a bit of a mishap with my soup- our server worked quickly with her manager to rectify the situation, which I always do appreciate.

Overall- if you like ramen, definitely come check it out. But if you aren't sure if ramen is your thing, keep in mind the wait time!

Phenomenal and unique! It's one thing to have well executed ramen; it's another to have ramen that introduces you to new flavors and combinations that I think really exemplifies what ramen is capable of. Got the Tori Paitan Ramen of course, and it was so delicious! Definitely in my top 2 ramen spots. excerpts: Opted for the Tori Paitan Ramen; chicken soup, pork and duck charshu, menma, kale, burdock root chips and katsuobushi paste.
The broth is thick, creamy and fatty.
Paired with the slices of charshu adds more fattiness and savoriness to the bowl.
The burdock was a nice textural component and had a nice toasted, nutty flavor.
The kale and menma were overpowered by the richness of everything else in the bowl.
Ramen was thick with a good chew, but a little too thick for my preference
and I'm a huge fan of curly and thick ramen noodles!
The dish is so unctuous I felt uneasy.
The broth is nearly a sauce instead of a drinkable broth, thick noodles and fatty pork and duck made this bowl of ramen too much of a good thing.
Some acidity or brightness from another ingredient such as scallions or a lighter green would've helped a great deal.
tori paitan.author: Janet N.
tori paitan.review:
HYPE, HYPE, HYPE

Don't get me wrong, I'm all for the hype but sometimes too much of a good thing can be overkill. Take the hypebeasts rocking multiple hype brands in a fit worth more than your car payment, for example.

Mensho known as the first outpost of Tokyo's ramen chain, sets a high standard for ramen with its experimental flavor profiles, rich broth and modern approach. 

With a line forming outside the small shop in the Tenderloin, took a look over the menu and noticed the higher end of ingredients being used in the food they serve with of course an A5 Wagyu option for $39, limited to 10 bowls a day. Opted for the Tori Paitan Ramen; chicken soup, pork and duck charshu, menma, kale, burdock root chips and katsuobushi paste. The broth is thick, creamy and fatty. Paired with the slices of charshu adds more fattiness and savoriness to the bowl. The burdock was a nice textural component and had a nice toasted, nutty flavor. The kale and menma were overpowered by the richness of everything else in the bowl. Ramen was thick with a good chew, but a little too thick for my preference and I'm a huge fan of curly and thick ramen noodles! The dish is so unctuous I felt uneasy. The broth is nearly a sauce instead of a drinkable broth, thick noodles and fatty pork and duck made this bowl of ramen too much of a good thing. Some acidity or brightness from another ingredient such as scallions or a lighter green would've helped a great deal. Ate half of my bowl and was just overwhelmed by how excessively rich it was, it was crazy rich.

Small shop with really close quarters here, be forewarned. If you have social anxiety and/or have issues with people being in your personal bubble this is definitely not the place for you. You are literally elbow-to-elbow with people and yes, if your ramen slurp game is not on point you will get broth splattered on yourself as well as the guy next to you. Service wise the wait staff is attentive and quick. Food doesn't take too long to come out of the kitchen and you can keep yourself entertained watching their process on the TV or to look at their decor. You can keep your belongings in a basket on the ground.

Price point is high, which makes sense for the quality of ingredients used and the compositions of the ramen bowls. However, this isn't my cup of tea - I mean bowl of ramen.

Broth was super rich, creamy, heavy and delicious.
tori paitan.author: Karen H.
tori paitan.review:
Gosh I feel bad I didn't brave the lines earlier for this place. I loved it. One of the best if not the best shoyu or paitan ramen in the SF area. 

We arrived at 8:30 Pm on a Friday night and the line was about 20 deep. Wait was around 40 minutes. Staff is super attentive collecting party numbers in the line and accommodated everyone on a first come first serve basis. We were waiting for a table for 4 and even as double seats showed up, and though smaller parties were behind us, they took care to seat us first.

The menu is clean and easy to read. We ordered:

Oysters in shoyu dare oil - doesn't look appetizing, tastes like canned oysters in oil (not a bad thing).

Organic shoyu ramen with double chasu - this was DELICIOUS. I was opting for a less-rich broth so went with the shoyu. Great choice. They double chasu is an extra slice, totally also worth it. The smoky flavor of the chasu pairs well with the clean shoyu based broth. The kale was so tender yet held texture in the bowl, and I adored the noodles. Tender, squiggly awesomeness. The duck chasu is new to me in ramen, and added depth to the bowl. 

Spicy tori paitan ramen with double chasu - spicy isn't too spicy, noodles were a little different than the shoyu ramen (closer to typical ramen noodles). Broth was super rich, creamy, heavy and delicious. Some with duck and pork chasu as well.

Although this ramen in general is much more rich than what I'm used to, it's GOOD. It's not exactly comparable but seems to me to stand In its own category - I've not had ramen like this before and it was so good.

Egg isn't included and it's a must add for $1. A whole egg, perfectly cooked. $1 is worth it.

Parking and neighborhood is kinda sketch... but I didn't feel unsafe dining here. The spoon provided is also way too large IMO, and made of heavy metal and my hand was tired after using it halfway through.

I'll be back!

excerpts: This was my first time trying a tori paitan ramen, as I've always been more loyal to tonkotsu.
tori paitan.author: Calvin Z.
tori paitan.review:
I recommend coming here by yourself, as I was able to skip half the line. I would say it's worth ditching your friends to shorten your wait, since this is in the Tenderloin after all. The sooner you get inside, the less likely you'll get stabbed by a needle.

This was my first time trying a tori paitan ramen, as I've always been more loyal to tonkotsu. I will break down each component of the ramen.

The broth was so rich and packed with umami; if I could, I would carry around a thermos full of it everyday and just drink it. It was hot, savoury, creamy, and really hits the spot, even in the summer. If ramen broth could give out warm hugs, this would be it.

The toppings... were a bit weird. I'm not sure why there were random vegetables. They didn't really taste like anything, and if anything actually distracted me from the part I really cared about (the ramen and the broth). They just tasted so drastically different and didn't pair well at all with the ramen, so that sorta killed it for me.

The noodles... were nice and thicc, just the way I like it. They paired really well with the broth, as the chewiness and thickness held up really well to the bold flavour of the broth.

It's not a perfect bowl of ramen, but it's still pretty good. If they ditched the weird vegetables, and added a bit more noodles, I'd be more willing to line up every week and risk my life for a bowl.

excerpts: That rich and creamy broth in their Tori Paitan is so delightful.
I was instantly in love with their ramen, completely satisfied after finishing, and left wanting to come back for more!
I have no more words to say but to try it for yourself!
All of my friends loved their dishes - the Tori Paitan Ramen,  the Vegan Tantanmen, Spicy Tori Paitan Ramen, Shoyu Ramen and A5 Wagyu.
tori paitan.author: Katrine U.
tori paitan.review:
Mensho Tokyo is my favorite ramen place in the bay area. That rich and creamy broth in their Tori Paitan is so delightful. I was instantly in love with their ramen, completely satisfied after finishing, and left wanting to come back for more! I have no more words to say but to try it for yourself! All of my friends loved their dishes - the Tori Paitan Ramen,  the Vegan Tantanmen, Spicy Tori Paitan Ramen, Shoyu Ramen and A5 Wagyu. Delicious!!!

Please come between 4:00-4:30, so that you're in the first group of 28 that is served at 5 PM!  It feels so much better getting seated and served first, so you get to skip having to wait in line and watch people eat their food. 

Thank you to Yoshi for the delectable food! I will always recommend this place and their great service.

excerpts: We got the tori paitan and the shoyu.
I had heard that the tori paitan had a rich broth
but I didn't expect it to taste so thick and creamy.
It was actually a bit disgusting.
I really wanted to like it, but I just could not.

It felt like they just threw a bunch of veggies that really didn't need to be there - the burdock root that they add really made the dish taste out of place - the texture was very similar to apple peels..
The noodles were thick and wrinkly and didn't really taste like ramen noodles - felt a lot more like instant noodles, which was pretty disappointing.
I had a taste of the shoyu broth which was much lighter and edible than the tori paitan.
The best description of the tori paitan broth was a remark that I heard from the group beside me: "is this even soup?
tori paitan.author: Elisa L.
tori paitan.review:
There's overrated ramen, and then there's Mensho, where the ramen literally just tastes bad. I was craving ramen today and since it was only ~630pm we were willing to try waiting in line today. We waited 30-40 min for a table of 2. If you're an SF resident, you'll know that Mensho is in the heart of Tenderloin, so waiting in line here is not a pleasant thing with all of the drugged up homeless passing by yelling uncontrollably. 

When we got seated, we sat down at the communal table squished in between two groups. We got the tori paitan and the shoyu. I had heard that the tori paitan had a rich broth but I didn't expect it to taste so thick and creamy. It was actually a bit disgusting. I really wanted to like it, but I just could not. It felt like they just threw a bunch of veggies that really didn't need to be there - the burdock root that they add really made the dish taste out of place - the texture was very similar to apple peels.. The noodles were thick and wrinkly and didn't really taste like ramen noodles - felt a lot more like instant noodles, which was pretty disappointing. I had a taste of the shoyu broth which was much lighter and edible than the tori paitan.

The best description of the tori paitan broth was a remark that I heard from the group beside me: "is this even soup? it looks like peanut sauce". 

So.. yes if you'd like a peanut sauce soup with instant noodles and a bunch of random vegetables, try Mensho. 

Aside from the food and wait, our service wasn't anything special. She asked whether my friend was done his meal pretty early in. The front door was also left open so there was a cold draft in the restaurant. 

Do yourself a favor and go to Iza Ramen or Hinodeya and you won't have to wait as long nor eat shitty ramen.

excerpts: For the Macca Tori Paitan - The broth was too heavy for my palate.
The Macca powder dispersed on top the ramen was great for show, but did not add much to the culinary experience as I consumed chunks of Matcha powder here and
there - it did not blend well in the soup.
tori paitan.author: Vivienne K.
tori paitan.review:
The American child of Tokyo's famed Mensho ramen bar, the minimalistic, no-frills joint serves up innovative spins on traditional thick tonkotsu broth - tasty and satisfying indeed, yet too hyped for my tastes. It is good, but not wait 1.5hours good. 

The decor is simple, modern, and scientific - the science of molecular ramen.  The space is cozy - sitting around 20 people in short segments of time. 

For the Macca Tori Paitan - The broth was too heavy for my palate.  The Macca powder dispersed on top the ramen was great for show, but did not add much to the culinary experience as I consumed chunks of Matcha powder here and there - it did not blend well in the soup.  The chewiness of the noodle was fine, but the noodle width was a bit on the thick side. 

For the Organic Shoyu Ramen - The broth was too salty. Again, the chewiness of noodles fine - the noodles were flat and thin like Chinese style Wonton noodles.  It was a good, but not an amazing bowl of ramen that dreams are made of. 

For the Vegan tantanmen, the broth was too salty for me to handle. The chef was incredibly liberal with the salt in this dish.  The dish was thick and lacked a balance of flavors. I appreciate the use of mame, pea shorts and cilantro, but the vegetables were very much overshadowed by the thickness and saltiness. 

For the Aburasoba, I was quite actually pleasantly surprised!  This was my favorite ramen dish here. Certainly not the signature thick tonkotsu broth, but most certainly more well balanced, with chewier noodles in a delectable lighter sauce with a mix of Chashu, menma, green onion, and daikon sporouts.

excerpts: I ordered the Tori Paitan Ramen, and the BF ordered the Spicy Tori Paitan with double pork chashu (note that this one doesn't come with duck!).
Like I said, wow.
The broth is viscous and rich, like chicken noodle soup living its very best, fattiest life.

All of the toppings were delightful, from the burdock (a first for me) and the menma to the two chashus; the duck was the star, but I ended up sharing one of my two slices with the BF because his dish only came with pork.
We didn't love the spicy miso paste in his bowl, but it has a nice jalapeño kick that I wouldn't mind trying in other dishes.
tori paitan.author: Becca M.
tori paitan.review:
Wow. The broth alone is worth 5 stars.

We arrived a bit after opening (5:15) to a healthy line. Luckily, the line moved at a reasonable pace (people are obviously lingering over their bowls, but not obnoxiously so), and we finally sat down around 6. If you're in a hurry, definitely come around 4:30 to make sure you're included in the first seating--everyone in our group seemed to have joined the line after 5.

Onto the food. I ordered the Tori Paitan Ramen, and the BF ordered the Spicy Tori Paitan with double pork chashu (note that this one doesn't come with duck!). Like I said, wow. The broth is viscous and rich, like chicken noodle soup living its very best, fattiest life. All of the toppings were delightful, from the burdock (a first for me) and the menma to the two chashus; the duck was the star, but I ended up sharing one of my two slices with the BF because his dish only came with pork. We didn't love the spicy miso paste in his bowl, but it has a nice jalapeño kick that I wouldn't mind trying in other dishes. Honestly, the broth just felt too perfect to mess with.

One last note: I wasn't a huge fan of the noodles, since I've been on a thin, firm noodle kick lately (ever since we binged on Ichiran in Shinjuku), but they did work nicely with the thickness of the broth.

excerpts: I wish I ordered their Tori Paitan Ramen, which seems to be the highlight of their shop!
I'll try it next time I come.
Noodles seem to be handmade (?)
tori paitan.author: Jessica H.
tori paitan.review:
I came to Mensho Tokyo after being heavily referred to it. We arrived around 5:21PM on a Saturday afternoon, and had to wait around an hour before we were seated. There seems to always be a line no matter what, because the place is super small, and only has two rows of seats. The service is pretty quick though. They're quick to take your order, and quick to get your food out, so I recommend looking at the menu before you head inside. 

My party ordered 2 orders of Orangic Shoyu Ramen ($14.5) , and 1 Shio Ramen ($12). The Shoyu Ramen's broth tastes great at first, but after eating it for a while, it gets super salty, and makes you crave water. Their broth has a soy sauce like taste to it, while the Shio has a Fish Oil taste to their broth. I wish I ordered their Tori Paitan Ramen, which seems to be the highlight of their shop! I'll try it next time I come. Noodles seem to be handmade (?) because of their difference in length. 

Mensho Tokyo will always have a line, so I recommend getting here as early as possible, and waiting before opening. Prices are decent, but eating here made me feel really rushed since I felt like I didn't really get to sit and enjoy the place before finishing my food and getting out. The vibe here is very hipster with their white walls being decorated with chemistry ramen facts, and Drake being played in the background. 

This is not the place to go for authentic, whole in the wall ramen, but a place to go if you want simplistic, nice ramen (looks great in pictures!) I prefer more Japanese authenticity in my ramen, and a shorter wait time if possible personally, but this seems to be the place to try, for the moment.

excerpts: I would willingly die a thousand times waiting for another bowl of Tori Paitan.
The broth was so rich, so thick that after I finished all of the components, I looked deep into the remnants searching for answers to my deepest concerns.
I was sure as the sky would be blue in the morning that in that broth I could find Waldo, Carmen San Diego, the President's tax returns, the fabled land of Atlantis, and my lucky sock.
tori paitan.author: Albert L.
tori paitan.review:
I'm ready. 


Patience is a virtue. But, what is a 'virtue'? The dictionary describes a 'virtue' as "behavior showing high moral standards." The dictionary does not outline who's moral standards we follow and the bar for keeping ourselves high above those standards. I am only interested in high food standards. Waiting in line for 40+ minutes for 1 seat is definitely a high virtue. I only wished Mensho Tokyo positioned all of the seats to look outward into the salivating, longing eyes of hungry virtuous patrons. I've been on both sides of the glass and -- while one culminates in the other -- I would gladly pay more to watch someone upset with waiting watch me eat my super delicious food. 

In life, if you wait long enough, you might die waiting or you'll get what you were waiting for. There's only two options: wait or die waiting. I would willingly die a thousand times waiting for another bowl of Tori Paitan. The broth was so rich, so thick that after I finished all of the components, I looked deep into the remnants searching for answers to my deepest concerns. I was sure as the sky would be blue in the morning that in that broth I could find Waldo, Carmen San Diego, the President's tax returns, the fabled land of Atlantis, and my lucky sock. Alas, I only found satisfaction, tranquility, and a smile from heaven's door shining upon me welcoming a long lost stranger to nirvana. 

I then ordered another bowl so the hapless sacks in line would test their virtues.

excerpts: The Spicy Tori Paitan Ramen was as advertised, thick chicken/pork broth soup with tender chashu that melts in your mouth.
The spice was a lot
so I only used about 2/3 of it to reach the perfect blend of heat and umami.
The noodles made my face light up.
tori paitan.author: Barron C.
tori paitan.review:
Wow! I've walked past Mensho a dozen times and have always been too intimidated by the line to take the plunge. I'm glad that I found a time when there was no line and snuck in. 

The atmosphere is very clean and modern. The communal seating tables are very fun for anyone from groups to singles because you get to see all the interesting types of ramen people get. I didn't eat it, but the matcha ramen looked super cool!

The mushroom fries were fun, light, and tasteful. I've never had anything quite like it. 

The Spicy Tori Paitan Ramen was as advertised, thick chicken/pork broth soup with tender chashu that melts in your mouth. The spice was a lot so I only used about 2/3 of it to reach the perfect blend of heat and umami. The noodles made my face light up. Soooooo yum. 

The vegan ramen was very unique, almost nutty in a good way. I normally don't go for the vegan option but glad I tried it! 

I see why everyone says such good things about this place. Definitely will go back.

excerpts: The Tori Paitan was verrrrry thick and rich, almost like a gravy.
Both the Tori Paitan and Shoyu contained one piece of Chashu(option for double Chashu for 2$ more) and 2 slices of duck breast.
The duck was soo tender and the Chashu was melt in your mouth.
My friend had the Spicy Lamb
...mmmm the lamb flavor was prominent and the combination of spices were just perfect.
The noodles had a nice bite to 'em.
tori paitan.author: Mary R.
tori paitan.review:
I've been here twice in one month, both times around opening on a weekday. I've been lucky enough to get the last few spots without waiting. The place is small and fills up quickly. Seating style is communal, so expect to sit closely and share long tables with fellow ramen lovers. 

The ramen here is different from any other ramen spot I've tried in San Francisco. The Tori Paitan was verrrrry thick and rich, almost like a gravy. I also had the Organic Shoyu, the broth was flavored just enough n much lighter that the others I've tried here. Both the Tori Paitan and Shoyu contained one piece of Chashu(option for double Chashu for 2$ more) and 2 slices of duck breast. The duck was soo tender and the Chashu was melt in your mouth. My friend had the Spicy Lamb...mmmm the lamb flavor was prominent and the combination of spices were just perfect. The noodles had a nice bite to 'em. Bouncy and cut on the thicker side, just how I like it.

Definitely worth the wait! Would recommend to give Mensho a try!

excerpts: But, once I was inside, I ordered the Tori Paitan Ramen.
tori paitan.author: Mikayla R.
tori paitan.review:
I cry. This place has magical ramen. 

It was a pretty cold and windy night out in San Fran. My hunger for a good ole bowl of ramen was stirring up in my tummy. I quickly filed into the line that had formed outside of the restaurant. I gleamed at the people with their steamy bowls through the window glass; I knew this wait would be worth it.It took about 20-30 mins to get seated. But, once I was inside, I ordered the Tori Paitan Ramen.

HOLY SCHNIKES.

I've watched foodie videos my entire life practically, and this bowl in front of me had ALL the aspects of a great bowl of ramen. The noodles weren't too soft and had enough chew. The broth was soulful and intense, but not too salty. The duck and pork chashu were treated so beautifully; I should've ordered double. They even paid attention to the bamboo shoots. You could tell that they either made their bamboo shoots in house or had some local shop bring them in. The ramen bowl in it's entirety was happiness itself. 

I'd wait in that line out in the cold time and time again for another bowl of their ramen. If shipping a bowl of ramen to Texas was a thing, I'd have way too many orders by now.

excerpts: I got the Tori Paitan ramen.
The food came out fairly quick after ordering.
It was the creamiest broth I've ever tasted in ramen.
The noodles were firm at first, but got softer as it soaked in the broth.
It was a tad salty to me if I drank only the broth (but I am more sensitive to salt than others).
tori paitan.author: Maggie C.
tori paitan.review:
Waited for 75 minutes on a Saturday night around 6 pm. There are only 28 seats in the restaurant. 

I got the Tori Paitan ramen. The food came out fairly quick after ordering. It was the creamiest broth I've ever tasted in ramen. The noodles were firm at first, but got softer as it soaked in the broth. It was a tad salty to me if I drank only the broth (but I am more sensitive to salt than others). This place has definitely ranked in my top 3 for ramen places! 

Tips:
-No leftover containers so finish your food !!! 
-There are only 10 bowls each day of the clam butter ramen and wagyu ramen so come early for that!

excerpts: I ordered the Tori Paitan Ramen which I believe is their signature.
At $18, it's verrrryyyyy pricey
and it didn't even come with an egg.
I recommend adding the egg even though it's extra, it's quite tasty.
The broth is thick and very salty, almost like gravy.
It was rich but not the good kind of rich I was looking for.
The noodles were not my favorite type of ramen noodles, they were kind of like egg noodles combined with udon noodles.
Thicker and didn't help much with absorbing the soup flavor.
tori paitan.author: Nancy L.
tori paitan.review:
Michelin recommended, is Mensho the best ramen in SF? Probably....not? 2.5 stars for the ramen and .5 extra for their delicious egg and their enoki chips that topped your ramen. I've been getting mixed reviews about this place, some say it's good because it's so rich and some say it's bad because it's so rich. I really had to come and try it for myself. 

The line is a little intimidating but people don't really take that long when they're eating here, so it moves relatively fast if you're waiting for groups of 2-4. Can't tell you how long the wait is if you're waiting for anything larger.

I ordered the Tori Paitan Ramen which I believe is their signature. At $18, it's verrrryyyyy pricey and it didn't even come with an egg. I recommend adding the egg even though it's extra, it's quite tasty. The broth is thick and very salty, almost like gravy. It was rich but not the good kind of rich I was looking for. The noodles were not my favorite type of ramen noodles, they were kind of like egg noodles combined with udon noodles. Thicker and didn't help much with absorbing the soup flavor. I prefer the thinner and more supple Ichiran noodles because it makes for a much easier bite, while I found it difficult to pick up the noodles with the gravy like broth at Mensho.

Gratuity is already included, is that why they don't care to provide you any service at all? For three people after gratuity and adding an egg each, it came out to $25 a person. WHAT THE?!! I can understand the appeal if you're into thick gravy like ramen broth, but it's not what I'm used to and it's not what I enjoy. If you're looking for a very different type of ramen experience, then I say come thru, but whether it's worth $25 and waiting 30 minutes or more? Well that's for you to decide.

excerpts: My boyfriend and I shared a Tori Paitan ramen (extra chashu) and a Spicy Lamb ramen (also extra chashu - yeah
, we're extra).
Both were super flavorful but also very thick and creamy with thick noodles, so if that's really not your thing, I'd recommend ordering something else or going elsewhere for ramen.
The duck chashu in the Tori Paitan was a unique touch that was perfectly cooked, and the pork chashu was so tender that it literally just broke into pieces at the touch of my chopsticks.
tori paitan.author: Sara L.
tori paitan.review:
Move over, Nojo and Marafuku - I think I've found my new favorite ramen spot in the city.

I'll be real, I don't know if this review would be 5 stars if I had some ridiculous wait. By some miracle, I only waited 20 minutes to get seated for a table for two at 7:30pm on a Friday night, which was a great start.

My boyfriend and I shared a Tori Paitan ramen (extra chashu) and a Spicy Lamb ramen (also extra chashu - yeah, we're extra). Both were super flavorful but also very thick and creamy with thick noodles, so if that's really not your thing, I'd recommend ordering something else or going elsewhere for ramen. Ordering a Japanese beer with the bowl was the PERFECT way to cut the richness of it all, but if you don't, it'll definitely feel heavier than most ramen. 

Toppings wise, the best part was the meat. The lamb inside the spicy lamb ramen was super tender cumin lamb with just a hint of numbing spice (ugh, I LOVE cumin lamb). The duck chashu in the Tori Paitan was a unique touch that was perfectly cooked, and the pork chashu was so tender that it literally just broke into pieces at the touch of my chopsticks.

Price wasn't unreasonable for SF. The surrounding area isn't great, but if you go at a slower time it's not much of an issue.

excerpts: After seeing some amazing reviews and the picture of the Matcha Tori Paitan ramen i was totally sold that i had to try this place out and endure the line up!
My group and i arrived to the restaurant around 6pm and there was about 30 people lining up.
The wait wasn't too bad for a Michelin recommended restaurant.
Waited for about an hour and we were in and seated together.
I ordered the Matcha Tori Paitan and was pretty happy with the order!
The broth was really really creamy and thick
but i didn't taste much of the matcha.
It was really pretty and unique so worth a try for $17.
When i went they also had a wagyu ramen as well for $39 and they only serve 10 of those a day.
Didn't see anyone order wagyu ramen
but it was neat to see them have specialty ramen every now and then.
The experience did take a bit of turn when one of our friends chewed out out piece of thick string in their ramen.
The server explained it was used for wrapping the chasu and apologized and replaced the bowl right away.
But it was very unfortunate that she found a small fly floating in the soup in her replacement bowl...
it was a bit ironic to have this happen to a Michelin recommended restaurant
but i guess these things can happen anywhere.
The server was yet again very kind and apologetic and replaced it with a third bowl and comp the meal for her.
Luckily no finding in the third bowl!
It was unfortunate this happened but their service and taste definitely makes up for it.
Hope this will be a good chance for them to be a bit more aware and reflect to be more attentive with their food preparation even when they are highlighted as Michelin recommended.

excerpts: we ordered the shoyu oysters, fried enoki mushrooms, tori paiton spicy ramen, and tori paitan with extra chashu ramen along with their craft beer Coedo Shiro.
Tori Paitan Ramen 3/5
The ramen was a bit murky and grainy.. and I don't know.. a little flat without depth of flavor.
Or maybe there was too much flavor
everything was kind of fighting each other
so it cancelled everything out, which made it just.. murky.
The noodles had a good bite to it and the soup was able to hold on to the noodles.
The chashu was good, the best thing about the bowl of noodles, it literally melts in your mouth.
tori paitan.author: Jean C.
tori paitan.review:
So we heard a lot about this place and happen to be in town so we were really excited to try it. When we got there at 7:30pm, already the line was out the door. We waited for an hour and our appetite was building by the time we got seated. Being ravenous, we ordered almost everything on the menu.. we ordered the shoyu oysters, fried enoki mushrooms, tori paiton spicy ramen, and tori paitan with extra chashu ramen along with their craft beer Coedo Shiro.

Here's the breakdown of the food:

Fried Enoki Mushrooms 5/5
The best thing we had here were definitely the fried enoki mushroom. They were meaty and has such great umami flavors and super crunchy. Yummmm

Shoyu Oysters 0/5
This definitely was not for me and it's really an acquired taste. The oysters seem to be cured in the shoyu leaving it in a kind of pasty and chalky kind of texture. It doesn't have that sort of plump texture that oysters have so that definitely kind of threw me off. Also, the brininess flavor was also lost and all you could taste was the soy sauce flavor. 

Tori Paitan Ramen 3/5
The ramen was a bit murky and grainy.. and I don't know.. a little flat without depth of flavor. Or maybe there was too much flavor everything was kind of fighting each other so it cancelled everything out, which made it just.. murky. The noodles had a good bite to it and the soup was able to hold on to the noodles. The chashu was good, the best thing about the bowl of noodles, it literally melts in your mouth. Overall, I thought the broth was just too murky and salty, it was hard to taste the broth altogether.  

Coedo Shiro 4/5
I like it, it's very light and refreshing but it wasn't cold which was kind of strange. Cold beer is a must, so I had to deduct a point there. 

All in all, our bill plus the mandatory tips came out to be $68 which is ridiculous for two bowls of ramen with appetizers and a bottle of beer. I mean yes I know this is SF prices but I wouldn't come here again to wait an hour for the food here.

excerpts: The broth that immediately caught my attention was the Tori Paitan; although I usually don't care for a chicken-based broth, I've heard amazing things about Mensho's rendition.
For those of ya'll who can eat a horse, this restaurant also serves two appetizers and double meat/extra toppings can be added to any ramen.
Plus, the list of drinks is almost as large as the number of food items!
In terms of pricing, Mensho is definitely on the higher end.
I ended up ordering the Spicy Tori Paitan and my girlfriend got the regular Tori Paitan.
-Spicy Tori Paitan (8/10): Besides the consistency of the broth, I really enjoyed this bowl.
The spicy miso definitely added some heat (was sweating!), the cabbage was fresh, and I felt like they gave a decent amount of noodles.
Tori Paitan is SLIGHTLY DIFFERENT compared to the spicy version.
For example, the regular one has both pork and duck.
On my girlfriend's end, she echoed the same sentiments I had about my Spicy Tori.
tori paitan.author: Bryan W.
tori paitan.review:
For the longest time, I had Mensho Tokyo bookmarked at the top of my list. With over 1k reviews, this place is regarded as one of the top ramen shops in San Francisco. After months of trying to find the best time to go, I finally had the chance to check Mensho out with my girlfriend last week.

To describe our experience, I need to use a basketball analogy. For many fans, LeBron James is considered the greatest player of all time. To me, I find this debatable (Kobe 5ever!). But just because I don't believe LeBron is the best doesn't mean I do not respect his greatness.

So what's this got to do with Mensho? Before y'all report this review as irrelevant, let me explain. First off, I understand the hype around this restaurant. Overall, the food was tasty, atmosphere felt chill, and service seemed efficient. But, just like how I feel about LeBron, I didn't think Mensho was the best ramen shop ever. Nevertheless, I have to admit that this place was legit!

Coming into Mensho, I had actually thought this restaurant would have a limited amount of choices. In my experience, well-established ramen joints usually specialize in only a few dishes. One look at their menu and it was clear that I was wrong. Mensho has at least 8 distinct kinds of ramen - each unique in its own way. The broth that immediately caught my attention was the Tori Paitan; although I usually don't care for a chicken-based broth, I've heard amazing things about Mensho's rendition. For those of ya'll who can eat a horse, this restaurant also serves two appetizers and double meat/extra toppings can be added to any ramen. Plus, the list of drinks is almost as large as the number of food items! In terms of pricing, Mensho is definitely on the higher end. Ramen here can cost anywhere from $14-$20 not including tax+tip. 

I ended up ordering the Spicy Tori Paitan and my girlfriend got the regular Tori Paitan. Here's what we thought: 

-- GOOD, BUT NOT FOR EVERYONE --
To put it bluntly, the ramen here was great but definitely not what we expected. For both our bowls, the sheer quality of our ingredients - the texture of the noodles, melt-in-your-mouth softness of the meat, and freshness of the toppings - was unrivaled. However, when it came to the broth we felt like it was WAY TOO CREAMY. I LOVE thick af soup, but the Paitain broth tasted more like a sauce than anything else. 

-Spicy Tori Paitan (8/10): Besides the consistency of the broth, I really enjoyed this bowl. The spicy miso definitely added some heat (was sweating!), the cabbage was fresh, and I felt like they gave a decent amount of noodles. On the other hand, I wished that I got more than 1-2 pieces of Chasu - especially if I'm paying $20 (including tax+tip).

-Tori Paitan (7/10): Protip for everyone...Tori Paitan is SLIGHTLY DIFFERENT compared to the spicy version. For example, the regular one has both pork and duck. On my girlfriend's end, she echoed the same sentiments I had about my Spicy Tori. Creamy soup aside, she really loved the Chasu (very soft and flavorful) as well as the noodles. 

-- SMALL, BUT HOSPITABLE ATMOSPHERE -- 
Although the size of Mensho was SUPER TINY (can only fit like 20 people max at one time?), the restaurant made up for this with a really welcoming environment. For instance, I loved the lighting, the decor was beautiful, and they even had coat hangers/boxes for bags that helped save space. Ironically, the bathroom was big too! My favorite part had to be the setup. Every table is essentially communal, and it may force you to interact with your neighbor; some may hate this, but I was all for it.

-- FRIENDLY, EFFICIENT SERVICE -- 
Every employee was super kind and very quick to respond. Even with the large crowds, we were able to take as long as we needed to eat without ever feeling rushed. 

-- LONGER WAIT THAN THE DMV -- 
If you ever want to try this place you better get here BEFORE THEY OPEN (5pm Tuesday-Sunday). We stopped by around 5:10pm and still had to wait ~30 minutes to get in. Also, don't bother showing up with more than four people unless you have all night.

When planning a trip here, I encourage y'all to take advantage of San Francisco's public transportation system because parking/driving around this area SUCKS. The restaurant is half a mile from Powell St. BART, and there are plenty of bus lines along/near Geary. I will feel bad for you if you end up spending 30 minutes trying to find parking and then having to wait another hour to be seated.

All in all, I find that Mensho Tokyo is really for individuals who love a super thick broth in their ramen - at least when it comes to most of their options. For me personally, I enjoyed my first time here. Despite the wait, it was worth it to say that I finally had a chance to eat at Mensho. But for the price and some of the nitpicky things, I probably wouldn't come back often. I give Mensho Tokyo a "Nice-su, you can take your parents here and they'll be happy" rating. Itadakimasu!

Eat well and prosper,

excerpts: We were able to try the Tori Paitan and of course the Matcha Tori Paitan.
You can definitely tell why they're the crowd favorites.
tori paitan.author: Isabel C.
tori paitan.review:
Matcha Ramen and ALL THE (well-deserved) HYPE. 

I'd be lying if I said that wasn't the reason why my friends and I tried this ramen spot. Mensho Tokyo has had such a good reputation in terms of the quality of their food and the atmosphere of their restaurant. They have a very modern, communal design for their restaurant that gives off a very at-home vibe for their customers. They also have an automatic service charge since they are a gratuity free establishment!

We were able to try the Tori Paitan and of course the Matcha Tori Paitan. You can definitely tell why they're the crowd favorites. The broth was SO rich and creamy, the noodles were better than anything we've had anywhere else, and the meat was melt in your mouth good. 

We arrived an hour before closing on a Tuesday night and there was about a 10 min wait (which is not bad at all especially since were expecting a much longer wait). One thing to note is that it was a pretty cold night so my friends and I went inside to wait inside the restaurant for a little bit. A server acknowledged us and told us that it will be a couple of minutes and we should be seated soon. Before we got a chance to go back out, another server saw us and condescendingly told us to go outside since we weren't allowed to wait inside. Our apologies, we've never been there before and we were cold. 

Other than the weird customer service hiccup, highly recommend Mensho Tokyo!

excerpts: For food I went with the Spicy Tori Paitan Ramen with double chashu each time.
The first round I forgot to order an egg, the second time I wasn't so careless.
The broth had a good kick and it had an amazing creamy texture.
tori paitan.author: Ryan C.
tori paitan.review:
Mensho was one of those places that was so good, I had to come back the next day to have it again.

There is always a line. I heard it's super crazy when they first open, but I waited until after 8PM on both occasions and went by myself for easier seating. By doing this, the wait was always less than 15 minutes before I snagged a spot. If you go in a group of two, the wait wont be as bad, but if you try to come with more than that, then good luck - you might be there for a while.

Because the place is small, single eaters will be sat wherever there is space. That means if a party of five is having a dinner full of inside jokes, guess who's the creepy uncle in the corner quietly trying not to make eye contact. I didn't mind. Just buried my face into one of the best bowls of ramen I've ever had.

For food I went with the Spicy Tori Paitan Ramen with double chashu each time. The first round I forgot to order an egg, the second time I wasn't so careless. The broth had a good kick and it had an amazing creamy texture. The noodles were perfectly cooked and a little thicker than the traditional ramen that I was used to.

I wish you could order extra noodles, but they have the food coming out like a well oiled machine. One bowl is plenty and you'll be sweating out all those amazing spices for the next 24 hours. Worth it.

If you have some time to kill and you don't mind waiting for your food, I highly recommend Menhso.

I never eat duck but it came with
so I went for it.
It was actually delicious and very tender.
The broth was rich, but it was just that.

The chives and cabbage were a great touch.
The eggs was deliciously fermented but it was cooked all the way through.
There's something oddly satisfying with that hot broth and partially runny egg

tori paitan.author: C T.
tori paitan.review:
2 of us waited for about 45-50 minutes to get seated. It was crazy because when we called the staff person said "45-50 min". He's obviously timed these lines perfectly! 

We ordered the tori paitan ramen and it was good. I never eat duck but it came with so I went for it. It was actually delicious and very tender. The broth was rich, but it was just that. It was extremely flavorful for the amount of richness that appears in the photos. The chives and cabbage were a great touch. The eggs was deliciously fermented but it was cooked all the way through. There's something oddly satisfying with that hot broth and partially runny egg but oh well.

Prices were steep. With the wait factored into it, the broth not being my #1, and not allowing to go containers for your leftovers, I give this 4 starts. I would not go again simply because of the way and can think of several other places I'd rather go to.

excerpts: We ordered the fried enoki chips to share and I ordered the Tori Paitan ramen with double chashu and a soft boiled egg.
They brought us our appetizer first to start before then preparing our entrees.
The enoki chips were crispy and were pleasant to snack on, however for the $6 price tag I wouldn't get it twice.
Once we worked our way through the chips, they brought out our ramen.
Upon trying the broth, you're hit with a lot of flavors as well as the thick/creamy texture.
It was also interesting to see a variety of vegetables including kale and cabbage included.
The chashu was worth adding, falling apart immediately as you pick it up or bite into it.
The egg was a bit of a disappointment.
It was marinated in tea and the flavor permeated the egg, but the egg itself was more cooked than soft boiled, unfortunately.
The same went for my 2 other friends that also ordered an egg.
I wouldn't pay for the egg again.
Despite that, the overall dish was very filling and we all left in a food coma.

Paying about $27 per person (15% tip is automatically added to your bill), it was definitely a hefty price tag as well as a very long wait if you don't come early enough, and for that I wouldn't come here often just to get my ramen fix.
However, I wouldn't be averse to coming once or twice more to try some of the other options here.
tori paitan.author: Vivian Y.
tori paitan.review:
Our friend living in SF brought my boyfriend and I here on a late Friday afternoon. We got here about 30 minutes before opening and there was already a decent number of people lined up outside the restaurant, a sign of the huge hype for this place. We were able to make it in the first wave right after opening and were seated at a shared table with several other people. The space inside is fairly small but it seats a decent number of people. The tables are also very similar to the restaurants in Japan, with small cubbies to store your bags and belongings.
We ordered the fried enoki chips to share and I ordered the Tori Paitan ramen with double chashu and a soft boiled egg. They brought us our appetizer first to start before then preparing our entrees. The enoki chips were crispy and were pleasant to snack on, however for the $6 price tag I wouldn't get it twice.
Once we worked our way through the chips, they brought out our ramen. Upon trying the broth, you're hit with a lot of flavors as well as the thick/creamy texture. It was also interesting to see a variety of vegetables including kale and cabbage included. The chashu was worth adding, falling apart immediately as you pick it up or bite into it. The egg was a bit of a disappointment. It was marinated in tea and the flavor permeated the egg, but the egg itself was more cooked than soft boiled, unfortunately. The same went for my 2 other friends that also ordered an egg. I wouldn't pay for the egg again.
Despite that, the overall dish was very filling and we all left in a food coma. Paying about $27 per person (15% tip is automatically added to your bill), it was definitely a hefty price tag as well as a very long wait if you don't come early enough, and for that I wouldn't come here often just to get my ramen fix. However, I wouldn't be averse to coming once or twice more to try some of the other options here.

excerpts: We got the Tori Paitan.
The soup was thick and salty.
But everything else was not very flavorful.
The pork chashu also didn't have a very good texture.
tori paitan.author: Iris H.
tori paitan.review:
I had put off coming here for the longest time since they always had a line. But one Friday night around 10 pm, I decided to give it a try -- there couldn't possibly be a long line at 10:30 at night, right? Right? 

Wrong, we waited for over an hour for a table for 2, getting seated right before 11:30pm, their closing time. So I guess the lesson here is they have a pretty long line at any time of day, if you want to eat here, just accept that you will have to wait ;) 

The wait would've been okay if the food was good. But the ramen was disappointing -- it could just be my personal preference but my husband and I both didn't like it at all, and we LOVE ramen. 

We got the Tori Paitan. The soup was thick and salty. But everything else was not very flavorful. The pork chashu also didn't have a very good texture. The duck chashu was the only thing that was okay. 

To make it worse, the service was not attentive at all. We didn't get a glass water until 45 minutes after we arrived and asked for water twice. 

Not to mention the very noisy environment where the people who we sat right next to (big shares tables) were very drunk...

excerpts: I ordered the Tori Paitan Ramen which came pretty quickly.
The broth was rich.
The noodles and the other items tasted good as well.
tori paitan.author: Mitch T.
tori paitan.review:
I've been hearing so much about this place.  I've noticed that the inside is always packed and the line is outrageously long.  So, I decided to check this place out one Thursday evening.  I arrived at about 4:15pm and was the 3rd person in line.  As expected, a large crowd started filing in behind me.  As the doors opened, I was intrigued by the attentiveness and efficiency of the staff.  I got a seat at the counter looking into the kitchen which I thought was pretty cool.   I ordered the Tori Paitan Ramen which came pretty quickly.  The broth was rich.  The noodles and the other items tasted good as well.  I'd have to say I enjoyed having the duck included because I personally don't eat it often.  

It worked out well for a single diner.  But be aware, this is no place for a large group or an intimate dinner.  People are packed into this place and you might feel you are on your neighbors lap listening to their conversation.  

Overall, I really enjoyed this place.  I'm giving this place a 4+ because I can't say I am a Ramen connoisseur compared to some of my friends.

excerpts: I got the Matcha Tori Paitan, and I tried my friend's Spicy Tori Paitan, which I liked more (the kick is there!).
When I took my first bite out of the Matcha Tori Paitan, I got a lot of pepper in that bite, which was not pleasant at all.
LOL, so make sure you mix everything before consuming.
Also, I could taste a bit of a bitter aftertaste from the matcha.
tori paitan.author: Tiffany H.
tori paitan.review:
Yaas! Super creamy broth and thick noods are the way to go. I really liked their noodles because the noodles were a bit chewier and had a bounce/elasticity to them. 

I got the Matcha Tori Paitan, and I tried my friend's Spicy Tori Paitan, which I liked more (the kick is there!). When I took my first bite out of the Matcha Tori Paitan, I got a lot of pepper in that bite, which was not pleasant at all. LOL, so make sure you mix everything before consuming. Also, I could taste a bit of a bitter aftertaste from the matcha. Overall, the dish was an interesting try, but I'm not sure if the matcha such a good match. 

Do get their soft boiled egg! Ajitama comes in two flavors: soy sauce or miso. I got the miso flavored egg, and I was super impressed with how they got flavor in the yolk! So delish.

Came here at 5pm on Super Bowl day, so the line wasn't bad. My friend and I were seated when the restaurant opened, so there was minimal wait time. Good stuff. Super filling meal due to creamy broth. Service was decent. Gratuity is included.

excerpts: I've tried their tori paitan, matcha, and lamb ramens and they are all satisfying.
Parking is hard in the area and there may be a wait outside, but just give yourself more time and strategize your dinner plans!
Be patient, arrive a little earlier (they open at 5pm, so try and get there before 5:30), and enjoy your meal
tori paitan.author: Tiffany Z.
tori paitan.review:
So good!!! Love this ramen spot. A bit more pricey, but worth it! It's the most tastiest ramen in the area without a doubt. The ramen noodles have a nice texture and the soup base is thick and creamy.  

The entire bowl's ingredients and proportions compliment each other really well. Never felt that there was too much or too little of something.
They have a pretty unique menu to pick from, none seem to disappoint.
The restaurant is pretty small, seating wise. They have 2 long tables for people to sit across from each other and pretty much shoulder to shoulder with your neighbor lol. There are baskets under the table to put your bags in (and your feet I suppose). I've tried their tori paitan, matcha, and lamb ramens and they are all satisfying. 
Parking is hard in the area and there may be a wait outside, but just give yourself more time and strategize your dinner plans! Be patient, arrive a little earlier (they open at 5pm, so try and get there before 5:30), and enjoy your meal :).

excerpts: I had the Tori Paitan and it was delicious!
tori paitan.author: Tyler T.
tori paitan.review:
Despite the long wait, I would say the ramen here is some of the best there is in San Francisco. The place is rather small, so you may be sitting with some neighbors if you come with a small party, but it was an overall cozy and enjoyable atmosphere.

I had the Tori Paitan and it was delicious! Be aware that it is rather chickeny, especially the broth which at points did feel a bit too heavy and kind of felt like there was chicken blended into it.

That being said, it was still amazingly delicious, and the flavors, textures, and profile were all on point! I especially enjoyed the addition of the egg, which was soft-boiled just right and had the perfect amount of flavoring.

The foaminess of the ramen soup base was also quite excellent, and honestly, I'll probably have to come back to try the other ramen flavors cause this one was so delicious.

excerpts: I ordered the enoki mushroom chips and the tori paitan ramen.
The enoki mushrooms were deep fried and very similar in taste and texture to hash browns so needless to say they were great.
The tori paitan ramen had a creamy chicken soup broth, pork and duck chashu, kale, and burdock
and I added a soft boiled dark soy egg.
The tori paitan ramen had a creamy chicken soup broth, pork and duck chashu, kale, and burdock

tori paitan.author: Sean G.
tori paitan.review:
Tiny little shop which results in long lines but it has a nice atmosphere for dates. I came late at night on a random week day tho by myself so it wasnt too bad. 

I ordered the enoki mushroom chips and the tori paitan ramen. The enoki mushrooms were deep fried and very similar in taste and texture to hash browns so needless to say they were great. The tori paitan ramen had a creamy chicken soup broth, pork and duck chashu, kale, and burdock and I added a soft boiled dark soy egg. It was very filling and flavorful and among the best ramen iv had in the area.

In the running for the best ramen in the area the only downsides are the hot cramped location and they charged me a hidden 15% gratuity while dining alone at off peak hours. No one was able to explain to me why or what it was for but they ran my card without leaving me an option to tip on the receipt. I usually tip 20% minimum so financially it balanced out it just made no sense to me.

Will come back again, again and again...

tori paitan.review:
By far my favorite ramen shop in SF! I'd dream about their tori paitan ramen sometimes cuz it's that unique (has chicken thick broth and duck breast) and good! 
We had the matcha tori ramen and the limited A5 wagyu ramen this time. The matcha taste is not that strong so it's similar to the regular tori paitan ramen. The wagyu ramen is flavorful. However I prefer the broth to be a little bit lighter so the wagyu can standout even more. 
Prepare for a super long wait (1-2 hours) and entertain yourself in line. Other than that everything else is fantastic! Staff is super friendly too! Will come back again, again and again...

excerpts: The second time I got the spicy tori paitan, which wasn't as tasty.
Still better than all the other ramen I've had in the Bay, I think, but the flavor was less interesting than the spicy lamb.
It was less spicy and a good bit cleaner, with a less intricate flavor.
tori paitan.author: Shawn W.
tori paitan.review:
I waited 45 minutes in line at Mensho, then an hour a second time exactly  a week later. Both times were totally worth it.

The first time I got the spicy lamb ramen and it may have been the best ramen I've ever had. The ground lamb was moist and had a very strong, appetizing cumin flavor, the pork chashu was most and tender, and the thick noodles were delicious down to the last shreds hiding away at the bottom.

The broth was similarly fantastic. It was at that perfect spicy level where it feels good to eat, but didn't have me downing glass after glass of water. It was very rich and what I would call "dirty", but in a good way. There was a lot of flavor and texture going on, with each sip making me want to take the next. Overall masterfully executed, even better than most of the ramen I had in Tokyo.

The second time I got the spicy tori paitan, which wasn't as tasty. Still better than all the other ramen I've had in the Bay, I think, but the flavor was less interesting than the spicy lamb. It was less spicy and a good bit cleaner, with a less intricate flavor. It was still very thick though, and filled me up fast.

The ramen itself was easily five stars, but the line is awfully long and frequented by aggressive panhandlers. A system to allow customers to wait in a warmer, less-shifty place and be notified via text message would be greatly appreciated (Nowait, anyone?). Also, a bowl of ramen after tax and included 15% tip comes out to $20, which is a bit pricey for what is essentially Japanese fast food. But overall, the food outweighs the other stuff and it's overall definitely worth the wait and price to visit Mensho.

excerpts: * Tori Paitan Ramen: DELICIOUS!
omg my mouth is watering just thinking about it.
What's special about this ramen is that it has chashu and duck!
The broth is rich, flavorful, with that umani flavor as well.
* plum wine: really sweet and good!
Really small portions though
* matcha ramen: pretty good, but not worth the extra couple dollars.
The tori paitan is just as good!
tori paitan.author: Jamie N.
tori paitan.review:
Make sure to get there 30 minutes before it opens!! Otherwise the line is HELLA LONG. 

I've been here twice and ordered the same thing both times because it was that good.
I ordered:
* Fried enokki: SO GOOD! Crispy with that umani flavor
* Tori Paitan Ramen: DELICIOUS! omg my mouth is watering just thinking about it. What's special about this ramen is that it has chashu and duck! The broth is rich, flavorful, with that umani flavor as well. 
* plum wine: really sweet and good! Really small portions though 
* matcha ramen: pretty good, but not worth the extra couple dollars. The tori paitan is just as good! 

Really recommend, but make sure to go early!

excerpts: My go tos are the Tori Paitan and the Spicy Lamb.
Tori Paitan never disappoints on cold SF evenings with its thick rich flavorful broth, but spicy lamb can be a little too salty sometimes.
tori paitan.author: Solongo B.
tori paitan.review:
For some strange reason, I crave Mensho almost exclusively on Mondays...the only day I can't have Mensho. Then I go through the test of patience and suffering until Tuesday. 

Needless to say Mensho is my favorite ramen spot in the city because of my love for. Thick. Rich. Ramen. 

My go tos are the Tori Paitan and the Spicy Lamb. Tori Paitan never disappoints on cold SF evenings with its thick rich flavorful broth, but spicy lamb can be a little too salty sometimes. Let's just say the spicy lamb is burst with flavors - sometimes your mouth gets confused and overwhelmed in a good way.

Enoki mushrooms? I could go either way , but get it only if you are ordering a beer :P 

I tried their other ramen choices , such as shio and clam ramen - however, wasn't too impressed. I think it's just personal preference/taste thing though because my other friends liked the shio. FYI: clam butter ramen is limited to 10 each day, and takes longer to make than other ramen.

I dare you to point out a rich thick ramen spot that's better than Mensho in SF.

excerpts: The Tori Paitan is their most popular
and I thought after reading other reviews that I wouldn't like it.
But after a taste, my mind and taste buds changed.
The broth is on the thicker and creamier side
but I didn't think it was too much.
It wasn't salty either but tasted like a richer tonkatsu.
tori paitan.author: James H.
tori paitan.review:
Been seeing crazy lines and finally got a chance to check it out on a Saturday at 9:50 pm. The line was about 20 people and took half an hour. Not bad considering during prime time hours it could be a hour. 

The Tori Paitan is their most popular and I thought after reading other reviews that I wouldn't like it. But after a taste, my mind and taste buds changed. The broth is on the thicker and creamier side but I didn't think it was too much. It wasn't salty either but tasted like a richer tonkatsu. I had the extra chasu which was duck chashu and it was good.

Prices are a bit high and it's small inside with a long line but it's worth it.

excerpts: The flavors are not as "heavy" as the other favorite, the Tori Paitan, but yet it's still a filling meal here.
It feels a little healthier too!
- Tori Paitan:
Creamy, rich, delicious pork broth
; this one is a classic.
It's mouth-watering savory!
tori paitan.author: Joanne Y.
tori paitan.review:
I don't like ramen.

I don't like ramen.

I don't like ramen.

Oh wait, wtf... I do.

Mensho has shaped the way I think about ramen and completely turned me on to my obsessive search for good ramen everywhere. I've eaten practically every item on their menu now and still love it. The lines, yes, are still ridiculously long unless you get there just before 5pm or after 11pm, but it's worth the wait.

My favorites are:
- Vegan Ramen: I love meat, but this vegan ramen is quite something. The flavors are not as "heavy" as the other favorite, the Tori Paitan, but yet it's still a filling meal here. It feels a little healthier too!
- Tori Paitan: Creamy, rich, delicious pork broth; this one is a classic. It's mouth-watering savory!
- Shio: If you're into fishy flavors, this lighter ramen for under $10 fills a lighter meal than the above two items and has a deep umami flavor. Not a fan of fishiness? Probably shouldn't choose this or the shoyu.

The only bad ramen I've had here was the worst ramen I've ever had in my life, but it was a temporary summer chicken and corn special that isn't a menu staple. I've tried some of the dry ramens too which are good as well, but not exactly my cup of tea (or soup for that matter).

Why Mensho stands out:
- Ramen: has a lot of chew, and are thicker noodles to my liking.
- Broth: deep, deep umami flavor that gives it the complexity many ramen places miss.
- Meat: by far the BEST meat on ramen I've ever had. It's seasoned well, isn't dry at all, and they have both duck and pork options (both which are amazing).

Basically, Mensho's ramen stands out in all regards.

Note: They do not do takeout, they do not let you box home food, everyone who comes in has to order their own bowl of ramen, and sometimes they play very hyped up music which doesn't really make sense for the environment... but for the amazing ramen that hits the spot every time, I will deal with these minor inconveniences.

excerpts: Took me away from basic shoyu/miso broth and shove my face into tori paitan and changed my life.
The creamy broth was incredible, rich, umami, warm, and comforting.
Broth alone
it got me.
Noodle itself is normal nothing oomph.
But the meat itself was equally lit.
Duck + pork, tender, melt in your mouth kind of loving.
Appetite for seduction...
oh wait.
It's good.
Even the crunchy burdock part elevate the bowl to a whole nother level.
Drink the entire soup, not a drop left.
tori paitan.author: Quynh Nhu D.
tori paitan.review:
Holynoodlers. Mensho have restore my faith in SF Ramen.

Prior to Mensho the best ramen I've tasted was Hinomaru's in Astoria, NY. I lived in Boston previously so Santouka had been our go to place and I never thought I could replace Santouka until now.

Mensho. Took me away from basic shoyu/miso broth and shove my face into tori paitan and changed my life. The creamy broth was incredible, rich, umami, warm, and comforting. Broth alone it got me. Noodle itself is normal nothing oomph. But the meat itself was equally lit. Duck + pork, tender, melt in your mouth kind of loving. Appetite for seduction...oh wait. It's good. Even the crunchy burdock part elevate the bowl to a whole nother level. Drink the entire soup, not a drop left. Amazingly not salty like other ramen place, though I do drink a whole cup of water.

Now is the wait worth it? It is and it isn't. Up to a point your hunger take over and if you're not a very patient and discipline person you'll give up and may or may not just go to Kim Thanh down the street which is also delicious, that may or may not happen with me on more than one occasion. 

But when I am a good girl and wait it's so worth it. It's so beautifully good that most of the time if I am waiting alone I can wait for it. Trying to go on off hours again is a better choice though now everyone will know the trick and go early so there is no way around the waiting. And it is infuriating when you're at the window and you see people finished their food, paid and proceed to sit their and chat for another 15 minutes and you are like "LEAVE GO OUTSIDE AND TALK OMB IM STAVING PLZZZ" but they must have waited in line for 30 minutes and think they deserve to make people wait more after that? Meh? 

Service is normal, you are expected to read the menu while waiting in line and just order asap so they can get you your food so you can eat and then gtfo for the next few customers. It's like literally going to war, delicious rameny war.

excerpts: This place is popular for their Tori Paitan ramen which consists of a rich and creamy chicken broth and comes with lots (and lots) of noodles, a couple slices of cha su and duck, and vegetables (such as bamboo shoots, mmm).
I assumed an egg came with it, but unfortunately it didn't-
you have to order it as an add-on.
While the cha su was standard the duck was quite tasty and didn't taste gamey.
The noodles itself was thick and flat which I don't prefer for my ramen
but it was ok, better than I expected.
I was really full from the abundance of noodles
so I couldn't imagine getting double cha su.
tori paitan.author: Donna M.
tori paitan.review:
Waited about an hour for seating on a Saturday around 5:30pm. There is no wait list, so you have to wait in line. I'd say the wait time isn't worth the meal but if there is a short line then it's ok trying this place out. The ramen is pricey for what it is. This place is popular for their Tori Paitan ramen which consists of a rich and creamy chicken broth and comes with lots (and lots) of noodles, a couple slices of cha su and duck, and vegetables (such as bamboo shoots, mmm). I assumed an egg came with it, but unfortunately it didn't- you have to order it as an add-on. While the cha su was standard the duck was quite tasty and didn't taste gamey. The noodles itself was thick and flat which I don't prefer for my ramen but it was ok, better than I expected. I was really full from the abundance of noodles so I couldn't imagine getting double cha su. I did try the fried enoki mushrooms which I would personally skip, it was just like eating fried batter.

Might I add the bar seating was really uncomfortable, my back started hurting.

tori paitan.author: Chesa C.
tori paitan.review:
I don't normally go for chicken ramen, but I think Mensho's Tori Paitan ramen with double duck chashu might be my favorite ramen in the US right now. As a person who loves pork, I don't even know what I'm saying. But that tori paitan ramen broth made me feel like I was drinking a whole chicken--and yes, that tastes as amazing as it sounds.

My partner and I came on a weekday evening about half an hour after they opened. There was a line of ~6 people in front of us. We waited about a 30 minutes before being seated at one of the communal tables. I think some diners might be put off by this but in Japan, tiny, packed restaurants are pretty common. For me, it sort of added to the authenticity. The only thing missing was a vending machine taking my order instead of a cute, but edgy waitress.

I think some people don't like this ramen because they prefer a thinner broth. I, on the other hand, prefer a very thick broth (like tsukemen) to coat my noodles so this ramen aligns perfectly with my preferences. 
The chashu has that sort of complex, dark meat flavor that I love about duck. The broth was thick and very chicken-y while the noodles were the perfect width for holding broth. The texture of the noodles had a nice gentle chew to them.

The price and wait make expectations for this place super high. For me, it really surpassed my expectations so I definitely think it's worth the price. I haven't had ramen that was this good since Japan (travel not-so-humblebrag). 

TL;DR?
- With ~1400 reviews, is there anymore that needs to be said? Mensho is a popular ramen spot that will always have a wait.

- If you like thick noodles, thick broth, and juicy duck this meal will be heavenly for you.

- I've never seen matcha in ramen before! Looking forward to trying it next time I'm in the city.
