Man...the thickest and heaviest broth I've ever had.  I've heard so much good things about this place, but the long wait times always scared me and I never explicitly sought to come.  But things always work out and just happened to be in the neighborhood and a group of 6 of us decided to give it a try.  

Even an hour before opening, the line was packed and we had to wait about 40 minutes before getting seated.  I can see why the wait so darn long; they only have 15-20 seats inside!  The setting is mostly community format, so unless you have a large party, you're more than likely to be seated with other die-hard ramen lovers.  

I recall that on this particular day, I wasn't really hungry but ended up getting Tori Paitan (Double Chashu).  I know I know...no shame!  First sip of the broth....wow is it filling, rich, and creamy.  I don't know if I'm in the minority here, but wasn't that big a fan of the thickness of the broth.  The chashu however, was some of the best I've had compared to other ramen establishments.  I loved the texture of the noodles though!  We also had the oysters in shoyu dare oil to share, and those were incredible; highly recommend to order that to start off.

Maybe I'll come back and try this for a second go round in the near future, but my initial experience has me questioning if the richness of the broth is really my style or if I just didn't have the best appetite on my visit.

tori paitan.author: Shirley H.
tori paitan.review:
Sorry, but I really don't get the hype here.

Waited over an hour in line on Sunday at 5:15pm for a party of two.

I ordered the Tori Paitan ramen with double chashu (+egg 1.80) and my s/o got the shoyu with double chashu.

The shoyu broth was incredibly oily and fishy. The noodles were thin and flat, which was interesting and had a nice bite. But the fishiness of the broth was really overpowering and off putting, IMO.

The tori paitan was rich and creamy, but I was expecting a lot more depth in the broth. I really enjoyed the thick and chewy noodles, though. The chashu was nice and fatty and the duck chashu was a nice addition, as well. Due to the broth and the chashu, I was stuffed and tired of the flavors after a few bites. 

I went with the server's recommendation of the soy sauce egg, but wasn't a fan. The yolk was nice and soft boiled, but the egg didn't pair very nicely with the ramen, as it was like adding more salt to something already salty. 

Noodles were done very well, but both bowls of ramen were overall incredibly salty.

Service was decent. Note that tips are already included in your total bill. The servers repeatedly came by and tried to take our bowls away even though there was still food left, which got really annoying. I waited over an hour for this, at least let me finish it!!

Overall: I was honestly pretty disappointed after hearing nothing but great things about Mensho. The flavors are good, but it's just not my bowl of ramen :(

tori paitan.author: Keizzel C.
tori paitan.review:
After having this place bookmarked for months, I finally decided to trek all the way to Mensho since the gloomy weather was perfect for ramen. As you all know this place is notorious for ALWAYS having a line. My coworkers and I came here just a little before 5 and we missed the first group by 5 people. :( We ended up waiting 1hr for our group of 4 to have to get seated. 

| AMBIANCE | 

When you enter you realize how small this place actually is. I think it seats only around 30ish people? The place is set up with long communal tables and some bar seats.I would recommend coming with groups 4 or less since a group of 6 came in and their group had to be separated between the bar and a communal table. There's also one bathroom so you have to keep an eye out. 

| FOOD | 

I was afraid that this place was going to be anti-climactic and that maybe my expectations were too hyped up from all my friends, but I'm glad to say that they were just right. We ordered the: 

- Fried Mushrooms: YUM! We saw everyone getting these so we asked the waitress to bring us some as well. It was a big enough size to share between 4 people. The mushrooms were coated in a light batter that wasn't too oily. Squeeze the lemon slice on top and add some of the spices and delish! 

- Tori Paitan: This is definitely a heavy bowl. I only ended up eating only half of my bowl since the broth was so rich and cream (not a bad thing though). My favorite part was a split between the chasu which was so tender and the noodles which were cooked perfeclty al dente. I will say that the noodle for this bowl are thicker than the shoyu but it's probably to fit the broth. 

- Shoyu Ramen: A lighter bowl than the tori paitan. The noodles in this dish are thinner since the broth isn't as creamy but it's still just as good. 

| SERVICE | 

I did feel that since there was such a long line outside the waiters rushed us as soon as they saw some of our bowls empty or us taking a break in between bites. I get it since they want to be able to serve everyone, but at the same time I felt like towards the end I didn't get to enjoy my meal as much. 

***They don't do take out or give you containers for leftovers so be sure to come hungry!

We left around 7PM and the line was even longer than when we first came. I would recommend coming before they open at 5 or a little bit before they close because any other time in between warrants a 1.5-2hr wait.

tori paitan.review:
Definitely get here earlier than opening time as there will likely be a line formed! We arrived at 4:45 but missed the first round of seats and ended up waiting about 45-50 min to be seated, which isn't too outrageous. Fortunately the food comes out very quickly.

I had the spicy tori paitan + soft shoyu egg. This bowl of ramen was very unique, unlike any kind of ramen I've ever had. SUPER creamy & rich broth. While the dish was definitely tasty, the thick consistency of the broth made it difficult to finish. I think it was too rich for me. The flavor is great  and the noodles are very good though, don't get me wrong! We also ordered a side of the enoki chips, which were such a yummy and fun twist to tempura. 

Our server was very nice and the workers were all quick to refill our waters. I'm not sure this place is worth waiting over an hour for but if you beat the line, I recommend trying it at least once.

[79/100]

tori paitan.author: Janice C.
tori paitan.review:
Ramen it up.

People, the seasons have turned. We've said goodbye to our Indian summer in SF, so that means, pull out the chunky sweaters and scarves and head over to Mensho Tokyo in the 'Loin to warm up your soul with some incredibly rich ramen.

This is the first Japanese outpost outside of Tokyo and I loved that the owners chose SF. (why should NYC get all the cool places all the time?!) Years ago, I used to whine to my friends that I'll have to drive to San Mateo to get some fantastic ramen. But, now that we actually have choices, I can happily stay in SF and my friends don't have to hear my whining. 

First: YES. There is always a line. Come right when they open at 5pm or maybe closer to 11:30pm (but what if the soup runs out?) chances are, your wait will be less than an hour. There were 3 of us who waited around 530pm and got sat down in 20 mins. 

Second: it's all communal seating. Most are high tops where you will uncomfortably balance yourself. So, leave the kids with a babysitter and don't bring big groups. You will rub elbows with your neighbors. You won't have much space for your said purse/jacket/scarves, but there are baskets on the floor where you can store them, just like in Tokyo!

Third: get the Tori Paitan. Everyone talks about it, right? it's their signature bowl. At $16, you get rich and creamy chicken soup, pork chashu, duck chashu, menma, Kale, Burdock and katsuobushi sauce. I love duck and I love that they give you duck here. Double up and pay the extra $2 for another slice of MMMeat. If you got vegan friends, say hello to their Vegan Tantanmen with made several types of mushrooms, nuts, chili oil, etc. in premium Japanese soy cream. You won't miss the real thing. Trust. 

Fourth: the broth is like GRAVY. Is that groovy? if you think so (I think so!) then you'll love this place. If you prefer a lighter, cleaner taste, you won't like Mensho and you'll be pissed that you waited an hour in line for this sh*t. 

Fifth: just like in Tokyo, eat your ramen, don't linger and leave. People got things to see and places to go. Rye is next door and they make killer basil gimlets. You're welcome!

tori paitan.author: Dianna H.
tori paitan.review:
Mensho's always a good time! Most recently, I came because I had heard about their new matcha tori paitan ramen and wanted to give that a shot.

I came right before they opened, around 4:45 on Wednesday, and there was only a handful of people in line. To be fair, it was a hot day--maybe 80 degrees--and only the most dedicated Mensho fans would even attempt ramen in that weather. The heat was definitely a barrier to enjoying the ramen; let's just say that I've been to Mensho many times but the lack of AC has never bothered me until this meal...

But was the matcha tori paitan worth it? YES it was! At $17 a bowl, it definitely doesn't come cheap, but I appreciated the subtle addition of the matcha to the already fabulous tori paitan ramen. Both my friend and I thought that the matcha flavor was very subtle and you had to stop and think about the flavors in your mouth to really taste it. Other than that, everything else about this dish is the same. The soup is still deliciously rich and creamy, the noodles thick and satisfying to chew, and the duck and pork chashu slices were perfectly tender. 

Also, I want to call out that they offer soft boiled eggs now! Unfortunately it's not included in the base ramen, so you have to fork out another $1.80 to add it, but it is completely worth it. I'm just really grateful that they've started offering it here, since for the longest time they didn't. I've had a lot of good ramen eggs before, but even then I think the one at Mensho is one of my favorites. It comes as a whole egg instead of sliced in half, and when you bite into it, you can see the perfectly partially cooked egg yolk inside. Plus it's marinated perfectly and that first bite of the marinated egg white and half cooked york is really memorable.

My friend and I also shared the poke soba ($18) as we were intrigued by the 10 bowl limit per day, but I would recommend skipping this. Because it was called poke soba, I thought all the proteins in the dish would be seafood, but for some reason there was also chashu in there. It ended up being a weird combination of warm and cold ingredients (the soba was also warm). Also we underestimated how full we'd be from the ramen. By the time we both finished with our tori paitan and were ready to start on the poke soba, we were already feeling pretty stuffed...

Another friend ordered the vegan tantanmen as he is vegetarian, and he was blown away by how delicious and flavorful the ramen is. I tried a sip and would highly recommend this even for non-vegetarians!

I know $17 for a bowl of ramen is really pricy, but I always end up coming back to Mensho time and time again for ramen. Definitely my fav spot in the bay area!

tori paitan.author: Nikki M.
tori paitan.review:
Our first ramen joint in San Francisco! We hardcore lucked out on the wait. We arrived around 8pm on a Wednesday night and only had to wait 10 minutes or so. The couple ahead of us told us the average wait time was 40 to an hour, and the reviews and the restaurant itself can confirm that. Like damn, we buyin' the lotto TONIGHT!

But anyways, I've read around that this was supposedly the best in town and I can see why both visitors and local think that. I ordered their famous Tori Paitan and the boyfriend ordered the vegan tantanmen. The Tori Paitan was filled with an incredibly savory chicken-based broth. Your first bite will immediately hit you with a ton of harmonious flavors. Lots of umami going on here. Lots of toppings. Certainly a good bowl of ramen so I thought we were off to a good start. While delicious, have to be honest and admit we were underwhelmed. The broth was too creamy, too thick for my taste. And I know it's weird to complain about spoons but quite honestly, their spoon was excessively large and made the eating experience a little difficult. Imagine trying to eat soup but with a flat giant wooden paddle. I'm sure it was more so for a *wow/cool* factor. Minor detail though. I also wasn't feeling' the noodles either. It made everything feel so thick. However, I did think that both the pork and duck chashu were juicy, tender and generous in portion. Granted I ordered the double chashu, but hey, they delivered. The soft egg was perfect. And if you're fiending for savory, this will do the trick. As a broth fanatic, I had to try a few bites of the vegan one and tbh - it was bomb af. Nice spicy kick to it. I would actually recommend that over the Paitan, or if anything, perhaps the Spicy Tori Paitan would've been the better route.

tori paitan.review:
My first meal in SF..... and it was worth the wait. This place makes ramen like no place I've been to before.  The broth is creamy and the noodles are just perfect.  The texture and wavy-ness of it was just superb. The tori paitan ramen is a definite must try. The broth is rich in flavor and the chasu melts in your mouth.  The spicy lamb ramen is also great.  The ground lamb with the spice... gives it a great kick. 

The place is pretty small... be prepared to wait 30-45 minutes.  It seems like there is always a line out front.  The place seats just under 30 ppl. The wait staff is super friendly and efficient with the orders. Definitely a must try place!

tori paitan.author: Sean W.
tori paitan.review:
To eat at Mensho, you'll have to put in some effort and brave the elements in the Tenderloin while waiting in a long queue. As one of the most hyped ramen places in SF, Mensho serves traditional Tokyo style ramen with some modern twists. What sets Mensho apart from other places is the richness of its broth/flavor. The broth is extremely thick, hence the strong flavors. Personally I thought the ramen was solid, but not worth an hour and a half wait/high prices (20$).

Mensho can only fit about 20 people. Things move relatively fast because it's a ramen place, but there will usually be a long queue. Usual waiting times are in the hours.

I ordered:
Enoki Mushroom Chips - I enjoyed these chips. While deep fried and crispy, still has a bit of chewy and that subtle enoki flavor.
Tori Paitan Ramen (Double Chashu) - comes with pork and duck chashu as well as your run-of-the-mill toppings. Good thick broth, almost too rich for me. The duck chashu was the best, extremely flavorful and tender!

tori paitan.review:
2.5 stars rounded up.

Wait time: 1 hour, starting at 5:15pm (they open at 5:00pm). Line moves VERY slowly.
Ramen: Not good, but the presentation was nice.
Atmosphere: Very rushed and cramped (the place is small, seats around 20 people at a time?)

I get it, but I don't get it. Mensho serves "artisanal" ramen, and I really wanted to like this place since it was recommended to us by our friends. We came as a party of 4, and one of our friends graciously waited in line for an entire hour. The tables are communal, and the servers very much expect you to know what you want to order the moment you sit down (they came by 3x before we finally ordered).

The lowdown:
I ordered the Spicy lamb ramen ($16) and my boyfriend got the Tori Paitan Ramen (Double Chashu) ($18.5). In short, my ramen was barely edible - the thick broth was so, SO SALTY (like the ocean)! I literally couldn't drink the soup (boyfriend can attest). The noodles were also a bit hard, but our friend who ordered the same thing said his was good (?!) so I just suffered silently and finished the noodles. The broth of the Tori Paitan ramen was a bit better - not as salty or thick - but the noodles were also a bit hard. My friend knew one of the servers, so they generously gave us free (soy saucey) oysters as an appetizer. My god, it was also incredibly salty! What is going on here?! I used to tell myself that if certain dishes weren't good, it's because I "ordered the wrong thing", but honestly, EVERY item on the menu should be good because restaurants have one chance to make a first impression - especially if you're highly rated like Mensho. Lastly, the bill came before we were even done and once we signed, the waitress stared us down until we left. 

Needless to say, I will not be coming back to Mensho.

tori paitan.author: Stephanie E.
tori paitan.review:
Every time I attempt to branch out and try a new ramen place I end up being disappointed. Why is that? Because Mensho Tokyo's ramen really is that good! 

There's so much attention to detail with every bite that I appreciate. You can tell that the chefs have carefully thought through every ingredient and then some. There is variety to be had here. If you are feeling like a hearty and thick soup is what you need, go for the tori paitan. If you're needing a lighter option, the shoyo ramen is great as well. All have unique flavors to them! 

It can be very loud inside the small space. I come here most often with just my fiancé, party of two, and it is almost impossible for us to have a conversation when we get seated across from each other and in between parties. 

Yes, this ramen shop is on Geary Street, but it really isn't in the heart of the tenderloin like others suggest. Sometimes there are homeless people asking for money but I have never had any issues or felt unsafe. 

Definitely come here, definitely try the ramen, it is delicious!

tori paitan.author: Jonas E.
tori paitan.review:
If I'm comparing ramen places, I think it goes Ippudo then Mensho, then everywhere else... I loved the ramen here, definitely quality ramen... noodles were cooked to perfect chewiness and had great texture... the broth was great tasting although I have to admit, it was thicker than I am used to. 

We got the Tori Paitan and the Matcha. Both were excellent... The matcha was surprisingly flavorful... gotta admit tho that the matcha taste kinda wore me out after a while. The duck chasu on the Tori was a great addition... 

The only real downside is the wait and the small space...

excerpts: I ordered the Tori Paitan which was great but the real surprise was adding a soft-boiled egg which was sweet and cooked perfectly.
tori paitan.author: Brandon L.
tori paitan.review: Tasty ramen, make sure to get here early to avoid a wait. I was able to get in line at ~4:40 on a Wednesday and was seated immediately as they opened at 5pm. I ordered the Tori Paitan which was great but the real surprise was adding a soft-boiled egg which was sweet and cooked perfectly.

excerpts: I had the Tori Paitan which is a heavier broth based ramen.
tori paitan.author: Danny N.
tori paitan.review:
edit: Not sure if this was intentional but they serve one of the cheapest  beers you can find in Japan (Suntory Premium Malts) at a premium price ($9). This is akin to opening an burger stand overseas and selling Budweiser as your only option.

The wait wasn't too terrible here. It was about a half hour to get seated for a group of three around 6pm on. Thursday.

The ramen here isn't anything special. It's good but not great. At the price point they're asking ($16-$18 a Bowl) you're not getting your money's worth. I had the Tori Paitan which is a heavier broth based ramen.

I would have given them 3 and am choosing to go down over their silly "gratuity-free" policy. They state they are a gratuity-free establishment but charge a mandatory 15% service charge. How does that make sense? I would be fine if they just charged a service charge and left out the gratuity-free part. Also, the service here is lacking. It's an environment where the waiters know they get paid regardless of the service they provide.

excerpts: I ordered the Tori Paitan Ramen with the double cha siu.
The noodles were good, the meat was melt in your mouth fall apart, and all the other toppings went nicely with the ramen, but my biggest issue was the broth.
For me, the broth is the most important part of the ramen, and here I felt like the broth was overly rich, to the point it tasted like I was drinking chicken fat.
I've had broths at other ramen places that had thick and rich broths
tori paitan.author: Jennifer C.
tori paitan.review:
Don't understand the hype, and this was the worst ramen I've ever had! 

I came here on a weekday night, there was a line but it wasn't crazy long. I ordered the Tori Paitan Ramen with the double cha siu. The noodles were good, the meat was melt in your mouth fall apart, and all the other toppings went nicely with the ramen, but my biggest issue was the broth. For me, the broth is the most important part of the ramen, and here I felt like the broth was overly rich, to the point it tasted like I was drinking chicken fat. I've had broths at other ramen places that had thick and rich broths but it never felt like I was just ingesting fat. 

Def would not come here again.

excerpts: The ramen was perfectly flavored - we ordered both the tori paitan and spicy tori paitan.
The broth was very rich and filling, but not greasy to the point I didn't want to finish the broth.
We also ordered shitake mushroom chips which were an interesting add to the mix.
Everything meshed together - the chewy noodles, tasty broth, and fresh veggies.
tori paitan.author: Connie L.
tori paitan.review:
This place is solid. I finally found ramen in the city that was not too salty! The downside of eating here is definitely the wait. We came the Wednesday before Thanksgiving, hoping most people would have left for the holidays, only to find out that its a prime ramen day... There is no sign-in clip board or anything - everyone has to wait in line. It took us roughly an hour to get to the front after starting to line up at 6pm. Luckily for us it was not too cold outside so the wait was bearable. Not sure I would wait a couple hours for this one bowl of ramen, but I have always wanted to try this place at least once.

The ramen was perfectly flavored - we ordered both the tori paitan and spicy tori paitan. The broth was very rich and filling, but not greasy to the point I didn't want to finish the broth. We also ordered shitake mushroom chips which were an interesting add to the mix. Everything meshed together - the chewy noodles, tasty broth, and fresh veggies. I wish it came with an egg though... 

Overall, ramen was bomb. Atmosphere was fun but seating/waiting in line were uncomfortable. I would come again only if I can find a way to not wait an hour for this ramen. They do not do take outs either.

excerpts: The Tori Paitan ramen ($16.50) has a rich and creamy chicken soup base.
The broth was much thicker than your average tonkotsu broth - almost like a curry consistency.
The duck chashu was glorious - so tender and flavorful!
It was a little weird to have kale in my ramen, but hey it's SF, so why not.
It was strange that they give you such a huge spoon for your soup.
It was as big as a serving spoon or rice scooper.
The noodles were thinner than the Tori Paitan ramen which went well with the lighter broth.
The noodles were thinner than the Tori Paitan ramen which went well with the lighter broth.
tori paitan.author: Susan D.
tori paitan.review:
Long lines ALL the time. There was a line when we got there at 9 pm and there was line there when we left around 11 pm. So, is it worth the hype and wait?! Yes, it's worth at least trying once. No, I probably wouldn't come back to stand in line unless I'm ok with the potential 1.5+ hour wait. It definitely seemed like other people didn't mind the wait since the line was always consistently long. Mensho is pretty small with 2 rows of communal tables for seating. 

By the time we were ordering a little after 10pm, they had already run out of their soft boiled eggs (both miso and soy). Come early if you want to try their eggs! The add ons seemed to be a little pricy like an extra $2 for fried garlic or green onions. If you want additional toppings, your bowl of ramen can easily be $20+. 

The Tori Paitan ramen ($16.50) has a rich and creamy chicken soup base. The broth was much thicker than your average tonkotsu broth - almost like a curry consistency. The duck chashu was glorious - so tender and flavorful! It was a little weird to have kale in my ramen, but hey it's SF, so why not. It was strange that they give you such a huge spoon for your soup. It was as big as a serving spoon or rice scooper. The Organic Shoyu ramen ($14) was packed with flavor too. If you're looking for something tasty, but less heavy, this is the ramen for you. The noodles were thinner than the Tori Paitan ramen which went well with the lighter broth.

They don't have to go boxes and you can't order to go, so make sure to slurp up all your delicious ramen before you leave!

excerpts: and I both ordered the spicy tori paitan ramen.
I can truly say that it's the best and closest to authentic ramen I've had.
The broth was thick and rich in flavor, which is exactly how ramen should be.
The noodles were thicker than usual and much more chewy but I enjoyed it.
The meat was tender and it was easier to pull apart in portions.
Overall, the ramen was delicious and for sure worth the wait AND hype.
If you're looking to try ramen that is truly reminiscent of Japan, pay Mensho a visit.
Your tastebuds will thank you.
tori paitan.author: Patricia B.
tori paitan.review:
I was craving for ramen this week and instead of going to my usual spot, I decided to try Mensho. My boyfriend insisted we go since he's been here before, and he said Mensho's ramen is much like the ones he had in Japan. In other words, authentic. We went on a Friday night at about 9:30 pm and there was a line outside. It was about a 30 minute wait, which I didn't mind. Plus, if it's Michelin-starred, it definitely has to be worth the wait. They also have some of their ingredients imported straight from Japan. The place is very small but its interior resembles an actual ramen shop from Japan. Seating is limited so it might not be good for groups or families. However, if you still choose to come in a large group, you most likely won't be seated all at once and eat at the same time. One thing to note is that in Japan, tipping isn't required and sometimes refused. Mensho doesn't take tips either so don't be offended if they don't accept yours! 
My boyfriend and I both ordered the spicy tori paitan ramen. I can truly say that it's the best and closest to authentic ramen I've had. The broth was thick and rich in flavor, which is exactly how ramen should be. The noodles were thicker than usual and much more chewy but I enjoyed it. The meat was tender and it was easier to pull apart in portions. Overall, the ramen was delicious and for sure worth the wait AND hype.
If you're looking to try ramen that is truly reminiscent of Japan, pay Mensho a visit. Your tastebuds will thank you.

excerpts: I ordered their famous Tori paitan ramen with an added ajitama (seasoned egg), and as all the reviews say, the broth for this ramen is extremely hearty.
It's not your typical smooth broth, but nonetheless I really enjoyed the depth of flavor.

The meat pieces were very generous, it came with two cuts of duck chasu and two of pork chasu, and both were not majority fat, and if you're like me and don't like to eat the fatty parts of meat then this is a big plus!
The ajitama was excellent - perfectly soft-boiled and great flavoring.
One of the best I've had.
tori paitan.author: Lisa T.
tori paitan.review:
After coming here twice, I can say that this is a solid ramen joint. The first time I came was during primetime dinner on a Saturday evening - the wait time was roughly an hour and a half. The second time I came during the weekday right around opening time and there was no wait time. The place sits just a little over 20 seats and is communal tables so you get real close to your neighbors, but it's typical for a traditional ramen store so get use to shrinking your personal bubble.

I ordered their famous Tori paitan ramen with an added ajitama (seasoned egg), and as all the reviews say, the broth for this ramen is extremely hearty. It's not your typical smooth broth, but nonetheless I really enjoyed the depth of flavor. The meat pieces were very generous, it came with two cuts of duck chasu and two of pork chasu, and both were not majority fat, and if you're like me and don't like to eat the fatty parts of meat then this is a big plus! The ajitama was excellent - perfectly soft-boiled and great flavoring. One of the best I've had. The kale and cabbage toppings we're a bit questionable and felt a bit off from the rest of the dish, but it didn't bother me too much. 

Being a Michelin recommended restaurant, it's no surprise that the price reflects the accolade. After tax and tip (which they already include in the bill) it comes out around $22. So is this a place I'd come to on the daily? Definitely not. It's one of those special occasions or treat yoself places. I'd recommend going on a weekday if you can to avoid the long lines

excerpts: Tori Paitan Ramen with egg - creamy and rich broth.
This bowl was full of flavors, my husband
and I favored this one a hundred times more!
Noodles are served a little thicker than the previous bowl which complemented the soup just nicely.
tori paitan.author: Jann B.
tori paitan.review:
Not the best ramen spot, but good enough to visit at least once!  They do not accept reservations, so I would advise you to come early if you can.  

Shio Chashu Ramen with egg - underwhelming, clear broth was lacking flavor.  

Tori Paitan Ramen with egg - creamy and rich broth.  This bowl was full of flavors, my husband and I favored this one a hundred times more!  Noodles are served a little thicker than the previous bowl which complemented the soup just nicely.  Definitely something I would order again.

A few things to note, automatic 15% added to your bill for gratuity and they do not offer take out containers for you.  Their portion sizes are quite generous so if you know you wont be able to finish your bowl, you are allowed to bring your own.  Overall, delicious ramen but not delicious enough to wait 90 min in the cold delicious.  Would return again on the rare occasion that there isn't a line out the door.

excerpts: Next I'll definitely try the Tori Paitan or the Spicy Lamb.
tori paitan.author: Karen L.
tori paitan.review:
One of my favorite ramen places in the city ! 

Be ready for a LONG wait because the place is pretty small and always packed. Communal tables - sits around 25 people or so. Do not recommend large groups - anything over 4 people !! Went on Saturday awhile back around 430pm and there was already a line forming before they were open. All these dedicated ramen fans. We were able to be part of the first wave to eat ! Woohoo! Made the cut !

Ordered:
Clam butter ramen with added duck chashu 

The Clam Butter Ramen comes with clam, pork chashu, onions, and whipped butter. At first it sounded weird to me but decided to give it a try since they only sell 10 bowls a day!! Mix the whipped butter. The broth was very rich & creamy and flavorful ! The chewiness of the noodles was A+. The noodles are very fresh! OMG the duck chashu was fabulous ! It was so good! MUST ADD! Chasu very tender and delicious as well. 

Around $18 for a bowl of ramen. Kinda pricey but definitely must try! 

Definitely recommend this place. But I wouldn't wait an hour to eat. Try to get there EARLY! Have to be patient. While you are waiting browse through the menu so when you sit down you are ready to order. But if the menu will make you hungrier then maybe don't look at it. :p

Next I'll definitely try the Tori Paitan or the Spicy Lamb.

excerpts: I ordered the Tori Paitan and it was one of the most different but best ramens I've ever had.
The broth was thick and creamy and the noodles were cooked perfectly.
Portion size left me full and satisfied.
tori paitan.author: Jane C.
tori paitan.review:
Been here twice and had to wait over 45 minutes for a table each time but it's definitely worth the wait!

I ordered the Tori Paitan and it was one of the most different but best ramens I've ever had. The broth was thick and creamy and the noodles were cooked perfectly. Portion size left me full and satisfied. I also added one of their soft boiled eggs and it was delicious.

My boyfriend ordered Lamb Ramen and I was not really a fan. It had lots of flavors but it was a little gamey for me. I heard lots of other customers ordering the lamb so maybe it's just me!

excerpts: I had the spicy tori paitan ramen and the noodles were unlike any other ramen I've had before.
It was in between a ramen and udon.
tori paitan.author: Sara J.
tori paitan.review:
I had the spicy tori paitan ramen and the noodles were unlike any other ramen I've had before. It was in between a ramen and udon. The noodles were a little too al dente. 

The waitress was kind of rude when I was telling her my order. I told her I didn't want the cabbage, bamboo shoots or green onions. Her response was "okay so what do you want?". Uhm... not a side of 'tude.

Luckily I didn't have to wait because my friends and I arrived about half an hour before closing. Worst ramen experience of my life.

excerpts: I got the Tori Paitan Ramen with Extra charsu.
The broth was a little bit more heavier than traditional ramens, I had but it was cream and flavorful.
The noodles we're decent.
My favorite topping was the duck charsu, if I can have all duck charsu.
I would be sooooooo happy!
So based on these categories, the ramen to me was a 4.5 out of 5.
If you include the wait time.
I would give this place a 4 out 5 stars.
Worth the ramen if you are pacient.
tori paitan.author: Terri L.
tori paitan.review:
I am not one who usually likes different styles of ramen, heck I perfer for it to be traditionally made but Mensho Tokyo was really good. 
We came here after the Japanese Cherry Blossom festival in SF. It was around 5:30pm when we arrived and there was a decent size line outside the door. We waited about for 40 ish minutes on a Saturday to get seat with a table of 5. Note there is like 5 types of seating: Bar and 4 tables. So it make sense for the wait. 
The decor gives it such a modern feel. The decor is also educational of what makes a good ramen. Those 5 components are broth, tare (base), oil, noodles, and topping. I got the Tori Paitan Ramen with Extra charsu. The broth was a little bit more heavier than traditional ramens, I had but it was cream and flavorful. The noodles we're decent. My favorite topping was the duck charsu, if I can have all duck charsu. I would be sooooooo happy! So based on these categories, the ramen to me was a 4.5 out of 5. If you include the wait time. I would give this place a 4 out 5 stars. Worth the ramen if you are pacient.

excerpts: I had the typical tori paitan and it was good, really thick and heavy.
It could have used a hit of acid or spice though, but it still was tasty.
Now, the line.
We had somewhere to be at 6:30, so got there around 4:40.
We weren't going to be the first seating and estimated we would get seated at 5:40.
We made a decision to go to where we needed to go, and then go back afterwards.
We got there around 8 and were seated around 9:15.
Was it worth it?!
I don't know.
I really hate waiting in long lines for food.
I think you can get better ramen in the Bay Area.
tori paitan.author: Samir K.
tori paitan.review:
I'm going to put this average at 3. My fiancee had the vegan ramen, which was WAY too spicy. She didn't ask for it to be spicy either. I can handle spice, and this was near-inedible in terms of spice. Thus, she would probably grade hers at a 2.5 or so. I had the typical tori paitan and it was good, really thick and heavy. It could have used a hit of acid or spice though, but it still was tasty. 
Now, the line. We had somewhere to be at 6:30, so got there around 4:40. We weren't going to be the first seating and estimated we would get seated at 5:40. We made a decision to go to where we needed to go, and then go back afterwards. We got there around 8 and were seated around 9:15. Was it worth it?! I don't know. I really hate waiting in long lines for food. I think you can get better ramen in the Bay Area.

excerpts:
Spicy Tori Paitan Ramen: 5 stars
Tori Paitan: 5 stars
The creamy "paitan" broth is to die for.
tori paitan.author: Letitia L.
tori paitan.review:
The line is always so long but it's worth the wait! Pretty different / original types of ramen, but quality wise it's a bit better than the San Francisco Ippudo in my opinion, and on par with Ippudo in Singapore.


---- RAMEN ----

Spicy Tori Paitan Ramen: 5 stars
Tori Paitan: 5 stars
The creamy "paitan" broth is to die for. It's like the most flavourful gravy ever.

Organic Shoyu Ramen: 3 stars

Shio: 3 stars
Broth tastes of fried garlic and fishy bonito flakes, a bit salty.

excerpts: The Tori Paitan was the best ramen I have ever had hands down.
The broth is so thick it's almost like chowder and the flavor has a lot of depth.
I had eaten immediately before coming here and still finished my bowl -
it was incredible.
Would I wait two hours to eat here during peak hours?
Yes.
Yes I would.
tori paitan.author: Joan H.
tori paitan.review:
I wanted to go here so badly on my family trip to San Fran that I went by myself.. and I'm SO glad that I did! I waited in line about 40 minutes at 10pm on a Saturday. The way their line works is you get in the back of the line and wait - no tickets, no lists or anything. Someone comes out to ask for your party size and that's it. They have very limited seating (like 25 seats) and just have big tables so you'll be eating with other folks, which was a fun experience for me! Service is quick and they have a really organized system to optimize their efficiency and get people in/out. Please do not be one of those groups who comes to a small place like this and sits for 45 minutes after finishing your foot to chat with your friends. This is a "get in, eat, leave" kind of spot.

Side note: Be warned that there are aggressive pan handlers that will come to the line. They even have a sign on their window where folks line up that warns you about it!

Now for the most important bit: the food. The Tori Paitan was the best ramen I have ever had hands down. The broth is so thick it's almost like chowder and the flavor has a lot of depth. I had eaten immediately before coming here and still finished my bowl - it was incredible. Would I wait two hours to eat here during peak hours? Yes. Yes I would.

excerpts: I would come again but will order the Tori Paitan or Shoyu.
Stars for great service.
tori paitan.author: Kitty K.
tori paitan.review: Waited about 45 mins but was able to skip the line since I came alone. I ordered the Matcha Paitan with the Ajitama Soysauce (egg) and was quite disappointed. The broth was creamy and thick but was spoiled by the too sweet matcha. The chashu was salty and the duck fat was not rendered long enough. The Ajitama was surprisingly sweet but was cooked perfectly with the medium soft yolk. I would come again but will order the Tori Paitan or Shoyu. Stars for great service.

excerpts: I ordered the tori paitan, and wow the broth was very rich and creamy.
Almost gravy like, I actually which it wasn't as thick.
But the flavors of the broth was intense and super flavorful.
They also have the thicker tsukemen like noodles.
My favorite part must be the chasu, super tender and melted in my mouth.
I wish I got the double order.
I also tried my friends matcha and vegan ramens, which were also very flavorful.
Definitely, the ramen was different from other places I've tried, and overall had a great ramen experience.
tori paitan.author: Wendy L.
tori paitan.review:
One and a half hour wait for ramen ? I can't believe I waited that long for ramen, but at least it did not disappoint. We were questioning our sanity for waiting during the cold sf night, but having heard such rave reviews on mensho, we braved through the chill. I probably would recommend coming in smaller groups, as they have limited seating in the restaurant. 

First, you must get the enoki mushroom chips! They were so addicting, but I also love enoki plus fried food so it was a win win for me. I ordered the tori paitan, and wow the broth was very rich and creamy. Almost gravy like, I actually which it wasn't as thick. But the flavors of the broth was intense and super flavorful. They also have the thicker tsukemen like noodles. My favorite part must be the chasu, super tender and melted in my mouth. I wish I got the double order. I also tried my friends matcha and vegan ramens, which were also very flavorful. Definitely, the ramen was different from other places I've tried, and overall had a great ramen experience.

excerpts: Spicy Tori Paitan, that's what you want to have
tori paitan.author: Rosalia M.
tori paitan.review: BEST ramen I've had! It is worth the long wait. Spicy Tori Paitan, that's what you want to have

excerpts: Their menu was rather simple, if you enjoy a thick creamy broth that itself might serves as a standalone meal, go with the Tori Paitan, which was as fulfilling as you could imagine.
tori paitan.author: Elaine H.
tori paitan.review:
This bowl of ramen was total worth the hype! If you are wondering whether you should wait for at least an hour, or like me, stood outside thirty minute before they opened their door, you can stop wasting your time there and just line up.

This place was the first US outpost of that trendy Japanese ramen bar Mensho, so people get insane, I get it. Their menu was rather simple, if you enjoy a thick creamy broth that itself might serves as a standalone meal, go with the Tori Paitan, which was as fulfilling as you could imagine. If you are like me, prefer something that is slightly lighter and go well with the noodles, I would suggest Shio or Shoyu, both made with clear soup base. I went a step further by ordering the veggie Dandan ramen, which was recommended by the chef as their "best", while added the duck slices. 

Unfortunately they stopped supplying the soy-marinated eggs, and according to the chef, it was due to the concern of egg quality in US. Ok totally with him, I'd rather skip the whole thing if it was no good.

Lastly, noodles - this is the best part! Very different from the traditional instant noodle type, the noodles here were thick, chewy, and tasted hand-made! Felt to me that they had absorbed the broth so very flavorful as well! Heaven!

I guess starting from today I would ignore ramen in SF, as I have already experienced the best.

excerpts: I ordered the tori paitan.
The noodle was cooked perfectly al dente but the broth was very thick and not that flavorful.
I felt like I was drinking liquid fat.
It was also missing some kind of punch.
The duck was very rubbery which made it hard for me to bite a piece off.
tori paitan.author: Michelle T.
tori paitan.review:
Came here for dinner on a weekday and the wait was about an hour. 

Due to the reviews on yelp I thought I was about to eat the most amazing bowl of ramen. I was wrong. I ordered the tori paitan. The noodle was cooked perfectly al dente but the broth was very thick and not that flavorful. I felt like I was drinking liquid fat. It was also missing some kind of punch. The duck was very rubbery which made it hard for me to bite a piece off. I had to put the entire big piece of duck in my mouth and chew and hope that it'll go down. 

My boyfriend ordered the clam ramen and one of the 4 clam was sandy. He also had to add more salt and pepper to his broth. 

For about $17 a bowl, this place is very expensive for mediocre ramen.

excerpts: If you think the Tori Paitan is thick and rich, this sucker is beats it.
It's a miso broth topped with ground lamb, pork chashu, nira (Chinese leeks) bamboo and green onions.
No egg for my spouse either as they ran out, but he did receive burdock shavings.
The spoonful of broth I tasted was intense and a bit like curry.
tori paitan.author: Vince N.
tori paitan.review:
We enjoyed our ramen so much that we had to go back and try more!

FOOD:
Enoki Mushroom Chips - $5.00 
Yum, like mushroom tempura!  The squeeze of lemon and sprinkling of a red spicy-looking salt really weren't needed. 

Organic Shoyu Ramen - $14.00
I'm a shoyu broth fanatic so this was a must-try.  The broth had a strong smoky-bonito flavor which I loved.  Unfortunately they ran out of both miso & shoyu ajitamas 2 hours after opening, but I did get added bean sprouts and the included pork and duck chashu, bamboo, nori square and yucky kale, though the kale sprouts were good.  The noodles in this version were flat and wide, still cooked perfectly chewy and came out searing hot.  This ranks right up there for me with the version at Momofuku. 

Spicy Lamb Ramen - $16.00 
If you think the Tori Paitan is thick and rich, this sucker is beats it.  It's a miso broth topped with ground lamb, pork chashu, nira (Chinese leeks) bamboo and green onions.  No egg for my spouse either as they ran out, but he did receive burdock shavings.  The spoonful of broth I tasted was intense and a bit like curry.  Personally, I'd stick to the paitan for a rich broth, but he absolutely loved it. 

SERVICE:
Our female server was so friendly and patient with our amateur ramen friends.  My spouse and I on the other hand are pretty profesh, lol. 

TIP:
No sodas are sold here.  

OVERALL:
A joint with two bomb versions of ramen for me?  That's saying A LOT!

excerpts: I had the chance to try the spicy tori paitan and the oysters in shoyu dare oil and the mushroom chip appetizers.
The spicy tori paitan came with pork chashu (yum!), spicy jalapeno miso, cabbage, burdock, and green onion.
The oysters were a bit herbal tasting to me
and I didn't like it.
The mushrooms were good if you like fried food.
It was greasy and oily.
My ramen was good, rich, and very pungent tasting.
The soup base was very creamy
but it went well with the thick noodles.
It was not as spicy as I thought it would be.
Additionally, I tried the tori paitan (pork chashu, duck chashu, kale, burdock, and katsuobushi sauce) and it was flavorful, pungent and savory as well.
Note that although one was spicy and one was not, there were differences in ingredients.
I would come back here
tori paitan.author: Kristy L.
tori paitan.review:
Features:
-After waiting nearly one hour on a weekend, we were finally seated inside.  I had the chance to try the spicy tori paitan and the oysters in shoyu dare oil and the mushroom chip appetizers.  The spicy tori paitan came with pork chashu (yum!), spicy jalapeno miso, cabbage, burdock, and green onion.  The oysters were a bit herbal tasting to me and I didn't like it.  The mushrooms were good if you like fried food.  It was greasy and oily.  My ramen was good, rich, and very pungent tasting.  The soup base was very creamy but it went well with the thick noodles. It was not as spicy as I thought it would be.  Additionally, I tried the tori paitan (pork chashu, duck chashu, kale, burdock, and katsuobushi sauce) and it was flavorful, pungent and savory as well.  Note that although one was spicy and one was not, there were differences in ingredients.  I would come back here but I would not wait an hour again. 
-Good and fast customer service, you could place your belongings in a basket below the table. 

Tips:
-Come early so you don't have to wait so long, I would recommend coming half an hour before they open.
-Each table sits up to six so if you have a bigger party, the wait may be longer.  
-Credit Cards and Cash accepted.

excerpts: I've tried the Tori Paitan Ramen and Spicy Lamb Ramen.
The noodles are incredibly fresh and flavorful .
The broth for the spicy lamb has a similarity with Indian curry.
Another note is that the broth is very creamy and has amazing flavor!
The spice level of the spicy lamb is very mild, so unless you have an extremely  low spice tolerance you'll love it.
I think I prefer the spicy lamb over the Tori Paitan but either one is a good choice!
tori paitan.author: Sim T.
tori paitan.review:
BEST RAMEN EVER!

One of my closest friends introduced me to this place last year. Although I was skeptical about trying it, I now understand why this place is so popular.

Food:
I've tried the Tori Paitan Ramen and Spicy Lamb Ramen. The noodles are incredibly fresh and flavorful . The broth for the spicy lamb has a similarity with Indian curry. Another note is that the broth is very creamy and has amazing flavor! The spice level of the spicy lamb is very mild, so unless you have an extremely  low spice tolerance you'll love it.  I think I prefer the spicy lamb over the Tori Paitan but either one is a good choice! 

Service:
The waitresses are great at answering your questions and giving recommendations. But for some reason once I got my ramen I was never checked on or asked for water refills until the end but it wasn't a big deal for me. Today I got a seat that has the view of the kitchen. While I was waiting for my order I was watching the cooks work and it was amazing to see how a Michelin-starred restaurant operates in the kitchen. The way that the team in the kitchen works together and perfectly times everything is just outstanding. 

Wait times:
They open at 5pm so I suggest you get their at least a half hour before. For example I showed up at 4:25pm and was the fourth person in line. At 4:50pm there was about 20 people behind me. So, show up early to get into the first wave of seating. If you have a party, make sure everyone is there or else they won't seat you. But you can try your luck and ask the waitress if you can order for the people that aren't here yet. 

Price:
I paid somewhere between $19-$20 for Spicy Lamb Ramen. They already include 15% gratuity into your bill. This is very reasonable price for the quality that you get and the fact that it's a Michelin-starred restaurant.

Overall this place is amazing!

excerpts: , I ordered Spicy Tori Paitan and it was AMAZEBALLSSS.
It was so creamy and rich, almost weird to look at when they first place the bowl down.
To think the Spicy Tori Paitan was rich and creamy, the vegan was BEYOND what I could've imagined.
I was having a mouth orgasm.
It was DELIGHTFUL!
The taste was exquisite and enticing.
I've never had anything like it.
Just one bowl itself was enough to fill me up.
The noodles were cook perfectly as it's not super soft.
I like my noodles on the more firmer side
, ya know waaa
tori paitan.author: Anna L.
tori paitan.review:
I AM A HUGE FAN. 

Personally, I think this is probably the best ramen restaurant in SF I've had thus far. 

This was beyond my expectations despite the long wait. Actually I think the longest time I was waiting for was probably 30 minutes, but we went at around 5 - 6PM so maybe that's not dinner time yet for most people? 

Anyway, the first time I came in, I ordered Spicy Tori Paitan and it was AMAZEBALLSSS. It was so creamy and rich, almost weird to look at when they first place the bowl down. It looked as though you're eating ramen in a bowl of milk, but once you get a sip, you just want to keep on going! 

The second time, I ordered the same thing even though I was tempted to order the Vegan one. Finally, my third time, I went for it and got the Vegan one and man, I am coming back FOR SURE. To think the Spicy Tori Paitan was rich and creamy, the vegan was BEYOND what I could've imagined. I was having a mouth orgasm. It was DELIGHTFUL! The taste was exquisite and enticing. I've never had anything like it. Just one bowl itself was enough to fill me up. The noodles were cook perfectly as it's not super soft. I like my noodles on the more firmer side, ya know waaa I mean? 

If you're thinking of something else rather than the noodles....I got nothing to say to you, you DIRTY MINDED people!!

Anyhow, I am smitten with this place despite the small capacity and close proximity you have to be with people, but hey, you're in SF, get used to it!

excerpts: The popular Tori Paitan was milder in flavor, with a very rich and creamy broth similar to Tonkatsu but not as 'meaty' in taste.
If you like simplicity at its best, this is the way to go.
tori paitan.author: Adrienne H.
tori paitan.review:
Dinner with a lovely friend finally convinced me to wait out the 1+ hour line for Mensho Tokyo. We arrived at 7:45PM on a Wednesday and the line didn't look too bad, but the wait was still an hour. This line moves sloooow. Luckily I was with someone I enjoyed talking to past the time!
 
I tried three different broths - all in the creamy style. Mensho stands out for the thickness of their broth. It's not the thickest I've had - that was at Muteppou in Osaka (we are talking almost pudding), but it's the thickest I've tried in the states. 

I've come to realize thick broth is not my thing. I like rich flavors, but I don't want clam chowder texture when I'm eating noodles. Make sense?
 
Thickness aside, the broth flavors were great. My favorite was the Spicy Lamb, though it was way too salty and actually not that spicy. The flavor was unique for ramen - very peppery and heavily spiced.
 
The popular Tori Paitan was milder in flavor, with a very rich and creamy broth similar to Tonkatsu but not as 'meaty' in taste. If you like simplicity at its best, this is the way to go.
 
I usually stay away from veggie bases, but I was surprised at how much I liked the Vegan Tantanmen! The mushroom and kombu broth had so much umami, it was ridiculous. The chili oil and nuts added a nice dimension. This will be my next order if I revisit.
 
As for the meats, the pork chashu and duck chashu were tender, but forgettable for me. I did like the hearty portion of ground lamb. The noodles were good - nice chew and springy texture.
 
I enjoyed the Fried Enoki Mushroom appetizer. It's a heavier amount of batter, but it crunches so pleasingly. Enjoy with togarashi and lemon.
 
So was it worth the wait? I thought so, though I'm not sure I would be so eager to wait again having experienced it once.

excerpts: Maybe I'll come back to try the tori paitan ramen
but it'll have to depend on the line which is pretty bad during prime dinner hours.
The crazy part is that people choose to wait - by the time I finished and left - the outside line tripled.
I don't think it's worth
the 1.5-2 hour wait in my opinion - there's plenty of other good options for ramen in the city.
tori paitan.author: Brenda L.
tori paitan.review:
I was on the fence between a 3 or a 4 but being one of those place with a 1-2 hour wait - you go in with a high expectation that this better be worth it. 

The ramen here is really good don't get me wrong but I'm not a person that enjoys waiting over an hour for food no matter how amazing it is. That said, the noodle quality here is probably the best I've had - great chewy texture and definitely handmade. 

The broth is very rich, creamy, and thick - I prefer a lighter and more soupier broth. My fiance got the lamb ramen ($16) - explosion of flavor but also very salty and heavy. I tried the vegan ramen ($18) which was a little lighter but still pretty thick as far as ramen broths go. The flavors were nice - peanut/ nuts and soy mixed in with a little kick of heat. I liked the toppings - edamame, kale sprouts, green onion, and mushrooms. The added poached egg is a must - cooked perfectly. Definitely one of the better vegan ramen's I've had. 

The space is pretty tight with communal tables and bench seating. The crowd usually lines up prior to opening at 5pm so get here early if you want to be part of the first wave. By the time I went (around 4:45) there was already a good amount of people and I ended up just missing the first seating and waiting a little over an hour to get seated. 

Maybe I'll come back to try the tori paitan ramen but it'll have to depend on the line which is pretty bad during prime dinner hours. The crazy part is that people choose to wait - by the time I finished and left - the outside line tripled. I don't think it's worth the 1.5-2 hour wait in my opinion - there's plenty of other good options for ramen in the city.

excerpts: I got the Tori Paitan Double Chashu Ramen.
tori paitan.author: Gabriel H.
tori paitan.review:
I got the Tori Paitan Double Chashu Ramen. My takeaways:

PROS:
- Chashu is melt-in-your-chopsticks tender
- Noodles were thick, curly and had a nice bite to them
- Soup is like a chickeny-tonkotsu gravy. Rich and creamy, but you can still slurp a decent amount without feeling too gross. It has a well-rounded savoriness to it. One of the more unique ramen soups
- Smoked Oysters are a briny delight. Get them.

CONS:
- Got there at 4:30pm on a Saturday (30 minutes before they open!) but still had to wait TWO HOURS in line.
- The toppings and very top of the soup weren't steaming hot - just only warm. Only the noodles themselves were hot. I kinda wish the whole thing was hot.
- The lights in the restaurant are super bright and were making my face all red. Given how the restaurant is laid out, chances are the person across from you is going to be a complete stranger. Most of the seating is on stools. All of this led to an uncomfortable dining experience.

It's a good ramen shop. I like it better than Ippudo - I feel like this is actually worth the $18 price point.

excerpts: The Tori Paitan was too thick.
The duck was good.
The noodles were perfectly cooked.
tori paitan.author: Sau y.
tori paitan.review:
We got there at 515pm on a Thursday, and it was nearly an hour wait for 4 of us. 

They were out of the fried enoki, but we got the oysters. The oysters were good, but couldn't eat too much due to overuse of oil. 

The Tori Paitan was too thick. The duck was good. The noodles were perfectly cooked. It's creamy and has pretty good flavor, but too damn thick. 

The clam ramen is great for seafood broth lovers. The noodles are different than the TP's and were delicious. Noodles were so good. 

Overall experience was good with service, decent food and clean space. The wait would deter me from any future visits... food was good quality, but not my favorite ramen bowls.

excerpts: I always go with the flavorful Tori Paitan which is delicious but
I'd definitely be back to stand in line again for your Tori Paitan!
tori paitan.author: Ticha B.
tori paitan.review:
Mensho Tokyo is my must have when I come up to catch the Giants in San Francisco. Almost a tradition that I come in for dinner after an afternoon game. The area is sketchy, I hate that you have to stand in line with all the locals of the Tenderloin coming up to you and asking for change and food. 

I think Mensho has the best ramen around. I also understand that there will always be a wait since the restaurant itself is small (fire marshal notice says 49 or so). So that's not the problem. 

I knocked off 1 start from their perfect rating because tonight's Shio ramen my friend ordered was pretty much bad. I always go with the flavorful Tori Paitan which is delicious but after trying my friend's Shio, Mensho dropped in ratings a bit. I also found out that they don't have togo boxes. My friend didn't finish the Shio but couldn't take it home. There was tons of ramen left! :(

Sorry...you were rated too honors in my books for a couple of years until tonight. I'd definitely be back to stand in line again for your Tori Paitan!

excerpts: The tori paitan is still my favorite.
The broth is super rich and clings to the thick noodles really well.
I'm not a huge fan of the spicy lamb.
It tastes like something halfway between ramen and schezuan cuisine.
I usually get my ramen spicy (or any food for that matter) so I recently tried it here.
In short, stick with the regular tori paitan.
tori paitan.author: Huey N.
tori paitan.review:
I've been here a few times now. The tori paitan is still my favorite. The broth is super rich and clings to the thick noodles really well. I'm not a huge fan of the spicy lamb. It tastes like something halfway between ramen and schezuan cuisine. I usually get my ramen spicy (or any food for that matter) so I recently tried it here. I thought the spice and extra flavorings took away from the deep chicken flavor. 

In short, stick with the regular tori paitan.

excerpts: We got the Spicy Tori Paitan, Oyster in Shoyu oil, and the soupless naked ramen.
Both the paitan and naked ramed was distastefully thick and fatty.
The taste was incredibly one dimensional in that I can only taste grease and salt.
The oyster was also disappointing.
The cooked oyster was shriveled up in the dark marinates on a tiny plate.
It tasted extremely fishy and salty as if I was snorkeling and suddenly breathed in a surge of salt water combined with fossilized kelp.
tori paitan.author: Michelle C.
tori paitan.review: This place is extremely overrated. The line was way too long for an $18 bowl of ramen that was drenched in fat and salt. Although we were lucky enough to be seated right when it was opened, the price and the taste of the food killed the excitement that was built up from waiting in line and reading other's reviews. We got the Spicy Tori Paitan, Oyster in Shoyu oil, and the soupless naked ramen. Both the paitan and naked ramed was distastefully thick and fatty. The taste was incredibly one dimensional in that I can only taste grease and salt. The oyster was also disappointing. The cooked oyster was shriveled up in the dark marinates on a tiny plate. It tasted extremely fishy and salty as if I was snorkeling and suddenly breathed in a surge of salt water combined with fossilized kelp.

excerpts: Between the three of us, we got the clam butter ramen ($18), tori paitan ramen ($16), and the shio chashyu ($13).
Tori Paitan -
The pork was delicious, and the broth was slightly sweeter than I anticipated.
Shio Chashyu - This broth was fantastic.
It was thick, and rich, and everything I look for in ....
but it was so delicious.
tori paitan.author: Gina L.
tori paitan.review:
Most people complain about the wait time, but if you're not waiting before it opens, you're not dedicated enough!!!!! There's enough seating for about 30 people +/- a few (4) depending on how the party sizes work out and if you can extend to the ends of the table.

Between the three of us, we got the clam butter ramen ($18), tori paitan ramen ($16), and the shio chashyu ($13).

HOLY MOLY I had an out of body experience like I watching myself eat the ramen because simply eating it wouldn't do it justice.

Clam Butter - This was my favorite - the broth, the ramen, the swirl of pork, the clam, the butter 5/5 absolutely delicious. The only serve 10 of these a day, so be sure to get there early! We joked that we would just order 10 for the 3 of us in the future because that's how good it was.

Tori Paitan - The pork was delicious, and the broth was slightly sweeter than I anticipated. However, all good stuff!

Shio Chashyu - This broth was fantastic. It was thick, and rich, and everything I look for in .... but it was so delicious. It was like drinking liquid gold, and my mouth is watering just writing about it.

Bring your own container if you want to bring back leftovers!

excerpts: Their infamous tori paitan was absolutely breathtaking.
I literally had to pause a second just to admire it for all its glory.
(Mind that, I'm usually one to devour my food in seconds)
I added duck meat and a soy sauce egg for toppings
tori paitan.author: Derek L.
tori paitan.review:
TLDR: WORTH THE WAIT !!!!!!

IT'S DEFINITELY NOT JUST A HYPE!  Mensho Tokyo is by far the best ramen I've tasted anywhere.  No wonder they have a line out the door a hour before they even open.  Trust me, it's worth it though.

I haven't been to Japan yet but Mensho is a franchise that started in Tokyo so that counts for something.  This is their first location in San Francisco and their ramen is clearly on another level.  Their infamous tori paitan was absolutely breathtaking. I literally had to pause a second just to admire it for all its glory.  (Mind that, I'm usually one to devour my food in seconds)  I added duck meat and a soy sauce egg for toppings and I would highly recommend you to as well! 

Their vegan tantanmen and matcha ramen is next on my radar to try!  I'll probably need to strategically pick a day where I won't freeze waiting in line for a hour though.

excerpts: I kept on seeing people raving about Tori Paitan, so gave that a go, add on ajitama and make it double chashu.
Boom, here comes my $20 bowl of ramen.

Ok, my $20 bowl was extremely filling, lots of flavors going on: my egg was marinated in miso, my soup was mainly chicken, I have pork chashu and duck chashu, got some fried burdock root with some earthy taste.
So much stuff going on, I can't even put it in words.
Duck chashu was amazing, it was so tender.
Pork chashu was just alright, I've had better ones at Ramen Shop, it was a bit tough here compared to Ramen Shop's.
Their noodles are pretty chewy, fun to chew but not fun to slurp.
I made a huge mess on myself
so had to eat more ladylike.
That soup though, it wasn't drying out my mouth but it was just so flavorful
, I couldn't stop.
tori paitan.author: Connie C.
tori paitan.review:
Woah... that's some thick and flavorful broth served at Mensho. I made it to the restaurant at 5:07, just missed the first round of seating, waited about 40 minutes to get seated as I was just party of 1, shouldn't be as bad even if you're with party of 2. I'm not sure if it's so good that I would wait an hour+ for this. half an hour is ok, 

If you're not comfortable with sharing tables with strangers where your elbows might touch, this place isn't really for you. If you're extremely claustrophobic, I think you should be looking for a plan B dinner spot. 

I kept on seeing people raving about Tori Paitan, so gave that a go, add on ajitama and make it double chashu. Boom, here comes my $20 bowl of ramen. Ok, my $20 bowl was extremely filling, lots of flavors going on: my egg was marinated in miso, my soup was mainly chicken, I have pork chashu and duck chashu, got some fried burdock root with some earthy taste. So much stuff going on, I can't even put it in words. Duck chashu was amazing, it was so tender. Pork chashu was just alright, I've had better ones at Ramen Shop, it was a bit tough here compared to Ramen Shop's. Their noodles are pretty chewy, fun to chew but not fun to slurp. I made a huge mess on myself so had to eat more ladylike. That soup though, it wasn't drying out my mouth but it was just so flavorful, I couldn't stop. By the time I should stop, I felt sick, guess my stomach wasn't used to the thick broth. 

I read from some reviews that they do have lighter broth like shio. My other friend also suggested the vegan ramen and said it's the best thing he's ever had. Probably next time, if I made my way to that area before 5pm.

excerpts: I ordered the Tori Paitan ($16.50).
Took about 15-20 minutes to come out.
Great, because I was really hungry waiting in that line.
The broth was really pretty thick - almost milky.
It was pretty delicious.
Noodles were a bit thick, and not quite like other many ramen noodles I've tried.
The meat for the ramen was actually "DUCK chashu" served in 2 different ways.
First, they give you a large cooked piece of duck which really tastes like chashu!
The other pieces of meat I think were slices of rare duck.
I've never seen that it in a ramen nor have I ever even seen duck in ramen.
tori paitan.author: Richie C.
tori paitan.review:
Came here around 5:45 pm on a Sunday. The wait was probably about 45 minutes for a table of 2. 
Semi-long wait, but I was really excited to try their ramen.

The atmosphere was cool, once you get inside you'll see that it's quite small. You're seated at a communal table which seats 6 - but up to 7 cause you can add a chair to the side. 

Food: 
I ordered the Tori Paitan ($16.50). Took about 15-20 minutes to come out. Great, because I was really hungry waiting in that line.
The broth was really pretty thick - almost milky. It was pretty delicious. Noodles were a bit thick, and not quite like other many ramen noodles I've tried.
The meat for the ramen was actually "DUCK chashu" served in 2 different ways. First, they give you a large cooked piece of duck which really tastes like chashu! The other pieces of meat I think were slices of rare duck. I've never seen that it in a ramen nor have I ever even seen duck in ramen. It was really good though.

Service:
Friendly, decent.

Overall, the food didn't blow me away. I'm from SoCal and I'd still prefer my ramen spots here over this place. For the bay area, however, I think it was probably my favorite so far, though it was pricey. They also have plenty of options i.e., soupless ramen, extra toppings (I had habanero), side dishes, drinks and all that! Try this place out if you're tired of boring ramen!

excerpts:
What I got:
Tori Paitan Ramen
Enoki Mushroom Chips
The Tori Paitan hit the spot!
The broth was rich and bursting with so much flavor.
It's a bit on the thicker side than what I'm use to, but that's because of the the way they make their chicken broth.
I think they blend like actual chicken into their broth to make the flavor pop.
It's great!
It also comes with pork chashu and duck chashu -- both were very tender and juicy.
tori paitan.author: Tony V.
tori paitan.review:
What I got:
Tori Paitan Ramen
Enoki Mushroom Chips

What I thought:
Mensho is based on an actual ramen restaurant in Tokyo with an American(Bay Area) twist to it. It's an incredibly popular place and typically has around a 45+ minute wait so be prepared to chill in line for a bit before you actually grub.

The ramen here is one of a kind. It's very different than most places that I've been to. The Tori Paitan hit the spot! The broth was rich and bursting with so much flavor. It's a bit on the thicker side than what I'm use to, but that's because of the the way they make their chicken broth. I think they blend like actual chicken into their broth to make the flavor pop. It's great! It also comes with pork chashu and duck chashu -- both were very tender and juicy. It even had kale in it (definitely a Bay Area thing).

The enoki mushrooms were fantastic as well. I've never had enoki deep fried before. It was a yummy snack to eat before our ramen bowls came out. Crispy and bomb.

Great place for a ramen fix. I usually don't finish all the broth when I eat ramen, but at Mensho I drank the bowl dry. It's the best ramen I've had in SF so far.

excerpts: The Tori Paitan is one of their most popular dishes and it was absolutely delicious!
The broth is on the creamier side.
tori paitan.author: Sophia D.
tori paitan.review: Delicious and worth the wait! Got here around 6:15pm on a Tuesday and waited about 25 min to get inside and then another 15 for food. The Tori Paitan is one of their most popular dishes and it was absolutely delicious! The broth is on the creamier side.

excerpts: I had the Tori Paitan ramen.
I saw Cathy S. when we were waiting in line outside of restaurant.
tori paitan.author: Miguel R.
tori paitan.review:
One of the best places ever for ramen!!!!

Be prepared to wait to get in. If you make it an hour early you will be fine. If you come later expect a long line. There is no way around the wait but you will see it was well worth it!!!!

Came here with my brother.It was his first ramen experience ever and he was impressed!!!! I had the Tori Paitan ramen. I saw Cathy S. when we were waiting in line outside of restaurant. It was great to see her and chat for a while!!!! 

The restaurant is small and gets packed. If you don't like communal dining don't come here.

It's a nice looking restaurant!!!! Service is great!!!!

The ramen here is not cheap but it is truly exceptional!!!! The broth is truly exceptional and the noodles are superior!!!! The meat is perfectly cooked!!!! Make sure you order an extra portion of meat though!!!! They also serve great beer here. Not merely your average Asahi and Sapporo, etc.here.

What can I do without at Mensho Ramen?

The wait!!!!

What stands out at Mensho Ramen?

The exceptional quality of the bowl of ramen you get!!!!

Five stars!!!! Mensho Ramen is really, really ridiculously great!!!!

excerpts: I recommend the tori paitan ramen (worth the $2 for double chashu) or add $1.50 for extra DUCK CHASHU.
It's so good and melts in your mouth!
I've also had the cold chicken ramen (refreshing broth but very bland), and arubasoba (nice first few bites, flavorful but super oily).
tori paitan.author: Cammy C.
tori paitan.review:
Been here twice now and both times we had to wait more than an hour in line but the ramen is definitely above par here! I recommend the tori paitan ramen (worth the $2 for double chashu) or add $1.50 for extra DUCK CHASHU. It's so good and melts in your mouth! I've also had the cold chicken ramen (refreshing broth but very bland), and arubasoba (nice first few bites, flavorful but super oily). Not sure if it's worth the wait to you, but I think every foodie/ramen lover must try this place at least once!!

TIP: 15% gratuity is already included in the tip, and all the servers share it at the end of the night--which creates a less competitive work environment for the servers but also allows them to slack off since they have guaranteed tips. Our server last night was slow, forgetful, and did not come back to refill waters or check on us even once, I would have chosen not to tip her if I could.

excerpts: Tried the famous tori paitan ramen here after waiting outside for 45 minutes on a Tuesday night at 6 PM.
Overall, the dining experience seemed a bit rushed since you can see everyone waiting outside and start feeling guilty.
tori paitan.author: Victoria L.
tori paitan.review:
Tried the famous tori paitan ramen here after waiting outside for 45 minutes on a Tuesday night at 6 PM. Overall, the dining experience seemed a bit rushed since you can see everyone waiting outside and start feeling guilty. The ramen itself was sub-par to me and not worth the 45 minute wait.

The plus side is that Mensho gives a good portion of meat to noodles and that the noodles were perfectly thick, curly and al dente. However, the broth wasn't hot (temperature-wise) enough for me and there wasn't enough broth. I think the noodles started to soak up the broth and it seemed like more of a noodle dish instead of a noodle soup. It seemed like a heavy bowl of ramen, with a very creamy broth, fatty meats, and thick noodles. Definitely a pricey, but filling bowl of ramen. Just wish it were hotter and more soupy!

excerpts: I ordered oysters in shoyu dare oil as an appetizer, the tori paitan ramen, and the bf ordered the organic shoyu ramen.
First off, the oysters were already de-shelled, and on the drier side.
But soooo good!
I would definitely order these again and again!
My tori paitan had such a rich and delicious broth.
And besides the usual pork chashu, they also had duck chashu.
Okay, I actually enjoyed the duck way more than the pork!
Everything was so appealing to the eyes and stomach!
The bf also enjoyed his organic shoyu ramen.
He said it was different from what he's usually used to eating
but it was still good.
I saw some reviews stating this was the best ramen ever, but that they've never been to Japan.
I would say, for the category of atypical Japanese ramen, it's definitely very good.
But it definitely cannot compare to traditional Japanese ramen in Japan.
If you're ever in SF, give this place a try!
But be sure to get there early!

tori paitan.author: Cara Y.
tori paitan.review:
Thank you Yelp for being my go-to when I'm traveling and looking for places to eat! This ramen place we visited during our SF trip definitely did not disappoint!
The first night we saw the line was almost a block down so we decided to try here another night. We made sure to get there early so we wouldn't have to wait in line as long. The wait was soooo worth it!!!
While in line I saw that the restaurant is Michelin rated and I perused the yelp photos and reviews on what would be the best thing to order.
