tori paitan.author: Jean S.
tori paitan.review:
Wow! Best Ramen I've had! Mensho's Tori Paitan Ramen (double chashu) ($18) was super amazing and full of delicious umami flavor! The broth was very rich and creamy, but the flavors were SO tasty, I could not stop drinking. The noodles were cooked to a perfect texture, the bamboo shoots and kale were a nice touch, but what was the crown on top was the EXTREMELY TENDER and flavorful chashu. Both the pork chashu and duck chashu were out-of-this-world amazing! Definitely the best I've had in any ramen bowl. I only wish there were more pieces.  

In addition to the tori paitan broth, Mensho also offers organic shoyu, shio, and a vegan tantanmen. The shoyu and shio broths are lighter and not as creamy, which might be good for those looking for something not as heavy. (But why come all the way out here, wait in an excruciatingly long line, and not get the best?) I also tried the oysters in shoyu dare oil ($5), which were not bad. The menu states 4 pieces...they gave us 6, but they were very small and not plated very nicely. 

Mensho Tokyo is one of Japan's most acclaimed ramen bars, and this very location in SF's Tenderloin district, is their first international shop outside of Japan. This location has been open for over a year now, but the long wait is still there. I came late Saturday evening (10:15pm) trying to avoid the long line, but it wasn't late enough. I still had to wait 45 minutes (only!?) and didn't get seated till just after 11:00pm. (They close at 11:30pm and there were people being seated all the way to the end.) I hate long waits, but the tori paitan ramen was well worth the travel out and 45 minute wait. On a positive side note, the restaurant was clean, the bathroom was clean, and their food safety score is 100.

excerpts: I tried the Tori Paitan, which came with both duck and pork chashu in a rich broth.
This was my first time having duck chashu, and while I appreciated its tender texture, I think I prefer my ramen with just pork (I tend to find duck meat to be somewhat hit or miss).
Overall, I thought the ramen was good, but I did not think it was worth waiting on a long line for it.
tori paitan.author: Keith H.
tori paitan.review:
When I saw the line at Mensho, I figured it would be a place I'd have to visit.  You don't often see a long line of people waiting for food in Nob Hill (especially in the rain), but I decided I would try to visit there during a different day; I hoped that if I arrived on the earlier side I could beat the mob.  

Fast forward to a subsequent Sunday-I arrive about 15 minutes prior to opening and the line was already massive.  After waiting about an hour, I finally got a seat (good thing I was only a party of one), and I was taken to a shared table setting.  If you are going to Mensho, you better be comfortable with sitting next to strangers, as you will be placed at a long table.  While the seating felt somewhat cramped, I did not mind the seating arrangement too much.  

I tried the Tori Paitan, which came with both duck and pork chashu in a rich broth.  This was my first time having duck chashu, and while I appreciated its tender texture, I think I prefer my ramen with just pork (I tend to find duck meat to be somewhat hit or miss).  Overall, I thought the ramen was good, but I did not think it was worth waiting on a long line for it.

excerpts: We got the tori paitan (with double chashu) and the organic shoyu ramen.
I liked the tori paitan better with the thick broth and rich flavor.
I'm not sure if the double chasui gets you more pork chasui or more of the duck chasui or both.
But I really liked the duck chasui - it's very unique.
The shoyu ramen had a thinner noodle than the paitan.
The broth was good but got really salty the more you kept drinking it.
Food came out quickly and service was fine, quick for the most part.
tori paitan.author: Alison W.
tori paitan.review: This has been on my to-try list forever. It's been touted as the best ramen in the city. The bf and I came around 5:40 on a weekday and still waited just under an hour to be seated. It's not a big place. They are actually pretty quick with the turnaround. Seats are not open for very long, which I appreciate as someone who's hungry and waiting for food. While in line, we were able to peruse the menu and decide beforehand so we were able to order right away. We got the tori paitan (with double chashu) and the organic shoyu ramen. I liked the tori paitan better with the thick broth and rich flavor. I'm not sure if the double chasui gets you more pork chasui or more of the duck chasui or both. But I really liked the duck chasui - it's very unique. The shoyu ramen had a thinner noodle than the paitan. The broth was good but got really salty the more you kept drinking it. Food came out quickly and service was fine, quick for the most part.

excerpts: I got the Tori Paitan and it was AMAZING.
The pork melts in your mouth, the noodles were perfect, and the broth was unlike any other.
Another person got the spicy lamb, which was also very good
but I preferred the Tori Paitan over it.
tori paitan.author: Poy W.
tori paitan.review:
If you're looking for rich, decadent dashi, Mensho is the place to go! I haven't been to a restaurant that does it better. It's pricey for ramen (expect to pay around $20) but it's delicious!! There's no reservations and no waitlist - you just line up in front of the restaurant. Expect at least an hour wait. We met around 8 on a Friday night and we didn't get in until 9:15. The restaurant is small with communal seating with raised chairs. Like most places in SF, parking is awful around this area. 

They have a small menu selection that's straight to the point. I got the Tori Paitan and it was AMAZING. The pork melts in your mouth, the noodles were perfect, and the broth was unlike any other. Another person got the spicy lamb, which was also very good but I preferred the Tori Paitan over it. 

If you're looking for a life-changing ramen experience, you have to go to Mensho!

excerpts: We got the Tori Paitan and the lamb.
Their signature is too heavy - could basically feel my arteries clog.
I thought the lamb was not harmonious, and it was super annoying trying to dig around for the little ground lamb bits.
The space is small and a bit cramped.
The wait staff are always hovering and try to rush you out.
tori paitan.author: Eva W.
tori paitan.review:
I don't understand why there is always a long line for this place? When we saw there was basically no line late on a Tuesday night, we figured we'd see what the hype was. It was decent, but we came away agreeing there was no way we'd actually wait in that line.

We got the Tori Paitan and the lamb. Their signature is too heavy - could basically feel my arteries clog. I thought the lamb was not harmonious, and it was super annoying trying to dig around for the little ground lamb bits. The space is small and a bit cramped. The wait staff are always hovering and try to rush you out. I get it, they want to serve more people, but jeez, let me finish my last bite and put my chopsticks down before you slip the bill on the table.

Also, it's super douchey that their website cover photo is of the line outside. C'mon Mensho, that's way too self-promotional.

excerpts: I got the most well-known speciality, the Tori Paitan.
The soup is a really creamy broth, for me too heavy too drink but because of its thickness it sticks to the noodles well.
However I would say the soup doesn't really have too much to a flavor to it; I prefer broth more with a shoyu taste.

This ramen comes with menma (marinated bamboo shoots), fried/dried burdock strips (SO delicious and fragrant, was one of my fav things about the ramen that made it even better) and kale (tender with flavor goes surprisingly well with everything else).
tori paitan.author: Shirley L.
tori paitan.review:
Finally tried the ramen place everyone in SF has been raving about.
The wait is definitely quite long - when we arrived at around 430 there were already around 22-24 people ahead of us. If you want to make it the first wave I would start waiting in line earlier to be safe since anyone after the cutoff would have basically been waiting since before store hours open and have to wait for people to finish. Luckily we made it! 

Interior is small and seats maybe 26 people. 

I got the most well-known speciality, the Tori Paitan.  The soup is a really creamy broth, for me too heavy too drink but because of its thickness it sticks to the noodles well. However I would say the soup doesn't really have too much to a flavor to it; I prefer broth more with a shoyu taste. This ramen comes with menma (marinated bamboo shoots), fried/dried burdock strips (SO delicious and fragrant, was one of my fav things about the ramen that made it even better) and kale (tender with flavor goes surprisingly well with everything else). The ramen also comes with a slice of pork chashu which is super soft & just melts in your mouth as well as a couple small slices of duck chashu equally as soft.

I recommend an add-on ajitama (egg) and they give you the option or soy or miso based.

I really liked the noodles -they're thick and chewy with that "Q" texture.
 
Overall very delicious and unique. Only downside is the steep price (but I guess this is the SF ramen price range) & long wait with fewer seats. I would say it's not better than all the LA ramen but definitely offers something different. Would definitely come again to try out the other menu items such as their soupless ramen!

excerpts: I ordered the Tori Paitan, which was rich and creamy ramen that I needed to fuel up my belly!
Although it's a little pricey for a bowl, the restaurant live up to its name for its Michelin star.
tori paitan.author: Jacklyn A.
tori paitan.review:
I came here to catch up with a good friend of mine after a long day of interview at UCSF. He wanted to come here for a while, so we both decided to come with hearty appetites and waited about an hour before we were seated. 

The line was long on a Friday night, but the food was really worth it. I ordered the Tori Paitan, which was rich and creamy ramen that I needed to fuel up my belly! Although it's a little pricey for a bowl, the restaurant live up to its name for its Michelin star. The staff was swift and organized, which made my experience a good one for a LA native who went to SF for the first time. 

Overall, I highly recommend this place for good ramen in SF! There's other places to check out nearby, a good excuse to walk around after a full meal! :)

excerpts: I was adventurous and ordered the Matcha Tori Paitan Ramen.
Given that I'm a fan of matcha everything, my opinion can be a little biased, but I found the matcha ramen very delicious!
tori paitan.author: Iris K.
tori paitan.review:
I was adventurous and ordered the Matcha Tori Paitan Ramen. Given that I'm a fan of matcha everything, my opinion can be a little biased, but I found the matcha ramen very delicious! The matcha flavor offset the rich creaminess in the soup base somewhat, which tasted refreshing to me.

Getting there before the restaurant opens seems to help reduce the wait time - I was able to get in within about 35 minutes in line. Wish the would consider opening for lunch!

excerpts: I got the spicy tori paitan ramen with the spicy stuff on the side -
I wanted it on the side
so I could taste the soup in its original form.
I forgot to ask for no bamboo.
The noodles also took their sweet time to come out, but I know they were getting freshly cooked since I had a seat that was right in front of the kitchen.
They have timers to tell the noodle person when to take the noodles out!
Amazing.
I waited at least ten minutes for my noodles to get served, but it was piping hot when it did and the spicy chili flakes and the jalapeno miso sauces were on the side.
The soup was quite thick but not overpowering, and it was pretty good.
I REALLY liked the jalapeno miso sauce.
It was very flavorful and had a nice kick.
I ended up using most of it in my soup and the chili flakes were more for show than anything else; they didn't taste spicy.
I also really enjoyed the noodles; they were really chewy and thick, and they're probably one of my personal favorite ramen noodles I've had.
I ate my noodles in about ten minutes though I did try really hard not to eat them too fast so as to enjoy them.
I ate everything in my bowl except the bamboo.
Oh also the one thick slice of chasu I got: very flavorful and a good amount of meat (versus fat).
There were also fried onions which added an extra fragrant flavor and pieces of cabbage which added texture and a break from the thick broth.
At the high price of $20.99 including tax and mandatory 15% tip, I definitely expected more than one measly piece of meat.
Also no egg?!
The service was pretty good as the waitresses were all quite friendly (note: why is everyone serving the food a female and all the cooks male?).
Good portion of noodles though.
Please get your wasting-time-in-mandatory-line policy changed.
tori paitan.author: Andrea W.
tori paitan.review:
Let me first preface my review by saying I really don't understand why this place forces you to wait outside its door in a line. Why not give out numbers? Customers literally cannot go do something else while waiting, and it's a big time waste. Why force wasting of (a LOT of people's) time? To prove what, exactly? I'm fine with waiting, but I'm not fine with a restaurant being so arrogant to force its customers to mandatorily wait in a line. The only reasons I can think of for this is: a) marketing - if there's a lot of people waiting, it must be good so let's convince even more people to waste their time to wait in line to eat at this place! and b) efficiency - if people are readily available, the restaurant can immediately seat people when a table clears out. Reason a is just selfish. Reason b can be solved by warning customers that if they're not there when they're called, they will be skipped over/crossed out. Or better yet, they can actually invest in a good technology system of calling/texting people. A bunch of restaurants have this, and I very much appreciate places that do. PLEASE change your must-wait-in-line policy. It's just selfish, arrogant, and wastes a LOT of people's time. Making people sign in on a sheet of paper or with one of the waiters/waitresses is fine; don't have to get all fancy with technology. But please think about your customers.
I waited in line for about 25 minutes on a Wednesday evening; I got into line at 5:45PM and got seated at 6:10PM. I was handed a menu and my order was taken shortly after. I got the spicy tori paitan ramen with the spicy stuff on the side - I wanted it on the side so I could taste the soup in its original form. I forgot to ask for no bamboo. The noodles also took their sweet time to come out, but I know they were getting freshly cooked since I had a seat that was right in front of the kitchen. They have timers to tell the noodle person when to take the noodles out! Amazing. I waited at least ten minutes for my noodles to get served, but it was piping hot when it did and the spicy chili flakes and the jalapeno miso sauces were on the side. The soup was quite thick but not overpowering, and it was pretty good. I REALLY liked the jalapeno miso sauce. It was very flavorful and had a nice kick. I ended up using most of it in my soup and the chili flakes were more for show than anything else; they didn't taste spicy. I also really enjoyed the noodles; they were really chewy and thick, and they're probably one of my personal favorite ramen noodles I've had. I ate my noodles in about ten minutes though I did try really hard not to eat them too fast so as to enjoy them. I ate everything in my bowl except the bamboo. Oh also the one thick slice of chasu I got: very flavorful and a good amount of meat (versus fat). There were also fried onions which added an extra fragrant flavor and pieces of cabbage which added texture and a break from the thick broth. 
At the high price of $20.99 including tax and mandatory 15% tip, I definitely expected more than one measly piece of meat. Also no egg?! The service was pretty good as the waitresses were all quite friendly (note: why is everyone serving the food a female and all the cooks male?). Good portion of noodles though.
Please get your wasting-time-in-mandatory-line policy changed.

excerpts: I had the Tori Paitan, because that is supposed to be the best.
The broth was flavorful, creamy, and unique.
tori paitan.author: Ty C.
tori paitan.review:
The ramen was good.  I had the Tori Paitan, because that is supposed to be the best.  The broth was flavorful, creamy, and unique.  I enjoyed the bowl of soup and the noodles.

I thought the chashu was good, but not great.  The duck was super tender and not bad, but I'm not a huge fan of duck.

I probably wouldn't go back because of the typical 1 hour wait, the prices (which seemed high to me) and you basically have to sit down, eat and get out.

I know ramen can be expensive and that is probably why I don't go out to ramen that often.  It can easily run you over $20 for a bowl if you add an egg after tax and tip (15% service charge is included automatically (I kind of like this feature)).

The service was fast and sufficient.  Waters were filled regularly.

I also tried one of the other ramens (I forget the name, started with a S, so it is one of two different possibilities) and it was too salty and a little fishy for my taste.  I certainly wouldn't drop $20+ to have a bowl of that one.

If you are a ramen enthusiast, you will probably love this place, especially if price is no obstacle for you.  Either way, give them a try and see how you like it.

excerpts: We got the spicy Tori Paitan ramen which was good but a bit too rich/heavy and not what I expected.
When they advertise rich and creamy broth that is what you get.
We didn't realize the Spicy Tori Paitan didn't come with duck but I tried some from another friend's bowl.
It was delicious and served medium rare.
They do their meats right here!
tori paitan.author: Jeanne L.
tori paitan.review:
3.5 stars but I'm rounding up for the unique experience.

Get here at least 40 minutes early to get first round seating otherwise you'll wait 1 hour before you get seated. The staff was quick and efficient and the restaurant is fairly small. They offer a modern, trendy ambiance and play R&B music. 

We got the spicy Tori Paitan ramen which was good but a bit too rich/heavy and not what I expected. When they advertise rich and creamy broth that is what you get. The broth is thick like gravy so if you were expecting a cleaner broth you'll be disappointed. 

The meat was amazing and it melts in your mouth! We didn't realize the Spicy Tori Paitan didn't come with duck but I tried some from another friend's bowl. It was delicious and served medium rare. They do their meats right here! You can also order side meats for added protein. 

The enoki chips were yummy and perfectly crispy. The oysters on the other hand are too salty for my palate and 1 order was really enough but we ordered 2 for 5 people. 

Overall, I thought Mensho was good and offered a unique experience for your taste buds but I much prefer Ramen Parlor and Ramen Dojo but the ambiance at Mensho is so much cooler!

excerpts: I ordered the Tori Paitan Ramen that way with a single Chashu and extra firm noodles.
It was perfection!
I really loved the duck and the kale in this Ramen.
The only thing I wasn't a fan of was the crispy burdock root fries which quickly became soggy.
tori paitan.author: Khamis H.
tori paitan.review: Turns out you can get any of their Ramen broths made to order without MSG! I ordered the Tori Paitan Ramen that way with a single Chashu and extra firm noodles. It was perfection! I really loved the duck and the kale in this Ramen. The only thing I wasn't a fan of was the crispy burdock root fries which quickly became soggy.

excerpts: I ordered the Tori Paitan with an egg on top (the eggs come in your choice of miso or soy sauce flavor, which is unique!).
I got the soy sauce flavor which basically reminded me of a tea egg.
I wasn't sure what to expect, but I think it was worth the hype!
I don't know if I'd wait an hour plus for it
(I've gotten lazier as I've gotten older), but the ramen was delicious, with a creamy flavorful broth, pork and duck slices and even some surprisingly tasty and well-cooked kale.
tori paitan.author: Vivian L.
tori paitan.review:
Haven't had a chance to try Mensho out yet since I was always a little concerned about how long the wait would be, but it actually wasn't terrible! Dropped by with a friend on a Wed night around 6:20pm and ended up waiting about half an hour. One of the workers initially quoted me 20 min, and it sounded too good to be true, but it ended up being a close estimate! 

Cute decor inside with a couple of high, communal tables and stools. You will definitely be getting cozy with your neighbors so don't expect to have any private conversations here =P. 

I liked that they had some wicker baskets below the tables where you could put your stuff, very female-friendly, I dig it. There's also a small shelf below the rim of each table where you can keep you phone handy to take pictures =). 

I ordered the Tori Paitan with an egg on top (the eggs come in your choice of miso or soy sauce flavor, which is unique!). I got the soy sauce flavor which basically reminded me of a tea egg. I wasn't sure what to expect, but I think it was worth the hype! I don't know if I'd wait an hour plus for it (I've gotten lazier as I've gotten older), but the ramen was delicious, with a creamy flavorful broth, pork and duck slices and even some surprisingly tasty and well-cooked kale. I slurped up every drop. 

Best ramen I've had in SF!

excerpts: Tori paitan ramen - one of the best I've ever had.
Worth the hour plus wait.
Matcha (green tea) in tori paitan is interesting; Worth trying for novelty.
Sushi bowls are forgettable.
tori paitan.author: Billy D.
tori paitan.review:
Tori paitan ramen - one of the best I've ever had. Worth the hour plus wait. 
RamenRating overall 5/5:

Noodles 4/5
Broth 5/5 - so creamy; so tasty, so perfect. This is not your mana's chicken broth
Chashu 4/5 - yummy duck
Toppings 5/5 - Egg with runny yolk, other good toppings
Spicyiness - not spicy and that's perfect for this bowl. Don't bother with spicy. 
Value 4/5 - $17 for a medium sized portion

Other mentions:
Lamb ramen is great.
Matcha (green tea) in tori paitan is interesting; Worth trying for novelty. 
Sushi bowls are forgettable.

excerpts:
Tori Paitan Ramen, Double Chashu ($18) - 5 stars
Mensho's signature dish is the Bay Area's best rendition of the classic tori paitan.
The chicken broth was rich and creamy as it should be.
The chashu was so tender that even chopsticks could easily tear it apart.
The noodles were cooked al dente and had a great bite to them.
tori paitan.author: Miko B.

excerpts: The Tori Paitan.
I didn't order it myself
but I fell in love with how creamy, rich, and smooth this broth was.
I was having dinner with a ramen afficinado who claimed this
was Top 3 best bowl of ramen he's ever had.
tori paitan.author: Arushi S.
tori paitan.review:
The GOOD: Mensho was mind-blowing and totally worth the 25-30 minute wait (despite it being a Sunday evening)

The BAD: This was my first time eating ramen at a restaurant (EVER. I know...)

The AMAZING: The Tori Paitan. I didn't order it myself but I fell in love with how creamy, rich, and smooth this broth was. I was having dinner with a ramen afficinado who claimed this was Top 3 best bowl of ramen he's ever had. I thoroughly enjoyed my own shoyu ramen with duck but next time I'm coming for this. 

The FUNNY: There's a lot to do once you've conquered the line and are ushered in. You can read about the molecular chemistry of key ramen glutamates which is painted onto the wall. You can watch the TV screen which plays Twitch-style food videos of other people eating ramen...or you can just watch other patrons slurping away from their bowls of umami goodness. Note: Aforementioned options are all equally agonizing.

excerpts: I got the Tori Paitan as that's the one everyone raves about, and as someone who is 100% a fan of a proper soup/broth, I was stoked for it to come.
But I found that the broth was like a gravy.
It was SO THICK.
It's not rich in a way that makes me think deep extract if bones or a ton of flavor - it's the kind of rich that makes me think they must have added cuts of pure fat to the broth.
Besides the broth, everything else was good - I just wasn't able to get over the soup.
tori paitan.author: Jessie Y.
tori paitan.review: To be honest, I don't really buy into the hype. I got the Tori Paitan as that's the one everyone raves about, and as someone who is 100% a fan of a proper soup/broth, I was stoked for it to come. But I found that the broth was like a gravy. It was SO THICK. It's not rich in a way that makes me think deep extract if bones or a ton of flavor - it's the kind of rich that makes me think they must have added cuts of pure fat to the broth. Besides the broth, everything else was good - I just wasn't able to get over the soup.

excerpts: We got seated and decided to order four different ramens: Maccha Tori Paitan, Spicy Lamb, Shio, and Clam Butter Chashu Ramen.
We placed our order with our waitress and as she was about to walk away
I asked if they have Pepsi or Coke for my boyfriend.
Instead of being polite and professional, she gave my boyfriend
and I a snooty response, "UH NO".
Okay?!?!?!
Wouldn't be more professional to say something like,
"I apologize but our restaurant does not carry sodas"???
But how dare you respond to us in that tone, those words, and in such a disapproved expression?
Who are you to disapprove what he likes to drink?
If you don't have it, it's fine but don't disrespect us like that!
My boyfriend got the Shio and yes it came in a broth
but it was way too salty and again lack flavor!
Where are the chicken and pork flavors in this broth?
Was this just salt water with soy sauce for coloring???
And then guess what happened?
The same snooty waitress came by with a pitcher of water and asked to refill our waters.
She was pleasant when she filled my glass
but when she got to my boyfriend, she didn't say anything and just reach between my boyfriend's face and his ramen with her pitcher and dripped water into the ramen.
How rude can you be?
Didn't even acknowledged what she did and just went off.
I mean the water helped a little in diluting the broth but really?!?!
Anyway, my cousin got the Matcha and it was matcha flavored!
YAY!
But that was it!
The taste of Matcha powder sprinkled on the ramen!
My bestie got the Clam Butter Chashu ramen.
We all tasted the broth and we all agreed that the broth tasted the best out of ours.
It has a scoop of butter, we assumed, on top of the ramen but turns out my bestie said it tasted like sour cream.
She didn't think that will mix well with her ramen so she decided to remove it.
She did the right thing or her ramen will be ruined.
tori paitan.author: kaY C.
tori paitan.review:
My cousin recommended this place, said this place was better than many famous ramen restaurants. I was hyped about it as I loveeeeee ramen! I was warned to arrive early as this place always have a line out the door. But since my friend and my schedule didn't permit us to get there early, we got there around 5:30pm. Looking at the line, I thought to myself that this place must be good if all these people are willing to stand around in this neighborhood. As we got to the front of the line, we looked through the menu and saw a selection of different flavored ramen. Everything on the menu sounded interesting so we decided to each get a different flavor ramen to share. We also noticed a tip disclaimer by their menu posted outside that there is a 15% mandatory service fee added to each bill. 

We got seated and decided to order four different ramens: Maccha Tori Paitan, Spicy Lamb, Shio, and Clam Butter Chashu Ramen. We placed our order with our waitress and as she was about to walk away I asked if they have Pepsi or Coke for my boyfriend. Instead of being polite and professional, she gave my boyfriend and I a snooty response, "UH NO". Okay?!?!?! Wouldn't be more professional to say something like, "I apologize but our restaurant does not carry sodas"??? But how dare you respond to us in that tone, those words, and in such a disapproved expression? Who are you to disapprove what he likes to drink? If you don't have it, it's fine but don't disrespect us like that! Is this what your mandatory service fee includes, being rude???

Ramen arrived! Each bowl was presented beautifully! We were excited to dig in! We each took a spoonful of broth to try. I had the Spicy Lamb, OMG the broth is not broth, it's gravy! It's thicker than gravy and I cannot taste miso. Isn't this supposed to be MISO? The chashu was not bad, it was tender but lacks flavor. I do like the little kick in spiciness but I wish it was spicier. Overall, I would not recommend this ramen as I like broth type ramen with flavors! My boyfriend got the Shio and yes it came in a broth but it was way too salty and again lack flavor! Where are the chicken and pork flavors in this broth? Was this just salt water with soy sauce for coloring??? And then guess what happened? The same snooty waitress came by with a pitcher of water and asked to refill our waters. She was pleasant when she filled my glass but when she got to my boyfriend, she didn't say anything and just reach between my boyfriend's face and his ramen with her pitcher and dripped water into the ramen. How rude can you be? Didn't even acknowledged what she did and just went off. I mean the water helped a little in diluting the broth but really?!?! Anyway, my cousin got the Matcha and it was matcha flavored! YAY! But that was it! The taste of Matcha powder sprinkled on the ramen! My bestie got the Clam Butter Chashu ramen. We all tasted the broth and we all agreed that the broth tasted the best out of ours.  It has a scoop of butter, we assumed, on top of the ramen but turns out my bestie said it tasted like sour cream. She didn't think that will mix well with her ramen so she decided to remove it. She did the right thing or her ramen will be ruined. At lease she got the best one out of all the ones we ordered. 

Overall, I was not impressed this place and definitely not going there ever again. Every one has different preference in food so I'm not going to say don't try it as I'm sure this type of ramens suit other people's taste.

excerpts: If you love creamy thick broth, either the spicy tori paitan or spicy lamb ramen will be a great choice!
tori paitan.author: Tiffany C.
tori paitan.review:
Mensho is by far my favorite ramen place in town. I've been here five times in the past few months and I've always experienced great food, friendly and efficient service, and of course... long line. Expect to wait for at least 40 minutes for a smaller party size (2-4 people), and probably longer for bigger groups. 

If you hate waiting in line and don't mind eating late at night, consider going after 9pm on a weekday. I went there for a Wednesday evening ramen run at 10 and waited only 15 minutes to be seated. The only downside is that they might run out of eggs by then. (This might potentially be a deal breaker, I know.)

The best part about their ramen for me has to be the broth. If you love creamy thick broth, either the spicy tori paitan or spicy lamb ramen will be a great choice!

Definitely order some oysters to start! Coming there on an empty stomach is recommended, they don't do takeout. Though if you like it as much as I do, you won't ever need one -- it's so good I always finish it all, even when I'm already so full I could barely walk.

excerpts: Their signature dish is the tori Paitan with duck and pork chashu and is a must try for any ramen fan (just remember to order an egg separately).
Got there around 6p on a Friday and the wait was about 30 min, not bad for SF.
tori paitan.author: EJ A.
tori paitan.review: Finally got around to trying Mensho now that the hype has kind of died down, and was not disappointed! Their signature dish is the tori Paitan with duck and pork chashu and is a must try for any ramen fan (just remember to order an egg separately). Got there around 6p on a Friday and the wait was about 30 min, not bad for SF. The shio ramen is pretty good too.

excerpts: After our 30-45 min wait in line, we wanted to try the store's specialty, the Tori Paitan.
The Tori Paitan was super rich, but I actually want to say it was too rich.
This reminded me of Tsujita's tsukemen in LA, but as a broth rather than a tsukemen dipping sauce.
It was rich, and almost greasy like a pasta sauce.
Weird description, but I am not sure how else to describe it.
The thing is, part way through, I started to have trouble finishing it.
Bottom line: if you've never had super rich ramen broth this is something to try, but shio may be a better option than the Tori Paitan.
If the Tori Paitan was a tsukemen or had some acidity we could add to the broth, I'd give it 5 stars.
tori paitan.author: Kathy O.
tori paitan.review:
We walked to this place after a thrilling escape room experience.  This place opens at 5pm and we got in line around 5:20pm. Parking, like most of SF, seemed about impossible so try to utilize a ride share company or public transit to get here. 

The restaurant is tiny and tables are kind of communal, so you'll be sitting at a table with other customers. We were lucky and sat next to a nice repeat customer. After our 30-45 min wait in line, we wanted to try the store's specialty, the Tori Paitan. 

The Tori Paitan was super rich, but I actually want to say it was too rich. This reminded me of Tsujita's tsukemen in LA, but as a broth rather than a tsukemen dipping sauce. It was rich, and almost greasy like a pasta sauce. Weird description, but I am not sure how else to describe it. The thing is, part way through, I started to have trouble finishing it. The noodles were a great texture, and the meat toppings were amazingly tender, but the soup really needed something to lighten it.

By the end, the soup itself also started to taste and feel gritty. I thought I was imagining it, but my friend agreed with me. Tsujita in LA provides a lime wedge with their tsukemen and it makes all the difference. The nice repeat customer sitting at our table suggested trying the soy sauce flavor ramen, as it is a less rich broth. If I come back, I'll probably do that, or try the shio.

Bottom line: if you've never had super rich ramen broth this is something to try, but shio may be a better option than the Tori Paitan. If the Tori Paitan was a tsukemen or had some acidity we could add to the broth, I'd give it 5 stars.

excerpts: The Tori Paitan was incredible - with a rich, creamy chicken soup, pork chashu, duck chashu, menma, kale, burdock, katsuobushi sauce.
Everything about this ramen was standout but the soup blew it out of the park.
I've always believed the magic lies in the broth and the broth had a wonderfully aromatic umami flavor.
tori paitan.author: Cindy W.
tori paitan.review:
I'm 100% sure this place gave me the food poisoning but ... maybe it was worth it (?) Now that speaks volumes about the broth ... or my standard.

The Tori Paitan was incredible - with a rich, creamy chicken soup, pork chashu, duck chashu, menma, kale, burdock, katsuobushi sauce. Everything about this ramen was standout but the soup blew it out of the park. I've always believed the magic lies in the broth and the broth had a wonderfully aromatic umami flavor. Chashu was great too.

Of course, don't forget that touch of kale because... well it's SF.

Skip the enoki chips or use it as tempura. It definitely gets soggy fast. Maybe that's what gave me the food poisoning. 

Line was maybe 30 minutes long starting at 6pm on a Thursday night. Not bad.

excerpts: We both ordered the tori paitan ramen, which costs $16 per bowl.
While that may seem pretty expensive for ramen, I feel that it's justified.
tori paitan.author: Trang T.
tori paitan.review:
I came here with a friend around 8:30pm on a Friday and finally got seated at around 9:25pm. Yep, a pretty long wait. We both ordered the tori paitan ramen, which costs $16 per bowl. While that may seem pretty expensive for ramen, I feel that it's justified. You get a pretty big serving of chewy noodles, a heap of burdock roots, and some slices of chashu and duck.

Mensho is so different from other ramen joints because they specialize in a very thick chicken based broth. While everyone raves about it, I couldn't find myself enjoying it that much. It left a very grainy texture in my mouth. The chashu, noodles, and burdock were much more enjoyable. Ramen restaurants rely mostly on their broth so while Mensho's broth is super unique, it didn't have enough of an interesting flavor to amaze me.

excerpts: Had the tori paitan and vegan tantanmen and mushroom chips.
Delicious!
Very limited seating and the wait was very long.
Very cool space though and
it has a communal feel.
tori paitan.author: Shalini C.
tori paitan.review: Solid food. Had the tori paitan and vegan tantanmen and mushroom chips. Delicious! Very limited seating and the wait was very long. Very cool space though and it has a communal feel.

excerpts: This is where Mensho Tokyo comes in with their Tori Paitan ramen, which had an incredibly rich and thicker broth than most of what you'd find in the Bay.
It's very good
and I was impressed.
I also enjoyed the noodles here, they were pretty al dente which I usually prefer.
The toppings were also great.
While there wasn't much of it, the duck is worth a try!
Also be sure to get the enoki mushroom chips if you're a fan of the stuff.
tori paitan.author: Bryson L.
tori paitan.review:
I can see why San Francisco would be going crazy for this place.  Coming from Hawaii, I've had a variety of ramen styles, but the Bay Area seems mostly dominated by Tonkatsu style ramen.  This is where Mensho Tokyo comes in with their Tori Paitan ramen, which had an incredibly rich and thicker broth than most of what you'd find in the Bay.  It's very good and I was impressed.  I also enjoyed the noodles here, they were pretty al dente which I usually prefer.  The toppings were also great.  While there wasn't much of it, the duck is worth a try!  Also be sure to get the enoki mushroom chips if you're a fan of the stuff.  They're really good with the chili flakes and the lemon, perfect appetizer.  

As for the wait, we got there around 5pm on a Saturday and ended up making it in the second rotation.  It took under an hour.  The restaurant itself is small so you'll be sitting on communal tables here, just fyi.

excerpts: Tried the Tori Paitan Ramen....
Flavorful and creamy broth.
The combo with the pork and duck chashu was so good!
tori paitan.author: Hiedie S.
tori paitan.review:
Found this place after going to a concert in SF. It was near by and we decide to try it. There wasn't a line just 1 party ahead of us. Apparently during the day there's a long line.

Tried the Tori Paitan Ramen.... Flavorful and creamy broth. The combo with the pork and duck chashu was so good! The Duck chashu has a citrus and tangy hint to it and it tasted delicious with the broth. 

Service was good! It's a small place and seating is communal. The tables have a little area where you can place small belongings. Underneath there are baskets where you can place larger items like purses and backpacks.

excerpts: Got the Tori Paitan: rich & creamy chicken soup with pork and duck chashu, menma, kale, burdock, and katsuobushi sauce.
The soup is very rich and creamy, its a little more overwhelming in flavor then I prefer but good.
Its so rich it tastes a little grainy but it works.
The noodles are well cooked and the right amount of chewy.
The duck and pork chashu were flavorful and a nice addition.
I didn't really care for the kale but its SF so not surprising to see it in there.
The ramen here was good but not worth the long waits or the prices they charge.
If you don't mind waiting and want to try something a little different, then i'd say its worth checking out.
tori paitan.author: Peter P.
tori paitan.review:
The ramen here is good. Now is it worth the wait which typically is at least an hour or the price? Absolutely not, you can go to plenty of other places in town and get ramen thats decent for no wait and a more reasonable price. 
There is almost always a line here as it is IMO way too over hyped. The place is very small only 4 communal tables so expect to sit close to other people. The service here is meh, not great but not bad. The biggest problem here is the people who come to eat here and honestly I think its more a cultural thing. In asian culture when you go to a ramen shop, you sit, you order, you eat, you pay, and then you leave. There is no time wasted talking and hanging out which american culture expects for any meal which is why this place typically has a terribly long wait. Come here a few hours before they close or right when they open to miss the larger crowds and have a shorter wait, otherwise be prepared mentally and with your stomach to wait. 
The ramen itself it wasn't that bad. Got the Tori Paitan: rich & creamy chicken soup with pork and duck chashu, menma, kale, burdock, and katsuobushi sauce. The soup is very rich and creamy, its a little more overwhelming in flavor then I prefer but good. Its so rich it tastes a little grainy but it works. The noodles are well cooked and the right amount of chewy. The duck and pork chashu were flavorful and a nice addition. I didn't really care for the kale but its SF so not surprising to see it in there. 
The ramen here was good but not worth the long waits or the prices they charge. If you don't mind waiting and want to try something a little different, then i'd say its worth checking out.

excerpts: I got the Spicy Tori Paitan, and the broth was exceptionally rich.
I ended up finishing the broth and not the noodles; would come again!
tori paitan.author: Kailin L.
tori paitan.review: Came here on a Sunday evening (5pm) with a friend; waited about 40 minutes before being seated. The space inside is modern but pretty narrow. I got the Spicy Tori Paitan, and the broth was exceptionally rich. I ended up finishing the broth and not the noodles; would come again!

excerpts: I got the Spicy Tori Paitan ramen.
The flavor is just okay - the broth is super thick and the noodles are also super thick.
I guess I'm just not a fan of this style of ramen and I will not be back.
Orenchi still remains my favorite ramen in the bay area.
tori paitan.author: Jenann P.
tori paitan.review:
After seeing the long line outside of this place for over a year, I decided to try it out on a weekend. We got there right when it opened (5pm) and waited for an hour.

I got the Spicy Tori Paitan ramen. The flavor is just okay - the broth is super thick and the noodles are also super thick. I guess I'm just not a fan of this style of ramen and I will not be back. Orenchi still remains my favorite ramen in the bay area.

excerpts: and I both ordered the tori paitan because we were looking for a more creamier/heavier broth.
I added habaneros, chives, chili oil, and garlic flakes.
At $2 each addon, my bowl of ramen became pretty pricey.
Between the two of us, our total was about $67.
Overall, I think the ramen was pretty good.
Portion was very generous and I was struggling to finish.
tori paitan.author: Brian J.
tori paitan.review:
COME EARLY!!! If you plan to come here for a dinner, just know that you're going to be waiting for a very very very very very long time. This place has a capacity of only probably 35 people max and the wait to be seated takes over an hour, at least that's how it was like for us. When we left, the line was even longer and that was about 9:30pm!

We found this place based on the yelp reviews and after walking around San Francisco especially in the Golden Gate Park with temperatures in the lower 60s, we needed some hot Ramen to end our day. 

First impression upon arriving was the fact that there was a long line with approximately 25 people. The place itself is tricky to find because they don't have very many signs or indications that there is an actual restaurant. Like I mentioned previously we waited over an hour and the line was even longer when we left.

My fiancée and I both ordered the tori paitan because we were looking for a more creamier/heavier broth. I added habaneros, chives, chili oil, and garlic flakes. At $2 each addon, my bowl of ramen became pretty pricey. Between the two of us, our total was about $67. Overall, I think the ramen was pretty good. Portion was very generous and I was struggling to finish. They also give a generous amount of noodles which is awesome because a lot of ramen places I've been to short you on the noodles requiring you to order more at an extra charge.

Would We go back? Eh... We can't really justify waiting for over an hour again... maybe We would try to go right when they open to eat sooner. Regardless we liked it and would recommend this place to people looking for some good ramen!

excerpts: We ended up ordering the Tori Paitan, which is what they're known for!
The first sip of my broth had me in nirvana.
I was pretty shocked at how rich and thick the broth was.
I've had ramen in Japan, and don't get me wrong!
Ramen in Japan was incredible, but this place definitely is my new #1 favorite.
Anyways, the noodles were chewy and the meat was tender and delicious.
tori paitan.author: Veronica D.
tori paitan.review:
Best. Ramen. Ever!!

My friends and I went to go try this place on a Friday night, and they insisted that they had heard so many things about this tiny ramen shop. The wait was about an hour, and there was no wait list, just a line. The place is very tiny with communal style seating. But despite the wait and the awkward seating, it was absolutely worth it! 

We ended up ordering the Tori Paitan, which is what they're known for! The first sip of my broth had me in nirvana. I was pretty shocked at how rich and thick the broth was. I've had ramen in Japan, and don't get me wrong! Ramen in Japan was incredible, but this place definitely is my new #1 favorite. Anyways, the noodles were chewy and the meat was tender and delicious. It was a bit pricey for ramen, $16 for the bowl, but it was well worth it. 

I absolutely need to go back, I'm already drooling at the thought of our next trip!

excerpts: I got the tori paitan ramen because it was the closest thing to my traditional creamy ramen I would always get in Tokyo.
The broth was good, but a tad too salty for what I am used to.
If you want your egg it is an up charge.
The noodle was what ruined the experience.
All the ramen place I had in Japan had this soft yet bouncy texture to their noodles which were all made from scratch.
Here I got this thick and undercooked doughy noodle, nothing that reminded me of Japan.
tori paitan.author: Diana N.
tori paitan.review:
I personally think this place is overrated. I guess the idea of this place is to be much like ramen shops in Japan. The plus was no tipping (which is offensive to do so in Japan), especially when it's is one of the more expensive ramen places in SF. 
I got the tori paitan ramen because it was the closest thing to my traditional creamy ramen I would always get in Tokyo. The broth was good, but a tad too salty for what I am used to. If you want your egg it is an up charge. The noodle was what ruined the experience. All the ramen place I had in Japan had this soft yet bouncy texture to their noodles which were all made from scratch. Here I got this thick and undercooked doughy noodle, nothing that reminded me of Japan. 
My friend got the shio ramen and didn't feel it was any more special than other ramen places around.
We won't be making our way back considering the price, and the not so great area that it located in as well.

excerpts: Tori Paitan Ramen soup was rich and creamy.
Noodles were soft and tender, but they weren't made onsite.
Duck and pork charsu were succulent and not super fatty.
Dried mushrooms and seaweed were standard ramen items.
Kale in the ramen is an odd combination and just added color.
tori paitan.author: Elmo ..
tori paitan.review:
On Friday, 12/22, I got in line at 420p and there were already 20+ people in line for 31 seats (4+12+7+8).  I got in the 1st wave of seating with 2 seats to spare which they never filled up for some unknown reason.  At 5p, the line was about 100+ people long (half block).

Tori Paitan Ramen soup was rich and creamy.  Noodles were soft and tender, but they weren't made onsite.  Duck and pork charsu were succulent and not super fatty.  Dried mushrooms and seaweed were standard ramen items.   Kale in the ramen is an odd combination and just added color.  Golden egg (miso flavored) add on was spot on.  

Overall, the ramen was tasty, but it is not worth the 1+ hour wait unless you have never been there.  There are numerous places like Mensho that are all over Tokyo.

excerpts: I had the Tori Paitan...
Had 1/2 the bowl and then asked for the chili spice to add a little zing to the 2nd half.
Next time I would go for the spicy version.
I typically think the pork is going to be chewy and hard to with chopsticks and soup spoon...
But this was so well cooked that it broke off into bite size pieces just with the chopsticks.
Have to bring the family here since my daughter just loves Ramen!
tori paitan.author: Ravinder S.
tori paitan.review: Awesome Ramen! I had the Tori Paitan...Had 1/2 the bowl and then asked for the chili spice to add a little zing to the 2nd half. Next time I would go for the spicy version. I typically think the pork is going to be chewy and hard to with chopsticks and soup spoon...But this was so well cooked that it broke off into bite size pieces just with the chopsticks. Have to bring the family here since my daughter just loves Ramen!

excerpts: I ordered the Organic Shoyu and my friend ordered Tori Paitan.
Both of them were delicious
but I loved the rich and creamy soup way more,
and I know some of you are thinking, it's richer and creamy but more fat
but hey majority of the best and delicious food are fat.
You know what that means?
Time to go gym and workout to lose all the fat and calories and eat more again!
The ramen was honestly the best, I think it's handmade on the spot.
And OMG their duck and chasu is litty!
The organic shoyu was around $14 and the tori paitan was $16 just like it says on the menu on yelp.
The organic shoyu was around $14 and the tori paitan was $16 just like it says on the menu on yelp.
tori paitan.author: Christopher G.
tori paitan.review:
Three words.... OMG! 

This place is like the best ramen I ever had in my life so far! I came here with my friend around 5:30pm and the line was crazy long. If your from San Francisco you know there's like a long line for every restaurant that's really delicious. Well I can tell you that this place is definitely worth the wait and price for the quality of the food.

I ordered the Organic Shoyu and my friend ordered Tori Paitan. Both of them were delicious but I loved the rich and creamy soup way more, and I know some of you are thinking, it's richer and creamy but more fat but hey majority of the best and delicious food are fat. You know what that means? Time to go gym and workout to lose all the fat and calories and eat more again! The ramen was honestly the best, I think it's handmade on the spot. And OMG their duck and chasu is litty! The organic shoyu was around $14 and the tori paitan was $16 just like it says on the menu on yelp. 

Overall it was a great experience just come early to avoid being the last one. And for those of you hesitating to come, just come or you miss out on the best ramen in San Francisco. Definitely one of those spots that I will be coming back again!

excerpts: My daughter and I ordered a spicy Tori paitan ramen and agreed it was good in broth and noodle texture.
Although we prefer the ingredients in the regular Tori paitan with kale and duck chashu.
Ours only came with cabbage, pork chashu and bamboo shoots.
That's the only downside to our dish.
Spice is just right not too spicy.
Will definitely be back to try other stuff like the oysters and clam ramen!
We got our food pretty fast too.
People are friendly enough to talk to one another at our shared table.
Overall legit ramen spot in SF!
tori paitan.author: Corinne Z.
tori paitan.review: Went there 30 mins before closing on a Thursday night. Short line outside. Got seated fast. My daughter and I ordered a spicy Tori paitan ramen and agreed it was good in broth and noodle texture. Although we prefer the ingredients in the regular Tori paitan with kale and duck chashu. Ours only came with cabbage, pork chashu and bamboo shoots. That's the only downside to our dish. Spice is just right not too spicy. Will definitely be back to try other stuff like the oysters and clam ramen!  We got our food pretty fast too. People are friendly enough to talk to one another at our shared table. Overall legit ramen spot in SF!

excerpts: We ordered a regular as well as a Matcha Tori Paitan.
The latter was surprisingly tasty and unique to try.
The oyster appetizer is also a great opener with its light umami flavor.
tori paitan.author: Regina L.
tori paitan.review: Great ramen concept. Although the venue was on the smaller scale and there was a wait, all my expectations of good ramen were fulfilled and more. We ordered a regular as well as a Matcha Tori Paitan. The latter was surprisingly tasty and unique to try. The oyster appetizer is also a great opener with its light umami flavor.

excerpts: I ordered the Spicy Tori Paitan.
The broth was really rich but delicious.
I loved all the different textures found in the ramen.
tori paitan.author: Yi L.
tori paitan.review: It was definitely worth the wait! Make sure to get there before they open so that you are able to get first seating like others mentioned. I ordered the Spicy Tori Paitan. The broth was really rich but delicious. I loved all the different textures found in the ramen.

excerpts: Tori paitan was rich and creamy with thick noodles and a good sized portion.
Well worth the wait and trip to SF.
tori paitan.author: Naomi S.
tori paitan.review: Hands down the best ramen I have ever eaten, and likely in the top 20 best tasting things I have ever eaten. Tori paitan was rich and creamy with thick noodles and a good sized portion. Well worth the wait and trip to SF.

excerpts: -double chasu tori paitan ramen ($18)
I really enjoyed the broth, it was very flavorful and still somewhat light, but toward the end of my meal it did get a little heavy.
Still I enjoyed the noodle texture a lot too.
tori paitan.author: Isabel L.
tori paitan.review:
The hype is real! We came around 745pm on a Saturday and there was a 40 min wait even in the rain! But I didn't mind too much since I wasn't too hungry. The interior is small but service is quick once you're seated.

We ordered:
-shoyu oysters ($5 for 4) -very just okay to me. A little in the fishy side, would skip!
-chasu bowl-4.5/5-yum!!! Had 3 huge fatty pieces of chasu with rice ! So delicious and tender ! 
-double chasu tori paitan ramen ($18) -4/5. I really enjoyed the broth, it was very flavorful and still somewhat light, but toward the end of my meal it did get a little heavy. Still I enjoyed the noodle texture a lot too. The chasu pieces were just okay 

Overall it was pretty good ! A little on the pricey side, but a solid choice in sf!

excerpts: I had the Tori Paitan and while the noodles were enjoyable, the broth was overly rich and creamy from the gelatin.
It becomes overwhelming after a few spoons.
The chashu was good, but nothing spectacular.
For almost $30 I would try my luck somewhere else.
tori paitan.author: Harrison T.
tori paitan.review: For the price and the wait in line (~1 hour), I have to say that it was quite underwhelming. I had the Tori Paitan and while the noodles were enjoyable, the broth was overly rich and creamy from the gelatin. It becomes overwhelming after a few spoons. The chashu was good, but nothing spectacular. For almost $30 I would try my luck somewhere else.

excerpts: I ordered the Tori Paitan ramen.
Now I've never, ever been too picky with my ramen.
I would be perfectly content with instant noodles,  obviously preferring dine in when occasions rose for it.
But I think this spot definitely changed my idea of what GREAT ramen is.
The broth was thick, creamy, and rich.
Although we agreed all the elements of it didn't match as well as the Tori Paitan.
tori paitan.author: Sarah L.
tori paitan.review:
Like all other reviewers before me said, the wait is long! My friend and I came in around 7 on a Tuesday night, and got in approximately an hour later. We luckily managed to snag two spots at the bar, which was more personable than the other tables, and the place was small. Also asked the waitress if there was a time limit we could dine in and she said no. 

I ordered the Tori Paitan ramen. Now I've never, ever been too picky with my ramen. I would be perfectly content with instant noodles,  obviously preferring dine in when occasions rose for it. But I think this spot definitely changed my idea of what GREAT ramen is. The broth was thick, creamy, and rich. And all the elements combined made for an enriching experience, from the soft, chewy noodles to the tender chashu pork, to the burdock root which added a very nice texture. 

My friend had ordered the organic shoyu ramen,  which tasted a lot lighter. Probably the healthier alternative, if you're looking for one. Although we agreed all the elements of it didn't match as well as the Tori Paitan.

I was also very impressed by our appetizer, oysters in shoyu dare oil. The plate was small with only a few pieces. However, from the very first bite, your taste buds just get sent through the roof. I don't know how else to explain it, but I was hooked. 

The whole meal was very filling, the service was good, and I would happily wait in line again for this place.

excerpts: I've tried three of the ramens: tori paitan, shoyu, and shio.
If you like creamy go for the tori paitan if not the shoyu or shio will better suit you.
If you like creamy go for the tori paitan if not the shoyu or shio will better suit you.
I preferred the shoyu over the shio just based on the soup and would come back for the shoyu or the clam ramen
tori paitan.author: Jenny E.
tori paitan.review:
I really wanted to like this place but I just don't prefer it to others but keep in mind I don't have a very refined ramen palate. 

I've tried three of the ramens: tori paitan, shoyu, and shio. If you like creamy go for the tori paitan if not the shoyu or shio will better suit you. I preferred the shoyu over the shio just based on the soup and would come back for the shoyu or the clam ramen but that's never available when I get here anyways. 

The reason I don't like this place..... honestly there's a certain and smell and flavor to the ramen I just didn't like it kinda just reminded me of an Asian market but in my mouth... this could be just me but my boyfriend felt the same way. Just my two cents, still a nice place for ramen but definitely many worthy competitors out there!

excerpts: I usually get the Tori Paitan ramen with double chashu.
I recommend getting the double chashu as it is the perfect amount of meat for the ramen.
When you see it at first, the bowl appears to be a little on the small side; however, as you eat, you begin to wonder how you're not finished with your bowl.
The broth is very thick and flavorful, with the chashu complimenting the broth.
The one thing that I thought would take it over the top would be an egg.
tori paitan.author: Jason P.
tori paitan.review:
I can be very particular about my ramen, and overall, the ramen in the bay isn't as good as it is in LA. Fortunately, this place can stack up to the ramen in LA. There is only street parking here, and more then likely you will be waiting outside for while. The dining area is very small, and you will be siting very close to strangers. The restroom is unisex and is well maintained. The place is very bright and there is a TV on the side.

I usually get the Tori Paitan ramen with double chashu. I recommend getting the double chashu as it is the perfect amount of meat for the ramen. When you see it at first, the bowl appears to be a little on the small side; however, as you eat, you begin to wonder how you're not finished with your bowl. The broth is very thick and flavorful, with the chashu complimenting the broth. The one thing that I thought would take it over the top would be an egg. Sadly, I did not see that add-on option on the menu.

The service is pretty fast once you get seated. The people working here are kind and respectful. Overall, I would have to say that this is my go to ramen spot in the city. I will be definitely be coming back here many more times. 4.5 stars.

excerpts: I recommend getting the Tori Paitan.
It has really thick, chewy noodles and a creamy, flavorful broth.
tori paitan.author: Danielle C.
tori paitan.review:
Definitely my favorite ramen in San Francisco. Way better than Marufuku Ramen in my opinion. I recommend getting the Tori Paitan. It has really thick, chewy noodles and a creamy, flavorful broth. The meat was also melt-in-your-mouth tender.

Admittedly the wait is very long (upwards of 30min-1hr) and the restaurant is small with a communal seating arrangement. Though, the service is very fast and food comes out quickly.

excerpts: I ordered the Tori Paitan ramen and added an egg.
As expected it was a thick and delicious broth with tons of flavor.
Enjoyed every bite and every slurp.
I can see how some people may find it a bit too much since it is very thick and many will not be used to it.
tori paitan.author: Ruben P.
tori paitan.review:
The ultimate question: Is it worth the wait? If you are starving, the answer is no. I would likely never bring most of my family here as we get HANGRY, and waiting is not something we would like to do as a group for dinner.

After a late meeting at work I decided to trek over to Mensho Tokyo after having read about it a while ago. As I approached, I immediately knew I had arrived because of the line outside. I hopped in and was surprised that the line never really got shorter. The line was as expected in the wait was about 45 minutes to an hour.

When I was finally seated the service was quick, attentive, and friendly enough. I ordered the Tori Paitan ramen and added an egg. As expected it was a thick and delicious broth with tons of flavor. Enjoyed every bite and every slurp. I can see how some people may find it a bit too much since it is very thick and many will not be used to it. I thoroughly enjoyed it and thought it was delicious.

Now, is it worth the wait....again? Possibly, yes. BUT...you'll have to catch me on patient day and when I'm not that hungry because of the line.

excerpts:
If you are expecting a full face broth with sinus cleansing and pore cleaning attributes this is not one of the places you go if you order the Tori Paitan or the Spicy Lamb that is, I was told the vegetarian ramen is very good,

Here is the description of what we sampled and how each item faired

the Tori Paitan - this is their signature ramen bowl, I ordered it with the double chashu (pork slices), the broth is not broth, it is literally thick as gravy, I also added duck slices to my soup which was made slightly raw, that too was delicious the taste was interesting, slightly spicy, the noodles were springy, the chashu was delicious, I just can't get over the thickness of the gravy type broth, was not expecting that, the veggies and half egg soy sauce infused were good, but the broth on this dish was not my favorite.

the Spicy Lamb with Chashu was very good, the broth was close to the Tori Paitan but with lamb and the spicy kick made for a much better dish, my wife ordered this dish, I would have finished her bowl easy, the lamb flavor with the spicy kick was really good, the gravy like broth on this dish again was similar but due to the kick of spice and lamb made the ramen bowl completely different, if you like lamb this is a no brainer, I will have to come back and just order this dish

the appetizer was oysters which tasted like they were cured or strained with something vinegary, I was not a fan but please try it is not for everyone, your tastebuds may not have the same likes mine do.

there was other sub dishes I did not see on the menu, small bowls of rice and pork belly, I will have to come back for that

Tori Paitan -

tori paitan.review:
3.5 stars if you have never had this type ramen you will be in for a surprize, I will probably get flack for writing this review but hey if you don't like it don't read it.

The wait for this place has always been fairly long, the night we tried it was about 20min wait for 2 people late night around 9:30pm

So let me get down to the why it fell short in my book. It was not the service, it was not the ambiance, it was not the price, it was the ramen. Here is the description of what we sampled and how each item faired
