the Spicy Lamb with Chashu was very good, the broth was close to the Tori Paitan but with lamb and the spicy kick made for a much better dish, my wife ordered this dish, I would have finished her bowl easy, the lamb flavor with the spicy kick was really good, the gravy like broth on this dish again was similar but due to the kick of spice and lamb made the ramen bowl completely different, if you like lamb this is a no brainer, I will have to come back and just order this dish

the appetizer was oysters which tasted like they were cured or strained with something vinegary, I was not a fan but please try it is not for everyone, your tastebuds may not have the same likes mine do.

sake 300ml was cold, excellent pairing with the ramen

there was other sub dishes I did not see on the menu, small bowls of rice and pork belly, I will have to come back for that

Tori Paitan - *** oddly not my cup of tea
spicy lamb - **** order this!!!
oysters - ** hard pass
service ***** very helpful staff
price $$
ambiance *****

excerpts:
Tori paitan ramen - creamy chicken broth noodle and the duck chasu is really unique
3.
Vegetarian dandanmen - this was my favorite.
tori paitan.author: Regina A.
tori paitan.review:
I've been hearing about the hype of mensho ramen for a while and finally got a time to go to this place. The place open at 5pm and we arrived at the place around 4.15 pm. We manage to get the fist spot in the line but at 4.30 the line was already soo loong!!

The place is so small so they only have 4 big table which you have to share with other party and there was 4 seat in the bar. 

These are our order:
1. Oyster for appetizer - really good
2. Tori paitan ramen - creamy chicken broth noodle and the duck chasu is really unique
3. Vegetarian dandanmen - this was my favorite. I was hesitant to order vegetarian ramen but it actually taste really2 good.

Will definitely come back to try the other noodle.

excerpts: I got the Tori Paitan
(I think that's he right spelling!), and the broth was so savory.
tori paitan.author: Jana L.
tori paitan.review:
This restaurant is DELICIOUS.  I can honestly say that this is probably the best ramen I've ever had (but I'm not as well-versed in the ramen scene as other Yelpers).  

My cousins and I were so lucky to get in line at around 4:30 pm on a Saturday!  There were only a couple of parties ahead of us, so we got seated during the "first round" - GO us!  The menu is pretty simple, with a couple of ramen choices and options if you want double chashu.  I got the Tori Paitan (I think that's he right spelling!), and the broth was so savory.  This soup was definitely on the more oily side, if we were to compare the shio ramen.  It was so delicious that I wouldn't even second guess my choice for getting it.

Our ramen was complimented with some quality green tea that the waitresses were so quick to refill.  I think this place would be nice for a date, but maybe not a first date.  The turn-around time is quick, since a majority of the time, there's a line outside.  But be warned, this restaurant is TINY!  There are like 3 total tables, two of which are large enough to fit maybe 8-10 people.  So, if you come with a party of two, you'd probably be seated next to random strangers (also an opportunity to make friends)! 

Overall, really great restaurant.  If this is what Japan's ramen tastes like, I'm going to book a flight to visit Japan next week!!!!  Definitely will return again, when the chance presents itself! :)

excerpts: The shop offers a variety of bowls, but I highly recommend the Tori Paitan.
tori paitan.author: Amy G.
tori paitan.review:
Hands down best tasting ramen in SF. Quality is on par with Ippudo, even better than Totto Ramen in NYC.

The shop offers a variety of bowls, but I highly recommend the Tori Paitan. It's high quality and uniquely differentiated from any other type of ramen I've had - the broth is thick, the noodles are thick and chewy, and it's simply delicious.

Bowls run $16-18. Ambiance is very bright and clean, with tight, but not too tight seating for a ramen shop. Servers come frequently to refill your drink. The lines are just really long (45-60 min on average). Even on a Tuesday night at 10pm it took me 20 minutes to get seated.

excerpts: I had the tori paitan double cha shu
tori paitan.author: Audrey D.
tori paitan.review:
Honestly tempted to rate a 2 just because the overhype is real. If you're a ramen connoisseur, I'd say try it for yourself! But it's definitely not on my top 5 Bay Area ramen list.

Don't get us wrong, service is top notch and authenticity is there. The (super) thick, (super) salty rich fatty broth just wasn't for us. We were guzzling many glasses of water during and after eating. The chashu was thinly sliced and overcooked, it fell apart before I could pick it up with chopsticks. Kale was even cooked to a softness comparable to baby food. And no egg? Not even half an egg? My only thumbs up would be the noodles. I really appreciated the thick al dente consistency of mensho's ramen. I had the tori paitan double cha shu and Vincent had the spicy lamb. 

Small small place. Wait can be long, but their turnover is quick. Came around 6pm and we got in in half an hour. Keep your parties small to get in quicker. Fun community style tables where you're sitting inches away from your neighbors. Unique experience but if your neighbors are loud, it's gonna be a challenge to make sure your friends can hear you.

excerpts: Their most popular ramen is the tori paitan ramen
so I got that with the enoki mushroom chips as appetizer.
Food came out quickly despite the amount of people.
The mushroom chips were interesting, different than what most places have to offer, but it did taste somewhat similar to calamari.
On to the ramen, it was beautiful when I received it.
The noodles were thick and curly, yet bouncy
noodles(that's the ramen check).
The meat was so tender, yet flavorful with each bite.
The broth is also different compared to other places, super rich and thick.
I  did end up not really liking the broth towards the end because of how creamy and oily it was.
Besides everything the broth, everything else was enjoyable.
Service was good, filled our waters twice.
I'd definitely come back for their shoyu ramen next time.
tori paitan.author: Lisa W.
tori paitan.review: Been on my to try list for the longest and I finally get to say I tried Mensho Tokyo! I got there when it was about time to open on a Wednesday evening and the line wasn't so bad. The restaurant itself is definitely on the smaller side which makes sense why the wait can be so long. Once they opened up, we didn't have to wait in line, everyone got seated and the staff quickly went around getting everyone's orders. The seats are however, kind of uncomfortable. Tall tables with high stools, with almost no arm space between me and the person next door. Their most popular ramen is the tori paitan ramen so I got that with the enoki mushroom chips as appetizer. Food came out quickly despite the amount of people. The mushroom chips were interesting, different than what most places have to offer, but it did taste somewhat similar to calamari. On to the ramen, it was beautiful when I received it. The noodles were thick and curly, yet bouncy noodles(that's the ramen check). The meat was so tender, yet flavorful with each bite. The broth is also different compared to other places, super rich and thick. I  did end up not really liking the broth towards the end because of how creamy and oily it was. Besides everything the broth, everything else was enjoyable. Service was good, filled our waters twice. I'd definitely come back for their shoyu ramen next time.

excerpts:
I would really love to give Mensho a 4 at least but

The tori paitan came with almost no meat!
tori paitan.author: Foodie A.
tori paitan.review:
I would really love to give Mensho a 4 at least but

The tori paitan came with almost no meat! For $17!

Its not really a restaurant, it's a small room with two communal tables and you sit jam packed with strangers. Someone you sit across from strangers. Just not justifiable with the hefty price.

They do not allow to-go bowls? Why?? Each ramen bowl is at $16. I should have the freedom to do whatever I want with my food. I finished my meal but the stranger beside me barely ate hers and its goes straight to the trash. With the increasing amount of homeless people in SF, least one can do is pack up your food and offer it to someone graciously and respectfully. However Mensho does not even give its customers this possibility 

The only reason i really want to give it a 4/5 is their vegan tantanmen is very very good.
Otherwise if you are not vegetarian, it is not worth the hype or the money.

excerpts: We both got the Tori Paitan, which was sublime.
After just tasting the soup (no noodle, no topping), we both knew it was the best ramen we've ever had.
tori paitan.author: Pedro K.
tori paitan.review:
Classic case of "you get what you paid for"...only you're paying with your time, not $. My gf and I went at 8pm on a Sunday night and waited for almost an hour, anxious to try this very hyped up ramen joint. 

It was well worth it. We got the oysters, which were very unique. It was a completely foreign combination of taste and texture, which I enjoyed but my gf hated (more for me). We both got the Tori Paitan, which was sublime. After just tasting the soup (no noodle, no topping), we both knew it was the best ramen we've ever had. Quick note -- the double cashu is makes the soup slightly heartier, and in my opinion is worth the $2. 

I consider myself an intermediate ramen consumer, and this was in a league of its own.

excerpts: I got the organic shoyu ramen and my boyfriend got the tori paitan.
WOWWW
I loved the tori paitan more than the shoyu broth.
Probably because it's so thick, dense, and creamy.
One of the best broths I've ever tasted in my life!
I remember my shoyu ramen had pork chashu, duck chashu, kale, bamboo shoots, and some microgreens.
The pork chashu was soooo fatty it melted in my mouth.
I liked it
tori paitan.author: Caroline B.
tori paitan.review:
This is a very tiny restaurant, most likely only fits ~40 people. The wait is different from any other place. You and your entire party has to wait in line the entire time until you are called. The wait can be from 45 mins - more than an hour.

I got the organic shoyu ramen and my boyfriend got the tori paitan. WOWWW I loved the tori paitan more than the shoyu broth. Probably because it's so thick, dense, and creamy. One of the best broths I've ever tasted in my life! I remember my shoyu ramen had pork chashu, duck chashu, kale, bamboo shoots, and some microgreens. The pork chashu was soooo fatty it melted in my mouth. I liked it but, I prefer it to be more meaty. 

Overall, I thought it was delicious. I didn't mind how cramped it was but if you have major claustrophobia then maybe this isn't for you. Even though the ramen is pricey ($14-16) it's made with organic products.

excerpts: The tori paitan was really good, but the broth was way too thick for me.
But, the ramen noodles themselves and the meats inside were amazing.
The duck chashu was so good.
Probably one of the best things I've eaten.
tori paitan.author: Charissa S.
tori paitan.review:
Honestly, the hype might have overkilled it for me. But, it was equally as good as I thought. The tori paitan was really good, but the broth was way too thick for me. But, the ramen noodles themselves and the meats inside were amazing. The duck chashu was so good. Probably one of the best things I've eaten. Other than that, if you're not a big fan of thick creamy soups accompanied with your ramen, then I would recommend getting a different soup base. 

Other than the food, the wait was really long. We wired an hour. But service was fast!

excerpts: We also ordered the basic Tori Paitan double chashu ramen ($18).
I was not a big fan of this one because of how rich, thick, and creamy the broth was.
But then again, I imagine this place is pretty popular because of their broth.
tori paitan.author: Amy L.
tori paitan.review:
I'm so sorry that my review might be biased because I came to Mensho Tokyo on a very full stomach after eating AYCE dim sum for brunch. My sister's boyfriend really wanted ramen so my friend looked up a place and Mensho came up. We came around 7:20pm and waited in line until about 8:20pm (so 1 hour wait). Would I say the line is worth it? Yes and no. 

Let me tell you why: Yes because we ordered something really unique--I think it's called the white butter clam ramen ($20)? Or something along the lines of that. My sister ate the clam and she said it was the freshest clam she has ever. I say this dish was unique because they literally have a big white scoop of butter. This added a whole new flavor that I've never tasted before and I wish I was hungry enough to actually enjoy it. HIGHLY RECOMMEND THIS DISH. 

We also ordered the basic Tori Paitan double chashu ramen ($18). I was not a big fan of this one because of how rich, thick, and creamy the broth was. But then again, I imagine this place is pretty popular because of their broth. The only thing I really like about this bowl of ramen was the fact that their bowls came out super hot. 

I was sitting at the bar right in front of their kitchen and I saw how they made a real effort to heat up the bowls by dipping it in boiling water. LOVED that they do that. 

So there are some good and bad, but overall, I don't think I will be visiting this place again. Long line, pricey, and I'm also not a huge ramen fan...

excerpts: On to the ramen, I got the tori paitan
and I thought the flavors were great!
I enjoyed it.
The noodles were also pretty unique and actually really good.
BUT... What is wrong with the texture of their broth?
It was... grainy.
I'm not sure why it wasn't smooth or creamy.
Also, i've seen multiple images where the broth is supposed to be white.
The one I got was more brown.
So I'm not sure if there are inconsistency or what.
Another downfall is...
THEY DON'T HAVE EGGS!
At all.
I can't even pay extra for it.
tori paitan.author: Yen P.
tori paitan.review:
I think I've talked about going to this place for like 3 whole months. There were a lot of hype around it. Always a line- they said. Luckily I came on a rainy day so the line was pretty short, about 15 minutes. Not too bad. Actually, if I had waited longer I would have probably given this place a lower rating. 

First off. I really don't like their seating arrangement. I understand that it's a european style seating where everyone just sit together at one long table but it's just wayyyyyyy tooo crowded! OMG. I couldn't even have a conversation with the person sitting across from me because I kept getting distracted by all the conversations next to me. There are no privacy here at all. I mean, I don't mind the long table. But I'd appreciate it if they had space the seats out a bit more so I'm not touching the strangers next to me. I tried to finish my ramen as fast as I could so I could just get out of there. Don't go here on a date lol. 

On to the ramen, I got the tori paitan and I thought the flavors were great! I enjoyed it. The noodles were also pretty unique and actually really good. BUT... What is wrong with the texture of their broth? It was... grainy. I'm not sure why it wasn't smooth or creamy. Also, i've seen multiple images where the broth is supposed to be white. The one I got was more brown. So I'm not sure if there are inconsistency or what. Another downfall is... THEY DON'T HAVE EGGS! At all. I can't even pay extra for it. Wtf. 

Maybe I'll come back to try their other ramen. And request a seat at the bar. But I'm not sure if I'd wait an hour for this. The only reason why they have a wait is because the restaurant can only seat about 24 people. So are you really waiting for the ramen? Or are you waiting for the seat? questionable

excerpts: Got the Tori Paitan Double Chashu (pork and duck chashu) with a miso egg and the portion was huge!!
The broth was so creamy and everything melted in my mouth.
They had a special ramen that was matcha flavored and as much as I love matcha that seemed too wild
so I stuck with the creamy broth.
The wait was about 20 minutes on a Wednesday night, not too bad!!
The interior is very cozy and warm, my friends and I thoroughly enjoyed our meals and left feeling very satisfied.
A bit pricey but very well worth
and I highly recommend getting double chashu!!
tori paitan.author: Isabelle N.
tori paitan.review: Got the Tori Paitan Double Chashu (pork and duck chashu) with a miso egg and the portion was huge!! The broth was so creamy and everything melted in my mouth. They had a special ramen that was matcha flavored and as much as I love matcha that seemed too wild so I stuck with the creamy broth. The wait was about 20 minutes on a Wednesday night, not too bad!! The interior is very cozy and warm, my friends and I thoroughly enjoyed our meals and left feeling very satisfied. A bit pricey but very well worth and I highly recommend getting double chashu!!

excerpts: We got the Tori Paitan  (where everyone should get on their first try) and
Clam Butter Ramen.
Both was super good and amazingggg balls.
The Tori Paitan has a creamy broth and I finished everything except the soup because it was kind of thick to drink it all.
I tried the Clan Butter Ramen and the seafood taste was strong in broth.
It is all natural and they handmade their noodles.
tori paitan.author: Judy M.
tori paitan.review:
THE BEST RAMEN EVAR!! OR the most exquisite taste I ever experienced...so far. 

The only worst part is the wait. The over-hyped ramen place have a long line where we waited for 1 hour and 20 minutes. And it was freezing at the time, so I would say come early if you want to experience extraordinary taste for those ramen lovers. 

The wait for ordering and receiving the ramen was super quick. We got the Tori Paitan  (where everyone should get on their first try) and  Clam Butter Ramen. Both was super good and amazingggg balls. The Tori Paitan has a creamy broth and I finished everything except the soup because it was kind of thick to drink it all. I tried the Clan Butter Ramen and the seafood taste was strong in broth. It is all natural and they handmade their noodles. We got seated in-front of the kitchen, so we get to see how the kitchen staff operates. 

I would come again to bring my sisters because they offer a vegan option :)

excerpts: I ordered the Tori Paitan with double pork.
The Tori Paitan is a rich and creamy chicken based soup with pork and duck and kale.
I did not add anything to it.
Others around ordered lamb and vegan based soups.
tori paitan.author: Kambiz K.
tori paitan.review:
I am not sure what makes this place so well reviewed. Let me paint you the picture of my experience. 

We got there early on Saturday night, right before they opened. We were about the 4th to be seated. I saw the line build up, the hostess surveyed the line asking how many were in each party. I observed the pre-opening ritual the staff partook in. The excitement was on the tip of my tongue. 

We were seated with Japanese efficiency, they packed us like tuna at the Tokyo fish market. We were cramped, it was a cozy however because it was a cold, damp rainy November evening. It was so cozy and upclose an personal that I got a very thick wiff of my neighboring patron's BO. I wish they would space us out a bit more. I would have appreciated not having his odor in my upper respiratory system throughout the meal. 

I ordered the Tori Paitan with double pork. The Tori Paitan is a rich and creamy chicken based soup with pork and duck and kale. I did not add anything to it. Others around ordered lamb and vegan based soups. The orders came out with surgical efficiency. 

We eat with our eyes and my food was not appetizing when it came. It was grey, dull, without bright colors. The bowl was not large, it was not warm. It was very unappealing. 

I dug in, a bit apprehensive but still eager. My first impressions was like I was eating cardboard drenched in fat. It was rich, it was heavy. But it had no flavor. It was more texture than substance.  The noodles were about the only thing they did well. The noodles were cooked perfectly al dente, thick, wavy and filling. I just wish the broth had a but more flavor. I added pepper, without avail. It just couldn't be recovered. I left disappointed with a unsatisfied tongue and empty stomach and an even emptier pocket. 

Bottom line is the place is cramped, very intimate you barely have any room, the service is surgical and efficient. The Tori Paitain, soup is different, bland and fatty, lacking in bold flavors but with great noodles. Not sure if I would ever go back again, there are certainly better options.

excerpts: We each got a Tori Paitan.
tori paitan.author: Debbie C.
tori paitan.review:
Three of us came tonight. We each got a Tori Paitan.

They weren't kidding when they said "rich and creamy." The whole time I was eating, I kept thinking of "Thanksgiving." The broth was more like gravy than broth.

Overall, I'd give the ramen 3 stars. If I was in the area, craving for something rich and creamy, and there wasn't a line, I'd probably go in and have a bowl....probably.

I had to knock off a star due to the lumps of ramen found in our bowls.

If I'm paying over $20 for a bowl of ramen, someone better be making sure my ramen stays as separate strands when they're cooking it.

If I come again, I'll give their other broths a try...maybe.

excerpts: I had the tori paitan ramen with duck.
They weren't kidding when they called it rich and creamy.
My stomach was half full and I was going to burst from the ramen.
The bowl isn't that big but the broth is so rich and delicious.
I was most impressed by the duck.
Even by fancy French restaurant standards this is very well done.
The duck is so intense in flavor and tender to chew it's almost like ham.
tori paitan.author: Michael H.
tori paitan.review:
This might be my favorite ramen in SF. I had just eaten a fairly big meal but I was literally walking past Mensho when I remembered this place had huge lines. It was only 20 minutes away from opening so I decided to stick it out. One of the employees kindly gave me a stool to sit on as I waited. Soon thereafter a healthy line started to form. Once the doors opened there was already a wait list.

The interior is not so big. It seats about 30-40, most of which are bar stool seating. There's not much to look at since it's so small. There are banners and sayings, along with these glass coffee makers.

Since I was first I had received regular chair and a view of the kitchen. The menu is unsurprisingly narrow to ramen, non-ramen, and beverages. I'd say they have a good variety of ramen to choose from, even vegetarian. I had the tori paitan ramen with duck. They weren't kidding when they called it rich and creamy. My stomach was half full and I was going to burst from the ramen. The bowl isn't that big but the broth is so rich and delicious. I was most impressed by the duck. Even by fancy French restaurant standards this is very well done. The duck is so intense in flavor and tender to chew it's almost like ham.
____

I'd only wait 30 minutes max, but it's worth it. Go on an empty stomach and fill that tank up. Get the duck!

excerpts: I ordered the tori paitan to see what everyone was raving about.
The duck was SO tender, the noodles were thick and chewy, and broth was extremely flavorful.
However, while I loved the taste of the broth, it was a bit too thick and for me.
I personally enjoy slurping soup but the froth of it made the soup less enjoyable, even though the concept was novel.
I also wasn't a fan of the powder-y texture of it...
I like my soup to go down smoothly
tori paitan.author: Catherine C.
tori paitan.review:
Came here expecting a great bowl of ramen and got a great bowl ramen, but it wasn't 100% for me. 

I ordered the tori paitan to see what everyone was raving about. The duck was SO tender, the noodles were thick and chewy, and broth was extremely flavorful. However, while I loved the taste of the broth, it was a bit too thick and for me. I personally enjoy slurping soup but the froth of it made the soup less enjoyable, even though the concept was novel. I also wasn't a fan of the powder-y texture of it... I like my soup to go down smoothly ya know?

I really appreciate that the ramen was really filling and didn't leave my mouth super dry at the end, despite being really flavorful. I can see why many people enjoy this place, but if I ever go back, I'll probably go for a lighter broth instead!

excerpts: I ordered the Spicy Tori Paitan with an order of egg while my bf got the spicy lamb ramen.
First off before I go rambling about my ramen, the spicy lamb broth was a little salty for me.
Okay, so the first sip of soup I took was life changing.
The broths was perfectly delicious and the both of us would have to agree.
This place is prefect for those whole appreciates a thick broth.
After few bites in, the broth got too overwhelming for me
and I realized that I did not enjoy it as much as my first bite (which is worth every penny).
I would say that the noodle grabs onto the soup really well and the soft boiled egg was prefect with the runny yolk.
The chashu had the perfect meat to fat ratio; the piece of meat literally melted in my mouth.
No chewing was needed!
The Spicy Tori Paitan ramen that I got was $17 and the spicy lamb was $16.
The portion size was like any other ramen shop but it is super filling because of the broth.
tori paitan.author: Helen H.
tori paitan.review:
This got to be the CREAMIEST and THICKEST ramen broth I have ever tried! It's rich in flavor and I've never tried anything like it before. After some shopping at Westfield mall, I was craving some ramen and happen to stumble across this place on Yelp and decided to give this place a try. The ramen did not disappoint but the wait was pretty bad. We waited for over an hour before we got seated.

Environment: 5/5 I really like clean and simple decor. Although there wasn't a lot of decoration, I've noticed some coffee brewers along the glass that allows you to see the kitchen. The first thing I noticed when I walked in were coat hangers but no one seems to be using them. The restaurant is very small with bar top tables and not much space to put your belongings (carry shopping bags was a bad idea). There isn't a lot of room for seating, everyone seems to be squished. I was glad that I got seated in one of the regular chairs and I got the view the kitchen.

Food: 4.5/5 DELICIOUS! Like many people probably said already, the broth here is super rich and creamy. I ordered the Spicy Tori Paitan with an order of egg while my bf got the spicy lamb ramen. First off before I go rambling about my ramen, the spicy lamb broth was a little salty for me. Okay, so the first sip of soup I took was life changing. The broths was perfectly delicious and the both of us would have to agree. This place is prefect for those whole appreciates a thick broth. After few bites in, the broth got too overwhelming for me and I realized that I did not enjoy it as much as my first bite (which is worth every penny). I would say that the noodle grabs onto the soup really well and the soft boiled egg was prefect with the runny yolk. The chashu had the perfect meat to fat ratio; the piece of meat literally melted in my mouth. No chewing was needed! The overall texture of the ramen was great because of the complexity of the toppings that accompanies the noodle.  

Price: 4/5 It is quite pricey for a bowl of ramen here. The Spicy Tori Paitan ramen that I got was $17 and the spicy lamb was $16. The portion size was like any other ramen shop but it is super filling because of the broth. I would say that it is worth every penny of your money because the ramen is just that good. 

Customer Service: 2.5/5 I feel like I didn't really receive much customer service while I was her. The waitresses all seem super busy to even notice us. Our server just brought over some water, took our order, and brought out the ramen. I don't like how there is an 18% automatic charge for service fee when I feel like the service wasn't that great. 

Overall, you must come and try at least once. It will be life changing, I promise! Although the price is a little high for ramen and the wait is terrible, I think it's worth a try. I probably won't be coming here again unless it's for a special occasion or something. The wait time is just too long for me. They didn't really have chairs for people to rest on so we literally had to stand outside the store the entire wait time. Since they don't take reservations, some people have waited more than 2 hours to try this place.

excerpts: I got the Tori Paitan ramen, with an egg (for some reason the egg is not included.)
So rich and tasty!
tori paitan.author: Marta F.
tori paitan.review:
This place is so good! They don't take reservations and you may have to wait to get seated, but it's worth it. I got the Tori Paitan ramen, with an egg (for some reason the egg is not included.) So rich and tasty! I don't remember having eaten so good ramen outside of Japan! 

This is gonna be my go-to place for ramen.

excerpts: 4 out of 5 of us ordered the Tori Paitan with double Chashu (boys gotta eat!)

I waited an extra 10-15 minutes for my ramen while everyone else at my table got their Tori Paitan a little while after ordering and even had to ask the waitress to check on my food (politely of course).
I was incredibly surprised when my ramen came and it was really watery broth~
I should've checked Yelp pictures before ordering because I definitely wanted a creamier thick broth...
so let's just say you definitely get what you pay for.
I ended up eating 1/4 of my boyfriend's Tori Paitan and mixing it with my garlic ramen (which tasted really good!)
I think Mensho should expand and add more garlic into their creamy rich chicken broth - which by the way, is kind of unique because ramen usually has pork broth.
One of my friends complained that the broth was too creamy and oily..
but he's going through a health phase.
If you want to be that healthy, just stay in and eat food that you cook yourself ;)
The ingredients were fresh and delicious but the prices are really unnecessarily steep.

Maybe this is just San Francisco and the way it is but after tax/tip you're definitely paying $20+ if you order their staple ramen dish which is a lot more than other places like Ramen Parlor in San Mateo.
tori paitan.author: Leslie T.
tori paitan.review:
Heard a lot about this place before visiting and waited 2 hours to get in (as many people have mentioned, very small space and limited seating). I was pretty hangry by the time we got seated (table of 5) so we ordered the oyster appetizer. 3 oysters for $5 and they were pretty overly salted and oily (very strong shoyu taste). I could feel my blood pressure go up.

4 out of 5 of us ordered the Tori Paitan with double Chashu (boys gotta eat!) and then I ordered the Shio Ramen with egg because I looove garlic. I waited an extra 10-15 minutes for my ramen while everyone else at my table got their Tori Paitan a little while after ordering and even had to ask the waitress to check on my food (politely of course). I was incredibly surprised when my ramen came and it was really watery broth~ I should've checked Yelp pictures before ordering because I definitely wanted a creamier thick broth... so let's just say you definitely get what you pay for. I ended up eating 1/4 of my boyfriend's Tori Paitan and mixing it with my garlic ramen (which tasted really good!) I think Mensho should expand and add more garlic into their creamy rich chicken broth - which by the way, is kind of unique because ramen usually has pork broth. One of my friends complained that the broth was too creamy and oily.. but he's going through a health phase. If you want to be that healthy, just stay in and eat food that you cook yourself ;) The ingredients were fresh and delicious but the prices are really unnecessarily steep. Maybe this is just San Francisco and the way it is but after tax/tip you're definitely paying $20+ if you order their staple ramen dish which is a lot more than other places like Ramen Parlor in San Mateo.

excerpts:
We ordered the following:

Tori Paitan Classic- get this if it's your first time.
Matcha Tori Paitan - basically the Classic version plus green tea powder on top.
You get a hint of green tea as a result -
not overly so.
It simple paled in comparison to the Tori Paitan Classic.
tori paitan.author: Judy H.
tori paitan.review:
After arriving at 5:15pm on a Saturday night, our group of 4 waited for 1 hr 20 min before being seated.  The space is super tight, but fortunately they have bamboo baskets beneath each table for bags (as many restaurants in Japan) 

We ordered the following:

Tori Paitan Classic- get this if it's your first time. The broth is super rich (you almost feel like you could start biting into it!) and flavorful.  The noodle was perfectly al dente.

Matcha Tori Paitan - basically the Classic version plus green tea powder on top.  You get a hint of green tea as a result - not overly so.  I do wonder if this might taste better if they used some kind of green tea noodle instead.   

clam ramen - this was probably our least favorite one.  It turned out to be some kind of seafood combo.  It wasn't bad.  It simple paled in comparison to the Tori Paitan Classic.

soy-marinated oysters - served cold.  I think I had expected a warm dish.  As a result, I was somewhat disappointed and thought this was just OK. 

This place deserves the hype.  However, I am not sure I would return again unless the wait is less than half an hour. If I do return, I would love to try the vegan tantanmen!

excerpts: I ordered Spicy Tori Paitan, the first thing that surprised me is the quality of the noodles, noodles at this place are disparate, they are thick and hard.
The meat is super good, which melts in the mouth.
Yet broth is super thick which fulfilled me super fast.
I would definitely come back to try a different ramen on the menu.
tori paitan.author: Julie T.
tori paitan.review: Me and my friend made a last minute plan to visit this Michelin ramen place. We arrive around 6PM, good thing the line wasn't too long. However we still have to wait around 1 hr. I ordered Spicy Tori Paitan, the first thing that surprised me is the quality of the noodles, noodles at this place are disparate, they are thick and hard. The meat is super good, which melts in the mouth. Yet broth is super thick which fulfilled me super fast. I would definitely come back to try a different ramen on the menu.

excerpts: I tried the $16 Tori Paitan.
Very creamy and rich broth.
tori paitan.author: Jennifer W.
tori paitan.review:
Mensho is incredibly good and NOT over-hyped! It is worth the wait. The wait is actually not bad at all if you show up, say, before 4:45. Then you're probably only waiting 15 minutes tops. They open at 5PM and you'd get in on the first seating. I got there a little after 4:50 and waited only(!) 45 minutes. I noticed that people tend to be eating pretty fast and leaving. Probably because the bright lights in there and tight spaces are not conducive to loitering around. The service is fast and friendly. They're efficient. 

The ramen is the best I've ever had. I tried the $16 Tori Paitan. Very creamy and rich broth. I also tried some of the Shoyu broth; the best Shoyu broth I've ever had. 

Definitely worth the wait, and I'd go back. Can't wait to try the Shio flavored broth!

excerpts: We got the tori paitan with double cha shu , matcha tori paitan, and spicy lamb ramen.
The OG tori paitan has a very rich broth.
The matcha one tasted pretty healthy and earthy since there was a bunch of matcha powder in it.
My favorite is definitely the spicy lamb ramen.
If you like a rich and bold broth with a kick of spice and a ton of onions, this one is definitely for you !!
Although, don't expect to see a fatty piece of lamb meat.
There are only little broken pieces hidden in the broth, so it's really like digging for treasure.
But you can definitely taste/smell the lamb in the broth.
This was my first ramen place in SF and it definitely hit the spot and set the bars high!
tori paitan.author: Chi L.
tori paitan.review: On a cold, windy night in SF - ramen is definitely an excellent choice for dinner!y party of 3 people waited about an hour outside before being seated. The restaurant itself is pretty small, so one hour wait isn't too bad. We sat at the little bar and it was quite cramped, just like the little ramen shops in Japan. We got the tori paitan with double cha shu , matcha tori paitan, and spicy lamb ramen. The OG tori paitan has a very rich broth. The matcha one tasted pretty healthy and earthy since there was a bunch of matcha powder in it. My favorite is definitely the spicy lamb ramen. If you like a rich and bold broth with a kick of spice and a ton of onions, this one is definitely for you !! Although, don't expect to see a fatty piece of lamb meat. There are only little broken pieces hidden in the broth, so it's really like digging for treasure. But you can definitely taste/smell the lamb in the broth. This was my first ramen place in SF and it definitely hit the spot and set the bars high!

excerpts: I got myself the Tori Paitan Ramen with Double Chashu ($18), which was a creamy broth.
The broth is so rich and flavorful, which I really enjoyed.
Alongside, the chashu meat just slid off with every bite and truly cooked through.
I wasn't all too fond of the condiments as I usually would prefer some chili flakes in my ramen.
Overall, pretty good bowl of ramen but definitely pricey.
I tried some of my friend's new Spicy Lamb Ramen, which was filled with flavor in the broth as well.
If thick broth is your thing, this spot is it.
In addition, we ordered the Oysters in Shoyu Oil ($5) for three piece.
The oysters were so delicious and absolutely worth a try.
tori paitan.author: Cindy Z.
tori paitan.review:
My friend was in line by 4:30 before their opening and got us a table for four. Luckily, they gave us a table even though the other three of us didn't show up yet, but we knew what to order already.

I got myself the Tori Paitan Ramen with Double Chashu ($18), which was a creamy broth. The broth is so rich and flavorful, which I really enjoyed. Alongside, the chashu meat just slid off with every bite and truly cooked through. I wasn't all too fond of the condiments as I usually would prefer some chili flakes in my ramen. Overall, pretty good bowl of ramen but definitely pricey. I tried some of my friend's new Spicy Lamb Ramen, which was filled with flavor in the broth as well. If thick broth is your thing, this spot is it. In addition, we ordered the Oysters in Shoyu Oil ($5) for three piece. The oysters were so delicious and absolutely worth a try. It was a new way of eating oysters for me off the shell and soaked in soy. 

The place is tiny and it's mainly communal tables. They do offer baskets under your tables to store your purse and such, so that was nice. It's definitely a crowded space, so expect to be in and out as they try to get the next customer in.

excerpts: Tori Paitan (single chasu) $16: super creamy chicken and pork broth and really thick and chewy noodles with a pinch of cabbage and 2 duck chasus, No egg
The broth was perfectly flavored and a little on the creamier side but not too oily or salty.
Spicy Lamb $16:
This was SO SALTY.
It tasted like they dunk 10 packs of spicy msg ramen packs in the broth.
There were bits of ground lamb and bean sprouts mixed in.
No Tonkatsu (although I think Tori Paitan is closest to it but a bit more heavy).
They advertise for Tsukemen (dipping) Ramen on their walls, but don't actually have it on their menu which is a little misleading.
tori paitan.author: Samantha F.
tori paitan.review:
Came here on a Thurs night around 530pm and there was a line forming already. Thank god, my friend got there earlier than me around 5ish and got a seat 5mins later. 

RAMEN:
We ordered: 
1) Tori Paitan (single chasu) $16: super creamy chicken and pork broth and really thick and chewy noodles with a pinch of cabbage and 2 duck chasus, No egg :( The broth was perfectly flavored and a little on the creamier side but not too oily or salty. 
2) Spicy Lamb $16: This was SO SALTY. It tasted like they dunk 10 packs of spicy msg ramen packs in the broth. There were bits of ground lamb and bean sprouts mixed in. I felt like the overly saltiness of the broth toke away the enjoyment of the ramen overall. 

Others:
They also have small appetizers and other types of ramen including: no broth ramen, shio and shoyu and a vegan ramen! No Tonkatsu (although I think Tori Paitan is closest to it but a bit more heavy). They advertise for Tsukemen (dipping) Ramen on their walls, but don't actually have it on their menu which is a little misleading. And for $16/bowl with no boiled egg was a little disappointing.

AMBIANCE:
Super small and packed interior. There are basically 3 long tables so be prepared to sit side-by-side with strangers. Cute decor though! 

SERVICE: 
Very fast and attentive! 

VERDICT:
For flavors and thick chewy noodles I give them a 5! However, for the lack of meat, boiled egg and overly salty lamb broth it drops to a 3. I can get the same ramen quality in Little Tokyo with more meat for less. Would I wait in line if it would have been longer? No.

excerpts: I ordered the tori paitan because it's what everyone's been raving about.
It was unlike any bowl of ramen I've ever eaten before.
The broth was thick and creamy, not to mention chicken based.
The pork chasu was the most tender I've ever had in ramen, and I loved the flavorful addition of duck.
My intolerant thoughts aside, the tori paitan was nonetheless a delicious bowl of soup that I would order again if I have a specific hankering for it.
tori paitan.author: Stephanie Joyce D.
tori paitan.review:
Literally what happens: "I'm craving ramen... Hm, maybe I'll pass by Mensho Tokyo... Nooope, ridiculously long line... Maybe next time." Repeat. Repeat. Repeat.

Finally I decided that on a Wednesday I was going to get there early to line up before they opened. Safest bet and smart move because my group of 3 waited no longer than 20 min after opening to get seated.

I ordered the tori paitan because it's what everyone's been raving about. It was unlike any bowl of ramen I've ever eaten before. The broth was thick and creamy, not to mention chicken based. The pork chasu was the most tender I've ever had in ramen, and I loved the flavorful addition of duck. The noodles were also handmade, unlike most ramen shops, which truly added to the uniqueness of the dish.

My problem? I've just been so used to ordering my ramen a specific way that it didn't entirely satisfy my ramen craving. I'm almost embarrassed to say this but my usual basic bitch order is spicy tonkatsu w/ soft-boiled EGG. OMG it was driving me crazy that I could not have the pornographic satisfaction of yolky egg in my ramen. I was also desperate for some heat, and was disappointed that none of the condiments on the table were spicy :( My friend ordered the organic shoyu, which I sort of wished I ordered instead because even without the spiciness or egg, it just looked more familiar as a soy-based broth. My intolerant thoughts aside, the tori paitan was nonetheless a delicious bowl of soup that I would order again if I have a specific hankering for it.

excerpts: Tori Paitan ramen I had was so rich and creamy yet
it wasn't overwhelming.
Went well with tori Paitan broth.
tori paitan.author: Yuko H.
tori paitan.review:
One of the best ramen I had in North America. I haven't tried every places but since I really like ramen, I try as often as possible when traveling.

Tori Paitan ramen I had was so rich and creamy yet it wasn't overwhelming. Sometimes chicken base broth could be overwhelming but this felt light while maintaining rich and creamy texture.

I got lucky when I came. Arrived here on Thursday at 5:50pm, I only saw five people waiting outside. Since they were all together, she took me in before then. I was seated with almost no wait at all!  When I left after a nice bowl of ramen, I saw a very long queue (looked like about an hour wait). Must have came in such a perfect timing!

Service was good, just what you expect from any ramen shop in Japan. Fast and efficient.

Noodles were also prepared to perfection. Went well with tori Paitan broth.

They have vegan ramen as well as shio, tonkotsu and organic soy. I was really tempted to come back the next day as I enjoyed it so much. 

Next day I told several of my local contacts and they all knew about this place but unable to try yet due to long wait.  I was so glad I got to try here during my short visit to SF!

excerpts: If you want the round noodles, go for the Tori Paitan!
The people sitting to my right had the Tori Paitan, Maze Soba (which looked amazing) and also had the Oyster dish.
All the dishes looked gorgeous and were served within minutes after taking our orders.
If you want very good ramen in San Francisco, you should give this place a try!
:D
tori paitan.author: Joey R.
tori paitan.review:
From the reviews, the recommendation was to go as early as possible! So, we were there by 430PM and were one of the first in line. NOICE!

Mensho Tokyo is a tiny place with a cozy feel. Once the door opens, they sit you and your group in a very organized system. All of the dining tables are communal and you'll often find yourself next to a new face or two. When you are seated, know what you want because they will take your order right away! We all ordered the same ramen: Shio Ramen! Note: the Shio ramen has the flat noodles. If you want the round noodles, go for the Tori Paitan!

The broth was clear but had depth and was very flavorful. The noodles were cooked really well and had a nice chewy texture. We didn't speak much throughout the entire meal. The people sitting to my right had the Tori Paitan, Maze Soba (which looked amazing) and also had the Oyster dish. All the dishes looked gorgeous and were served within minutes after taking our orders. If you want very good ramen in San Francisco, you should give this place a try! :D

excerpts: I got the Tori Paitan double chashu.
It is amazing from the specific noodle chosen for the thick broth to the sides in the bowl that compliments it.
And my boyfriend likes shoyu
so he got
tori paitan.author: Cindy H.
tori paitan.review:
If ramen in Japan taste like this I cannot wait for my trip. Every ramen bowl should taste this good and nothing less. It's so simple and yet delicate. The broth is so delicious it makes you come back for more. Literally I had to pay 2 bridge tolls to eat this again! I got the Tori Paitan double chashu. It is amazing from the specific noodle chosen for the thick broth to the sides in the bowl that compliments it. And my boyfriend likes shoyu so he got the organic shoyu double chashu and he loves it. I got a taste of it and it's phenomenal. Thin noodles changed my life. I know I sound over exaggerating it's just ramen is my favorite dish, food, choice to eat! So I really appreciate Tomoharu Shono for letting us experience your food from home to us here, arigato!

P.S- the line looks intimidating but so worth it, the longest I waited was about an hour and we went for dinner at 7pm. So do always expect a line since they only open for dinner and it's a small shop but again WORTH

excerpts: but I'm so obsessed with the tori paitan!
My favorite is the Tori Paitan (with extra chasu!)
but all of my vegetarian and vegan friends also love the vegan ramen!
The tori paitan is a bit heavy and a thick
so I would get another ramen if you want something lighter!
tori paitan.author: Tram N.
tori paitan.review:
There's one thing I hate the most in life and that's me waiting in line for my food because I get super hangry but I will make an exception for Mensho.

Possibly one of the best ramen places in the city (despite the ridiculous long line every time I'm there) but I'm so obsessed with the tori paitan! 

The line can vary from 30 mins to an hour + depending on the day of the week and the dinner time. I think the best time to go is right when it opens because you'll be the first wave of people in. Even if you miss the first wave, the second wave will be about 20 minute. The shortest wait I've experienced was about 20 minutes (woo!) and the longest was about an hour and a half. I think everyone dining at Mensho is pretty good with their time but I remember one time when this group of girls was just chatting their lives away for 30 minutes after they finished their ramen. I don't want to sound rude but please do everyone a favor and not talk about your life problems at Mensho.

My favorite is the Tori Paitan (with extra chasu!) but all of my vegetarian and vegan friends also love the vegan ramen! The tori paitan is a bit heavy and a thick so I would get another ramen if you want something lighter!

excerpts: We ordered the following: special of the night lobster ramen, the tori paitan double chashu ramen, vegan ramen, enoki mushroom chips, and oysters in shoyu dare oil.
tori paitan.author: K S.
tori paitan.review:
Worth. The. Wait. Walked up to the restaurant at opening. There was already a line of 25 people. The place only sits about 20 or so. Brace yourself (and maybe bring a warm jacket.) The wait will be long. On the upside, there is a liquor store across the street. I recommend bagging a cold one and sipping in line. (Do what you gotta do for ramen.) 

After one hour and forty minutes, we got in! We ordered the following: special of the night lobster ramen, the tori paitan double chashu ramen, vegan ramen, enoki mushroom chips, and oysters in shoyu dare oil. 

Bomb. Bomb. And more bomb. I would highly recommend ordering the special of the night. Even my devout vegan friend wanted to break the rules and eat the lobster ramen.

You might want to take some to go. But, don't forget your tupperware! (But seriously, bring your tupperware because they do not offer to-go containers. BYOT, baby.)

In the name of all his holy noodleness... Ramen!

excerpts: 4) Must get the TORI PAITAN.
Rich, creamy and flavorful.
tori paitan.author: Owie N.
tori paitan.review:
A few weeks ago I came here with my Bestest for dinner and I love it! I already want to come back to try their other noodles such as their soba! UMM YUM!!!

Some tips to know before coming here:

1) Come EARLY because there's a line...like everything else nowadays in SF...
2) Communal dining with high top tables and no back bar stool.
3) Ask to sit facing the kitchen because it's a better view AND you get a normal chair to lean against. 
4) Must get the TORI PAITAN. Rich, creamy and flavorful.
5) Must try the Organic Shoyu. Great broth texture. 

For about $16 for a bowl of ramen, my happy belly was satisfied. I hope you give this ramen place a try. Cheers!

excerpts: No it's their famous TORI PAITAN!
First of all, I hate thick broths with a passion, but this was so flavorful and creamy.
I don't know if its the Katsuobushi sauce or the Burdock, but this is a stand out ramen and maybe one of the best!
The noodles were a pleasant surprise and the broth was honestly more flavorful (for my taste) than the tori paitan.
tori paitan.author: Eric Joseph D.
tori paitan.review:
Every time I have tried to go here, the line has been way too long. Yesterday was my 5th attempt and I seriously was contemplating on selling my frikkin body or paint someones nails to cut the line... but luckily (at 6 o clock), my party of 3 was seated immediately. So I guess the hype has died down a little bit. 

Small space with communal seating (Seats only 24 so wouldn't suggest going in a big group) and modern decor. The menu has expanded since its opening so there is a mix of dishes to choose from. I was starving so I got a cup of sake ($10 and overflowed into a box lol) and 2 bowls of ramen ($16 each) for MYSELF:

-Tori Paitan: OMG is that Tori Spelling.. No it's their famous TORI PAITAN! First of all, I hate thick broths with a passion, but this was so flavorful and creamy. I don't know if its the Katsuobushi sauce or the Burdock, but this is a stand out ramen and maybe one of the best! Pair it with their tender chashu, and homaigahd, your mouth is tasting heaven right hurrr. 

-Organic Shoyu: Clear Translucent broth and the noodles kind of reminded me of pad thai noodles. The noodles were a pleasant surprise and the broth was honestly more flavorful (for my taste) than the tori paitan. I preferred the umami taste in this and the overall combination of flavors. 

Overall, Mensho Tokyo is hands down one of the best RAMEN spots in California. Again, everything is up to every person's taste, but this was seriously good and they do have a variety of ramen for every type of palette. The wait can be longer around 7 ish I hear, but it is worth the wait if you really want to try it!

excerpts: We had 2 bottles of sake (among a group of 6) and 3 shio and 3 tori paitan all with extra chashu.
I wished we had ordered a shoyu ramen to try but maybe next time.
The broth of the tori paitan was rich and heavy but not too heavy.
It was delicious and I definitely would recommend this.
The noodles were cooked perfectly.
The shio ramen's broth was good
but I preferred the noodles used in the tori paitan ramen.
The shio noodles reminded me too much of korean kalguksu noodles rather than ramen noodles.
tori paitan.author: Linda H.
tori paitan.review:
We had ramen a few streets down on our first day in SF and was totally disappointed but this place is definitely worth the wait!

We were in line before they opened. They open at 5pm. We stood in line around 4:45pm and was seated around 6pm. There was a gentleman who came out and calculated the number of people in each party so he knew how to seat everyone. This made everything move faster. People who had a party of 2 were seated prior to us but since we had 6 our wait was a bit longer (but not too long). He even took our order before we were seated so the wait once we sat was not that long. 

We had 2 bottles of sake (among a group of 6) and 3 shio and 3 tori paitan all with extra chashu. I wished we had ordered a shoyu ramen to try but maybe next time. The broth of the tori paitan was rich and heavy but not too heavy. It was delicious and I definitely would recommend this. The noodles were cooked perfectly. The shio ramen's broth was good but I preferred the noodles used in the tori paitan ramen. The shio noodles reminded me too much of korean kalguksu noodles rather than ramen noodles. 

Other than that everything was great. Including the service.

excerpts: and we both had the Tori Paitan Ramen (Double Chasu) and Oysters in Dare Oil, the only appetizer they served.
The oysters had a subtle smoky and soy sauce flavor that was quite delightful, but may be an acquired taste for some.
tori paitan.author: John G.
tori paitan.review:
In Japan, it is polite to slurp your noodles. 

Sometimes I would walk to my wife's work all the way to Presidio Heights from downtown and take Geary as my main route. One day, I noticed a long line of people waiting outside the Alcazar Theatre and wondered what the hoopla was all about. It suddenly clicked that this was one of the most anticipated opening of a Ramen shop straight from Japan. 

Chef and owner Tomoharu Shono's Mensho Tokyo is one of many restaurants he owns in Japan, and this is the first restaurant opened outside of Japan. I think it's fitting he chose San Francisco as we have been starved of good, authentic Ramen for so long. Most of my "best Ramen experience" so far have been in L.A., Vegas and the Peninsula. 

During the next couple months while walking pass this place, I would often gauge at the line and figured it would eventually die down but that never happened. So this past Sunday, I tried to convince the Wifey to get here early prior to their opening time, but she didn't want to "waste" time waiting in line and instead we got here around 7PM. You gotta have patience and brave the crackheads and crazies if you want some good Ramen and it better be worth it....and it was. 

After about an hour, we finally got seated and we both had the Tori Paitan Ramen (Double Chasu) and Oysters in Dare Oil, the only appetizer they served. The oysters had a subtle smoky and soy sauce flavor that was quite delightful, but may be an acquired taste for some. The Ramen is a creamy mixture of chicken soup with two slices of pork belly, two slices of duck breast, menma (bamboo shoots), burdock, kale and Katsuobushi sauce. 

The broth of the Ramen was thick, rich, creamy that was not too overpowering and it was quite an exquisite flavor bursting of umami. The noodles were thicker and cooked al dente to which I thoroughly enjoyed as it had a good snap to it. Now, had this been in Japan, I would have been slurping the noodles as the technique aerates the noodles and the broth, allowing the flavors to mellow out and fully develop before you chew and swallow. It also cools off your mouthful of noodles just enough to let you enjoy them while the rest of the bowl stays piping hot.

However....I couldn't get myself to do it since we are in a communal table. I was tempted to, but this ain't Japan and I wanted to eat "politely" to the rest of the patrons eating beside me. Regardless, we were enjoying our bowls of Ramen as these were right up there with some of the best we've had so far. 

Side note: I did some researching on the Chef and I am excited to see what bold new flavors he can come up with next. There's a particular lamb-based broth he made in Japan and wonder if he can recreate that here. He also can't make the same exact broths as he would like here due to health codes and regulations. I just hope he finds a way and I will slurp my way back here if he does.

tori paitan.review:
After being at the bar across the street, birthday girl wanted Mensho ramen, so off to Mensho we went. We waited in line, and with a fun group, the line goes decently fast. We went in as groups of two to get seated faster and it just lucked out for us that we got to sit next to each other anyways!

Upon sitting down, we asked the server for recommendations. Both servers working there suggested the Vegan Tantanmen! Shocked but intrigued, I ordered it and added chashu. It was amazing. I tried a bit of the Tori Paitan (their signature dish), but it was too rich for me. I'm glad I got the vegan option!

My favorite, hands down, was the Tori Paitan.

tori paitan.author: Elena N.
tori paitan.review:
I've been wanting to try Mensho for some time, but the line always deterred me. Finally, on Thursday, July 28th, my group of three decided to brave the line around 10:30pm. It honestly didn't take too long. I think about 20 mins.

*Tori Paitan Ramen: Rich and Creamy Chicken Soup, Pork Chashu, Duck Chashu, Menma, Kale, Burdock, Katsuobushi Sauce ($18 double chashu)
*Organic Shoyu Ramen: Clear Organic Chicken and Pork Soup, Shoyu Dare, Pork Chashu, Duck Chashu, Kale, Kale Sprouts,Chives, Menma, Nori ($16 double chashu)
*Shio Ramen: Clear Chicken and Pork Soup, Shio Dare, Pork Chashu, Kale, Menma, Fried Garlic, Chives, Nori ($9)

My favorite, hands down, was the Tori Paitan. The noodles were the right consistency and the broth was rich and flavorful. I wasn't the one who ended up with this bowl, but I was wishing I had ordered it. My Shio ramen was okay. A light flavorful broth. But the noodles were the flat kind and I preferred the thicker noodles from the Tori Paitan better. They had a much better chew. I only tried a spoonful of the broth from the Shoyu Ramen which was fine.

We all know I can't have a meal without alcohol! Two of us got the Sapporo Premium: 355ml/12.0oz ($4.75) and one of us tried the Ozenoyukidoke IPA 12.75: 330ml/11.5oz ($12.75). Pricey for a beer, but a better choice if you like IPAs. I, myself prefer the lighter beers, so the sapporo was perfect for me.

Glad I was finally able to check Mensho Tokyo off my list. Was it worth the 20 min wait? Yes, I would say so. But if I had to wait 1+ hours in the SF cold, I don't know. I'm just happy I'll never have to find out.

excerpts: I also had the Tori Paitan ramen with double chashu.

It was very delicious and for sure unlike any ramen broth I've had before.
I loved the thick springy noodles and the tender chashu.
The pork was excellent but the standout for me was the duck which had a really nice floral flavor.
I have to say I didn't enjoy the menma as they didn't taste like they had enough TLC since they still had that mustiness.
tori paitan.author: Maya S.
tori paitan.review:
We got in line at 4:35pm on a Wednesday with 8 ppl ahead of us.

The staff starting seating customers just after 5pm.

Seating was communal and extra cozy. There are baskets on the floor to place your belongings inside.

Service was courteous and the staff stay on top of everything. Upon getting seated, we placed our order pretty quickly. We wanted to try the Ozenoyukidoke IPA but our waitress said they didn't have it. While waiting for our order, I counted 24 seats in the restaurant. 

I had the oysters in shoyu dare oil and while these weren't quite what I was expecting, I enjoyed them. The oysters were flavorful and firm with a texture similar to liver.

I also had the Tori Paitan ramen with double chashu. I tasted the broth first and immediately picked up on its intense chicken flavor and richness. When I cook chicken thighs in a pan, and that skin is browning and the fat renders, I could smell the same aroma in the Tori Paitan broth. It was very delicious and for sure unlike any ramen broth I've had before. I loved the thick springy noodles and the tender chashu. The pork was excellent but the standout for me was the duck which had a really nice floral flavor. I have to say I didn't enjoy the menma as they didn't taste like they had enough TLC since they still had that mustiness. I did find that as I finished up the broth, it began to feel grainy and my body was feeling that salt so water was much needed.

We were out the door by 5:52pm.

tori paitan.author: Jennifer Z.
tori paitan.review:
Fantastic food, exceptional service!

I had to try the ramen here, despite the rumored hour long wait. As a fellow Yelper suggested, I arrived a little after 5PM to avoid the hour long wait. I got here around 5:30PM and found parking right around the block. When I got in line at around 5:30PM, there were approximately 5-6 groups ahead of us in line. As I studied the restaurant through their window, I realized they only had 3 large tables that seated roughly 6-10 people and a counter in the back facing the kitchen, which seated around 4. The walls had descriptions of the growing popularity of the cuisine and its origin. There were TV screens displaying clips of ramen chefs, ramen eaters and soft music playing in the background. The lamps that hung down from the ceiling was also interesting as the brightness changed throughout the night. 

My friend and I both got the tori paitan and shared the enoki chips. The tori paitan was on top of the menu and a great selection for first timers. With the tori paitan, you can really taste the essence and quality of their signature features. The tori paitan consisted of a rich, creamy and smooth chicken flavored broth with duck cha siu, pork cha siu, kale, menma (bamboo shoots), burdock (herb) and katsuobushi sauce. The combination was super satisfying. The noodles resembled the shape of Maruchan ramen, but the noodles are way better in quality, thickness and consistency. 

The enoki chips were one of a kind because I have never seen it on any other menu in San Francisco. Comes with a side of chili powder and black sesame seeds. The taste reminded me of crispy hash browns. I definitely enjoyed the odd associations that came with ordering the enoki chips, because it also reminded me eating enoki mushrooms during hot pot too. xD

I think Mensho Tokyo absolutely deserves 4-5 stars, but there is always room for improvement. The slight anticipation you get from the wait is always something you can complain about. :P

It came their fresh ramen noodles, 2 pieces of pork (which were quite thin), topped with some veggies, bonito flakes.
The tori paitan broth was quite unfamiliar to me.
Maybe it is just
wasn't my style, because a chicken broth tends to be a lighter base compared to the typical tonkatsu broth you find elsewhere.

tori paitan.author: Jacky C.
tori paitan.review:
For all the hype that is Mensho, it just doesn't hit the mark.  

I ordered their signature Tori paitan ramen with extra chashu, which is a chicken white broth ramen.  It came their fresh ramen noodles, 2 pieces of pork (which were quite thin), topped with some veggies, bonito flakes. Overall, i just found it quite lacking.

The three criteria which I usually judge quality ramen are:

1. Noodles - cooked with a bit of bite to it, similar to al dente
2. The broth - flavorful and compliments the noodles and toppings
3. The soft boil egg - a staple to most ramen, and shows how well the place cooks their food.

Now, to put these criteria to the test.

1. Mensho have some great ramen noodles. It was perfectly cooked and quite delicious 5/5.
2. The tori paitan broth was quite unfamiliar to me. Maybe it is just wasn't my style, because a chicken broth tends to be a lighter base compared to the typical tonkatsu broth you find elsewhere.  But the "light" broth with the heaviness of the creamy base just seemed to be unbalanced and just not as appealing to the palate. This is just my opinion, but seeing as how this is their most popular dish, they must be appealing to others  2/5
3. Soft boil egg.... There was none.  This is the first popular ramen place I have been to which did not serve an egg with their ramen.  This baffled me. Maybe their are trying to appeal to the "vegan" sensibility which makes no sense since ramen usually has an animal based broth.  0/5

For a $18 dollar bowl of ramen ( it was $2 extra for a thin slice of pork), it did not meet my expectation.  The broth was dull and unbalanced, the toppings lacking, and even the noodles couldn't save the dish.  It is quite a shame. Maybe this place is more of a hype since the long lines and small location make it seem like an amazing ramen parlor.

The long lines and mediocre broth just push this place to the wayside, but I guess if you are willing to wait for average food, and have the money to spend, try it out.

tori paitan.author: Jang N.
tori paitan.review:
I've only been here on 3 different occasions and I will make sure I make a visit each and every time I'm in SF.  
The one and only bad thing about this place is that we had to wait about an hour every time we've been here but that's given when you show up for dinner during its peak hours.  The chairs can get a bit uncomfortable but i mean it's a ramen spot, you're not going to be there for that long so... SUCK IT UP!!!  

When people used to tell me "oh their noodles are extra good bc it's handmade noodles", I would just smile but think to myself like "YOU CAN'T TELL IF IT'S HANDMADE NOODLES OR NOT!!!"  Well, I thought that until I had Mensho.  The noodles are nice & thick but very soft AND chewy.  You can tell tell they're handmade noodles!!!  The texture is great but I think the best thing about these noddles is the fact that the broth flavor sticks to the noodles very well, making your bite that much more flavorful.  Most ramen places I go to, I'm that guy eating the noddles with chopsticks AND spoon like I'm eating a bowl of pho, trying to eat the noodles while enjoying the flavor of the broth.  Well, you don't need to do that here.  The broth flavor sticks very well to the nice thick noodles so you can enjoy your bowl how you're supposed to.

What's also amazing about this place is that the broth is not overly salty like other places where you have to drink a gallon of water to keep yourself hydrated from all that salt.  I can't quite put my finger on what it is about the broth but it's very flavorful without being overly salty.

I'm not going to act like this is my regular ramen place I've been eating at for the past 5 years but I highly recommend the Tori Paitan which comes with pork & duck meat!  I am not a big fan of duck meat but TRUST ME!!!  You have to try it!  The lamb ramen was really good also.  Again, I'm not a big fan of lamb but you really have to try it!!!  Shoyu chasu ramen is probably the best I've had in its category.  

PLEASE NOTE:  15% gratuity is already added to your tab.  You will most likely end up sitting at a community table next to strangers but that's part of the experience.

tori paitan.review:
Craving for ramen? More like...YAH...man. Bad joke/pun aside, Mensho Tokyo is anything but cringe worthy. 

The Tori Paitan Ramen ($16) is the chicken soup with pork and duck chashu, menma, kale, burdock, and katsuobushi sauce. My boyfriend and I both ordered the Tori Paitan Ramen with DOUBLE chashu ($18) for extra meat. 

After our first taste, my boyfriend and I both looked at each other with amazed faces. The chicken broth was rich, creamy, and super flavorful -- it made my insides feel warm and fuzzy. My boyfriend usually doesn't care about finishing the soup in ramen, but he finished this one (I did too). The meat was also tender and the noodles were chewy and thick. I'm currently drooling as I reminisce about this magical bowl. 

Service is polite and attentive. Wait time can range from 30 minutes to 2 hours. My boyfriend and I went on a Friday at 6:00 PM and waited in line for about an hour. Not sure if a 2 hour wait is worth it; an hour and a half is cutting it close. I highly recommend you go in small groups (1-3 people). 

The restaurant is also quite tiny and seems to accommodate about 28 to 30 people. There are only three communal tables: one long table and two smaller tables. Be ready to sit next to strangers elbow to elbow.

Despite the wait and tiny space, I will definitely come back!

tori paitan.author: Rohenne L.
tori paitan.review:
Worried about the line? Come early on a weekday! I went on a Wednesday at 6pm and there was no line and quite a few seats available. However, by 7pm when we left, there was a line out the door with ~15 people. Not too bad. 

Highly recommend the Tori Paitan Ramen. The soup is AWESOME, super flavorful but not too salty like a lot of ramen places. The noodles were also the kind I like - chewy and al dente. (So, if you like very soft noodles, this probably isn't the place for you.) 

We also ordered the vegan tantan noodles. Can't believe it was VEGAN! Tasted as if it had meat. If you're not a soup noodle type person, go with the tan tan noodles. 

The Shoyu or Salt flavored ramens are just not as flavorful or umami like the Tori Paitan or the tan tan noodles. So I would recommend sticking to what they're known for!

tori paitan.author: Justin L.
tori paitan.review:
Wait time is about an hour to an hour and a half (pending) There is no reservations so prepare to have some time on your hands.  

Fortunately this is San Francisco and the people outside are nice, and the weather is pretty good.  

I tried 3 different ramen's when I entered.  The lamb / / chicken (Tori Paitan) / / Organic Shoyu

Noodle Firmness:  All similar firmness from what I recall.  Very good noodle texture.  Perfectly al dente.  

Broth:  Lamb broth was way too thick, and I usually like my broth pretty thick.  It was almost like a paste- I do not recommend this one.  Chicken broth had a very strong flavor too it.  I recommend the Tori Paitan for anyone who likes thick broth.  The Organic Shoyu was a good light ramen.  

Price:  It's an expensive ramen ($15-$20) but will definitely fill you up simply because the broth is so thick.  I think it's ok if factor in the price of rent for San Francisco and the demand they're in.  

Overall it was a good experience from start to finish.  I would recommend they allow noodle refills for a lower cost.
