tori paitan.author: Kris W.
tori paitan.review:
Over-hyped. Over-salty. Over it.

There must be something buried deep in our Americanized taste buds that confuses "tasty" with "an abundance of sodium". There must be something that makes us stand in line for hours to drool over the newest, coolest thing, to brag about it to our friends, to blab on Instagram about this beautiful, postable, tasty thing that landed in this tech-infested, brunch-addicted, 5-star-inflated city. Ramen in America has become such a dining experience. Something that was made to be fast, cheap and good has metamorphosed into long waits, double-priced, and salty to the point of unbearable, but somehow still receives raving reviews, even Michelin-recommended. 

"Just over a century ago, two French tire manufacturers created the Michelin guide. According to the author, it has blighted the lives of chefs from Brooklyn to Bombay, while spawning legions of checklist gourmands." -Vanity Fair

We got there at 430pm, 30 minutes before opening, and the line was already 40 people deep. After waiting an hour, we ordered the Tori paitan and spicy lamb ramen. Don't get the Spicy lamb ramen. It's like someone poured a cup of salt in a bowl of meat and noodles and water. no matter how good the pics look.  Maybe that day they spilled a gallon of salt in the pot. The Tori Paitan was okay, but still makes you want to pass out immediately from the heaviness. Maybe I'm just crazy. Or maybe theres a reason why there's so much obesity and diabetes in this country. I really hope the Japan Tokyo Mensho is better. If it's anything like this, Tabelog would not be kind.

excerpts: Most of us ordered the tori paitan, and one of my friends ordered the tantanmen, which she enjoyed.
The broth for the tori paitan was amazing - probably the richest soup I've ever tasted!
tori paitan.author: Delia Z.
tori paitan.review:
So much hype. Such a long wait. And yet... Such amazing food!!

We waited over an hour as a party of 4 for a weeknight dinner; the line was consistently pretty huge. Service is quick, and the place is small, but cute and clean. The tables are communal so you're in pretty close quarters with your neighbors.

Most of us ordered the tori paitan, and one of my friends ordered the tantanmen, which she enjoyed. The broth for the tori paitan was amazing - probably the richest soup I've ever tasted! Noodles were a great consistency; everything about the dish was great overall. 

I would absolutely come back. I just need to brace myself for the always significant wait...

excerpts: Tori Paitan Ramen once
and they were both amazing.
When a bowl ramen has the perfect cooked noodles and flavorful broth, it's hard not to come back for it.
tori paitan.author: Leslie C.
tori paitan.review:
Mensho is by far my favorite ramen spot in San Francisco (my #1 used to be Orenchi in Santa Clara but I haven't been there for years). I've visited Mensho for 3 times and I had great dining experiences each time. The waiting time during weekdays is manageable, I waited 30 mins the most and got seated right after (around 7:30pm). Weekend is tricky, like other popular restaurants, at least an hour if you are lucky.

I got the Ume Shio Ramen twice (was trying to get something else but I really like Ume Shio, plus you can't find this anywhere), Tori Paitan Ramen once and they were both amazing. When a bowl ramen has the perfect cooked noodles and flavorful broth, it's hard not to come back for it. It's a bit pricy, but it's definitely worth it!

2017007

excerpts: Tori Paitan Double Chashu...must get, would order again and again.
The broth was nothing short of excellent.
It was unlike any ramen broth I've ever had considering
I've never had chicken based broth.
Real thick in consistency
but it clinged onto each and every bite of noodles as I almost slurped my face off.
The noodles had the perfect balance of resilience to it.
Not too chewy, not too soft.
Absorbant enough to pick up the broth's flavor.
I loved that.
The egg though...
I was not expecting it to be flavored.
I believe we got the soy sauce flavored egg which was something new and different to me.
Don't get me started with the combination of pork&duck chashu.
I've never had duck in my ramen but now I can't imagine my bowls of ramen without it.
First world problems smh.
The enoki mushroom chips were also a great idea... so light and crisp.
I ended up using these mushroom chips as a garnish to my ramen.
tori paitan.author: David N.
tori paitan.review:
Good things happen to those to wait. A phrase that fits my experience at Mensho Tokyo. I mean the complexity of flavors you are getting from any great ramen broth takes time and love...hours of it. Trust me.. I've seen documentaries on it??..pause. hahahah ¯\_(ツ)_/¯ . Well, try to pay some damn respect to the art! An hour wait for amazing ramen such as mensho is a small price to pay so get to scrolling through your social media feeds or better yet talk to others who are waiting alongside you. You guys are all in line for some the same bowl of ramen so you must share interests. Sheesh. 

Tori Paitan Double Chashu...must get, would order again and again. The broth was nothing short of excellent. It was unlike any ramen broth I've ever had considering I've never had chicken based broth. Real thick in consistency but it clinged onto each and every bite of noodles as I almost slurped my face off.  The noodles had the perfect balance of resilience to it. Not too chewy, not too soft. Absorbant enough to pick up the broth's flavor. I loved that. The egg though...I was not expecting it to be flavored. I believe we got the soy sauce flavored egg which was something new and different to me. Don't get me started with the combination of pork&duck chashu. I've never had duck in my ramen but now I can't imagine my bowls of ramen without it. First world problems smh. The enoki mushroom chips were also a great idea... so light and crisp. I ended up using these mushroom chips as a garnish to my ramen. Next level... 

No complaints about their quick and great service. Gratuity is automatically applied to the your bill though. I wish the shop was larger but I wouldn't complain if my shop had a line out the door on a daily basis. The decor and ambiance is a nice touch. The nerd within me can't hate on the organic compounds related to umami drawn out and explained on the walls. 

I'm coming back to try their tsukemen whenever I get the chance. Leeeeeessss get it.

excerpts: I tried their Tori Paitan Ramen with double ChaShu - after my first bite, I knew I was in for something special for the entire meal.
Broth was loaded with flavor, very thick and creamy
tori paitan.author: Sam K.
tori paitan.review:
Pretty amazing I must say, although the bill didn't look too appealing for two people. Went a little overboard with one of my buds and we spent more than we had anticipated for two bowls of ramen, oysters, beer and sake (woops!). Money well spent at the end of the day (to justify the hole in my wallet).

Was in the mood for ramen and just so happened to be in the area as well... hey... why not give Mensho a shot? Line was not too long and table for two was seated in 45 minutes (it was 10:00 pm on Friday at the time though). This place is also very tiny, so not such a good place to dine at if you're with a party larger than 4 folks.

My bud and I were feeling adventurous so we went ahead and ordered the Oysters in Shoyu Dare Oil and I think our experience would have been better off if we didn't order it (personal preference of ours, it might be amazing to someone else). 

Japanese IPA and Sake made for an awesome double-fist combo as we downed the oysters.

I tried their Tori Paitan Ramen with double ChaShu - after my first bite, I knew I was in for something special for the entire meal. Broth was loaded with flavor, very thick and creamy and it was nothing I have ever tried before... definitely the highlight of Mensho.

Overall lovely experience, it is a shame that this place is so small. I'd love to keep coming back, but the wait is absurdly long during peak hours. You'd have to start lining up for at least 30 minutes before they open in order to dodge the epic-long wait.

excerpts: I had the tori paitan ramen.
Soup was very rich in  flavors.
It's kinda like a soy sauce based soup which is a bit too strong for me.
tori paitan.author: Caitlin P.
tori paitan.review:
This place truly does have good ramen. I had the tori paitan ramen. Soup was very rich in  flavors. It's kinda like a soy sauce based soup which is a bit too strong for me. I prefer the shio ramen more. But the noodles were fantastic! And the chasu meat was so good....very soft and flavorful. Was not impressed with the options for the sides. They did not have corn!! So used to eating my ramen with corn..and no chili flakes either! But I guess those ingredients would taken away the flavors of the broth. 

I also got the oysters in shoyu oil. It's 5 dollars for 4 pieces but they gave us 6 instead! Yes! We definitely came up with that so wooot! This was surpsingly very goood...it was oysters in soy sauce. Never had it that way before but it was amazing. Definitely worth the 5 bucks.

Update:
The vegan broth is so good. Think I'm gonna get vegan broth with a side of chasu next time I'm here. 

Come early if you  wanna eat here. Come an hour before it opens. We came at 4 last sat and to our surprise, some one was already in line when we got there. By the time it was 430, the line was  insanely long already !! Just do yourself a favor and come early. There's only enough seat for like 25 people there so wait can be long.

excerpts: Ever since my visit to Mensho Tokyo, now I just crave Tori Paitan Ramen.
It's so deliciously perfect in every way.
The broth is wonderfully flavorful and creamy, and the noodles are the perfect texture and chewiness.
It's like they took all my disappointments with other ramen bowls, fixed them, and added their own special mix.
and I had my doubts about eating there or ordering the Tori Paitan.
However, it's worth every penny.
Regardless, go get that Tori Paitan!
You will not regret it!
tori paitan.author: Tsyria T.
tori paitan.review:
I crave ramen pretty frequently and regularly. Ever since my visit to Mensho Tokyo, now I just crave Tori Paitan Ramen. It's so deliciously perfect in every way. The broth is wonderfully flavorful and creamy, and the noodles are the perfect texture and chewiness. It's like they took all my disappointments with other ramen bowls, fixed them, and added their own special mix. It's absolutely fantastic!

At first glance, it's one of the more pricey bowls of ramen that I've had and I had my doubts about eating there or ordering the Tori Paitan. However, it's worth every penny. This is one bowl of ramen I'd gladly wait for, and shell out the $$$ for. 

Apparently it's usually a long wait, but I went on a weekday close to opening, and there wasn't too long of a wait (~20 min)

Service is nice, the atmosphere is bright and the decorations are modern. The restaurant is very small, and from what I could see, all the seats were high chairs. So maybe not optimal for a large group or kids.

Regardless, go get that Tori Paitan! You will not regret it!

excerpts: My friends got the Tori Paitan Ramen with Duck Chashu and the Spicy Lamb Chashu Ramen.
tori paitan.author: Connie C.
tori paitan.review:
There's so many ramen joints around the Bay Area and they're all good in their own way but none has ever stood out to me until I came to Mensho. Prior to trying Mensho, Ippudo Ramen in NY was my favorite ramen spot ever. Unfortunately Mensho has stolen Ippudo's spotlight and is seriously the best ramen that I've ever had.

Had an impromptu day with some friends in the city and kinda winged it as to where to get food. My friend was browsing through Yelp for awhile and he picked very wisely. He asked if we were down for some ramen and off we went. Luckily when we got there, the line was starting to form so it wasn't too bad. We got in line while my friend tried to find parking. We waited in line for about 1.5 hour which honestly isn't that bad since Mensho is pretty small inside. So keep in mind it's not friendly for groups. As the line started to move once their doors opened and people were filling up the tables, my friends and I were so close to getting in and we were close to making the cut.

While anxiously waiting we browsed through their menu and as people were leaving, we asked what they got which made the decision process a lot easier. Finally we got seated by this counter seating which was fine. We got to see the chefs in action and it was interesting to see the process of it all. I had ordered the Clam Butter Chashu Ramen since I've never seen anywhere serve clams with ramen. My friends got the Tori Paitan Ramen with Duck Chashu and the Spicy Lamb Chashu Ramen. We ordered the Oysters in Shoyu Dare Oil, which was really yummy. There was enough pieces for the 3 of us to try and to hold off our appetite as we patiently waited for our ramen.

Once our ramen had arrived, we tried each other's broths. The ones that my friends ordered had a creamy broth and it was so savory and delicious. My broth was lighter but still delicious. At first when I tried the broth for my ramen, it had a strong seafood taste but after mixing that whipped butter and all the other ingredients in my bowl together, there was a huge shift in the taste of my broth. It was much more flavorful and that strong seafood taste was masked...probably by the butter but I'm not complaining. The noodles in my ramen were a bit different from my friends but they were so fresh and tasty. So delicious!

The service was alright. Had to flag down a server a few times to get more water. They were busy and it was packed so I understand. The decor was very simple and minimal.

When my friend had told me it was Michelin star rated I wasn't sure how I felt but after trying the food, it definitely proved me wrong. The quality of the ingredients was amazing. As mentioned earlier, it's one of the best ramen that I've ever had. I was craving for more the next day because it was so good. We had met some tourists in line and they told us it was their second time going during their trip in SF. That speaks volume.

Highly suggest trying this place and try to come as early as possible to wait in line. There was already a line at 4PM and they don't open until 5PM. Be patient and you'll have some of the best ramen ever!

excerpts: Anyway, had the Tori Paitan ramen and the Vegan Tantanmen.
-Tori
Paitan:
Deep chicken broth flavor.
Very creamy and filling.
I think I heard it described as a chicken soup for rich people.
I may be able to buy into this description.
For our patience in line, we got an extra chashu (which is not the best anyway).
Noodles were very enjoyable, al dente, and on point.
However, the broth just didn't do it for me.
-Vegan tantanmen:
Surprisingly, I will have to rate this above the tori paitan.
The flavor is fuller and more complex.
It has almost a nutty quality to it, so if you don't like nuts, would not suggest this one.
But it was always very creamy and filly of a broth.
tori paitan.author: Edward L.
tori paitan.review:
Had high hopes for this place. Maybe too high.

As with most ramen places, you expect to wait in line. You can either wait in line later, or you can wait in line before it opens. We chose the latter. We got there at 430pm, expecting to wait 30 minutes for the 5pm opening. Luckily, there was only 1 person ahead of us. Was able to walk down the street grab a cup of coffee from Starbucks and return without any problems.

Come 5 pm, window shades open. Pristine, small, clean dining room with the kitchen in the back. You could just anticipate a good ramen experience. Appeared it was well-staffed. Unfortunately, no one opened the door, as everyone just peered through the window, watching the staff working on the computer system.... Wait 5 minutes, nothing. Wait 10 minutes, nothing. Wait 30 minutes, finally, the head hostess comes out.

"Sorry, but our system is not accepting credit card. We can only accept cash. Please go to an ATM." Are you kidding me? I think cash-only establishments are OK, and I have no problem with this. But really? It took you 30 minutes to let us know this? Of course, all of us in line have been waiting and waiting, so we all make a dash to the nearest ATM. I think it makes more sense to let us know at the very beginning there was issues, so while we inevitably wait more in line, we can go get some cash......... amiright?

Further insult to injury. we didn't get seated for another 15 minutes... So really, 45 minutes after "opening." It doesn't make common sense.

Anyway, had the Tori Paitan ramen and the Vegan Tantanmen.
-Tori Paitan: Deep chicken broth flavor. Very creamy and filling. I think I heard it described as a chicken soup for rich people. I may be able to buy into this description. For our patience in line, we got an extra chashu (which is not the best anyway). Noodles were very enjoyable, al dente, and on point. However, the broth just didn't do it for me.
-Vegan tantanmen: Surprisingly, I will have to rate this above the tori paitan. The flavor is fuller and more complex. It has almost a nutty quality to it, so if you don't like nuts, would not suggest this one. But it was always very creamy and filly of a broth. Noodles the same. 

Unfortunately, given the late start and unreasonable wait without explanation (and even with an explanation, still does not explain make us wait beyond the opening time), I have to rate an overall 2 stars. Service while seated is great, but the compilation of average ramen and initial impression once we got there, has left a bad taste in my mouth.

excerpts: Their tori paitan is a bit heavy
but it is so good.
Not the traditional type of Japanese ramen.
Their ingredients are fresh and blends well together.
The only thing I dread is the wait and the parking.
Also the seatings are not that comfortable.
Other than that, I would come here for a late night dinner.
tori paitan.author: Amy T.
tori paitan.review: This place always hit the spot when I am craving for some good old ramen. Their tori paitan is a bit heavy but it is so good. Not the traditional type of Japanese ramen. Their ingredients are fresh and blends well together. The only thing I dread is the wait and the parking. Also the seatings are not that comfortable. Other than that, I would come here for a late night dinner.

excerpts: The tori paitan broth is unlike any I have had.
Thick and rich, but not chunky.
Full of umami.
In fact, the tori paitan is the best chicken based broth you can find in San Francisco.
Toppings were extremely complementing and portioned perfectly.
The chasu is especially notable.
Have not had better chasu at any ramen house.
Noodles were thicker, bouncy, chewy, and oozing with flavor from the broth.
tori paitan.author: Kathy Z.
tori paitan.review:
Mensho is amazing. Don't even read the reviews, just go. Wait is usually ~1 hour. If you go alone, it's possible that you may be able to skip the line sometimes when one seat opens up. I love Mensho so much, it's now the only experience I am willing to wait this long for.

Review:

Now having gone to Mensho about once a week, I know that the ramen is consistently made and every item is excellent. 

Mensho is ALL ABOUT RAMEN. Your snack options are the fried enoki mushrooms and oyster appetizer. But you come here to be taught how ramen can be transcendental and get an experience closer to what you might have in Japan.

The tori paitan broth is unlike any I have had. Thick and rich, but not chunky. Full of umami. In fact, the tori paitan is the best chicken based broth you can find in San Francisco. Toppings were extremely complementing and portioned perfectly. The chasu is especially notable. Have not had better chasu at any ramen house. Noodles were thicker, bouncy, chewy, and oozing with flavor from the broth. The balance between the ramen noodles and broth was absolutely perfect such that the broth clung to the noodles to give your every bite flavor. 

If you would like a lighter meal, try the shoyu broth. This is my usual go to :) The noodles a little flatter and the broth is absolutely rich, but not heavy at all. My other favorite is the arubasoba -- a soupless ramen made with a soyu, garlic, and pork base. 

Between eating ramen in Tokyo and here, Mensho is the only spot that satisfies.

excerpts: After waiting in line for about an hour and finally being ushered into the small restaurant space, I decided to order the Tori Paitan Ramen, containing Rich and Creamy Chicken Soup, Pork Chashu, Duck Chashu, Menma, Kale, Burdock, Katsuobushi Sauce.
tori paitan.author: Sarah N.
tori paitan.review:
I almost want to give 3.5 stars, but the handmade noodles and the quality of the pork and duck slices was too prime to lower. This was my first time at Mensho, and I was immediately astonished by the line on an early Saturday evening. After waiting in line for about an hour and finally being ushered into the small restaurant space, I decided to order the Tori Paitan Ramen, containing Rich and Creamy Chicken Soup, Pork Chashu, Duck Chashu, Menma, Kale, Burdock, Katsuobushi Sauce. 

PROS: 
- delicious (!!) pork and duck chasu. I had never had duck in my ramen before, but it was so tender and juicy and a great addition.
- handmade noodles. They had that inconsistent size and shape characteristic of a handmade noodle and they weren't chewy and harder like the premade or packaged ramen at some other spots. 

CONS:
- the broth! This might be an unpopular opinion, but it was just too damn rich and creamy, almost as if they had poured cups and cups of cream and milk. I definitely wasn't able to consume much of the broth after getting through the ramen and for hours after my meal, I felt like I was going to be sick. If (IF!) I were to come back again (maybe when it's raining and there's no ridiculous line), I'd try the Shoyu broth instead. 
- so there's kale in your ramen...but no option to add an egg? What??
- that line. Sorry, there's no justifying it, and in my case, not sure it was worth it. 

In summary, I didn't have the most mindblowing experience here, and perhaps it was because I was let down given all the hype. But due to the quality of meat and the delicious handmade ramen, I didn't feel I could go lower than 4 stars here.

excerpts: I decided to go with the Tori Paitan, since it looked the most appealing and my boyfriend suggested I add double chashu...and it was the best decision I ever made.
The chashu was so tender and buttery that it literally melted in my mouth.
The Tori Paitan was just as delicious with its flavorful broth and creamy texture.
If this was how every ramen I ever tasted actually tasted like, I can say I love ramen.
tori paitan.author: Victoria K.
tori paitan.review:
I'll start off by saying I am in no way a fan of Ramen. at all. However, the hype around this place made it that much more intriguing to want to try this place out. And my goodness - probably the BEST ramen I have ever tasted in my life! 

I came here with a group of friends when we first heard wind of the restaurant's grand opening. We decided to be smart people and arrived here right when the restaurant opened. Boy, were we late. We waited an additional 2 hours in line after arriving at the restaurant right when it opened. The restaurant itself is fairly small and only had room for seating for a small amount of people. Majority of the people at the restaurant ended up sharing with another party when they sat down. Even so, by the time we got to the front of the line, we were greeted by one of the owners of the restaurants. With a smile on his face and thanking us for being so so patient, it made us less agitated and more excited to go in and try out the food! I decided to go with the Tori Paitan, since it looked the most appealing and my boyfriend suggested I add double chashu...and it was the best decision I ever made. The chashu was so tender and buttery that it literally melted in my mouth. The Tori Paitan was just as delicious with its flavorful broth and creamy texture. If this was how every ramen I ever tasted actually tasted like, I can say I love ramen. BUT, every ramen I have tried since this place has been a disappointment because the ramen here is THAT good. 

Despite the long wait and the small seating area, it is still absolutely worth it. You have to come and try this place out to really know what I'm talking about.

excerpts: We also had the Tori Paitan, which was really thick and creamy, garnished with thin slices of duck, chasrsiu, burdock and kale.
tori paitan.author: Elaine Y.
tori paitan.review:
We got 30 mins before opening time on Thursday at 4.30 pm and were the first in line.  People started to show up after us and we got in on the first seating, which is about 30 people.  This place can be quite cramped and baskets are provided on the floor for your belongings.  Just remember to pick them up when u leave.

Been meaning to try this place since my friends said it was so good.   The menu is very limited, only one appetizer offered, oysters for $5, which had a oily smoky taste.  We also had the Tori Paitan, which was really thick and creamy, garnished with thin slices of duck, chasrsiu, burdock and kale. For extra charsiu, there was an extra $2 charge. 

Would come back to try other items on the menu.  We sat on the counter facing the kitchen, so it was entertaining watching our order being made and served to us.  But I wasn't keen on that huge silver serving spoon to eat my ramen, too big and it retained heat and just weren't suitable to use...just wished I said something coz I noticed the yelp photos showed small wooden ones. Also, there are no boxes for take out or left overs, so bring ur own or finished everything up, which I'm sure would not be a prob!

excerpts: Mensho Tokyo is a good place to have some Japanese flavor, I really love their noodles because the noodles are chewier and have a elasticity to them, the ramen at this place is just amazing starting from thr Maccha Tori Paitan, Spicy Lmb,Shio and Clam Butter.
Though the wait is long due to the busy nature and too many customers, the wait is worth it eventually since the services are amazing and food comes very fast compared to other restaurants around.
Every employee is super kind and very quick to respond.
Even with the large crowds, I was able to take as long as we needed to eat without ever feeling rushed.
tori paitan.author: Brian M.
tori paitan.review: Mensho Tokyo is a good place to have some Japanese flavor, I really love their noodles because the noodles are chewier and have a elasticity to them, the ramen at this place is just amazing starting from thr Maccha Tori Paitan, Spicy Lmb,Shio and Clam Butter. Though the wait is long due to the busy nature and too many customers, the wait is worth it eventually since the services are amazing and food comes very fast compared to other restaurants around. excerpts: The Tori Paitan ($16, $18 if you want to add extra chashu) is the chicken soup with pork and duck chashu, kale, burdock, and katsobushi sauce.
The broth was rich, creamy, and very flavorful.
But the shining star of this bowl of ramen was definitely the noodles.
tori paitan.author: Christine S.
tori paitan.review:
Eating at Mensho is like eating brunch in San Francisco: the wait is RIDICULOUS.

They open at 5pm, but David C. and Allen C. were there at 4pm to be the first ones in line. (Yay friends!) By 4:30pm, there was a pretty decent line going on. The restaurant only seats 28 people, so do the math to see if you will be part of the first wave that gets seated! If not, you're looking at (at least) a 30 minute wait.

The Tori Paitan ($16, $18 if you want to add extra chashu) is the chicken soup with pork and duck chashu, kale, burdock, and katsobushi sauce. The broth was rich, creamy, and very flavorful. But the shining star of this bowl of ramen was definitely the noodles. They were thick and perfectly QQ! 

They have two communal tables and a few bar seats. So not the best place for a first date unless you want other people to overhear your awkward conversations!

excerpts: We ordered the shoyu (which I always tend to go for), the tori paitan, and the limited clam butter ramen.
All the soups were very rich and the noodles were cooked perfectly.
Once they put the tori paitan in front of the bf, he didn't want to let me have any of it, and totally fair.
The shoyu ramen was the best shoyu ramen I've had.
I've been going to Japan for many years, and I eat ramen at least once a day when I'm there.
The clam ramen was on a whole other level.
They only serve 10 bowls a day.
Pro tip: get double chashu for $2 extra in the tori paitan.
tori paitan.author: Carolyn Z.
tori paitan.review:
Hands down best ramen in SF. We came here as part of our ramen 2K17 run. Le bf and I came on a weekday and waited in line 20 minutes before the restaurant opened. We were the second group to be seated that day. Between the 2 of us, we ordered 3 bowls, definitely worth it. We both left stuffed. 

We ordered the shoyu (which I always tend to go for), the tori paitan, and the limited clam butter ramen. All the soups were very rich and the noodles were cooked perfectly. Once they put the tori paitan in front of the bf, he didn't want to let me have any of it, and totally fair. The shoyu ramen was the best shoyu ramen I've had. I've been going to Japan for many years, and I eat ramen at least once a day when I'm there. The clam ramen was on a whole other level. They only serve 10 bowls a day. It had a ton of shaved butter that melted into the broth making it so very creamy. 

Pro tip: get double chashu for $2 extra in the tori paitan. You will not regret it. 

5 star service and 5 star food. We will definitely be back.

excerpts: but I got the Tori Paitan which is a rich, creamy chicken broth.
I haven't really seen this kind of broth in other places, but it's so delicious and indulgent.
It's definitely not healthy, and I don't want to see what this broth looks like when it is cold and starts to solidify.
The chashu was tender and almost fell apart, and the other toppings were delicious.
The noodles were al dente and just perfect.
It was really filling -
tori paitan.author: Christina L.
tori paitan.review:
I've eaten ramen in a lot of places in the Bay Area (Ramen Dojo, Orenchi, etc), in LA, Vancouver, NYC, and Tokyo, so I've definitely eaten my share of ramen. This is definitely up there in the top 5 ramens that I've had. 

This place is tiny, so brace yourself for a wait. I came at 7:30 pm on a Friday evening with just one other person, and waited about 30-45 min. I probably wouldn't wait more than an hour for the ramen. It's good, but there are other things to eat that are good that don't warrant just standing in line outside in the Tenderloin. Because the place is tiny and communal seating, don't come with more than one other person. Maybe a max of 4 people.

There are 3 different types of broth you can order but I got the Tori Paitan which is a rich, creamy chicken broth. I haven't really seen this kind of broth in other places, but it's so delicious and indulgent. It's definitely not healthy, and I don't want to see what this broth looks like when it is cold and starts to solidify. The chashu was tender and almost fell apart, and the other toppings were delicious. The noodles were al dente and just perfect. It was really filling - I don't think I could have done extra noodles or extra chashu.

We also shared enoki chips which were deep fried enoki with a slightly spiced batter. They were definitely unique and delicious and would recommend this. The serving size was pretty decent on this.

I can't wait to come back here again - everything was delicious and I felt like I could have been transported to Japan. If you like a good bowl of ramen and have the patience to wait 30 min - 1 hour, go here.  The service, ambiance and food were all on pointe. The only downside is that it's a bit expensive for ramen - one bowl is ~$16-18 but I'd rather pay $5 more for good ramen than for mediocre ramen.

excerpts: Fortunately, we didn't have to wait too long to be seated when we came here a couple days ago, and the Tori Paitan Ramen was pretty good!
I kinda wish they made a thick pork based broth, but the tori paitan was still delicious.
Some people have mentioned that it's too salty, but I thought it was the right degree of saltiness.
If I had to suggest anything, they could add more green onions or something else to offset the heaviness of the broth and meat toppings.
While I enjoyed the rich profile of the ramen, having some sort of contrast would make it even better.
tori paitan.author: Nei N.
tori paitan.review:
This has been on my to-try list for a while, and I put it off mainly so I wouldn't have to wait in some ridiculous line. Fortunately, we didn't have to wait too long to be seated when we came here a couple days ago, and the Tori Paitan Ramen was pretty good!

Broth - Rich, creamy, and super chickeny. I kinda wish they made a thick pork based broth, but the tori paitan was still delicious. Some people have mentioned that it's too salty, but I thought it was the right degree of saltiness. If I had to suggest anything, they could add more green onions or something else to offset the heaviness of the broth and meat toppings. While I enjoyed the rich profile of the ramen, having some sort of contrast would make it even better. Also, those weird metals spoons have got to go!

Noodles - Firm and springy. The noodles were great!

Toppings - I didn't care too much about the duck chashu, burdock, or kale. The pork chashu was very well made. It had a very earthy sweet flavor kinda like a Hakka style braised pork belly. 

Overall, it was pretty good, and I'd return when the line isn't super long.

excerpts: I honestly did not know what to order so I ordered the first thing I saw- the Tori Paitan Ramen.
My order came out quickly (within 10-15 mins max) and it was the most amazing ramen I have ever had.
The broth is SO flavorful and thick
.. there was no way I left anything in that bowl.
Seriously, 10/10 would recommend.
tori paitan.author: Esther M.
tori paitan.review:
Just flew in last night at around 10 and I was madly craving ramen. All the local ramen spots around me were already closed or nearly closing til I found this gem. Let me tell you, PLEASE TRY THIS PLACE OUT. Although it's a fairly small space (I would say atleast 30 people max can be seated & its bar seating) the wait is not that long. People little sit, eat & drink, and pay their tab and leave. I spent about 30 minutes max in there eating (I was solo). 
Great customer service. Honestly don't remember the gal's name but she was very tentative and took my order rather quickly. I honestly did not know what to order so I ordered the first thing I saw- the Tori Paitan Ramen. My order came out quickly (within 10-15 mins max) and it was the most amazing ramen I have ever had. The broth is SO flavorful and thick.. there was no way I left anything in that bowl. Seriously, 10/10 would recommend.

excerpts: My friend and I got the most popular ramen option on the menu, the tori paitan.
I don't remember much about the noodles, but the broth was amazing!
It was super rich and and flavorful.
The texture is almost foamy, reminding us of a latte or hot chocolate..but savory.
tori paitan.author: Shelly L.
tori paitan.review:
Definitely worth the wait, though don't know if it's worth the price. 

Once you order, the food comes out super fast, probably within 5-10 minutes, making up for the waiting you do outside of the restaurant.

My friend and I got the most popular ramen option on the menu, the tori paitan. I don't remember much about the noodles, but the broth was amazing! It was super rich and and flavorful. The texture is almost foamy, reminding us of a latte or hot chocolate..but savory.  Having visited shisengumi, daikokuya, and tsujita back in socal, I would still say Mensho still stands out, offering a great bowl of hot soup and noodles especially in the cold SF weather!! 

Will definitely be back to try other options on the menu..when I am in a patient and generous mood for a long wait and $20 ramen.

excerpts: We got the fried enoki mushroom, spicy tori paitan, spicy lamb, and soba noodles.
All were really good, though the lamb was a little gamey.
They do give you a lot, but meat to noodle ratio was lacking.
I would definitely come back.
tori paitan.author: Theresa N.
tori paitan.review: This place is amazing. Totally worth the wait. Perfect for a cold Fall SF night. The restaurant opens at 5pm. We got there around 515, got seated at 630 and food didn't take long to come out. There was 5 of us. We got the fried enoki mushroom, spicy tori paitan, spicy lamb, and soba noodles. All were really good, though the lamb was a little gamey. They do give you a lot, but meat to noodle ratio was lacking. I would definitely come back.

excerpts: The Tori Paitan is the move if you like thicker broth.
Toppings include Rich and Creamy Chicken Soup, Pork Chashu, Duck Chashu, Menma, Kale, Burdock, and Katsuobushi Sauce.
Double chasu is recommended.
Read back those ingredients and tell me what is missing....
I'll give you a second....
That's right--NO SOFT BOILED EGG.
tori paitan.author: Vasiliy M.
tori paitan.review:
Finally, got around to checking this ramen shop out. I have walked by it several times, only to see a huge line outside the door. This past weekend, I decided to wait in this line with a couple of buddies and we waited...and waited..and waited. I stood in line longer here, than I did at Rokurinsha in Tokyo!! Finally we made it to the front and got seated. As they do in Japan, Mensho will take your order while you are in line, so that your ramen is ready as soon as you get seated. 

The Tori Paitan is the move if you like thicker broth. Toppings include Rich and Creamy Chicken Soup, Pork Chashu, Duck Chashu, Menma, Kale, Burdock, and Katsuobushi Sauce. Double chasu is recommended. Read back those ingredients and tell me what is missing....I'll give you a second....That's right--NO SOFT BOILED EGG. Make sure you don't forget to order that as an extra topping ;)

Pros:
-HUGE portions. The way ramen should be (and is in Japan). 
-Lots of meat and high-quality meat.

Cons:
-Long line
-Space is space and seating is limited. Sometimes you have to share a table with someone you don't know. Ramen is supposed to be an intimate experience :(
-Why do they use chicken broth? It adds nothing to the taste and flavor :/
-There's an enormous latern hanging in the window that says "Tsukemen." Great, except for they don't serve tsukemen ramen -___-

excerpts: Tori Paitan was freaking awesome, spicy lamb is good but very heavy on the spice (gave me major heartburn
The food: we ordered the tori paitan with double chashu, spicy lamb, and enoki chips.
The tori paitan was deeeeelish, albeit heavy, since it's a 'creamy' ramen.
tori paitan.author: Kristen T.
tori paitan.review:
TLDR: Tori Paitan was freaking awesome, spicy lamb is good but very heavy on the spice (gave me major heartburn and I didn't even finish the whole thing, wouldn't order again), enoki chips were too oily and dense (wouldn't order again), wait was 1 h 15 m, glad I waited this first time, not sure it's worth waiting that long for a meal that took less than 30 m to eat and pay other than on occasions where we feel like coming to eat at this specific restaurant. 

The wait: Came on a Saturday night and arrived to line up at 6:40 PM, knowing it would be a loooong wait. Ended up waiting 1 h 15 m, which is both far longer than we ever like to wait on a normal basis but also shorter than we expected for a clear and cold weekend evening. I was, however, already fairly hungry when we got in line, so waiting really kicked my hunger up even further, and I basically inhaled my food when I got in. I would suggest going when you're just getting hungry, or otherwise have a light snack before you head out, because if not, you'll end up scarfing your meal down without taking a moment to enjoy it!

The food: we ordered the tori paitan with double chashu, spicy lamb, and enoki chips. 

The 'chips' were more like an oily pile of mushrooms, and although interesting in theory, way too oily and heavy - would have loved something a little lighter. The portion size was actually larger than we expected, so we probably could have gone without them knowing we were ordering two bowls of ramen. 

The tori paitan was deeeeelish, albeit heavy, since it's a 'creamy' ramen. The duck chashu was a nice change from the typical ramen we go out for, and the pork was unbelievably tender.

The spicy lamb was not too spicy in the heat sense, but rather overly spiced for my taste, which detracted significantly from my experience. The spices used were ones I've eaten before with no trouble, but usually far less in amounts, so I ended up with a severely sour stomach. Quality is still there, so my dislike of it is more a matter of preference - and the fact that I apparently have a slightly more sensitive stomach.

Overall, quality and quantity is definitely more than a few notches above other ramen places I've eaten at in SF, and I would recommend going at least once to try it for yourself. Whether or not you end up going back to wait in that line subsequent times is really up to how amazing you think the ramen is.

excerpts: I ordered the Spicy Tori Paitan and tasted the base soup before mixing in the red peppers and miso that make this the spicy version.
The base soup was thick, creamy, and frothy but paradoxically tasted both rich and bland
(flavors didn't pop) at same time.
Something was missing.
tori paitan.author: Yong P.
tori paitan.review:
Some context, I'm a foodie from LA visiting SF over winter vacation. Mensho Tokyo was one of my top restaurants to check out after reading a yelp review ranking this place over other LA places this particular yelper had tried. I've scoured the LA ramen scene and rank Tsujita Annex above all else, which is the bar to which all other ramens are judged for me.

Broth: To me, broth in ramen is most important followed by the noodles. I ordered the Spicy Tori Paitan and tasted the base soup before mixing in the red peppers and miso that make this the spicy version. The base soup was thick, creamy, and frothy but paradoxically tasted both rich and bland (flavors didn't pop) at same time. Something was missing. After mixing in spices the soup started to taste like Korean doenjang jjigae, which was kinda weird because I've never had doenjang jjigae with noodles.

Compared to Tsujita Annex's broth which I just want to keep drinking against my better judgment (i.e., heart attack), the broth at Mensho lost my interest after a few spoonfuls.

Also, the thickness of broth made all the other ingredients sink into it, which made my bowl of ramen looked like a primordial soup halfway through.

Overall, although the broth had layers of different flavors, but it didn't grab me. Perhaps I just didn't get the complexity. I had high expectations coming in given all the signage of its unique umami flavor and special nori that they use. IMO, the soup lacked  that "yummy" quality that makes my mouth water, which happens when I just think about the broth from Tsujita Annex or other places like Hakata Ikkousha or even the humble Santouka in Mitsuwa food court.

Noodles: Thick, chewy, bouncy, nice texture and cooked a bit al dente. The noodles in themselves were great, and on par with Tsujita Annex.  Broth clung to the noodles well, however because I wasn't that big a fan of the broth, I didn't feel a desire to finish the noodles.

Chashu: I ordered single portion and didn't get to try the duck chashu. The pork chashu was mediocre and served thin, lukewarm, and on lean side compared to other places. It was tender but did not melt in my mouth.

Extras: Surprisingly, my favorite part of the bowl was the bamboo shoots. They were flavored very well and had a nice crunch to them.

Venue: Venue is small with about four communal tables and a few seats at bar facing kitchen. I came alone and had fun watching the chefs do their magic.

Wait: It is what it is. There wasn't a sign in sheet which required everyone to stay in line. I waited 35 minutes at around 9pm Friday, but if longer, it would be great to have option of putting name down and wander streets a bit to pass time. 

Service: Given how busy they are, it is understandable that waiting staff are inattentive, but they were also not very cordial. Back in my hometown of Torrance, I'm used to mom and pop japanese places where there is a loud greeting and farewell regardless of how busy the place is. At Mensho, the waitress didn't give any acknowledgement (verbal or nonverbal) after I thanked her for the meal as I walked out. Not a big deal but I left with an unwelcome feeling. Also worth noting is that they included a service charge to bill. Total came out to $22 for one bowl of ramen (ouch). I've had really really good service at other busy SF eateries so my experience here may not just be a stranger effect ("people are strange when you're a stranger").

Atmosphere: Decor is a bit generic and did not feel like a Japanese place in a traditional sense. I don't think I heard one word of japanese my entire time there.

excerpts: It was the $18 Tori Paitan Ramen with Double Pork Chashu, and I had them add an extra couple of Duck Chashu slices for $1.50 extra because why not go to town?
The noodles were perfectly al dente, and the chashu was meaty without being overwhelming.
tori paitan.author: Ed U.
tori paitan.review:
The advance hype on this place was off the charts, and the breathless texting and taxing anticipation from the hipsterati of self-proclaimed ramen connoisseurs has been quite deafening. A two-plus-hour wait for an $18 bowl of ramen sounds like a Louis C.K. joke about San Francisco millennials with no punchline. I got exhausted thinking about the hoops I'd have to jump through to get a taste of the broth here. However, now that at least six weeks have elapsed since the grand opening in February, I had an opening that I couldn't bypass, the Thursday before Good Friday when I got off work early.

Everyone says to be there at 4PM even though they don't open until an hour later, and so I did. If you don't count the screeching homeless woman who kept sauntering by, no one else showed up until around 4:35PM. That's not to say the staff was indifferent to my presence as they thanked me for coming and waiting patiently. Eventually a line did start to form and rather quickly. I got seated at the front counter promptly at 5PM where I had a nice view of the kitchen where activity was bustling behind he coffee beakers with the broth at full boil and the pork and duck chashu being meticulously sliced. I was sitting with a Filipino family who could barely contain their enthusiasm over the forthcoming noodlefest.

I was feeling the same way and knew what to order since I had well over an hour to decide. I started with their one and only appetizer, the $5 Oysters in Shoyu Dare Oil. There were four of them completely shelled and marinated (photo: http://bit.ly/1Vp0sEV). Tasty freshness gone too soon, but the main event was about to occur. It was the $18 Tori Paitan Ramen with Double Pork Chashu, and I had them add an extra couple of Duck Chashu slices for $1.50 extra because why not go to town? The noodles were perfectly al dente, and the chashu was meaty without being overwhelming. Slices of menma, kale and burdock floated on top with a katsuobushi (bonito) sauce spooned on top (photo: http://bit.ly/224L6pv).

However, for all the fresh ingredients, it was that rich paitan chicken broth that lingers not only on the palate but in my sense-memory. Just the natural creaminess of it was amazing, and what really makes this bowl of ramen stand out against the others. There are three other ramen bowls on the menu - organic shoyu, shio, and vegan tantanmen, as well as a selection of mazesoba bowls. I was timid and just had a $4.75 bottle of Sapporo Premium to wash it all down (photo: http://bit.ly/1RTN9dq), but they have pricier Japanese artisan beers which they strongly recommended to me for the next time. And there will be a next time even as I saw the line go down the block as I departed.

FOOD - 5 stars...best paitan ramen broth ever, period
AMBIANCE - 4.5 stars...clean, white and you only wish it was triple the size to make the line move faster
SERVICE - 5 stars...lovely people work here
TOTAL - 5 stars...not just for self-proclaimed ramen connoisseurs...be patient or come near closing

excerpts: The tori paitan ramen was incredibly creamy, and I had a hard time finishing all the broth, it was that rich.
tori paitan.author: Steph D.
tori paitan.review:
I know pretty much nothing about ramen, but holy crap, best japanese pot o' noodles I have ever eaten. The tori paitan ramen was incredibly creamy, and I had a hard time finishing all the broth, it was that rich. Twenty bucks is a little steep, but I would highly recommend this bowl.

Long line at 4:55, but we were seated by 6pm. When we left at about 6:50, the line was pretty short. I definitely think the wait is worth it, for currently the "best" ramen in SF. I definitely would recommend coming with a smaller party, though.

excerpts: I really enjoyed my tori paitan ramen, and I must say it was a unique dish.
First, as someone who generally does not like getting too close to strangers, I thought the close seating arrangement was tolerable.
Since the wait is so long, the literature on the walls was enough to educate/entertain me, and the specialty of their kombu broth does seem authentic after tasting it.
However, I think this particular broth needed time getting adjusted with because it was much earthier than what I've had at typical American ramen places.
I would even suggest nixing the bamboo shoots because for the first half of my meal, I could not taste anything but that strong pickly bamboo taste which took away from the broth flavor.
The egg was seasoned to the T--rich, pungent, and oversalted even.
I had to be careful eating that egg.
Overall, not worth the wait or the price tag for me as someone who has affordable ramen options back home, and not unique enough for me to come back.
tori paitan.author: Hong L.
tori paitan.review: I really enjoyed my tori paitan ramen, and I must say it was a unique dish. First, as someone who generally does not like getting too close to strangers, I thought the close seating arrangement was tolerable. Since the wait is so long, the literature on the walls was enough to educate/entertain me, and the specialty of their kombu broth does seem authentic after tasting it. However, I think this particular broth needed time getting adjusted with because it was much earthier than what I've had at typical American ramen places. I would even suggest nixing the bamboo shoots because for the first half of my meal, I could not taste anything but that strong pickly bamboo taste which took away from the broth flavor. The egg was seasoned to the T--rich, pungent, and oversalted even. I had to be careful eating that egg. Overall, not worth the wait or the price tag for me as someone who has affordable ramen options back home, and not unique enough for me to come back.

excerpts: but I got the Tori Paitan (single not double)
cause I didn't want to pay that much for ramen, but it was amazing!
So much flavor and the duck and pork were so tender and just melted in my mouth.
The broth was filled with all this flavoring and was a bit thick
but I slurrrrped it all down.
I could've drank the whole broth but decided against that lol.
This is a must get, definitely, for real for real.
tori paitan.author: Nyla K.
tori paitan.review:
There's always a huge line to this place but this time it was a bit short and even then we were still debating on leaving and going somewhere else.  We stuck it out and very glad we did.  The place is super small and if you are going in as a couple you'll most likely share a table with someone else.  Also if you have a big party (6 or 8) it's gonna take ages for you to get seated.  Single diners get seated pretty much immediately.

Ok now for the food.  We didn't get a starter but I got the Tori Paitan (single not double) cause I didn't want to pay that much for ramen, but it was amazing!  So much flavor and the duck and pork were so tender and just melted in my mouth.  The broth was filled with all this flavoring and was a bit thick but I slurrrrped it all down.  I could've drank the whole broth but decided against that lol.  This is a must get, definitely, for real for real.  Get this one!

My bf got the clear soup, Shoya ramen, and tbh I didn't like it.  The broth was a big tangy and kinda salty and mine was wayyy better.  Kinda felt bad cause I know he wanted to switch with me, but sorry buddy you just get a taste! Lol

Also, they give you this huge silver spoon to slurp up your broth.  Never seen that before!

excerpts: My hubby got Tori Paitan and he couldn't finish because it was too thick.
I got Shoyu and it was good.
Light and tasty.
tori paitan.author: Maria M.
tori paitan.review:
An hour wait in line and we got our ramen. Can't say if it worth it or not but after 15 min waiting it becomes principal not to leave.
My hubby got Tori Paitan and he couldn't finish because it was too thick. I got Shoyu and it was good. Light and tasty. Not thick and not too salty as I like. 

So if you are ok with waiting it could be nice experience:)

excerpts: Tori Paitan
tori paitan.author: Tian Q.
tori paitan.review:
Above average ramen, but 2hrs in line and $20 a bowl doesn't give you a bowl of gold.

Tori Paitan
- Thick broth but subtly flavored, tastes like chinese porridge infused with some fat
- Awkwardly thick noodles that don't soak up any flavors, but I can see how some of the same people who like to chew on dough like this simply because it's "al dente"
- Best two pieces of pork chashu I've had in a ramen bowl (duck chashu tasted weak AF however)

Tantanmen
- Equally thick broth mixed with a ton of nuts that looks like a bowl of fodder you stole from some pigs' trough, but pretty solid flavors

Friendly service after you spend 2hrs in line smelling sun dried hobo piss outside.

Tip: Come 20 min before they open on weekdays for generally guaranteed first seating

excerpts: I got the the Tori Paitan and my friend got the Spicy Lamb.
The meat was great in both, but we ended up not being able to finish our bowls because the cream was so heavy, even more so in the spicy lamb.
tori paitan.author: Anna M.
tori paitan.review:
Unfortunately for me this place didn't live up to the hype or the 40 minute wait...

Food: While the noodles were fantastic and obviously made fresh the creamy broth (while nicely flavorful) was just too creamy for me. I got the the Tori Paitan and my friend got the Spicy Lamb. The meat was great in both, but we ended up not being able to finish our bowls because the cream was so heavy, even more so in the spicy lamb. Next time I would definitely try the clear broth. 

Ambiance: the seating area is decorated nicely and customers are sat at communal tables which is nice. What I couldn't stand was the very loud dubstep music that was playing. I could barely hear my friend while he was talking to me and it made me feel a little irritated during the meal. 

Service: our servers were awesome! We were asked if we were ready to order 3 times in the first 5 minutes we were there which made me worried that the meal would be rushed, but once we ordered and food came I didn't feel rushed at all. 

I'm not sure if I will be back or not, but if so I hope the music is quieter and I'd try a clear broth for sure.

excerpts: The Tori Paitan is hands down my favorite one.
I have tried Shoyo based one, the Vegan, and the spicy Tori Paitan, but I always go back to my roots.
tori paitan.author: Nicole N.
tori paitan.review:
First things first, the line is worth. This is my go to place when taking my family or friends that are not from the city. I first came here during the open week in 2016 and have gone at least twice a month ever since.

The Tori Paitan is hands down my favorite one. I have tried Shoyo based one, the Vegan, and the spicy Tori Paitan, but I always go back to my roots. The oysters are also pretty amazing.

Forever my favorite ramen place in San Francisco.

excerpts: Not necessarily the best bowl of ramen I've ever had but the broth in their Tori Paitan (TP) ramen is INSANE.
It's super thick, almost gravy like, yet still remains pretty light.
I haven't had anything like it before.
You can tell the broths quality with it's texture and deep flavor, definitely been cooking for HOURS.Add
in some super tender chashu (both pork AND duck), menma, springy and squiggly noodles, kale, and some katsuoboshi (bonito shavings) and you got yourself their TP ramen.
tori paitan.author: Earl G.
tori paitan.review:
Not necessarily the best bowl of ramen I've ever had but the broth in their Tori Paitan (TP) ramen is INSANE. It's super thick, almost gravy like, yet still remains pretty light. I haven't had anything like it before. You can tell the broths quality with it's texture and deep flavor, definitely been cooking for HOURS.Add in some super tender chashu (both pork AND duck), menma, springy and squiggly noodles, kale, and some katsuoboshi (bonito shavings) and you got yourself their TP ramen. Hella flavor! 

Normally, it's $16 for a bowl but you only get one piece of meat so I'd recommend getting a double chashu for $18. Personally, I got the double and got an extra piece of chashu (since that's how I roll) and boom, baller bowl of ramen for $20. 

Perfect comfort food for those cold SF summer nights. I ain't spending hours making a ramen broth so it wasn't bad waiting an hour in line (Arrived on a Thursday @8:30pm, seated at 9:30pm). My tip - It's better to go later, wait times are shorter. 

Other bites. 
*SHIO RAMEN $11 - very clean, deep, clear. The noodles were fettucine like.
*OYSTERS IN SHOYU DARE OIL - 4 for $5. Like little chewy umami bombs. Reminded me of smoked oysters from the can. 

Can't wait to check out more flavors of ramen when they bring them over.

excerpts: The most popular one is the Tori Paitan Ramen, but I hear the Tsukemen is bomb as well (chilled ramen separated from the broth).
There's not too many choices for additional toppings like soft boiled eggs or corn, but
hey if the ramen tastes amazing by itself, who needs it?
Once my Tori Paitan Double Chashu ($18) came out, I just stared at my ramen for a good 10 seconds.
IT LOOKS
SO GOOD.
Okay looks are one thing, but let's taste the broth.
DROOLS.
A rich, thick, & creamy broth packed with a lot of flavor.
It doesn't taste overly saturated with sodium at all.
Double Chashu is so worth.
Most of the flavors from the ramen came from the pork, and the chashu just melts in your mouth.
The duck was good too, but it had a subtle lemon taste to it.
tori paitan.author: Kevin S.
tori paitan.review:
Mensho is so worth the wait!

I've heard from many people that this place is like THE best ramen ever. That's impossible right? Well, I'm not easy to please in terms of ramen, but the fact that I actually drank the entire chicken broth is saying something! The restaurant opens at 5pm, but a huge line already started forming before it even opened. My friends got a spot in line at about 4:45pm, and I met up with them 30 minutes later. Total wait for us was about 1.5 hours, but I heard people have waited at least 2 hours for this. There is no sign up sheet for waiting, just an old fashioned wait your turn in line kinda deal. There's also not a lot of seating inside, so the wait makes more sense. Once you're inside, you still have to wait about 30 minutes from being seated to having your ramen come out.

TIP: If you're comfortable and brave enough to eat alone, single seats are most likely available for you to skip the line if there are groups with odd numbers.

Parking in this area is kind of difficult, especially with all the one way streets and meter parking. If you wait till about 5:45pm on weekdays, rush over to take the parking right across the street. Parking is free and allowed at 6pm along this part of Geary. 

The menu is pretty simple too, with your choice of Ramen, Tsukemen, and Mazesoba. The most popular one is the Tori Paitan Ramen, but I hear the Tsukemen is bomb as well (chilled ramen separated from the broth). There's not too many choices for additional toppings like soft boiled eggs or corn, but hey if the ramen tastes amazing by itself, who needs it? Just kidding I still want my soft boiled egg and corn.

We ordered oysters in shoyu dare oil for appetizers, and it was tasty. 4-5 pieces for $5 so not a bad deal. Once my Tori Paitan Double Chashu ($18) came out, I just stared at my ramen for a good 10 seconds. IT LOOKS SO GOOD. Okay looks are one thing, but let's taste the broth. DROOLS. A rich, thick, & creamy broth packed with a lot of flavor. It doesn't taste overly saturated with sodium at all. Double Chashu is so worth. Most of the flavors from the ramen came from the pork, and the chashu just melts in your mouth. The duck was good too, but it had a subtle lemon taste to it. Crispy bamboo shoots were a nice touch.

The hype couldn't be more real.

excerpts: Get the Tori Paitan ($18 for double chashu)!
That was by far my favorite dish here and
one of the best ramen bowls I have ever had.
The broth was super thick almost like gravy and very rich.
The noodles were springy and had a generous serving size.
The pork was extremely tender and flavorful.
I thought the slices of duck were just okay.
I thought it was good but not nearly as delicious as the Tori Paitan.
tori paitan.author: Linda X.
tori paitan.review:
Expect a long wait but it's worth it to try this place. We came at 5 pm on Sunday right when the restaurant opened and the line was already an hour long. There aren't too many seats inside most of which are communal tables. The service was quick and friendly.

Get the Tori Paitan ($18 for double chashu)! That was by far my favorite dish here and one of the best ramen bowls I have ever had. The broth was super thick almost like gravy and very rich. The noodles were springy and had a generous serving size. The pork was extremely tender and flavorful. I thought the slices of duck were just okay. Only wish was they had an egg inside!

My boyfriend got the shoyu which he really liked. The broth is a lot lighter and clearer. I thought it was good but not nearly as delicious as the Tori Paitan.

Overall this place stood up to its hype for me!

excerpts: The best thing about the Tori Paitan Ramen was how tender the cha shu was.
I don't know how they cook it
so there's still a pink hue
but it's amazing.
The regular portion is pretty generous
tori paitan.author: Shannon L.
tori paitan.review:
Well, that was the meatiest and nuttiest vegan ramen I've ever had. It's nutty to the point that bits get stuck between your teeth and you're occasionally chewing on larger pieces that you sip up. Reviewers and even other customers raved about how good the vegan ramen was and that may possibly be better than its meat-based brethren.

While I liked it, it's definitely a once-in-a-while ramen because of how heavy and sodium laden it was. I'm parched as I'm writing this. 

The best thing about the Tori Paitan Ramen was how tender the cha shu was. I don't know how they cook it so there's still a pink hue but it's amazing. The regular portion is pretty generous but if you love pork, you might want to pay extra for the double portion.

With both ramen types, the broths were super heavy in flavor so how much you like this place may depend on how you like your ramen. I actually prefer the milky, creamy broth but this place still does an excellent job making what they specialize in. 

The place looks bigger in pictures but it's a pretty tight space. They have a coat rack for you to hang up your belongings and also bins underneath the tables for purses and backpacks. I went at 5:30pm on a Friday and the wait was a little less than an hour. They took our order a few minutes after we sat and the food came out in 10 minutes.

excerpts: I went with the most popular Tori Paitan Ramen with double chashu.
WOW this was definitely the creamiest ramen I've ever had, and the noodles themselves were the best tasting ramen noodles I've ever eaten.
They were very thick and chewy and the broth was very very rich and creamy.
tori paitan.author: Catherine S.
tori paitan.review:
I came to this place completely unaware that the line would be this ridiculous. I was so shocked at the length of this line on a Tuesday evening - I definitely should've read the reviews and tips beforehand. Nonetheless, my friends and I decided to wait 1.5 hours in line to try the ramen. I mean there has to be a reason why everyone else is also waiting in line. This place just opened around 3 weeks ago, and the chain is straight from Tokyo. Honestly, they should really expand their venue considering how amazingly popular they are! They only have about 4 bar tables that seat 6 people and a small area that seats about 3-4 people. If you come here alone, you could probably skip most of the line!

The service here is really great. The host was really friendly and even remembered our names! He also brought the chef out to meet us and the chef was so adorable and sweet. The staff honestly believes the vegan ramen is the best one, and if you really love meat you can add meat to the ramen. Both my friends went for the vegan ramen, but once I saw that it contained 7 types of nuts, I didn't order it considering I'm allergic to a couple types of nuts. I went with the most popular Tori Paitan Ramen with double chashu. WOW this was definitely the creamiest ramen I've ever had, and the noodles themselves were the best tasting ramen noodles I've ever eaten. They were very thick and chewy and the broth was very very rich and creamy. This was definitely one-of-a-kind ramen!

If ramen is like this in Tokyo, I'm definitely going to have to pay a visit to Japan soon! Although the line here was quite painful, I will try come back here again hopefully when the line isn't as terrible. It is pretty pricey but definitely worth. They're also adding eggs to the ramen in 2 days for all you egg-lovers!

excerpts: Tori Paitan:
Rich, creamy chicken soup, pork chashu, duck chashu, menma, kale, burdock, katsuobushi sauce, chashu $16.
It was really creamy & rich broth, noodles were chewy, good amount of meat, kale was a few pieces that was ok,
other stuff
tori paitan.author: Ann L.
tori paitan.review:
Since I wasn't too hungry for dinner I decided I would walk from 1 Embarcadero Center after watching City of Gold (which is really good by the way) on Sat 3/26/16.  It's a good 1.4 mile walk.  I stood in line with about 20+ people in front of me.  Place opens at 5pm.

It was about a 1 hr wait because I showed up around 4:35pm and people must have been there 4pm or even earlier.  Once in one of the waitress took my order and then had to wait maybe 5-10 minutes to get my ramen.

I picked: Tori Paitan: Rich, creamy chicken soup, pork chashu, duck chashu, menma, kale, burdock, katsuobushi sauce, chashu $16.  It was really creamy & rich broth, noodles were chewy, good amount of meat, kale was a few pieces that was ok, other stuff ok.  

There is red salt w/ grinder, whole black pepper with grinder, and lemon and salted plum seasoning on the table.

One unisex bathroom on the side.  Charge cards accepted.

Hrs: 5pm-11:30pm I think daily, no sign posted.

PS: Bring your own small folding chair so you don't have to stand while in line!

excerpts: We got seated around 6 pm and I ordered the Tori Paitan.
tori paitan.author: Emily M.
tori paitan.review:
Mmmm, one of the best ramen spots in the city. 

Went on a Friday around 5:30 pm and there was a line forming already. For about 15 people in front of us, the wait wasn't too bad. We got seated around 6 pm and I ordered the Tori Paitan. 

Priced at $18, I thought it was a bit steep but I was willing to pay the extra to see what the rave was about. Oh. My. Goodness. I finally knew why people loved it once I ate a spoonful. The texture of the ramen is exactly how I like it - al dente - and the broth was packed with creamy goodness! The chasu is also very tender! I devoured my bowl and wanted more. I wish they offered extra noodles. 

Would come back some day for another bowl.

excerpts: Their Tori Paitan is out of the world.
The broth is insanely murky with an almost viscous consistency and hits all the right marks on your tastebuds.
tori paitan.author: Mona W.
tori paitan.review:
It's true. Here you will find the best bowl ramen bay area has to offer. Their Tori Paitan is out of the world. The broth is insanely murky with an almost viscous consistency and hits all the right marks on your tastebuds. The souyu broth is just as good if you prefer something relatively lighter. 

Was it really worth over an hour wait and $18? That's debatable. Bring your friends and hang out while you wait. Don't come here hungry and grumpy. No matter how good it is, it's still just a bowl of ramen.

excerpts: Tori Paitan Ramen (Double Chashu) was way too creamy and rich for me.
Felt a tad bit of nausea afterwards.
I finished the noodles but left most of the sauce/broth untouched.
And unfortunately, the ground lamb was so ground up that it got lost in the sauce.
tori paitan.author: Lydia Z.
tori paitan.review:
Tori Paitan Ramen (Double Chashu) was way too creamy and rich for me. Felt a tad bit of nausea afterwards. I finished the noodles but left most of the sauce/broth untouched. And unfortunately, the ground lamb was so ground up that it got lost in the sauce. #rip 

I'd try another dish next time but future me would not wait such a long line for ramen in such a small shop. There are 3 tables total so you'll definitely have to share--fun but not fun if you need to tolerate annoying neighbors.

excerpts: I ordered the Tori Paitan ramen with double chasu, an egg, and fried garlic aka full AF.
tori paitan.author: Danny L.
tori paitan.review:
I tried to disregard the hype, but I'm sure I had my own biases coming into Mensho expecting it to be amazing. Here is my attempt to be objective. I ordered the Tori Paitan ramen with double chasu, an egg, and fried garlic aka full AF. 

Broth: This broth is THICK. First impression when sipping it was that it was very rich and almost even gritty since it was so thick. I warmed up to it after several bites and having it together with the noodles and the other ingredients. At the end, it made me feel pretty gross though. 

Noodles: Springy, my favorite type. 

Chasu: Two types of chasu, pork and duck, both thinly sliced, both had great flavor. 

Egg: Shoyu egg, flavorful where you can actually taste the soy sauce marinade. Perfectly soft-boiled

Other: Bamboo shoots tasted a bit more fermented than what I was used to but still good. The fried onions, kale, and cabbage were good additions as it added different complimenting textures and flavors to the dish. Fried garlic was a waste of an add for 2 dollars more as I felt it didn't add that much to the dish. 

Wait time: 10 minutes; Came 10 minutes before opening on a Tuesday and there was already a small line in front but was able to get in with the first wave of people. 

Service: Waitresses were friendly and knowledgeable about the ramen. Had sound suggestions regarding which egg to get (miso or shoyu), which ramen to try as a first timer, and what I should try in the future. 

Price: Steep for ramen. Ingredients seem high quality and the place is pretty hyped up so I guess its understandable. 

Overall, the Tori Paiten ramen was good but may be too rich and thick for my taste. I'd come back to try the other ramens here (the lamb miso ramen, the clam ramen, and the soup-less ramen) since they have the potential to be really good.

excerpts: So the four categories are: tori paitan (most ordered based on pictures and reviews), shoyu (what I ordered), shio, and vegan tantanmen.
tori paitan.author: Catherine W.
tori paitan.review:
The short: organic shoyu ramen hits the spot

If you're not one of the first in line, be prepared to wait about an hour. This place seats about 30 people max, with 2 very long tables, and some seats facing the kitchen. Also be prepared for sitting at a communal table. Some people don't like this...? I don't mind, as long as I have elbow room and have good food!

While in line, we checked out the menu and had a face palm moment when I realized that the description described the items below. Basically, the items below the header start with the basic bowl, and increase in price for additional items. So the four categories are: tori paitan (most ordered based on pictures and reviews), shoyu (what I ordered), shio, and vegan tantanmen.

When the shoyu ramen arrived, I quickly dug in because I was so hungry. The duck chasu and pork chasu was tender, perfectly cooked, and enhanced the broth (wishing there were doubles of each!). Even the kale was an unusual, but nice addition. The broth was perfect, not salty or oily. And the noodles were chewy! At first, it doesn't look like there's a lot of noodles, but the bowl is shaped quite deeply at the bottom, so all the noodles are hidden there. There was so much I liked about this ramen. 

I couldn't figure out what the seasonings on the table were, though there was pink himalayan salt, and maybe some other seasonings to personally enhance the broth to the right taste. I didn't need to as I liked it the way it was.

The waiter was very kind and smiling, which is something I don't see too often. All the seating is on stools, and there are baskets on the ground for bags. The whole inside has a clean and modern aesthetic, with a living wall at the entrance, descriptions of the different types of ramen, and a view into the kitchen. So exciting!

One downside is that this isn't a place to sit and chat after you've eaten the food. Somebody will kindly let you know that there are other patrons outside who are waiting.

It's hard to say if I would wait in line for another hour, but I would come back to arrive right around opening so I don't have to wait so long. Thanks for the experience Mensho!

excerpts: We ordered the oysters in shoyu dare oil to share and for myself, I got the tori paitan ramen with double chashu (because dammit, I waited too long in line to limit myself).
Tori Paitan Ramen (Double Chashu) $18: WOW!
The chicken broth was so rich and creamy.
I would expect it to be salty judging from the look of it
but it wasn't although it was SUPER FLAVORFUL.
In fact, most of the salty taste came from the pork chashu.
The pork chashu broke apart easily with my chopsticks and melts in my mouth with each bite.
Duck chashu was interesting since it had a slight lemon-y flavor.
I definitely enjoyed the pork more.
The noodles were thick (chow mein thick) and chewy.
Tori Paitan Ramen (Double Chashu) $18: WOW!
The chicken broth was so rich and creamy.
I would expect it to be salty judging from the look of it
but it wasn't although it was SUPER FLAVORFUL.
In fact, most of the salty taste came from the pork chashu.
The pork chashu broke apart easily with my chopsticks and melts in my mouth with each bite.
Duck chashu was interesting since it had a slight lemon-y flavor.
I definitely enjoyed the pork more.
The noodles were thick (chow mein thick) and chewy.
tori paitan.author: Diana C.
tori paitan.review:
Pencil in an hour or two of waiting. But it's worth it. 

Mensho Tokyo opens at 5pm and so my friend and I came here at exactly 5pm. There was already a long line waiting outside the restaurant. Were they there since 4pm or just five minutes ago? I have no clue but 5 minutes later, half of the line went in so my heart skipped a beat at the possibility of having my wait time reduced in half. Even then, we waited for at least another hour and 15 minutes until we were finally seated. At reaching the top of the line, there was still a good thirty people behind us. 

There is no wait list to put your name down or reservations. You do it the good old fashioned stand and wait your turn. Finding parking in this area can be a hassle but there is parking across the street that is free and available after 6pm assuming you can snag the spot (it is a no stopping zone before 6pm). The restaurant is quite small and there's two rows of tables. The front row was one long table and the back row near the windows was sectioned off into two separate tables. It's communal seating so you may be sitting with other parties if you are a small group. I was sitting in the back row near the windows and our table seated 7 so our party of 3 was seated with two other parties of 2. If you're eating by yourself, you may be lucky enough to move up in line since you can sit with the odd number groups. 

We ordered the oysters in shoyu dare oil to share and for myself, I got the tori paitan ramen with double chashu (because dammit, I waited too long in line to limit myself). 

Oysters: For $5, you get four pieces although I counted five unless one oyster cloned itself. They're really tiny pieces and the Yelp photos are a lie when you see the close-up and think it's bigger than it really is (so sorry, my photo is now a lie). It's a little salty but still kind of tasty if you're into oysters. I'm definitely used to raw oysters with the lemon and marinara so it was a bit strange to taste cooked oysters in soy sauce. A good starting appetizer as you wait for your ramen. 

Tori Paitan Ramen (Double Chashu) $18: WOW! The chicken broth was so rich and creamy. I would expect it to be salty judging from the look of it but it wasn't although it was SUPER FLAVORFUL. In fact, most of the salty taste came from the pork chashu. The pork chashu broke apart easily with my chopsticks and melts in my mouth with each bite. Duck chashu was interesting since it had a slight lemon-y flavor. I definitely enjoyed the pork more. The noodles were thick (chow mein thick) and chewy. You get a big silver ladle spoon so you can spoon up both the delicious broth along with your thick noodles.

Be prepared to open up your wallet and drop almost $20 a person. With three bowls of ramen and oysters, we paid about $75 with tax and tips. Thankfully it's not cash only and they do take card. To the side of the restaurant, they have a single unisex bathroom that is quite spacious for such a small restaurant.

excerpts: I tried the Tori Paitan and Spicy Lamb broth.
The noodle was impressively fresh and the meat were soft and delicious.
My only complaint was the soup flavor.
Tori Paitan broth was flavorful and smell perfect, but the taste was too salty for me
(this is coming from someone who dip my fries with salt).
It would be nice if i can ask for 3/4 salt or something.
tori paitan.author: Ivana L.
tori paitan.review:
Waited until now to try out this ramen shop with the hope the hype will be slowing down. Finally was able to try it and was not impress up to my expectation. To be fair, I have tried almost all of the popular ramen shops around Bay Area and few locations in Asia (including Ippudo in Kyoto). 

I tried the Tori Paitan and Spicy Lamb broth. The noodle was impressively fresh and the meat were soft and delicious. My only complaint was the soup flavor. Tori Paitan broth was flavorful and smell perfect, but the taste was too salty for me (this is coming from someone who dip my fries with salt).
