It would be nice if i can ask for 3/4 salt or something. Spicy lamb was creamy and not very spicy, but you def had the curry like smell.

For $18 per bowl, I don't think its something I would rave about. 

I would stick going down to San Mateo or Sunnyvale for my ramen crave..

excerpts: I'd recommend trying the Tori Paitan ramen with extra chashu the first time you're here.
tori paitan.author: Edward W.
tori paitan.review:
I came at 830pm on a Saturday night and surprisingly only waited around 30-35 minutes. I'd recommend trying the Tori Paitan ramen with extra chashu the first time you're here.

The duck chashu was so tender and fatty and it surpassed all my expectations! The pork chashu was also quite fatty and delicious. The chicken soup base was surprisingly heavy and rich and the noodles were of average chewiness. I also had a chance to try my friend's vegan ramen and it was surprisingly delicious! The soup base is the perfect mixture of soy and peanut. Plenty of peanut flavor that doesn't overpower the rest of the flavors. 

The communal seating makes it a bit difficult to hear across the table because the restaurant is quite small and the voices echo. I love that the restaurant provides boxes underneath the table to store your bulkier items. The table also has space inbetween for smaller items like a phone or purse.

Service was quick and efficient.

excerpts: I got the Tori Paitan ramen.
Definitely will come back here again even if I have to stand outside for over an hour.
Lol.
But it's that good.
tori paitan.author: Joelle L.
tori paitan.review: Best ramen I've ever had. The broth is so creamy and flavorful, but it gets really thick by the time you get to the bottom and bowl and cools down! I recommend getting the extra chashu, it's so worth it. But be warned, this is a  pretty big bowl of ramen so come hungry! I got the Tori Paitan ramen. :) Definitely will come back here again even if I have to stand outside for over an hour. Lol. But it's that good. ;)

excerpts: We ordered the Tori Paitan, Organic Shoyu and Shio.
Favorite of the three?
Tie between Tori Paitan and Shoyu.
They both have the DELICIOUS DUCK CHASHU but otherwise very different bowls of ramen.
Tori Paitan's rich creamy broth is hard to compare to the lightness of the shoyu.
Compared to other shoyu broths at other restaurants, Mensho's is definitely one of the better bowls.
Great noodles all around.
tori paitan.author: Samantha L.
tori paitan.review:
This line is only for the patient and determined. Got there 15 min before opening on a weekday and the wait was 80 minutes. Right in the "TenderNob", there were we a few beggars hassling the line but Mensho Tokyo was trying the best they could to ask them politely not bother the customers in line. I don't know if there's any way to really get around this with all the hype! 

Oysters: Tiny little oysters in shoyu dare oil. They were served cold and not quite appetizing. Dark brown in color from the oil ost likely, oddly very shriveled and almost chewy. Flavor was okay but not what i was hoping.

We ordered the Tori Paitan, Organic Shoyu and Shio. Favorite of the three? Tie between Tori Paitan and Shoyu. They both have the DELICIOUS DUCK CHASHU but otherwise very different bowls of ramen. Tori Paitan's rich creamy broth is hard to compare to the lightness of the shoyu. Compared to other shoyu broths at other restaurants, Mensho's is definitely one of the better bowls. Great noodles all around.

excerpts: All 4 of us ordered the tori paitan ramen ($16), which was seemingly the most popular!
The tori paitan was incredibly flavorful, creamy, and THICK!
Like others have said, the tori paitan broth has more of a sauce or gravy-like consistency rather than your normal thinner broth.
If you don't like heavy meals...
don't get the tori paitan.
The tori paitan broth got a bit too rich as I was finishing the bowl.
However, I enjoyed it!
tori paitan.author: Tara A.
tori paitan.review:
Authentic ramen from Japan? Count me in!!! 

My friends and I lined up at 4 pm and we were 2nd in line. By 4:30 pm, the line was growing. We only waited an hour compared to some of the crazy 3 hours that other people have waited. All 4 of us ordered the tori paitan ramen ($16), which was seemingly the most popular! We were all really excited especially just to be some of the first people in the restaurant. 

The tori paitan was incredibly flavorful, creamy, and THICK! Like others have said, the tori paitan broth has more of a sauce or gravy-like consistency rather than your normal thinner broth. If you don't like heavy meals... don't get the tori paitan. You're probably better off with the lighter shoyu or shio ramen (both look delicious!). The tori paitan broth got a bit too rich as I was finishing the bowl. However, I enjoyed it! I normally order tonkotsu at ramen places, so the chicken flavor was definitely something different to try out. 

The noodles are round and thicker than your average (think chow mein noodle size), but perfectly cooked and chewy. As for the toppings, the chasu was melt in your mouth delicious, but the duck was subpar for me. My friends and I also thought there should be a little more veggies just to lighten up the heavy bowl. I liked the bonito flakes, but the small amounts of kale and bamboo shoots did not cut it for us. But we did really like the toppings on the tables! The red salt was something we'd never seen before, and the other brown seasoning (smells like bonito flakes) was pretty tasty.

By the time we left at 6 pm, the line outside was crazy! If you don't like waiting, definitely don't come around that time. You're better off coming anywhere from 4-4:30 pm. The restaurant seats less than 30 people at one time, and it seems like there's a slow turnover rate. Mensho was good, but I probably wouldn't wait 2-3 hours for it.

excerpts: I've ordered the tori paitan and spicy miso lamb ramen here.
The tori paitan is a solid ramen, rich broth (a little on the salty side), chewy noodles, fall-apart-chashu pieces and some garnish.
It's definitely not worth $20 (incl. tip & tax) though.
I just don't think it's special enough to warrant the wait and price.
The spicy miso lamb ramen is more unique - it's definitely spicy enough to make you sweat, and the lamb is cooked really well.
Haven't tried any of the special seasonal ramens, but I would come back to try those next.
Also, if you're with 1-2 others, definitely order the fried enoki!
It's a great starter and a unique dish.
tori paitan.author: Ada C.
tori paitan.review:
Even though Mensho's been open for a while now, there's always a wait when I go. There's a trick to minimize your wait time though - on weekends, I've been there at 4:30 to wait for the first seating, and at weeknights things tend to calm down after 6PM. The service is impeccable and fast (they automatically add a 15% tip to all bills) and all of the servers want to make sure you have a good experience while getting everyone in and out of the small space. 

I've ordered the tori paitan and spicy miso lamb ramen here. The tori paitan is a solid ramen, rich broth (a little on the salty side), chewy noodles, fall-apart-chashu pieces and some garnish. It's definitely not worth $20 (incl. tip & tax) though. I just don't think it's special enough to warrant the wait and price. The spicy miso lamb ramen is more unique - it's definitely spicy enough to make you sweat, and the lamb is cooked really well. Haven't tried any of the special seasonal ramens, but I would come back to try those next. Also, if you're with 1-2 others, definitely order the fried enoki! It's a great starter and a unique dish.

excerpts: I got the Tori Paitan Ramen.
IMO, way greasy.
I know, I know, its like eating fried chicken and wanting it to be healthy.
Blah blah.
I did actually like the flavor and consistency of the broth; quite viscous and oily (perfect for coating ramen!).
The duck was actually very well cooked
and so was the chasu.
We also got the shoyu ramen.
I love the noodles of this bowl.
Thin and wavy.
The broth was also a lot less greasy, but still flavorful.
My friend just got back from Japan and said that he actually preferred the ramen here to some that he had on holidays.
tori paitan.author: Crystal Z.
tori paitan.review:
TL;DR - Hype worthy? You betcha. Personally, I'm just not that into ramen anymore. (I kinda consider it a sick-day kinda craving)

Wait time. Honestly, not terrible. Showed up at 7:30 and only took us about 20 minutes. 

Inside, clean and compact. I love that they have the baskets on the floor for your stuff. -Ahem- Us ladies and our purses.

Finally, food. I got the Tori Paitan Ramen. IMO, way greasy. I know, I know, its like eating fried chicken and wanting it to be healthy. Blah blah. I did actually like the flavor and consistency of the broth; quite viscous and oily (perfect for coating ramen!). The duck was actually very well cooked and so was the chasu. We also got the shoyu ramen. I love the noodles of this bowl. Thin and wavy. The broth was also a lot less greasy, but still flavorful. My friend just got back from Japan and said that he actually preferred the ramen here to some that he had on holidays. Haha.

Side note, this is the only ramen place I've ever seen that charges more for a vegetarian dish than a meat dish. What a shame. Not sure if I would be willing to drop $20 for veggie ramen, ya dig?

Overall, yes, the 4-star rating of Mensho is pretty accurate. But if ramen isn't your thing, I'd pass on Mensho as there are plenty of other places to dine in SF.

excerpts: I ordered the Tori Paitan - rich, creamy chicken broth which is more like gravy.
Thick, savory and packed with flavor.
The noodles are thick and just the right texture.
The chashu....ahhh, yes, PORK AND DUCK!
So tender it melts in your mouth.
Their ramen is a little bit hipster with substituting kale instead of seaweed which works but (insert sad face)
NO EGG!!
Nonetheless the ramen is one of the better joints in the Bay.
tori paitan.author: Caye Q.
tori paitan.review:
As a Bay Area native I'm used to waiting in line for good food but lining up like you did in grade school, single file is another thing! The question is whether or not Mensho Tokyo is worth this process, well is it? The answer is YES. 

The long awaited Mesho Tokyo has lived up to the hype - the ramen is hella good. I ordered the Tori Paitan - rich, creamy chicken broth which is more like gravy. Thick, savory and packed with flavor. The noodles are thick and just the right texture. The chashu....ahhh, yes, PORK AND DUCK! So tender it melts in your mouth. Their ramen is a little bit hipster with substituting kale instead of seaweed which works but (insert sad face) NO EGG!! Nonetheless the ramen is one of the better joints in the Bay. I can't wait to try the vegan tantanmen, thats if I can ever find time to wait in that damn line.

ps Don't bother with the oyster appetizer, it was meh. Save your appetite for the ramen.

excerpts: (1) Tori Paitan:
Rich, creamy chicken soup, pork chashu, duck chashu, menma, kale, burdock, katsuobushi sauce | double chashu $18
The only other ramen shop that offers Tori Paitan is Nojo Ramen Tavern (that I'm aware of).
I tried Nojo's last night and there's absolutely no comparison.
The duo of chashu were perfection just like in the Tori Paitan ramen.
The broth contains soy cream and 7 kinds of nuts, producing a creamy kotteri broth that looked similar to the Tori Paitan.
tori paitan.author: Cherylynn N.
tori paitan.review:
4.5 STARS

San Franciscans love shiny new places (and things). 

When it comes to the hottest new restaurant and food trends, many of us spare no expense with our paycheck (and time).

Last year, it was $8 for toast. Ok, not just "toast" but phuckin' bougie, tweezified toast. 

This year, it's $15 coffee (for one cup!) and $18 ramen.

Because, San Francisco! 

Next year, I'm bracing myself for $100 pizza. Oh wait, we already had that during the super bowl (well, I didn't but it was available at Tony's Pizza Napoletana). 

Seriously, what's next? 

Kindly let me know so I can start harvesting my eggs to sell! 

$18 ramen may sound crazy but people waited 3+ hours for this ramen on opening night! 

$18 for a taste of Tokyo? Why not! 

Mensho's first U.S. location is one of the most, if not the most highly anticipated restaurant opening this year in SF! 

Tip: Come at 4 pm (earlier on the weekends) or after 10 pm to avoid long wait times. 

Currently, Mensho has 4 ramen options available ($9-$18) with a single or double chashu option. When the owner returns from Japan in March, their menu will expand. No housemade noodles yet. They have a noodle machine but are awaiting permit(s) to use it (same for the tonkotsu equipment). Disappointingly no marinated soft boiled egg is available but maybe in the future? Beer only; no sake, soda, or juice.

My friend and I ordered three bowls of ramen to share:

(1) Tori Paitan: Rich, creamy chicken soup, pork chashu, duck chashu, menma, kale, burdock, katsuobushi sauce | double chashu $18
http://bit.ly/1XrzETT

Our favorite of the three, the kotteri broth was deliciously creamy (gravy-like) and richly satisfying. It had great depth of umami flavor but did get a bit gritty mid-way. The al-dente noodles were thick, springy, and had a fantastic toothsome chew. 

The chashu is sublime so pony up the extra $ and double up on it! The pork chashu is melt-in-your-mouth tender, like pork butter. It's so ridiculously tender, it falls apart when you pick it up. The duck chashu is silky smooth and chews effortlessly.

The only other ramen shop that offers Tori Paitan is Nojo Ramen Tavern (that I'm aware of). I tried Nojo's last night and there's absolutely no comparison. Mensho's is infinitely superior. 

(2) Organic Shoyu: Organic chicken + pork soup, shoyu dare, pork chashu, duck chashu, kale, kale sprouts, chives, menma, nori | double chashu $16
http://bit.ly/1QfmuKm

A much lighter assari broth but saltier with a slight sweetness since it's a soy sauce based. The duo of chashu were perfection just like in the Tori Paitan ramen. I didn't like the noodles which were overcooked, flat, and lacked chew. 

(3) Shio: Organic chicken + pork soup, shio dare, pork chashu, kale, menma, chives, fried garlic, nori | double chashu $11
http://bit.ly/1Loeijq

The most affordable bowl available, the shio ramen was simple and pure. The assari broth was light and salty but still had depth. Same delicious chashu as the other bowls but the noodles were disappointing like the shoyu ramen. In this bowl, not only were the noodles overcooked, there were two clumps. *sad pouty lip*

(4) Vegan Tantanmen | $18
I'm kicking myself for NOT ordering this too because I love nuts! The broth contains soy cream and 7 kinds of nuts, producing a creamy kotteri broth that looked similar to the Tori Paitan.

I washed everything down with a Sansho beer ($11.75): http://bit.ly/1Px6vnx. Beer usually tastes like carbonated piss to me but this one was refreshing with a gingery lemon spice. Loved it but not the price. 

Service is a work in progress which is understandable since this is Mensho's first foray in the U.S.. They only let 8 or so customers in at a time to not overwhelm the kitchen. They don't fire up orders by tickets, instead they prepare the ramen by type (they really should do the former). We received our order at different times and after people who ordered after us. If your companion(s) orders different ramen than yourself, be prepared to start eating first before the noodles get soggy. 

When I was line I met one of the restaurant partners, Abram aka Ramen Beast. He was uber nice and offered to answer any questions I had. Really cool guy! 

The space is small and only seats 28 - two communal tables and four seats at the counter. We choose to sit at the counter. There's more privacy (if you're on a date) and you can watch the chefs in action.

Read all signs before parking. Do NOT park on Geary from 4-6 pm (tow-away zone) on the weekdays, otherwise your $18 bowl of ramen will turn into a $618+ bowl of ramen. 

Because, San Francisco!

excerpts: Once we got in, we both ordered the Tori Paitan Ramen (Double Chashu) $18.
Best decision ever.
It was filled with mouthwatering noodles, tender Duck and Pork Chashu, Kale, Menma, Burdock and Katsuobushi Sauce.
The broth itself was rich, creamy and just overall yummy.
It was piping hot too, which was a plus.
Unfortunately, there wasn't an option to add a soft boiled egg yet.
tori paitan.author: Chinsin S.
tori paitan.review:
Solid five-star ramen place in San Francisco. To be honest, I never heard about MENSHO TOKYO until they came to the Bay Area, but decided to check it out based on the hype.

**Side announcement: The wait staff was super friendly and informative. I definitely loved their customer experience, especially when they work at such a fast-pace and crowded restaurant like this one**

Our party of 2 waited for about an hour or so after 10 pm, which wasn't too bad! The only thing that was a bit concerning was the neighborhood and constant loiters. Parking was tricky too, so I'd definitely recommend taking an Uber here. *PRO TIP: Send one of your friends to wait in line if you need to find parking. There's no list, but just a straight up old school line.*

Once we got in, we both ordered the Tori Paitan Ramen (Double Chashu) $18. Best decision ever. It was filled with mouthwatering noodles, tender Duck and Pork Chashu, Kale, Menma, Burdock and Katsuobushi Sauce. The broth itself was rich, creamy and just overall yummy. It was piping hot too, which was a plus. Unfortunately, there wasn't an option to add a soft boiled egg yet. Bummer, but the staff said it was coming soon!

The noodles themselves were thicker than usual, which was unique and different. I actually enjoyed them. They were perfectly cooked and chewy. The Chasu was so amazing that they melted in my mouth. I was indifferent about the Duck Chashu and leaned more towards the Pork Chashu.

Overall, this a great ramen place. It's probably in the the top 5 Bay Area ramen places by far. I was hesitant at first, but this place was definitely delicious beyond disbelief! I'm a MENSHO TOKYO fan.

excerpts: Looks like I should have gotten the Tori Paitan since everyone on here is raving about that one's broth.
tori paitan.author: Shanise M.
tori paitan.review:
Our group had just finished up at Wilson & Wilson. After splurging on drinks there it was pretty difficult for me to dive right into some pricey ramen! But we were all ready for some drunchies.

We got here at 11 and asked for a seat for 4. Another customer came up behind us and said with a surprised tone, 'There's no line!?' I just told him that we're the line. I was confused too because I thought, why would there be? But now that I've actually seen the reviews and pictures... I now get it. Didn't realize this spot was THAT poppin' lol. I'm always wary about restaurants that have crazy lines - usually it doesn't meet the hype... not for me at least.

We were seated in no time. I love the communal tables! And I actually really like the small space haha, reminds me of a lot of shops I've been in throughout Asia.

Since I had just burned through my wallet on drinks, I opted for the lower priced Shio Ramen w/ Chasiu ($9 something, ~$11 w/ tip and tax). Food came out surprisingly fast. I was kinda sad that there wasn't much in my bowl. Everything was delicious but I want a lot more for the price! Everything definitely tasted top quality but when you only get one piece of meat, it kinda has you scratching your head. Broth was great. Looks like I should have gotten the Tori Paitan since everyone on here is raving about that one's broth.

I'll stick to my cheap, hefty ramen shops for now. I like quality and quantity - but, this was definitely a nice treat for one splurge-y night!

excerpts: Their Tori Paitan is so incredibly luxurious and rich
it's almost too much goodness in a bowl.
tori paitan.author: Vivian C.
tori paitan.review:
I can't say I've ever had a ramen that would make me want to wait in a line that goes out the door but Mensho Tokyo comes close. Their Tori Paitan is so incredibly luxurious and rich it's almost too much goodness in a bowl. Not going to lie, you will probably feel like crap after a while but at least you get some joy before the regret.

Came on a weekend for dinner with a friend. I arrived about 30 minutes early and was able to get in after about 50 minutes of waiting (including the early half hour). The shop itself is very small and has very few seats. The seats that are there are honestly very uncomfortable. The tables are communal style and since they're high chairs I kept feeling like I was going to fall off and knock someone over. However, the product may be worth at least some of the suffering. This soup is so delicious, I can't believe they didn't just dump cream into it. I do find it a bit salty but I usually do. The noodles had a great bite to them as well. The chashu was good and bad. The fatty portions were tender and delicious but the rest was just average. Overall a delicious bowl of ramen but wish there were more items to help lighten it a bit.

I also ordered the oysters appetizer. I'm going to be frank. I did not enjoy these at all. I didn't quite know what to expect. It seems to be cured in shoyu so it has almost a liver/kidney like texture but much saltier. I could see myself enjoying this with a big bowl of plain porridge but it is not enjoyable at all when it's accompanying a bowl of salty rich ramen.

Overall, the seating is miserable, the wait is miserable, and the price isn't great, but the ramen itself is good. While there are better places out there, they really do make one heck of a broth here.

excerpts: Okay.. I got the Tori Paitan and even though it was the most recommended ramen here on Yelp, I didn't exactly enjoy it because the broth was way too thick and creamy for my preference.
I felt like I was eating clam chowder with noodles soaked right in.
The duck and pork chashu was melt in your mouth goodness however.
Additionally I got the oysters for the appetizer and it was okay
was well.
tori paitan.author: Jenny N.
tori paitan.review:
Did I really just waited 3 hours for ramen? Yes
Did I really just spent $18 on one bowl of ramen? Yes
Did the waiter forgot our order? Yes
How was the food? 
Okay.. I got the Tori Paitan and even though it was the most recommended ramen here on Yelp, I didn't exactly enjoy it because the broth was way too thick and creamy for my preference. I felt like I was eating clam chowder with noodles soaked right in. The duck and pork chashu was melt in your mouth goodness however. Additionally I got the oysters for the appetizer and it was okay was well. Nothing in particular stood out about them other than they tasted exactly what they're suppose to be, cooked oysters.

Would I come back? Yes.. probably when the lines are shorter and to try the other ramens that they have.

excerpts: I ordered the Tori Paitan Ramen and bf ordered the same thing with chashu (to this day I kick myself for not ordering something different but at the time I wanted to try their most popular dish and wasn't sure if I would be happy just having half).
tori paitan.author: Noelle H.
tori paitan.review:
I saw that Mensho Tokyo's Grand Opening would be Saturday at 6pm. I figured if we couldn't see Alicia Keys for free, we should try and at least try some authentic ramen. 

Alicia Keys was a no since it was wayy over capacity. So me and the bf headed on over to Mensho Tokyo. We arrived at 5:30 and the line was fairly long ( I think there was about 70 people in front of us?). But I was determined to try it! 

After 3.5 hours standing outside in line (this was by far the longest I have ever waited for anything, so the expectations were high!) we were finally in front of the door and we were seated at the bar in the back. In my opinion, those 4 seats are the best seats in the house! You don't have eager people staring at you the entire time you're eating and you're seating facing the kitchen!

Drink orders were taken and we immediately placed our order for ramen. I ordered the Tori Paitan Ramen and bf ordered the same thing with chashu (to this day I kick myself for not ordering something different but at the time I wanted to try their most popular dish and wasn't sure if I would be happy just having half). 

This was my first time having paitan ramen and I loved it! So incredibly rich and flavorful, almost gravy like. The noodles were thick and chewy, by far the best I've ever had! I'm not a fan of pork and usually don't eat it, but the chasu was OUT OF THIS WORLD. Super tender and melt in your mouth. All the components that came in the bowl complimented each other well and it indeed, was a spectacular bowl of ramen. 

Was it worth the 3.5 hour wait? Yes, I believe it was. It was also the most expensive bowl of ramen I've ever paid for, but I think it was worth it as well. 

If you're willing to wait, then come here!!! You'll be rewarded with the best ramen in the Bay!

excerpts: I tried Tori Paitan and it was good the first few bites but it became really salty.
tori paitan.author: Leilani Y.
tori paitan.review:
3.5 STARS.

Came here on Tuesday at 9:00pm thinking the line wouldn't be as long during this time, but I still ended up waiting a little over an hour..

I tried Tori Paitan and it was good the first few bites but it became really salty. The broth is very thick, creamy and very flavorful! 

The two things I really liked  in my ramen bowl were the noodles and the chasu! 
The handmade ramen noodles were just cooked to perfection! I never had ramen with this consistency before so it was pretty interesting. 
As for the Chasu...it just... melts in your mouth..

However, the broth just got too salty near the end and my taste buds felt like they were shivering up T_T.

All in all, this place is definitely worth a try. Still good ramen and experience, but I would rather wait an hour for Ramen Dojo in San Mateo.

excerpts: and I both chose the spicy Tori Paitan Ramen
and it came out pretty quickly!!
Instantly you can tell the broth is going to be thick and fatty..yumm!!
The noodles were the perfect amount of chewy and thickness and the pork belly was seasoned really well.
I have a small appetite
so I usually don't finish my food at restaurants, but I cleared my bowl :
If you're a fan of thick and fatty ramen broths I would recommend this place, but if you prefer more clean and lighter broths, maybe get the shoyu?
tori paitan.author: Hannah C.
tori paitan.review:
Mensho ramen is one the best places in the bay area to get ramen ( in my opinion), BUT the wait is realllllyyy long :(!! My boyfriend and I waited 2 hours in the FREEZING WINDY COLD weather in San Fran :/ but the wait was worth it!! The shop is really small so we understood why the line was so long.
My boyfriend and I got seated in front of the kitchen so we got to see the chefs make the ramen which was pretty cool! My boyfriend and I both chose the spicy Tori Paitan Ramen and it came out pretty quickly!! 
Instantly you can tell the broth is going to be thick and fatty..yumm!! The noodles were the perfect amount of chewy and thickness and the pork belly was seasoned really well. 
I have a small appetite so I usually don't finish my food at restaurants, but I cleared my bowl :D!! 
If you're a fan of thick and fatty ramen broths I would recommend this place, but if you prefer more clean and lighter broths, maybe get the shoyu?

excerpts:
* *
Tori Paitan Ramen: A+.
Oh boy that soup base
.... it was the thickest/creamiest ramen soup I have ever tasted.
I almost  regard that as a paste.
The taste was super rich and flavorful yet non-oily nor too salty.
After weeks I still remember how the soup tasted like.
It came with both pork and duck chashu; pork was tender as expected but the duck was surprisingly juicy as well.
The noodle was also one of the thickest I have tried with spongy texture.
The whole presentation definitely makes this the best ramen I have ever tried in the US without a doubt.
tori paitan.author: Simon C.
tori paitan.review:
After reading the raving reviews of this place I had been wanting to try this place so badly. On a weekend night I was done with gym close by and got pretty hungry, so I decided to just forget my workout and gain all my calories back...!

* * * EXPERIENCE * * *
Pros:
- Friendly staff (even though the place was always full and they were working nonstop)
- Simple and neat decorations and furnitures
- TV which was showing an interview with the founder/owner of this place explaining the uniqueness of their food (for ramen enthusiast)
- Food came fairly quickly

Cons:
- Looooooong wait outside the restaurant: Thursday night, started lining up at 8:30pm, waited for 1 whole hour
- Kind of pricey
- Cramped interior (almost elbow to elbow)

* * * FOOD * * *
Tori Paitan Ramen: A+.
Oh boy that soup base.... it was the thickest/creamiest ramen soup I have ever tasted. I almost  regard that as a paste. The taste was super rich and flavorful yet non-oily nor too salty. After weeks I still remember how the soup tasted like. It came with both pork and duck chashu; pork was tender as expected but the duck was surprisingly juicy as well. The noodle was also one of the thickest I have tried with spongy texture. The whole presentation definitely makes this the best ramen I have ever tried in the US without a doubt. With double chashu this ramen cost $18, SF price on the high side.

Sansho Beer: B+.
Yes, I did order that $11.75/11.5oz beer. How could a beer be so expensive I was thinking. Well, it did have its own unique flavor - it's an interesting combination of herbs, peppercorn into a beer, and it did go well with the thick ramen soup in a way that it flushed out the soup taste from the last bite so that every next bite was new and refreshing. But after all, I still have to say this beer is VERY expensive.

I absolutely cannot wait to go back either to get the same ramen again, or the Tantanmen looks very interesting to me too.

excerpts: We ordered one of the signature Tori Paitan and one of the spicy lamb ramen.
Tori Paitan - The pork and duck chasu are both to die for.
Each bowl of ramen is already pretty pricey, but I'd totally pay additional for more of the duck chasu.
The noodles are perfectly all dente.
I honestly don't remember much about the spicy lamb ramen other than it was good, but I prefer the Tori Paitan more.
tori paitan.author: Judy C.
tori paitan.review:
Came here on a rainy weeknight and scored a seat within a 20 minutes since the rest of San Francisco decided to stay at home and stay dry. So worth braving the rain for this. We ordered one of the signature Tori Paitan and one of the spicy lamb ramen. 

Tori Paitan - The pork and duck chasu are both to die for. Each bowl of ramen is already pretty pricey, but I'd totally pay additional for more of the duck chasu. The noodles are perfectly all dente. The frothy broth was very unique and full of umami (although if you don't like thick broth, you might not like Mensho). 

I honestly don't remember much about the spicy lamb ramen other than it was good, but I prefer the Tori Paitan more.

excerpts: The Tori Paitan ($16 or $18 with DOUBLE Pork/Duck) is super frothy and tasty - the broth was super thick, almost  like a flavorful sauce.
The DUCK was mind-blowingly good.
tori paitan.author: Veronica S.
tori paitan.review:
SLURPILICIOUS !!!!!!!

Ramen - it's one of those comfort foods that anyone can appreciate!

Started getting hooked onto ramen a decade ago and my favorites include Santouka, Dojo, Santa, & Parlor. I've been following the Mensho opening for a few months and for the past few two months I've walked past it every week to monitor the progress of their construction/opening. Finally saw their plans to open up in February, but each time we thought about going, the lines were overwhelming so I made it a plan to come here on a weeknight 30 minutes before opening.

This is definitely one of the best ramens I've ever had - it's delicate but delicious and exploding in flavor. The SHIO ($9 or $11 with DOUBLE Pork) tasted so clean but I loved the chewy, al dente noodles. The pork melted in my mouth and I didn't even need to sink my teeth in the meat whatsoever. The Tori Paitan ($16 or $18 with DOUBLE Pork/Duck) is super frothy and tasty - the broth was super thick, almost  like a flavorful sauce. The DUCK was mind-blowingly good. I haven't had duck so tender in so long.

The restaurant is casual but comfortable. With the exception of the 4 seats at the "bar" (low seats), most of these tables are communal and you're obligated to share your place with others- so come here for a casual meal with close friends/loved ones - probably not the best location for a business meeting or something of that nature.

They do have a 1-hour limit BUT they serve beer so they ultimately let you enjoy your meal/drinks and don't rush you at all. It's not like in Japan where you sit, slurp slurp, and leave. I still felt like I had a really pleasant experience where I sat, drank, observed, ate, slurped, ate, drank some more, then left - completely satisfied.

Worth it!

excerpts: the portions here are not huge but they're very very heavy given the amount of fat that's in the tori paitan.
tori paitan.author: Annie Z.
tori paitan.review:
I love ramen, I really do and Mensho is definitely an amazing ramen place. HOWEVER, I honestly would not wait in line for 30 minutes again or pay another $25 for mensho. While I thought the flavor was delicious and I enjoyed the chewy-ness of my noodles. I do not think it's mind-blowingly better than other options such as orenchi beyond, or shalala before they closed. This location is tiny and on a cold SF day, you're better off eating at a different ramen joint and not getting sick. the portions here are not huge but they're very very heavy given the amount of fat that's in the tori paitan. 

I would stop by again to try the Shio or the Shoyu one day when there isn't a ridiculously long wait.

excerpts: I ordered the tori paitan ramen with double chashu.
Broth was salty.
I usually don't drink the broth but with this bowl, it was different!
I kept wanting more!
Had to restrain myself.
The ramen was pretty simple with the toppings.
In addition to the chashu, toppings came with lettuce, kale, chives, and what I think was fried garlic skin?
Was super sad that they didn't have the soft boiled egg offered as a topping!
The chashu was melt-in-your-mouth amazing!
Glad
tori paitan.author: Cynthia T.
tori paitan.review:
TLDR: clean place, long wait, delicious ramen, limited menu, friendly service, will try again for sure! 

Thank goodness I had my friends go first and met them there. They got there at 6:45 and we finally got in at 8pm. This place is very very small. They have four tables that fits six people each and the bar that fits four people. 

It was raining today. Quite surprised by the amount of people willing to wait in this weather!Next to the entryway, they have hooks numbered 1-10 to hang up your belongings. If the hooks are all occupied, no need to fret! They have baskets under the tables to put your belongings in as well! Very clever idea that I think more places need to implement! The place is very very clean! 

I ordered the tori paitan ramen with double chashu.  Broth was salty. I usually don't drink the broth but with this bowl, it was different! I kept wanting more! Had to restrain myself. The ramen was pretty simple with the toppings. In addition to the chashu, toppings came with lettuce, kale, chives, and what I think was fried garlic skin? Was super sad that they didn't have the soft boiled egg offered as a topping! The chashu was melt-in-your-mouth amazing! Glad I got the double for sure. 

Service was super friendly! Constantly came around to check if everything was okay at our table and refilled our waters. Limited menu so I'll definitely be back to try their other ramen bowls!

excerpts: I got the Tori Paitan ramen since they don't have tonkotsu on the soft opening menu yet.
The soup was SUPER thick, rich, and creamy, almost like a chicken stew broth.
It was rich but at just the right amount of salty.
tori paitan.author: Hoyan L.
tori paitan.review:
So happy to see SF finally expanding on its ramen scene! I have been waiting to give this place a try since the grand opening day on Saturday, but the mob of people on grand opening day was crazy! We left and came back on a weekday night around 8:30pm and the wait was only about 40 minutes, even shorter if you are a solo diner! 

I got the Tori Paitan ramen since they don't have tonkotsu on the soft opening menu yet. The soup was SUPER thick, rich, and creamy, almost like a chicken stew broth. It was rich but at just the right amount of salty. It was a little on the heavy side, so you prefer lighter soup, you should go for shio or shoyu. 

The noodles were cooked to perfect al dente, thicker than usual which gave a very nice chew. The duck chashu was luxurious and tender. The pork chashu was melt in your mouth good. Towards the later half of my ramen, I started tasting these little bits of grit or sandy like texture in the broth which threw me off a little bit (hence not perfect 5 stars) I'm not sure if that is how the broth should be? 

They are still working out the kinks (i.e., not giving me a pen to sign my credit card txn, forgot about refilling water, etc), but I am pretty excited about this new ramen place in SF and I can't wait to go back to try their tonkotsu and tsukemen when they become available! This place still hasn't won the Orenchi spot in my heart yet though, and also Tenderloin is sketchy at night.

I was debating if I should visit this place some more to try their other ramen before writing a yelp, but then I also want to be in their first 50th reviews list... :)

excerpts: I got the Tori Paitan.
I was happy with it, but it's not what I expected.
The soup is VERY rich, but the pork was cooked perfectly!
It's worth it to pay $2 more to have double meat.
To drink I got a Coedo Beniaka, lager brewed with sweet potato.
It was the first time I tried it
and it didn't disappoint me.
I have to say that isn't my favorite beer, but not bad at all.
Good choice if you wanna try something different....just be prepared for the wait and bring someone fun to talk to!
tori paitan.author: Gustavo C.
tori paitan.review: Heard a lot about this tiny ramen stop and was excited to try it! But, I don't think it's worth it to waste your time on the nightly 45+ minute line. Don't get me wrong, this place is good, but just not 45 minute line good. I got the Tori Paitan. I was happy with it, but it's not what I expected. The soup is VERY rich, but the pork was cooked perfectly! It's worth it to pay $2 more to have double meat. To drink I got a Coedo Beniaka, lager brewed with sweet potato. It was the first time I tried it and it didn't disappoint me. I have to say that isn't my favorite beer, but not bad at all. Good choice if you wanna try something different....just be prepared for the wait and bring someone fun to talk to!

excerpts: I wasn't in the mood for their speciality, the heartier Tori Paitan, so I went with Shio Chashu and it tasted pretty clean.
I was afraid it might be a bit too salty and, while it hit the spot, I didn't love it?
I might just be more of a Hakata (Tonkotsu) ramen type of gal though.
The service was efficient and attentive.
One of my servers went out of her way to ask me what I thought of the food and that made an impression on me.
tori paitan.author: Julia G.
tori paitan.review:
Is it good? Yes. Is it worth the wait? Not sure. Is it "authentic"? Maybe, but you should probably ask a Japanese person that. I wasn't in the mood for their speciality, the heartier Tori Paitan, so I went with Shio Chashu and it tasted pretty clean. I was afraid it might be a bit too salty and, while it hit the spot, I didn't love it? I might just be more of a Hakata (Tonkotsu) ramen type of gal though. The service was efficient and attentive. One of my servers went out of her way to ask me what I thought of the food and that made an impression on me. I can't compare it to other ramen places in the Bay Area simply because I haven't been to any. 

I'd definitely go again though to try their specialty and the Tan Tan Men, which the couple behind me was markedly unimpressed with and complained was "SO spicy" lol

excerpts: In which I recommend the Tori Paitan.
tori paitan.author: Kevin L.
tori paitan.review:
Get ready to wait in line :D This place definitely specializes in the ramen. In which I recommend the Tori Paitan. 

The table set up is interesting because they are small, so if somehow you hate sitting next to random people, sorry dude...

The place is clean and modern (love the lights btw) and the beer is a nice pairing to the ramen. I wish though, that they have more option for appetizers and advertise the chili more because it's underrated, it's actually really good. 

But yea, just get ready to wait in line. Most people I know love the place, but I know some others who prefer thinner sauces as this place tend to have thicker sauces. 

This is a great place to bring someone new to the city and close to downtown. They close late night too for those supper peeps.

excerpts: I ordered the Tori Paitan Ramen which was DELICIOUS!
I noticed that everyone at our communal table was eating the same thing.
If you like rich, creamy ramen, this is your dish!
It was so rich that I couldn't finish it all, but that is definitely some of the best ramen I have ever head.
It's very hearty, filling, with pork & duck chasu.
The noodles were also pretty thick.
She was kind enough to take my husband's dish back and he ordered the Tori Paitan and ate the entire thing!
tori paitan.author: Chisholm T.
tori paitan.review:
I freaking love ramen, so the second my husband mentioned this new place I was stoked! However walking up to the restaurant, all we could see was a big line out the door. We almost left, but the line was moving a little faster than we thought it would so we stayed and I'm so glad we did! We came on a Wednesday night around 7:30 PM and waited about 45 min before we were seated. But time went by very quickly. As you get closer to the door, an employee will hand you a menu so that you can figure out what you want while you are waiting in line.

Mensho Tokyo is very small. It reminded me of the ramen noodle stalls in Japan. Not a lot of space, but the service is very quick so people are constantly going in and out. All of the tables in the restaurant are communal, so you'll be sitting with other people. Since there isn't a lot of room for you to put your purse, backpack, jacket, etc. they place baskets underneath the tables for you to store your belongings. Thoughtful little touch! 

As soon as we sat down, we were greeted by our server who took our order right away. I ordered the Tori Paitan Ramen which was DELICIOUS! I noticed that everyone at our communal table was eating the same thing. If you like rich, creamy ramen, this is your dish! It was so rich that I couldn't finish it all, but that is definitely some of the best ramen I have ever head. It's very hearty, filling, with pork & duck chasu. The noodles were also pretty thick. Very yummy dish!

My husband got the Organic Shoyu which was served with a clear, organic chicken and pork broth. Also served with pork & duck chasu. Unfortunately he didn't like his dish and it's because it had a very fishy flavor. He asked me to try it and I could immediately smell the fish scent. Neither of us like fish but we didn't know this dish would have fish flavor since it didn't mention it anywhere in the entree description. My husband asked our server if there was fish in the ramen and she confirmed yes, and that a good way to indicate that is if you see Nori as one of the ingredients. We were glad she told us that little fun fact so that we could keep it in mind for future ordering! She was kind enough to take my husband's dish back and he ordered the Tori Paitan and ate the entire thing!

We left Mensho feeling very full and happy. This place is a genuine ramen restaurant that serves amazing food and quick service. Worth standing in line for!

excerpts: I had the tori paitan and my sister had the ume tsukemen (limit 30 of each tsukemen made daily!).
The noodles were thick and chewy, with the tsukemen ones staying al dente the entire time since they weren't sitting in warm broth.
I really liked their noodles.
The tori paitan broth was rich and creamy, and got to be a little much by the end of the bowl, but the first piping hot spoonfuls were delicious.
The tsukemen dipping broth was on the saltier side, but I've found this to be true for many places.
It wasn't unbearable, though.
The duck chasu was absolutely amazing, even better than the pork which literally melted in your mouth.
tori paitan.author: Kathy L.
tori paitan.review:
Waited an hour to eat, but it was worth it to try it! Not the best ramen ever, but definitely one of the better ramen shops in the city. I had the tori paitan and my sister had the ume tsukemen (limit 30 of each tsukemen made daily!). The noodles were thick and chewy, with the tsukemen ones staying al dente the entire time since they weren't sitting in warm broth. I really liked their noodles. The tori paitan broth was rich and creamy, and got to be a little much by the end of the bowl, but the first piping hot spoonfuls were delicious. The tsukemen dipping broth was on the saltier side, but I've found this to be true for many places. It wasn't unbearable, though. The duck chasu was absolutely amazing, even better than the pork which literally melted in your mouth. The duck just had a great flavor.

We arrived about 5 minutes to opening on Saturday, and were in the second wave of being seated, an hour later. I'd recommend getting here by 4:30 to make the first round. Service was efficient and courteous. On the expensive side, but it is more unique than other ramen shops.

excerpts: The Tori Paitan Ramen was absolutely delicious!
A little pricey for a ramen joint!
But the broth was so rich and it tasted amazing!
I got the double (double chashu) for $2 more.
$18 is definitely steep for a bowl of ramen
but I say it was worth the try!
tori paitan.author: Daniel S.
tori paitan.review:
I am a fan of Mensho! Just not a fan of the lines.

This place is ALWAYS packed and there is always a line out the door. The restaurant is pretty small. If you get there about 15 minutes before opening (5pm) you should be able to get a seat! But other than that be prepared to wait a while!

The Tori Paitan Ramen was absolutely delicious! A little pricey for a ramen joint! But the broth was so rich and it tasted amazing! I got the double (double chashu) for $2 more. $18 is definitely steep for a bowl of ramen but I say it was worth the try!

excerpts: Everyone ordered the Tori Paitan ($16, additional $2 for double the chashu).
The soup was creamy, rich, and just phenomenal.
Best ramen soup ever!
The noodles were a perfect al dente and had a good chew, but I still can't wait for the fresh housemade noodles.
The chashu was the star of the dish.
Just the perfect amount of fat and cooked to perfection, so soft and tender.
It literally melted in my mouth so fast I was regretting not ordering extra.
The duck was also delicious, very tender and comes medium rare, that beautiful pink.
It comes with some bonito flakes and cabbage.
tori paitan.author: Stephanie L.
tori paitan.review:
Mensho Ramen, a famous ramen chain from Japan, has finally landed itself in the states and happens to find itself in San Francisco. 

Only in San Francisco will there always be a long line with eager foodies for any hot joint. Mensho does not take any reservations and no name on the clipboard. You have to wait in line for your turn and your entire party has to be present in order to be seated. This place is tiny, I mean tiny, capacity at 49 with 4 communal tables and a bar seating area that holds 4. They limit each table to 1 hr for their meal so that the line can move.

I went on a Wednesday night, lined up around 8 pm and waiting about 1.5 hrs. We had 6 people but split into 2 groups of 3.

They offer 4 types of ramen and a couple tsukemen and soba options ranging $9+. They also offer beer, no sake yet. Draft and asahi starts at around $6 and the imported fancier beers are $10+.

Everyone ordered the Tori Paitan ($16, additional $2 for double the chashu). The soup was creamy, rich, and just phenomenal. Best ramen soup ever! The noodles were a perfect al dente and had a good chew, but I still can't wait for the fresh housemade noodles. The chashu was the star of the dish. Just the perfect amount of fat and cooked to perfection, so soft and tender. It literally melted in my mouth so fast I was regretting not ordering extra. The duck was also delicious, very tender and comes medium rare, that beautiful pink. It comes with some bonito flakes and cabbage. On the table they have some dried plum salt and bonito powder to complement your ramen. 

However, to make this bowl of ramen complete, it's missing the marinated soft boiled egg.

This is one place I would highly recommend everyone lining up for and trying at least once. This is the only hype that lived up to it.

excerpts: I got the Tori Paitan Double Chashu- with rich and creamy broth, pork and duck chashu, menma, kale, burdock.
If you want extra slices of cha it's about 1.50 A SLICE.
The broth was good, but the toppings were really boring.
It was good, and I was suffed, but for me this is one of those places you try once to cross it off your list.
tori paitan.author: Jessica S.
tori paitan.review:
A really long line and $16-$18 for a medicore bowl of ramen with meh toppings. Had to do a double take to make sure I wasn't in Vegas where they charge about $20 for a Pad Thai on the strip.

My friends came from out of town and wanted to try this place. We waited about 30 mins in the rain. It was good but I didn't think there was anything special about it to warrant that kind of price range.

I got the Tori Paitan Double Chashu- with rich and creamy broth, pork and duck chashu, menma, kale, burdock. If you want extra slices of cha it's about 1.50 A SLICE. The broth was good, but the toppings were really boring. It was good, and I was suffed, but for me this is one of those places you try once to cross it off your list. I wouldn't come back here.

I don't think it's that great or worth the money.

excerpts: The tori paitan broth is so creamy and thick.
It's a very unique broth.
The chashu was so good - fatty and delicious.
tori paitan.author: Stella S.
tori paitan.review:
This place is hella good.  They didn't have the tonkotsu on the menu yet, so I will definitely be back to try it.  The tori paitan broth is so creamy and thick. It's a very unique broth.  The chashu was so good - fatty and delicious.  The oysters are okay, probably wouldn't order it next time. 

We waited for 2 hours on a Sunday night.  Definitely not worth the wait unless it's your first time trying this place. Will come back when the wait is less than an hour long.

excerpts: Tori Paitan - http://tinyurl.com/zmhmezu
Amazingly thick and rich broth that has a strong chicken flavor.
The first couple bites of this ramen is just heavenly.
Then the richness gets to be a bit too much after a while.
I could barely finish my bowl!
The ramen came with two thin slices of pork chashu and duck chashu.
The pork slices were very tender and the duck was cooked closer to medium than well - which is unusual for asian cuisine.
The main flavor in both types of meat was the meat itself, not the typical chashu flavor.
The burdock roots were thinly crispy and thinly sliced, which really added to the texture of the whole dish.
The noodles were thick and average in terms of taste.
I really liked this ramen as a whole.
Overall, I liked this ramen more than the Tori Paitan.
It still had a rich broth, but not so overwhelmingly rich that it made me feel bad after finishing it.
The broth tasted like a combination of peanuts and sesame.
tori paitan.author: Lily L.
tori paitan.review:
Unique and delicious ramen that is well worth the wait. I went here on a Thursday night around 10:00pm and was seated in about 1 hour (for a party of 2). When we left the restaurant, the line was just as long as when we first got there.  I liked the ramen here so much that I came back again the next day. 

Tori Paitan - http://tinyurl.com/zmhmezu
Amazingly thick and rich broth that has a strong chicken flavor. The first couple bites of this ramen is just heavenly. Then the richness gets to be a bit too much after a while. I could barely finish my bowl! The ramen came with two thin slices of pork chashu and duck chashu. The pork slices were very tender and the duck was cooked closer to medium than well - which is unusual for asian cuisine. The main flavor in both types of meat was the meat itself, not the typical chashu flavor. The burdock roots were thinly crispy and thinly sliced, which really added to the texture of the whole dish. The noodles were thick and average in terms of taste. I really liked this ramen as a whole. I felt kind of bad after finishing it because it was overwhelmingly rich and fatty. 

Vegan Tantanmen - http://tinyurl.com/h29wb6x
Overall, I liked this ramen more than the Tori Paitan. It still had a rich broth, but not so overwhelmingly rich that it made me feel bad after finishing it. The broth tasted like a combination of peanuts and sesame. There were a couple drops of spicy chili oil in the soup was only slightly spicy.

Oysters in Dare Shoyu Sauce - http://tinyurl.com/ztsb6kt
This is the only appetizer here. I don't eat oysters often and I've never had it cooked so this was a completely new dish to me. The order came with 6 pieces of oysters even though the menu says it's supposed to be 3 pieces. The oysters were well braised and topped with chives. (The 2nd time I came back, I saw an order of oysters topped with sprouts instead of chives so they probably change up the toppings). Taste wise, it kind of reminded me of chicken gizzard or heart. I wasn't super in love with this dish but I'm pretty sure that's just because I'm not a huge fan of oysters.

You can ask for a side of chili oil if you want to add some spice to your ramen. I really liked this place and will definitely come back again to try their new menu items!

excerpts: I ordered the Tori Paitan Ramen which came with both Duck and Pork Chashu.
It seems that most people who enjoy this place love the thick broth, but for me the broth was a bit too thick.
Extremely fatty to the point I couldn't quite enjoy the flavour.
I feel if the broth wasn't so thick I would have enjoyed this place more, but don't let me stop you from trying this place!
Seems many people enjoy it.
tori paitan.author: Galen W.
tori paitan.review: To be honest I'm not quite sure what the Hype is all about. I ordered the Tori Paitan Ramen which came with both Duck and Pork Chashu. It seems that most people who enjoy this place love the thick broth, but for me the broth was a bit too thick. Extremely fatty to the point I couldn't quite enjoy the flavour. I feel if the broth wasn't so thick I would have enjoyed this place more, but don't let me stop you from trying this place! Seems many people enjoy it.

excerpts:
* Tori Paitan (chicken soup, pork & duck chashu, $18 for double chashu) - 5 stars
Amazing!
I love the udon-style (thick) noodles.
They were on the soft side but still had a good amount of give for you al-dente-lovers out there.
tori paitan.author: Ziyan C.
tori paitan.review:
Mensho opens at 5pm on Sundays. I got there at 4:50pm and there were about 20-30 people in line ahead of us (about the length of the restaurant). We ended up just barely missing the first seating - maybe we would've made it if we were a smaller group (there were 4 of us). We ended up getting sat at 6:00pm and were out of there by 6:40pm, just in time to catch a 7pm Caltrain!

For SF, 1 hour isn't too bad, and it was definitely worth the ramen. It cost a little over $20 a person.
Sun dinner 2016-06-05
* Tori Paitan (chicken soup, pork & duck chashu, $18 for double chashu) - 5 stars
Amazing! I love the udon-style (thick) noodles. They were on the soft side but still had a good amount of give for you al-dente-lovers out there. The broth was super tasty, and the meat incredibly tender. 

* Super Limited Menu - Chashu Tsukemen ($19) - 4 stars
The broth on this one was much thicker. I have a pretty much bottomless stomach and this was almost too much for me! (Don't worry, I got through it.) This richer, creamier broth made the ramen much more intense, so if you aren't super hungry or want something you may be more used to (at least for the Bay Area), don't get this. This did have the same amazing noodles and was served in a more "traditional" style with the noodles in a separate bowl. This was definitely an interesting way to eat more ramen, giving me more control over how much noodle vs. broth was in each spoonful.

excerpts: The Tori Paitan was superb, and the wait staff was friendly and quite competent.
tori paitan.author: Frank S.
tori paitan.review: I finally decided to wait in line to get into this rather small place.  It was worth the wait!  The Tori Paitan was superb, and the wait staff was friendly and quite competent.

excerpts: If the broth for their Tori Paitan Ramen is this viscous then I can't wait to try their Tsukemen version.
tori paitan.author: Taffany H.
tori paitan.review:
It takes duck, pork, fish, and many more deep secret animal umami taste to make a broth this complex. But you can't quite distinguish the complexity of all that's happening in your mouth, since it's all muddled up together. 

And this is what it taste like to brew-up a broth so deep, viscously caramel creamy brown that makes waiting 40 minutes for a bowl of ramen worth while. Ramen is truly a religion and each of us have our own sect we follow. Some likes it porky, some likes citrusy with yuzu, and some just like it thick and muddy. Mensho ramen definitely makes a legitimate ramen fare. If the broth for their Tori Paitan Ramen is this viscous then I can't wait to try their Tsukemen version.

excerpts: I've had all except the matcha tori paitan.
tori paitan.author: Kelly L.
tori paitan.review:
Five stars is solely for the vegan ramen. I am anything but a vegan/vegetarian but this is my ALL TIME favorite ramen on their menu. I've had all except the matcha tori paitan. 

I don't actually care for the chashu meat in any ramen at all so having no meat wasn't any much of a difference in experience to me. You will never guess it's vegan. I also love that it's a little spicy from the chili oil they add. 

CONS: long waits and difficult to find parking!

excerpts: Tori Paitan ramen
tori paitan.author: Alan N.
tori paitan.review:
My friend Bryan and I waited two full hours for three bowls of Ramen from Mensho Tokyo. Here's how it went down and read more to be convinced it is worth the wait.

Mensho Tokyo Ramen opened exactly three weeks ago, February 6, 2016. Mensho Tokyo is one of Japan's most popular ramen spots, and San Francisco is its first attempt in North America. I spoke to Abram during my visit, where he told me that the owner has a total of 8 ramen bars in Tokyo, and each of them has its unique menu including Mensho Tokyo so this is not your typical franchise. The two-hour wait was a bit long, but I occasionally chatted with ramen lovers in line, and kept myself occupied.

The hype for this ramen shop is not going to slow down anytime, because of the quality of the ramen it offers. After having lived in Vancouver for more than half my life, and have visited Tokyo and had authentic ramen, I can say that the Organic Shoyu flavour in Mensho Tokyo this is the best bowl of ramen I have ever had in the West Coast of North America.

What I recommend to order:
1) Organic Shoyu ramen
2) Tantan Vegan ramen, add chase
3) Tori Paitan ramen

excerpts: I got the tori paitan ramen, which consists of a lovely chicken soup, pork chashu, duck chashu, menma, kale, burdock, and katsuobushi sauce.
The soup was my favorite part, and it's probably the best ramen soup I've had in my life so far.
It was so savory and the umami* flavor of the broth was incredible.
The noodles were nice and chewy and the kale was a lovely addition.
The duck and pork chashu, while used very frugally, was incredibly delicious and melted in your mouth.
Wish they included a bit more of it.
Ambience is very modern, space is pretty cramped, but my friend and I were pretty lucky in that we got seated facing the kitchen, so we could see the magic happen.
It was like watching Food Network while eating - best thing ever?
tori paitan.author: Katherine Z.
tori paitan.review:
This place is incredible. Expect to wait because it is so popular. My friend and I got in after about a 25 minute wait and then waited about 20 minutes before we got our ramen, so we were ravenous by the time we started eating. I got the tori paitan ramen, which consists of a lovely chicken soup, pork chashu, duck chashu, menma, kale, burdock, and katsuobushi sauce. The soup was my favorite part, and it's probably the best ramen soup I've had in my life so far. It was so savory and the umami* flavor of the broth was incredible. The noodles were nice and chewy and the kale was a lovely addition. The duck and pork chashu, while used very frugally, was incredibly delicious and melted in your mouth. Wish they included a bit more of it. Ambience is very modern, space is pretty cramped, but my friend and I were pretty lucky in that we got seated facing the kitchen, so we could see the magic happen. It was like watching Food Network while eating - best thing ever? I'd say so.

*Normally I have a pretty difficult time wrapping my head around the umami flavor and distinguishing what it is, but this soup was different in that it just hits you instantly and you KNOW it's wonderfully umami.

excerpts: Tori Paitan was killer and 2
I have to go back.
The broth was incredibly silky and thick, coating the chewy, spring noodles.
At $30 for beer and ramen
it's pricey but worth it.
I dream about this ramen.
But don't go.
You won't like it and there will be more for me LOL
tori paitan.author: Dina L.
tori paitan.review:
I caught the chef's eye because I had to tell him that my ramen brought me to the point of tears it was so delicious.  This is a peak eating experience 

Yes you will have to wait,but isn't that true of most good things in life? Arriving an hour before service will get you into the first or second setting. I was luck to get in the second setting after meeting the Chef. It was his birthday and he was amazed a the block long line that had formed out front.  Surely, that will be a nightly occurrence with food this good.

I love a well designed restuarant and Tokoyo Mensho is very well designed. Right down to a shelf and baskets under the communal tables to hold belongings. There's a sweet 4 seat chefs table that offers a fascinating peek into the kitchen.

I'm a Tonkontsu girl but it wasn't available that day.  That's good because 1. Tori Paitan was killer and 2 I have to go back. The broth was incredibly silky and thick, coating the chewy, spring noodles. At $30 for beer and ramen it's pricey but worth it.   I dream about this ramen.  But don't go. You won't like it and there will be more for me LOL

excerpts: Me and my 3 other friends all got the Tori Paitan ramen with extra chashu
(our total came out to be about $80).
The meat is so so tender and melts in your mouth
- so delicious!!
And the broth is creamy and gets a little heavy towards the end (but I still finished it!!).
The flavor is all there - they only use top quality ingredients and only use the best of the best.
tori paitan.author: Fiona G.
tori paitan.review:
I came here because my friend has recommended this place to me. I'm a ramen lover and fanatic and I have to say that Mensho definitely deserves 5 stars for both food and service. The wait was pretty long and it was difficult to find parking but for top-quality ramen, it's worth it! 

Me and my 3 other friends all got the Tori Paitan ramen with extra chashu (our total came out to be about $80). The meat is so so tender and melts in your mouth - so delicious!! And the broth is creamy and gets a little heavy towards the end (but I still finished it!!). The flavor is all there - they only use top quality ingredients and only use the best of the best. They also provide seasonings like pure pink Himalayan sea salt that are placed on every table which I thought added a really nice touch even though I didn't use any of it. 

The staff here are very welcoming and efficient. You can tell that they really care about customer service and want to serve you as quickly as possible. If you have the time, I would definitely recommend coming here because this is a unique ramen experience that is difficult to find in the Bay Area.

excerpts: I may come back and try their regular ramen Tori Paitan.
tori paitan.author: Audrey W.
tori paitan.review:
The Line: Came here 15 minutes before opening on a Tuesday and got seated in the first seating. I sat at the bar facing the kitchen. On Tuesday's and Wednesday's, you can probably get here a little after 5 and still get seated right away if you come alone.

The Service: Not bad. Very attentive but not super pushy. They serve fast and give you the check when they see you're almost done. But I never felt pushed. With that said, the restaurant is cramped and hot that I wouldn't linger for too long anyway.

The Drink: I opted to pay $4.75 for a Sapporo bottled beer. Would I have ordered it on its own? Absolutely no. With ramen? Heck yah. Trust me, it'll help wash down the super rich soup.

The Dish: I opted for the popular vegan tantanmen given that it's my first time. The verdict....best tantanmen I've ever had in my life. But it's definitely not the best bowl of ramen I've ever had in the states. The best ones in the states are still NYC's Ippudo and SD's Menya Ultra (an absolute must try if you're in SoCal). I may come back and try their regular ramen Tori Paitan.

Finally, would I wait 1.5 hrs for this bowl of ramen? No. I'll wait max 15 minutes.

excerpts: She said the Tori Paitan and Vegan Tantanmen.
My friend and I decided to try both.
They were amazing!
The tori paitan was rich and delicious.
The Vegan tantanmen was spicy in all the right ways.
Everything about it was just right.
tori paitan.author: Veronica L.
tori paitan.review:
I've eaten a fair share of ramen in the bay area. I even waited in a relatively short (in comparison) two hour line at that crazy ramen festival.. and this is hands down the best ramen I've had. 

Yes i still had to wait in a line but still it was only about 30 minutes long and the weather was nice and I had great company so the line flew by.  It helps that Mensho is an organized and well run establishment. I appreciate their efficiency in getting people in and out without feeling overly rushed. 

The place is pretty small but they use every little bit of it with community seating. The menu is simple with few choices which I love. I assume their limited menu means they put a lot more thought into the few things they make. 

I asked the waitress what was most popular. She said the Tori Paitan and Vegan Tantanmen. My friend and I decided to try both. They were amazing! The tori paitan was rich and delicious. The Vegan tantanmen was spicy in all the right ways. Everything about it was just right. It even came with a giant spoon to make the event a little more delightful. 

I really want to go again but I also really don't want to stand in line.

excerpts: Vegan tantanmen had amazing depth of flavor, even better than the broth in the tori paitan.
Chashu in the tori paitan was probably some of the best I've ever had.
tori paitan.author: Dinah V.
tori paitan.review:
Four stars for the food but overall experience was closer to three stars. Came 25 minutes before open on Sunday, was the first batch of people seated, and received ramen around 5:30. Vegan tantanmen had amazing depth of flavor, even better than the broth in the tori paitan. Chashu in the tori paitan was probably some of the best I've ever had. Only critique is that the noodles are pretty thick and air on the side of being too dense/chewy. 

Cons: very loud edm made it hard to carry on a conversation, tall bar stools were uncomfortable to sit on, very very close proximity to other people so it was awkward getting food before them (in your peripheral they'd stare and watch you try it) and people waiting in line outside kept gazing around inside waiting to get seated 

Don't get me wrong, this is really solid ramen with excellent depth of flavor. But everything else made this experience very strange. I'm glad I tried it but I wouldn't go out of my way to eat here again.

excerpts: Not a lot of ramen shops serve tori paitan so
when I saw it here, I knew I wanted that.
I missed the first group of people being seated so waited about 45 minutes until a seat was ready for me.
They only have communal tables and everyone, no matter how big or small your group is, shares the table.
Got me my tori paitan which came out super hot, broth was thick, milky and flavorful.
Noodles were thick and al dente.
It comes with a slice of tender fatty cha sui and 2 slices of medium rare duck slices.
It was loaded with bamboo shoots and a few kale for some green.
I can slurp this ramen everyday,
especially this 60 degrees sf weather!
tori paitan.author: Linda T.
tori paitan.review:
I recently just came back from Japan and my standards for ramen have definitely became more harsh.  Not a lot of ramen shops serve tori paitan so when I saw it here, I knew I wanted that.  I missed the first group of people being seated so waited about 45 minutes until a seat was ready for me.  They only have communal tables and everyone, no matter how big or small your group is, shares the table.
Got me my tori paitan which came out super hot, broth was thick, milky and flavorful.  Noodles were thick and al dente.  It comes with a slice of tender fatty cha sui and 2 slices of medium rare duck slices.  It was loaded with bamboo shoots and a few kale for some green.  
I can slurp this ramen everyday, especially this 60 degrees sf weather! 
They have vegan options and light broths like shio and even dipping ramens. 
Definitely bringing friends here next time to try more! 
Line fills up fast.. and you would think, a bowl of ramen should only take no more than 10 mins to slurp down in Japan... but be prepared to wait 45 mins to an hour or more!  It is delicious though!

excerpts: I ordered the Tori Paitan (totally sounds like a football player) ramen with a double helping of pork and duck chashu.
I will say it now, this was probably the best ramen I've ever had.
Shono is credited for creating ramen dishes with unique ingredients.
The addition of braised kale, duck chaschu, and some sort of thinly sliced deep fried chip was a unique concept.
There wasn't a single ingredient that tasted out of place.
All the ingredients were cooked well, meaning, the fried chips were crispy, the chaschu was tender, and of course, the noodles had great tenacity to them.
The broth didn't have a charred or bitter flavor.
tori paitan.author: Josh S.
tori paitan.review:
Mensho Tokyo is no longer exclusive to Japan!  Tomoharu Shono partnered with ramen critique Abram Plaut (the gentleman that mans the door) to bring Mensho stateside.  The restaurant probably holds no more than 30 people at a time, but the limited space doesn't make you feel like you're on the #38 during rush hour.  There is enough elbow room to wiggle around.  

The service is extremely polite and friendly.  The servers and cooks work like a well oiled machine, churning out hot delicious bowls of ramen here.  I ordered the Tori Paitan (totally sounds like a football player) ramen with a double helping of pork and duck chashu.  I will say it now, this was probably the best ramen I've ever had.  Shono is credited for creating ramen dishes with unique ingredients.  The addition of braised kale, duck chaschu, and some sort of thinly sliced deep fried chip was a unique concept.  There wasn't a single ingredient that tasted out of place.  All the ingredients were cooked well, meaning, the fried chips were crispy, the chaschu was tender, and of course, the noodles had great tenacity to them.  The broth didn't have a charred or bitter flavor.  It was fatty, rich, and full bodied.  

Gyoza lovers, hang in there!  Plaut said he definitely wants to bring gyoza to the menu, but would first like to get things up and running fully before creating additions.  

I really enjoyed my bowl of ramen at Mensho and would highly recommend it to those that are willing to wait.  I got there maybe 15 minuted before they opened and waited 45 minutes total.  The line moved pretty fast.  Go slurp and enjoy some awesome ramen!

excerpts: I'm a huge fan of the creamy broth and got the Tori Paitan which is a rich and creamy chicken soup with pork Chashu.
tori paitan.author: Kunal T.
tori paitan.review:
One of the best ramen's i've had in the city! The only drawback is its like a 1.5-2 hour wait for a 20 minute dinner session.

I'm a huge fan of the creamy broth and got the Tori Paitan which is a rich and creamy chicken soup with pork Chashu.

Mensho brings an authentic style Ramen to SF with a very unique taste. The noodles are by far one of the best i've had with tender, slightly thicker than normal noodles, and cooked to perfection.

I would highly recommend this place if you're looking to try authentic Japanese ramen. The service is nothing special it is very fast and quick service.

excerpts: The broth tori paitan was amazing, flavorful, creamy and tasty, not salty.
The noodles were thickened homemade.
Best ramen in SF
tori paitan.author: Abby C.
tori paitan.review: Worth the wait and standing in the cold. The broth tori paitan was amazing, flavorful, creamy and tasty, not salty.  The noodles were thickened homemade.  Best ramen in SF

excerpts:
The FOOD:

Friend and I ordered the same thing: the Tori Paitan Ramen with a soy sauce egg (+$1.80/each).
tori paitan.author: Lenerd J.
tori paitan.review:
I've passed this place a couple of times and there's ALWAYS a long line (at least 10+ people) but this time friend and I got there around 8:15ishPM and we waited about 15-20 mins - there were 4-5 groups in front of us. Mostly pairs of people. We got to the front of the line and there's a menu on a podium. There was a note that this is a "Gratuity Free" restaurant - a flat rate of 15% is added to all diners check. This was a little off putting at first but I came to agree with the flat rate percentage. I'll make more comments further below to support my decision.

Ambiance and seating:

Great ambiance. They have three main tables: the largest seating 10-12 individuals and the other two tables seat 6 people each. The tables are elevated and have barstool seats. The tables are interesting in a sense that there's a gap built into the table, large enough to slide a thin-ish purse (anything wider than 3 inches might not fit) or a wallet and phone into the space if you don't want to put your purse on the floor. There is a coat hook by the door (I believe another person posted a photo of this). My friend and I were seated across from each over and next to us was another pair. Seating is a shared experience - most people seem to be seated across from their partner with exception of one pair that sat side to side. The fact that they only have three tables sort of suggests this. The ambiance is very welcoming, bright, and clean. Lots of chatter and you may need to raise your voice a little bit to hear your friend/SO, but definitely nice. Music in the background seemed pretty varied. It wasn't stuck on a specific radio with one type of music. There was also a TV mounted above the rest room, but it was playing on mute and no captions. It appeared to be on a loop and I believe it was more of an infomercial for the restaurant (?) - unclear.

The FOOD:

Friend and I ordered the same thing: the Tori Paitan Ramen with a soy sauce egg (+$1.80/each). Menu doesn't offer that ramen as spicy but you can request Habanero (+$2/each) to spice it up - it came out in a slightly chopped/pulverized paste; makes it easier to mix into the broth in my opinion. We also ordered fried garlic (+$2) which came out in a diced form (see photo). I tried the broth first and it was sooooo delicious!! It had a milkier consistency than what I've had at other ramen places but the balance was great. It wasn't too salty nor under seasoned but just right. The chasiu was SO perfect - cooked to the point where it's falling apart when you try to bite down. I LOVED the texture and al dente-ness of the ramen. I personally prefer ramen noodles (and wonton noodles) with more of a resistance when I bite into it. I hate it when noodles are cooked to the point that they're falling apart when I pick them up with chop sticks. I cannot rave enough about their noodles!!! There were a few leaves of kale, some cabbage, bamboo shoots, and some fried/baked veg that I can't put my finger on that was also in the broth.I recognize the fried/baked beg but can't remember the name. At some point, friend and I weren't talking. We were slurping and eating intensely.

The drink menu consisted mostly of Asian (?) beers, sake, and soju. I don't believe any sodas were on the menu. Water is always an option 

The SERVICE:

Great! There were three ladies taking orders,serving, and clearing tables. All of them were efficient and unobtrusive. Sometimes I feel very rushed or I'm waiting a long time to place my order but here, it felt like when I glanced around, one of the ladies immediately sensed my eyes and came right over. Everyone had a smile and was offering refills at a good rate. Food came out about 10 mins after ordering and when we were slowing down and coming to the end of our meal, I didn't feel pressured to hurry up, pay, and get out. We slowly savored the broth and when WE were done, someone came up and asked if they could take away our bowls - definitely appreciate the attention the servers give. Not too much but enough to know they're there. 

All in all I would DEFINITELY come here again...I'll keep my fingers crossed that there won't be a hella long line.

excerpts: I tried the organic shoyu, spicy lamb, and tori paitan broths and the flavors are all super strong (bordering on too salty)
but they're just sooo thick and heavy.
I ordered the clear shoyu broth because I knew the creamy ones would be too much for me, but even the shoyu broth was intensely oily.
There was a legit 3-5mm layer of oil floating in my bowl.
I felt a little sick after finishing my bowl just cause it was so intensely rich.
tori paitan.author: Melissa H.
tori paitan.review:
The noodles here are the best I've ever had! They're so thick and chewy! But unfortunately that's about where the hype stops. It's expensive, even for SF ramen, and the broth has good flavor but is just TOO thick/fatty/oily.

I tried the organic shoyu, spicy lamb, and tori paitan broths and the flavors are all super strong (bordering on too salty) but they're just sooo thick and heavy. I ordered the clear shoyu broth because I knew the creamy ones would be too much for me, but even the shoyu broth was intensely oily. There was a legit 3-5mm layer of oil floating in my bowl.
