excerpts: All four of us ordered the Tori Paitan, which is their signature ramen.
We were all disappointed.
The soup was too thick, almost like gravy consistency.
Although I do prefer thick noodles over thin, their noodles were too thick- similar to Shanghaiese noodle.
The noodles were bland and not chewy.
tori paitan.author: Beatrice L.
tori paitan.review:
I would say I am a Ramen connoisseur so I know what is good ramen.  All four of us ordered the Tori Paitan, which is their signature ramen.  We were all disappointed.  The soup was too thick, almost like gravy consistency.  Although I do prefer thick noodles over thin, their noodles were too thick- similar to Shanghaiese noodle. The noodles were bland and not chewy.  The hour and a half wait was definitely not worth it.  

The service and atmosphere were the only thing I would rave about.

excerpts: Most people in our group ordered the Double Chasu Tori Paitan ($18).
The tori paitan had good flavor, but was a bit thick for my liking.
It is a little less thick than the tori paitan.
tori paitan.author: Amanda R.
tori paitan.review:
Came here at a 4.30pm on Subday and there were already 3 groups in line. Luckily we were seated right away at opening. Most people in our group ordered the Double Chasu Tori Paitan ($18). Although a couple people get the vegan ramen ($18). 

The tori paitan had good flavor, but was a bit thick for my liking. That's a lot coming from someone who loves thick, deep flavored ramen.

The vegan ramen was my favorite. It had a peanut-satay spicy flavor. It is a little less thick than the tori paitan. It's hard to believe this ramen is vegan, it's so good.

With that being said, I can still only rate this 3*. The price is a little outrageous, and the lines are way too long. While the ramen was good, I would never wait more than 20mi s for this place. If this ramen is your jam, try Izakaya Goku in the Mission - slightly less thick ramen broth but equal flavor, cheaper,much shorter wait.

I did appreciate how you can order more broth or noodles here. This is definitely the true Japanese way to eat ramen.

excerpts: I got recommended the Tori Paitan, which is their rich & creamy chicken soup.
I enjoyed all of the meats included, especially the chashu.
I read the ingredients but had no idea that "menma" was bamboo.
Now I dont necessarily hate bamboo, I'd just rather not eat it.
I would describe to you what I think bamboo tastes like, but it might spoil your appetite.
This broth has an extremely strong bamboo flavor.
I wish I had ordered the shoyu instead, so next time I'll do just that.
tori paitan.author: Kenneth L.
tori paitan.review:
I came here off a suggestion from a SF native.  The wait was about an hour for 3 people around 6:30PM on a chilly March night, so you might want to have a snack before dinner.
There is no take out here, so dont even think about it.

The setting is quite small, but clean. Its what comes to mind when I think of a contemporary ramen shop. There are high top stools and bench tables with boxes underneath that you can put your stuff in (I was wondering why the random boxes were there).  You will share a table and sit closely with whoever youre next to, be it a random person or not.  This allows you to eavesdrop easily so you can sit there and silently judge while eating your ramen.  The staff is super friendly and once youre inside, service is fast.

I got recommended the Tori Paitan, which is their rich & creamy chicken soup.  I enjoyed all of the meats included, especially the chashu.  I read the ingredients but had no idea that "menma" was bamboo.  Now I dont necessarily hate bamboo, I'd just rather not eat it.  I would describe to you what I think bamboo tastes like, but it might spoil your appetite.  This broth has an extremely strong bamboo flavor. I wish I had ordered the shoyu instead, so next time I'll do just that.

excerpts:
So here are the bowls of ramen we tried:

tori paitan.author: Lin Z.
tori paitan.review:
First of all, the line for this place is insane. You want a tip on when to come? Probably even at weird times, the line is better but it's still long. We came on a Thursday night around 9:15p. Maybe it was because of the NBA finals, with a game that just recently ended and people still at the bar, or maybe it was just because we caught the lull in between the dinner rush and the late dinner crowd. We ended up waiting for about 20 minutes. I would also recommend you come in a smaller group of like 2 people. You are likely to get seated faster with a small party because the shop is very small. Bigger parties just have to wait for more tables to open up. 

Ok, on to the ramen. You want to know if it's worth the wait? I don't think any food is really worth a two-hour wait, so that's where I'm coming from. But it is very good ramen. We got three bowls to share between the two of us so that we could try more things.  My friend who had been there before said that her favorite is vegan tantanmen, and we are both partial to spicy ramen. However, they ran out by the time we got there. At least that's what our server said - but I think she must have gotten false information from the kitchen.  The dude next to us who came after got a bowl, which made us very sad. Note that if you get more food than you can eat, they do NOT do to-go orders. Meaning they won't give you a to-go box. I'm not sure I like this policy. You shouldn't make delicious food and then not let people bring it home with them to enjoy if they can't finish it all. I will also say that I still like Ramen Dojo better than this place because I'm partial to spicy broth and they didn't have the spicy one when we were here. 

So here are the bowls of ramen we tried: 

(1) Tori Paitan: I think this is their specialty. I don't really like chicken broth ramen, but this place has the best chicken ramen I've ever had. The broth is frothy and creamy and satisfying. Also the noodles here are some of the best ramen noodles I've ever had. They're thicker than normal and really yummy. Still, I love spicy ramen and this was delicious but a little too bland for me. The toppings are good too - duck chashu and pork chashu are both yummy. 

(2) Shoyu: If you like shoyu ramen, this is probably the best one I've ever had. If you like lighter broths this is the one for you. I'm not as big a fan of lighter broths, but I could tell this ramen was done really well. The noodles are really good in this one too, still chewy but a little thinner than the ones that come in the tori paitan. 

(3) Spicy Mazesoba: Originally, we were going to get the vegan tantanmen as our third bowl but they ran out. Then we wanted to get the tsukemen, but they said they run out at 7p. So we decided on the spicy mazesoba. I have never had this before, so I had no idea what it is. Basically, it's like noodles with sauce but no soup. It comes in a bowl (see attached pic) with an egg yolk and various toppings. Note that the spicy one also comes with a side of what I think are habanero peppers, but not super sure. We thought these were carrots and put the entire thing in - it was wayyyyy too spicy this way - like wasabi style spicy. Do not do what we did! I think this noodle dish would have been really yummy to try and share if we didn't accidentally make it so darn spicy, it came with thick and chewy delicious noodles. Good alternative to the soup ramens, and interesting to try if you come with a group. 

All in all, I'd give this place five stars for the food. But docking it one star because of the to-go policy and because they didn't explain how to eat the mazesoba to us. It's not really intuitive! Just don't go in expecting great service either because it's a little too crowded and busy to give great service. 

I will definitely be back to try to get my hands on bowls of tsukemen and the vegan tantanmen!

excerpts: I got the single Tori Paitan which it seems this place is known for.
The broth is really thick with a kind of foamy texture that I found pretty unique and very flavorful.
Noodles were on the thicker side which I like, and the vegetables (kale and bamboo mostly) went really well with it.

tori paitan.author: Quan N.
tori paitan.review:
Waited an hour in line, totally worth it.

I got the single Tori Paitan which it seems this place is known for. The broth is really thick with a kind of foamy texture that I found pretty unique and very flavorful. Noodles were on the thicker side which I like, and the vegetables (kale and bamboo mostly) went really well with it. The highlight of the ramen was the two type of chashu (duck and pork) that came with it. Super tender and flavorful, especially the duck.

I also tried a bit of my friend's Shio broth which was nice and light with a really nice seaweed-y flavor to it. Very nice!

All in all, this place is 100% worth the wait, especially if it's your first time. The ramen tastes unlike any others I've had in the Bay Area. Highly recommend a visit!

tori paitan.author: Cassie Z.
tori paitan.review:

Overall, for how hyped this place is, it was actually kind of disappointing. If there is not line and I happened to be nearby, I may come back but I can't see myself going out of my way to come here again.

tori paitan.author: Alyssa C.
tori paitan.review:
Mmm, definitely coming back here. This place is in my top 3 for ramen in the Bay Area. Had a great first time here with coworkers. I went with their specialty, Tori Paitan. When can you go to a ramen place serving both pork AND duck? What can make this better? The broth is very creamy, and the noodles are the perfect texture without being overcooked. It tasted like heaven.

The place is very packed, but in my opinion worth it. I waited 20 minutes to sit down, and my party arrived around 5:30PM. The weekday is probably your best bet for less waiting time, and I would expect the weekend to be the most crowded.

excerpts: I got the miso spicy ramen and got to try my friends' Tori Paitan ramen which was pretty on point.
2) tori paitan: the broth is soooo thick and creamy but so good!
tori paitan.author: Shannon N.
tori paitan.review:
My friend got here around 4:50pm and the line was already super long on a Thursday. I got there to meet with him and a couple other friends around 6:15 and we weren't seated until close to 7pm! The space only has enough seating for maybe...30-35 people max? So definitely be prepared to wait if you don't come super early before they open.

Service was pretty on point, food didn't take too long to come out and if you know what you want they usually take down your order when you're at the front of the line. 

I got the miso spicy ramen and got to try my friends' Tori Paitan ramen which was pretty on point. 

1) Miso spicy ramen with chashu: comes in a huge bowl and was actually pretty spicy (I like spicy food so it was tolerable but the broth definitely had a kick to it). Afterward my stomach kinda burned...was not expecting the spice to still be so prominent after eating! The chashu was super fatty but in a good way--tender and flavorful. Loved the addition of corn in the dish as well.

2) tori paitan: the broth is soooo thick and creamy but so good! I'd probably get this if I were to go again.

The noodles--super yummy, right amount of chewiness and the broth coated every inch of the noodles. 

Since the place is so small, they definitely try and get you in and out ASAP so they can seat the people waiting in line. Overall, I think the ramen was super good, but not mindblowing. I don't think I'd wait in line for 2 hours for a bowl here--maybe just come here once in a while.

excerpts: I highly recommend the Tori Paitan ramen for its rich and creamy broth!
I LOVED the creamy broth!
Definitely one of the best broths I've had.
Overall, amazing ramen, long wait and pricey but worth the try!
tori paitan.author: Lynn T.
tori paitan.review: My boyfriend and I decided to bite the bullet and wait in the line at Mensho! We arrived at 7:30pm on a Saturday and as expected, waited over an hour. 1 hour 15 mins to be exact. The restaurant is very small, only a few tables and is community seating. If possible, I would recommend going alone since you can get seated faster! I highly recommend the Tori Paitan ramen for its rich and creamy broth! I LOVED the creamy broth! Definitely one of the best broths I've had. Overall, amazing ramen, long wait and pricey but worth the try!

excerpts: and I both got the Tori Paitan Ramen.
Wow that was the creamiest, thickest, richest ramen broth I've ever tried.
I can't even really compare it to others - it's just on a whole other level.
It comes with one slice of chashu and two small slices of duck.
It was good
but I don't think it was truly worth $16.
Honestly, I did get tired of the creaminess halfway through my bowl.
It just started to become too much - and out of my boyfriend
and I, I typically like the creamy, tonkatsu flavored broths
so that says something.
tori paitan.author: Amanda L.
tori paitan.review:
Wow that was an interesting experience...

Got in line around 4:45pm on a Friday - my boyfriend and I both got off work early to stand in line before 5. The line wasn't bad at all. We were maybe the 6th to 8th party in line? After we sat down, there were only a couple parties left standing outside so I would say early Friday isn't a bad time to go! 

How did I not see any reviews about really HOW SMALL this place is?! Honestly, it seems like the size of a boba, ice cream, or froyo place... It's so small, you don't even get your own table. You sit very closely next to strangers on the same table, unless you get one of the four seats at the bar. It was a little...too cozy for my liking. Definitely not a place to spill juicy secrets with a friend if you don't want your table neighbors potentially listening in also. I'm quite a small person but I still would've preferred to have more space. I sat at the table closest to the bar and I kept getting bumped into by people walking toward or serving the people at the bar. Also, you're sitting on bar stools and have to put your coats and bags in baskets underneath the tall table. I like having my stuff a little closer to me but oh well. They also played their music really loudly so it was a little harder to have a conversation - and it was already hard because people were talking right next to us.

Alright, onto the food. My boyfriend and I both got the Tori Paitan Ramen. Wow that was the creamiest, thickest, richest ramen broth I've ever tried. I can't even really compare it to others - it's just on a whole other level. It comes with one slice of chashu and two small slices of duck. It was good but I don't think it was truly worth $16. Honestly, I did get tired of the creaminess halfway through my bowl. It just started to become too much - and out of my boyfriend and I, I typically like the creamy, tonkatsu flavored broths so that says something. Maybe this type of rich ramen just isn't for me? 

I think because of its authenticity and taste, we give it 4 stars. It's not 5 stars because the overall experience was only okay and we didn't think it was worth $16. It was definitely cool to try but might not make the effort to come again.

excerpts: I wanted to order the Tori Paitan with double cha siu
but I guess our waitress was confused as to how I could eat so much because she tried to clarify the difference between the regular and the double
and I kept saying I wanted the double
but she was very confused.
I eventually was just like yes
I want the regular DOUBLE cha siu not DOUBLE DOUBLE, but the $18 one.

Sad.

LOL.

HERE TAKE THIS TEA

LOL if that makes sense.
I'm weird

tori paitan.author: Amy T.
tori paitan.review:
CONDENSED VERSION: I waited a long time. Food is DELICIOUS. SO FREAKIN GOOD. Service could be better. Come here if you don't mind the long wait.

Read on if you dare:

I stood in line for 2.5 hours for this. Wow. I can't believe I did that LOL. Thankfully my friend and I were just chatting and catching up the whole time, so it really didn't feel like that long -- we didn't realize we had been in line for that long until we got in and looked at the time actually LOL. We got in line around 4:30 PM on Sunday evening and it was already pretty long. It started raining a bit while we were in line and by the time we were inside, it was POURING. But the line was just as long at 8 PM as it was at 4:30.

+ DECOR/AMBIANCE
The decor is very interesting and trendy. It's a hip, modern spin on a Japanese restaurant -- tons of writing on the walls, which are very fun to read! It explains what ramen is, what umami is, etc. There's a coat rack towards the front. It's very cozy and homey feeling. The restaurant itself is INSANELY small. There's three longish communal tables, and the restaurant can probably seat about 25-30 people. You will be in close quarters with everyone sitting around you. However, it's easy to ignore the conversations next to you because it is CRAZY LOUD. It was so hard to hear anything my friend said and he was sitting right across from me. It was even harder to hear/comprehend the waitresses since they all seemed to talk very quietly and softly. They play some loud pop music in the back and with the constant yelling from people trying to hear each other, I definitely wouldn't describe it as a calming atmosphere LOL. Probably not good for a date. Good for friends and small groups. 

+ SERVICE
Well aside from the insanely long line, our waitresses were very attentive. There were a lot of them too. They were all girls that spoke very quietly so it made it hard to hear/understand what they were saying. I wanted to order the Tori Paitan with double cha siu but I guess our waitress was confused as to how I could eat so much because she tried to clarify the difference between the regular and the double and I kept saying I wanted the double but she was very confused. I eventually was just like yes I want the regular DOUBLE cha siu not DOUBLE DOUBLE, but the $18 one. I ended up with the normal Tori Paitain, $16 one not the $18. Sad. But oh well. They also didn't seem to know the items on the menu that well. The group next to us would ask which ramen was which once she brought it out to the table, and she'd have to run back and ask. I ordered the Tori Paitan and my friend ordered the Shoyu, and they swapped it accidentally. This made me very sad. LOL. But I will say they were very nice and apologetic about it. They randomly gave us green tea LOL. We didn't ask for it but they were just like HERE TAKE THIS TEA, so we did and we were very grateful LOL. 

+ THE RAMEN
SO FREAKING GOOD. YUM. As I said, I had the Tori Paitan. It was a great portion size. They did not skimp on the noodles, which I appreciated. Sadly I did not get to eat the ramen how I usually do since they gave my friend my ramen at first and when we realized, it was already all stirred up. I like to leave it as is and eat all the vegetables first, and then eat the noodles and meat without like...disturbing the presentation of any of it LOL if that makes sense. I'm weird I know. I just like my food to look nice while I eat it. I didn't get the double cha siu like I wanted but the meat was very delicious and flavorful. Perfectly cooked, and just melted in your mouth. The vegetables were also SO GOOD. Strangely, to me it tasted very meaty. And it seemed to melt in your mouth also. The Tori Paitain comes with a thicker noodle than the Shoyu, which I loved since I'm all for the fat noodles. The broth was VERY thick, and sort of gritty...not in a bad way. It was creamy and very flavorful. It's not for the faint of heart. I tried some of the Shoyu broth, and it's noticeably lighter. Very salty. I definitely preferred the Tori Paitan more. 

Overall, delicious ramen. VERY LONG WAIT. Maybe the wait will die down in a few months. And by then, hopefully the service will be better. I think they just needed to work on speaking more clearly, and knowing the orders better. Obviously this place just opened recently, so I'll let the slightly less than satisfactory service slide for now. The waitresses were all very nice and the complimentary tea was a nice gesture. If you aren't dedicated to the foodie life, wait a few months because the line is insane. If you are dedicated and willing to wait for hours in line, GO FOR IT. TRY THIS PLACE. IT'S GREAT.

excerpts: We each opted for the Tori Paitan, with a double chashu order for the gents.
While it's doubtful any new opinions can be offered, it was easily one of the best bowls of ramen I've experienced.
The broth, very thick -- even moreso than most tonkotsu, and coaxed mostly from chicken vs. pork bone, yielding softer but more nuanced flavor than its porcine counterpart.
Its texture: were I the photo editor of a dictionary, this is what I'd use for the word "mouthfeel."

The noodles -- the best I've had, a bit thicker and more full-bodied than Oakland's Ramen Shop.
The toppings, from the dash of chives to the menma, each adding to what makes eating a great bowl of ramen a true experience.
And last but
tori paitan.author: John Z.
tori paitan.review:
First off:  the lines to get in. Yes, they're long. And those on line will talk about the long line, what they read about the line, will take pix of the line -- line, line. Ours was also long but timed well on a Sunday by getting their at 3:50 and were seated within minutes of their 5pm opening. 

So, again: Lines = Long. You have been warned. And hopefully you'll be lucky like us and won't be behind an individual who holds spots for large parties who, as witnessed and reported in other reviews, show up minutes before opening. 

Was Mensho worth it? For our trio, absolutely. Again, partly due to luck and good timing. But mostly, for the ramen. We each opted for the Tori Paitan, with a double chashu order for the gents. While it's doubtful any new opinions can be offered, it was easily one of the best bowls of ramen I've experienced. The broth, very thick -- even moreso than most tonkotsu, and coaxed mostly from chicken vs. pork bone, yielding softer but more nuanced flavor than its porcine counterpart. Its texture: were I the photo editor of a dictionary, this is what I'd use for the word "mouthfeel." https://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/mensho-tokyo-san-francisco-2?select=qqf4OrsRY0VRa3VVJ7fV6Q The noodles -- the best I've had, a bit thicker and more full-bodied than Oakland's Ramen Shop. The toppings, from the dash of chives to the menma, each adding to what makes eating a great bowl of ramen a true experience.  And last but no means least, both chashu, especially the duck, beautifully subtle in its individuality and synergy. 

Portions larger than Ramen Shop too. Speaking of R.S., they've gotta be a little worried about the competition, particularly since they practically stopped serving tonkotsu broth ... but that's another story. 

We also had the oysters, which weren't a personal fave, but I'm not a fan of fishy fish. If you are, might be worth your indulgence. 

Beyond the food, the interior is clean and lovely and fun. And, despite their efficiency, all the staff, particularly the host and our waitress, demonstrated uncommon courtesy and conviviality. They deserve big props for their friendliness and customer service. 

Next visit, I'm going for the vegan, with the option of chashu toppings. It's a very accommodating place. And, despite all the hype, IMHO worth it.  Just don't forget: lines.

excerpts: I had the Tori Paitan - but he made the wise decision of going with the double.
I stuck to the original because of my history of chashu at other ramen places being too dry
but MAN I wish I had gotten the double.
The pork chashu was so freaking good!

tori paitan.author: Stephanie L.
tori paitan.review:
Dare I say the best ramen in SF? This is not a statement to be taken lightly!

The line is long but it's definitely worth it. It was about an hour wait at 5:30pm on a Friday. Could be worse I suppose (ahem Orenchi in South Bay). 

Hubby and I had the Tori Paitan - but he made the wise decision of going with the double. I stuck to the original because of my history of chashu at other ramen places being too dry but MAN I wish I had gotten the double. The pork chashu was so freaking good! The duck chashu was even better. I for sure had ramen envy with the hubby that night. 

Only comment was that the noodles were more on the al dente side than I like but otherwise it was really really delicious ramen.

excerpts: If you want something creamy and thick, go with vegan tantanmen or tori paitan ramen.
Tori Paitan ramen 16.00: thick creamy rich chicken soup with BOTH pork chashu and duck chashu topped with menma, kale, burdock, and katsuobushi sauce.
The sauce was SO rich and creamy.
It wasn't too salty despite the creaminess.
However half way through it got too heavy for me.
Nonetheless the meat were all melt in your mouth perfection and the noodles were thick and cooked to amazing "bounciness" level.
Tori Paitan ramen 16.00: thick creamy rich chicken soup with BOTH pork chashu and duck chashu topped with menma, kale, burdock, and katsuobushi sauce.
The sauce was SO rich and creamy.
It wasn't too salty despite the creaminess.
However half way through it got too heavy for me.
Nonetheless the meat were all melt in your mouth perfection and the noodles were thick and cooked to amazing "bounciness" level.
tori paitan.author: Chena N.
tori paitan.review:
Imagine Wal-Mart during Black Friday, that's exactly what Mensho Tokyo was like. 
If you walk in the TL and see a long line out the door, it's most likely Mensho. 

Authentic ramen from JAPAN?! Count me in to join in on the hype! Gave it a couple days to let the crowd simmer down a bit... Not that it really has.... 

Did my research and realized that in order to get in first seating you have to be there around 4-4:20pm. On a Tuesday, my friend and I came at 4:10pm and were the 3rd ones in line. Around 4:20pm the line was pretty long. I hear that if you come at 5pm (their opening time it would be a TWO hr wait) anything after that is 3-4 hr. HELL NAH. Lol. 

::Parking/Service/Ambiance::
Parking. Ha. Don't even think about it especially after 6pm. Luckily we got there around 4pm and there was parking 5-6 blocks away from the restaurant. Paid $2.25/hr because it was meters. 
It's kind of ironic that a restaurant from Japan opened up in the most ghetto part of SF, in the tenderloins. I felt super scared at night, good thing I was with a guy. 
Service was amazing. While we were in line I think the manager of some sort came out and thanked us for waiting and asked if we have any questions at all. The staff were all friendly too from start to end. 
They fit about 28 people for max capacity says the manager. There were 3 separate benches: one long bench that fits 12, two short bench that fit 6 each, and 4 chairs near the chef window. The place was definitely small but very clean and simple. Below each table were cubbies that reminded me of elementary school where we could fit our small purses or jackets. 
Came at 4:10pm so we were seated immediately and got to order before the large groups came in. 

::BLACK FRIDAY DEALS::
If you want something creamy and thick, go with vegan tantanmen or tori paitan ramen. If you want a lighter base, shio or shoyu.

Tori Paitan ramen 16.00: thick creamy rich chicken soup with BOTH pork chashu and duck chashu topped with menma, kale, burdock, and katsuobushi sauce. The sauce was SO rich and creamy. It wasn't too salty despite the creaminess. However half way through it got too heavy for me. Nonetheless the meat were all melt in your mouth perfection and the noodles were thick and cooked to amazing "bounciness" level.

It comes with 2 pieces of duck meat
but it's definitely better to double the meat for $2 dollars more (18 total).
The ramen noodles were cooked to perfection.
Broth flavor was a bit too creamy.
It lost its savory awesomeness after 3 bite.
The duck meat broke apart cause it was so tender!!
tori paitan.author: Ben N.
tori paitan.review:
If you like creamy savory ramen you should get the Tori Paitan, it's a combination of duck a beef. It comes with 2 pieces of duck meat but it's definitely better to double the meat for $2 dollars more (18 total). The ramen noodles were cooked to perfection. Broth flavor was a bit too creamy. It lost its savory awesomeness after 3 bite. The duck meat broke apart cause it was so tender!! I definitely prefer Himawari in San Mateo.

Service is awesome, place it small so get use to sharing tables! You'll wait outside in a line we got there at 7:10 on Thursday and waited about 35-40 minutes. I heard the wait was insane so it might not be worth it if you're waiting 1+ hour for it.

Maybe it's cause I'm new here but street parking only (difficult). Enjoy!

excerpts: Try the tori paitan.
You will thank me later
tori paitan.author: Paul M.
tori paitan.review: This is the best ramen available in San Francisco. Try the tori paitan. You will thank me later

excerpts: My belly is full and mouth has a satisfied pallette from the luxury creamy Tori Paitan Ramen with double Chasu.
So creamy that you think its made with milk.
Wrong!
tori paitan.author: Michelle P.
tori paitan.review:
My Oh My! My belly is full and mouth has a satisfied pallette from the luxury creamy Tori Paitan Ramen with double Chasu. So creamy that you think its made with milk. Wrong! Its a mixture of chicken broth and rice but no sight of either. 

Slightly disappointed with a selection of only 2 appetizers to choose from. 

Believe me after one bowl of ramen you wont walk away with any regrets. 

I didnt see a selection for Miso, Shoyu or spicy broth. Their broth their signature broth.  Good! You can ask for their signature chili oil if you need spice. 

Be prepared for seating arrangements. There are only 4 tables, one of which seats 13. Seating arrangements are all shared so prepare to get cozy. On a warm day like today powder up cuz you can get wet!  

This is a place that you sit eat and leave. It moves fast so dont be discouraged by the line. Fast eating. 

I will consider it for individuals or small parties cuz you have to share the table.

excerpts: and I got the Tori Paitan double chashu ramen, oyster appetizer and the premium malt beer.
One of his other friends got the shoyu ramen and that was okay/something you could get something similar elsewhere, but the tori paitan is where it's at.
The broth was SO creamy, rich, and something I wasn't normally used to.
It was surprisingly not salty at all yet VERY flavorful.
The noodles were cooked perfectly, nice and thick.
Out of the pork and duck chashu, I loved the duck.
It didn't fall apart like the pork, but it was melt-in-your-mouth/to-die-for perfect.
tori paitan.author: Kathleen S.
tori paitan.review:
Oh my god. I can't even describe how great the ramen is here. I haven't had anything like it until now.

The wait can be crazy, but hey it's SF. People wait over an hour for good brunch; I'm down to wait over an hour for some delicious ramen (and because I just love noodles). It was cute seeing people play games in line to kill time and made friends with other groups in line.

Was it worth it? YES. My boyfriend and I got the Tori Paitan double chashu ramen, oyster appetizer and the premium malt beer. One of his other friends got the shoyu ramen and that was okay/something you could get something similar elsewhere, but the tori paitan is where it's at. The broth was SO creamy, rich, and something I wasn't normally used to. It was surprisingly not salty at all yet VERY flavorful. The noodles were cooked perfectly, nice and thick. Out of the pork and duck chashu, I loved the duck. It didn't fall apart like the pork, but it was melt-in-your-mouth/to-die-for perfect. Everything about it was like heaven in a bowl.

The oysters were good to try once; marinaded heavily in shoyu dare oil that not everyone would like but worth a try if you're feeling adventurous. It usually comes with three pieces but because they brought out our ramen before the appetizer, they gave us an extra piece. Our beer was one of the Suntory malts that was one of the best Japanese beers I've had. 

This place is great. Bring some good company or try your luck by yourself in hopes that you could skip the line. I'm definitely looking forward to when they start making their own noodles & the tsukemen! Hopefully some decent tsukemen in SF!!

excerpts: We both got the tori paitan ramen.
The noodles are great and the broth was creamier than any other ramen restaurants I've been to.
My only gripe about the food here is that there's not much options.
I love spice and from looking at what they have to offer, I can only get that by ordering the veggie ramen.
If there's another way to do so, I could not find it. & adding spices is just not the same.
Overall, the ramen was delicious and if my boyfriend was writing this review, he would've given them a 5.
I'm sure we'll be visiting here again.
tori paitan.author: Trina V.
tori paitan.review:
So this restaurant isn't very huge and it's set up where customers share tables. They have 4 bar-height community tables, which I assume makes it difficult to sit bigger groups. 

The boyfriend and I came here one weekend and had a hard time finding parking. By the time we got there, there weren't a ridiculous amount of people in front of us, but still took about an hour to be seated. They need to take note of what Ramen Parlor in San Mateo does where they take your order and prepared shortly before you get seated so that by the time you are, your meal is ready. This might help in getting the wait time shorter. Because it takes some time to get your meal after you've ordered here.

Once you are seated, the space felt slightly cramped and you had to decide whether to sit across or next to whoever you went with. There are also bins underneath the table for your belongings, because there's nowhere else to put anything. 

We both got the tori paitan ramen. The noodles are great and the broth was creamier than any other ramen restaurants I've been to. My only gripe about the food here is that there's not much options. I love spice and from looking at what they have to offer, I can only get that by ordering the veggie ramen. If there's another way to do so, I could not find it. & adding spices is just not the same. Overall, the ramen was delicious and if my boyfriend was writing this review, he would've given them a 5. I'm sure we'll be visiting here again.

excerpts: Tori Paitan is their claim to fame.
It is rich
but oh so decadent.
The base of the sauce is almost a concentrated version of the Tori Paitan broth, with TONS of toppings, including the beloved duck chasu (treat yo self and get the double chasu).
tori paitan.author: Virginia Q.
tori paitan.review:
Tori Paitan is their claim to fame. It is rich but oh so decadent. The duck chasu is what dreams are made of. 

Mazesoba: is my secret, so here it is. MazeSoba is similar to Dan Dan Mein, but better. If one were to Google Maze Soba, it is described as ramen without the broth. The base of the sauce is almost a concentrated version of the Tori Paitan broth, with TONS of toppings, including the beloved duck chasu (treat yo self and get the double chasu). 

They also have my beloved Coedo beers.

The staff is incredibly friendly and they move fast. So be ready. 

Pro Tips: 
-Ramen etiquette, order your ramen, eat your ramen and leave. If you want to hangout with your friends, go across the street to the bar. You are the reason why the line is 2+hrs at any given time. 
-order the MazeSoba or coerce someone else in your party to.

excerpts: All three of us ordered the Tori Paitan Ramen.
The broth was way too rich and fatty.
I did like the texture of the noodles.
For $18 and a long wait, it's not worth the hype.
tori paitan.author: Yi Z.
tori paitan.review:
Shout-out to my friend Berta for waiting in line at 4:15pm so that we can get seated at opening time. If she had gotten there 5 minutes later, it would've been too late for the first seating.

The restaurant is small and lots of people are crammed into a few tables. I liked that the tables have a little cubby to put your stuff but the opening is too narrow for most women's purses. Given the lack of purse hooks combined with tall stools, there was no good place to put my bag. I also found the stools to be about 2 inches too high for the height of the table. If you have big legs, you may not fit.

Onto the food. I love tsukemen but apparently that is not being served yet. All three of us ordered the Tori Paitan Ramen. The broth was way too rich and fatty. I did like the texture of the noodles. For $18 and a long wait, it's not worth the hype.

excerpts: My first impression of their tori paitan ramen was the flawless execution of its individual components.

The noodles were a perfect al dente with some satisfying give to them on every bite; the pork chashu melted away with just right amount of fat and pork flavor; the chicken broth--very creamy and rich, maybe overpoweringly so, but still complex and enjoyable enough to have with every slurp; and the duck chashu...
just wow...
tori paitan.author: Derrek C.
tori paitan.review:
Historically, SF has had mediocore ramen at best, and shit-tier ramen at worst.  Meanwhile, the Peninsula hosts the remarkable Ramen Dojo/Parlor duo, while in the South Bay, solid ramen establishments seem to popup every year.  With Mensho Tokyo, SF can finally compete with all the other titans in the Bay Area.  And they're bringing more than just ramen--their mazesoba is delicious too!

My first impression of their tori paitan ramen was the flawless execution of its individual components.  The noodles were a perfect al dente with some satisfying give to them on every bite; the pork chashu melted away with just right amount of fat and pork flavor; the chicken broth--very creamy and rich, maybe overpoweringly so, but still complex and enjoyable enough to have with every slurp; and the duck chashu...just wow...it's DUCK chashu god dammit, something to die for.  

The whole bowl of ramen, with all of these components, was quite heavy, and might not be for everyone--but if extreme savoriness is your jam, then this might just be the best ramen in the Bay Area for you.

Also of interest is their mazesoba!  It's apparently a recent food trend in Japan, so Mensho Tokyo might currently be one of the only places to offer this dish in the United States.  Regardless, it's absolutely delicious and totally worth trying.  It's essentially a dry bowl of noodles (not quite soba though, a bit thicker and similar in consistency to their ramen) with some vegetable (green onions, chives, watercress, seaweed, garlic, etc.) and meat toppings (ground pork)--somewhat of a cross between bibimbap (it has the raw egg too) and zha jiang mian.  

Mixing it all together is when the magic happens.  Every bite of noodles was accompanied with a saucy mixture of meat, fragant herbs, and crunch from the vegetables.  Why hasn't anyone thought about doing this before?  It's worth mentioning that we got the extra spicy version, and it certainly did pack quite a kick!

The wait on a random Tuesday night was about 2 hours, and when we finished eating at 9ish, the line was still just as long!  Whether or not Mensho Tokyo is worth the steep prices (actually, probably normal pricing for SF) or absurd waiting times is really up to you, but the quality and meticulous execution of their dishes is undeniable.

excerpts: Ordered the tori paitan
and I wasn't impressed (esp how they are charging $16 for a bowl).
There's nothing really special about the ramen, more on the thicker side for noodles and the broth is more on the rich and creamy side.
tori paitan.author: Jessica L.
tori paitan.review:
Came to try this place out due to the crazy hype and a couple of friends saying it's the 'best ramen they had'. I got there Sunday around 8 something for dinner, didn't get seated until 9ish. 

Ordered the tori paitan and I wasn't impressed (esp how they are charging $16 for a bowl). There's nothing really special about the ramen, more on the thicker side for noodles and the broth is more on the rich and creamy side. Toppings were lacking (u have the option to add more kale/chasu for extra $). 

For $16 you'd expect that it comes with an egg or corn or something special.  However, it does come with a small piece of kale with the stem on (very unusual).  Definitely not worth the wait if you do decide to come try this place out and not worth $16 either.

excerpts: Following the footsteps of fellow Yelpers, we each ordered the Double Chasu Tori Paitan Ramen at $18.
I thought it was a little steep considering that the ramen didn't come with an egg, and double meat really just meant two thin slices of pork chasu and two thin slices of duck chasu.
The duck was definitely the highlight of meal.
The pork was on the salty side.
Noodles were chewy and el dente just the way I like it.
Broth was creamy but so loaded with chicken fat that it was deemed too unhealthy and rich to be drinkable by my friends...
The Tori Paitan was the clear winner here, but if you're not into thick broths, don't even bother coming here.
tori paitan.author: Catherine C.
tori paitan.review:
I hate waiting in lines, but like half of the Asian population in SF I just couldn't resist coming here to test my luck on a Saturday afternoon. I recommend coming 40 mins before opening in order to avoid a 1.5+ hour wait. We almost made it to the first round of seating by coming 20 mins before opening, but clearly there were people out there more determined than we were. The line only got worse after we were done eating around 7pm. 

Following the footsteps of fellow Yelpers, we each ordered the Double Chasu Tori Paitan Ramen at $18. I thought it was a little steep considering that the ramen didn't come with an egg, and double meat really just meant two thin slices of pork chasu and two thin slices of duck chasu. The duck was definitely the highlight of meal. The pork was on the salty side. Noodles were chewy and el dente just the way I like it. Broth was creamy but so loaded with chicken fat that it was deemed too unhealthy and rich to be drinkable by my friends...but I did it anyways! 

The organic shoyu ramen was too salty with strong a undercurrent of bonito and seaweed. The Tori Paitan was the clear winner here, but if you're not into thick broths, don't even bother coming here.

Customer service was efficient, and the greeter at the door was friendly. 

The restaurant seats around 25 people and is pretty tiny. Expect to squeeze with strangers at your table. Decor was clean and modern. I like that they have personal baskets below the table for you to store your purse and jacket. 

Overall worth a try for the duck chasu and delightfully chewy noodles, but not worth repeat visits because of the line.

excerpts: I got the tori paitan because I prefer the thicker, creamy broth.
The noodles have a little bite to them which I love.
And the duck and pork chashu just melts in your mouth.
tori paitan.author: Christine L.
tori paitan.review:
The BEST ramen you will ever have. I got the tori paitan because I prefer the thicker, creamy broth. The noodles have a little bite to them which I love. And the duck and pork chashu just melts in your mouth. It's like a dream. 

Me and my boyfriend always come around 10:30-11:00 to avoid the long line. Even then it's still about a 20 to 30 minute wait which I really don't mind because the food and service is sooo worth it. They always have a door man at the front who happily answers any questions you may have about the menu and fills you in on what the owner has planned for for the restaurant. 

I recommend coming in small groups or even by yourself because there is no way a large party can sit together without waiting for hours and hours. They only have Japanese style communal tables so you're always going to be sitting with strangers. I actually enjoy that because every time we go we get seated next to some really fun people :) 

5 stars for the whole experience.

excerpts: So my tummy was already a bit too occupied for the super thick broth and chashu and delicious noodles of the Tori Paitan Ramen.
The broth is creamy and tastes great, definitely, but it was super thick.
Next time I'll come back after a leg day for the Tori Paitan.
Then the vegan ramen for the third time.
tori paitan.author: Sheila D.
tori paitan.review:
When you're planning a first date, Mensho is a good choice because you have to stand with them in line for about 45 minutes on a cold SF Tuesday evening. If you're introverted or shy or socially awkward, tell your date to meet you there and show up a little later to minimize the waiting and awkward small talk and homeless approaching you for money.  

Come here when you're hungry, borderline starving. I inhaled an açaí bowl as I was leaving work, right before I came here. So my tummy was already a bit too occupied for the super thick broth and chashu and delicious noodles of the Tori Paitan Ramen. The broth is creamy and tastes great, definitely, but it was super thick. The friendly people sitting next to us suggested the vegan ramen for next time. 

Did I mention the restaurant is small and cozy? The plus side is you get to listen to your neighbors talk about girls they like and their game plan to dating them. Interesting. 

I felt ashamed looking at the leftover food. I usually kill my ramen. But I couldn't handle it. On top of that, Mensho does not have take out containers. So like I said.. come here when you're hungry. 

Next time I'll come back after a leg day for the Tori Paitan. Then the vegan ramen for the third time.

excerpts: Delicious ramen, we had the Tori Paitan and fried mushrooms.
What I like the most about the ramen were the noodles, thick but perfectly cooked.
tori paitan.author: Lorely G.
tori paitan.review: Worth the wait in line, if you need to catch up with a friend, like I did, it wouldn't bother you. Once you are seated service is efficient. Delicious ramen, we had the Tori Paitan and fried mushrooms. What I like the most about the ramen were the noodles, thick but perfectly cooked.

excerpts: Got the Tori Paitan: I'm a bit conservative
so I get thrown off when they have kale in my ramen
(it's SF, duh!).
Despite being open-minded, I prefer my spinach.
Another point that I'm extremely disappointed: they don't have the soft-boiled eggs.
tori paitan.author: Connie T.
tori paitan.review:
Came in at 8pm, got in 915pm, weekend. Overrated by the wait but I'll try to be super objective. 

Got the oyster app: unique flavour, strong soy taste, bit salty, but for sure worth a try. Why not, you waited for so long already.

Got the Tori Paitan: I'm a bit conservative so I get thrown off when they have kale in my ramen (it's SF, duh!). Despite being open-minded, I prefer my spinach. Another point that I'm extremely disappointed: they don't have the soft-boiled eggs. Great al-dente noodles, flavourful broth but nothing out of this world that you should wait for 1.5hrs.

Part of the reason why the line is so long, is the restaurant can only house up to 25seats. Overall: I'll pass.

excerpts:
Me and boyfriend ended up sharing a total of 3 bowls:
- Tori Paitan ($18):
The most decadent of them all, a creamy and rich chicken based broth with pork + duck chashu.
The broth was good, however I couldn't get over the slight grittiness of the broth.
That duck chashu though!
Served with round thick chewy noodles.
- Oraganic Ramen ($14):
A blend of chicken + pork clear broth seasoned with shoyu and comes with pork + duck chasu.
Served with flat thick chewy noodles.
tori paitan.author: Minh N.
tori paitan.review:
Finally a worthy ramen shop in the Bay Area!

I happened to stumble upon Mensho Tokyo by pure coincidence on Instagram of all places. My plan of attack was to come straight here right after the halftime Super Bowl show. Line was about 30 people stacked already, but it took us only 45 minutes of waiting. Not bad, considering I overheard people waiting 2-3 hours grand opening night on Saturday. Plan worked! 

Totally digging the interior design and details of this place. There's coat hooks on the wall to hang your jacket, woven baskets underneath the table to stash your purse, and even a storage space under the table to keep your phone ready for some picture action. I totally geeked out on the molecular structures and science blurb of umami on the wall. Even the wooden spoon and chopsticks neatly laying on top of the ceramic plate was just perfect.

Me and boyfriend ended up sharing a total of 3 bowls:
- Tori Paitan ($18): The most decadent of them all, a creamy and rich chicken based broth with pork + duck chashu. The broth was good, however I couldn't get over the slight grittiness of the broth. That duck chashu though! Served with round thick chewy noodles.
- Oraganic Ramen ($14): A blend of chicken + pork clear broth seasoned with shoyu and comes with pork + duck chasu. Served with flat thick chewy noodles. My boyfriend's favorite of the 3.
- Shio Ramen ($9): The cheapest bowl and also my favorite. Similar to Organic Ramen, but with a salt (not shoyu). Simple fixings with pork chashu and some fried garlic bits. Served with flat thick chewy noodles.

I loved the clear broths of both the organic and shio ramen. It was flavorfu and not overly salty. Can really taste the complex flavors of seaweed and seafood notes. I like the Shio Ramen just a bit more because of its simplicity, allowing the broth to shine. The broth comes out HOT (the way it should be). I won't lie, I slurped that bowl clean!

The pork chashu was melt in your mouth delicious. Duck chashu was completely new to my tastebuds and is as amazing as it sounds. Their in-house made ramen noodles are the thicker kind and the shape depends on which bowl you get. The toppings were different, such as fried burdock, kale, or sprouts, but the novelty works.

There's 28 seats in this joint, but turn over seems fast. I dined in and out in 30 minutes.

Since they just opened, they have a very limited menu, hopefully to expand next month with tonkotsu and tsukemen. The vegan ramen sounds intriguing as well. Can't wait to try more!

excerpts: I had the opportunity to try the Tori Paitan Double Chashu and the Organic Shoyu Ramen Double Chasu.
Tori Paitan -
This isn't your typical ramen you'll get at Santouka or Orenchi; it is a must try.
The broth is thicker, heavier, and I would say a little bit creamy.
The noodles here are definitely hand made.
The broth stuck to the noodles so well that it was like eating soup and noodles at the same time!
It was a very harmonious dish.
Organic Shoyu -
The soup for this ramen isn't as heavy as the Tori Paitan.
It is lighter but came across super oily in my opinion.
Noodles in my Ramen were in the softer side.
So if you like stiff noodles, then don't expect that here.
Also the chashu is so soft, flavorful, and tender.
tori paitan.author: Stefanie W.
tori paitan.review:
This place is like a hidden gem. 

The shop itself is quite small so be prepared to wait to be seated. I arrived at the shop around 6ish and ended up waiting for an hour before we got seated. Luckily it was a nice warm day in San Francisco. 

Once you are seated, they are very prompt and quick with their service as their line is never ending. I had the opportunity to try the Tori Paitan Double Chashu and the Organic Shoyu Ramen Double Chasu.

Tori Paitan - This isn't your typical ramen you'll get at Santouka or Orenchi; it is a must try. The broth is thicker, heavier, and I would say a little bit creamy. The noodles here are definitely hand made. The broth stuck to the noodles so well that it was like eating soup and noodles at the same time! It was a very harmonious dish. If you're looking for something with a powerful flavor you should get this dish.

Organic Shoyu - The soup for this ramen isn't as heavy as the Tori Paitan. It is lighter but came across super oily in my opinion. Noodles in my Ramen were in the softer side. So if you like stiff noodles, then don't expect that here. Also the chashu is so soft, flavorful, and tender. It falls apart easily and makes it easy to eat. 

This place definitely has nailed the umami taste.

excerpts: We had the Shoyu and Tori Paitan ramen, and the Tori Paitan was much better than the Shoyu (it was too salty).
The broths did taste much more deluxe than other ramen places, but the bowl as a whole didn't impress me with the lack of ingredients and saltiness.
tori paitan.author: Claudia C.
tori paitan.review:
The ramen wasn't bad, but it wasn't great. Honestly feel like Mensho is way overhyped. 

We waited in line for almost 2 hours (service is slow and the shop is tiny), so we were really excited to finally sit down and try the ramen. We had the Shoyu and Tori Paitan ramen, and the Tori Paitan was much better than the Shoyu (it was too salty). The broths did taste much more deluxe than other ramen places, but the bowl as a whole didn't impress me with the lack of ingredients and saltiness.

excerpts: Our group ordered mostly the Tori Paitan ramen which appears to be their signature "house" dish.
But I have heard great things about the vegan ramen and I would want to try that
the next time I come back.
The quality of the ramen soup is extremely thick, less like a broth and more like a sauce.
Although the quantity does not look like much, it will be very filling because of how dense the soup is.
Someone also ordered the mazesoba, which is known for a spicy kick and is very delicious.
You can get it at a variety of spice levels, but even the medium was pretty hot.
Their spicy doesn't "linger" the way chili paste sometimes can, but I don't know if I would be able to handle an entire dish of that.
We also asked for a recommendation of sake and got the Dassai, which was so good
tori paitan.author: Maureen C.
tori paitan.review:
When I first heard about Mensho and subsequently read about the art of ramen, I was very excited to come here. By now, surely you must have heard about the potentially monumental wait times. My friends and I arrived at around 4:30 and the six of us were the last to get first seating at 5:00 and it was a pretty good feeling to make it into the door, especially after we turned around and looked at the line that grew behind us. 

Our group ordered mostly the Tori Paitan ramen which appears to be their signature "house" dish. But I have heard great things about the vegan ramen and I would want to try that the next time I come back. The quality of the ramen soup is extremely thick, less like a broth and more like a sauce. Although the quantity does not look like much, it will be very filling because of how dense the soup is. Someone also ordered the mazesoba, which is known for a spicy kick and is very delicious. You can get it at a variety of spice levels, but even the medium was pretty hot. Their spicy doesn't "linger" the way chili paste sometimes can, but I don't know if I would be able to handle an entire dish of that. We also asked for a recommendation of sake and got the Dassai, which was so good it got me reading a bunch of articles about sake making.

My recommendation would be to go with people you like because you should just expect a wait of some substance, know that you will be dropping about $20 for a bowl of ramen, and just enjoy the experience without getting hung up on that other stuff.

excerpts: We got two orders of the Tori Paitan and one order of the Shio ramen.
The Tori Paitan is basically a chicken based Tonkotsu ramen and the Shio is salt based.
The Tori Paitan is basically a chicken based Tonkotsu ramen and the Shio is salt based.
The Tori Paitan was freaking amazing.
It was just packed with flavor.
The broth was thick and there was heaps of meat inside.
The chashu was very delicious and quite possibly the best chashu I had in a bowl of ramen.
Well, actually, this is probably the best ramen I've had in my life.
I've been to Japan and eaten plenty of too.
The Shio ramen was very light in comparison to the Tori Paitan.
It was very delicious as well.
It had a nice clean flavor and was very beautiful.
It was very very very good as well
The Shio ramen was very light in comparison to the Tori Paitan.
It was very delicious as well.
It had a nice clean flavor and was very beautiful.
It was very very very good as well
, I just preferred the Tori Paitan because I'm a fan of thicker broths.
Tip, if you order two bowls of ramen start off with the lighter bowl first (not Tori Paitan) because once you go light to thick broth you can really taste and notice the difference of thickness.
tori paitan.author: Allen C.
tori paitan.review:
Came here on the grand opening on the first day and waited for LONG LONG time to get inside even though I was one of the first 20 people. 

The restaurant opened at 5PM, but I probably didn't get in until like 6:30PM. It was the first day on grand opening and it was superbowl weekend. It was pretty cool to see Chef Shono come out and greet everybody and also Abram AKA Ramen Beast. They took photos, some of us got interviewed. 

They didn't want to overwhelm the staff and chefs in the back so they only seated a few people at once. Everybody waiting in line was a little angry because we've been waiting for so long, but they just want to make sure everything goes well for the first day. 

Because me and my friend waited for so long we ordered 3 bowls of ramen. We got two orders of the Tori Paitan and one order of the Shio ramen. The Tori Paitan is basically a chicken based Tonkotsu ramen and the Shio is salt based. 

The Tori Paitan was freaking amazing. It was just packed with flavor. The broth was thick and there was heaps of meat inside. The chashu was very delicious and quite possibly the best chashu I had in a bowl of ramen. Well, actually, this is probably the best ramen I've had in my life. I've been to Japan and eaten plenty of too. This was definitely on that japan-level. 

The Shio ramen was very light in comparison to the Tori Paitan. It was very delicious as well. It had a nice clean flavor and was very beautiful. It was very very very good as well, I just preferred the Tori Paitan because I'm a fan of thicker broths. It was paired with flat noodles.

Tip, if you order two bowls of ramen start off with the lighter bowl first (not Tori Paitan) because once you go light to thick broth you can really taste and notice the difference of thickness. 

This is by far the best ramen shop in the Bay Area. The wait is incredibly long right now, so I'd advise you to wait till the hype dies down. Shono-san will be coming back to Mensho in March and will be added new items to the Menu. I cant wait!

excerpts: I felt the tori paitan's broth texture seemed a bit too powdery.
It's like when you cook broth and  the all that remained was the powdery portion.
tori paitan.author: Kent H.
tori paitan.review:
Unfortunately I do not know what the buzz was about.  It's definitely on the pricey side, but it's SF.  

I felt the tori paitan's broth texture seemed a bit too powdery.  It's like when you cook broth and  the all that remained was the powdery portion.  The meats weren't bad.

The shio ramen was better, though not by much.  The broth was light and flavorful.  For both dishes I didn't like the ramen noodles themselves, not your typical noodles, they were of the flat wavy style.

We waited about 1 hr on a Thursday night.

excerpts: The wait didn't feel too terrible--we were seated at 5:36PM--and I was excited to try the much raved-about $18 Tori Paitan (Double Chashu), as well as the $18 Clam Butter Ramen (currently limited to 10 bowls daily).
The Tori Paitan was definitely the highlight of the night.
As many other reviews have noted, the broth is thick and almost gravy-like.
The noodles were hot and just the right amount of chewy, and the the only thing missing from the bowl was a soft-boiled egg.
tori paitan.author: Amanda W.
tori paitan.review:
Have you ever had ramen that was SO amazing, it absolutely ruins all other ramen for you?

Unfortunately, that was not my experience at Mensho Tokyo.  While the ramen is undeniably good and I am by no means a ramen connoisseur, I think I would have been similarly satisfied with a bowl at Waraku or Men Oh.  Maybe this was a dangerous product of high expectations combined with over-hype, but my meal last Friday night did not blow me away as much as I had hoped.

My boyfriend and I got in line at 4:40PM last Friday night, and we missed the first seating by 1 party of two.  The wait didn't feel too terrible--we were seated at 5:36PM--and I was excited to try the much raved-about $18 Tori Paitan (Double Chashu), as well as the $18 Clam Butter Ramen (currently limited to 10 bowls daily).  We also ordered the $5 Oysters in Shoyu Dare Oil for appetizer, as well as a $18.55 bottle of Kikusui "Perfect Snow" Sake.  Service was fast and we did not have to wait long for our food to come out.

The Tori Paitan was definitely the highlight of the night.  As many other reviews have noted, the broth is thick and almost gravy-like.  The noodles were hot and just the right amount of chewy, and the the only thing missing from the bowl was a soft-boiled egg.  It was my first time having duck chashu, and I LOVE duck, but I can't say I prefer it any more or less to the standard pork chashu.

The Clam Butter Ramen was a little more of a miss, and we probably should have ordered something more traditional like the Shio or Shoyu Ramen.  The broth started off tasting light and delicious, but over time the taste of raw seafood ("like the ocean") permeated the entire bowl.  My boyfriend noted the noodles were not hot as in the Tori Paitain; perhaps that was to prevent overcooking of the clams and scallops in the dish?  I was expecting the broth to taste a little more "cooked," so I would not recommend this dish if you are adverse to an overly "raw" seafood taste.

The Oysters in Shoyu Dare Oil were similarly raw tasting; I love oysters, but from the pictures I did not expect it to taste this much like the ocean.  Some pieces had sand/gravel in them, so at least you know it's fresh?

The waitresses are prompt in cleaning up your bowls after you are done, which I appreciated; however, they took away my napkin before I was done drinking my sake. :(

Overall, I am not in a rush to return, but on the off-chance I walk by and there is no line, I'd give this place another shot.  Finally, note that they do not offer to-go or take-out containers, but you won't be needing any since the portions run on the small side for the price.

excerpts: The Tori Paitan is pretty rich, stew like (similar to tonkotsu) and perfectly seasoned.
The star of the dish was the duck chashu, so tender and thin.
tori paitan.author: Jeff T.
tori paitan.review:
There's a new ramen wave hitting the bay and I can't say I'm mad at this. The latest addition is Mensho Tokyo and there's already lines out the door even before it opens for dinner. Had to wait 2 hours (worth it!)

The Tori Paitan is pretty rich, stew like (similar to tonkotsu) and perfectly seasoned. The star of the dish was the duck chashu, so tender and thin. The shoyu is the lighter choice, although it was a tad bit oily 

The restaurant seems to be still working out kinks. The menu is currently limited to four main items. The creator is supposed to be back by the end of the month to roll out more items and homemade noodles are also expected later this year. I can't wait to try this place out again in the near future.

excerpts: I had the tori paitan.
I was surprised to hear that they don't have the tonkatsu ramen yet.
Should I dock them a star for not having that ready yet?
Uh, no.
The soup for tori paitan is VERY rich.
To the point where it's almost like a gravy.
So drink sparingly if you can't handle the richness.
I'm used to having tonkatsu ramen hakata style, so while tonkatsu is rich, it's less thick than this variation of tori paitan.
So basically I am saying the tori paitan was a bit too rich and thick for my liking.
tori paitan.author: Kai C.
tori paitan.review:
I feel strongly and shake my head when I read the other reviews when they docked this place for a couple of stars because of the long wait or the ramen is too salty. Ramen is my JAM. These amateurs obviously don't know ramen. Ramen is always salty. It's not mean to be a bland soup. Also, good food is worth the wait if you have the time to wait and if you want to eat the good food enough. I must admit in SF, many people love to wait BUT there are very few places that I am willing to wait long for the food. This is one of them. 

On a Sunday night around 9:15pm, I waited 45 minutes to eat so I already had high expectations for the food since this is more than the average amount of time I am willing to wait for the food. 

I had the tori paitan. I was surprised to hear that they don't have the tonkatsu ramen yet. Should I dock them a star for not having that ready yet? Uh, no. The soup for tori paitan is VERY rich. To the point where it's almost like a gravy. So drink sparingly if you can't handle the richness. I'm used to having tonkatsu ramen hakata style, so while tonkatsu is rich, it's less thick than this variation of tori paitan. So basically I am saying the tori paitan was a bit too rich and thick for my liking. 

But why am I giving this place 5 stars even though I think the broth is too rich and thick? Because it was freaking tasty and the ingredients are fantastic. The ramen goes for $16 which is on the higher end but the ingredients are high quality so you get what you pay for. For those people who gripe over the price probably are those who like bang for buck over quality...not my type of food philosophy. If you want the best ramen in SF and willing to pay on the higher side for it then this is your place. The lines will be long because everyone else wants in on this greatness. Come when you have the time to spare. I certainly don't have much time to spare so I probably won't be coming more than once a month or every other month. But I will look forward to it when I do.

excerpts: The Tori Paitan has one of the most flavorful broths I've ever tasted and every sip is like having pure concentrated chicken.
tori paitan.author: Matt M.
tori paitan.review:
If you haven't lived in San Francisco you'll probably make the assumption that there are a lot of great ramen places there - it's a major city after all. Sadly the locals will disappoint you immediately by dissuading you of this myth and telling you to trek south to the far remote lands of San Mateo and San Jose to seek what you crave. If you're like me and the thought of ever leaving downtown is off the table you've just kind of accepted that you'll never have ramen quite as good as you would in Tokyo or even Los Angeles.

And then, Mensho Tokyo opened its doors. Since that day it's been really clear that the inhabitants of San Francisco are suffering from a severe ramen shortage because the lines to eat at this tiny place haven't let up. Part of the reason is that there are only around twenty spots to eat in this place but still, I would have expected the demand to let up a bit after a few months; your best bet is to show up around 4:30pm before the restaurant opens if you want to be seated in less than an hour.

There is good reason for the demand: the ramen is unquestionably the best in the city. The Tori Paitan has one of the most flavorful broths I've ever tasted and every sip is like having pure concentrated chicken. The Vegan Tantanmen is shockingly savory and meat-like for a dish that is meat-free - I know some of you are likely skeptical of this one but I guarantee you will not be disappointed and go out on a limb here.

I would say that despite how good everything I've eaten here has been I still wouldn't put it up there with my favorite ramens. For truly satisfying comfort food ecstasy you're still going to have to heed the advice of your local friends and travel south on the peninsula to the likes of Ramen Dojo and Santouka.
