excerpts: I ordered the Tori Paitan Ramen with extra Chashu.
The broth was everything I wanted it to be: thick, creamy, fully seasoned, with a hearty feel.
The pork chashu was amazing, and did not disappoint to melt in my mouth.
tori paitan.author: Sarah B.
tori paitan.review:
I went to Mensho Tokyo at 6:15 and was seated around 8:00. Yes, the line was long, but the real question: was it worth it?

I ordered the Tori Paitan Ramen with extra Chashu. The broth was everything I wanted it to be: thick, creamy, fully seasoned, with a hearty feel. The pork chashu was amazing, and did not disappoint to melt in my mouth. The duck was a little less memorable, but still really nice. 

If I had extra time to devote to standing in line every day, I would definitely be a regular! This place is a great addition to the neighborhood, and I love having a remarkable ramen shop right up the street!

excerpts: My boyfriend & I both got the tori paitan and it was so good!
The broth was extremely creamy and thick and the noodles were cooked to perfection.
tori paitan.author: Lina T.
tori paitan.review:
I came here because I've been looking for a good ramen place in the city & my friend recommended me Mensho. And let me tell you guys, this place is the real deal. I came here on a Wednesday night and I waited maybe 5 minutes before getting seated. The place is super super small, but still comfortable. The service was decent. 

My boyfriend & I both got the tori paitan and it was so good! The broth was extremely creamy and thick and the noodles were cooked to perfection. The pork and duck chasu were delicious and everything about the dish had a great flavor balance. 

They also do an automatic 15% gratuity/service charge just fyi.

All in all, I would definitely come back here again! Looking forward to trying other dishes on their menu :-)

excerpts: Our group tried the Tori Paitan, the Shoyu Ramen, and the Shio Ramen.
I had the Shoyu and it was super flavorful.
The broth was pretty strong on the bonito flavor, so if that's something you dislike you should try the Tori Paitan instead.
tori paitan.author: Kelly L.
tori paitan.review:
Best ramen in SF!

We tried our luck on Saturday to see if the hype was legit. Be warned: the restaurant only seats 28 people at a time and the line gets BANANAS. The wait for people end of the line at 5 pm (opening time) was about 2 hours. It was twice as long by the time we left. The host mentioned that 10 or 10:30pm was a good time to come if you didn't mind waiting until after the regular dinner rush.

Be aware that they are not currently serving Tonkotsu Ramen or White Truffle Shio ramen.

We shared two orders of the oysters in shoyu dare oil. They were good but nothing to really write home about. Definitely don't get them if you're planning on getting the shoyu ramen (unless you really, really like shoyu) because they taste pretty much the same. 

Our group tried the Tori Paitan, the Shoyu Ramen, and the Shio Ramen. I had the Shoyu and it was super flavorful. The broth was pretty strong on the bonito flavor, so if that's something you dislike you should try the Tori Paitan instead.

The chashu was A+ and practically fell apart when I picked it up. The noodles were excellent as well.

Service could have been better. I understand that they're working out the kinks and that the demand is super crazy, but with only 28 seats and a constant feeling of "we need to turn these tables over quickly" I don't think we should have needed to flag someone down for water and our check.

Overall, the food was pretty great and is definitely bringing the SF Ramen scene in the right direction. I'd love to come back later on when they have a fuller menu.

excerpts: I ordered the Tori Paitan, double chashu.
From the yelp reviews I read prior, I expected the creamy, slightly heavy, rich broth.
It's definitely something I haven't had before.
There's a lot of hype around this bowl of ramen and it's justified.
It was delicious.
The noodles were spot on; the chashu was incredible -- melt in your mouth.
tori paitan.author: Jeannie L.
tori paitan.review:
I came here at 3:50pm on a Saturday to secure a first seating seat. People start showing up after 4pm, so the line increased rapidly after that. They open right at 5pm and you're greeted by Abram, who is super welcoming, nice and willing to answer all questions you may have.

They make the most of the small space so there are three communal tables and four seats at the bar. Supposedly, there's 28 seats total but I didn't bother to count -- I was too excited. 

The menu is also posted on the wall. It's currently a tease of things to come since there are only 4 items listed as of Saturday. The chef is coming back this week (2/29/16) and they plan on putting more items on the menu. 

We got the one appetizer listed on the menu - oysters in dare oil. Beware, it doesn't taste like an oyster. It's this creamy and rich oyster that tastes borderline like monkfish liver. It was surprisingly yummy. 

I ordered the Tori Paitan, double chashu. From the yelp reviews I read prior, I expected the creamy, slightly heavy, rich broth. It's definitely something I haven't had before. There's a lot of hype around this bowl of ramen and it's justified. It was delicious. The noodles were spot on; the chashu was incredible -- melt in your mouth. Order double, no question about it. 

The only reason this doesn't get 5 stars in my book is that my flavor profile gears towards a thinner broth, which is why I'll be back once there are additional items on the menu. I can't wait! I can imagine that with the different broths, this will be a spot I will highly recommend. 

You have to come to this spot expecting two things 1) a wait and 2) the price tag. I understand both and still will gladly return. There are just some things that just are worth my money and this is one of them. And to everyone saying, you could make this at home with a package of top ramen -- you're delusional.

excerpts: Tori Paitan Ramen has a full body and very dense broth.
Very flavorful, every sip is a surprise, and it won't get me bored.
Some people might found it a bit too oily or creamy, but I think it is thick yet not too much.
The ramen noodle itself is one of the best noodle I had in the Bay.
All other ingredients are pretty good.
The Shoyu broth is very good, too.
It is saltier than the Tori Paitan, which it should be.
tori paitan.author: Zack Y.
tori paitan.review:
I really wanna give this place a bad review and make people stop going, so I can skip the long wait at their door.

This place ain't gonna be a typical ramen shop that you may find near the bay, the ramen is close to a traditional Japanese ramen.

You should be there before they open, like 4:30 is a good time to be there, and sometimes that even won't make you in the top 3. If you be there at 5, expect at least half an hour wait. By 5:30, it is going to be at least 1.5 hour wait.

The place didn't even have a sign outside, and the address on Yelp is wrong(672 is the right one.) Inside is pretty small that only have around 30 settings. Interior is good, lets get to the food.

Tori Paitan Ramen has a full body and very dense broth. Very flavorful, every sip is a surprise, and it won't get me bored. Some people might found it a bit too oily or creamy, but I think it is thick yet not too much. The ramen noodle itself is one of the best noodle I had in the Bay. All other ingredients are pretty good. The Shoyu broth is very good, too. It is saltier than the Tori Paitan, which it should be. I have not yet tried the shio base yet, will try it next time.

over all very good, service may not be the best because they are not very good at English, but I am very happy with my visit.

excerpts: then the Tori paitan.
Noodles were cooked to perfection
I don't think you'll go wrong with whatever ramen.
I tried my friend's Tori paitan and it was super delicious as well with the creamiest taken broth I've ever had.
Next time I think I'll try the maze spicy ramen because I love spice.
tori paitan.author: Thao T.
tori paitan.review:
Really great ramen that's worth the wait. I had the double ume ship ramen which had lighter flatter noodles then the Tori paitan. Noodles were cooked to perfection I don't think you'll go wrong with whatever ramen. I tried my friend's Tori paitan and it was super delicious as well with the creamiest taken broth I've ever had. Next time I think I'll try the maze spicy ramen because I love spice. This place doesn't do any Togo, even with leftovers, so keep that in mind! 

Waiting experience: Went there yesterday with my group of 8 people. I started lining up at 4 and my group formed by 4:30. We were asked for orders while in line and were promptly seated at 5. So yes, about an hour wait, but it was with friends so I didn't mind much. I really love the little baskets they provide underneath the tables, great for storing your things. Although, the chairs were high and wobbly which made me a bit concerned. Atmosphere was overall very nice. Place is very cramped though, if you don't like dining so close with strangers this place may not be for you. It's also an extremely busy and tiny restaurant so they expect you to leave right after. My whole group left by 5:30. All in all, I really enjoyed the food and experience.

excerpts: I ordered the tori paitan ramen, easily one of the most unique bowls of ramen I've had in years.
It's a chicken-based broth so thick that it almost tastes like gravy.
The deliciously soft pieces of pork chashu are complimented by pieces of duck chasu (you have to order these on top of your ramen), both of which basically melt in your mouth.
tori paitan.author: Philip W.
tori paitan.review:
Mensho has taken my stomach by storm and edged itself very securely into my top 3 favorite ramen restaurants in the Bay Area. I had no idea what to expect walking in and was blown away by the ramen I experienced in Mensho. 

I ordered the tori paitan ramen, easily one of the most unique bowls of ramen I've had in years. It's a chicken-based broth so thick that it almost tastes like gravy. The deliciously soft pieces of pork chashu are complimented by pieces of duck chasu (you have to order these on top of your ramen), both of which basically melt in your mouth. Within this concoction of broth and chashu sits strands upon strands of the most delicious noodles in San Francisco. 

I've always considered good ramen to be art in food form. Sometimes it looks beautiful, sometimes it tastes beautiful, and in rare situations it's both. Mensho is such a case. The way the chasu floats in the rich broth is gorgeous but the way everything tastes is even better. Everything has a different consistency here that tastes just right, from the melt-in-your-mouth chasu to the gravy-thick broth to the sturdy noodles. I had a great time eating here.

excerpts: I happened to finish the Tori Paitan in under 10 minutes.
That is how good it was.
I highly recommend this place.
tori paitan.author: Allyson L.
tori paitan.review: Of course I have had ramen before but wow this was delicious. Honestly worth the wait. My cousin and I got there at 4:25 and we were the 15th and 16th person in line. We were seated and they got to us right away. We didn't have to wait long for our food thankfully. When it came out, my mouth started watering and the smell was delicious. You know food is good when you eat it fast. I happened to finish the Tori Paitan in under 10 minutes. That is how good it was. I highly recommend this place.

excerpts: I opted to get their fancy tori paitan for my first visit,
juuuust in case
I decided it would also be my last.
The broth was SUPER rich, almost thick enough for what you would expect to find with tsukemen.
The tori paitan comes with pork and duck chashu, both of which were really good - but I have to admit the duck threw me off.
It was kind of weird to have it in my ramen, even if it was super tasty.
Where I think Mensho really shines are their noodles
- they were thick, chewy, and al dente - SO GOOD.
I'm coming back purely based on how much I liked their noodles, but I'll definitely opt for one of the lighter broths (which are a more reasonable $9-$12 range).
tori paitan.author: Lily C.
tori paitan.review:
Got here around 4:30pm on a weekday, so I just had to wait for them to open, but there was already a line when I got there. This small ramen joint only seats 24, so wait times can obviously get long. I opted to get their fancy tori paitan for my first visit, juuuust in case I decided it would also be my last. The broth was SUPER rich, almost thick enough for what you would expect to find with tsukemen. The tori paitan comes with pork and duck chashu, both of which were really good - but I have to admit the duck threw me off. It was kind of weird to have it in my ramen, even if it was super tasty. Where I think Mensho really shines are their noodles - they were thick, chewy, and al dente - SO GOOD. I'm coming back purely based on how much I liked their noodles, but I'll definitely opt for one of the lighter broths (which are a more reasonable $9-$12 range). They also don't have their full menu up yet, so I'd love to see what else is on offer.

Service was really nice, friendly, and quick. We all slurped up our noodles and we were in and outta there in 35 mins. Def ranks in my top 5 ramen places in the city.

The Tori Paitan seemed like it was a thicker and creamier broth compared to the Organic Shoyu but had very good noodles.

tori paitan.author: Howard J.
tori paitan.review:
Arriving one hour early to be ahead of the line, we had pretty high expectations going into the restaurant. My friends ordered the Tori Paitan ramen while I ordered the Organic Shoyu Ramen. 

The Tori Paitan seemed like it was a thicker and creamier broth compared to the Organic Shoyu but had very good noodles. 

The Organic Shoyu Ramen had a much lighter taste but still retaining the taste of shoyu that other restaurants. I recommend this for those that like lighter tastes or are in a mood for something not too creamy. The chashu was very tasteful and would be considered one of the better chashu that I've had. The noodles however for the Organic Shoyu Ramen was the flatter noodles which I don't like as much as the normal ramen noodles. 

Overall, despite the lack of egg, I was plenty pleased with the Organic Shoyu Ramen but I would be more pleased if I could have the other noodles with it.

excerpts: We ordered the one that everyone else on Yelp ordered and recommended which was the Tori Paitan.
tori paitan.author: Dara S.
tori paitan.review:
I had dinner here last night with a friend. Came around 9:40 PM and was seated at about 10:25 PM. I heard the wait is longer if you come around dinner time so we opted for a later time. We ordered the one that everyone else on Yelp ordered and recommended which was the Tori Paitan. 

Wow, that was literally the best bowl of ramen I have ever had. Up until now I wasn't such a huge fan of ramen because none really stuck out to me. They all pretty much tasted the same to me to be quite honest. 

The broth was probably my favorite part, it was creamy, thick, and loaded with tons of flavor. I think the noodles resembled garlic noodles but that's just my opinion. Pretty much everything in that bowl of ramen was delicious and all gone at the end. We devoured that bowl.

This new ramen addition in SF is worth the hype and the wait!

excerpts: Tried the tori paitan, vegan tantan, and shio ramens -- LOVED ALL OF THEM.
You really can't go wrong with any of these.
Going in, I definitely had my usual pessimistic doubts about the place.
+ Tori Paitan - Richest broth of them all.
This was my top pick at the start.
Got through half the bowl and just couldn't do it anymore.
+ Vegan tantan
- Upon first taste, was a bit sweet but
a lovely complexity and spice/heat comes out as you eat it.
A bit of a creamy peanut-y taste.
I would probably get this over the tori paitan next time.
+ Shio - The true favorite.
A true broth rather than a creamy soup, it was rich in flavor profile.
Noodles are flatter in the shio.
tori paitan.author: Jennifer M.
tori paitan.review:
Lined up at 5:15pm on a Friday and waited about 2 hours. Tried the tori paitan, vegan tantan, and shio ramens -- LOVED ALL OF THEM. You really can't go wrong with any of these. Going in, I definitely had my usual pessimistic doubts about the place. Mensho is truly worth the wait though! 

+ Tori Paitan - Richest broth of them all. This was my top pick at the start. Got through half the bowl and just couldn't do it anymore.
+ Vegan tantan - Upon first taste, was a bit sweet but a lovely complexity and spice/heat comes out as you eat it. A bit of a creamy peanut-y taste. I would probably get this over the tori paitan next time.
+ Shio - The true favorite. A true broth rather than a creamy soup, it was rich in flavor profile. I could finish this whole bowl by myself, unlike with the other two.

Duck 'chashu' in ramen is new to me... but ended up being a good thing as I love duck and it is served at a perfect medium rare! Noodles are nicely chewy and pick up the soup perfectly. Noodles are flatter in the shio.

excerpts: After 20min we ordered our Ramen a Tori Paitan and an Organic Short with an extra pork, OMG it was just delicious!
tori paitan.author: Lino M.
tori paitan.review:
Just AMAZING!! I've heard a lot about this place so it was time to give it a shot! A really good Ramen. I went there with my friends. A pretty long line,  maybe 20 min at 10:30PM, my friend told me that's usually longer!! 

From outside we could see that the place was very crowded, but pretty small too. Cool. After 20min we ordered our Ramen a Tori Paitan and an Organic Short with an extra pork, OMG it was just delicious! Our waiting just paid off, the taste, the meat, well everything was great.

How about the place? Maybe too small, noisy, with only 1 restrooms. Otherwise, the service was great, the servers really polite. $14, yeah that's a good deal!

excerpts: Love the tori paitan ramen.
Broth was so creamy and yummy!
Worth
the 20-30 min wait.
Food came out really quick and service was great too!
tori paitan.author: Shay B.
tori paitan.review: Love the tori paitan ramen. Broth was so creamy and yummy! Worth the 20-30 min wait. Food came out really quick and service was great too!

excerpts: I loved their tori paitan - really rich and flavorful, perfect for all tonkatsu lovers like me.
The chashu was soooo good and practically melts in your mouth.
tori paitan.author: Vivian H.
tori paitan.review:
The hype is real. Seriously the best ramen I've had in the bay area. I loved their tori paitan - really rich and flavorful, perfect for all tonkatsu lovers like me. The chashu was soooo good and practically melts in your mouth. Order the DOUBLE portion!!

Lines were long, as expected. I definitely wouldn't wait over an hour. It was also pricy for a bowl of ramen ($16-18), but worth it. Definitely can't wait to come back!

excerpts: Tori Paitan Ramen was oh so rich rich rich rich rich RIIIICHHH and creamy.
That broth was pretty close to a chowder!
And the noodles had the nicest thick texture along with it.
MMMmm.
The duck chashu was definitely a nice, flavor changing bonus!
tori paitan.author: Kim N.
tori paitan.review:
HOLY SHIT WAS THIS PLACE DEELISH. 

Tori Paitan Ramen was oh so rich rich rich rich rich RIIIICHHH and creamy. That broth was pretty close to a chowder! And the noodles had the nicest thick texture along with it. MMMmm. The duck chashu was definitely a nice, flavor changing bonus! I enjoyed that addition into the ramen very much, and usually, I'm not a big fan of duck! 

Little sister got the Shoyu Ramen. It comes with a different textured noodle - a flatter styled noodle. And heol, definitely complimented the clean, soothing broth it was served with. 

GODDAMMNN. How did this place perfect both the fatty, rich tonkotsu broth ANNNND clean, clearer broths?! I could eat either of them all daaay loooong.

Setup was supah hip and rad. There's a bar-ish seating and like two long high, communal tables. They play clubbing-esque/edm music inside. Haha, threw me off for a second.

Overall, the hype lived up to my standards. Definitely worth that one hour wait.

excerpts:
The overview of the food:

Tori Paitan - the broth was very good the first few bites but the broth became too overwhelming and creamy for my taste (I don't favor creamy food so if you enjoy creamy food then you would probably like this).
, I prefer this one over the Tori Paitan.
The broth was a little spicy but it wasn't too creamy.
For those who think that the Tori Paitan might be too creamy should try this one!
tori paitan.author: Whan T.
tori paitan.review:
When I arrived at the restaurant (9.30 on a Friday night), the line was pretty long so I was kind of skeptical if it was worth the wait. Surprisingly, the wait was only 30 minutes and I only had to wait 10 minutes for the food. The overview of the food:

Tori Paitan - the broth was very good the first few bites but the broth became too overwhelming and creamy for my taste (I don't favor creamy food so if you enjoy creamy food then you would probably like this). The chashu pork was delicious, though!

Vegan Tantanmen - despite the consensus, I prefer this one over the Tori Paitan. The broth was a little spicy but it wasn't too creamy. For those who think that the Tori Paitan might be too creamy should try this one! It kind of reminds me of a Thai dish called Kao Soi (which is also delicious). 

Oysters - this is not your typical oyster in a shell which I expected but turns out to be oyster dipped in shoyu. The taste wasn't bad but I was hoping for something else.

The overall experience was good. I would definitely come again if I didn't have to wait in line.

excerpts: The ramen itself is the perfect amount of springiness, but the kale is for decoration, and the tori paitan (duck breast and pork) could be anything because of the overwhelming flavor of the bamboo.
While the quality of the meat was solid, and the texture was tender, $18 for a bowl of this was not worth the wait.
Nice touch with the burdock, but I can't slurp another bowl of bamboo-flavored noodles.
tori paitan.author: Danny C.
tori paitan.review: I'm sorry. Everyone throwing down 5 stars have not had the pleasure of experiencing Totto, Ippudo, or even Marufuku. This is okay ramen, at best. For the price point and portions, it's just mediocre. If you take away the handmade noodles, it's a two-star joint at best, and those two stars would be for their stellar service and system. Otherwise, the hour-long wait for this ramen is not deserved. Maybe it was too hyped up to begin with, the overpowering bamboo quantity and flavor just overwhelmed any sense of the ramen itself. The broth was a hearty chicken stock, but you could only taste the bamboo after the initial. The ramen itself is the perfect amount of springiness, but the kale is for decoration, and the tori paitan (duck breast and pork) could be anything because of the overwhelming flavor of the bamboo. While the quality of the meat was solid, and the texture was tender, $18 for a bowl of this was not worth the wait. Nice touch with the burdock, but I can't slurp another bowl of bamboo-flavored noodles.

excerpts:
We got two items here: 

Tori paitan: 5/5.
Highly enjoyable also, but just not as good as the tori paitan, and I thought it was a little too salty
tori paitan.author: Anna C.
tori paitan.review:
One of the best ramen places in the city! After having recently moved from the east coast to SF, it was hard to find an abundance of good ramen here, but I'm so glad I found this place. We came here late on a Sunday night, around 9pm, but had to wait at least an hour to get seats, so be prepared to spend some time here. They usually close when the broth runs out. 

We got two items here: 

Tori paitan: 5/5. Dangerously rich and delicious, with every bit of that melt-in-your-mouth flavor 
Organic shoyu: 4/5. Highly enjoyable also, but just not as good as the tori paitan, and I thought it was a little too salty 

Can't wait to come again. This is definitely a place I'd revisit and even bring people to.

excerpts: Amazingly frothy and creamy tori paitan (chicken bone broth).
Duck chasu that tastes like it was marinated in something sweet and citrusy.
Crispy burdock root.
tori paitan.author: Audrey L.
tori paitan.review:
Amazingly frothy and creamy tori paitan (chicken bone broth). Duck chasu that tastes like it was marinated in something sweet and citrusy. Crispy burdock root. Extra large soup spoons. 

All these things make me respect Mensho as a ramen shop that has perfected their craft. 

Note that this style of ramen does not currently include soft-boiled egg...but everything else was perfection.

excerpts: I ordered the tori paitan ramen and my bestie ordered the shoyu.
It was actually quite comical as I ended up enjoying hers more
so we switched.
But the tori paitan was ridiculously rich and the "soup" was definitely more of a gravy than an actual soup.
I couldn't take a few bites without feeling completely overwhelmed by fat and salt.
The shoyu was much lighter although still just as salty.
It did however have an amazing mushroom / umami flavor that I was willing to drink a few glasses of water to enjoy.
The noodles in the shoyu were more of an egg type noodle than the ramen I am used to.
tori paitan.author: Megan W.
tori paitan.review:
The hype for this ramen shop right now is extremely real. The best friend and I decided we had to come to see if it was really THAT good. We waited an hour and a half just to be seated. And although the host was very friendly all of the waitresses made me feel as though I was doing a disservice to them by requesting water or the bill.

I ordered the tori paitan ramen and my bestie ordered the shoyu. It was actually quite comical as I ended up enjoying hers more so we switched. But the tori paitan was ridiculously rich and the "soup" was definitely more of a gravy than an actual soup. I couldn't take a few bites without feeling completely overwhelmed by fat and salt. The shoyu was much lighter although still just as salty. It did however have an amazing mushroom / umami flavor that I was willing to drink a few glasses of water to enjoy. The noodles in the shoyu were more of an egg type noodle than the ramen I am used to. The tori however had more traditional noodles.

Although I did not care for the broths I do feel that the meats included in the two ramens were perfectly, delicately cooked and very delicious. I've never had duck chashu and I was pleasantly surprised to say the least. The regular pork chashu was also thinly sliced and amazingly tender. They both just melt in your mouth.

The bits of kale and seaweed unfortunately did not help enough to combat the overwhelming fat that lingers on your palate which is ultimately what led to my 3 stars.  I honestly feel like this ramen was not to type to be enjoyed on a continuous basis. The flavors were great for that of a tasting menu, but for a full bowl of ramen it was much too salty and heavy to enjoy for more than a few bites. Overall I could not get over the overwhelming soup bases which clouded my ability to really enjoy this ramen.

excerpts: We had so much time in line looking at the menu, I already knew what I wanted - Tori Paitan with double meat!
I was so excited when I got my bowl of ramen!
I always think that if others are willing to wait in line that long as well, it must be pretty damn good.
I dug in and the noodles were good.
I like to let them soak in the broth so that they get a little softer.
The broth is made with chicken and it was thick and creamy - perfect for a cold day.
All the toppings were good as well.
The pork chashu was tender and delicious and the duck chashu was melting in my mouth.
So good!
Overall, was it worth the 2 hour wait and $18 bowl of ramen?
I think you should definitely try it at least once, but it's pretty pricey (even though the quality is really good)
and I'd only go back if the line was shorter.
tori paitan.author: Sophia Y.
tori paitan.review:
2 hours of waiting and one trip all the way to Chinatown for boba and back later, our party of 3 finally got seated at the communal table they had. If you don't mind eating alone, come alone and you definitely won't have to wait as long. We had so much time in line looking at the menu, I already knew what I wanted - Tori Paitan with double meat! I was so excited when I got my bowl of ramen! I always think that if others are willing to wait in line that long as well, it must be pretty damn good. I dug in and the noodles were good. I like to let them soak in the broth so that they get a little softer. The broth is made with chicken and it was thick and creamy - perfect for a cold day. All the toppings were good as well. The pork chashu was tender and delicious and the duck chashu was melting in my mouth. So good!
 
Overall, was it worth the 2 hour wait and $18 bowl of ramen? I think you should definitely try it at least once, but it's pretty pricey (even though the quality is really good) and I'd only go back if the line was shorter.

excerpts: Food: I got the Tori Paitan, which was ultra rich.
I believe the broth is chicken based.
Pork chashu melts in your mouth like butter.
The sliced duck is also a savory spin on things.
Also, I because Mensho is an international entity, they try to 'theme' ingredients based on the city.
Guess what SF's is?
tori paitan.author: Justin S.
tori paitan.review:
Going to assert that this is best ramen place in the city. 

Wait time on a Friday night at 8:30PM-- 1 hr 15 minutes to seating. 

Food: I got the Tori Paitan, which was ultra rich. I believe the broth is chicken based. Pork chashu melts in your mouth like butter. The sliced duck is also a savory spin on things. Also, I because Mensho is an international entity, they try to 'theme' ingredients based on the city. Guess what SF's is? You may have/will notice the kale in the soup. 

My buddy got the organic shoyu ramen, and let me tell you, it was as if I instantly transported to a dark alleyway ramen shop in Osaka, only frequented by the locals and salarymen. The subtle katsuobushi flavoring reminded me of the fresh bonito flakes sourced from the local booths of the Nishiki farmer's market straight from Kyoto.  

I heard they also import local Japanese craft beer but I didn't have a chance to try that. 

Service: Great service, can't complain. 

Final prognosis? This place is bomb. If you eat here PLEASE do your fellow patrons a service and clear out shortly after finishing your meal :)

excerpts:
Food:

TORI PAITAN.
tori paitan.author: Stephanie C.
tori paitan.review:
Note: 4 stars rather than 3 (3.5) because for what it is, it deserves 4. For my personal taste, it's a 3.5.

Food:

TORI PAITAN. Pricey $16. This seems to be one of their #1 dishes. I've never had it thus did not expect it to be so thick. 
- Soup. To me it was as thick as tsukemen (dipping noodles) which I believe is not meant to be consumed like soup. After 1/3 of the bowl, I had to call it quits... too heavy. For those who love that heavy creamy texture, I could see it being 4+ stars.
- Noodles. These were fantastic. Slightly al-dente and chewy. The way I think it should be.
- Additives. The meat served in the bowl included duck and pork, both delicious and good proportioning of fat. Plus some veggies but no egg :(

SHOYU. Less pricey but not by that much $14. This I would come back for. I however can only speak for the soup; I only tasted my friend's order. The broth was delicious and as my friend put it "has complex layers of flavors". My only issue is that the soup had a thick layer of grease sitting on top of the soup; I'm sure this can be easily remedied by the kitchen prior to serving. Otherwise, fantastic! Same or very similar meats and toppings as above.

TSUKEMEN. These dipping noodles were on the menu but have not come to their kitchen yet. Apparently the founder/head chef is still in Japan and will return in a couple weeks to teach the chefs how to make. I will have to come back to try.

Other:
- Friendly staff. Host is very helpful explaining each dish if asked or with identifying ingredients for those with allergies.
- Waited close to 2hrs (lined up at 4:50pm on a Friday). Note that restaurant only opened a couple months ago so people are still hyped about it. If you're eating on your own, you'll be seated sooner. The host walked by 3x asking if there were any parties of one.
- Food comes out within a reasonable time after ordering.

excerpts: The tori paitan is amazing- super creamy and thick, flavorful broth.
The noodles are thick and al dente, just the way I love it.
tori paitan.author: Jocelyn L.
tori paitan.review:
We got super lucky last Thursday- we waited 20 mins for a table for 2; we arrived at 5.25p.

The tori paitan is amazing- super creamy and thick, flavorful broth. The noodles are thick and al dente, just the way I love it. The duck charsiu is to die for/ tender and full of flavor.

I didn't want my bowl of ramen to end. 
Would come back here again if the line was just 20 mins

excerpts: My Tori Paitan had a really thick fatty broth (not sure if I would get this again due to fatty broth) with thick noodles that look like hand made noodles.
Very good.
tori paitan.author: Sarah C.
tori paitan.review:
Thanks for my bestie for taking me here. It has been a while since I've hung out in SF and I felt a bit out of the foodie scene. This place is relatively new and can only fit 25 people commune style with three large tables. The design is quite nice with high stools and a little basket at our feet to hold your purse/jackets. The ladies that work here is really efficient although it appears they do not have enough menus for all 25 people at one time. 

The ramen noodles were definitely different from what I am used to. My Tori Paitan had a really thick fatty broth (not sure if I would get this again due to fatty broth) with thick noodles that look like hand made noodles. Very good. This fed me but if you can eat then this would not be enough. 

My friend ordered the organic ramen with extra chasu. Hers looked like Chinese thick egg noodle soup. She enjoyed it. 

I definitely would like to come back and try their other ramen.

excerpts: As for the food, my friends and I all ordered the Tori Paitan which was a rich creamy chicken broth with pork chasiu and duck.
The broth is very heavy and flavorful.
I like the flavor
but I felt that it was a too salty for my preferences.
The noodles were a perfect texture and the meat was delicious.
The Tori Paitan is a little more expensive for ramen at $16.
I'm interested in trying the other ramen dishes and perhaps going for a less creamy broth.
However, I don't feel that it's worth it to wait nearly 90 minutes for it.
tori paitan.author: Jonathan C.
tori paitan.review:
You know you and your friends are addicted to ramen when they send you messages about a new place opening up!

Just to note, I would say it's more like a 3.5 star for me. 

A lot of people must have known about the opening since the lines were super long. I went on the Wednesday after the weekend opening. I know you expect lines for food in San Francisco but this is first time I've waited this long for a ramen place in the city. Expect to wait 1.5 hours for the dinner rush. I do hear that the lines die down around 10pm (it closes at 12).

As for the food, my friends and I all ordered the Tori Paitan which was a rich creamy chicken broth with pork chasiu and duck. The broth is very heavy and flavorful. I like the flavor but I felt that it was a too salty for my preferences. The noodles were a perfect texture and the meat was delicious. The burdock added a contrast in texture as well as the kale, but I could do without these two. 

The Tori Paitan is a little more expensive for ramen at $16. I'm interested in trying the other ramen dishes and perhaps going for a less creamy broth. However, I don't feel that it's worth it to wait nearly 90 minutes for it.

excerpts: We shared an oyster appetizer, SO ordered the Shoyu Ramen, I ordered the Tori Paitan.
The Tori Paitan ramen on the other hand, was delicious.
The chashu and duck melted in your mouth, the noodles were perfect, and the broth was so very rich and creamy.
Sadly, the Shoyu Ramen was too salty.
tori paitan.author: Jenny Y.
tori paitan.review:
Things you can do while you wait for a seat at Mensho Tokyo:
- Tailgate: The people behind us may or may not have been brown bagging. We were told that there have been people who will break out six packs cause they DGAF.
- Get yur hur did: leave a designated wait person and get a haircut from across the street. Trust me, you have enough time.
- Meditate: You probably won't do this, but I'm not going to lie, my hangryness was taking over my body real quick. If every crevice of SF wasn't covered in piss, I'd be sitting in a corner collecting myself.

So we arrived at about 5:15 on a Sunday and had to wait for a good 2 hours before we were able to enter the door. Abram was really nice and thanked us for waiting. We shared an oyster appetizer, SO ordered the Shoyu Ramen, I ordered the Tori Paitan.

The oysters were nice but forgettable. I wouldn't order them again. The Tori Paitan ramen on the other hand, was delicious. The chashu and duck melted in your mouth, the noodles were perfect, and the broth was so very rich and creamy. Sadly, the Shoyu Ramen was too salty. Each bite was followed by a gulp of water.

I can't wait for the rest of the menu to come, we'll definitely be back. I want to try the Vegan Tantanmen. OH, just a suggestion, if you want to get in quick, come alone, there were some lucky ducks who got to skip the line for that.

excerpts: We both ordered the single Tori Paitan $18, which is the most popular here.
Took a taste of that broth and DIED!
I never really understood the concept of umami until that hit my taste buds.
It is an indescribable taste that comes in a thicker than normal broth and the most perfectly cooked noodles.
The broth tastes almost oily/fatty and buttery at the same time, but the taste you get is just insane.
I didn't care much for the chashu, but they were excellently cooked.
Currently saving up my quarters for my next visit because that broth is something I need again.
tori paitan.author: Brie R.
tori paitan.review:
I don't know why it has taken me so long to write this review, but I can assure you the experience and taste of the ramen left a lasting impression on my palate (1 month and counting).
A friend and I read about this spot and HAD to give it a go. We arrived at 9:30 and had ordered around 10:20. Definitely not bad considering other reviews of up to 2 hour wait times. We both ordered the single Tori Paitan $18, which is the most popular here. Took a taste of that broth and DIED! I never really understood the concept of umami until that hit my taste buds. It is an indescribable taste that comes in a thicker than normal broth and the most perfectly cooked noodles. The broth tastes almost oily/fatty and buttery at the same time, but the taste you get is just insane. I didn't care much for the chashu, but they were excellently cooked. 
Currently saving up my quarters for my next visit because that broth is something I need again. It's addicting I promise you. 

***Communal Tables Only***
- This isn't the type of place where you can sit and gossip about your friend and her new boyfriend after you finish your ramen. People are hungry and waiting to taste this ramen so please, GET IN AND GET OUT.

excerpts: I opted for the tori paitan ramen with two slices of chashu.
The handmade noodles were stellar with the appropriate texture and chewiness.
The noodles perfectly absorbed the rich and balanced broth.
I would have been able to finish it had I not camped out for happy hour at the friendly Resolute next door.
My objectivity for this review is compromised because I had a relaxing time lined up an hour and a half before opening.
the Suntory malt and the Sansho may not have been the best standalone beers but they paired so well with the tori paitan.
It was nice to see a change in roster for the typical ramen house beverages.
- They use Square payment and were able to quickly rectify an erroneous bill.
- The music selection was hilariously comforting.
It was what seemed to be a wedding covers playlist during the first hour - including hits like a diluted acoustic version of Peter Cetera's "Glory of Love"
- There's a clipboard.
tori paitan.author: Joseph V.
tori paitan.review:
I was fortunate enough to be seated at the inaugural table (of 6) during the grand opening. The other patrons were a blast to be around - we agreed that it was strange to have only 6 seated until the food arrived but it was thrilling to be part of the exhibit. This is the nature of grand openings so I imagine Mensho will have it sussed out very soon. 

I opted for the tori paitan ramen with two slices of chashu. The handmade noodles were stellar with the appropriate texture and chewiness. The noodles perfectly absorbed the rich and balanced broth. I would have been able to finish it had I not camped out for happy hour at the friendly Resolute next door. My objectivity for this review is compromised because I had a relaxing time lined up an hour and a half before opening. In my mind, it was guaranteed to be a great experience.

Abram was a delightful host. His enthusiasm and engagement with the crowd were appropriately uplifting for the public opening. Chef Shono's spirits were high and he personally delivered my bowl with a smile and a handshake. I'll never forget the connection when he reciprocated my emphatic thumbs up through the kitchen window. 

Miscellany:
- The beer selection is stellar. the Suntory malt and the Sansho may not have been the best standalone beers but they paired so well with the tori paitan. It was nice to see a change in roster for the typical ramen house beverages.
- They use Square payment and were able to quickly rectify an erroneous bill.
- The music selection was hilariously comforting. It was what seemed to be a wedding covers playlist during the first hour - including hits like a diluted acoustic version of Peter Cetera's "Glory of Love"
- There's a clipboard. The sequence of names was honored for at least the first 6 people (mild gloating). 

The per bowl pricing is higher than average but it was worth it to be part of the spectacle. Cheers to Mensho! I'll be back.

excerpts: Ordered the tori paitan.
First bite was heaven.
Best ramen in SF imo.
But because of the creamy broth, it does get pretty heavy by the end.
tori paitan.author: Dana C.
tori paitan.review:
Have to be mentally prepared to wait. Lined up at 5:30 on a Tues for 5 ppl and got seated 2 hrs later.

Ordered the tori paitan. First bite was heaven. Best ramen in SF imo. But because of the creamy broth, it does get pretty heavy by the end. The shoyu/shio ones are probably lighter. Noodle's thick and cooked really well.

excerpts: I decided to go for the Tori Paitan, which sounded delicious and was recommended to me.
tori paitan.author: Jei C.
tori paitan.review:
There comes a time in a cats life where as much as he wants to avoid the "in" restaurants of the world, he cant help but give in to try something new with some friends. That is what happened to me, in my journey over to Mensho Tokyo.

Mensho Tokyo is a little place on geary that I learned has a very high reputation. Due to this, diners line up long before the place opens to try to get a seat. With the restaurant opening at 5, I was surprised to see customers already forming a line at 4:15! 

Luckily, my group was able to be seated in the first round of diners, and we were greeted warmly and happily. 

Menu here is smaller, but each dish had a high reputation. I decided to go for the Tori Paitan, which sounded delicious and was recommended to me.

We were first served an oyster appetizer which was very flavorful and delicious! Being a cat, I have had lots of oyster before, but this was super special to me.

My ramen arrived and I took the first bites with the broth. This broth is phenomenal. There is so much flavor in it, and it feels so smooth and creamy. The meat cuts were superb and tender, and the noodles were cooked perfectly. I instantly could see why people line up for so long to get a taste of the ramen here, I can honestly say that this ramen is the best I have ever had. 

Service is fast and pleasant, and the intimate and close setting meant that you could get to know those dining with you as well!

Ill definitely try to make it back here one day. Its definitely on the pricier side, but I firmly believe and can say that paw's down, it was worth every penny.

Line up early, and give this place a try!

*chirp!*

excerpts: Tori paitan, rich, creamy, broth paired with perfectly cooked ramen and tender, melt in your mouth chasiu.
Sounds perfect right?
Unfortunately for me, it didn't pan out that way.
You know when you get to the bottom of a carton of OJ that's settled
and you get all the pulp (no offense to pulp)?
My broth tasted like it's equivalent.
It came out extremely frothy and with crystalized salty bits, which made me think it was the very end of a pot.
Not entirely sure if this was true, but that's my assumption, esp after tasting another party member's order.
Like I said, I want to give it 5 stars, but I can't based off of my experience.
4 stars is still plenty good in my book for ramen though.
tori paitan.author: Ryan C.
tori paitan.review:
Can't express how conflicted I am writing this review. I want to give it 5 stars, I know it deserves 5 stars, but I can't give it based on my experience. Here's my reason why: 

Be expected to wait a while. The hope of getting inside rests on how close you can see the front of the line, and your fellow food-lovers inside taking their quick, or sweet time devouring their delectable ramen. Parking for me came at an ease, but be sure you take all your valuables and leave nothing exposed. Wait time? 2 hours for me. Granted it was a Saturday night at 6:30 so it was to be expected. Now for the star of the night, which didn't shine as bright as I expected. Tori paitan, rich, creamy, broth paired with perfectly cooked ramen and tender, melt in your mouth chasiu. Sounds perfect right? Unfortunately for me, it didn't pan out that way. You know when you get to the bottom of a carton of OJ that's settled and you get all the pulp (no offense to pulp)? My broth tasted like it's equivalent. It came out extremely frothy and with crystalized salty bits, which made me think it was the very end of a pot. Not entirely sure if this was true, but that's my assumption, esp after tasting another party member's order. Like I said, I want to give it 5 stars, but I can't based off of my experience. 4 stars is still plenty good in my book for ramen though.

excerpts: Four of us got the tori paitan (chicken white soup - creamy and rich), and the other friend got shoyu ramen.
The broth was very dense, the guys loved it
but it was too heavy for me and even slightly upset my stomach for the rest of the night.
Veggie toppings (bamboo shoots and greens) were tiny portions, I wish there could be more to balance the heavy broth.
tori paitan.author: Jaclyn C.
tori paitan.review:
Five of us started lining up 5:40pm on a Friday and got seated exactly two hours later. The ramen shop is tiny, like 20 seats, so we waited a bit longer than smaller parties.

I didn't really mind the wait, it's just not for me. Four of us got the tori paitan (chicken white soup - creamy and rich), and the other friend got shoyu ramen. The broth was very dense, the guys loved it but it was too heavy for me and even slightly upset my stomach for the rest of the night. Veggie toppings (bamboo shoots and greens) were tiny portions, I wish there could be more to balance the heavy broth. Duck chashu was unconventional, but I personally preferred traditional pork chashu.

Overall, the ramen was unique but I wouldn't wait for more than half an hour again. I'd also try other lighter ramen/soba options. Worth trying it, just grab some friends to chat over the wait or go alone for high chance of skipping the line.

excerpts:
In terms of the food:

Tori Paitan (Double Chashu--$18):
---The broth was the richest ramen broth I have ever had.
tori paitan.author: Lawrence E.
tori paitan.review:
Long wait: 1 hour and 20 minutes on a Saturday night.  This restaurant is tiny and does not seat very many people.  We probably would've shaved off 20 minutes of waiting had our party not been a group of 5 and was a group of 2 instead.  Not a good place for large parties.

In terms of the food:

Tori Paitan (Double Chashu--$18):
---The broth was the richest ramen broth I have ever had.  It was very unique in that it tasted like chicken pâté broth.  I literally had chicken pâté the week before at another popular restaurant in SF and the flavor profile was very similar.  It tasted good, but I don't think I could eat it on a regular basis.  There were two types of chashu in the dish, pork and duck.  I have never had duck chashu before, but it was very tender and succulent and did not taste fatty or oily compared to Chinese roast duck.  The accoutrements with the food were pretty decent with the bamboo shoots, bonito flakes, etc.  The burdock root was a nice surprise with the katsuobushi sauce as it made it taste like there was bacon in the dish almost (or like bacon + brussel sprouts taste).  In terms of the noodles themselves, they were not as firm/springy as I would have liked, and it seemed as though I got all really short/cut up noodles and not the long strands of noodles where you can "slurp" the noodles as a sign of respect that you like the dish.  This could have just been my particular bowl as I noticed others in my party had longer noodles.

Overall, worth a try, I probably wouldn't wait another hour for the bowl if I was really craving ramen as there are other places to get my ramen fix, but a solid choice/restaurant to visit.

excerpts: The broth of the tori paitan was creamy AF.
Definitely not my cup of tea.
It was less of a broth and more of a creamy, grainy gravy sauce.
It reminded me of eating the foam that forms at the top of your shabu pot after you've cooked so much meat in it.
However, I will say that both the noodles and the chasu were good.
But when it comes ramen, the broth is everything for me.
Not worth the wait in line or the hype.
Hard pass.

tori paitan.review: HOOOOLLLYYYYYY mother of God. Help me, Jesus. The broth of the tori paitan was creamy AF. Definitely not my cup of tea. It was less of a broth and more of a creamy, grainy gravy sauce. It reminded me of eating the foam that forms at the top of your shabu pot after you've cooked so much meat in it. However, I will say that both the noodles and the chasu were good. But when it comes ramen, the broth is everything for me. Not worth the wait in line or the hype. Hard pass.

excerpts:
What we ordered:

Tori Paitan double chashu ramen, $16 + $2 for the chashu [http://bit.ly/1VsPPBt]
tori paitan.author: Jasmin H.
tori paitan.review:
Finally had a chance to check out what the hype was about and the verdict was - yes, totally worth the wait!

Wait time: 2 hrs on a Friday night (arrived at 6:05pm, got in at 8)

Space: Roughly 24 seats. Easier to get seated right away if you go by yourself or as a couple than parties of 3+. They let my friend and I come in before two large groups ahead of us.

What we ordered:

Tori Paitan double chashu ramen, $16 + $2 for the chashu [http://bit.ly/1VsPPBt]
Rich, creamy chicken soup, pork chashu, duck chashu, menma (condiment made from dried bamboo shoots), kale, etc.
---The server gave me the option of single or double chashu, but **ORDER DOUBLE CHASHU!!!!**  ...trust me one won't be enough!! All my friends who made the mistake of ordering just one walked out the door day dreaming about that other chashu... Also, about the broth, as many Yelpers say here, it is definitely on the thicker side but has a flavorful and creamy twist. Noodles were chewy and perfectly cooked.

Vegan Tantanmen, $18 [http://bit.ly/22xt7tY]
Vegetable soup with konbu and mushrooms, Japanese soy cream, sesame, cilantro, chili oil, green onion, menma, etc.
---My friend ordered this one but I was able to try some of the broth and noodles. The broth was very creamy as well - think tonkotsu without meat. It's sprinkled with seven kinds of nuts and a bit spicy because of the chili oil. 

Bill ended up to be $39.15 sans tip.

No doubt, if you're craving authentic ramen from Japan, you cannot go wrong with this one!

excerpts: Their signature ramen, the tori paitan is excellent.
; Very rich and flavorful broth with thicker textured noodles.
The chasu melts in your mouth, but was quite a small piece.
tori paitan.author: Ali F.
tori paitan.review:
Small restaurant on the border of downtown SF and tenderloin. I wouldn't recommend coming here with anymore more than 4 people; 2 is best. Their signature ramen, the tori paitan is excellent.; Very rich and flavorful broth with thicker textured noodles. The chasu melts in your mouth, but was quite a small piece. The Shio ramen was ok. The broth was good, but this noodle was flat and smooth, similar to egg noodles. 

The wait was one hour long on a Sat night. I'd say worth it to try once.

excerpts: I ordered the Tori Paitan, which had a thick and rich but still tasted one dimensional as though it lacked umami or salt.
tori paitan.author: Craig V.
tori paitan.review:
The place is definitely over hyped, and the Ramen is just slightly above average.

We got there at 9:15 and only waited for 25 minutes.  I ordered the Tori Paitan, which had a thick and rich but still tasted one dimensional as though it lacked umami or salt.  

The service was good in that they were very attentive and took care of the line well.

Conclusion: I wouldn't come back.  The price, overhype, and lack of flavor wasn't worth the experience

tori paitan.author: Nick C.

excerpts: We ordered Tori Paitan and Vegan Ramen.
tori paitan.author: Jonathan X.
tori paitan.review:
My wife and I came here for the first time due to the great review and hype. We came on a Friday afternoon around 4:45pm. They open at 5pm. There was a line outside already. We were able to get in the first group of people getting a seat. It's a tiny restaurant with about 30 seats. Seating was a bit crowded and you would be sitting right next to a stranger. Here's how we rated our experience. We ordered Tori Paitan and Vegan Ramen.

(5 = best.    1 = worst). 

Restaurant setting: 4. 
Service: 4. 
Time duration from order to getting the food: 3. 
Tastiness of Ramen: 2. 
Portion of Ramen: 3. 
Price: 2 ($$$). 
Overall experience: 3. 

After we ate, we felt thirsty. So I guess the broth might have MSG in it. Of course, everyone's taste buds are different. Give it a try and you will know whether or not you like it yourself.

excerpts: So I opted for their Tori Paitan double order of chashu.
tori paitan.author: Vince L.
tori paitan.review:
I've been hearing all this hype about Mensho from a few friends so decided to check it out. Come early because the wait is pretty long. Waited a little over an hour for a party of 5. 

What we ordered:

Appetizer: Oysters in shoyu dare oil

This reminded me of the Chinese canned dace you would have for breakfast with congee. Texture and saltiness were about the same. Would've never guessed it was oysters. 

The Ramen:

When I arrived at Mensho, I saw signs everywhere that said Tsukemen. I was extremely happy and anxious because not a lot of places serves it. I've been on a search of Tsukemen for quite awhile after my trip to Tokyo in 2011. We I saw their menu, no Tsukemen . It's plastered everywhere on their wall but no go. So I opted for their Tori Paitan double order of chashu. 

Interesting take on ramen. Their broth is extremely thick and one note. Noodles were cooked perfectly and had the right amount of chewiness and texture. Duck chashu was pretty good but their pork chashu was the highlight of the dish. 

Overall, nothing impressive about their ramen. I'm just glad it wasn't bland. Their shoyu ramen may be the better option.

excerpts:
4.5 stars

Tori Paitan Ramen $18 - perfect broth, duck was good.
tori paitan.author: T H.
tori paitan.review:
4.5 stars

Tori Paitan Ramen $18 - perfect broth, duck was good. My noodles were a lil too al dente. 

Organic Ramen $16 - a bit on the salty side, noodles were a tiny bit flatter but more cooked than the Tori.

Portion size is good. Overall it was good, authentic. Service is excellent.

excerpts: We went for the Tori Paitan ramen w/ double cha siu.
The fat of the duck meat just melts in your mouth!

YUM YUM YUM.

tori paitan.author: Alice Z.
tori paitan.review:
I finally get to try this place after hearing all the good reviews about this place! I came with the BFF on a Friday around 5:40ish and the line was getting longer by the minute. They do NOT do to-gos nor do they have to-go boxes! 

We were seated around 6:15ish at one of their community tables. If you are looking for a romantic date night followed by 1hr+ conversations--this is NOT the place for that. People come and go rather quickly and you are most likely going to be seated ACROSS from the other person in a big tall table along with 8 other people. I already knew what I wanted once we sat down. We went for the Tori Paitan ramen w/ double cha siu. The fat of the duck meat just melts in your mouth! And the big metal spoon is given so you can drink all the broth! YUM YUM YUM. Best ramen in my book so far! I want to come back and try their tonkatsu next time!

tori paitan.review: Really felt this place was a letdown. We were lucky and only waited about 10 minutes. If I'd waited over an hour I would have been even more let down.  The tori paitan was way too rich. And I don't know if I've ever said that before about a food. excerpts: We all ordered the Tori Paitan.
I loved the chasu so much
, I wished I got double meat for an extra $2.
The meat was perfectly marinated, and it was "fall-apart" tender.
The noodles aren't your typical ramen noodles.
It's wide and flat with the perfect bounciness.
The noodles interact harmoniously with the creamy, grainy broth while capturing the flavors of the broth.
I can see why some may think the broth is too heavy!
If you want to change up/balance out the flavors, ask for a side of the chili paste with chili oil.
tori paitan.author: Fanny H.
tori paitan.review:
Worth the hype? I think so. A little pricey for ramen ($16), but delicious nonetheless!

I came on a Saturday night at around 10:30 pm and waited roughly 30 minutes (for a group of 4). Two parties behind us in line were able to skip ahead of us because they had smaller parties of 1 or 2! So yes, DO go in small groups! 
 
We all ordered the Tori Paitan. I loved the chasu so much, I wished I got double meat for an extra $2. The meat was perfectly marinated, and it was "fall-apart" tender. The noodles aren't your typical ramen noodles. It's wide and flat with the perfect bounciness. The noodles interact harmoniously with the creamy, grainy broth while capturing the flavors of the broth.  I can see why some may think the broth is too heavy! If you want to change up/balance out the flavors, ask for a side of the chili paste with chili oil. It adds a kick to the ramen and makes it less heavy and salty (in my opinion). 

I would definitely go to Mensho more often if the lines weren't always so long. No ramen is worth waiting 2+ hours for.. lol

excerpts: I got the tori paitan broth and my partner got the shio one.

They said that they do not offer egg with their ramen because it detracts from the flavor.
tori paitan.author: Diana B.
tori paitan.review: I've been wanting to eat at Mensho since they've opened but was deterred by the long lines. I thought I'd try the Mensho in Tokyo but ended up trying other ramen shops there. Finally my partner and I happened to be in the area late on a weeknight and stopped by. There were about 6 people ahead of us in line. We saw a lot of parties finish their meals and leave, but we had to wait for the servers to seat everyone in line at once. They didn't have the tsukemen noodles today. They also don't have the tonkotsu broth yet which is what the shop in Tokyo is known for. I got the tori paitan broth and my partner got the shio one. Noodles are homemade and thicker/fatter than your normal ramen noodles. They were still good and so were both of the broths. I liked the thick, creamy tori paitan broth and was tempted to take it home for later (but resisted). I was worried that the shio (salt) broth would be too salty but it wasn't, it surprisingly had a fish taste that I liked. They said that they do not offer egg with their ramen because it detracts from the flavor.

Probably not!). I had the Tori Paitan ramen, and I went in a little overboard ordering double pork (the original amount is just fine). I enjoyed it as it (especially the broth, pork was delicious) was so flavorful, and it was well worth the wait! They have their system down, nice and simple: sit, take your order, eat, go. Two people normally sit across from each other at the long communal table, and if you're by yourself, you might get seated with another person across from you to be space- and time-efficient. I did that once at another place, and we ended up having an ok conversation. So why not? I hope to go back again!

excerpts: I ordered the Tori Paitan Ramen.
tori paitan.author: Erni L.
tori paitan.review:
Food is 5 star. I ordered the Tori Paitan Ramen. It was delicious and broth is super thick and yummy. 

But, the overall experience is just... tiring and disappointing. I would never come here again. 

Ramen costs $20 a bowl. Which is super expensive. It would be okay if I don't have to stand in line outside waiting for 30-40 minutes to finally be seated. Not only that, after getting seated, the experience gets more and more terrible. The space is really really small and it was super uncomfortable.

The seats are really small and it's very hard to squish in and sit comfortably. I was trapped between the wall and a person beside me. The whole dining experience was simply terrible.

Honestly, if there's more space in the restaurant and I can sit comfortably, I would come back here again despite having to stand outside in the cold. But at its current state, there's no chance that I'd put myself through that experience again.

Try it as a once in a lifetime experience to see what the hype is about. After that, judge for yourself.
