excerpts: I ordered the Tori Paitan Double Chashu ramen with a side of fried enoki mushrooms.
Given that this is a Paitan ramen, I knew that the broth was going to be very thick and heavy bordering on a gravy-like consistency.
It's not particularly common
tori paitan.author: Ray L.
tori paitan.review:
I came here for the first time maybe about 2 weeks ago and it was still a pretty long line at around 9PM. However, they seem to always have spots for people who are eating alone so I was lucky enough to come on my own and not have any wait.

I ordered the Tori Paitan Double Chashu ramen with a side of fried enoki mushrooms. Given that this is a Paitan ramen, I knew that the broth was going to be very thick and heavy bordering on a gravy-like consistency. It's not particularly common so I understand how some people might not be particular fans of this style.  

The fried enoki were very crispy and delicious but if you let them sit for a bit, they start to really develop that oily feel in your mouth which is a no-go for me. The ramen was very good. I was a little hesitant when they told me there was kale in it (This kale phenomenon in SF is getting ridiculously out of hand) but it was surprisingly good and didn't have the strong bitter taste of kale. I also think you need to order the double chashu since the meat was extremely tender and good but a double portion felt just right and not too much.

All in all, this was a great experience and I would like to come back but at $18 for a bowl, I think that's just ridiculous. Maybe it's because SF is so expensive but even the Tokyo branch is almost half the price of SF. Given that most other ramen places in this vicinity have yet to come close to what I've had here, it's probably the only place I could recommend for good ramen if you're in the city and want some place that's not too difficult or will take too long to get to.

excerpts: My first time here I tried the tori paitan and that was way too salty.
But I was determined to give this place
another go.
The second here, I tried their mazesoba and that... will go on my list of "best things I ever ate".
tori paitan.author: Claire D.
tori paitan.review: My first time here I tried the tori paitan and that was way too salty. But I was determined to give this place another go. The second here, I tried their mazesoba and that... will go on my list of "best things I ever ate".

excerpts: Tip: the Tori Paitan is way less fishy than the shiyo organic ramen.
Paitan all the way.
tori paitan.author: Christina R.
tori paitan.review: Aaaaaah! This is the closest I've gotten to REAL Ramen outside of Japan. It's good. Worth an hour wait? Ugh... yes, it is.  Lines suck. And I hate adding to them. But this one I'll gladly do again (I'll bring snacks next time). Tip: the Tori Paitan is way less fishy than the shiyo organic ramen. Paitan all the way.

excerpts: I had the Tori Paitan, which I believe is their signature menu item.
It was quite good!
I've had ramen from a number of top ramen restaurants on the west coast, as well as quite a few authentic ramen shops in Tokyo.
There are many types of ramen, so it's important to frame my review with the kind I prefer, which is hakata ramen, which has very thick broth.
This definitely delivers.
Additionally, it's different, unique, and it's clear they try new things that really work, all while still delivering an authentic taste.
That being said, I don't think it quite lives up to the hype I've heard.
There are many comparable ramen shops.
tori paitan.author: Ryan H.
tori paitan.review:
I had the Tori Paitan, which I believe is their signature menu item.  It was quite good!  I've had ramen from a number of top ramen restaurants on the west coast, as well as quite a few authentic ramen shops in Tokyo.  There are many types of ramen, so it's important to frame my review with the kind I prefer, which is hakata ramen, which has very thick broth.  This definitely delivers.  Additionally, it's different, unique, and it's clear they try new things that really work, all while still delivering an authentic taste.  That being said, I don't think it quite lives up to the hype I've heard.  There are many comparable ramen shops.  Come here if you want something that's very good as well as unique, but don't expect it to outclass other top-tier places, either.

One real complaint: I found that the dregs of the broth are a bit gritty, like there is a fine silt which sinks to the bottom.  This makes drinking the remainder impossible to enjoy, something I've never encountered at a ramen shop before.  Ramen aficionados always slurp the broth remaining, right?  You won't want to do that here.

excerpts: I first tried the Tori Paitan and I was in creamy heaven!
I've been to Japan and while of course the ramen is good everywhere there, nothing I tried was mind blowing and this Tori Paitan was mind blowing!
I also tried the clam ramen which was very good if you love seafood.
It's very rich is clam buttery flavor.
And lastly I had the Vegan ramen which was good, but my favorite by far was Tori Paitan with a side of Lamb :)
tori paitan.author: Stacey P.
tori paitan.review: Go when it rains! I only had to wait 30 minutes for the 3 times I visited. I first tried the Tori Paitan and I was in creamy heaven! I've been to Japan and while of course the ramen is good everywhere there, nothing I tried was mind blowing and this Tori Paitan was mind blowing! I also tried the clam ramen which was very good if you love seafood. It's very rich is clam buttery flavor. And lastly I had the Vegan ramen which was good, but my favorite by far was Tori Paitan with a side of Lamb :)

excerpts: The Tori Paitan was thick and creamy.
It was a refreshing taste for the first few bites but it got slightly too overwhelming towards the end.
tori paitan.author: Rachel T.
tori paitan.review:
Being Singaporeans and having tried a lot of ramen before, we think that this ramen is unique. The Tori Paitan was thick and creamy. It was a refreshing taste for the first few bites but it got slightly too overwhelming towards the end. The organic shoyu ramen had a fragrant and tasty broth. We bought fried enoki mushrooms that were fried to perfection. 

The most exciting thing of the meal was the Japanese ramune soda. It was sealed with a marble ball and we had to pop the marble out to open the drink. 

Overall, it was a pretty interesting experience but we doubt we could be back again.

excerpts: Had some tori paitan with double chashu.
Got there around 15 mins before closing, had about 4 groups in front of us and the wait was about 20-30 mins, so no complaints.
tori paitan.author: Ross B.
tori paitan.review: Hands down best ramen I've ever had. Had some tori paitan with double chashu. Got there around 15 mins before closing, had about 4 groups in front of us and the wait was about 20-30 mins, so no complaints.

excerpts: I had the shio double chashu ramen and my friend tried the tori paitan ramen.
My shio ramen was very flavorful.
The broth was amazing, but it got pretty salty near the end of my meal.
The pork was so soft and delicious.
There was a perfect amount of noodles to satisfy me.
My friend also really enjoyed his duck ramen.
The pieces of duck are rather small
so he suggested getting double meat.
tori paitan.author: Cindy C.
tori paitan.review:
+ THE FOOD
Definitely one of the best ramen's I've ever had. I had the shio double chashu ramen and my friend tried the tori paitan ramen. My shio ramen was very flavorful. The broth was amazing, but it got pretty salty near the end of my meal. The pork was so soft and delicious. There was a perfect amount of noodles to satisfy me. My friend also really enjoyed his duck ramen. The pieces of duck are rather small so he suggested getting double meat. The duck ramen's broth is more frothy but it still tastes amazing. 

+ THE SERVICE
Service is friendly and fast! Although you wait at least an hour in line, they serve you really quickly once you order. Everything seems very efficient there, from the way you are seated to how you are served!

excerpts: Our server was very friendly and helpful when it came to ordering; she actually recommended the Vegan Tantanmen, but said that the Tori Paitan was the most popular item.
We ordered one of each, although surprisingly I ended up preferring the vegan ramen.
It truly was some of the best ramen I've EVER had (and I've had quite a lot in my lifetime).
Everything was perfect, from the al dente noodles, to the level of spice in the broth.
There's no way you could tell it's vegan, and the broth had a great earthy, nutty flavor.
Even the chopsticks and spoon were fantastic (you'll see what I mean what you go there).
The chicken ramen was unlike anything I had tried before - super creamy but also light at the same time.
It was such a delicious culinary experience, and while I would not wait over an hour for it, I am SO happy I had the chance to try it.
The ramen is so good that perhaps I might even start walking by after work just to see if there happens to be a short line...
tori paitan.author: Regina L.
tori paitan.review:
My friend and I decided to take advantage of the Warriors game being on and hit up Mensho Tokyo. We figured that with the game being on, the line would at least be slightly shorter than their infamous 1.5+ hour-long lines. Thankfully it was a lovely evening out and we only waited about 35 minutes before we were sat. They run a VERY tight ship; seats are turned incredibly quickly and efficiently. We were sat at the bar, which allowed us to look into the kitchen. The kitchen, along with the dining space, looked incredibly clean and everyone was operating very efficiently. The dining area, although packed quite tight, doesn't feel too crowded, and I thought I had a lot of personal space at the bar. 

Our server was very friendly and helpful when it came to ordering; she actually recommended the Vegan Tantanmen, but said that the Tori Paitan was the most popular item. We ordered one of each, although surprisingly I ended up preferring the vegan ramen. It truly was some of the best ramen I've EVER had (and I've had quite a lot in my lifetime). Everything was perfect, from the al dente noodles, to the level of spice in the broth. There's no way you could tell it's vegan, and the broth had a great earthy, nutty flavor. Even the chopsticks and spoon were fantastic (you'll see what I mean what you go there). The chicken ramen was unlike anything I had tried before - super creamy but also light at the same time. It was such a delicious culinary experience, and while I would not wait over an hour for it, I am SO happy I had the chance to try it. The ramen is so good that perhaps I might even start walking by after work just to see if there happens to be a short line...

excerpts: I tried the Tori Paitan and it was delicious.
The broth was super creamy and the texture of the noodle was amazing.
It came with two types of chashu, pork and duck.
I could eat the duck chashu all day every day.
A bowl of ramen here is quite pricey but it really fills you up and you leave full and satisfied.
If you're looking for traditional ramen though, this might not be your style.
Overall, a very unique and enjoyable experience.
tori paitan.author: Catherine T.
tori paitan.review: This ramen shop serves novelty ramen. Their flavor and broth are pretty unique. I tried the Tori Paitan and it was delicious. The broth was super creamy and the texture of the noodle was amazing. It came with two types of chashu, pork and duck. I could eat the duck chashu all day every day. A bowl of ramen here is quite pricey but it really fills you up and you leave full and satisfied. If you're looking for traditional ramen though, this might not be your style. Overall, a very unique and enjoyable experience.

excerpts: TORI PAITAN - my first time having this kind of ramen.
I was drawn to this place because the pictures made the noodles look really thick and curly - my favorite!
When the ramen first came out, it was very frothy on top because they whisk it before serving.
The broth was a bit of a disappointment because it was so thick it was almost like a gravy.
The taste was decent, not quite as tasty as other broths
I've had (Orenchi, Tsujita) but pretty "intense."
The noodles were also a disappointment, they looked so good
but they fell flat!
They weren't chewy.
They had a different color and texture to them than normal ramen noodles like at Tsujita or Orenchi, and they weren't yellow.
This leads me to believe that they have a different type of flour in them that don't give them as much bounce as I was hoping.
They definitely were thick though, which was good.
As for the toppings, the pork was cold and a little gelatin-like.
The actual meat part almost had the same consistency as the fatty parts.
I did enjoy the duck meat though, very flavorful and good.
The kale was interesting but kind of hard to eat.
tori paitan.author: Brittany T.
tori paitan.review:
3.75 stars, haha but I decided to round up to 4.

PARKING: It's street parking so you just have to circle around until you find something.

WAIT: We came on a Sunday night at 5:30 pm and had to wait 1.5 hours.  The line was about 60 people deep. Unfortunately the inside is very small (seats about 28 people or so) and people seem to take a while to eat their ramen so the line moves but isn't that quick.  When you get to the front of the line the waiter takes your order so you get your food quicker, but even then it does take about 7 minutes to get your food.  

ATMOSPHERE: The inside is small with 2 sets of long communal high tables.  If you're with a weird number expect to sit with or close to strangers.  There is also a small counter/bar area that is regular height and seats 4.  If you come here alone they will come out and ask for "party of 1?" so you can take advantage.  Inside is pretty modern with information about their ramen on the walls, a TV that plays ramen videos and modern Japanese music.  The kitchen is open so you can see them making the ramen.

FOOD:

TORI PAITAN - my first time having this kind of ramen.  I was drawn to this place because the pictures made the noodles look really thick and curly - my favorite! When the ramen first came out, it was very frothy on top because they whisk it before serving.  The broth was a bit of a disappointment because it was so thick it was almost like a gravy.  The taste was decent, not quite as tasty as other broths I've had (Orenchi, Tsujita) but pretty "intense."  The noodles were also a disappointment, they looked so good but they fell flat! They weren't chewy.  They had a different color and texture to them than normal ramen noodles like at Tsujita or Orenchi, and they weren't yellow.  This leads me to believe that they have a different type of flour in them that don't give them as much bounce as I was hoping.  They definitely were thick though, which was good.  As for the toppings, the pork was cold and a little gelatin-like.  The actual meat part almost had the same consistency as the fatty parts.  I did enjoy the duck meat though, very flavorful and good.  The kale was interesting but kind of hard to eat.  I did notice that they do not offer an egg, which is interesting.

I'm starting to think that Tsukemen noodles tend to be the chewiest because they are not cooked in soup.  Next time, I would get the Tsukemen.  The problem is that they only have a certain number of bowls.  

Overall, it wasn't worth the 1.5 hour wait in my opinion.  I could definitely see why people would like this ramen because of the unique flavor and noodles but overall, I would rather go to Orenchi Beyond if I was in SF.

excerpts: We both ordered the Tori Paitan.
The noodles were thick and unlike any ramen noodles I've had before.
The broth was very thick and probably incredibly fatty.
The flavors of the ramen were perhaps too advanced for my palette.
tori paitan.author: Jackie G.
tori paitan.review: Ok. I know I'll get some heat for saying this but I'm really not picky about my ramen and almost prefer more simple traditional broths. We waited an hour and 10 mins after we arrived at 5:20.  We both ordered the Tori Paitan. The noodles were thick and unlike any ramen noodles I've had before. The broth was very thick and probably incredibly fatty. The flavors of the ramen were perhaps too advanced for my palette.

excerpts: Tori Paitan soup base is creamy but too thick and lack umami (in my opinion).
tori paitan.author: Michael L.
tori paitan.review:
I don't like it. The ramen is different for sure, but different does not mean good. 

$50+ for two people, we left unsatisfied. Japanese IPA for $12.75 and it's flat. Tori Paitan soup base is creamy but too thick and lack umami (in my opinion). We liked the shio ramen with plum paste, but not enough to return. Servers were nice.

excerpts: the tori paitan has such a rich and thick broth but it is very obivous that it was made well because the flavor was not too overly rich or salty.
by the end of the bowl though, it was a little too much for me however because it was so thick.
i was also very full from the broth the whole night.
tori paitan.author: Alex H.
tori paitan.review:
finally tried the ramen here at 9:30pm on a wednesday and there is always a line.

the tori paitan has such a rich and thick broth but it is very obivous that it was made well because the flavor was not too overly rich or salty. by the end of the bowl though, it was a little too much for me however because it was so thick. i was also very full from the broth the whole night. everything else in the ramen was also made well.

i would definitely come back to try the other flavors.

excerpts: We had the Tori paitan, which is a creamy chicken broth ramen with pork and duck chashu, along with their draft beer.
tori paitan.author: Christine L.
tori paitan.review:
Just got back from dinner at Mensho, Day 2 of opening. It was an hour and a half wait arriving in line 30 minutes before opening, which is not surprising given the limited number of seats (around 24 bar seats) and the fan following (people in line raving about the quality of the Japan site).  

Due to the recent opening, there was a limited offering, with the promise of further options in the future, i.e. Tsukemen, soba, others. We had the Tori paitan, which is a creamy chicken broth ramen with pork and duck chashu, along with their draft beer.

The broth was rich, flavorful, umami goodness (despite being fully chicken, no pork), and the noodles were a thicker variety with nice chewiness. The pork and duck chashu were nicely salty, tender, and tasty. I didn't care for the odd texture of the vegetable toppings, and would've preferred something a little more crisp, maybe with something pickled.  The service was friendly and efficient, especially considering they are still early in their rollout.  Once we were seated, we ordered immediately and were served and finished in about 30 minutes. 

The final tally for two ramens, extra chashu, and two draft beers was $56 without tip. Not cheap, but certainly this was a definitely a higher quality ramen.  I would definitely go back in a month or two when they expand their menu and some of the initial excitement dies down.

excerpts: I tried the tori paitan with double chashu.
Really rich with complex flavors.
The chashu was so tender that it almost melted in your mouth.
tori paitan.author: Philbert W.
tori paitan.review:
Got here at about 4:30pm on a wednesday.  There were already 15 people ahead of us!  Luckily, we got in for the first sitting.

I tried the tori paitan with double chashu.  Really rich with complex flavors.  The chashu was so tender that it almost melted in your mouth.  It was really good ramen.  

Our server didn't speak english very well, so I think she had a hard time taking our order.  In the end, I corrected her on what I wanted to order, but I was left wondering if she actually understood what I wanted.  Thankfully it all worked out in the end and I got my correct order.  The server was very nice, though, and came back often to check up on us.

For the first sitting, I believe they make each of the different types of ramen in series.  For us, all of the tori paitans in the restaurant came out at the same time.  Then the next type, followed by a different type. This means that some folks might be halfway finished before others get their ramen.  (I don't recommend waiting since the ramen will get cold!)  This was true for our first sitting, so I'm not sure if that happens every day.  Just be prepared.

Overall, the food was great and I'd like to come back to try their different varieties.  The difficulties with the ordering and the staggered serving times knock off a half star for me.  4.5 stars.

excerpts: The is by far the best ramen I've every had specifically the Tori Paitan.
I've been to all the best ramen places in the Bay Area.
Go there and order either the Tori Paitan or the Vegan.
Do not get anything else.
tori paitan.author: Rico S.
tori paitan.review: The is by far the best ramen I've every had specifically the Tori Paitan. I've been to all the best ramen places in the Bay Area. Go there and order either the Tori Paitan or the Vegan. Do not get anything else.

excerpts: Tori Paitan bowl with extra chasu, topped with fried garlic~
that's gonna be my regular order.
To get a guaranteed seat, we were told to get there ~ 4-4:45pm to be one of the first 24 seated at 5pm.
We got there at 4:40 pm and got seated when they opened on a Sunday.
So happy we finally got to try!
tori paitan.author: judy l.
tori paitan.review: The best ramen we've tried in the Bay Area! Broth is delicious and full of that hyped up umami flavor! Tori Paitan bowl with extra chasu, topped with fried garlic~ that's gonna be my regular order. To get a guaranteed seat, we were told to get there ~ 4-4:45pm to be one of the first 24 seated at 5pm. We got there at 4:40 pm and got seated when they opened on a Sunday. So happy we finally got to try!

excerpts: I ordered the Tori Paitan and something
just seemed to be off about the flavors.
I'd definitely say the flavors are Americanized.
It's not a bad thing
but it's not what I like to eat.
There was kale used for the veggies which was kind of a letdown.
The duck chasu however was pleasantly delicious.
Chashu was mediocre.
tori paitan.author: David C.
tori paitan.review:
I was told Mensho was the place to go while visiting SF.
I waited 30 minutes outside on a chilly day in SF before being seated by the kitchen. The restaurant is quite small but it didn't bother me. However, I do wish there was more than communal seating. I've had ramen in Japan and throughout the states and I do prefer a thick pork based soup. 

I ordered the Tori Paitan and something just seemed to be off about the flavors. I'd definitely say the flavors are Americanized. It's not a bad thing but it's not what I like to eat. There was kale used for the veggies which was kind of a letdown. The duck chasu however was pleasantly delicious. Chashu was mediocre. We also ordered the oysters in shoyu dare oil appetizer. They were just OK. Think pickled oysters. 

You leave with sticky lips which I love after eating ramen but the flavor profile isn't your traditional flavor so just know that going in. Service was excellent but you do feel rushed when there are 20 pairs of eyes watching you slurp through the big window. 

I wouldn't go back a second time but if you want something slightly different from your ramen you can give it a shot.

excerpts: I got the tori paitan ramen.
It's difficult to cater for all taste, but the noodles are very hard to me.
Dunno if anyone else feel the same.
The broth is creamy, a bit too tasty and oily.
A piece of 70% fats chasu pork cost 2 bucks...
Smh...
tori paitan.author: Lyn Z.
tori paitan.review:
Finally decided to stay in line to try the best Ramen from JP, but I got really disappointed:( I hope you are not seated in the front of the kitchen , otherwise you might can't enjoy your meal anymore. What I saw what really disgusting. The guy with white headband took the meat out from a leftover ramen and put into someone else's bow... How could you even have this thought ? I hope I really didn't see this happening....

I got the tori paitan ramen. It's difficult to cater for all taste, but the noodles are very hard to me. Dunno if anyone else feel the same. The broth is creamy, a bit too tasty and oily. A piece of 70% fats chasu pork cost 2 bucks... Smh... I'm not a meat person but seriously, if you are more expensive then all the other places, at least make it worth the money and waiting time. 

The service was great. The lady who delivered the ramen was very sweet. She came back twice to check on us if everything is ok. 

Overall a nice place w great service. Just a heads-up for Mensho. You might want to improve the sanitary part since its an open kitchen. We see everything!

excerpts: We ordered (1) enoki chips (2) tori paitan chashu ramen (3) organic shoyu double chashu ramen (3) sansho beer.
We received the organic shoyu ramen first which was slightly fishy and caught me off guard.
It wasn't bad just very different.
The noodle were also flat noodles, which was also different from other ramen places I've tried.
Next we receive the tori pain tan which came with noodles similar to chow mein.
We both preferred the tori paitan broth.
It was much richer and, for lack of a better word, the texture of the soup was "fluffy.
We then received our appetizer, which was fried enoki.
tori paitan.author: Remus L.
tori paitan.review:
I finally got off work early on a Friday and was driving in the area with my partner in crime at 5:10pm. I told him I've been wanting to try this ramen restaurant that makes their noodles in house. So what do we do? We drove by to see how bad the line was. We saw two people in line, which meant we would catch the second seating.

I dropped the hubby off to stand in line while I circled for parking, which was atrocious at the time. Make sure you don't park in a spot that's a tow away zone from 4-6pm! When I finally got parking, hubby was 5th in line. Not too bad. We were seated within 20 minutes of my dropping him off.

When we were at the front of the line, the server asked us what we wanted to order. This way our food would be served to us shortly after we were seated. As others have mentioned, this is communal type seating in a small space. I couldn't quite carry a conversation with my husband because it was so loud.

We ordered (1) enoki chips (2) tori paitan chashu ramen (3) organic shoyu double chashu ramen (3) sansho beer. We received the organic shoyu ramen first which was slightly fishy and caught me off guard. It wasn't bad just very different. The noodle were also flat noodles, which was also different from other ramen places I've tried. Next we receive the tori pain tan which came with noodles similar to chow mein. We both preferred the tori paitan broth. It was much richer and, for lack of a better word, the texture of the soup was "fluffy." We then received our appetizer, which was fried enoki. We never had a dish like it and would order it again.

Service at the establishment needs work. The communal tables have these weird cubbies that the workers place setting in them. Without an excuse me, the workers would reach into the cubbies and startle patrons. I would never expect for someone to reach for something in front of my stomach. They should either (1) learn to say excuse me (2) place these setting elsewhere. I'm not one that dings an establishment for service but more of an FYI.

Would I go back? Only if the wait didn't exceed the one we experienced. Considering the price point (our tab was over $60 with tip), I can't justify waiting 1+ hours for ramen with mediocre service. Was it good? Hard to say but it was definitely different.

excerpts: Unfortunately they didn't have tsukemen when I went but the tori paitan really is great.
tori paitan.author: Josh C.
tori paitan.review:
Unfortunately they didn't have tsukemen when I went but the tori paitan really is great. Full flavor, deep, and delicious.

Worth the wait!

excerpts: Had the tori paitan ramen (double chashu).
tori paitan.author: Amy H.
tori paitan.review:
3.5 Stars. It was fine but nothing exciting.

Waited for an hour at 6pm but it seemed to go faster since the line moved consistently.

Had the tori paitan ramen (double chashu). The tables have pink salt, pepper, ume (dried plum) and bonito (dried fish) powder which I tasted but didn't add to my ramen.

The ramen was a rich thick chicken broth. It came with two large pieces of pork charshu, duck charshu, burdock, menma (marinated bamboo shoot), kale and cabbage.

The broth was creamy with a strong stewed flavor which was good quality but one dimensional. It was a little too thick for me. The noodles were thick which I dont prefer, chewy and slightly curly (you can ask for the noodles to be cooked a little longer if you don't prefer your noodles al dente). The pork chashu was flavorful but a little over stewed. The duck chashu had good texture but had an herbal flavor that I couldn't pinpoint. Why is there kale and random cabbage in the broth? Is it to cater to San Francisco clientele? Why isn't there a soft boiled egg option? Why can you get Michelin star ramen in Tokyo for under $10 when a bowl of ramen here is $16-$18?

Haven't tried a lot of paitan ramen so it might just be that I dont prefer this style.

I'd rather go to the other ramen places in the city instead of here especially because of the line (Waraku will fulfill my ramen cravings). Compared to Orenchi, Santouka etc. in the Bay Area and places I've tried in LA, NY and Japan, it's only okay. Other people seemed to like it so I would give it a try.

excerpts: The tori paitan is amazing.
The broth is rich and milky, and so good that I forget that the dish is missing a soft boiled egg that I'm usually obsessed with.
I've also had the shoyu ramen, but the tori paitan is so much richer
it's hard to go to the shoyu.
However, it is really good and probably worth ordering if you feel like something lighter.
Seriously, the ramen here is better than some ramen we had in Japan.
Yes, the line is always long, and the TL is ghetto, and sometimes they pull a party of 1 to be seated right away even though you're way further up the line...but really it's worth the wait.
Just wish they would add more options for appetizers though
(but I guess that would just increase the table turn over times).
tori paitan.author: Tiffany C.
tori paitan.review: OMG addicting like crack! Yes, it's that good!  The tori paitan is amazing. The broth is rich and milky, and so good that I forget that the dish is missing a soft boiled egg that I'm usually obsessed with.  I've also had the shoyu ramen, but the tori paitan is so much richer it's hard to go to the shoyu. However, it is really good and probably worth ordering if you feel like something lighter.  Seriously, the ramen here is better than some ramen we had in Japan.  Yes, the line is always long, and the TL is ghetto, and sometimes they pull a party of 1 to be seated right away even though you're way further up the line...but really it's worth the wait.  Just wish they would add more options for appetizers though (but I guess that would just increase the table turn over times).

excerpts: My friend ordered a tori paitan ramen.
The broth was runny, AH-Nah.
Flavor: salty.
It felt like they were running low on broth and try to dilute the original one with water than try to make up for it with more salt.
Also, this is the big turn-off for me.
There didn't discard of the white bubble on top of the broth.
These makes the whole broth smelled like I just bite a real-life pork instead of a well-developed elegant bowl of ramen.
Their spicy miso ramen caught my eyes but they ran out.
I might come back to try this, but others thing, nah.
tori paitan.author: Thanh N.
tori paitan.review:
Me and my friend got there by 9:15p on Thursday, waited in line for 45' so we were very excited to try their thick creamy broth. I ordered a spicy dried ramen. Nothing special. All the components in the bowl goes well together to enhance the flavor. However, under-seasoned. 
My friend ordered a tori paitan ramen. The broth was runny, AH-Nah. Flavor: salty. It felt like they were running low on broth and try to dilute the original one with water than try to make up for it with more salt. Also, this is the big turn-off for me. There didn't discard of the white bubble on top of the broth. These makes the whole broth smelled like I just bite a real-life pork instead of a well-developed elegant bowl of ramen. 
Their spicy miso ramen caught my eyes but they ran out. I might come back to try this, but others thing, nah.

excerpts: Everyone goes for the Tori Paitan -
that's what people are used to eating in SF - but their tantan noodles and soba are really special.
tori paitan.author: Tiffany L.
tori paitan.review:
Those long lines but best ramen I've had in the United States! I think I'm in love. If you don't agree with me, either your tastebuds are dead, or you don't understand Asian noodles. 

Great selection of different types of ramen/noodles - most ramen joints in America usually focus on just 1 type of ramen so I'm in awe if the fact that this little shop can provide such high quality noodle dish variety.

Everyone goes for the Tori Paitan - that's what people are used to eating in SF - but their tantan noodles and soba are really special. You can't find those two dishes anywhere else in the Bay, not even close.

Patiently awaiting their Tsukemen. Bay Area, we're getting Tsukemen!!!!!!!!!!!!! (I know Iza has Tsukemen, but....)

The 6th time I went, the quality was slightly lower than the first 5 times. Not sure why, maybe they were having an off day.

Pro-tip, for the shortest lines, go Friday at 9:30PM, when everyone else about to go to the bars!

excerpts:
Food: 5 Stars
Costumer Service (particular to one lady): 1 Stars

Really enjoy the tori paitan ramen here, the soup is creamy and thick why very heavy chicken favor; the noodle cooked on point with the right amount of chewiness; and the duck chashu is also very delicious.
tori paitan.author: Hunter S.
tori paitan.review:
Food: 5 Stars
Costumer Service (particular to one lady): 1 Stars

Really enjoy the tori paitan ramen here, the soup is creamy and thick why very heavy chicken favor; the noodle cooked on point with the right amount of chewiness; and the duck chashu is also very delicious. The only thing I complain is their stuff, one of the ladies there (older lady with shoulder length black hair) is super rude, she was literally yelling at people when they don't sit according to her direction (she wants everyone to sit opposite of each other, rather than sitting next to each other).

excerpts: The Ume broth and Tori Paitan broths were delicious, but the noodles themselves were different from what I was used to (not bad, just not what I was expecting from a bowl of ramen).
tori paitan.author: Jessica J.
tori paitan.review:
I've driven past here on multiple occasions and wondered what the big deal was. The line is always super long. So, when my coworkers were deciding on an early dinner one night, we stopped by to see if there would be a line and lo and behold (despite the restaurant being full) we were the first in line outside. 

I learned why there is always this line, that makes it appear to be deceptively popular. The restaurant itself is rather tiny, only seating maybe 20 or so people at once. 

SEATING: You get seated at these long, communal tables so seating can get a little complicated if you have a big party. 

BROTH: If you enjoy super rich, creamy, thick broth then this is your place. I have to be honest, I really enjoyed the broth. It was unique, savory, and really really hit the spot. 

NOODLES: The Ume broth and Tori Paitan broths were delicious, but the noodles themselves were different from what I was used to (not bad, just not what I was expecting from a bowl of ramen).

PRICE: I would've given this place maybe 4/5... Unfortunately, I think the priciness of each bowl kind of put me off. It was about $16-18 per bowl, and the bowls weren't particularly large nor did it come with a lot of toppings. That was disappointing. I just can't justify paying that much for ramen, when I've had ramen that has tasted just as great (or even better) over in San Mateo for less. 

SERVICE: Because of the table arrangement, it was really difficult for the servers to get around us without reaching around / over you which was kind of uncomfortable. We also felt super rushed - they asked us MULTIPLE times whether we were done (and we're not even slow eaters), and tried to bus our bowls away on several occasions while we were still working on drinking the broth. I used to be a waitress, so I understand the importance of turning over tables, but definitely not at the expense of your customers' dining experience.

All in all, would I come back? Maybe.. if I was in the area and there's no line. The broth is definitely unique enough that I might come back, and it's worth a try if you've never had it. 

Maybe next time will be better!

excerpts: I got the Tori Paitan.
The broth is rich and creamy.
I loved the duck cashu.
I've never had that before and it went very well with the broth.
The noodles are thick the way I like.
Everything just meshed together.
tori paitan.author: Julie S.
tori paitan.review:
I came here solo and still waited like 20 minutes. I'd recommend coming 30 minutes before they open. Would I wait more than an hour for this place? Probably not. If I am with friends who are fun and willing to wait, probably yes. I'm all about the foodie adventure! 

Compared to other ramen places, the broth is what made this place stand out. I got the Tori Paitan. The broth is rich and creamy. I loved the duck cashu. I've never had that before and it went very well with the broth. The noodles are thick the way I like. Everything just meshed together. I just wish you could add a marinated soft boiled egg.

 I also ordered the Oysters in Shoyu Dare Oil. They were interesting... not what you expect when you think of oysters. Tasted like oysters from a can drenched in soy sauce. I wasn't a fan. Also, I wanted to try a spicy ramen but they didn't have it yet. It was on the wall menu but I'd like to come back and try it.

This place is super small and you will probably end up at a communal table. Interesting fact I learned from someone I met at my communal table: the ramen broth making process in Japan would not meet food safety requirements here in the US. And I heard the owner is an expert Ramen creator from Japan, I trust that this could be the closest we can get to authentic Japanese ramen!

excerpts: I tried the Tori Paitan
tori paitan.author: Lucy W.
tori paitan.review:
Solid ramen. 

I tried the Tori Paitan - it was rich, creamy, and chewy, just as I imagined.

I would definitely come back and try the vegan and shoyu ones.

Waited for an hour and half to get in, but it's expected for a popular ramen place. The taste is one of the best I've had in the U.S., similar level as Totto Ramen and Ippudo in New York

excerpts: Tori Paitan is more like thick gravy than what I would think as soup 'broth'.
So be it.
It was very flavorful, I may just add some water to it from  my glass next time..
tori paitan.author: Monsieur_Meursault _.
tori paitan.review:
2 visits. Have had 3 (out of their 4?) types of ramen (did not get the vegan one). Some with double pork chasu. 5 total bowls. 

I don't care if it's "authentic". Authentic doesn't always mean "good". 

The tall bald man that runs the door the times we went was super helpful on the style of ramen each was. We appreciated his descriptions and personable demeanor. The waitresses inside I felt were poor. More because of their lack of command of the English language than anything else though.

All their ramen is great I thought. I highly recommend adding more pork chasu to it.

Tori Paitan is more like thick gravy than what I would think as soup 'broth'. So be it. It was very flavorful, I may just add some water to it from  my glass next time.._

The other 2 we had were lighter in style but all had distinct flavors.

3 Japanese beers with only 1 under$10. The IPA was solid, I've had Sansho and the lager before. Probably gonna stick to crushing a beer or 2 in line.

tori paitan.author: eric w.
tori paitan.review:
$16 to eat ramen in the TL!??!?! What the hell was I thinking?!??!

Definitely disappointed by the experience and the quality.  Do yourself a favor, if you love ramen, go to Himawari in San Mateo and get the Tan Tan Men Deluxe:
https://www.yelp.com/biz/himawari-san-mateo

Being a fan of thick, creamy broth, I decided to get the Tori Paitan.  The stock was definitely thick, but it had this grainy texture that was not appealing.  The noodles were definitely thick and good.  The ramen includes a paltry slice of pork, duck and a few pieces of bamboo to supplement the soup and noodles.  Having eaten at Himawari and Orenchi, by far this is not a value.

I have tried to go to this place numerous times but the line and waiting system is just ridiculous.  Standing like cattle, tethered to a line might be a psychological factor for attracting customers and a form of free advertisement, but it's completely intolerable.  There are name lists, pagers and call back options the business could have implemented to make better use of your time.  

For you city folk, do yourself a favor.  Hop on a caltrain southbound to Downtown San Mateo, enjoy excrement free streets and a scenic tranquil landscape and experience ramen nirvana at Himawari.

excerpts: The tori paitan with double chasu came in the perfect size, with the right soup to noodle ratio; however, the ratio of toppings to the noodle+ soup was underwhelming and disappointing.
While I thoroughly enjoyed the menma and burdock, which provided a punch of saltiness and texture to the ramen, the kale was the odd one out, arriving in a sad lump of overly cooked green mess.
I do love my noodles and soup, I just wish there were more toppings to accommodate the carby goodness.
I feel like the lack of egg is a good thing, as the soup itself is already very rich.
I first tasted the broth, which was lacking in flavour and almost seemed like a thick and creamy gravy, as another yelp reviewer pointed out.
Granted, this is the second paitan I've ever tried, but it just seemed like the thickness of the broth should have been remedied with more spices or whatnot.
By the end of the ramen, I had no desire to continue drinking (eating?)
the broth.
I don't think I would get the tori paitan often, just once in a while when I'm craving a whole lot of richness and comfort food in the form of japanese cuisine.
I prefer the chicken paitan at Nojo's which is impeccable and much tastier in my opinion in terms of broth and overall balance.
tori paitan.author: Jennifer S.
tori paitan.review:
My boss had told me about this new ramen shop opening up months ago, and I decided it was about time to brave the line and try it out. I started standing in line at 5:30, and wasn't in the restaurant until 7:15. Service was immediate, seating is communal which is smart for a ramen shop, and overall the atmosphere was positive. 

We started off with the oyster appetizer which was outstanding! The oysters (4 on a plate) came prepared in a semi-dried treatment, yet still oozed with texture and flavour of the soy sauce. It was a surprising burst of flavour, sweet and salty, with a slight tang of nut and acidity. 

The tori paitan with double chasu came in the perfect size, with the right soup to noodle ratio; however, the ratio of toppings to the noodle+ soup was underwhelming and disappointing. While I thoroughly enjoyed the menma and burdock, which provided a punch of saltiness and texture to the ramen, the kale was the odd one out, arriving in a sad lump of overly cooked green mess. I do love my noodles and soup, I just wish there were more toppings to accommodate the carby goodness. I feel like the lack of egg is a good thing, as the soup itself is already very rich. I first tasted the broth, which was lacking in flavour and almost seemed like a thick and creamy gravy, as another yelp reviewer pointed out. Granted, this is the second paitan I've ever tried, but it just seemed like the thickness of the broth should have been remedied with more spices or whatnot. By the end of the ramen, I had no desire to continue drinking (eating?) the broth. It is true that the broth is slightly grainier towards the bottom of the bowl.  

The strangest thing was that everything in the bowl was fairly lukewarm which was alarming when I first tried it, however the noodles were steaming hot in contrast! Once you mix the bowl up, the broth becomes steamier and the temperature is more balanced out. Unfortunately the meat is still not hot, something I prefer my meat to be in all of my ramens. The duck was the winner compared to the pork chasu, which I've had better pork chasu's at Parlor or other places. I tried the broth of the soyu ramen which was delicious, just a tad bit too salty. The noodles for the paitain were thick and Al Dente, for the shoyu they were flatter but still consistent in springiness and chewiness.

Overall, I enjoyed the food here. You can tell that it's high quality, and made with a lot of thought and love. I would come here after the chef arrives back from Japan and the other dishes are in stock--very eager to try the tonkotsu and the umi miso ramen (miso ramen is my favourite!! Go to Ramen Parlor for a bomb miso ramen). There are also tsukemen ramen and soba that are in the works. I don't think I would get the tori paitan often, just once in a while when I'm craving a whole lot of richness and comfort food in the form of japanese cuisine. I prefer the chicken paitan at Nojo's which is impeccable and much tastier in my opinion in terms of broth and overall balance.

excerpts: As for the Tori Paitan: is it broth or is it gravy?
tori paitan.author: Huey K.
tori paitan.review:
It's like a movie where all the parts are well-acted, but it doesn't come together. You find yourself praising the quality of the each ingredient because you're not ready to admit you're not as happy with the dish.

Waiting in line seems silly when they could just take names. 

As for the Tori Paitan: is it broth or is it gravy? It's tasty, but it gets a little gritty towards the bottom.

The shoyu is fishy.

Both the duck and pork chashu are excellent. 

The noodles are good.

There is no soft boiled egg. Apparently this will be fixed once Shono finds some eggs here he likes, but this still needs to be mentioned.

excerpts: I had the Tori Paitan with extra chashu.

He had the vegan tantanman.
tori paitan.author: Jeff L.
tori paitan.review:
I had the Tori Paitan with extra chashu. It was very flavorful, and except for a few times when it was unexpectedly temperature hot it was very good. My friend has never had ramen before as he's never figured the cuisine as being friendly to vegetarians. He had the vegan tantanman. Once I explained that you eat ramen with the spoon in your left hand and chopsticks in your right he really enjoyed the meal.

The main worry here is the line. Setting up a restaurant like this with no reservations in the tenderloin is a little ridiculous. Fortunately, there wasn't much of a line at 5:45pm on a Thursday evening, we were inside within 10 minutes. But I wouldn't want to go back on a busy evening and have to wait outside this area for more than that. They really ought to start taking reservations.

We split a 300ml bottle of sake. Only after I ordered it did I remember that this was not a sake I particularly liked. 

The waitresses speak only the most basic english. My friend had a question as to what some things on his food were and she answered "vegan!" as if he was only concerned with whether or not he was eating meat.

Overall the ramen was quite good. I'll come back when times work out for it being convenient. But their location and average long waiting time makes it hard to just decide to go here.

excerpts: I was happy with tori paitan and my guy enjoyed his shoyu.
tori paitan.author: Michelle K.
tori paitan.review:
From the time Mensho opens, there is a line out the door.  I joined the crowd at 5:30pm and was grateful that I had a short wait (around 30 minutes).

There are four seats by the bar or four large communal tables.  They fill the tables as soon as seats are available, this means your larger party may get skipped for a single or double.

There are limited types of ramen on the menu, and each come with different noodles (and spoons).  I was happy with tori paitan and my guy enjoyed his shoyu.  The price for both (without sides or drinks) was more expensive than typical ramen ($30), but was worth trying.

The place is packed and they don't take reservations.  Get there early or wait in the long line.  While it was delicious, I think I'll stick with my less crowded spots when I need a ramen fix.

excerpts: I ordered the $18 Tori Paitan Chashu Ramen, got served w/o too long of a wait (yay but $18??!!).
But wait...
my spoon was missing from my setting...

At this point, my ramen is just mocking me.
Such a slap in the face since I couldn't properly enjoy it like the next guy who got his food just before me
but he's happily slurping away tasting the broth w/ his SPOON!
I waited yet again for my waitress to reappear and asked for spoons for me & others at my table who were also missing theirs as I observed spoons were all missing from our settings.
tori paitan.author: Stephanie C.
tori paitan.review:
Waited for more than 3 hours in line for my perfect bowl of happiness but went home feeling a little let down, and woke up still w/ that damn curly leave of kale in my bowl haunting me this am.  Let me explain - I grew up in restaurants, worked in both small & large-scale operations, lived in Japan & LOVE ramen.  Please pardon the long review as I'm about to share...

WAIT - I get it's the long anticipated grand opening, and over SB50 weekend no less but you should know there's such thing as a soft opening to work out all the kinks before your highly-anticipated US debut.  Never mind the 3hr+ wait, train your staff to know the mechanics of seating & managing a hungry mob outside.  I came by myself & waited in line patiently before the door opened but noticed how they failed to move the line (you see a LOT when you had to go thru a long wait like mine).  There were plenty of single seats available throughout the evening but they never seated solo diners to ease the line...guess they wanted to be fair to others who waited (which I get) but this only added to the angry crowd.  Either 1) designate a few chairs for solo diners to ease the line or 2) insert them where there's already a single diner seating across from an EMPTY chair or 3) seat them where there's a party of 3 or 5.  This is a ramen joint not a fancy sit-down, so operate like one...in, out & no one gets hurt!

MENU - Once inside, waited yet again patiently for a menu, any menu...at this point, I was weak from enduring the cold and just sat in silence getting warm-up but quickly found out how hectic the place was w/ no server in sight, so as soon as a waitress showed up I had to flag her down for a menu.  What amazed me was the moment she handed me the menu, she asked whether I was ready to order!  I told her you just gave me the menu so please give me a sec, so she stood there expecting for an order, instantly.  Menu was limited during grand opening, no Mensho "welcome ramen", no chicken karaage, etc...just ramen for now.

FOOD - I'm a Tonkatsu Ramen lover, was shocked to see there's none offered out of the 7 types of ramen on the menu.  I ordered the $18 Tori Paitan Chashu Ramen, got served w/o too long of a wait (yay but $18??!!).  But wait...my spoon was missing from my setting...BIG no-no!  I came so close to happiness thinking they got 1 thing right - prompt food delivery.  At this point, my ramen is just mocking me.  Such a slap in the face since I couldn't properly enjoy it like the next guy who got his food just before me but he's happily slurping away tasting the broth w/ his SPOON!  I waited yet again for my waitress to reappear and asked for spoons for me & others at my table who were also missing theirs as I observed spoons were all missing from our settings.  Finally, I just dived in, too hungry to wait around for a silly spoon while my ramen's getting cold (another no-no)...who cares if I had to hold the bowl up like I was in Japan just to taste that rich, creamy broth full of yummy umami.  

Forget the traditional toppings of a sexy ramen 1/2 egg, nori, menma (bamboo shoot) etc...you get fried gobo (burdock root), a few chives mixed in, an odd curly leaf of kale which haunts me like an unnecessary garnish of a curly parsley in any bad dishes I've seen (let alone in a Mensho ramen).  The broth tasted incredible and lived up to the Mensho name.  I can just see how much time & effort that went into it, but the noodles was just too thick for the already thick broth.  I couldn't help but envy others who had a different flat noodle in their ramen.  Guess I'll have to come back when their ramen machine is up & running to taste it again, but for now the thick noodles just don't really belong in that rich broth...I can see it being an incredible ramen dish served cold as the noodles were perfectly chewy & got a great bite!  

CUSTOMER SERVICE - I was so hungry, I finished my bowl under 10min vs. my 3hr+ wait outside but at least tummy got fed.  Waited patiently for my check which never came since my waitress whom I finally had to flag down for a check said they had lost my check after some investigating.  She later came back w/ a manual check but never came back to gather my cc.  I sat & observed how hectic the place was still at 9:40pm and realized how green the staff must had been w/o much training as to offer proper customer service.  Finally, I had to flag down another waitress who was nice enough to run back w/ my cc.

OVERALL - 3.5 stars and will wait for them to work out the kinks & all the hype before returning.  Lots of ideas for improvement.  It will be interesting to see if anything improved then.  I really wanted to try another bowl of ramen (that tells you how much I wanted to like Mensho) but didn't want to wait & go home at midnight due to the sheer chaos.

P.S. our table (long table closet to kitchen against the wall) kept collapsing a bit on us any time someone puts their elbow down.  Worth looking into...

Pricey

The wait is long but fun to chat with people in line who loves ramen as much as much as I do.

excerpts: Tori Paitan - The broth was more sweet than savory, but SUPER CREAMY!
tori paitan.author: Jackie O.
tori paitan.review:
Finally tried Mensho Tokyo ramen this weekend... I've been avoiding it like the plague because of the line BUT I was surprised at how fast the line went! The line was down the block but we only waited 40 mins max for 4 people.

Once you're seated the restaurant itself is tiny so please be respectful of the other waiting ramen lovers... just eat and go! Redford is across the street if you wanna drink and chit chat ;) 

As soon as we were in front and waiting to get seated the waitress took our order, then within 5 minutes we were seated. The tables are interestingly shaped they have these like slots for extra plating and napkins, then baskets underneath for your belongings. Stools so no leaning back and you'll most likely be sharing the table with other ramen goers. I loved the big ass spoons they give you... it's RIDICULOUSLY HUGE! :P

Probably another 5-10 minutes and our ramens came out! We got the following items:
Oysters in Shoyu Dare Oil - Livery texture and the Dare Oil is almost like a soy sauce/ponzu mixture. It's cold but a great burst of flavor if you love oysters and salty/sweet sauces
Shio Chashu Ramen - OMG... The broth is clear and super flavorful for a clear broth. I'm usually a tonkotsu kinda of gal. The noodles are not your typical kind and the Korean kalguksu kind, so chewy and perfectly al dente. The chashu just falls apart as you try to grab and eat... Only sad thing is that they don't do marinated eggs :(
Tori Paitan - The broth was more sweet than savory, but SUPER CREAMY! The noodles were different from the Shio and I wasn't a huge fan of this dish, but the best part was the duck... it was like pinkish and fatty but man. It melted in your mouth!

Service was phenomenal!

excerpts: The tori paitan is thick and rich, for those of you who like a ramen with more body, and the noodles are appropriately matched.
Agreed with others that the sprig of kale isn't much to my liking, and I miss having some of my Japanese ramen favorites
(menma is a big one for me), but the fried gobo is excellent and adds a flavor that a lot of Americans aren't familiar with.
Crossing my fingers that the tori paitan gyokai will be reminiscent of Fuunji in Tokyo!
tori paitan.author: Kevin L.
tori paitan.review:
Reposting my prior review -- this was taken down by Yelp because it was posted prior to the restaurant opening, but after having revisited several times since, my opinion hasn't changed:

I was lucky enough to get a chance to taste the organic shoyu ramen before the grand opening, and I'm happy to report that Mensho Tokyo is as good as it gets for those of us that love our ramen as authentic as possible -- noodles with a good chew, a beautiful slick of fat ladled over the soup, and the whole thing served properly hot (temperature-wise). The soup was a great change of pace from the same old tepid, weak tonkotsu broth with curly pre-frozen noodles that you can get elsewhere in the area. The chashu was generous and delicious: a soft and fatty round of simmered pork, with two juicy slices of duck meat on the side. The tori paitan is thick and rich, for those of you who like a ramen with more body, and the noodles are appropriately matched. Agreed with others that the sprig of kale isn't much to my liking, and I miss having some of my Japanese ramen favorites (menma is a big one for me), but the fried gobo is excellent and adds a flavor that a lot of Americans aren't familiar with. The shio ramen at $9 is the single best value bowl of ramen I've had in the US: the shoyu just edges it out, but for those looking for something delicious that won't weigh you down, it's a proper shio ramen with a strong chicken flavor. The garlic tends to settle on the bottom, which leads to an interesting shift in flavor as you make your way through the bowl and the garlic sits longer in the remaining soup.

This feels like a shop transplanted from Tokyo (which it is), and beats out every one of the other 36 ramen shops I've tried across the US to take the title of #1. It competes handily with the best shops in Tokyo as well. The interior is beautifully appointed, clean, and modern, and I love that they've turned the entire restaurant into counter seating (albeit with the concession of counter-height tables for groups) for a more Japanese dining experience.

They're not launching with everything on the menu, and they're waiting on the go-ahead from the health department before they can start making their own noodles with the machine that they imported from Japan, but Mensho Tokyo is already far and away better than anything else available in the area. Can't wait until they finish sourcing ingredients and start serving additional items from the menu! When that happens, we'll finally be able to have proper tsukemen in the Bay Area. Crossing my fingers that the tori paitan gyokai will be reminiscent of Fuunji in Tokyo!

SF is in for a real treat. This place is worth the wait.

excerpts: Also Tori Paitan is good.
tori paitan.author: Wiryan T.
tori paitan.review:
4.5. That -0.5 down bump is for the price. But don't let that get to you.

I frequent Tokyo a lot due to travel routes and I DAMN VOUCH for this place. This is what Ramen is suppose to be. Its thick, because its suppose to be. Why do y'all think Ramen is like chinese clear soup noodles anyway? (for YF who said they over rely on creaminess: D'UH. Thats what its suppose to be.)

Anyways, please stay like this, dear Mensho Ramen people, don't water anything down. Don't listen to those ignorant people. Let them go away somewhere else. YOU have a crowd of your own.

Also Tori Paitan is good.

excerpts: After consulting Yelp (cause food fomo is a real thing),  we both settled on the Tori Paitan Ramen.
tori paitan.author: Lucy C.
tori paitan.review:
My eyelids droop slowly as I type this review and I feel myself sinking lower and lower into my seat. I am a blob. A round, floppy blob. If this is death by food, then this is the way I want to go. 

I stopped by here with a friend after work. At 6:10pm on a Tuesday, the line was already at 30-40 people and it took us over 1.5 hours to get seated. Luckily, the long line offered us ample opportunity to stare wistfully through the window. Making patrons uncomfortable? My specialty. Besides, that just means they'll eat faster.

After consulting Yelp (cause food fomo is a real thing),  we both settled on the Tori Paitan Ramen. I ambitiously opted for the double chashu- spoiler: there were no regrets.

The Ramen itself came out fairly quickly (maybe about 10-15 min?) and looked absolutely gorgeous. One sip of the broth and we both swooned. The Paitan broth is incredibly savory and creamy, the texture like a mix of soup and gravy. The Ramen comes with both duck and pork chashu (1 slice of each in the regular Ramen and two slices of each in the double). The duck chashu was an interesting addition. As my friend commented, you could definitely taste the lemon. To me, it felt a little out of place in the creamy broth, but whatever floats your boat. The PORK chashu though. Omigod. I'm already a sucker for pork, so this absolutely stole my heart. 

About a third of the way through the meal, however, I could definitely feel some regret. It was sooo rich, maybe a little too rich for my personal taste. I think if I had to do it over, I'd personally try one of the lighter broths but hey- maybe you'll like it more!

Overall, really delicious Ramen and a place I'd definitely recommend trying. Was it worth 1.5 hours of waiting? Not so much. I've heard that lines tend to be better if you come 30+ minutes before opening, so maybe try that!

tori paitan.author: Cat G.
tori paitan.review:

My favorite part: the NOODLES... omg. So good. Definitely recommend coming by for ramen. Staff is super friendly and tables turn pretty fast.

excerpts: We ordered two classic Tori Paitan Ramen's with double chashu, one with the miso egg and another with the soy egg.
The broth is thick, flavorful, full of umami, but *not too salty* (!).
For me, the broth is the most important part.
I don't think I've ever had a thick broth ramen where I could drink the soup without a bowl of rice.
The duck and chashu were cooked exquisitely, and the noodles were thick and yummy.
The eggs were both tasty and cooked to runny perfection; I preferred the miso egg (sweeter) to the soy egg (more fermented flavor).
You can't order a side of rice here, and I'm not a huge eater, but the double chashu + whole egg was the perfect amount of food for me (maybe sliiiightly too much, but no regerts).
My friend who can eat more than me finished all his food and the broth, whereas I wasn't able to finish the broth.
We almost ordered one Maccha Ramen instead, but looking at others, the amount of matcha they add was a lot
tori paitan.author: A T.
tori paitan.review:
Best ramen I've had outside of Japan. (Have yet to try Iza Ramen though) Went with a ramen connoisseur friend who ranked this place in his top 2 ramen places in all of California.

FOOD:
We ordered two classic Tori Paitan Ramen's with double chashu, one with the miso egg and another with the soy egg. The broth is thick, flavorful, full of umami, but *not too salty* (!). For me, the broth is the most important part. I don't think I've ever had a thick broth ramen where I could drink the soup without a bowl of rice. The duck and chashu were cooked exquisitely, and the noodles were thick and yummy. The eggs were both tasty and cooked to runny perfection; I preferred the miso egg (sweeter) to the soy egg (more fermented flavor). You can't order a side of rice here, and I'm not a huge eater, but the double chashu + whole egg was the perfect amount of food for me (maybe sliiiightly too much, but no regerts). My friend who can eat more than me finished all his food and the broth, whereas I wasn't able to finish the broth. We almost ordered one Maccha Ramen instead, but looking at others, the amount of matcha they add was a lot and we overheard people discussing the graininess of it, so decided to stick to the classic for a first time.

SERVICE etc.:
We waited in line for ~one hour on Sunday at 6pm for two people. Waiters were all very nice and responsive. They forgot our double chashu and were a little quick to blame us for not ordering correctly rather than taking the blame for not taking down our orders correctly in the first place (we made sure to double check that it was double chashu when ordering). There are baskets under the table for your things, and coat hooks by the door. Decor was slick and urban -- big glass windows, communal wood tables, stool seating -- but still somewhat cozy because of the small space. If you're on a date, get ready to sit across from the other person, because they won't let you sit side by side (the table width is pretty wide). We were lucky enough to be able to trade with another couple to sit side by side. (Personally, I prefer this because I don't like to watch people eat, you're closer to the other person, and it makes sharing food easier, but I understand why they make this rule since there's high customer turnover.) Bathrooms were clean, which is a good sign to me of the level of kitchen cleanliness.

We will definitely be coming back! Also plan to update my review once I've tried Iza Ramen and Marufuku for comparison.

excerpts: Tori Paitan: If you want to try something different, this is it.
Broth is extremely rich (much different from the tori paitan i had in Japan at Kagari which is by far one of the best ramen
bowls i've had) but good.
tori paitan.author: Dylan T.
tori paitan.review:
Probably the best ramen spot in SF right now. Don't go here if you are going to complain about a 20$ bowl of ramen. The quality is excellent.

Tori Paitan: If you want to try something different, this is it. Broth is extremely rich (much different from the tori paitan i had in Japan at Kagari which is by far one of the best ramen bowls i've had) but good. They use very fatty duck and regular chashu although not much.

If you want a more balanced bowl, get the organic shoyu. Definitely enjoyed the lightness but still delicious broth of the shoyu. Noodles are a bit thicker than you'd expect but that is just how they do it. If you want to pick at it for their choice of noodles, don't go.

Just make sure to double your chashu order if you go.

Line: Gets kind of crazy because of the hype so expect at least 30 mins. Shorter if you go before 5 or after 9.

tori paitan.review:
Hoping to shorten the two hour wait that many yelpers have mentioned, I came here on Wednesday before the restaurant opened. Did I mention it was one of those days where SF hit the high 70s. Service **
Although we were the 3rd party to enter and order, our food did not come until 20-30 mins later. The ramen was made in about 7-8 mins, but I believe some kind of mistake was made by the chef or server. The first two parties ahead of us have already received their order, but the waitress did not notice that we did not have our ramen until 4-5 parties that ordered later was already half way done with their ramen. After asking about our ramen, the answer was oh you guys did not receive your ramen yet. 

*****
Tori Paitan 
This is definitely worth the wait. The broth is rich and flavorful, where you could taste the meats boiled for hours. I have to agree with what the customers across mentioned, "this broth is too good to waste." 

Thicker ramen is paired with this broth. 

***
Shio

Soft Ramen

excerpts: The Tori Paitan ($16) was good.
tori paitan.author: D V.
tori paitan.review:

Glad we tried it but not a spot we would frequent.

tori paitan.author: Jeffrey Z.
tori paitan.review:
The Tori Paitan Ramen (chicken broth) is amazing. Creamiest, thickest ramen broth I've had since being in Tokyo. Noodles were thick and chewy. Each topping had its own distinct flavor - no ingredient was a "filler." You could really taste the quality and care. Kitchen staff far outnumbered wait staff.

Not cheap - $16 before tax for Tori Paitan Ramen. Other options are cheaper. Shoyu (soy sauce) ramen is $14 before tax, Shio (salt) ramen is $9 before tax.

They do not yet have tsukemen and tonkotsu - those are coming in a couple months. So if you enjoy creamy ramen then Tori Paitan is your only option, but you won't regret trying it.

For seating, they only have communal high tables and a few bar seats.

Mensho Tokyo is well acclaimed in Tokyo and this is their first US location. The co-owner is from the Bay Area and is a ramen critic in Japan. He's the host and is super knowledgeable.

They do not have a waiting list, so you have to wait in line. I was in a party of 2 and we had to wait an hour after arriving at 8pm.

excerpts: I tried the Tori Paitan ramen and the soup was very thick and creamy, way thicker if you compare it to even the extra fatty version of Daikokuya's tonkatsu ramen.
I was expecting something more flavorful, but perhaps this type of broth is meant to be mild?
I've never tried Tori Paitan anywhere else.
The noodles themselves were excellent.
It's pretty pricey too, Tori Paitan was $16, so be prepared.
tori paitan.author: Angella A.
tori paitan.review:
For those counting the people going in and coming out, the there are 28 seats total in Mensho (including the four facing the kitchen wall).

I tried the Tori Paitan ramen and the soup was very thick and creamy, way thicker if you compare it to even the extra fatty version of Daikokuya's tonkatsu ramen.  I was expecting something more flavorful, but perhaps this type of broth is meant to be mild? I've never tried Tori Paitan anywhere else. The noodles themselves were excellent. It's pretty pricey too, Tori Paitan was $16, so be prepared.

The service staff is still trying to figure things out but I think that just comes with being a new restaurant. For example, the pepper mill cap was not screwed on tightly and we saw peppercorns fly everywhere when someone tried to pick up the container. I also noticed there was no soap in the bathroom an hour into service. Hopefully these things will get sorted out with time. 

I hope the expand to the full menu soon. The choices on the wall (but not on the limited menu) like the ebi miso sound so good.

excerpts: I came here today 35 before opening time, ordered tori paitan...
And boy, did it blow me away.
The creamy, buttery broth combined with melting chashu and perfectly made noodles took the whole package to a whole another dimension from the other ramen in the Bay Area.
This is the best ramen in the Bay Area without question.
tori paitan.author: Kuan P.
tori paitan.review:
I've been to Orenchi, Ramen dojo, kotetsu, and a few other ramen places around the Bay Area, and I think I can tell a good bowl of ramen from the rest. When this place opened up and got the hype it was even better than Orenchi (although I personally think it was arguable it was THE best, but certainly very good), I had to go.

I came here today 35 before opening time, ordered tori paitan... And boy, did it blow me away. The creamy, buttery broth combined with melting chashu and perfectly made noodles took the whole package to a whole another dimension from the other ramen in the Bay Area. This is the best ramen in the Bay Area without question. It cost $18, pricy, but heck, I would've paid $30 if I had to. 

The restaurant is run by a mostly fully Japanese staff, with a really modern design-y look inside. However it can sit 25 ish people inside, with no reservations or even a list to write your name down. As such, I recommend you to come at least 30 min before opening and physically wait - even earlier if you want to get in on the first wave!

excerpts: - Ordered the Tori Paitan and the first few bites were really good.
The soup was hot, noodles were al dente, but mostly, it was just so novel
and I've never had anything similar, despite having been to Japan twice.
I probably should've just stopped there.
- The soup was SO heavy and creamy that everything else just kind of melted into it.
After that, the flavor profile instantly became salty and flat.
The toppings that would have offered a contrast in texture and taste basically got drowned out by the broth.
However, the chicken flavor did stand out.

- The broth had a strange grainy texture...
- The duck was interesting and had a hint of acidity.
Interesting isn't always good.
Also do you really need chicken, duck, and pork in the same bowl?
- The pork was amazing, I'll give them that.
Soft and melted in my mouth.
Unfortunately, once it got mixed in with everything else, I could hardly differentiate the pieces of chashu from the soup, since the textures were equally fatty.

- The noodles clumped together a bit but were thick enough to hold the flavor of the soup.
- I really wanted to love this place, but a broth that thick and creamy probably just isn't my thing.
I guess I thought it'd be okay since I absolutely adore Ichiran's fatty broth.
I really regretted finishing it.
Felt nauseated after.
I've felt less gross after eating 20 McNuggets and fries.

I ordered the organic Shoyu ramen and my bf ordered the Tori Paitan ramen. The Shoyu soup base tasted amazing but the noodles in the Tori Paitan were better. I wish people would eat a little faster though, considering the fact that there is always a long line... Eat like the people in Japan do!

excerpts: Tori Paitan much better.
Shorter wait time and the egg was good.
tori paitan.author: Nam N.
tori paitan.review: Came back a second time. Tori Paitan much better. Shorter wait time and the egg was good.

excerpts: Given that our only options were the Tori Paitan, which is written about very favorably here, and the vegan ramen due to the limited menu during Mensho's early operations, we both went with the Paitan.
tori paitan.author: Adam G.
tori paitan.review:
Arrived at 4:15pm on 2/14 with my girlfriend and we found ourselves at the 30+ mark in line. We decided to wait despite the fact that they had run out of the noodles for the Shio and Shoyu ramen. I even went across the street to get Hot Cheetos because I was so hungry. We entered the restaurant around 5:50 or so and sat at the "bar" which is really just 4 chairs looking into the kitchen. Given that our only options were the Tori Paitan, which is written about very favorably here, and the vegan ramen due to the limited menu during Mensho's early operations, we both went with the Paitan.

When the reviews say the Paitan is really creamy, they mean it. It is almost too overwhelming with meat flavor and we could not even finish our whole bowl because we got a bit grossed out. It was just a lot of the same flavor. If you've never had Paitan, think Tonkotsu, but WAY creamier. 

I could tell that the ramen was really high quality, which is why I am giving 4 stars and perhaps if I would've tried the Shoyu or Shio, I would give 5 stars. I've had ramen at the best places in New York (Ippudo, Totto) so I have some idea of what good ramen should taste like. There's just no way I see myself waiting that long again for ramen, especially in San Francisco, where there must be a dozen places to get at least a decent bowl without the hassle of waiting. 

For Mensho: You guys need to start recording people's cell phone numbers and texting them when their table is ready. There are two bars across the street I would have much rather sat at for 90 minutes. Also, the servers seemed confused about which seats they were covering, as I ordered with 3 different servers. I'm sure this kink will be worked out as the weeks go by, however. 

TL;DR - if the wait is over 1 hour, go somewhere else, especially in the first few months of the restaurant being open. They told me they are expanding the menu in the next 2 months. The ramen is really good but not worth the wait and countless people walking and driving by thinking you're crazy

My only complain is they don't have appetizers besides those oysters!
