The broth was better than the other ramen restaurants I've been to where I'm from, very creamy and not extremely salty.
tori paitan.author: Beth H.
tori paitan.review:
I went with my boyfriend around 9pm and the wait was an hour. While I stood in line I watched the tv which was some Japanese variety show of some girl eating a variety of food, weird but I guess entertaining. The restaurant had limited space but was cute in design. 

Food: We both got the tori paitan. When I eat ramen I care mostly about the flavor of the soup and the texture of the noodles. The broth was better than the other ramen restaurants I've been to where I'm from, very creamy and not extremely salty. However the noodles were kind of hard and the meat was alright, not amazing but still pretty good. 

Service: We saw our waiter three times in total. We were out of water ten minutes into our meal and it was never refilled. There weren't very many waiters available for us to flag down. The food took awhile to come out as well. 

So was it worth the one hour wait in the cold? Probably not, but if you've never had good ramen this is a pretty good place to try.

excerpts: First, the Tori Paitan Ramen, with double chasu.
The broth was incredibly thick, almost gravy like!
An immense amount of flavor in each spoonful and incredibly satisfying in both flavor and fullness.
Both the duck and the pork chashu melt in the mouth; the slow cooking of the meats allows the flavor to concentrate it and it stands out despite the incredibly flavorful broth.
tori paitan.author: Chen L.
tori paitan.review:
Without a doubt the best ramen I've had in San Francisco.  I'll be coming back again.

Food
First, the Tori Paitan Ramen, with double chasu.  The broth was incredibly thick, almost gravy like!  An immense amount of flavor in each spoonful and incredibly satisfying in both flavor and fullness.  Both the duck and the pork chashu melt in the mouth; the slow cooking of the meats allows the flavor to concentrate it and it stands out despite the incredibly flavorful broth.  The noodles themselves are thick and take on the flavors of the other ingredients, all while having a firm but easy to eat consistency.

Second, the Shio Ramen.  Being a shio ramen, the broth is much lighter, but with a much more intense salty flavor.  The initial taste of the soup can definitely taste a bit *too* salty, but it quickly passes by eating more.  The noodles here are much thinner, but it definitely compliments the lighter but more flavorful soup.  The chashu is once again fantastic, and the flavors of the meat stands out in the broth.

The other vegetables were incredibly fresh, which really adds to the complexity to the overall dish.  It's incredible how they packed so many different flavors into a single dish!  And as a personal preference, I hate when food gets cold too quickly, but the choice of dishware and freshness of the food kept everything hot!

Environment
It's very intimate seating, so bring a party or a friend!  The food is the main attraction of the restaurant, not the decor! Clean, average loudness, and the service was fantastic.

In short, if you like ramen, you'll love Mensho Tokyo!

excerpts: Only tried the Tori Paitan and Organic Shoyu so far.
The Tori Paitan has a really creamy and heavy broth with chewy noodles.
The toppings are plentiful and everything blended together really well.
Second time I tried the Organic Shoyu and it was ridiculously good.
Very well balanced and just the right amount of saltiness.
tori paitan.author: Lynn C.
tori paitan.review:
4.5 stars. Only tried the Tori Paitan and Organic Shoyu so far. The Tori Paitan has a really creamy and heavy broth with chewy noodles. The toppings are plentiful and everything blended together really well. It is heavy though, so I couldn't finish my bowl. 

Second time I tried the Organic Shoyu and it was ridiculously good. Very well balanced and just the right amount of saltiness. Some of my ramen noodles were clumped together into a ball, so I spent some time pulling them apart. 

Easily the best ramen in town. They will expand the menu to include Tonkotsu and Spicy Miso ramen in the near future. 

Get ready to line up for an hour or two any time of the day.

excerpts: We both ordered the Tori Paitan and loved it.
The soup is creamy and the noodles delicious on their own.
The meat is a little fatty but we were really enamoured with how good the soup was that we didn't really care.
tori paitan.author: Tim L.
tori paitan.review:
We came all the way from London to San Francisco to try out the ramen here in SF. Actually, no, we just happened to be in town visiting and my cousin had recommended this place. It was 9:00pm sharp, and we waited in line for about 45 minutes. However, the line is totally worth the wait. We both ordered the Tori Paitan and loved it. The soup is creamy and the noodles delicious on their own. The meat is a little fatty but we were really enamoured with how good the soup was that we didn't really care. However, it was hard to tell which was the duck and which was the pork. 

Slurptastic, service was much like it is in Tokyo, save the little coin vending machine at the entrance and J-pop blaring through the speakers. Man, I'm glad we had the chance to come here whilst we were on holiday.

excerpts:
Now I know you're going to order the tori paitan ramen which is their deservedly famous meaty dish with a chicken-ish broth, but let me also encourage you to order a couple other things:
- The vegan tantamen, which the chef recommended as his second choice, and which is an awesome, slightly nutty contrast with the tori paitan.
In fact, we kept alternating between the two because each one seemed to make the other one taste awesomer and each was awesome by itself.
- The oysters!

These had "shiyo oil" on them, which gave me flashback to the first time I had truffle oil: the first bite is a bit "unusual" or foreign, the second bite affirms that this foreign taste is actually good and fits in with other savory aromatic foods, and by the third bite you are ready to pay double the price just to have a little more.
Don't tell anyone

but I actually licked the oil off the mini plate after the oysters were gone.  
-
tori paitan.author: Aaron M.
tori paitan.review:
YUM - welcome Tokyo to SF!  Yes, this is the crazy thick broth ramen place that will change your life.  So do it.  Now I know you're going to order the tori paitan ramen which is their deservedly famous meaty dish with a chicken-ish broth, but let me also encourage you to order a couple other things:
- The vegan tantamen, which the chef recommended as his second choice, and which is an awesome, slightly nutty contrast with the tori paitan.  In fact, we kept alternating between the two because each one seemed to make the other one taste awesomer and each was awesome by itself.
- The oysters!  These had "shiyo oil" on them, which gave me flashback to the first time I had truffle oil: the first bite is a bit "unusual" or foreign, the second bite affirms that this foreign taste is actually good and fits in with other savory aromatic foods, and by the third bite you are ready to pay double the price just to have a little more.  Don't tell anyone but I actually licked the oil off the mini plate after the oysters were gone.  
- The Sansho beer, which is perhaps my favorite "herbal" beer ever - with a hint of Japanese peppercorn.  Disclosure: this beer is expensive as f*ck at over $1 per ounce.  Splurge and get two.

Out of curiosity we also ordered the $14 Shiyo ramen, which is listed on the receipt as "organic ramen."  OK to be honest, actually I wrote down "shiyo" based on phonetics but now that I look at their menu online, they have $14 "organic shoyu ramen" and $9 "shio ramen" so I'm not totally sure what we ordered.  Anyway, it was what thinner and what most people would probably recognize as "ramen."  Not as good as the others.  Still need to try the Shio... or Shoyu.

excerpts: Now about the food: I got the Tori Paitan with double chasu, which is the bowl that most people get and the most talked about.
It's pretty different from all the other ramen bowls that I've had.
The broth is really creamy, like creamy enough that my friends thought it was weird that I was drinking a lot of it once I finished the noodles.
tori paitan.author: Paul U.
tori paitan.review:
Heard that this place was new and had a long wait, so we came here around 9PM on a Wednesday. We still had to wait about an hour and 15 mins to get seated. Get ready to wait if you're coming here! There's a Redford bar and a liquor store across the street if you want to help make time go by faster. Someone would need to wait in line at the restaurant though.

The inside is pretty small. There were a few long tables and a table in the back that looked into the kitchen. The tables had baskets below them so you can put your bags. My huge Mission Workshop bag was able to fit in one of them.

Now about the food: I got the Tori Paitan with double chasu, which is the bowl that most people get and the most talked about. It's pretty different from all the other ramen bowls that I've had. The broth is really creamy, like creamy enough that my friends thought it was weird that I was drinking a lot of it once I finished the noodles. It's a pretty unique taste and I would definitely suggest trying it out, especially if you wait that long in line. 

Overall, the ramen here is unique and tasty but the long line may or may not be worth it, depending on how much you like ramen. 

Pros:
-Unique creamy ramen

Cons:
-Long wait to get seated
-Limited seating inside

excerpts: I had the Tori Paitan and it was thick and full of flavor.

Lastly, if you don't want to wait 1+ hour in line on Saturdays get there by 4:20 and you should be the first set of group to get seated.
Definitely worth going to.
Will be back many times even though I have to drive 1 hour.

tori paitan.author: Sylvia L.
tori paitan.review:
Finally made it out to Mensho. We wandered over Saturday night around 10ish - and were surprised that the line wasn't very long (probably around 20 minute wait). The noodles were very fresh-tasting and chewy. The broth (we ordered the tori paitan and the vegan) was thick and creamy. Tori paitan tasted full and meaty (even porky tasting) and vegan was very nutty with some spicy kick. 

Qualms are that the broth is a bit too over-the-top creamy (more of a noodly chowder than a ramen) and there's no egg option. Oh man an egg would have been awesome. Also, maybe I should get the shoyu (clear broth) option instead next time.

To be quite honest, I really enjoyed the meal but don't see myself coming back often. The wait in line isn't worth it to me and $18/bowl of ramen (I think our bill for two ramens and a tea was around $40) is a bit ludicrous, even for San Francisco.

All in all, a great place to have down the street!

excerpts: I ended up with the Tori Paitan, but for me it wasn't "blow me out of the water" amazing.
The broth was decent, definitely different, but didn't shock me
(I didn't end up finishing all the soup).
I felt that it was a little too rich for my tastes, so maybe next time I'll try a different one.
The meat was so-so: I didn't enjoy the regular pork chasau (it had a wine or alcoholic taste to it that didn't quite sit right with me), but I LOVED the duck chasau.
For my companion, it was the opposite, he loved the pork and hated the duck.
The one thing that made me really sad was the lack of soft-boiled egg.
For me, I love ramen for the soft-boiled egg, and was sad to see that they didn't have it :
[ I also think that the variety of the menu was a little disappointing.
I would like to see additional add on options, such as extra corn, extra broth, etc.
tori paitan.author: Li S.
tori paitan.review:
After going to a show, we ended up here on a Friday night around 10 PM. The line wasn't terribly long - but there was still about a 30 minute wait. Pro tip: If you're willing to dine alone, you can get a seat pretty quickly (I've noticed within 5-10 minutes tops). 

The Venue - 4/5
Definitely small, and communal. There aren't any individual tables, rather, you'll end up at a communal table that seats about 6 guests. I noticed that most people kept to themselves/the people they came with - but some people (generally the individual diners) would have a great conversation with the complete strangers that they sat next to. There isn't much wiggle room, but there's enough to not bump elbows with your neighbor. They provide a little basket under each pair of seats, meant for putting any belongings (bags/jackets etc) during your dining experience. The servers and staff seemed friendly, although when ordering, I felt that we were slightly rushed. 

The Food - 3/5
I wasn't a huge fan of the food. The ramen noodles seemed slightly undercooked (and different bowls had different types). I ended up with the Tori Paitan, but for me it wasn't "blow me out of the water" amazing. The broth was decent, definitely different, but didn't shock me (I didn't end up finishing all the soup). I felt that it was a little too rich for my tastes, so maybe next time I'll try a different one. The meat was so-so: I didn't enjoy the regular pork chasau (it had a wine or alcoholic taste to it that didn't quite sit right with me), but I LOVED the duck chasau. For my companion, it was the opposite, he loved the pork and hated the duck. The one thing that made me really sad was the lack of soft-boiled egg. For me, I love ramen for the soft-boiled egg, and was sad to see that they didn't have it :[ I also think that the variety of the menu was a little disappointing. I would like to see additional add on options, such as extra corn, extra broth, etc. Currently, they only have add extra types of chasau.

Overall - 3/5
I think this was definitely a place to try once, for the experience. Perhaps it's my particular taste preference, but I didn't love the ramen. It's very  bare minimum and focuses more on the particular broths. I would say try it to see if you like it, but I think it's more of a taste preference type of place. I would love to see more explanation of the different menu items (since they didn't really explain much), and more options for additional add-ons. I think this place definitely has potential, but still needs to work out the kinks before they get a higher rating for me. I'll probably try this place again in a few months or so, to see if they've improved.

excerpts: $16 Tori Paitan Ramen with super stingy toppings and super small portion noodles which I finished in less than 3mins, faster than it takes to make instant noodles.
$11.75 for Sansho "highway robbery" beer.
My total comes to $31.90 or $32 for noodles that are nothing special, especially for those who comes from East Asian countries.
The owner must be laughing all the way to the bank.
Ingredients cost $5 at most and was charged $32USD for a bowl of noodles and beer.
Only the dumbest people buy into the ramen hype.
This stuff is fast food in Japan and all over Asia, it's nothing special
but somehow there's a ramen craze in the West and
fast food chefs from East Asia are flocking over here like it's a gold rush to capitalize on the craze.
I feel like the biggest sucker for playing $32 for something that easily passes for $10 tops.
Ramen Yamadaya is still the best in SF, Ramen Dojo/Ramen Parlor (same owner) if you're in San Mateo.
Stay away from this place unless you're someone who likes hype, getting ripped off or being the best ramen sucker in the West.

excerpts: Their soup base tends to be on the richer side, especially Tori Paitan.
tori paitan.author: Alex T.
tori paitan.review:
I came here more than a dozen times already and I wanted to update my review.  

Their ramens, though expensive, is one of the best in the city.  Their soup base tends to be on the richer side, especially Tori Paitan.  If you want a lighter soup, go for the Shio Ramen.  Their noodles are pretty fresh and chewy, so no matter what you order, you can't go wrong.

Lines are usually pretty long especially during the weekends so the best time to go is before 7pm earlier during the work week where the lines tend to be the shortest.  If you are by yourself, your chances of jumping the lines are pretty high should they have a single spot open up.

Why 4 instead of 5 stars?  Sometimes service can be bad, but it has been steadily improving.  Also, $17.50-20+ is just a lot to pay for a ramen, even one as good as Mensho.

excerpts: Tori Paitan was the choice.
Thick and full of flavor.
The right amount of abura.
Noodle:
Usually in the USA you'll see the thin noodle more akin to Hakata style noodles.
Mensho uses thicker noodles more like ones you'll find in the Kanto region.
Makes for more al dente and it soaks up some of the soup.
Well worth a wait in my opinion!
Looking forward to their fuller menu to become available!

excerpts: We ordered tori paitan and the shoyu ramen with extra chasu for both.
The tori paitan was a really creamy, heavy broth.. perhaps, a bit too heavy for my liking.
It also had a duck flavor to it, which wasn't my favorite.
The shoyu ramen, on the other hand, was great.
Loved the lighter taste.
Plus, it was just the right amount of seasoning.
For both bowls of ramen, the noodle was pretty good and actually kind of reminded me of Chinese noodles a little.
tori paitan.author: Cassy H.
tori paitan.review:
I'm always on the look out for great ramen, so when I heard about Mensho Tokyo from a friend, I had to give it a try! 

Mensho opens at 5pm. When I arrived at 5:10pm, there was already a line of about 15 people! What is going on?! So it turns out according to the host.. that the chefs have requested to let in a few guests when the restaurant first opens so they can get the first orders out without it backing up orders in the kitchen. Anyway, my friend and I waited for about 30 mins and then were seated. It's a pretty small spot, so be prepared to wait now and in the foreseeable future. 

We ordered tori paitan and the shoyu ramen with extra chasu for both. The tori paitan was a really creamy, heavy broth.. perhaps, a bit too heavy for my liking. It also had a duck flavor to it, which wasn't my favorite. The shoyu ramen, on the other hand, was great. Loved the lighter taste. Plus, it was just the right amount of seasoning. For both bowls of ramen, the noodle was pretty good and actually kind of reminded me of Chinese noodles a little. The chasu was on point - pretty much melted in your mouth.

As for service, everyone was friendly and great. Pretty quick about getting the ramen out as well. Kudos and shoutout to the host, who was really friendly and cared about our dining experience.

I look forward to their full menu and would love to try their tonkotsu ramen. Until next time, Mensho!

(10/100)

excerpts: The name of the game is thick, THICK, rich broth if you get the classic Tori Paitan.
It's by far richer than Totto's, which kind of overdid it for me personally, but there's no denying that the ramen is still delicious.
tori paitan.author: Hope X.
tori paitan.review:
If you've ever been to Totto Ramen in NYC, this place will definitely ring some bells. The name of the game is thick, THICK, rich broth if you get the classic Tori Paitan. It's by far richer than Totto's, which kind of overdid it for me personally, but there's no denying that the ramen is still delicious. Just be warned that this is a very rich meal, and trying to drink all the broth along with your noodles is more ambitious than your average bowl of soup. 

My boyfriend has been here before when this place first opened, and he commented on how the slices of duck always seem raw and undercooked. This time, they were also a noticeably pink color, but we figured it was on purpose. Neither of us came down with any illnesses except the sheer distension of our very full stomachs afterwards.

excerpts: Once seated we ordered the oysters, shio chashyu and tori paitan.

The ramen was amazing!
Shio was light and sharp with a flatter noodle.
The tori was creamy, rich and had a round thicker noodle.

tori paitan.author: L L.
tori paitan.review:
We arrived to a line and waited one hour. The shop is small, but the line moves pretty quick. Once seated we ordered the oysters, shio chashyu and tori paitan. The oysters were good and helped ease our hunger pains while waiting for the ramen. The ramen was amazing! Shio was light and sharp with a flatter noodle. The tori was creamy, rich and had a round thicker noodle. They were both delicious and a nice compliment to each other. I would recommend getting both if you come with a friend. 

We have had ramen from coast to coast in the US and this is hands down the best we've had so far! We will be back next time we are in the Bay Area.

excerpts: I got the vegan tantanmen and she got the tori paitan.
Both were amazing!
The noodles had the right amount of density and chew  and the broth was rich and layered with flavor.
I particularly loved my vegan broth, which had some nice peanut and spicy notes.
The only warning I have is to come hungry so that you can finish the entire bowl.
The type I got was pretty rich and filling.
I can't wait to come back and try some of the other broths.
tori paitan.author: Bethany D.
tori paitan.review: Mensho serves some of the best ramen I've had in the Bay. My friend and I arrived around 10 on a Saturday, and the line actually moved pretty quickly. Once we got in, we were not disappointed. I got the vegan tantanmen and she got the tori paitan. Both were amazing! The noodles had the right amount of density and chew  and the broth was rich and layered with flavor. I particularly loved my vegan broth, which had some nice peanut and spicy notes. The only warning I have is to come hungry so that you can finish the entire bowl. The type I got was pretty rich and filling. I can't wait to come back and try some of the other broths.

excerpts: I ordered the Tori Paitan, which was $16, a bit on the pricey end that I am used to paying for ramen.
As soon as I took a sip of the broth, I couldn't help but smile.
tori paitan.author: Shirley L.
tori paitan.review:
...I think this may be the most delicious bowl of ramen I have ever had..and I will try my best, but I don't think my review will do it justice.

The wait: I got to Mensho around 6:30pm on a Wednesday night, and waited about 40 mins before getting a seat. I expect the wait for Fridays and weekends to be much longer, but I swear it is worth it. 

Inside: Mensho is a super small ramen shop, with a simple, clean cut themed interior design. Everything looked super clean and new. All white everything. 

Staff: Service was not extraordinary, but its more or less like a service you get at most authentic asian restaurants. The staff's priority is to get the line rolling but rotating people in an out as fast as possible. 

The Ramen: WAS UNBELIEVABLY AMAZING.

 I ordered the Tori Paitan, which was $16, a bit on the pricey end that I am used to paying for ramen. As soon as I took a sip of the broth, I couldn't help but smile. I was absolutely stunned by the richness and intense flavor of the ramen. 

It came with 2 small slivers of duck chashu and 1 ginormous sliver of pork chashu. The duck chashu was seasoned perfectly and tasted unique but delicious. The pork chashu was a bit fatty, but still flavorful. There was also a small bushel of kale and bamboo shoots. The noodles were thicker than most ramen shops I have been too (which I personally prefer) and had a little bounce to them. It was the perfect combination of chewiness and tenderness- perfect for slurping. Best of all was the broth- it was creamy, rich but not too heavy, and EXTREMELY flavorful. It tasted as if a chicken was used to make the first batch of broth, which was then boiled again with a fresh new chicken, but 10 times. Everything in the bowl came together perfectly. Although the portions may seem a bit small, the richness of the broth will make up for it. By the time I finished 3/4 of the ramen, the broth was getting a little bit overwhelming, but nevertheless I could not stop until I finished every last noodle in the bowl. So if you are worried that this bowl of ramen won't fill you, I promise that you will be A-OK. 

If you are looking to get your mind blown by a bowl of ramen, Mensho is the closest you will get to authentic Japanese ramen in the city.

JUST DO IT. NO REGRETS.

tori paitan.author: Danny G.
tori paitan.review:
As much as I hate waiting, I don't want to be the type who pays a TaskRabbit to stand in line on their behalf. Oh no, I've done [insert name of any place vaguely hipsterish in The Mission] the hard way. And probably complained about it, except on the rare occasion I thought it really worth the wait...

Step forward Mensho. Or rather, step forward imperceptibly slowly along a somewhat gritty stretch of Geary. I couldn't get Google Maps Popular Times to work for this place - probably because it's so new - but my suspicion is the chart would be solid blue lines i.e. constantly busy. Fortunately my friend lives right across the street and has been carefully monitoring the line on an almost constant basis. She should really set up a pay-per-view MenshoCam (TM) that integrates seamlessly with the Eater app. That'd help fund the $18 ramen addiction.

Utilizing our insider knowledge of line dynamics we seized our opportunity and the wait - thankfully - was only around 35-40 minutes. The weather wasn't terrible and we even made new acquaintances and exchanged ramen recos as we inched toward our supper. The space itself is tiny yet minimalist chic and, given the hype combined with limited capacity, it's easy to understand the long lines. The confusing thing was that the menu written on the wall doesn't correspond to what they actually sell so best not to pay attention to that.

My go-to in most noodle shops is the Tonkotsu Ramen which unfortunately Mensho doesn't yet offer, apparently they're still in the process of setting up the necessary equipment. Instead I went with the Tori Paitan, a recommendation from our line buddy, which was decent but not really my cup of soup. I kind of regretted not going with the Shoyu Ramen.

Overall I liked the experience and didn't so much mind the wait but can only really give 3 stars based on the food, which admittedly was largely down to my own rash selection. I'd like to come back and try the Shoyu Ramen, or ideally the Tonkotsu once they finally have that available, and will rate again. The only thing I would say is that there was no hot sauce or hot pepper available, and frankly I like a bit of heat in my ramen - I get that this is a purist type of place though. If you like that you might want to bring your own. Just saying.

As to whether it was worth the wait, I'd say yes in this case as a new experience but wouldn't want to wait close to 1 hour even once the menu is updated. I did try to come back a few weeks after my initial visit but the line was much longer than before so ended up elsewhere. I'm sure many devotees will continue to endure the long waits but, for those who love the ramen places down there, you'd probably be eating sooner if you drove all the way to Santa Clara. Or, you know, just have your TaskRabbit bring it to The Marina.

tori paitan.author: Sharie H.
tori paitan.review:
Came here on grand opening day and they have very few options of ramen to choose from. I'm a HUGE FAN of ramen. I hunt for ramen whenever I go travel. I've had ramen in Tokyo, NY, Hong Kong, and some other popular Bay Area ramen places, and I definitely will NOT say this is the best ramen place in even just SF. 

I got the Tori Paitan Ramen on this visit.
Broth:
The broth is favorable yet waayy too thick. it's prob the thickest broth I've had in my life. Don't get me wrong, I love thick broth in ramen but this one is just too much. It also left a strong residue on my throat, which made me drink tons of water afterwards. 

Noodle: 
I kind of felt like there's a sand-ish like texture on the ramen(probably due to the thickness of the broth). The noodle itself was too thick as well, feeling more like udon. 

Chashu:
I dont know if it's day 1 and they're unprepared, but the chashu I got is more than 70% fat. I like chashu with a bit of fat, but def not something like this. 

Overall, I would not go back again. 

Just as a reference, I love Ichiran Ramen the most. They're perfect in terms of broth, ramen, and chashu.

excerpts: $18 for the tori paitan ramen with double chashu is not a bad price for the city's dreadful prices.
tori paitan.author: Alex M.
tori paitan.review:
This is the best ramen you can get in San Francisco, probably the best in the city and East Bay. $18 for the tori paitan ramen with double chashu is not a bad price for the city's dreadful prices. 

This is just what you want in a bowl of ramen. Thick, rich, and flavorful broth that's not overwhelming. The handmade noodles were thick, delicious, and cooked just right. The chashu melted apart. Everything is made with care. It is all quality. That's what you want. All grievances can be boiled down to personal preference. They are serious about their ramen and the quality reflects this.

tori paitan.author: Howard K.
tori paitan.review:
Here are the longest lines known to man: the DMV, Disneyland's Space Mountain, Immigration line at the international airports, and Mensho's 5PM opening line on a saturday night. Seriously, how the hell do you expect me to wait 2 hours? We get it supply and demand. But there's something wrong when potential customers are leaving frustrated and hungry after waiting in line for an hour and not having move at all (not even an exaggeration). How my girlfriend and I managed is beyond me. You guys must enjoy the free advertisement from having people see other people wait in a line for your food, especially in that part of town. Don't worry! They have no name list and they don't have reservations, and they are not friendly to groups bigger than 3/4 people! So you can slave away and wait in a line for 2 hours to try something that I sincerely believe does not cost $18 a bowl. Ramen isn't supposed to be this expensive. 

I got the Tori Paitan with extra meat for $18. It was OK. Just OK.

All in all, was it worth the wait? No.
Was it worth the price? No.
Was it worth the experience of waiting in line for 2 hours in anticipation for the "best" ramen in SF? For some people yes; for me, paying $16/$18 for a bowl of ramen is more or less daylight robbery. But I get it supply and demand. Well after this review, your business will have one less person demanding this kind of food.

tori paitan.author: Sharon L.
tori paitan.review: After planning for weeks about the best time to come here, we finally decided to come here on a Tuesday evening at 5:15. There was (of course) already a line outside (presumably before they even opened). We waited around 45 minutes before being seated (party of 4), which was actually a lot faster than we expected. My boyfriend originally wanted to order Tonkotsu Ramen as it was one of the dish written on the wall, but apparently they're still doing a limited opening and Tonkotsu wasn't one of the dish we can order. We all opted to then get the Tori Paitan, which was what they're famous for. IMO the Tori Paitan is even more rich than Tonkotsu (it's basically a white thick chicken broth). So if you're not really into rich broth, opt for the Shoyu or Shio ramen (Shoyu, imo, is less rich compared to Shio). It was super delicious, comes with both duck and pork chashu (my boyfriend opted to get double chashu), and the noodle is pretty thick with a nice chewiness. One thing I hope they will add in the future would be an option for extra noodle. Is it the best ramen place in the bay? I personally still like Orenchi and Ramen Dojo/Parlor better, but it's definitely in the top 5 (especially if the wait isn't as long and they have a more extensive menu). I would come back again if the wait is under an hour, but overall, 5/5 in terms of food quality!

excerpts: My boyfriend had the tori paitan, their specialty ramen, which comes with both pork and duck chashu.

I'm hoping the lines start to dissipate because I'm dying to go back for the ramen here as it's definitely some of the best you can find in San Francisco!
tori paitan.author: Ashley T.
tori paitan.review: Mensho Tokyo is the newest ramen shop in SF, with lines out the door at least an hour before opening almost every night. My boyfriend and I got in line at around 4:45 PM on a Saturday, and waited almost an hour and half to get into the restaurant. We learned the story behind the store while talking to the owner, who is a Bay Area native and well-known ramen critic in Japan. For now, they only have a couple of their ramens on the menu and a oyster appetizer. I had the vegan tantanmen, which was one of the most flavorful vegan broths I've ever had. Made out of seven kinds of nuts, it had a hearty flavor and thick texture that was coated on each noodle just perfectly. The noodles themselves were some of the best I've had, both chewy and thick. I loved the additional toppings, from the menma to the edamame. My boyfriend had the tori paitan, their specialty ramen, which comes with both pork and duck chashu. Again, the broth had such well-developed flavor. I'm hoping the lines start to dissipate because I'm dying to go back for the ramen here as it's definitely some of the best you can find in San Francisco!

excerpts: I got the tori paitan ramen, which was amazing and well worth the wait.
tori paitan.author: J L.
tori paitan.review:
YUMMY! Came here on a Tuesday night at 8 and waited probably 40+ minutes to be seated. Definitely come early or be prepared to wait. Their turnover seems pretty fast, though. Once seated we were out the door within 30-40 minutes.

They mainly serve ramen, with a few additional snacks. I got the tori paitan ramen, which was amazing and well worth the wait. It was like drinking the most umami gravy, with perfectly cooked piping hot noodles and really flavorful toppings. 

I don't know if I would jump to wait in line again... but man that was some amazing ramen.

excerpts: I always get the tori paitan and it's always delicious.
What I like about this place is they seem to cook each ingredient in the ramen bowl separately so that each element is perfectly cooked.

The noodles have just the right level of firmness and springy quality, the chashu slices and duck slices are also cooked perfectly so the meat is melt-in-your mouth tender, each vegetable is the right texture.
If you need more spice, you can ask the wait staff for chili sauce or shichimi powder.
You can also order extra meat, extra egg, extra vegetables etc., for extra $.
The oysters are not worth ordering in my opinion.
They are tiny and hard and covered in a sweet sauce and taste like the kind of oysters you get out of a Chinese can.
Ambiance: you sit REALLY close to the people next to you and the seats are backless high stools.
In other words, stay home if you want to be comfortable.
Come to Mensho if you want to eat ridiculously good ramen!
tori paitan.author: Cat M.
tori paitan.review: I came here when it first opened and waited maybe...15 minutes? I tried again in April 2017, and the wait was much longer. At like 6:30 pm in the pouring rain and gusting wind the wait was an hour. Still, I don't mind the wait. I always get the tori paitan and it's always delicious. What I like about this place is they seem to cook each ingredient in the ramen bowl separately so that each element is perfectly cooked. The noodles have just the right level of firmness and springy quality, the chashu slices and duck slices are also cooked perfectly so the meat is melt-in-your mouth tender, each vegetable is the right texture. If you need more spice, you can ask the wait staff for chili sauce or shichimi powder. You can also order extra meat, extra egg, extra vegetables etc., for extra $. The oysters are not worth ordering in my opinion. They are tiny and hard and covered in a sweet sauce and taste like the kind of oysters you get out of a Chinese can. Ambiance: you sit REALLY close to the people next to you and the seats are backless high stools. In other words, stay home if you want to be comfortable. Come to Mensho if you want to eat ridiculously good ramen!

excerpts: tori paitan:
this was pretty tasty.
Rich, without being too heavy.
Garlic was yummy, but not overpowering.
The pork and duck chasu were really good; not sure I would pay $2 or $1.50 for an small extra slice of either though.
I liked the noodles in this one better than the other two.
I do think that overall, these aren't the best ramen noodles I've ever had.
I like mine with more bite/chew to them.
These noodles were maybe 1-2 mins too long.
Also, towards the middle to the end of the bowl, I got a lot of residue/grit/something.
I think they need to strain the broth a few more times to get rid of that stuff.
Too soggy and they were different than the tori paitan noodles and not springy at all.
tori paitan.author: Victoria S.
tori paitan.review:
I like it. Do I love it? Nah.  We waited an hour in the line. I don't think this is worth a 2-3 hour wait. So for those of you thinking about it; just wait until the hype dies down and they've worked out the kinks. 

For two of us (we needed to make it worth our while to wait):

1.) tori paitan:  this was pretty tasty. Rich, without being too heavy. Garlic was yummy, but not overpowering. The pork and duck chasu were really good; not sure I would pay $2 or $1.50 for an small extra slice of either though. I liked the noodles in this one better than the other two.  I do think that overall, these aren't the best ramen noodles I've ever had. I like mine with more bite/chew to them. These noodles were maybe 1-2 mins too long. Also, towards the middle to the end of the bowl, I got a lot of residue/grit/something. I think they need to strain the broth a few more times to get rid of that stuff. It was a bad way to end the bowl. 

2.) shoyu: this was my favorite bowl of the three. It had a nice subtle sweetness and was flavorful. The soup gave my mouth a nice coat, but it wasn't fatty or greasy. But, as mentioned above, I didn't love the actual ramen noodles. Too soggy and they were different than the tori paitan noodles and not springy at all. 

3.) shio:  this was was also nice. Good, clean flavor. I like the garlic in this, also. I probably won't remember this one in a month. 

4.) oysters:  pass. I've had better smoked ones from Whole Foods. 

Service was good; they are trying really hard. 

I think they need to construct the table to be more stabilized. Every time some sat down and leaned on the table, it would knock the other end of the table. Could be hazardous with molten bowls of porky soup. 

The lines for this place tells me that SF is in dire need for some great, not good ramen.  Maybe we can send some of our good LA ramen juju up north.

excerpts: I got the tori paitan & my bf got the shoyu ramen.

Still really delicious, rich, & flavorful, though!
The pork was perfectly fatty & pretty much broke apart as soon as you touched it.
The noodles are perfectly QQ!
I think overall I liked the shoyu broth more because it's more clear/less heavy.
Was it worth the $16 & the wait?
I would say yes, because I heard about this place for so long & didn't feel disappointed.
If I lived nearby, it definitely wouldn't be my monthly or even bimonthly ramen place (who wants to wait that long all the time?
then again, it is SF)

excerpts: I ordered the Tori Paitan ramen with double chashu.
Long story short

The broth, while very flavorful, had an overly rich taste and was just a bit too salty to be enjoyable.
It was also very opaque, so you couldn't quite see what else was in your bowl without having to fish around in it.
The noodles though were actually tasty, and had a nice texture and bite...slightly reminiscent of an udon noodle, but not as thick.
Overall, too much for me to handle after more than just a few bites.
tori paitan.author: Daniel H.
tori paitan.review:
I was truly excited as I waited in line to try the ramen here, and got here with my friend a full 45 minutes to wait before the restaurant opened (we were not even the first party to arrive!). Luckily, we made the first seating though! 

Food: My rating for this place ultimately comes down to the food. I ordered the Tori Paitan ramen with double chashu. Long story short, I was just not impressed and this type of ramen is just not to my liking. The broth, while very flavorful, had an overly rich taste and was just a bit too salty to be enjoyable. It was also very opaque, so you couldn't quite see what else was in your bowl without having to fish around in it. The noodles though were actually tasty, and had a nice texture and bite...slightly reminiscent of an udon noodle, but not as thick. Overall, too much for me to handle after more than just a few bites. I was actually sad that they do not have to go boxes since this was way too much for me to handle in one sitting. 

Service: The people here are welcoming and friendly, especially since the location is quite small. I never found it difficult to let someone know if I needed anything like a water refill or the bill. The one issue that my party had was communicating with some of the people here when we had questions. I had a difficult time understanding them, so at some points I just nodded my head in agreement. 

Atmosphere: The restaurant is tiny on the inside and seating is done on communal tables (so you might not know who is across or to the left or right of you). I didn't mind so it was not too much of an issue. I do wish that there were other seating options besides stools, especially after waiting outside for so long. It would have been nice to have some back support to make the dining experience more comfortable (though I do understand the stools for aesthetic purposes). There are also baskets under each table for you to store your things, which are convenient too. This location also has just one bathroom, which had an unusual odor to it, but since it's located so close to the dining and kitchen area, there was not an opportunity to properly air it out. Better ventilation in the dining room would have also been appreciated because the aroma of the rich flavored food was a bit intense at times. 

If the hype ever dies down, I might come back here and try another noodle option, but based on my first experience I am in certainly no rush. I wish they took to-go orders (or at least a boxing option), but perhaps that's an area they can get into once their business starts to grow. I would also like to see them adopt a sign in system either manually or through an app instead of just having people wait in a long line. This would give people some mobility instead of having to wait outside until room clears up for dining.

excerpts: The Tori Paitan was incredibly rich, with thicker noodles.
The chashu literally melts in your mouth, and combined with the creamy broth delivered a monster umami punch.
The broth itself definitely rivals most tonkotsu's
I've had in terms of richness.
The fact that it was so robust without being very oily was a huge plus too.

The duck was a bit cool

tori paitan.author: Sebastian A.
tori paitan.review:
The Wait: Not nearly as bad as we thought it would be. Got in line about 9:15PM on a Saturday and we were seated shortly before 10PM. The staff is very efficient so tables flip quickly. 

The Dining Room: 28 seats, all community style tables. A little tight, but we didn't even notice once the food arrived because our faces were glued to our bowls the rest of the night. Simple and clean design with cool lighting. 

The Food: The Tori Paitan was incredibly rich, with thicker noodles. The chashu literally melts in your mouth, and combined with the creamy broth delivered a monster umami punch. The broth itself definitely rivals most tonkotsu's I've had in terms of richness. The fact that it was so robust without being very oily was a huge plus too. The chashu is literally the best I've ever had, and I'm definitely adding a few extra pieces next time I go. The duck was a bit cool and I probably would've preferred it a little more done, but the texture balanced with everything else in the bowl. No eggs available which I thought was a bit odd, but it was rich enough even without it.

Bottom Line: Best ramen I've had in the city. Totally worth the wait and price. If you're like me and were let down by the new Orenchi and Ramen Bar, you'll be relieved to know Mensho hit a home run here. My go to ramen place from now on!

Old review:
So I am giving the place 5 because they do a really good job at what they do even though it isn't my new favorite ramen place.
So, I sat a the "bar", four seats, 3 lefties?
Solo, male, left-handed, "sit here so you can crowd each other and not knock elbows with the righties".
The good thing was that I got to watch the "ramen magic" happen.

For someone who spent many years working in restaurants, and had way too many opportunities too watch people cook, as well as the ongoing dreams of people cooking in slow motion, got to admit I still love to watch.
Wow, are those chunks of lard they are adding?
I guess so
, that is pretty much what paitan is, tasty liquid lard.
Slightly disconcerting, but then why boil those pig ankles for hours if not to extract delicious components.
And, it is delicious, can't speak for the paitan since I had spicy miso ramen, but it was certainly delicious.
Maybe a little too "kotteri" for my taste.
I used to get a magazine called "Lucky Peach", not sure if it still exists, but it was kind of interesting.
The first issue was all about ramen, and they included some recipes (which had some major mistakes, still want to spit thinking about the alkali soap noodles I made).
This cat Chang, I think his name is, has some hot ramen place in NYC, and was "sharing" his secrets, or trying to poison the unsuspecting.
He used Benton bacon instead of katsuobushi, and if you have ever tried this stuff, the bacon I mean, it tastes like it was smoked over truck tires.
It is industrial strength.
So my point is....
Mensho is kinda an industrial strength ramen, lots of flavor, intense, delicious, perfectly prepared, just not my style.
I think the phrase "it is the Mission Chinese of ramen" kind of sums it up.
Or as an old "Was, Not Was" song said...
Love how hard the kitchen works to prepare a delicious and beautiful bowl.

He used Benton bacon instead of katsuobushi, and if you have ever tried this stuff, the bacon I mean, it tastes like it was smoked over truck tires. It is industrial strength. So my point is....
Mensho is kinda an industrial strength ramen, lots of flavor, intense, delicious, perfectly prepared, just not my style. I think the phrase "it is the Mission Chinese of ramen" kind of sums it up. Or as an old "Was, Not Was" song said...
Love how hard the kitchen works to prepare a delicious and beautiful bowl.

tori paitan.author: Amy K.
tori paitan.review:
We walked by late on a Friday night, and as we looked in the large windows, a passerby told us that it's the best ramen in SF, so we decided to check it out the next day. We got in line about 7 pm on a Saturday night, and the line seemed to move reasonably fast. For a party of 2, we waited about 40 minutes. 

The restaurant is clean and bright, with a semi-open kitchen. Unless you have a party of 6, you are going to be sharing a table, but it was spacious enough that it didn't feel crowded. If you want the miso ramen, show up early because they only have 30 bowls a day. We ended up with the shoyu and tori paitan, both had very flavorful broths and distinct flavors. The chasu was good, I preferred the pork over the duck. Overall, the ramen was good, but not so crave-worthy that I'd regularly wait in line for an hour.

excerpts: My bf got the Tori Paitan Ramen and I got the Vegan Tantanmen.

And the noodles were cooked so perfect.

the tori paitan was good, a very creamy and strong broth, could fill up the stomach very quickly.

excerpts: I had the Tori Paitan ramen and really enjoyed it.
It was very creamy and flavorful, enjoyed every last bit.
The staff was really friendly and served us as soon as we got seated.
I learned that the chefs came straight from Japan so the ramen is as authentic as it gets.
The place is pretty small though, seats maybe 25 people max and we did wait for awhile to get seated but they're utilizing the resources they have the best they can.
I stood in line around 5pm, about the time that they open, and took us about 2.5 hours to seat our group of 5 people so expect to wait.
So if you don't mind waiting a long time and want to try a good ramen, this is the place!

excerpts: I tried the Tori Paitan Ramen and this broth is arguably the thickest, richest, creamiest non-tsukemen broth I've ever had.
tori paitan.author: Hamlet A.
tori paitan.review:
I've been to most of the most highly regarded ramen places in the Bay Area and LA. This is easily one of the best ramen places I've ever been to. I tried the Tori Paitan Ramen and this broth is arguably the thickest, richest, creamiest non-tsukemen broth I've ever had. And it was delicious.

I also tried the Vegan Tantamen, which had so much rich flavor that I think it may have been the best Vegan food I've ever had. It was like a rainbow of flavor dancing around my taste buds. 

The only downside was they didn't have a tonkotsu ramen or tsukemen available yet. Waiting for that to happen. Oh, the line wasn't too bad when we got there, but I could see people waiting for a while. My fear is that this place gets too popular that the lines stretch forever. There isn't a lot of seating room.

excerpts: Tori paitan broth was deliciously creamy, combined slow braised chashu/wonderfully tender rarer, wasn't too oily, but did lack a soft boiled egg.
tori paitan.author: Alex L.
tori paitan.review: Food came out at different times, water from previous patrons wasn't cleared, preferencial treatment given to surrounding tables/no recommendations made on food or drink, older woman/hostess and young male host snubbed us throughout meal. For a place that seats 24ish people you would think they would have a full set of silverware and not a hodge podge of bowls/spoons. The place is small and seems very intentionally designed to maximize the use of the space. Servers were very nice, apologetic, and easy to flag down. Long wait time, but that's to be expected given the hype around this restaurant and the multiple delays in its initial open. Tori paitan broth was deliciously creamy, combined slow braised chashu/wonderfully tender rarer, wasn't too oily, but did lack a soft boiled egg.

excerpts: Two friends ordered the tori paitan, which is their richest, creamiest option.
tori paitan.author: Jules G.
tori paitan.review:
My friends and I were here on a misty Friday evening. We arrived before 5:30 pm and there was already a long line. Be ready for a really long wait! If you're super hungry, you may want to bring snacks. The group behind us left to buy snacks at some point. Our party of four were finally seated a little after 7:30 pm. Thankfully our bowls of deliciousness were quick to arrive after we'd ordered.

Was it worth the wait? It certainly was! Two friends ordered the tori paitan, which is their richest, creamiest option. One friend ordered the vegan tantanmen, which I loved and attempted to switch with my own bowl of ramen. I ordered the organic shoyu ramen; it was slightly lighter but just as flavorful. They're all good; it just depends on personal preferences.

They currently don't serve eggs in their ramen. We asked the staff and they mentioned they're carefully selecting a type of egg that is equivalent to those in Japan. It's nice to know they're so particular about their ingredients.

I would definitely return but I wouldn't wait over two hours again.

excerpts: I would suggest getting the Tori Paitan ramen for first timers.
tori paitan.author: Andrew W.
tori paitan.review:
By far the best ramen shop in San Francisco. Absolutely worth the 1-2 hour wait; the trick is to go at opening or at closing for shorter wait times. I would suggest getting the Tori Paitan ramen for first timers. The soup is extremely rich and creamy, and the pork + duck slices are among the best I've had.

The head chef and owners are extremely knowledgeable about their ramen (one of them has been to over 1,500 different ramen shops in Japan as a professional ramen taster). In fact, they have even refused to add eggs to their ramen until they've found a perfect source in California. Just goes to show how much they care about their craftsmanship. I hope they eventually expand to other locations in the Bay!

excerpts: it was hands down better than any ramen bowl I've ever eaten get the tori paitan it was honestly perfect
tori paitan.author: Dylan G.
tori paitan.review: Waited an hour and a half and couldn't possibly be happier the owner was very helpful with his descriptions and ramen knowledge it was hands down better than any ramen bowl I've ever eaten get the tori paitan it was honestly perfect

excerpts: Also tried the tori paitan ramen and highly recommend!

tori paitan.author: Sri S.
tori paitan.review: After Ramen Underground got rid of their tomato ramen, this is my new favorite! It's much better - creamier broth and thick noodles. I had the vegan tantanmen and I liked it! Also tried the tori paitan ramen and highly recommend! Took us an hour to get seated on a Friday at 6:15 pm.

excerpts: I got the tori paitan ramen and I was bummed that they didn't have a tonkotsu, but then this magical bowl was placed before me and it was truly the best thing that's ever happened to me.
I've never had something so flavorful, thick and creamy as this ramen
YOU GUYS!
I cannot rave about this ramen a lot.
Like I said, the vocabulary hasn't been invented yet.
All I can say is, I'd wait in a 2 hour long line every day if I had to to get to taste this ramen again and again and again...
tori paitan.author: Shayan S.
tori paitan.review: There isn't a word yet for how delicious this ramen is.  This ramen TAKES THE CAKE. Hands down & no way around it. I was eyeing this spot for a long time, and would always see a long line of people out in the front. So one gloomy sf day I braved the line, which ended up moving very quickly to my surprise. Super small spot, very cozy, cool interior, with high tables & stools with wooden boxes below for storing your purses/coats in which I really liked so nothing was hanging or bumping into your legs while you ate. Mensho Tokyo is not  traditional style ramen, it's a little more inventive and "cutting edge" in terms of the ingredients and the style...I THINK. I admit I'm basing this statement off of what I've seen at other ramen restaurants around the Bay Area and Mensho doesn't really have most of the usual items you'd expect. I got the tori paitan ramen and I was bummed that they didn't have a tonkotsu, but then this magical bowl was placed before me and it was truly the best thing that's ever happened to me. I've never had something so flavorful, thick and creamy as this ramen YOU GUYS! I cannot rave about this ramen a lot. Like I said, the vocabulary hasn't been invented yet. All I can say is, I'd wait in a 2 hour long line every day if I had to to get to taste this ramen again and again and again...

We are looking forward to visiting more in the coming months when their currently limited menu is expected to expand.

tori paitan ramen.author: Dave S.
tori paitan ramen.review:
I stopped by on a Friday night around 8:30 pm and there were about 20 people in front of me in line. They do not take reservations and the seating inside is limited to about 25-30 and it is also communal seating. Since I came by myself, the server was able to offer me a single seat at the bar after waiting about 30 minutes. The bar seating overlooks the kitchen. 

After being seated the server came over quickly and I went ahead and ordered the Tori Paitan Ramen with a soft boil egg. The service was very efficient and friendly. The ramen was also brought out quickly. The broth was very rich and flavorful and the meat was tender. However, the egg was sweeter than I expected and closer to hard boiled than soft.    

They also charge a mandatory 15% service fee into the bill and they don't have any take out containers but you can bring your own. I would not recommend coming with a large group of friends and be expected to wait no matter when you come.

excerpts: Being our initial visit, the four of us agreed to go with the Tori Paitan ramen noodle soup.
Three of us went with the original, while my hubby had the spicy version.
That was the essence of our Tori Paitan.
Thick ramen noodles and great presentation.
tori paitan ramen.author: Shirley N.
tori paitan ramen.review:
We've been back from Japan about six months now.  Upon our return we stated we planned to try local ramen places.  So far this is just our 2nd place.  But definitely a winner!!!

We knew to come early before the restaurant opened at 5pm to secure first seating.  We arrived around 4:30pm on a Friday night, and already six people in line.  

Being our initial visit, the four of us agreed to go with the Tori Paitan ramen noodle soup.  Three of us went with the original, while my hubby had the spicy version.  We ordered imported Japanese beer to pair with our noodles.

The chicken soup broth was very flavorful.  That was the essence of our Tori Paitan.  Thick ramen noodles and great presentation.  Just the right amount of toppings.

We got the only 4 seats with chair backing.  Else you sit at one of two communal tables on high bar stools.

Service was quick and efficient.  We were in & out within the hour.

We've only been to two ramen shops in six months; however this one will be hard to beat.

excerpts: I am just okay with their best seller, Tori Paitan ramen.
tori paitan ramen.author: Shannen B.
tori paitan ramen.review:
Crazy about the Abura Soba here. The richness of the flavor is definitely enhanced by making the noodles "dry". It kind of reminds me of the dry saucy noodles I have back home in Indonesia, called Bakmi Ayam (Chicken Noodle). They give you a bottle of chili oil and a bottle of vinegar so you're able to adjust the amount of chili oil and vinegar for your noodles yourself. The noodles here are thick and chewy, just the way I like them. 

I am just okay with their best seller, Tori Paitan ramen. It's a little too heavy for me, but a lot of people like it. 

The restaurant is pretty tiny, so always expect a line, even on a weekday. The line is worth the wait, but honestly, try coming at around 4.40 to get first seating. They don't have any to-go boxes, so bring your own if you think you're not gonna finish the whole bowl, but honestly, you wouldn't be able to resist finishing the whole thing!
