tori paitan ramen.author: Jean S.
tori paitan ramen.review:
Wow! Best Ramen I've had! Mensho's Tori Paitan Ramen (double chashu) ($18) was super amazing and full of delicious umami flavor! The broth was very rich and creamy, but the flavors were SO tasty, I could not stop drinking. The noodles were cooked to a perfect texture, the bamboo shoots and kale were a nice touch, but what was the crown on top was the EXTREMELY TENDER and flavorful chashu. Both the pork chashu and duck chashu were out-of-this-world amazing! Definitely the best I've had in any ramen bowl. I only wish there were more pieces.  

In addition to the tori paitan broth, Mensho also offers organic shoyu, shio, and a vegan tantanmen. The shoyu and shio broths are lighter and not as creamy, which might be good for those looking for something not as heavy. (But why come all the way out here, wait in an excruciatingly long line, and not get the best?) I also tried the oysters in shoyu dare oil ($5), which were not bad. The menu states 4 pieces...they gave us 6, but they were very small and not plated very nicely. 

Mensho Tokyo is one of Japan's most acclaimed ramen bars, and this very location in SF's Tenderloin district, is their first international shop outside of Japan. This location has been open for over a year now, but the long wait is still there. I came late Saturday evening (10:15pm) trying to avoid the long line, but it wasn't late enough. I still had to wait 45 minutes (only!?) and didn't get seated till just after 11:00pm. (They close at 11:30pm and there were people being seated all the way to the end.) I hate long waits, but the tori paitan ramen was well worth the travel out and 45 minute wait. On a positive side note, the restaurant was clean, the bathroom was clean, and their food safety score is 100.

excerpts: I was adventurous and ordered the Matcha Tori Paitan Ramen.
Given that I'm a fan of matcha everything, my opinion can be a little biased, but I found the matcha ramen very delicious!
tori paitan ramen.author: Iris K.
tori paitan ramen.review:
I was adventurous and ordered the Matcha Tori Paitan Ramen. Given that I'm a fan of matcha everything, my opinion can be a little biased, but I found the matcha ramen very delicious! The matcha flavor offset the rich creaminess in the soup base somewhat, which tasted refreshing to me.

Getting there before the restaurant opens seems to help reduce the wait time - I was able to get in within about 35 minutes in line. Wish the would consider opening for lunch!

excerpts: I got the spicy tori paitan ramen with the spicy stuff on the side -
I wanted it on the side
so I could taste the soup in its original form.
I forgot to ask for no bamboo.
The noodles also took their sweet time to come out, but I know they were getting freshly cooked since I had a seat that was right in front of the kitchen.
They have timers to tell the noodle person when to take the noodles out!
Amazing.
I waited at least ten minutes for my noodles to get served, but it was piping hot when it did and the spicy chili flakes and the jalapeno miso sauces were on the side.
The soup was quite thick but not overpowering, and it was pretty good.
I REALLY liked the jalapeno miso sauce.
It was very flavorful and had a nice kick.
I ended up using most of it in my soup and the chili flakes were more for show than anything else; they didn't taste spicy.
I also really enjoyed the noodles; they were really chewy and thick, and they're probably one of my personal favorite ramen noodles I've had.
I ate my noodles in about ten minutes though I did try really hard not to eat them too fast so as to enjoy them.
I ate everything in my bowl except the bamboo.
Oh also the one thick slice of chasu I got: very flavorful and a good amount of meat (versus fat).
There were also fried onions which added an extra fragrant flavor and pieces of cabbage which added texture and a break from the thick broth.
At the high price of $20.99 including tax and mandatory 15% tip, I definitely expected more than one measly piece of meat.
Also no egg?!
The service was pretty good as the waitresses were all quite friendly (note: why is everyone serving the food a female and all the cooks male?).
Good portion of noodles though.
Please get your wasting-time-in-mandatory-line policy changed.
tori paitan ramen.author: Andrea W.
tori paitan ramen.review:
Let me first preface my review by saying I really don't understand why this place forces you to wait outside its door in a line. Why not give out numbers? Customers literally cannot go do something else while waiting, and it's a big time waste. Why force wasting of (a LOT of people's) time? To prove what, exactly? I'm fine with waiting, but I'm not fine with a restaurant being so arrogant to force its customers to mandatorily wait in a line. The only reasons I can think of for this is: a) marketing - if there's a lot of people waiting, it must be good so let's convince even more people to waste their time to wait in line to eat at this place! and b) efficiency - if people are readily available, the restaurant can immediately seat people when a table clears out. Reason a is just selfish. Reason b can be solved by warning customers that if they're not there when they're called, they will be skipped over/crossed out. Or better yet, they can actually invest in a good technology system of calling/texting people. A bunch of restaurants have this, and I very much appreciate places that do. PLEASE change your must-wait-in-line policy. It's just selfish, arrogant, and wastes a LOT of people's time. Making people sign in on a sheet of paper or with one of the waiters/waitresses is fine; don't have to get all fancy with technology. But please think about your customers.
I waited in line for about 25 minutes on a Wednesday evening; I got into line at 5:45PM and got seated at 6:10PM. I was handed a menu and my order was taken shortly after. I got the spicy tori paitan ramen with the spicy stuff on the side - I wanted it on the side so I could taste the soup in its original form. I forgot to ask for no bamboo. The noodles also took their sweet time to come out, but I know they were getting freshly cooked since I had a seat that was right in front of the kitchen. They have timers to tell the noodle person when to take the noodles out! Amazing. I waited at least ten minutes for my noodles to get served, but it was piping hot when it did and the spicy chili flakes and the jalapeno miso sauces were on the side. The soup was quite thick but not overpowering, and it was pretty good. I REALLY liked the jalapeno miso sauce. It was very flavorful and had a nice kick. I ended up using most of it in my soup and the chili flakes were more for show than anything else; they didn't taste spicy. I also really enjoyed the noodles; they were really chewy and thick, and they're probably one of my personal favorite ramen noodles I've had. I ate my noodles in about ten minutes though I did try really hard not to eat them too fast so as to enjoy them. I ate everything in my bowl except the bamboo. Oh also the one thick slice of chasu I got: very flavorful and a good amount of meat (versus fat). There were also fried onions which added an extra fragrant flavor and pieces of cabbage which added texture and a break from the thick broth. 
At the high price of $20.99 including tax and mandatory 15% tip, I definitely expected more than one measly piece of meat. Also no egg?! The service was pretty good as the waitresses were all quite friendly (note: why is everyone serving the food a female and all the cooks male?). Good portion of noodles though.
Please get your wasting-time-in-mandatory-line policy changed.

excerpts: We got the spicy Tori Paitan ramen which was good but a bit too rich/heavy and not what I expected.
When they advertise rich and creamy broth that is what you get.
We didn't realize the Spicy Tori Paitan didn't come with duck but I tried some from another friend's bowl.
It was delicious and served medium rare.
They do their meats right here!
tori paitan ramen.author: Jeanne L.
tori paitan ramen.review:
3.5 stars but I'm rounding up for the unique experience.

Get here at least 40 minutes early to get first round seating otherwise you'll wait 1 hour before you get seated. The staff was quick and efficient and the restaurant is fairly small. They offer a modern, trendy ambiance and play R&B music. 

We got the spicy Tori Paitan ramen which was good but a bit too rich/heavy and not what I expected. When they advertise rich and creamy broth that is what you get. The broth is thick like gravy so if you were expecting a cleaner broth you'll be disappointed. 

The meat was amazing and it melts in your mouth! We didn't realize the Spicy Tori Paitan didn't come with duck but I tried some from another friend's bowl. It was delicious and served medium rare. They do their meats right here! You can also order side meats for added protein. 

The enoki chips were yummy and perfectly crispy. The oysters on the other hand are too salty for my palate and 1 order was really enough but we ordered 2 for 5 people. 

Overall, I thought Mensho was good and offered a unique experience for your taste buds but I much prefer Ramen Parlor and Ramen Dojo but the ambiance at Mensho is so much cooler!

excerpts: I ordered the Tori Paitan Ramen that way with a single Chashu and extra firm noodles.
It was perfection!
I really loved the duck and the kale in this Ramen.
The only thing I wasn't a fan of was the crispy burdock root fries which quickly became soggy.
tori paitan ramen.author: Khamis H.
tori paitan ramen.review: Turns out you can get any of their Ramen broths made to order without MSG! I ordered the Tori Paitan Ramen that way with a single Chashu and extra firm noodles. It was perfection! I really loved the duck and the kale in this Ramen. The only thing I wasn't a fan of was the crispy burdock root fries which quickly became soggy.

excerpts: Tori paitan ramen - one of the best I've ever had.
Worth the hour plus wait.
Matcha (green tea) in tori paitan is interesting; Worth trying for novelty.
Sushi bowls are forgettable.
tori paitan ramen.author: Billy D.
tori paitan ramen.review:
Tori paitan ramen - one of the best I've ever had. Worth the hour plus wait. 
RamenRating overall 5/5:

Noodles 4/5
Broth 5/5 - so creamy; so tasty, so perfect. This is not your mana's chicken broth
Chashu 4/5 - yummy duck
Toppings 5/5 - Egg with runny yolk, other good toppings
Spicyiness - not spicy and that's perfect for this bowl. Don't bother with spicy. 
Value 4/5 - $17 for a medium sized portion

Other mentions:
Lamb ramen is great.
Matcha (green tea) in tori paitan is interesting; Worth trying for novelty. 
Sushi bowls are forgettable.

excerpts:
Tori Paitan Ramen, Double Chashu ($18) - 5 stars
Mensho's signature dish is the Bay Area's best rendition of the classic tori paitan.
The chicken broth was rich and creamy as it should be.
The chashu was so tender that even chopsticks could easily tear it apart.
The noodles were cooked al dente and had a great bite to them.
tori paitan ramen.author: Miko B.

excerpts: We both ordered the tori paitan ramen, which costs $16 per bowl.
While that may seem pretty expensive for ramen, I feel that it's justified.
tori paitan ramen.author: Trang T.
tori paitan ramen.review:
I came here with a friend around 8:30pm on a Friday and finally got seated at around 9:25pm. Yep, a pretty long wait. We both ordered the tori paitan ramen, which costs $16 per bowl. While that may seem pretty expensive for ramen, I feel that it's justified. You get a pretty big serving of chewy noodles, a heap of burdock roots, and some slices of chashu and duck.

Mensho is so different from other ramen joints because they specialize in a very thick chicken based broth. While everyone raves about it, I couldn't find myself enjoying it that much. It left a very grainy texture in my mouth. The chashu, noodles, and burdock were much more enjoyable. Ramen restaurants rely mostly on their broth so while Mensho's broth is super unique, it didn't have enough of an interesting flavor to amaze me.

excerpts: This is where Mensho Tokyo comes in with their Tori Paitan ramen, which had an incredibly rich and thicker broth than most of what you'd find in the Bay.
It's very good
and I was impressed.
I also enjoyed the noodles here, they were pretty al dente which I usually prefer.
The toppings were also great.
While there wasn't much of it, the duck is worth a try!
Also be sure to get the enoki mushroom chips if you're a fan of the stuff.
tori paitan ramen.author: Bryson L.
tori paitan ramen.review:
I can see why San Francisco would be going crazy for this place.  Coming from Hawaii, I've had a variety of ramen styles, but the Bay Area seems mostly dominated by Tonkatsu style ramen.  This is where Mensho Tokyo comes in with their Tori Paitan ramen, which had an incredibly rich and thicker broth than most of what you'd find in the Bay.  It's very good and I was impressed.  I also enjoyed the noodles here, they were pretty al dente which I usually prefer.  The toppings were also great.  While there wasn't much of it, the duck is worth a try!  Also be sure to get the enoki mushroom chips if you're a fan of the stuff.  They're really good with the chili flakes and the lemon, perfect appetizer.  

As for the wait, we got there around 5pm on a Saturday and ended up making it in the second rotation.  It took under an hour.  The restaurant itself is small so you'll be sitting on communal tables here, just fyi.

excerpts: Tried the Tori Paitan Ramen....
Flavorful and creamy broth.
The combo with the pork and duck chashu was so good!
tori paitan ramen.author: Hiedie S.
tori paitan ramen.review:
Found this place after going to a concert in SF. It was near by and we decide to try it. There wasn't a line just 1 party ahead of us. Apparently during the day there's a long line.

Tried the Tori Paitan Ramen.... Flavorful and creamy broth. The combo with the pork and duck chashu was so good! The Duck chashu has a citrus and tangy hint to it and it tasted delicious with the broth. 

Service was good! It's a small place and seating is communal. The tables have a little area where you can place small belongings. Underneath there are baskets where you can place larger items like purses and backpacks.

excerpts: I got the Spicy Tori Paitan ramen.
The flavor is just okay - the broth is super thick and the noodles are also super thick.
I guess I'm just not a fan of this style of ramen and I will not be back.
Orenchi still remains my favorite ramen in the bay area.
tori paitan ramen.author: Jenann P.
tori paitan ramen.review:
After seeing the long line outside of this place for over a year, I decided to try it out on a weekend. We got there right when it opened (5pm) and waited for an hour.

I got the Spicy Tori Paitan ramen. The flavor is just okay - the broth is super thick and the noodles are also super thick. I guess I'm just not a fan of this style of ramen and I will not be back. Orenchi still remains my favorite ramen in the bay area.

excerpts: I got the tori paitan ramen because it was the closest thing to my traditional creamy ramen I would always get in Tokyo.
The broth was good, but a tad too salty for what I am used to.
If you want your egg it is an up charge.
The noodle was what ruined the experience.
All the ramen place I had in Japan had this soft yet bouncy texture to their noodles which were all made from scratch.
Here I got this thick and undercooked doughy noodle, nothing that reminded me of Japan.
tori paitan ramen.author: Diana N.
tori paitan ramen.review:
I personally think this place is overrated. I guess the idea of this place is to be much like ramen shops in Japan. The plus was no tipping (which is offensive to do so in Japan), especially when it's is one of the more expensive ramen places in SF. 
I got the tori paitan ramen because it was the closest thing to my traditional creamy ramen I would always get in Tokyo. The broth was good, but a tad too salty for what I am used to. If you want your egg it is an up charge. The noodle was what ruined the experience. All the ramen place I had in Japan had this soft yet bouncy texture to their noodles which were all made from scratch. Here I got this thick and undercooked doughy noodle, nothing that reminded me of Japan. 
My friend got the shio ramen and didn't feel it was any more special than other ramen places around.
We won't be making our way back considering the price, and the not so great area that it located in as well.

excerpts: Tori Paitan Ramen soup was rich and creamy.
Noodles were soft and tender, but they weren't made onsite.
Duck and pork charsu were succulent and not super fatty.
Dried mushrooms and seaweed were standard ramen items.
Kale in the ramen is an odd combination and just added color.
tori paitan ramen.author: Elmo ..
tori paitan ramen.review:
On Friday, 12/22, I got in line at 420p and there were already 20+ people in line for 31 seats (4+12+7+8).  I got in the 1st wave of seating with 2 seats to spare which they never filled up for some unknown reason.  At 5p, the line was about 100+ people long (half block).

Tori Paitan Ramen soup was rich and creamy.  Noodles were soft and tender, but they weren't made onsite.  Duck and pork charsu were succulent and not super fatty.  Dried mushrooms and seaweed were standard ramen items.   Kale in the ramen is an odd combination and just added color.  Golden egg (miso flavored) add on was spot on.  

Overall, the ramen was tasty, but it is not worth the 1+ hour wait unless you have never been there.  There are numerous places like Mensho that are all over Tokyo.

excerpts: My daughter and I ordered a spicy Tori paitan ramen and agreed it was good in broth and noodle texture.
Although we prefer the ingredients in the regular Tori paitan with kale and duck chashu.
Ours only came with cabbage, pork chashu and bamboo shoots.
That's the only downside to our dish.
Spice is just right not too spicy.
Will definitely be back to try other stuff like the oysters and clam ramen!
We got our food pretty fast too.
People are friendly enough to talk to one another at our shared table.
Overall legit ramen spot in SF!
tori paitan ramen.author: Corinne Z.
tori paitan ramen.review: Went there 30 mins before closing on a Thursday night. Short line outside. Got seated fast. My daughter and I ordered a spicy Tori paitan ramen and agreed it was good in broth and noodle texture. Although we prefer the ingredients in the regular Tori paitan with kale and duck chashu. Ours only came with cabbage, pork chashu and bamboo shoots. That's the only downside to our dish. Spice is just right not too spicy. Will definitely be back to try other stuff like the oysters and clam ramen!  We got our food pretty fast too. People are friendly enough to talk to one another at our shared table. Overall legit ramen spot in SF!

excerpts: -double chasu tori paitan ramen ($18)
I really enjoyed the broth, it was very flavorful and still somewhat light, but toward the end of my meal it did get a little heavy.
Still I enjoyed the noodle texture a lot too.
tori paitan ramen.author: Isabel L.
tori paitan ramen.review:
The hype is real! We came around 745pm on a Saturday and there was a 40 min wait even in the rain! But I didn't mind too much since I wasn't too hungry. The interior is small but service is quick once you're seated.

We ordered:
-shoyu oysters ($5 for 4) -very just okay to me. A little in the fishy side, would skip!
-chasu bowl-4.5/5-yum!!! Had 3 huge fatty pieces of chasu with rice ! So delicious and tender ! 
-double chasu tori paitan ramen ($18) -4/5. I really enjoyed the broth, it was very flavorful and still somewhat light, but toward the end of my meal it did get a little heavy. Still I enjoyed the noodle texture a lot too. The chasu pieces were just okay 

Overall it was pretty good ! A little on the pricey side, but a solid choice in sf!

excerpts: I ordered the Tori Paitan ramen.
Now I've never, ever been too picky with my ramen.
I would be perfectly content with instant noodles,  obviously preferring dine in when occasions rose for it.
But I think this spot definitely changed my idea of what GREAT ramen is.
The broth was thick, creamy, and rich.
Although we agreed all the elements of it didn't match as well as the Tori Paitan.
tori paitan ramen.author: Sarah L.
tori paitan ramen.review:
Like all other reviewers before me said, the wait is long! My friend and I came in around 7 on a Tuesday night, and got in approximately an hour later. We luckily managed to snag two spots at the bar, which was more personable than the other tables, and the place was small. Also asked the waitress if there was a time limit we could dine in and she said no. 

I ordered the Tori Paitan ramen. Now I've never, ever been too picky with my ramen. I would be perfectly content with instant noodles,  obviously preferring dine in when occasions rose for it. But I think this spot definitely changed my idea of what GREAT ramen is. The broth was thick, creamy, and rich. And all the elements combined made for an enriching experience, from the soft, chewy noodles to the tender chashu pork, to the burdock root which added a very nice texture. 

My friend had ordered the organic shoyu ramen,  which tasted a lot lighter. Probably the healthier alternative, if you're looking for one. Although we agreed all the elements of it didn't match as well as the Tori Paitan.

I was also very impressed by our appetizer, oysters in shoyu dare oil. The plate was small with only a few pieces. However, from the very first bite, your taste buds just get sent through the roof. I don't know how else to explain it, but I was hooked. 

The whole meal was very filling, the service was good, and I would happily wait in line again for this place.

excerpts: I usually get the Tori Paitan ramen with double chashu.
I recommend getting the double chashu as it is the perfect amount of meat for the ramen.
When you see it at first, the bowl appears to be a little on the small side; however, as you eat, you begin to wonder how you're not finished with your bowl.
The broth is very thick and flavorful, with the chashu complimenting the broth.
The one thing that I thought would take it over the top would be an egg.
tori paitan ramen.author: Jason P.
tori paitan ramen.review:
I can be very particular about my ramen, and overall, the ramen in the bay isn't as good as it is in LA. Fortunately, this place can stack up to the ramen in LA. There is only street parking here, and more then likely you will be waiting outside for while. The dining area is very small, and you will be siting very close to strangers. The restroom is unisex and is well maintained. The place is very bright and there is a TV on the side.

I usually get the Tori Paitan ramen with double chashu. I recommend getting the double chashu as it is the perfect amount of meat for the ramen. When you see it at first, the bowl appears to be a little on the small side; however, as you eat, you begin to wonder how you're not finished with your bowl. The broth is very thick and flavorful, with the chashu complimenting the broth. The one thing that I thought would take it over the top would be an egg. Sadly, I did not see that add-on option on the menu.

The service is pretty fast once you get seated. The people working here are kind and respectful. Overall, I would have to say that this is my go to ramen spot in the city. I will be definitely be coming back here many more times. 4.5 stars.

excerpts: I ordered the Tori Paitan ramen and added an egg.
As expected it was a thick and delicious broth with tons of flavor.
Enjoyed every bite and every slurp.
I can see how some people may find it a bit too much since it is very thick and many will not be used to it.
tori paitan ramen.author: Ruben P.
tori paitan ramen.review:
The ultimate question: Is it worth the wait? If you are starving, the answer is no. I would likely never bring most of my family here as we get HANGRY, and waiting is not something we would like to do as a group for dinner.

After a late meeting at work I decided to trek over to Mensho Tokyo after having read about it a while ago. As I approached, I immediately knew I had arrived because of the line outside. I hopped in and was surprised that the line never really got shorter. The line was as expected in the wait was about 45 minutes to an hour.

When I was finally seated the service was quick, attentive, and friendly enough. I ordered the Tori Paitan ramen and added an egg. As expected it was a thick and delicious broth with tons of flavor. Enjoyed every bite and every slurp. I can see how some people may find it a bit too much since it is very thick and many will not be used to it. I thoroughly enjoyed it and thought it was delicious.

Now, is it worth the wait....again? Possibly, yes. BUT...you'll have to catch me on patient day and when I'm not that hungry because of the line.

excerpts:
Tori paitan ramen - creamy chicken broth noodle and the duck chasu is really unique
3.
Vegetarian dandanmen - this was my favorite.
tori paitan ramen.author: Regina A.
tori paitan ramen.review:
I've been hearing about the hype of mensho ramen for a while and finally got a time to go to this place. The place open at 5pm and we arrived at the place around 4.15 pm. We manage to get the fist spot in the line but at 4.30 the line was already soo loong!!

The place is so small so they only have 4 big table which you have to share with other party and there was 4 seat in the bar. 

These are our order:
1. Oyster for appetizer - really good
2. Tori paitan ramen - creamy chicken broth noodle and the duck chasu is really unique
3. Vegetarian dandanmen - this was my favorite. I was hesitant to order vegetarian ramen but it actually taste really2 good.

Will definitely come back to try the other noodle.

excerpts: Their most popular ramen is the tori paitan ramen
so I got that with the enoki mushroom chips as appetizer.
Food came out quickly despite the amount of people.
The mushroom chips were interesting, different than what most places have to offer, but it did taste somewhat similar to calamari.
On to the ramen, it was beautiful when I received it.
The noodles were thick and curly, yet bouncy
noodles(that's the ramen check).
The meat was so tender, yet flavorful with each bite.
The broth is also different compared to other places, super rich and thick.
I  did end up not really liking the broth towards the end because of how creamy and oily it was.
Besides everything the broth, everything else was enjoyable.
Service was good, filled our waters twice.
I'd definitely come back for their shoyu ramen next time.
tori paitan ramen.author: Lisa W.
tori paitan ramen.review: Been on my to try list for the longest and I finally get to say I tried Mensho Tokyo! I got there when it was about time to open on a Wednesday evening and the line wasn't so bad. The restaurant itself is definitely on the smaller side which makes sense why the wait can be so long. Once they opened up, we didn't have to wait in line, everyone got seated and the staff quickly went around getting everyone's orders. The seats are however, kind of uncomfortable. Tall tables with high stools, with almost no arm space between me and the person next door. Their most popular ramen is the tori paitan ramen so I got that with the enoki mushroom chips as appetizer. Food came out quickly despite the amount of people. The mushroom chips were interesting, different than what most places have to offer, but it did taste somewhat similar to calamari. On to the ramen, it was beautiful when I received it. The noodles were thick and curly, yet bouncy noodles(that's the ramen check). The meat was so tender, yet flavorful with each bite. The broth is also different compared to other places, super rich and thick. I  did end up not really liking the broth towards the end because of how creamy and oily it was. Besides everything the broth, everything else was enjoyable. Service was good, filled our waters twice. I'd definitely come back for their shoyu ramen next time.

excerpts: I had the tori paitan ramen with duck.
They weren't kidding when they called it rich and creamy.
My stomach was half full and I was going to burst from the ramen.
The bowl isn't that big but the broth is so rich and delicious.
I was most impressed by the duck.
Even by fancy French restaurant standards this is very well done.
The duck is so intense in flavor and tender to chew it's almost like ham.
tori paitan ramen.author: Michael H.
tori paitan ramen.review:
This might be my favorite ramen in SF. I had just eaten a fairly big meal but I was literally walking past Mensho when I remembered this place had huge lines. It was only 20 minutes away from opening so I decided to stick it out. One of the employees kindly gave me a stool to sit on as I waited. Soon thereafter a healthy line started to form. Once the doors opened there was already a wait list.

The interior is not so big. It seats about 30-40, most of which are bar stool seating. There's not much to look at since it's so small. There are banners and sayings, along with these glass coffee makers.

Since I was first I had received regular chair and a view of the kitchen. The menu is unsurprisingly narrow to ramen, non-ramen, and beverages. I'd say they have a good variety of ramen to choose from, even vegetarian. I had the tori paitan ramen with duck. They weren't kidding when they called it rich and creamy. My stomach was half full and I was going to burst from the ramen. The bowl isn't that big but the broth is so rich and delicious. I was most impressed by the duck. Even by fancy French restaurant standards this is very well done. The duck is so intense in flavor and tender to chew it's almost like ham.
____

I'd only wait 30 minutes max, but it's worth it. Go on an empty stomach and fill that tank up. Get the duck!

tori paitan ramen.author: Helen H.
tori paitan ramen.review:
This got to be the CREAMIEST and THICKEST ramen broth I have ever tried! It's rich in flavor and I've never tried anything like it before. After some shopping at Westfield mall, I was craving some ramen and happen to stumble across this place on Yelp and decided to give this place a try. The ramen did not disappoint but the wait was pretty bad. We waited for over an hour before we got seated.

Environment: 5/5 I really like clean and simple decor. Although there wasn't a lot of decoration, I've noticed some coffee brewers along the glass that allows you to see the kitchen. The first thing I noticed when I walked in were coat hangers but no one seems to be using them. The restaurant is very small with bar top tables and not much space to put your belongings (carry shopping bags was a bad idea). There isn't a lot of room for seating, everyone seems to be squished. I was glad that I got seated in one of the regular chairs and I got the view the kitchen.

Food: 4.5/5 DELICIOUS! Like many people probably said already, the broth here is super rich and creamy. I ordered the Spicy Tori Paitan with an order of egg while my bf got the spicy lamb ramen. First off before I go rambling about my ramen, the spicy lamb broth was a little salty for me. Okay, so the first sip of soup I took was life changing. The broths was perfectly delicious and the both of us would have to agree. This place is prefect for those whole appreciates a thick broth. After few bites in, the broth got too overwhelming for me and I realized that I did not enjoy it as much as my first bite (which is worth every penny). I would say that the noodle grabs onto the soup really well and the soft boiled egg was prefect with the runny yolk. The chashu had the perfect meat to fat ratio; the piece of meat literally melted in my mouth. No chewing was needed! The overall texture of the ramen was great because of the complexity of the toppings that accompanies the noodle.  

Price: 4/5 It is quite pricey for a bowl of ramen here. The Spicy Tori Paitan ramen that I got was $17 and the spicy lamb was $16. The portion size was like any other ramen shop but it is super filling because of the broth. I would say that it is worth every penny of your money because the ramen is just that good. 

Customer Service: 2.5/5 I feel like I didn't really receive much customer service while I was her. The waitresses all seem super busy to even notice us. Our server just brought over some water, took our order, and brought out the ramen. I don't like how there is an 18% automatic charge for service fee when I feel like the service wasn't that great. 

Overall, you must come and try at least once. It will be life changing, I promise! Although the price is a little high for ramen and the wait is terrible, I think it's worth a try. I probably won't be coming here again unless it's for a special occasion or something. The wait time is just too long for me. They didn't really have chairs for people to rest on so we literally had to stand outside the store the entire wait time. Since they don't take reservations, some people have waited more than 2 hours to try this place.

This is gonna be my go-to place for ramen.

tori paitan ramen.review:
One of the best ramen I had in North America. I haven't tried every places but since I really like ramen, I try as often as possible when traveling.

Tori Paitan ramen I had was so rich and creamy yet it wasn't overwhelming. Sometimes chicken base broth could be overwhelming but this felt light while maintaining rich and creamy texture.

I got lucky when I came. Arrived here on Thursday at 5:50pm, I only saw five people waiting outside. Since they were all together, she took me in before then. I was seated with almost no wait at all!  When I left after a nice bowl of ramen, I saw a very long queue (looked like about an hour wait). Must have came in such a perfect timing!

Service was good, just what you expect from any ramen shop in Japan. Fast and efficient.

Noodles were also prepared to perfection. Went well with tori Paitan broth.

They have vegan ramen as well as shio, tonkotsu and organic soy. I was really tempted to come back the next day as I enjoyed it so much. 

Next day I told several of my local contacts and they all knew about this place but unable to try yet due to long wait.  I was so glad I got to try here during my short visit to SF!

We had ramen a few streets down on our first day in SF and was totally disappointed but this place is definitely worth the wait!

We were in line before they opened. They open at 5pm. We stood in line around 4:45pm and was seated around 6pm. There was a gentleman who came out and calculated the number of people in each party so he knew how to seat everyone. This made everything move faster. People who had a party of 2 were seated prior to us but since we had 6 our wait was a bit longer (but not too long). He even took our order before we were seated so the wait once we sat was not that long. 

We had 2 bottles of sake (among a group of 6) and 3 shio and 3 tori paitan all with extra chashu. I wished we had ordered a shoyu ramen to try but maybe next time. The broth of the tori paitan was rich and heavy but not too heavy. It was delicious and I definitely would recommend this. The noodles were cooked perfectly. tori paitan ramen.author: John G.
tori paitan ramen.review:
In Japan, it is polite to slurp your noodles. 

Sometimes I would walk to my wife's work all the way to Presidio Heights from downtown and take Geary as my main route. One day, I noticed a long line of people waiting outside the Alcazar Theatre and wondered what the hoopla was all about. It suddenly clicked that this was one of the most anticipated opening of a Ramen shop straight from Japan. 

Chef and owner Tomoharu Shono's Mensho Tokyo is one of many restaurants he owns in Japan, and this is the first restaurant opened outside of Japan. I think it's fitting he chose San Francisco as we have been starved of good, authentic Ramen for so long. Most of my "best Ramen experience" so far have been in L.A., Vegas and the Peninsula. 

During the next couple months while walking pass this place, I would often gauge at the line and figured it would eventually die down but that never happened. So this past Sunday, I tried to convince the Wifey to get here early prior to their opening time, but she didn't want to "waste" time waiting in line and instead we got here around 7PM. You gotta have patience and brave the crackheads and crazies if you want some good Ramen and it better be worth it....and it was. 

After about an hour, we finally got seated and we both had the Tori Paitan Ramen (Double Chasu) and Oysters in Dare Oil, the only appetizer they served. The oysters had a subtle smoky and soy sauce flavor that was quite delightful, but may be an acquired taste for some. The Ramen is a creamy mixture of chicken soup with two slices of pork belly, two slices of duck breast, menma (bamboo shoots), burdock, kale and Katsuobushi sauce. 

The broth of the Ramen was thick, rich, creamy that was not too overpowering and it was quite an exquisite flavor bursting of umami. The noodles were thicker and cooked al dente to which I thoroughly enjoyed as it had a good snap to it. Now, had this been in Japan, I would have been slurping the noodles as the technique aerates the noodles and the broth, allowing the flavors to mellow out and fully develop before you chew and swallow. It also cools off your mouthful of noodles just enough to let you enjoy them while the rest of the bowl stays piping hot.

However....I couldn't get myself to do it since we are in a communal table. I was tempted to, but this ain't Japan and I wanted to eat "politely" to the rest of the patrons eating beside me. Regardless, we were enjoying our bowls of Ramen as these were right up there with some of the best we've had so far. 

Side note: I did some researching on the Chef and I am excited to see what bold new flavors he can come up with next. There's a particular lamb-based broth he made in Japan and wonder if he can recreate that here. He also can't make the same exact broths as he would like here due to health codes and regulations. I just hope he finds a way and I will slurp my way back here if he does.

tori paitan ramen.author: Elena N.
tori paitan ramen.review:
I've been wanting to try Mensho for some time, but the line always deterred me. Finally, on Thursday, July 28th, my group of three decided to brave the line around 10:30pm. It honestly didn't take too long. I think about 20 mins.

*Tori Paitan Ramen: Rich and Creamy Chicken Soup, Pork Chashu, Duck Chashu, Menma, Kale, Burdock, Katsuobushi Sauce ($18 double chashu)
*Organic Shoyu Ramen: Clear Organic Chicken and Pork Soup, Shoyu Dare, Pork Chashu, Duck Chashu, Kale, Kale Sprouts,Chives, Menma, Nori ($16 double chashu)
*Shio Ramen: Clear Chicken and Pork Soup, Shio Dare, Pork Chashu, Kale, Menma, Fried Garlic, Chives, Nori ($9)

My favorite, hands down, was the Tori Paitan. The noodles were the right consistency and the broth was rich and flavorful. I wasn't the one who ended up with this bowl, but I was wishing I had ordered it. My Shio ramen was okay. A light flavorful broth. But the noodles were the flat kind and I preferred the thicker noodles from the Tori Paitan better. They had a much better chew. I only tried a spoonful of the broth from the Shoyu Ramen which was fine.

We all know I can't have a meal without alcohol! Two of us got the Sapporo Premium: 355ml/12.0oz ($4.75) and one of us tried the Ozenoyukidoke IPA 12.75: 330ml/11.5oz ($12.75). Pricey for a beer, but a better choice if you like IPAs. I, myself prefer the lighter beers, so the sapporo was perfect for me.

Glad I was finally able to check Mensho Tokyo off my list. Was it worth the 20 min wait? Yes, I would say so. But if I had to wait 1+ hours in the SF cold, I don't know. I'm just happy I'll never have to find out.

Service was courteous and the staff stay on top of everything. Upon getting seated, we placed our order pretty quickly. We wanted to try the Ozenoyukidoke IPA but our waitress said they didn't have it. While waiting for our order, I counted 24 seats in the restaurant. 

I had the oysters in shoyu dare oil and while these weren't quite what I was expecting, I enjoyed them. The oysters were flavorful and firm with a texture similar to liver.

I also had the Tori Paitan ramen with double chashu. I tasted the broth first and immediately picked up on its intense chicken flavor and richness. When I cook chicken thighs in a pan, and that skin is browning and the fat renders, I could smell the same aroma in the Tori Paitan broth. It was very delicious and for sure unlike any ramen broth I've had before. I loved the thick springy noodles and the tender chashu. The pork was excellent but the standout for me was the duck which had a really nice floral flavor. tori paitan ramen.author: Jacky C.
tori paitan ramen.review:
For all the hype that is Mensho, it just doesn't hit the mark.  

I ordered their signature Tori paitan ramen with extra chashu, which is a chicken white broth ramen.  It came their fresh ramen noodles, 2 pieces of pork (which were quite thin), topped with some veggies, bonito flakes. Overall, i just found it quite lacking.

The three criteria which I usually judge quality ramen are:

1. Noodles - cooked with a bit of bite to it, similar to al dente
2. The broth - flavorful and compliments the noodles and toppings
3. The soft boil egg - a staple to most ramen, and shows how well the place cooks their food.

Now, to put these criteria to the test.

1. Mensho have some great ramen noodles. It was perfectly cooked and quite delicious 5/5.
2. The tori paitan broth was quite unfamiliar to me. Maybe it is just wasn't my style, because a chicken broth tends to be a lighter base compared to the typical tonkatsu broth you find elsewhere.  But the "light" broth with the heaviness of the creamy base just seemed to be unbalanced and just not as appealing to the palate. This is just my opinion, but seeing as how this is their most popular dish, they must be appealing to others  2/5
3. Soft boil egg.... There was none.  This is the first popular ramen place I have been to which did not serve an egg with their ramen.  This baffled me. Maybe their are trying to appeal to the "vegan" sensibility which makes no sense since ramen usually has an animal based broth.  0/5

For a $18 dollar bowl of ramen ( it was $2 extra for a thin slice of pork), it did not meet my expectation.  The broth was dull and unbalanced, the toppings lacking, and even the noodles couldn't save the dish.  It is quite a shame. Maybe this place is more of a hype since the long lines and small location make it seem like an amazing ramen parlor.

The long lines and mediocre broth just push this place to the wayside, but I guess if you are willing to wait for average food, and have the money to spend, try it out.

tori paitan ramen.review:
Craving for ramen? More like...YAH...man. Bad joke/pun aside, Mensho Tokyo is anything but cringe worthy. 

The Tori Paitan Ramen ($16) is the chicken soup with pork and duck chashu, menma, kale, burdock, and katsuobushi sauce. My boyfriend and I both ordered the Tori Paitan Ramen with DOUBLE chashu ($18) for extra meat. 

After our first taste, my boyfriend and I both looked at each other with amazed faces. The chicken broth was rich, creamy, and super flavorful -- it made my insides feel warm and fuzzy. My boyfriend usually doesn't care about finishing the soup in ramen, but he finished this one (I did too). The meat was also tender and the noodles were chewy and thick. I'm currently drooling as I reminisce about this magical bowl. 

Service is polite and attentive. Wait time can range from 30 minutes to 2 hours. My boyfriend and I went on a Friday at 6:00 PM and waited in line for about an hour. Not sure if a 2 hour wait is worth it; an hour and a half is cutting it close. I highly recommend you go in small groups (1-3 people). 

The restaurant is also quite tiny and seems to accommodate about 28 to 30 people. There are only three communal tables: one long table and two smaller tables. Be ready to sit next to strangers elbow to elbow.

Despite the wait and tiny space, I will definitely come back!

Worried about the line? Come early on a weekday! I went on a Wednesday at 6pm and there was no line and quite a few seats available. However, by 7pm when we left, there was a line out the door with ~15 people. Not too bad. 

Highly recommend the Tori Paitan Ramen. The soup is AWESOME, super flavorful but not too salty like a lot of ramen places. The noodles were also the kind I like - chewy and al dente. (So, if you like very soft noodles, this probably isn't the place for you.) 

We also ordered the vegan tantan noodles. Can't believe it was VEGAN! Tasted as if it had meat. If you're not a soup noodle type person, go with the tan tan noodles. 

The Shoyu or Salt flavored ramens are just not as flavorful or umami like the Tori Paitan or the tan tan noodles. So I would recommend sticking to what they're known for!

tori paitan ramen.review:
Pretty amazing I must say, although the bill didn't look too appealing for two people. Went a little overboard with one of my buds and we spent more than we had anticipated for two bowls of ramen, oysters, beer and sake (woops!). Money well spent at the end of the day (to justify the hole in my wallet).

Was in the mood for ramen and just so happened to be in the area as well... hey... why not give Mensho a shot? Line was not too long and table for two was seated in 45 minutes (it was 10:00 pm on Friday at the time though). This place is also very tiny, so not such a good place to dine at if you're with a party larger than 4 folks.

My bud and I were feeling adventurous so we went ahead and ordered the Oysters in Shoyu Dare Oil and I think our experience would have been better off if we didn't order it (personal preference of ours, it might be amazing to someone else). 

Japanese IPA and Sake made for an awesome double-fist combo as we downed the oysters.

I tried their Tori Paitan Ramen with double ChaShu - after my first bite, I knew I was in for something special for the entire meal. Broth was loaded with flavor, very thick and creamy and it was nothing I have ever tried before... definitely the highlight of Mensho.

Overall lovely experience, it is a shame that this place is so small. I'd love to keep coming back, but the wait is absurdly long during peak hours. You'd have to start lining up for at least 30 minutes before they open in order to dodge the epic-long wait.

The broth is wonderfully flavorful and creamy, and the noodles are the perfect texture and chewiness. It's like they took all my disappointments with other ramen bowls, fixed them, and added their own special mix. It's absolutely fantastic!

At first glance, it's one of the more pricey bowls of ramen that I've had and I had my doubts about eating there or ordering the Tori Paitan. However, it's worth every penny. This is one bowl of ramen I'd gladly wait for, and shell out the $$$ for. 

Apparently it's usually a long wait, but I went on a weekday close to opening, and there wasn't too long of a wait (~20 min)

Service is nice, the atmosphere is bright and the decorations are modern. The restaurant is very small, and from what I could see, all the seats were high chairs. So maybe not optimal for a large group or kids.

Regardless, go get that Tori Paitan! You will not regret it!

excerpts: My friends got the Tori Paitan Ramen with Duck Chashu and the Spicy Lamb Chashu Ramen.
tori paitan ramen.author: Connie C.
tori paitan ramen.review:
There's so many ramen joints around the Bay Area and they're all good in their own way but none has ever stood out to me until I came to Mensho. Prior to trying Mensho, Ippudo Ramen in NY was my favorite ramen spot ever. Unfortunately Mensho has stolen Ippudo's spotlight and is seriously the best ramen that I've ever had.

Had an impromptu day with some friends in the city and kinda winged it as to where to get food. My friend was browsing through Yelp for awhile and he picked very wisely. He asked if we were down for some ramen and off we went. Luckily when we got there, the line was starting to form so it wasn't too bad. We got in line while my friend tried to find parking. We waited in line for about 1.5 hour which honestly isn't that bad since Mensho is pretty small inside. So keep in mind it's not friendly for groups. As the line started to move once their doors opened and people were filling up the tables, my friends and I were so close to getting in and we were close to making the cut.

While anxiously waiting we browsed through their menu and as people were leaving, we asked what they got which made the decision process a lot easier. Finally we got seated by this counter seating which was fine. We got to see the chefs in action and it was interesting to see the process of it all. I had ordered the Clam Butter Chashu Ramen since I've never seen anywhere serve clams with ramen. My friends got the Tori Paitan Ramen with Duck Chashu and the Spicy Lamb Chashu Ramen. We ordered the Oysters in Shoyu Dare Oil, which was really yummy. There was enough pieces for the 3 of us to try and to hold off our appetite as we patiently waited for our ramen.

Once our ramen had arrived, we tried each other's broths. The ones that my friends ordered had a creamy broth and it was so savory and delicious. My broth was lighter but still delicious. At first when I tried the broth for my ramen, it had a strong seafood taste but after mixing that whipped butter and all the other ingredients in my bowl together, there was a huge shift in the taste of my broth. It was much more flavorful and that strong seafood taste was masked...probably by the butter but I'm not complaining. The noodles in my ramen were a bit different from my friends but they were so fresh and tasty. So delicious!

The service was alright. Had to flag down a server a few times to get more water. They were busy and it was packed so I understand. The decor was very simple and minimal.

When my friend had told me it was Michelin star rated I wasn't sure how I felt but after trying the food, it definitely proved me wrong. The quality of the ingredients was amazing. As mentioned earlier, it's one of the best ramen that I've ever had. I was craving for more the next day because it was so good. We had met some tourists in line and they told us it was their second time going during their trip in SF. That speaks volume.

Highly suggest trying this place and try to come as early as possible to wait in line. There was already a line at 4PM and they don't open until 5PM. Be patient and you'll have some of the best ramen ever!

excerpts: Anyway, had the Tori Paitan ramen and the Vegan Tantanmen.
-Tori
Paitan:
Deep chicken broth flavor.
Very creamy and filling.
I think I heard it described as a chicken soup for rich people.
I may be able to buy into this description.
For our patience in line, we got an extra chashu (which is not the best anyway).
Noodles were very enjoyable, al dente, and on point.
However, the broth just didn't do it for me.
-Vegan tantanmen:
Surprisingly, I will have to rate this above the tori paitan.
The flavor is fuller and more complex.
It has almost a nutty quality to it, so if you don't like nuts, would not suggest this one.
But it was always very creamy and filly of a broth.
tori paitan ramen.author: Edward L.
tori paitan ramen.review:
Had high hopes for this place. Maybe too high.

As with most ramen places, you expect to wait in line. You can either wait in line later, or you can wait in line before it opens. We chose the latter. We got there at 430pm, expecting to wait 30 minutes for the 5pm opening. Luckily, there was only 1 person ahead of us. Was able to walk down the street grab a cup of coffee from Starbucks and return without any problems.

Come 5 pm, window shades open. Pristine, small, clean dining room with the kitchen in the back. You could just anticipate a good ramen experience. Appeared it was well-staffed. Unfortunately, no one opened the door, as everyone just peered through the window, watching the staff working on the computer system.... Wait 5 minutes, nothing. Wait 10 minutes, nothing. Wait 30 minutes, finally, the head hostess comes out.

"Sorry, but our system is not accepting credit card. We can only accept cash. Please go to an ATM." Are you kidding me? I think cash-only establishments are OK, and I have no problem with this. But really? It took you 30 minutes to let us know this? Of course, all of us in line have been waiting and waiting, so we all make a dash to the nearest ATM. I think it makes more sense to let us know at the very beginning there was issues, so while we inevitably wait more in line, we can go get some cash......... amiright?

Further insult to injury. we didn't get seated for another 15 minutes... So really, 45 minutes after "opening." It doesn't make common sense.

Anyway, had the Tori Paitan ramen and the Vegan Tantanmen.
-Tori Paitan: Deep chicken broth flavor. Very creamy and filling. I think I heard it described as a chicken soup for rich people. I may be able to buy into this description. For our patience in line, we got an extra chashu (which is not the best anyway). Noodles were very enjoyable, al dente, and on point. However, the broth just didn't do it for me.
-Vegan tantanmen: Surprisingly, I will have to rate this above the tori paitan. The flavor is fuller and more complex. It has almost a nutty quality to it, so if you don't like nuts, would not suggest this one. But it was always very creamy and filly of a broth. Noodles the same. 

Unfortunately, given the late start and unreasonable wait without explanation (and even with an explanation, still does not explain make us wait beyond the opening time), I have to rate an overall 2 stars. Service while seated is great, but the compilation of average ramen and initial impression once we got there, has left a bad taste in my mouth.

excerpts: After waiting in line for about an hour and finally being ushered into the small restaurant space, I decided to order the Tori Paitan Ramen, containing Rich and Creamy Chicken Soup, Pork Chashu, Duck Chashu, Menma, Kale, Burdock, Katsuobushi Sauce.
tori paitan ramen.author: Sarah N.
tori paitan ramen.review:
I almost want to give 3.5 stars, but the handmade noodles and the quality of the pork and duck slices was too prime to lower. This was my first time at Mensho, and I was immediately astonished by the line on an early Saturday evening. After waiting in line for about an hour and finally being ushered into the small restaurant space, I decided to order the Tori Paitan Ramen, containing Rich and Creamy Chicken Soup, Pork Chashu, Duck Chashu, Menma, Kale, Burdock, Katsuobushi Sauce. 

PROS: 
- delicious (!!) pork and duck chasu. I had never had duck in my ramen before, but it was so tender and juicy and a great addition.
- handmade noodles. They had that inconsistent size and shape characteristic of a handmade noodle and they weren't chewy and harder like the premade or packaged ramen at some other spots. 

CONS:
- the broth! This might be an unpopular opinion, but it was just too damn rich and creamy, almost as if they had poured cups and cups of cream and milk. I definitely wasn't able to consume much of the broth after getting through the ramen and for hours after my meal, I felt like I was going to be sick. If (IF!) I were to come back again (maybe when it's raining and there's no ridiculous line), I'd try the Shoyu broth instead. 
- so there's kale in your ramen...but no option to add an egg? What??
- that line. Sorry, there's no justifying it, and in my case, not sure it was worth it. 

In summary, I didn't have the most mindblowing experience here, and perhaps it was because I was let down given all the hype. But due to the quality of meat and the delicious handmade ramen, I didn't feel I could go lower than 4 stars here.

excerpts: Fortunately, we didn't have to wait too long to be seated when we came here a couple days ago, and the Tori Paitan Ramen was pretty good!
I kinda wish they made a thick pork based broth, but the tori paitan was still delicious.
Some people have mentioned that it's too salty, but I thought it was the right degree of saltiness.
If I had to suggest anything, they could add more green onions or something else to offset the heaviness of the broth and meat toppings.
While I enjoyed the rich profile of the ramen, having some sort of contrast would make it even better.
tori paitan ramen.author: Nei N.
tori paitan ramen.review:
This has been on my to-try list for a while, and I put it off mainly so I wouldn't have to wait in some ridiculous line. Fortunately, we didn't have to wait too long to be seated when we came here a couple days ago, and the Tori Paitan Ramen was pretty good!

Broth - Rich, creamy, and super chickeny. I kinda wish they made a thick pork based broth, but the tori paitan was still delicious. Some people have mentioned that it's too salty, but I thought it was the right degree of saltiness. If I had to suggest anything, they could add more green onions or something else to offset the heaviness of the broth and meat toppings. While I enjoyed the rich profile of the ramen, having some sort of contrast would make it even better. Also, those weird metals spoons have got to go!

Noodles - Firm and springy. The noodles were great!

Toppings - I didn't care too much about the duck chashu, burdock, or kale. The pork chashu was very well made. It had a very earthy sweet flavor kinda like a Hakka style braised pork belly. 

Overall, it was pretty good, and I'd return when the line isn't super long.

excerpts: I honestly did not know what to order so I ordered the first thing I saw- the Tori Paitan Ramen.
My order came out quickly (within 10-15 mins max) and it was the most amazing ramen I have ever had.
The broth is SO flavorful and thick
.. there was no way I left anything in that bowl.
Seriously, 10/10 would recommend.
tori paitan ramen.author: Esther M.
tori paitan ramen.review:
Just flew in last night at around 10 and I was madly craving ramen. All the local ramen spots around me were already closed or nearly closing til I found this gem. Let me tell you, PLEASE TRY THIS PLACE OUT. Although it's a fairly small space (I would say atleast 30 people max can be seated & its bar seating) the wait is not that long. People little sit, eat & drink, and pay their tab and leave. I spent about 30 minutes max in there eating (I was solo). 
Great customer service. Honestly don't remember the gal's name but she was very tentative and took my order rather quickly. I honestly did not know what to order so I ordered the first thing I saw- the Tori Paitan Ramen. My order came out quickly (within 10-15 mins max) and it was the most amazing ramen I have ever had. The broth is SO flavorful and thick.. there was no way I left anything in that bowl. Seriously, 10/10 would recommend.

excerpts: It was the $18 Tori Paitan Ramen with Double Pork Chashu, and I had them add an extra couple of Duck Chashu slices for $1.50 extra because why not go to town?
The noodles were perfectly al dente, and the chashu was meaty without being overwhelming.
tori paitan ramen.author: Ed U.
tori paitan ramen.review:
The advance hype on this place was off the charts, and the breathless texting and taxing anticipation from the hipsterati of self-proclaimed ramen connoisseurs has been quite deafening. A two-plus-hour wait for an $18 bowl of ramen sounds like a Louis C.K. joke about San Francisco millennials with no punchline. I got exhausted thinking about the hoops I'd have to jump through to get a taste of the broth here. However, now that at least six weeks have elapsed since the grand opening in February, I had an opening that I couldn't bypass, the Thursday before Good Friday when I got off work early.

Everyone says to be there at 4PM even though they don't open until an hour later, and so I did. If you don't count the screeching homeless woman who kept sauntering by, no one else showed up until around 4:35PM. That's not to say the staff was indifferent to my presence as they thanked me for coming and waiting patiently. Eventually a line did start to form and rather quickly. I got seated at the front counter promptly at 5PM where I had a nice view of the kitchen where activity was bustling behind he coffee beakers with the broth at full boil and the pork and duck chashu being meticulously sliced. I was sitting with a Filipino family who could barely contain their enthusiasm over the forthcoming noodlefest.

I was feeling the same way and knew what to order since I had well over an hour to decide. I started with their one and only appetizer, the $5 Oysters in Shoyu Dare Oil. There were four of them completely shelled and marinated (photo: http://bit.ly/1Vp0sEV). Tasty freshness gone too soon, but the main event was about to occur. It was the $18 Tori Paitan Ramen with Double Pork Chashu, and I had them add an extra couple of Duck Chashu slices for $1.50 extra because why not go to town? The noodles were perfectly al dente, and the chashu was meaty without being overwhelming. Slices of menma, kale and burdock floated on top with a katsuobushi (bonito) sauce spooned on top (photo: http://bit.ly/224L6pv).

However, for all the fresh ingredients, it was that rich paitan chicken broth that lingers not only on the palate but in my sense-memory. Just the natural creaminess of it was amazing, and what really makes this bowl of ramen stand out against the others. There are three other ramen bowls on the menu - organic shoyu, shio, and vegan tantanmen, as well as a selection of mazesoba bowls. I was timid and just had a $4.75 bottle of Sapporo Premium to wash it all down (photo: http://bit.ly/1RTN9dq), but they have pricier Japanese artisan beers which they strongly recommended to me for the next time. And there will be a next time even as I saw the line go down the block as I departed.

FOOD - 5 stars...best paitan ramen broth ever, period
AMBIANCE - 4.5 stars...clean, white and you only wish it was triple the size to make the line move faster
SERVICE - 5 stars...lovely people work here
TOTAL - 5 stars...not just for self-proclaimed ramen connoisseurs...be patient or come near closing

excerpts: The tori paitan ramen was incredibly creamy, and I had a hard time finishing all the broth, it was that rich.
tori paitan ramen.author: Steph D.
tori paitan ramen.review:
I know pretty much nothing about ramen, but holy crap, best japanese pot o' noodles I have ever eaten. The tori paitan ramen was incredibly creamy, and I had a hard time finishing all the broth, it was that rich. Twenty bucks is a little steep, but I would highly recommend this bowl.

Long line at 4:55, but we were seated by 6pm. When we left at about 6:50, the line was pretty short. I definitely think the wait is worth it, for currently the "best" ramen in SF. I definitely would recommend coming with a smaller party, though.

excerpts: I really enjoyed my tori paitan ramen, and I must say it was a unique dish.
First, as someone who generally does not like getting too close to strangers, I thought the close seating arrangement was tolerable.
Since the wait is so long, the literature on the walls was enough to educate/entertain me, and the specialty of their kombu broth does seem authentic after tasting it.
However, I think this particular broth needed time getting adjusted with because it was much earthier than what I've had at typical American ramen places.
I would even suggest nixing the bamboo shoots because for the first half of my meal, I could not taste anything but that strong pickly bamboo taste which took away from the broth flavor.
The egg was seasoned to the T--rich, pungent, and oversalted even.
I had to be careful eating that egg.
Overall, not worth the wait or the price tag for me as someone who has affordable ramen options back home, and not unique enough for me to come back.
tori paitan ramen.author: Hong L.
tori paitan ramen.review: I really enjoyed my tori paitan ramen, and I must say it was a unique dish. First, as someone who generally does not like getting too close to strangers, I thought the close seating arrangement was tolerable. Since the wait is so long, the literature on the walls was enough to educate/entertain me, and the specialty of their kombu broth does seem authentic after tasting it. The egg was seasoned to the T--rich, pungent, and oversalted even. I had to be careful eating that egg. Overall, not worth the wait or the price tag for me as someone who has affordable ramen options back home, and not unique enough for me to come back.

excerpts: The most popular one is the Tori Paitan Ramen, but I hear the Tsukemen is bomb as well (chilled ramen separated from the broth).
There's not too many choices for additional toppings like soft boiled eggs or corn, but
hey if the ramen tastes amazing by itself, who needs it?
Once my Tori Paitan Double Chashu ($18) came out, I just stared at my ramen for a good 10 seconds.
IT LOOKS
SO GOOD.
Okay looks are one thing, but let's taste the broth.
DROOLS.
A rich, thick, & creamy broth packed with a lot of flavor.
It doesn't taste overly saturated with sodium at all.
Double Chashu is so worth.
Most of the flavors from the ramen came from the pork, and the chashu just melts in your mouth.
The duck was good too, but it had a subtle lemon taste to it.
tori paitan ramen.author: Kevin S.
tori paitan ramen.review:
Mensho is so worth the wait!

I've heard from many people that this place is like THE best ramen ever. That's impossible right? Well, I'm not easy to please in terms of ramen, but the fact that I actually drank the entire chicken broth is saying something! The restaurant opens at 5pm, but a huge line already started forming before it even opened. My friends got a spot in line at about 4:45pm, and I met up with them 30 minutes later. Total wait for us was about 1.5 hours, but I heard people have waited at least 2 hours for this. There is no sign up sheet for waiting, just an old fashioned wait your turn in line kinda deal. There's also not a lot of seating inside, so the wait makes more sense. Once you're inside, you still have to wait about 30 minutes from being seated to having your ramen come out.

TIP: If you're comfortable and brave enough to eat alone, single seats are most likely available for you to skip the line if there are groups with odd numbers.

Parking in this area is kind of difficult, especially with all the one way streets and meter parking. If you wait till about 5:45pm on weekdays, rush over to take the parking right across the street. Parking is free and allowed at 6pm along this part of Geary. 

The menu is pretty simple too, with your choice of Ramen, Tsukemen, and Mazesoba. The most popular one is the Tori Paitan Ramen, but I hear the Tsukemen is bomb as well (chilled ramen separated from the broth). There's not too many choices for additional toppings like soft boiled eggs or corn, but hey if the ramen tastes amazing by itself, who needs it? Just kidding I still want my soft boiled egg and corn.

We ordered oysters in shoyu dare oil for appetizers, and it was tasty. 4-5 pieces for $5 so not a bad deal. Once my Tori Paitan Double Chashu ($18) came out, I just stared at my ramen for a good 10 seconds. IT LOOKS SO GOOD. Okay looks are one thing, but let's taste the broth. DROOLS. A rich, thick, & creamy broth packed with a lot of flavor. It doesn't taste overly saturated with sodium at all. Double Chashu is so worth. Most of the flavors from the ramen came from the pork, and the chashu just melts in your mouth. The duck was good too, but it had a subtle lemon taste to it. Crispy bamboo shoots were a nice touch.

The hype couldn't be more real.

excerpts: The best thing about the Tori Paitan Ramen was how tender the cha shu was.
I don't know how they cook it
so there's still a pink hue
but it's amazing.
The regular portion is pretty generous
tori paitan ramen.author: Shannon L.
tori paitan ramen.review:
Well, that was the meatiest and nuttiest vegan ramen I've ever had. It's nutty to the point that bits get stuck between your teeth and you're occasionally chewing on larger pieces that you sip up. Reviewers and even other customers raved about how good the vegan ramen was and that may possibly be better than its meat-based brethren.

While I liked it, it's definitely a once-in-a-while ramen because of how heavy and sodium laden it was. I'm parched as I'm writing this. 

The best thing about the Tori Paitan Ramen was how tender the cha shu was. I don't know how they cook it so there's still a pink hue but it's amazing. The regular portion is pretty generous but if you love pork, you might want to pay extra for the double portion.

With both ramen types, the broths were super heavy in flavor so how much you like this place may depend on how you like your ramen. I actually prefer the milky, creamy broth but this place still does an excellent job making what they specialize in. 

The place looks bigger in pictures but it's a pretty tight space. They have a coat rack for you to hang up your belongings and also bins underneath the tables for purses and backpacks. I went at 5:30pm on a Friday and the wait was a little less than an hour. They took our order a few minutes after we sat and the food came out in 10 minutes.

excerpts: I went with the most popular Tori Paitan Ramen with double chashu.
WOW this was definitely the creamiest ramen I've ever had, and the noodles themselves were the best tasting ramen noodles I've ever eaten.
They were very thick and chewy and the broth was very very rich and creamy.
tori paitan ramen.author: Catherine S.
tori paitan ramen.review:
I came to this place completely unaware that the line would be this ridiculous. I was so shocked at the length of this line on a Tuesday evening - I definitely should've read the reviews and tips beforehand. Nonetheless, my friends and I decided to wait 1.5 hours in line to try the ramen. I mean there has to be a reason why everyone else is also waiting in line. This place just opened around 3 weeks ago, and the chain is straight from Tokyo. Honestly, they should really expand their venue considering how amazingly popular they are! They only have about 4 bar tables that seat 6 people and a small area that seats about 3-4 people. If you come here alone, you could probably skip most of the line!

The service here is really great. The host was really friendly and even remembered our names! He also brought the chef out to meet us and the chef was so adorable and sweet. The staff honestly believes the vegan ramen is the best one, and if you really love meat you can add meat to the ramen. Both my friends went for the vegan ramen, but once I saw that it contained 7 types of nuts, I didn't order it considering I'm allergic to a couple types of nuts. I went with the most popular Tori Paitan Ramen with double chashu. WOW this was definitely the creamiest ramen I've ever had, and the noodles themselves were the best tasting ramen noodles I've ever eaten. They were very thick and chewy and the broth was very very rich and creamy. This was definitely one-of-a-kind ramen!

If ramen is like this in Tokyo, I'm definitely going to have to pay a visit to Japan soon! Although the line here was quite painful, I will try come back here again hopefully when the line isn't as terrible. It is pretty pricey but definitely worth. They're also adding eggs to the ramen in 2 days for all you egg-lovers!

excerpts: Tori Paitan Ramen (Double Chashu) was way too creamy and rich for me.
Felt a tad bit of nausea afterwards.
I finished the noodles but left most of the sauce/broth untouched.
And unfortunately, the ground lamb was so ground up that it got lost in the sauce.
tori paitan ramen.author: Lydia Z.
tori paitan ramen.review:
Tori Paitan Ramen (Double Chashu) was way too creamy and rich for me. Felt a tad bit of nausea afterwards. I finished the noodles but left most of the sauce/broth untouched. And unfortunately, the ground lamb was so ground up that it got lost in the sauce. #rip 

I'd try another dish next time but future me would not wait such a long line for ramen in such a small shop. There are 3 tables total so you'll definitely have to share--fun but not fun if you need to tolerate annoying neighbors.

excerpts: I ordered the Tori Paitan ramen with double chasu, an egg, and fried garlic aka full AF.
tori paitan ramen.author: Danny L.
tori paitan ramen.review:
I tried to disregard the hype, but I'm sure I had my own biases coming into Mensho expecting it to be amazing. Here is my attempt to be objective. I ordered the Tori Paitan ramen with double chasu, an egg, and fried garlic aka full AF. 

Broth: This broth is THICK. First impression when sipping it was that it was very rich and almost even gritty since it was so thick. I warmed up to it after several bites and having it together with the noodles and the other ingredients. At the end, it made me feel pretty gross though. 

Noodles: Springy, my favorite type. 

Chasu: Two types of chasu, pork and duck, both thinly sliced, both had great flavor. 

Egg: Shoyu egg, flavorful where you can actually taste the soy sauce marinade. Perfectly soft-boiled

Other: Bamboo shoots tasted a bit more fermented than what I was used to but still good. The fried onions, kale, and cabbage were good additions as it added different complimenting textures and flavors to the dish. Fried garlic was a waste of an add for 2 dollars more as I felt it didn't add that much to the dish. 

Wait time: 10 minutes; Came 10 minutes before opening on a Tuesday and there was already a small line in front but was able to get in with the first wave of people. 

Service: Waitresses were friendly and knowledgeable about the ramen. Had sound suggestions regarding which egg to get (miso or shoyu), which ramen to try as a first timer, and what I should try in the future. 

Price: Steep for ramen. Ingredients seem high quality and the place is pretty hyped up so I guess its understandable. 

Overall, the Tori Paiten ramen was good but may be too rich and thick for my taste. I'd come back to try the other ramens here (the lamb miso ramen, the clam ramen, and the soup-less ramen) since they have the potential to be really good.

excerpts: We ordered the oysters in shoyu dare oil to share and for myself, I got the tori paitan ramen with double chashu (because dammit, I waited too long in line to limit myself).
Tori Paitan Ramen (Double Chashu) $18: WOW!
The chicken broth was so rich and creamy.
I would expect it to be salty judging from the look of it
but it wasn't although it was SUPER FLAVORFUL.
In fact, most of the salty taste came from the pork chashu.
The pork chashu broke apart easily with my chopsticks and melts in my mouth with each bite.
Duck chashu was interesting since it had a slight lemon-y flavor.
I definitely enjoyed the pork more.
The noodles were thick (chow mein thick) and chewy.
