tori paitan ramen.author: Diana C.
tori paitan ramen.review:
Pencil in an hour or two of waiting. But it's worth it. 

Mensho Tokyo opens at 5pm and so my friend and I came here at exactly 5pm. There was already a long line waiting outside the restaurant. Were they there since 4pm or just five minutes ago? I have no clue but 5 minutes later, half of the line went in so my heart skipped a beat at the possibility of having my wait time reduced in half. Even then, we waited for at least another hour and 15 minutes until we were finally seated. At reaching the top of the line, there was still a good thirty people behind us. 

There is no wait list to put your name down or reservations. You do it the good old fashioned stand and wait your turn. Finding parking in this area can be a hassle but there is parking across the street that is free and available after 6pm assuming you can snag the spot (it is a no stopping zone before 6pm). The restaurant is quite small and there's two rows of tables. The front row was one long table and the back row near the windows was sectioned off into two separate tables. It's communal seating so you may be sitting with other parties if you are a small group. I was sitting in the back row near the windows and our table seated 7 so our party of 3 was seated with two other parties of 2. If you're eating by yourself, you may be lucky enough to move up in line since you can sit with the odd number groups. 

We ordered the oysters in shoyu dare oil to share and for myself, I got the tori paitan ramen with double chashu (because dammit, I waited too long in line to limit myself). 

Oysters: For $5, you get four pieces although I counted five unless one oyster cloned itself. They're really tiny pieces and the Yelp photos are a lie when you see the close-up and think it's bigger than it really is (so sorry, my photo is now a lie). It's a little salty but still kind of tasty if you're into oysters. I'm definitely used to raw oysters with the lemon and marinara so it was a bit strange to taste cooked oysters in soy sauce. A good starting appetizer as you wait for your ramen. 

Tori Paitan Ramen (Double Chashu) $18: WOW! The chicken broth was so rich and creamy. I would expect it to be salty judging from the look of it but it wasn't although it was SUPER FLAVORFUL. In fact, most of the salty taste came from the pork chashu. The pork chashu broke apart easily with my chopsticks and melts in my mouth with each bite. Duck chashu was interesting since it had a slight lemon-y flavor. I definitely enjoyed the pork more. The noodles were thick (chow mein thick) and chewy. You get a big silver ladle spoon so you can spoon up both the delicious broth along with your thick noodles.

Be prepared to open up your wallet and drop almost $20 a person. With three bowls of ramen and oysters, we paid about $75 with tax and tips. Thankfully it's not cash only and they do take card. To the side of the restaurant, they have a single unisex bathroom that is quite spacious for such a small restaurant.

excerpts: I'd recommend trying the Tori Paitan ramen with extra chashu the first time you're here.
tori paitan ramen.author: Edward W.
tori paitan ramen.review:
I came at 830pm on a Saturday night and surprisingly only waited around 30-35 minutes. I'd recommend trying the Tori Paitan ramen with extra chashu the first time you're here.

The duck chashu was so tender and fatty and it surpassed all my expectations! The pork chashu was also quite fatty and delicious. The chicken soup base was surprisingly heavy and rich and the noodles were of average chewiness. I also had a chance to try my friend's vegan ramen and it was surprisingly delicious! The soup base is the perfect mixture of soy and peanut. Plenty of peanut flavor that doesn't overpower the rest of the flavors. 

The communal seating makes it a bit difficult to hear across the table because the restaurant is quite small and the voices echo. I love that the restaurant provides boxes underneath the table to store your bulkier items. The table also has space inbetween for smaller items like a phone or purse.

Service was quick and efficient.

excerpts: I got the Tori Paitan ramen.
Definitely will come back here again even if I have to stand outside for over an hour.
Lol.
But it's that good.
tori paitan ramen.author: Joelle L.
tori paitan ramen.review: Best ramen I've ever had. The broth is so creamy and flavorful, but it gets really thick by the time you get to the bottom and bowl and cools down! I recommend getting the extra chashu, it's so worth it. But be warned, this is a  pretty big bowl of ramen so come hungry! I got the Tori Paitan ramen. :) Definitely will come back here again even if I have to stand outside for over an hour. Lol. But it's that good. ;)

excerpts: All 4 of us ordered the tori paitan ramen ($16), which was seemingly the most popular!
The tori paitan was incredibly flavorful, creamy, and THICK!
Like others have said, the tori paitan broth has more of a sauce or gravy-like consistency rather than your normal thinner broth.
If you don't like heavy meals...
don't get the tori paitan.
The tori paitan broth got a bit too rich as I was finishing the bowl.
However, I enjoyed it!
tori paitan ramen.author: Tara A.
tori paitan ramen.review:
Authentic ramen from Japan? Count me in!!! 

My friends and I lined up at 4 pm and we were 2nd in line. By 4:30 pm, the line was growing. We only waited an hour compared to some of the crazy 3 hours that other people have waited. All 4 of us ordered the tori paitan ramen ($16), which was seemingly the most popular! We were all really excited especially just to be some of the first people in the restaurant. 

The tori paitan was incredibly flavorful, creamy, and THICK! Like others have said, the tori paitan broth has more of a sauce or gravy-like consistency rather than your normal thinner broth. If you don't like heavy meals... don't get the tori paitan. You're probably better off with the lighter shoyu or shio ramen (both look delicious!). The tori paitan broth got a bit too rich as I was finishing the bowl. However, I enjoyed it! I normally order tonkotsu at ramen places, so the chicken flavor was definitely something different to try out. 

The noodles are round and thicker than your average (think chow mein noodle size), but perfectly cooked and chewy. As for the toppings, the chasu was melt in your mouth delicious, but the duck was subpar for me. My friends and I also thought there should be a little more veggies just to lighten up the heavy bowl. I liked the bonito flakes, but the small amounts of kale and bamboo shoots did not cut it for us. But we did really like the toppings on the tables! The red salt was something we'd never seen before, and the other brown seasoning (smells like bonito flakes) was pretty tasty.

By the time we left at 6 pm, the line outside was crazy! If you don't like waiting, definitely don't come around that time. You're better off coming anywhere from 4-4:30 pm. The restaurant seats less than 30 people at one time, and it seems like there's a slow turnover rate. Mensho was good, but I probably wouldn't wait 2-3 hours for it.

excerpts: I got the Tori Paitan Ramen.
IMO, way greasy.
I know, I know, its like eating fried chicken and wanting it to be healthy.
Blah blah.
I did actually like the flavor and consistency of the broth; quite viscous and oily (perfect for coating ramen!).
The duck was actually very well cooked
and so was the chasu.
We also got the shoyu ramen.
I love the noodles of this bowl.
Thin and wavy.
The broth was also a lot less greasy, but still flavorful.
My friend just got back from Japan and said that he actually preferred the ramen here to some that he had on holidays.
tori paitan ramen.author: Crystal Z.
tori paitan ramen.review:
TL;DR - Hype worthy? You betcha. Personally, I'm just not that into ramen anymore. (I kinda consider it a sick-day kinda craving)

Wait time. Honestly, not terrible. Showed up at 7:30 and only took us about 20 minutes. 

Inside, clean and compact. I love that they have the baskets on the floor for your stuff. -Ahem- Us ladies and our purses.

Finally, food. I got the Tori Paitan Ramen. IMO, way greasy. I know, I know, its like eating fried chicken and wanting it to be healthy. Blah blah. I did actually like the flavor and consistency of the broth; quite viscous and oily (perfect for coating ramen!). The duck was actually very well cooked and so was the chasu. We also got the shoyu ramen. I love the noodles of this bowl. Thin and wavy. The broth was also a lot less greasy, but still flavorful. My friend just got back from Japan and said that he actually preferred the ramen here to some that he had on holidays. Haha.

Side note, this is the only ramen place I've ever seen that charges more for a vegetarian dish than a meat dish. What a shame. Not sure if I would be willing to drop $20 for veggie ramen, ya dig?

Overall, yes, the 4-star rating of Mensho is pretty accurate. But if ramen isn't your thing, I'd pass on Mensho as there are plenty of other places to dine in SF.

excerpts: The duo of chashu were perfection just like in the Tori Paitan ramen.
tori paitan ramen.author: Cherylynn N.
tori paitan ramen.review:
4.5 STARS

San Franciscans love shiny new places (and things). 

When it comes to the hottest new restaurant and food trends, many of us spare no expense with our paycheck (and time).

Last year, it was $8 for toast. Ok, not just "toast" but phuckin' bougie, tweezified toast. 

This year, it's $15 coffee (for one cup!) and $18 ramen.

Because, San Francisco! 

Next year, I'm bracing myself for $100 pizza. Oh wait, we already had that during the super bowl (well, I didn't but it was available at Tony's Pizza Napoletana). 

Seriously, what's next? 

Kindly let me know so I can start harvesting my eggs to sell! 

$18 ramen may sound crazy but people waited 3+ hours for this ramen on opening night! 

$18 for a taste of Tokyo? Why not! 

Mensho's first U.S. location is one of the most, if not the most highly anticipated restaurant opening this year in SF! 

Tip: Come at 4 pm (earlier on the weekends) or after 10 pm to avoid long wait times. 

Currently, Mensho has 4 ramen options available ($9-$18) with a single or double chashu option. When the owner returns from Japan in March, their menu will expand. No housemade noodles yet. They have a noodle machine but are awaiting permit(s) to use it (same for the tonkotsu equipment). Disappointingly no marinated soft boiled egg is available but maybe in the future? Beer only; no sake, soda, or juice.

My friend and I ordered three bowls of ramen to share:

(1) Tori Paitan: Rich, creamy chicken soup, pork chashu, duck chashu, menma, kale, burdock, katsuobushi sauce | double chashu $18
http://bit.ly/1XrzETT

Our favorite of the three, the kotteri broth was deliciously creamy (gravy-like) and richly satisfying. It had great depth of umami flavor but did get a bit gritty mid-way. The al-dente noodles were thick, springy, and had a fantastic toothsome chew. 

The chashu is sublime so pony up the extra $ and double up on it! The pork chashu is melt-in-your-mouth tender, like pork butter. It's so ridiculously tender, it falls apart when you pick it up. The duck chashu is silky smooth and chews effortlessly.

The only other ramen shop that offers Tori Paitan is Nojo Ramen Tavern (that I'm aware of). I tried Nojo's last night and there's absolutely no comparison. Mensho's is infinitely superior. 

(2) Organic Shoyu: Organic chicken + pork soup, shoyu dare, pork chashu, duck chashu, kale, kale sprouts, chives, menma, nori | double chashu $16
http://bit.ly/1QfmuKm

A much lighter assari broth but saltier with a slight sweetness since it's a soy sauce based. The duo of chashu were perfection just like in the Tori Paitan ramen. I didn't like the noodles which were overcooked, flat, and lacked chew. 

(3) Shio: Organic chicken + pork soup, shio dare, pork chashu, kale, menma, chives, fried garlic, nori | double chashu $11
http://bit.ly/1Loeijq

The most affordable bowl available, the shio ramen was simple and pure. The assari broth was light and salty but still had depth. Same delicious chashu as the other bowls but the noodles were disappointing like the shoyu ramen. In this bowl, not only were the noodles overcooked, there were two clumps. *sad pouty lip*

(4) Vegan Tantanmen | $18
I'm kicking myself for NOT ordering this too because I love nuts! The broth contains soy cream and 7 kinds of nuts, producing a creamy kotteri broth that looked similar to the Tori Paitan.

I washed everything down with a Sansho beer ($11.75): http://bit.ly/1Px6vnx. Beer usually tastes like carbonated piss to me but this one was refreshing with a gingery lemon spice. Loved it but not the price. 

Service is a work in progress which is understandable since this is Mensho's first foray in the U.S.. They only let 8 or so customers in at a time to not overwhelm the kitchen. They don't fire up orders by tickets, instead they prepare the ramen by type (they really should do the former). We received our order at different times and after people who ordered after us. If your companion(s) orders different ramen than yourself, be prepared to start eating first before the noodles get soggy. 

When I was line I met one of the restaurant partners, Abram aka Ramen Beast. He was uber nice and offered to answer any questions I had. Really cool guy! 

The space is small and only seats 28 - two communal tables and four seats at the counter. We choose to sit at the counter. There's more privacy (if you're on a date) and you can watch the chefs in action.

Read all signs before parking. Do NOT park on Geary from 4-6 pm (tow-away zone) on the weekdays, otherwise your $18 bowl of ramen will turn into a $618+ bowl of ramen. 

Because, San Francisco!

excerpts: Once we got in, we both ordered the Tori Paitan Ramen (Double Chashu) $18.
Best decision ever.
It was filled with mouthwatering noodles, tender Duck and Pork Chashu, Kale, Menma, Burdock and Katsuobushi Sauce.
The broth itself was rich, creamy and just overall yummy.
It was piping hot too, which was a plus.
Unfortunately, there wasn't an option to add a soft boiled egg yet.
tori paitan ramen.author: Chinsin S.
tori paitan ramen.review:
Solid five-star ramen place in San Francisco. To be honest, I never heard about MENSHO TOKYO until they came to the Bay Area, but decided to check it out based on the hype.

**Side announcement: The wait staff was super friendly and informative. I definitely loved their customer experience, especially when they work at such a fast-pace and crowded restaurant like this one**

Our party of 2 waited for about an hour or so after 10 pm, which wasn't too bad! The only thing that was a bit concerning was the neighborhood and constant loiters. Parking was tricky too, so I'd definitely recommend taking an Uber here. *PRO TIP: Send one of your friends to wait in line if you need to find parking. There's no list, but just a straight up old school line.*

Once we got in, we both ordered the Tori Paitan Ramen (Double Chashu) $18. Best decision ever. It was filled with mouthwatering noodles, tender Duck and Pork Chashu, Kale, Menma, Burdock and Katsuobushi Sauce. The broth itself was rich, creamy and just overall yummy. It was piping hot too, which was a plus. Unfortunately, there wasn't an option to add a soft boiled egg yet. Bummer, but the staff said it was coming soon!

The noodles themselves were thicker than usual, which was unique and different. I actually enjoyed them. They were perfectly cooked and chewy. The Chasu was so amazing that they melted in my mouth. I was indifferent about the Duck Chashu and leaned more towards the Pork Chashu.

Overall, this a great ramen place. It's probably in the the top 5 Bay Area ramen places by far. I was hesitant at first, but this place was definitely delicious beyond disbelief! I'm a MENSHO TOKYO fan.

excerpts: I ordered the Tori Paitan Ramen and bf ordered the same thing with chashu (to this day I kick myself for not ordering something different but at the time I wanted to try their most popular dish and wasn't sure if I would be happy just having half).
tori paitan ramen.author: Noelle H.
tori paitan ramen.review:
I saw that Mensho Tokyo's Grand Opening would be Saturday at 6pm. I figured if we couldn't see Alicia Keys for free, we should try and at least try some authentic ramen. 

Alicia Keys was a no since it was wayy over capacity. So me and the bf headed on over to Mensho Tokyo. We arrived at 5:30 and the line was fairly long ( I think there was about 70 people in front of us?). But I was determined to try it! 

After 3.5 hours standing outside in line (this was by far the longest I have ever waited for anything, so the expectations were high!) we were finally in front of the door and we were seated at the bar in the back. In my opinion, those 4 seats are the best seats in the house! You don't have eager people staring at you the entire time you're eating and you're seating facing the kitchen!

Drink orders were taken and we immediately placed our order for ramen. I ordered the Tori Paitan Ramen and bf ordered the same thing with chashu (to this day I kick myself for not ordering something different but at the time I wanted to try their most popular dish and wasn't sure if I would be happy just having half). 

This was my first time having paitan ramen and I loved it! So incredibly rich and flavorful, almost gravy like. The noodles were thick and chewy, by far the best I've ever had! I'm not a fan of pork and usually don't eat it, but the chasu was OUT OF THIS WORLD. Super tender and melt in your mouth. All the components that came in the bowl complimented each other well and it indeed, was a spectacular bowl of ramen. 

Was it worth the 3.5 hour wait? Yes, I believe it was. It was also the most expensive bowl of ramen I've ever paid for, but I think it was worth it as well. 

If you're willing to wait, then come here!!! You'll be rewarded with the best ramen in the Bay!

excerpts: and I both chose the spicy Tori Paitan Ramen
and it came out pretty quickly!!
Instantly you can tell the broth is going to be thick and fatty..yumm!!
The noodles were the perfect amount of chewy and thickness and the pork belly was seasoned really well.
I have a small appetite
so I usually don't finish my food at restaurants, but I cleared my bowl :
If you're a fan of thick and fatty ramen broths I would recommend this place, but if you prefer more clean and lighter broths, maybe get the shoyu?
tori paitan ramen.author: Hannah C.
tori paitan ramen.review:
Mensho ramen is one the best places in the bay area to get ramen ( in my opinion), BUT the wait is realllllyyy long :(!! My boyfriend and I waited 2 hours in the FREEZING WINDY COLD weather in San Fran :/ but the wait was worth it!! The shop is really small so we understood why the line was so long.
My boyfriend and I got seated in front of the kitchen so we got to see the chefs make the ramen which was pretty cool! My boyfriend and I both chose the spicy Tori Paitan Ramen and it came out pretty quickly!! 
Instantly you can tell the broth is going to be thick and fatty..yumm!! The noodles were the perfect amount of chewy and thickness and the pork belly was seasoned really well. 
I have a small appetite so I usually don't finish my food at restaurants, but I cleared my bowl :D!! 
If you're a fan of thick and fatty ramen broths I would recommend this place, but if you prefer more clean and lighter broths, maybe get the shoyu?

excerpts:
* *
Tori Paitan Ramen: A+.
Oh boy that soup base
.... it was the thickest/creamiest ramen soup I have ever tasted.
I almost  regard that as a paste.
The taste was super rich and flavorful yet non-oily nor too salty.
After weeks I still remember how the soup tasted like.
It came with both pork and duck chashu; pork was tender as expected but the duck was surprisingly juicy as well.
The noodle was also one of the thickest I have tried with spongy texture.
The whole presentation definitely makes this the best ramen I have ever tried in the US without a doubt.
tori paitan ramen.author: Simon C.
tori paitan ramen.review:
After reading the raving reviews of this place I had been wanting to try this place so badly. On a weekend night I was done with gym close by and got pretty hungry, so I decided to just forget my workout and gain all my calories back...!

* * * EXPERIENCE * * *
Pros:
- Friendly staff (even though the place was always full and they were working nonstop)
- Simple and neat decorations and furnitures
- TV which was showing an interview with the founder/owner of this place explaining the uniqueness of their food (for ramen enthusiast)
- Food came fairly quickly

Cons:
- Looooooong wait outside the restaurant: Thursday night, started lining up at 8:30pm, waited for 1 whole hour
- Kind of pricey
- Cramped interior (almost elbow to elbow)

* * * FOOD * * *
Tori Paitan Ramen: A+.
Oh boy that soup base.... it was the thickest/creamiest ramen soup I have ever tasted. I almost  regard that as a paste. The taste was super rich and flavorful yet non-oily nor too salty. After weeks I still remember how the soup tasted like. It came with both pork and duck chashu; pork was tender as expected but the duck was surprisingly juicy as well. The noodle was also one of the thickest I have tried with spongy texture. The whole presentation definitely makes this the best ramen I have ever tried in the US without a doubt. With double chashu this ramen cost $18, SF price on the high side.

Sansho Beer: B+.
Yes, I did order that $11.75/11.5oz beer. How could a beer be so expensive I was thinking. Well, it did have its own unique flavor - it's an interesting combination of herbs, peppercorn into a beer, and it did go well with the thick ramen soup in a way that it flushed out the soup taste from the last bite so that every next bite was new and refreshing. But after all, I still have to say this beer is VERY expensive.

I absolutely cannot wait to go back either to get the same ramen again, or the Tantanmen looks very interesting to me too.

excerpts: I ordered the tori paitan ramen with double chashu.
Broth was salty.
I usually don't drink the broth but with this bowl, it was different!
I kept wanting more!
Had to restrain myself.
The ramen was pretty simple with the toppings.
In addition to the chashu, toppings came with lettuce, kale, chives, and what I think was fried garlic skin?
Was super sad that they didn't have the soft boiled egg offered as a topping!
The chashu was melt-in-your-mouth amazing!
Glad
tori paitan ramen.author: Cynthia T.
tori paitan ramen.review:
TLDR: clean place, long wait, delicious ramen, limited menu, friendly service, will try again for sure! 

Thank goodness I had my friends go first and met them there. They got there at 6:45 and we finally got in at 8pm. This place is very very small. They have four tables that fits six people each and the bar that fits four people. 

It was raining today. Quite surprised by the amount of people willing to wait in this weather!Next to the entryway, they have hooks numbered 1-10 to hang up your belongings. If the hooks are all occupied, no need to fret! They have baskets under the tables to put your belongings in as well! Very clever idea that I think more places need to implement! The place is very very clean! 

I ordered the tori paitan ramen with double chashu.  Broth was salty. I usually don't drink the broth but with this bowl, it was different! I kept wanting more! Had to restrain myself. The ramen was pretty simple with the toppings. In addition to the chashu, toppings came with lettuce, kale, chives, and what I think was fried garlic skin? Was super sad that they didn't have the soft boiled egg offered as a topping! The chashu was melt-in-your-mouth amazing! Glad I got the double for sure. 

Service was super friendly! Constantly came around to check if everything was okay at our table and refilled our waters. Limited menu so I'll definitely be back to try their other ramen bowls!

excerpts: I got the Tori Paitan ramen since they don't have tonkotsu on the soft opening menu yet.
The soup was SUPER thick, rich, and creamy, almost like a chicken stew broth.
It was rich but at just the right amount of salty.
tori paitan ramen.author: Hoyan L.
tori paitan ramen.review:
So happy to see SF finally expanding on its ramen scene! I have been waiting to give this place a try since the grand opening day on Saturday, but the mob of people on grand opening day was crazy! We left and came back on a weekday night around 8:30pm and the wait was only about 40 minutes, even shorter if you are a solo diner! 

I got the Tori Paitan ramen since they don't have tonkotsu on the soft opening menu yet. The soup was SUPER thick, rich, and creamy, almost like a chicken stew broth. It was rich but at just the right amount of salty. It was a little on the heavy side, so you prefer lighter soup, you should go for shio or shoyu. 

The noodles were cooked to perfect al dente, thicker than usual which gave a very nice chew. The duck chashu was luxurious and tender. The pork chashu was melt in your mouth good. Towards the later half of my ramen, I started tasting these little bits of grit or sandy like texture in the broth which threw me off a little bit (hence not perfect 5 stars) I'm not sure if that is how the broth should be? 

They are still working out the kinks (i.e., not giving me a pen to sign my credit card txn, forgot about refilling water, etc), but I am pretty excited about this new ramen place in SF and I can't wait to go back to try their tonkotsu and tsukemen when they become available! This place still hasn't won the Orenchi spot in my heart yet though, and also Tenderloin is sketchy at night.

I was debating if I should visit this place some more to try their other ramen before writing a yelp, but then I also want to be in their first 50th reviews list... :)

excerpts: I ordered the Tori Paitan Ramen which was DELICIOUS!
I noticed that everyone at our communal table was eating the same thing.
If you like rich, creamy ramen, this is your dish!
It was so rich that I couldn't finish it all, but that is definitely some of the best ramen I have ever head.
It's very hearty, filling, with pork & duck chasu.
The noodles were also pretty thick.
She was kind enough to take my husband's dish back and he ordered the Tori Paitan and ate the entire thing!
tori paitan ramen.author: Chisholm T.
tori paitan ramen.review:
I freaking love ramen, so the second my husband mentioned this new place I was stoked! However walking up to the restaurant, all we could see was a big line out the door. We almost left, but the line was moving a little faster than we thought it would so we stayed and I'm so glad we did! We came on a Wednesday night around 7:30 PM and waited about 45 min before we were seated. But time went by very quickly. As you get closer to the door, an employee will hand you a menu so that you can figure out what you want while you are waiting in line.

Mensho Tokyo is very small. It reminded me of the ramen noodle stalls in Japan. Not a lot of space, but the service is very quick so people are constantly going in and out. All of the tables in the restaurant are communal, so you'll be sitting with other people. Since there isn't a lot of room for you to put your purse, backpack, jacket, etc. they place baskets underneath the tables for you to store your belongings. Thoughtful little touch! 

As soon as we sat down, we were greeted by our server who took our order right away. I ordered the Tori Paitan Ramen which was DELICIOUS! I noticed that everyone at our communal table was eating the same thing. If you like rich, creamy ramen, this is your dish! It was so rich that I couldn't finish it all, but that is definitely some of the best ramen I have ever head. It's very hearty, filling, with pork & duck chasu. The noodles were also pretty thick. Very yummy dish!

My husband got the Organic Shoyu which was served with a clear, organic chicken and pork broth. Also served with pork & duck chasu. Unfortunately he didn't like his dish and it's because it had a very fishy flavor. He asked me to try it and I could immediately smell the fish scent. Neither of us like fish but we didn't know this dish would have fish flavor since it didn't mention it anywhere in the entree description. My husband asked our server if there was fish in the ramen and she confirmed yes, and that a good way to indicate that is if you see Nori as one of the ingredients. We were glad she told us that little fun fact so that we could keep it in mind for future ordering! She was kind enough to take my husband's dish back and he ordered the Tori Paitan and ate the entire thing!

We left Mensho feeling very full and happy. This place is a genuine ramen restaurant that serves amazing food and quick service. Worth standing in line for!

excerpts: The Tori Paitan Ramen was absolutely delicious!
A little pricey for a ramen joint!
But the broth was so rich and it tasted amazing!
I got the double (double chashu) for $2 more.
$18 is definitely steep for a bowl of ramen
but I say it was worth the try!
tori paitan ramen.author: Daniel S.
tori paitan ramen.review:
I am a fan of Mensho! Just not a fan of the lines.

This place is ALWAYS packed and there is always a line out the door. The restaurant is pretty small. If you get there about 15 minutes before opening (5pm) you should be able to get a seat! But other than that be prepared to wait a while!

The Tori Paitan Ramen was absolutely delicious! A little pricey for a ramen joint! But the broth was so rich and it tasted amazing! I got the double (double chashu) for $2 more. $18 is definitely steep for a bowl of ramen but I say it was worth the try!

excerpts: I ordered the Tori Paitan Ramen which came with both Duck and Pork Chashu.
It seems that most people who enjoy this place love the thick broth, but for me the broth was a bit too thick.
Extremely fatty to the point I couldn't quite enjoy the flavour.
I feel if the broth wasn't so thick I would have enjoyed this place more, but don't let me stop you from trying this place!
Seems many people enjoy it.
tori paitan ramen.author: Galen W.
tori paitan ramen.review: To be honest I'm not quite sure what the Hype is all about. I ordered the Tori Paitan Ramen which came with both Duck and Pork Chashu. It seems that most people who enjoy this place love the thick broth, but for me the broth was a bit too thick. Extremely fatty to the point I couldn't quite enjoy the flavour. I feel if the broth wasn't so thick I would have enjoyed this place more, but don't let me stop you from trying this place! Seems many people enjoy it.

excerpts: If the broth for their Tori Paitan Ramen is this viscous then I can't wait to try their Tsukemen version.
tori paitan ramen.author: Taffany H.
tori paitan ramen.review:
It takes duck, pork, fish, and many more deep secret animal umami taste to make a broth this complex. But you can't quite distinguish the complexity of all that's happening in your mouth, since it's all muddled up together. 

And this is what it taste like to brew-up a broth so deep, viscously caramel creamy brown that makes waiting 40 minutes for a bowl of ramen worth while. Ramen is truly a religion and each of us have our own sect we follow. Some likes it porky, some likes citrusy with yuzu, and some just like it thick and muddy. Mensho ramen definitely makes a legitimate ramen fare. If the broth for their Tori Paitan Ramen is this viscous then I can't wait to try their Tsukemen version.

excerpts: Tori Paitan ramen

tori paitan ramen.review:
My friend Bryan and I waited two full hours for three bowls of Ramen from Mensho Tokyo. Here's how it went down and read more to be convinced it is worth the wait.

Mensho Tokyo Ramen opened exactly three weeks ago, February 6, 2016. Mensho Tokyo is one of Japan's most popular ramen spots, and San Francisco is its first attempt in North America. I spoke to Abram during my visit, where he told me that the owner has a total of 8 ramen bars in Tokyo, and each of them has its unique menu including Mensho Tokyo so this is not your typical franchise. The two-hour wait was a bit long, but I occasionally chatted with ramen lovers in line, and kept myself occupied.

The hype for this ramen shop is not going to slow down anytime, because of the quality of the ramen it offers. After having lived in Vancouver for more than half my life, and have visited Tokyo and had authentic ramen, I can say that the Organic Shoyu flavour in Mensho Tokyo this is the best bowl of ramen I have ever had in the West Coast of North America.

What I recommend to order:
1) Organic Shoyu ramen
2) Tantan Vegan ramen, add chase
3) Tori Paitan ramen

excerpts: I got the tori paitan ramen, which consists of a lovely chicken soup, pork chashu, duck chashu, menma, kale, burdock, and katsuobushi sauce.

excerpts:
The FOOD:

Friend and I ordered the same thing: the Tori Paitan Ramen with a soy sauce egg (+$1.80/each).
tori paitan ramen.author: Lenerd J.
tori paitan ramen.review:
I've passed this place a couple of times and there's ALWAYS a long line (at least 10+ people) but this time friend and I got there around 8:15ishPM and we waited about 15-20 mins - there were 4-5 groups in front of us. Mostly pairs of people. We got to the front of the line and there's a menu on a podium. There was a note that this is a "Gratuity Free" restaurant - a flat rate of 15% is added to all diners check. This was a little off putting at first but I came to agree with the flat rate percentage. I'll make more comments further below to support my decision.

Ambiance and seating:

Great ambiance. They have three main tables: the largest seating 10-12 individuals and the other two tables seat 6 people each. The tables are elevated and have barstool seats. The tables are interesting in a sense that there's a gap built into the table, large enough to slide a thin-ish purse (anything wider than 3 inches might not fit) or a wallet and phone into the space if you don't want to put your purse on the floor. There is a coat hook by the door (I believe another person posted a photo of this). My friend and I were seated across from each over and next to us was another pair. Seating is a shared experience - most people seem to be seated across from their partner with exception of one pair that sat side to side. The fact that they only have three tables sort of suggests this. The ambiance is very welcoming, bright, and clean. Lots of chatter and you may need to raise your voice a little bit to hear your friend/SO, but definitely nice. Music in the background seemed pretty varied. It wasn't stuck on a specific radio with one type of music. There was also a TV mounted above the rest room, but it was playing on mute and no captions. It appeared to be on a loop and I believe it was more of an infomercial for the restaurant (?) - unclear.

The FOOD:

Friend and I ordered the same thing: the Tori Paitan Ramen with a soy sauce egg (+$1.80/each). Menu doesn't offer that ramen as spicy but you can request Habanero (+$2/each) to spice it up - it came out in a slightly chopped/pulverized paste; makes it easier to mix into the broth in my opinion. We also ordered fried garlic (+$2) which came out in a diced form (see photo). I tried the broth first and it was sooooo delicious!! It had a milkier consistency than what I've had at other ramen places but the balance was great. It wasn't too salty nor under seasoned but just right. The chasiu was SO perfect - cooked to the point where it's falling apart when you try to bite down. I LOVED the texture and al dente-ness of the ramen. I personally prefer ramen noodles (and wonton noodles) with more of a resistance when I bite into it. I hate it when noodles are cooked to the point that they're falling apart when I pick them up with chop sticks. I cannot rave enough about their noodles!!! There were a few leaves of kale, some cabbage, bamboo shoots, and some fried/baked veg that I can't put my finger on that was also in the broth.I recognize the fried/baked beg but can't remember the name. At some point, friend and I weren't talking. We were slurping and eating intensely.

The drink menu consisted mostly of Asian (?) beers, sake, and soju. I don't believe any sodas were on the menu. Water is always an option 

The SERVICE:

Great! There were three ladies taking orders,serving, and clearing tables. All of them were efficient and unobtrusive. Sometimes I feel very rushed or I'm waiting a long time to place my order but here, it felt like when I glanced around, one of the ladies immediately sensed my eyes and came right over. Everyone had a smile and was offering refills at a good rate. Food came out about 10 mins after ordering and when we were slowing down and coming to the end of our meal, I didn't feel pressured to hurry up, pay, and get out. We slowly savored the broth and when WE were done, someone came up and asked if they could take away our bowls - definitely appreciate the attention the servers give. Not too much but enough to know they're there. 

All in all I would DEFINITELY come here again...I'll keep my fingers crossed that there won't be a hella long line.

tori paitan ramen.review:
This place deserves all the hype and it worth the wait in line. I was skeptical at first but with one bite of the Tori Paitan ramen, my only thought was 'Whoa, that's good!'

It is a creamier, heavier broth than most ramen places but oh so very very flavorful. Also, the noodles were cooked perfectly. They were not soft and soogy which is a bit of a no no for me. Noodle texture is important. The kale was tasty too and a good veggie in the bowl.

My friend and I arrived at 645 pm on a Thursday night. There were about 12 people in front of us, but mostly couples so the line went by fast. We were seated about 25 minutes and happily slurping away our noodles about 10 minutes after that. It is a small place but the service is good and attentive when needed.

Only criticism is the price as I am not sure a bowl of ramen should be that much $ and also my cha-su was super fatty -too fatty for me to eat. Other than that, I will be going back!

Ramen is definitely a preference thing. 
The tori paitan is very flavorful and on the lighter side.
tori paitan ramen.author: tsubasa m.
tori paitan ramen.review:
Probably the best ramen in sf. 

One of the few Tori paitan ramen in the Bay Area. 
Ramen is definitely a preference thing. Some prefer miso, shoyu, tonkotsu, etc

Oh btw it is not tonkatsu. It's tonkotsu. Tonkatsu is pork cutlet. Tonkotsu is pork bone. Get it right.

The tori paitan is very flavorful and on the lighter side. 
I'm not a fan of the very heavy "kotteri" soup that is very popular in the Bay Area.

They also have great noodles. I prefer the thicker noodles  "chijiri" rather than the thin noodles. 

Since we have not gotten Ichiran, ippudo, or afuri ramen yet in the Bay Area, this is probably the best place at the moment.

As soon as a couple was leaving, my girlfriend and I was seated. It was kind of awkward at first because the seating distance between me and my neighbors between me were too close. As soon as we finished ordering, the workers there were kind enough to wait for the five people that were sitting around us to finish eating altogether and offered them seats to my brothers and friends! probably the best chashu in a ramen that i've had.

tori paitan ramen.review:
Three stars for the noodles themselves. The soups I tried left much to be desired. Neither ramen that I tried would bring me back. I feel like I'm supposed to like this place because it's so hot right now. and new. and from tokyo. but, it's just okay. 

gomenaisai not gomenasai.

++1/2 Oysters in Shoyu Dare Oil. (3 pieces) $5

This was good; a nice, simple appetizer. the oysters aren't large, and seems like something that came out of a can, frankly, but still, I liked it and would order it again. It just works.

++ Tori Paitan Ramen (Double Chashu) $18
(Rich and Creamy Chicken Soup, Pork Chashu, Duck Chashu, Menma, Kale, Burdock, Katsuobushi Sauce)

Ahhh... I can't eat this. It sounds good, smells good, looks good as food porn, but it is SO RICH. It's just short of being a gravy. I ordered this on my first visit and made a mental note not to order it again. On my second visit, I didn't order it, but when I smelled it and saw it, I doubted my decision. Then I had a sip of the soup and I was like nope. The noodles are really chewy, and the soup flavor is good, but after the first few bites it already feels like too much. 


++ Organic Shoyu Ramen (Double Chashu) $16
(Clear Organic Chicken and Pork Soup, Shoyu Dare, Pork Chashu, Duck Chashu, Kale, Kale Sprouts,Chives, Menma, Nori)

The duck was okay; chashu was better but it was nice to have another meat choice in the ramen. I think it was hard to notice the chashu in the tori paitan, due to the decadence of the soup, but in the shoyu, the chashu is a fatty standout. probably the best chashu in a ramen that i've had. the noodles in the shoyu are good, but different - thinner and lighter than it's tori paitan counterpart. it paired well w/ the shoyu broth. The broth itself tasted like bonito more than shoyu. 


I would not come back for these two ramen dishes, but I still want to come back to try the other options. As for the wait, we waited about 30 minutes the first time, and maybe 20 minutes the second time. Not bad at all. Once you're in, though, the seats and ambiance are not intended to have patrons stay and shoot the shit. They want you in and out -- in that sense, it's a traditional ramen experience.

excerpts: I ordered the Shoyu ramen and oysters in dare oil, while my boyfriend ordered the Tori Paitan ramen and the enoki fries.
The reason I rate this restaurant a 2/5 is because both the oysters and the Shoyu ramen were INCREDIBLY salty and UNEDIBLE.
Furthermore, the Shoyu broth, made from chicken and pork broth, tasted so strongly of just fish - bonito flakes to be exact.
I had to ask them for a bowl of broth to mix in to reduce the saltiness, but even that was not enough to counteract the saltiness.
I've never had any ramen this salty before, which is a shame.
I feel like they need to constantly check the flavor of their broth, which I'm sure became more concentrated due to evaporation.
Furthermore, their Shoyu ramen has strange noodles that were slightly soft and overcooked.
I much prefer the thicker, al dente cooked noodles that my boyfriend had in his Tori Paitan noodles.
Also, duck chashu is just not that great.
The Tori Paitan was really thick which I don't enjoy much, but the broth tasted fine.

tori paitan ramen.review:
I came here yesterday with my boyfriend after shopping in Union Square. It wasn't too bad of a wait for a Sunday night at 7pm, but I was a bit confused that they didn't seat us when there were multiple seats opened and ready. It makes me believe that they seat people in waves, which is fine. 

I ordered the Shoyu ramen and oysters in dare oil, while my boyfriend ordered the Tori Paitan ramen and the enoki fries. The reason I rate this restaurant a 2/5 is because both the oysters and the Shoyu ramen were INCREDIBLY salty and UNEDIBLE. Furthermore, the Shoyu broth, made from chicken and pork broth, tasted so strongly of just fish - bonito flakes to be exact. I had to ask them for a bowl of broth to mix in to reduce the saltiness, but even that was not enough to counteract the saltiness. I've never had any ramen this salty before, which is a shame. I feel like they need to constantly check the flavor of their broth, which I'm sure became more concentrated due to evaporation. excerpts: The Tori Paitan ramen is on par wtih some of the NY greats like Ippudo and Totto, and the vegan ramen was a revelation for me.
I came in really skeptical mumbling things about mouthfeel and "depth of flavor," but I actually ended up liking it more than the Tori Paitan.
tori paitan ramen.author: Eric W.
tori paitan ramen.review:
Went here last Saturday for the 3rd time and I'm pleased to report that the wait at 7pm for a party of 4 was only 25 mins! Now's your chance folks! 

This is the best ramen place in SF, the bay area, and most likely in California. The Tori Paitan ramen is on par wtih some of the NY greats like Ippudo and Totto, and the vegan ramen was a revelation for me. I came in really skeptical mumbling things about mouthfeel and "depth of flavor," but I actually ended up liking it more than the Tori Paitan. 

And on to the dish that makes me dream about this place -- the spicy mazesoba. It's a dry noodle dish kind of similar to Zha Jiang Mian (black bean noodles) that comes with bbq pork, chashu, and diced habanero. Yes, you read that right, HABANERO. It's hands down the best noodle dish I've ever had, I'm not even joking right now. I tried to order the extra spicy, but the waitress advised against it, as it contains a full 2 diced habanero. Next time! 

Finally, they have a super delicious IPA called Ozeno Yukidoke for $13 a bottle. Yes, that's super duper expensive for an ipa, but it's really really good and you should at least try it once if you're into IPAs. 

The dishes here range from $13 for shio ramen, and up to around $18 for the extra spicy mazesoba.

excerpts: I ordered the Tori paitan double chasu ramen, my hubby ordered their spicy lamb double chasu ramen, and my daughter ordered just the regular tori paitan ramen, which she shared with her grandma and I shared mine with my youngest daughter.
tori paitan ramen.author: Lyn W.
tori paitan ramen.review:
I don't know where to begin... but I will start with their ramen.

I ordered the Tori paitan double chasu ramen, my hubby ordered their spicy lamb double chasu ramen, and my daughter ordered just the regular tori paitan ramen, which she shared with her grandma and I shared mine with my youngest daughter.

We waited for almost an hour in the rain just to get in and have a ramen. Now, the food was good but really overpriced for a ramen that is not even going to blow your mind. Just an FYI, my hubby and I lived in Japan for two years and we had never been given any grief by any staff at a ramen place for sharing our bowl to our family and some of the ramen places we've been in Japan are really good, plus the staff are very polite and respectful.

One of the staff literally came to our table and told us that we are not supposed to share our food because if there is 5 people in our table, we should order 5 bowls of ramen, her reason was because there are people waiting for seats. I mean seriously?? Does she want my mom and youngest daughter to wait outside in the rain because we didn't order them separate bowl of ramen???! 

I was shocked and felt humiliated because people that seating really close to our table heard all what she said to us, it felt like we could not afford to pay for five bowls and we should not eat out if we are just sharing it to the rest of our family. The fact that my youngest daughter only eat tiny amount of food and my mom is also the same, why would I waste 2 bowls of ramen that we can't even take home if we can't finish it?!! Yes, they don't have a to go container so how would they expect us to order more food if it will just end up into waste. 

The hype for getting a good ramen is just not right. Yes the food is good but not going back there again just because their staff have no respect for their paying customer. Hence the one star.

the broth was pretty heavy

tori paitan ramen.author: Grace L.
tori paitan ramen.review: I can see why Mensho is all the ramen hype in San Francisco right now. My friend and I were really lucky when it came to waiting in line- we arrived ten minutes before 6:00pm on a rainy day, waited close to the front of the line, and were ready to be seated half an hour later. However, we still had to wait for our husbands to arrive for the full party of 4. Tori Paitan Ramen 3.5/5

Noodle: 4/5 - the noodle was thick noodle in order to match the Paitan broth. Was cook to katame per my order.

Broth: 4/5 - the broth is solid chicken white soup (Paitan) while I don't complain too much, it was quite plain and there is no much layer of tastes from the veggie. In the default set, there is no menma or bamboo shoots but one thing provided different texture is kyle. (Secret: ask for the spicy sauce to add some in. It's not that spicy, but will totally change your view to the broth)

Chashu: 2/5 - probably the least thing I enjoyed about tonight. It all went into small pieces after my first mix the noodle with the soup. Meanwhile, it's not very flavorful and just totally blended into the soup.

Overall: Service is good. The bill is unfortunate a little bit pricy that comes out to ~$20 per person possibly due to the unaffordable rent in SF. With the same price, I could get me a bowl of good ramen and chicken kara-age in San Mateo or South Bay.

Secret: if you go by yourself and they have one person seat open up, they will accommodate single party first for the empty seat. See there you go the power of being single. I waited only for ~15 minutes in line today.

Baseline: I will go to check it out if I haven't been to this place. I might go back again if I am in SF and I want ramen badly.

Yummy, authentic and decently priced ramen. Just be prepared to wait.

== FOOD ==
Ordered a Tori Paitan Ramen (4/5) and a Shoyu Ramen (4/5).

Tori Paitan broth was thick and full of flavor. The meat that came with it was super soft and tasty, it soaked up all the essence of the soup that makes the meat taste so heavenly. Only wish would be if the noodles could have been more cooked.

The Shoyu Ramen broth was delicious! They had a different type of noodles from the Tori Paitan Ramen, it was pretty good. 

== AMBIENCE / SERVERS / WAIT ==
Street parking available right in front of the shop but only after 6pm. We were there approx. 5.30pm with the plan to beat the crowd, we had to park 2 blocks down. 

There was a line outside, thankfully the weather was good so waiting in line was bearable and considerably comfortable. We waited approx 20mins to get in. The line moved pretty quickly which was great. 

It is a pretty small shop that seats around 30 pax, not advisable for big group outings. Once you are seated, they are prompt to serve you water/tea and take your orders. We waited for 5-8 mins before our food arrived. 

Servers were great, prompt and move like ninja through the narrowly spaced area. Everyone was seated very closely to one another and kinda awkward to have conversations as your neighbours can pretty much hear everything you say!

Waiting for 20mins in a nice weather was fine. If it was any longer, i do not think it would be worth the time/wait.

It has a slight hipster vibe in there. Street parking can be tough, but you can park in an expensive garage a few blocks away, or take the bus. 

They list out some menu items on the wall, but they're not available yet. They currently offer a limited menu with just 4 ramen options. I had the Tori Paitan Ramen. It was delicious. The broth was thick, creamy, very rich and flavorful, but had a slight grittiness. The noodles were chewy and cooked to perfection. Toppings were unique, which I really liked. I had pork chasu and duck, which were both very tender. Since coming back from Japan, a bunch of ramen shops seem a bit mediocre to me. So I'm really glad to say that this was legit.

Service was pretty on point, food didn't take too long to come out and if you know what you want they usually take down your order when you're at the front of the line. 

I got the miso spicy ramen and got to try my friends' Tori Paitan ramen which was pretty on point. 

1) Miso spicy ramen with chashu: comes in a huge bowl and was actually pretty spicy (I like spicy food so it was tolerable but the broth definitely had a kick to it). Afterward my stomach kinda burned...was not expecting the spice to still be so prominent after eating! The chashu was super fatty but in a good way--tender and flavorful. Loved the addition of corn in the dish as well.

2) tori paitan: the broth is soooo thick and creamy but so good! I'd probably get this if I were to go again.

The noodles--super yummy, right amount of chewiness and the broth coated every inch of the noodles. 

Since the place is so small, they definitely try and get you in and out ASAP so they can seat the people waiting in line. Overall, I think the ramen was super good, but not mindblowing. I don't think I'd wait in line for 2 hours for a bowl here--maybe just come here once in a while.

Wow that was an interesting experience...

Got in line around 4:45pm on a Friday - my boyfriend and I both got off work early to stand in line before 5. The line wasn't bad at all. We were maybe the 6th to 8th party in line? After we sat down, there were only a couple parties left standing outside so I would say early Friday isn't a bad time to go! 

How did I not see any reviews about really HOW SMALL this place is?! Honestly, it seems like the size of a boba, ice cream, or froyo place... It's so small, you don't even get your own table. You sit very closely next to strangers on the same table, unless you get one of the four seats at the bar. It was a little...too cozy for my liking. Definitely not a place to spill juicy secrets with a friend if you don't want your table neighbors potentially listening in also. I'm quite a small person but I still would've preferred to have more space. I sat at the table closest to the bar and I kept getting bumped into by people walking toward or serving the people at the bar. Also, you're sitting on bar stools and have to put your coats and bags in baskets underneath the tall table. I like having my stuff a little closer to me but oh well. They also played their music really loudly so it was a little harder to have a conversation - and it was already hard because people were talking right next to us.

Alright, onto the food. My boyfriend and I both got the Tori Paitan Ramen. Wow that was the creamiest, thickest, richest ramen broth I've ever tried. I can't even really compare it to others - it's just on a whole other level. It comes with one slice of chashu and two small slices of duck. It was good but I don't think it was truly worth $16. Honestly, I did get tired of the creaminess halfway through my bowl. It just started to become too much - and out of my boyfriend and I, I typically like the creamy, tonkatsu flavored broths so that says something. Maybe this type of rich ramen just isn't for me? 

I think because of its authenticity and taste, we give it 4 stars. It's not 5 stars because the overall experience was only okay and we didn't think it was worth $16. It was definitely cool to try but might not make the effort to come again.

Imagine Wal-Mart during Black Friday, that's exactly what Mensho Tokyo was like. 
If you walk in the TL and see a long line out the door, it's most likely Mensho. 

Authentic ramen from JAPAN?! Count me in to join in on the hype! Gave it a couple days to let the crowd simmer down a bit... Not that it really has.... 

Did my research and realized that in order to get in first seating you have to be there around 4-4:20pm. On a Tuesday, my friend and I came at 4:10pm and were the 3rd ones in line. Around 4:20pm the line was pretty long. I hear that if you come at 5pm (their opening time it would be a TWO hr wait) anything after that is 3-4 hr. HELL NAH. Lol. 

::Parking/Service/Ambiance::
Parking. Ha. Don't even think about it especially after 6pm. Luckily we got there around 4pm and there was parking 5-6 blocks away from the restaurant. Paid $2.25/hr because it was meters. 
It's kind of ironic that a restaurant from Japan opened up in the most ghetto part of SF, in the tenderloins. I felt super scared at night, good thing I was with a guy. 
Service was amazing. While we were in line I think the manager of some sort came out and thanked us for waiting and asked if we have any questions at all. The staff were all friendly too from start to end. 
They fit about 28 people for max capacity says the manager. There were 3 separate benches: one long bench that fits 12, two short bench that fit 6 each, and 4 chairs near the chef window. The place was definitely small but very clean and simple. Below each table were cubbies that reminded me of elementary school where we could fit our small purses or jackets. 
Came at 4:10pm so we were seated immediately and got to order before the large groups came in. 

::BLACK FRIDAY DEALS::
If you want something creamy and thick, go with vegan tantanmen or tori paitan ramen. If you want a lighter base, shio or shoyu.

Tori Paitan ramen 16.00: thick creamy rich chicken soup with BOTH pork chashu and duck chashu topped with menma, kale, burdock, and katsuobushi sauce. The sauce was SO rich and creamy. It wasn't too salty despite the creaminess. However half way through it got too heavy for me. Nonetheless the meat were all melt in your mouth perfection and the noodles were thick and cooked to amazing "bounciness" level.

excerpts: My first impression of their tori paitan ramen was the flawless execution of its individual components.

The noodles were a perfect al dente with some satisfying give to them on every bite; the pork chashu melted away with just right amount of fat and pork flavor; the chicken broth--very creamy and rich, maybe overpoweringly so, but still complex and enjoyable enough to have with every slurp; and the duck chashu...
just wow...
tori paitan ramen.author: Derrek C.
tori paitan ramen.review:
Historically, SF has had mediocore ramen at best, and shit-tier ramen at worst.  Meanwhile, the Peninsula hosts the remarkable Ramen Dojo/Parlor duo, while in the South Bay, solid ramen establishments seem to popup every year.  With Mensho Tokyo, SF can finally compete with all the other titans in the Bay Area.  And they're bringing more than just ramen--their mazesoba is delicious too!

My first impression of their tori paitan ramen was the flawless execution of its individual components.  The noodles were a perfect al dente with some satisfying give to them on every bite; the pork chashu melted away with just right amount of fat and pork flavor; the chicken broth--very creamy and rich, maybe overpoweringly so, but still complex and enjoyable enough to have with every slurp; and the duck chashu...just wow...it's DUCK chashu god dammit, something to die for.  

The whole bowl of ramen, with all of these components, was quite heavy, and might not be for everyone--but if extreme savoriness is your jam, then this might just be the best ramen in the Bay Area for you.

Also of interest is their mazesoba!  It's apparently a recent food trend in Japan, so Mensho Tokyo might currently be one of the only places to offer this dish in the United States.  Regardless, it's absolutely delicious and totally worth trying.  It's essentially a dry bowl of noodles (not quite soba though, a bit thicker and similar in consistency to their ramen) with some vegetable (green onions, chives, watercress, seaweed, garlic, etc.) and meat toppings (ground pork)--somewhat of a cross between bibimbap (it has the raw egg too) and zha jiang mian.  

Mixing it all together is when the magic happens.  Every bite of noodles was accompanied with a saucy mixture of meat, fragant herbs, and crunch from the vegetables.  Why hasn't anyone thought about doing this before?  It's worth mentioning that we got the extra spicy version, and it certainly did pack quite a kick!

The wait on a random Tuesday night was about 2 hours, and when we finished eating at 9ish, the line was still just as long!  Whether or not Mensho Tokyo is worth the steep prices (actually, probably normal pricing for SF) or absurd waiting times is really up to you, but the quality and meticulous execution of their dishes is undeniable.

excerpts: Following the footsteps of fellow Yelpers, we each ordered the Double Chasu Tori Paitan Ramen at $18.
I thought it was a little steep considering that the ramen didn't come with an egg, and double meat really just meant two thin slices of pork chasu and two thin slices of duck chasu.
The duck was definitely the highlight of meal.
The pork was on the salty side.
Noodles were chewy and el dente just the way I like it.
Broth was creamy but so loaded with chicken fat that it was deemed too unhealthy and rich to be drinkable by my friends...
The Tori Paitan was the clear winner here, but if you're not into thick broths, don't even bother coming here.
tori paitan ramen.author: Catherine C.
tori paitan ramen.review:
I hate waiting in lines, but like half of the Asian population in SF I just couldn't resist coming here to test my luck on a Saturday afternoon. I recommend coming 40 mins before opening in order to avoid a 1.5+ hour wait. We almost made it to the first round of seating by coming 20 mins before opening, but clearly there were people out there more determined than we were. The line only got worse after we were done eating around 7pm. 

Following the footsteps of fellow Yelpers, we each ordered the Double Chasu Tori Paitan Ramen at $18. I thought it was a little steep considering that the ramen didn't come with an egg, and double meat really just meant two thin slices of pork chasu and two thin slices of duck chasu. The duck was definitely the highlight of meal. The pork was on the salty side. Noodles were chewy and el dente just the way I like it. Broth was creamy but so loaded with chicken fat that it was deemed too unhealthy and rich to be drinkable by my friends...but I did it anyways! 

The organic shoyu ramen was too salty with strong a undercurrent of bonito and seaweed. The Tori Paitan was the clear winner here, but if you're not into thick broths, don't even bother coming here.

Customer service was efficient, and the greeter at the door was friendly. 

The restaurant seats around 25 people and is pretty tiny. Expect to squeeze with strangers at your table. Decor was clean and modern. I like that they have personal baskets below the table for you to store your purse and jacket. 

Overall worth a try for the duck chasu and delightfully chewy noodles, but not worth repeat visits because of the line.

Come here when you're hungry, borderline starving. I inhaled an açaí bowl as I was leaving work, right before I came here. So my tummy was already a bit too occupied for the super thick broth and chashu and delicious noodles of the Tori Paitan Ramen. The broth is creamy and tastes great, definitely, but it was super thick. The friendly people sitting next to us suggested the vegan ramen for next time. 

Did I mention the restaurant is small and cozy? The plus side is you get to listen to your neighbors talk about girls they like and their game plan to dating them. Interesting. 

I felt ashamed looking at the leftover food. I usually kill my ramen. But I couldn't handle it. On top of that, Mensho does not have take out containers. So like I said.. come here when you're hungry. 

Next time I'll come back after a leg day for the Tori Paitan. Then the vegan ramen for the third time.

tori paitan ramen.review:
The ramen wasn't bad, but it wasn't great. Honestly feel like Mensho is way overhyped. 

We waited in line for almost 2 hours (service is slow and the shop is tiny), so we were really excited to finally sit down and try the ramen. We had the Shoyu and Tori Paitan ramen, and the Tori Paitan was much better than the Shoyu (it was too salty). The broths did taste much more deluxe than other ramen places, but the bowl as a whole didn't impress me with the lack of ingredients and saltiness.

excerpts: Our group ordered mostly the Tori Paitan ramen which appears to be their signature "house" dish.
But I have heard great things about the vegan ramen and I would want to try that
the next time I come back.
The quality of the ramen soup is extremely thick, less like a broth and more like a sauce.
Although the quantity does not look like much, it will be very filling because of how dense the soup is.
Someone also ordered the mazesoba, which is known for a spicy kick and is very delicious.
You can get it at a variety of spice levels, but even the medium was pretty hot.
Their spicy doesn't "linger" the way chili paste sometimes can, but I don't know if I would be able to handle an entire dish of that.
We also asked for a recommendation of sake and got the Dassai, which was so good
tori paitan ramen.author: Maureen C.
tori paitan ramen.review:
When I first heard about Mensho and subsequently read about the art of ramen, I was very excited to come here. By now, surely you must have heard about the potentially monumental wait times. My friends and I arrived at around 4:30 and the six of us were the last to get first seating at 5:00 and it was a pretty good feeling to make it into the door, especially after we turned around and looked at the line that grew behind us. 

Our group ordered mostly the Tori Paitan ramen which appears to be their signature "house" dish. But I have heard great things about the vegan ramen and I would want to try that the next time I come back. The quality of the ramen soup is extremely thick, less like a broth and more like a sauce. Although the quantity does not look like much, it will be very filling because of how dense the soup is. Someone also ordered the mazesoba, which is known for a spicy kick and is very delicious. You can get it at a variety of spice levels, but even the medium was pretty hot. Their spicy doesn't "linger" the way chili paste sometimes can, but I don't know if I would be able to handle an entire dish of that. We also asked for a recommendation of sake and got the Dassai, which was so good it got me reading a bunch of articles about sake making.

My recommendation would be to go with people you like because you should just expect a wait of some substance, know that you will be dropping about $20 for a bowl of ramen, and just enjoy the experience without getting hung up on that other stuff.

excerpts: I ordered the Tori Paitan Ramen with extra Chashu.
The broth was everything I wanted it to be: thick, creamy, fully seasoned, with a hearty feel.
The pork chashu was amazing, and did not disappoint to melt in my mouth.
tori paitan ramen.author: Sarah B.
tori paitan ramen.review:
I went to Mensho Tokyo at 6:15 and was seated around 8:00. Yes, the line was long, but the real question: was it worth it?

I ordered the Tori Paitan Ramen with extra Chashu. The broth was everything I wanted it to be: thick, creamy, fully seasoned, with a hearty feel. The pork chashu was amazing, and did not disappoint to melt in my mouth. The duck was a little less memorable, but still really nice. 

If I had extra time to devote to standing in line every day, I would definitely be a regular! This place is a great addition to the neighborhood, and I love having a remarkable ramen shop right up the street!

excerpts: Tori Paitan Ramen has a full body and very dense broth.
Very flavorful, every sip is a surprise, and it won't get me bored.
Some people might found it a bit too oily or creamy, but I think it is thick yet not too much.
The ramen noodle itself is one of the best noodle I had in the Bay.
All other ingredients are pretty good.
The Shoyu broth is very good, too.
It is saltier than the Tori Paitan, which it should be.
tori paitan ramen.author: Zack Y.
tori paitan ramen.review:
I really wanna give this place a bad review and make people stop going, so I can skip the long wait at their door.

This place ain't gonna be a typical ramen shop that you may find near the bay, the ramen is close to a traditional Japanese ramen.

You should be there before they open, like 4:30 is a good time to be there, and sometimes that even won't make you in the top 3. If you be there at 5, expect at least half an hour wait. By 5:30, it is going to be at least 1.5 hour wait.

The place didn't even have a sign outside, and the address on Yelp is wrong(672 is the right one.) Inside is pretty small that only have around 30 settings. Interior is good, lets get to the food.

Tori Paitan Ramen has a full body and very dense broth. Very flavorful, every sip is a surprise, and it won't get me bored. Some people might found it a bit too oily or creamy, but I think it is thick yet not too much. The ramen noodle itself is one of the best noodle I had in the Bay. All other ingredients are pretty good. The Shoyu broth is very good, too. It is saltier than the Tori Paitan, which it should be. I have not yet tried the shio base yet, will try it next time.

over all very good, service may not be the best because they are not very good at English, but I am very happy with my visit.

excerpts: I ordered the tori paitan ramen, easily one of the most unique bowls of ramen I've had in years.
It's a chicken-based broth so thick that it almost tastes like gravy.
The deliciously soft pieces of pork chashu are complimented by pieces of duck chasu (you have to order these on top of your ramen), both of which basically melt in your mouth.
tori paitan ramen.author: Philip W.
tori paitan ramen.review:
Mensho has taken my stomach by storm and edged itself very securely into my top 3 favorite ramen restaurants in the Bay Area. I had no idea what to expect walking in and was blown away by the ramen I experienced in Mensho. 

I ordered the tori paitan ramen, easily one of the most unique bowls of ramen I've had in years. It's a chicken-based broth so thick that it almost tastes like gravy. The deliciously soft pieces of pork chashu are complimented by pieces of duck chasu (you have to order these on top of your ramen), both of which basically melt in your mouth. Within this concoction of broth and chashu sits strands upon strands of the most delicious noodles in San Francisco. 

I've always considered good ramen to be art in food form. Sometimes it looks beautiful, sometimes it tastes beautiful, and in rare situations it's both. Mensho is such a case. The way the chasu floats in the rich broth is gorgeous but the way everything tastes is even better. Everything has a different consistency here that tastes just right, from the melt-in-your-mouth chasu to the gravy-thick broth to the sturdy noodles. I had a great time eating here.

excerpts: Tori Paitan Ramen was oh so rich rich rich rich rich RIIIICHHH and creamy.

MMMmm.

tori paitan ramen.author: Kim N.
tori paitan ramen.review:
HOLY SHIT WAS THIS PLACE DEELISH. 

Tori Paitan Ramen was oh so rich rich rich rich rich RIIIICHHH and creamy. That broth was pretty close to a chowder! And the noodles had the nicest thick texture along with it. MMMmm. The duck chashu was definitely a nice, flavor changing bonus! I enjoyed that addition into the ramen very much, and usually, I'm not a big fan of duck! 

Little sister got the Shoyu Ramen. It comes with a different textured noodle - a flatter styled noodle. And heol, definitely complimented the clean, soothing broth it was served with. 

GODDAMMNN. How did this place perfect both the fatty, rich tonkotsu broth ANNNND clean, clearer broths?! I could eat either of them all daaay loooong.

Setup was supah hip and rad. There's a bar-ish seating and like two long high, communal tables. They play clubbing-esque/edm music inside. Haha, threw me off for a second.

Overall, the hype lived up to my standards. Definitely worth that one hour wait.

excerpts: I ordered the tori paitan ramen and my bestie ordered the shoyu.
It was actually quite comical as I ended up enjoying hers more
so we switched.
But the tori paitan was ridiculously rich and the "soup" was definitely more of a gravy than an actual soup.
I couldn't take a few bites without feeling completely overwhelmed by fat and salt.
The shoyu was much lighter although still just as salty.
It did however have an amazing mushroom / umami flavor that I was willing to drink a few glasses of water to enjoy.
The noodles in the shoyu were more of an egg type noodle than the ramen I am used to.
tori paitan ramen.author: Megan W.
tori paitan ramen.review:
The hype for this ramen shop right now is extremely real. The best friend and I decided we had to come to see if it was really THAT good. We waited an hour and a half just to be seated. And although the host was very friendly all of the waitresses made me feel as though I was doing a disservice to them by requesting water or the bill.

I ordered the tori paitan ramen and my bestie ordered the shoyu. It was actually quite comical as I ended up enjoying hers more so we switched. But the tori paitan was ridiculously rich and the "soup" was definitely more of a gravy than an actual soup. I couldn't take a few bites without feeling completely overwhelmed by fat and salt. The shoyu was much lighter although still just as salty. It did however have an amazing mushroom / umami flavor that I was willing to drink a few glasses of water to enjoy. The noodles in the shoyu were more of an egg type noodle than the ramen I am used to. The tori however had more traditional noodles.

Although I did not care for the broths I do feel that the meats included in the two ramens were perfectly, delicately cooked and very delicious. I've never had duck chashu and I was pleasantly surprised to say the least. The regular pork chashu was also thinly sliced and amazingly tender. They both just melt in your mouth.

The bits of kale and seaweed unfortunately did not help enough to combat the overwhelming fat that lingers on your palate which is ultimately what led to my 3 stars.  I honestly feel like this ramen was not to type to be enjoyed on a continuous basis. The flavors were great for that of a tasting menu, but for a full bowl of ramen it was much too salty and heavy to enjoy for more than a few bites. Overall I could not get over the overwhelming soup bases which clouded my ability to really enjoy this ramen.

excerpts: The Tori Paitan ramen on the other hand, was delicious.
The chashu and duck melted in your mouth, the noodles were perfect, and the broth was so very rich and creamy.
Sadly, the Shoyu Ramen was too salty.
tori paitan ramen.author: Jenny Y.
tori paitan ramen.review:
Things you can do while you wait for a seat at Mensho Tokyo:
- Tailgate: The people behind us may or may not have been brown bagging. We were told that there have been people who will break out six packs cause they DGAF.
- Get yur hur did: leave a designated wait person and get a haircut from across the street. Trust me, you have enough time.
- Meditate: You probably won't do this, but I'm not going to lie, my hangryness was taking over my body real quick. If every crevice of SF wasn't covered in piss, I'd be sitting in a corner collecting myself.

So we arrived at about 5:15 on a Sunday and had to wait for a good 2 hours before we were able to enter the door. Abram was really nice and thanked us for waiting. We shared an oyster appetizer, SO ordered the Shoyu Ramen, I ordered the Tori Paitan.

The oysters were nice but forgettable. I wouldn't order them again. The Tori Paitan ramen on the other hand, was delicious. The chashu and duck melted in your mouth, the noodles were perfect, and the broth was so very rich and creamy. Sadly, the Shoyu Ramen was too salty. Each bite was followed by a gulp of water.

I can't wait for the rest of the menu to come, we'll definitely be back. I want to try the Vegan Tantanmen. OH, just a suggestion, if you want to get in quick, come alone, there were some lucky ducks who got to skip the line for that.

excerpts: I opted for the tori paitan ramen with two slices of chashu.
The handmade noodles were stellar with the appropriate texture and chewiness.
The noodles perfectly absorbed the rich and balanced broth.
I would have been able to finish it had I not camped out for happy hour at the friendly Resolute next door.
My objectivity for this review is compromised because I had a relaxing time lined up an hour and a half before opening.
the Suntory malt and the Sansho may not have been the best standalone beers but they paired so well with the tori paitan.
It was nice to see a change in roster for the typical ramen house beverages.
- They use Square payment and were able to quickly rectify an erroneous bill.
- The music selection was hilariously comforting.
It was what seemed to be a wedding covers playlist during the first hour - including hits like a diluted acoustic version of Peter Cetera's "Glory of Love"
- There's a clipboard.
tori paitan ramen.author: Joseph V.
tori paitan ramen.review:
I was fortunate enough to be seated at the inaugural table (of 6) during the grand opening. The other patrons were a blast to be around - we agreed that it was strange to have only 6 seated until the food arrived but it was thrilling to be part of the exhibit. This is the nature of grand openings so I imagine Mensho will have it sussed out very soon. 

I opted for the tori paitan ramen with two slices of chashu. The handmade noodles were stellar with the appropriate texture and chewiness. The noodles perfectly absorbed the rich and balanced broth. I would have been able to finish it had I not camped out for happy hour at the friendly Resolute next door. My objectivity for this review is compromised because I had a relaxing time lined up an hour and a half before opening. In my mind, it was guaranteed to be a great experience.

Abram was a delightful host. His enthusiasm and engagement with the crowd were appropriately uplifting for the public opening. Chef Shono's spirits were high and he personally delivered my bowl with a smile and a handshake. I'll never forget the connection when he reciprocated my emphatic thumbs up through the kitchen window. 

Miscellany:
- The beer selection is stellar. the Suntory malt and the Sansho may not have been the best standalone beers but they paired so well with the tori paitan. It was nice to see a change in roster for the typical ramen house beverages.
- They use Square payment and were able to quickly rectify an erroneous bill.
- The music selection was hilariously comforting. It was what seemed to be a wedding covers playlist during the first hour - including hits like a diluted acoustic version of Peter Cetera's "Glory of Love"
- There's a clipboard. The sequence of names was honored for at least the first 6 people (mild gloating). 

The per bowl pricing is higher than average but it was worth it to be part of the spectacle. Cheers to Mensho! I'll be back.

tori paitan ramen.review:
Food is 5 star. I ordered the Tori Paitan Ramen. It was delicious and broth is super thick and yummy. 

But, the overall experience is just... tiring and disappointing. I would never come here again. 

Ramen costs $20 a bowl. Which is super expensive. It would be okay if I don't have to stand in line outside waiting for 30-40 minutes to finally be seated. Not only that, after getting seated, the experience gets more and more terrible. The space is really really small and it was super uncomfortable.

The seats are really small and it's very hard to squish in and sit comfortably. I was trapped between the wall and a person beside me. The whole dining experience was simply terrible.

Honestly, if there's more space in the restaurant and I can sit comfortably, I would come back here again despite having to stand outside in the cold. But at its current state, there's no chance that I'd put myself through that experience again.

Try it as a once in a lifetime experience to see what the hype is about. After that, judge for yourself.
