tori paitan ramen.author: Amy H.
tori paitan ramen.review:
3.5 Stars. It was fine but nothing exciting.

Waited for an hour at 6pm but it seemed to go faster since the line moved consistently.

Had the tori paitan ramen (double chashu). The tables have pink salt, pepper, ume (dried plum) and bonito (dried fish) powder which I tasted but didn't add to my ramen.

The ramen was a rich thick chicken broth. It came with two large pieces of pork charshu, duck charshu, burdock, menma (marinated bamboo shoot), kale and cabbage.

The broth was creamy with a strong stewed flavor which was good quality but one dimensional. It was a little too thick for me. The noodles were thick which I dont prefer, chewy and slightly curly (you can ask for the noodles to be cooked a little longer if you don't prefer your noodles al dente). The pork chashu was flavorful but a little over stewed. The duck chashu had good texture but had an herbal flavor that I couldn't pinpoint. Why is there kale and random cabbage in the broth? Is it to cater to San Francisco clientele? Why isn't there a soft boiled egg option? Why can you get Michelin star ramen in Tokyo for under $10 when a bowl of ramen here is $16-$18?

Haven't tried a lot of paitan ramen so it might just be that I dont prefer this style.

I'd rather go to the other ramen places in the city instead of here especially because of the line (Waraku will fulfill my ramen cravings). Compared to Orenchi, Santouka etc. in the Bay Area and places I've tried in LA, NY and Japan, it's only okay. Other people seemed to like it so I would give it a try.

tori paitan ramen.review:
My eyelids droop slowly as I type this review and I feel myself sinking lower and lower into my seat. I am a blob. A round, floppy blob. If this is death by food, then this is the way I want to go. 

I stopped by here with a friend after work. At 6:10pm on a Tuesday, the line was already at 30-40 people and it took us over 1.5 hours to get seated. Luckily, the long line offered us ample opportunity to stare wistfully through the window. Making patrons uncomfortable? My specialty. Besides, that just means they'll eat faster.

After consulting Yelp (cause food fomo is a real thing),  we both settled on the Tori Paitan Ramen. I ambitiously opted for the double chashu- spoiler: there were no regrets.

The Ramen itself came out fairly quickly (maybe about 10-15 min?) and looked absolutely gorgeous. One sip of the broth and we both swooned. The Paitan broth is incredibly savory and creamy, the texture like a mix of soup and gravy. The Ramen comes with both duck and pork chashu (1 slice of each in the regular Ramen and two slices of each in the double). The duck chashu was an interesting addition. As my friend commented, you could definitely taste the lemon. To me, it felt a little out of place in the creamy broth, but whatever floats your boat. The PORK chashu though. Omigod. I'm already a sucker for pork, so this absolutely stole my heart. 

About a third of the way through the meal, however, I could definitely feel some regret. It was sooo rich, maybe a little too rich for my personal taste. I think if I had to do it over, I'd personally try one of the lighter broths but hey- maybe you'll like it more!

Overall, really delicious Ramen and a place I'd definitely recommend trying. Was it worth 1.5 hours of waiting? Not so much. I've heard that lines tend to be better if you come 30+ minutes before opening, so maybe try that!

excerpts: We ordered two classic Tori Paitan Ramen's with double chashu, one with the miso egg and another with the soy egg.
The broth is thick, flavorful, full of umami, but *not too salty* (!).
For me, the broth is the most important part.
I don't think I've ever had a thick broth ramen where I could drink the soup without a bowl of rice.
The duck and chashu were cooked exquisitely, and the noodles were thick and yummy.
The eggs were both tasty and cooked to runny perfection; I preferred the miso egg (sweeter) to the soy egg (more fermented flavor).
You can't order a side of rice here, and I'm not a huge eater, but the double chashu + whole egg was the perfect amount of food for me (maybe sliiiightly too much, but no regerts).
My friend who can eat more than me finished all his food and the broth, whereas I wasn't able to finish the broth.
We almost ordered one Maccha Ramen instead, but looking at others, the amount of matcha they add was a lot

tori paitan ramen.review:
Best ramen I've had outside of Japan. (Have yet to try Iza Ramen though) Went with a ramen connoisseur friend who ranked this place in his top 2 ramen places in all of California.

FOOD:
We ordered two classic Tori Paitan Ramen's with double chashu, one with the miso egg and another with the soy egg. The broth is thick, flavorful, full of umami, but *not too salty* (!). For me, the broth is the most important part. I don't think I've ever had a thick broth ramen where I could drink the soup without a bowl of rice. The duck and chashu were cooked exquisitely, and the noodles were thick and yummy. The eggs were both tasty and cooked to runny perfection; I preferred the miso egg (sweeter) to the soy egg (more fermented flavor). You can't order a side of rice here, and I'm not a huge eater, but the double chashu + whole egg was the perfect amount of food for me (maybe sliiiightly too much, but no regerts). My friend who can eat more than me finished all his food and the broth, whereas I wasn't able to finish the broth. We almost ordered one Maccha Ramen instead, but looking at others, the amount of matcha they add was a lot and we overheard people discussing the graininess of it, so decided to stick to the classic for a first time.

SERVICE etc.:
We waited in line for ~one hour on Sunday at 6pm for two people. Waiters were all very nice and responsive. They forgot our double chashu and were a little quick to blame us for not ordering correctly rather than taking the blame for not taking down our orders correctly in the first place (we made sure to double check that it was double chashu when ordering). There are baskets under the table for your things, and coat hooks by the door. Decor was slick and urban -- big glass windows, communal wood tables, stool seating -- but still somewhat cozy because of the small space. If you're on a date, get ready to sit across from the other person, because they won't let you sit side by side (the table width is pretty wide). We were lucky enough to be able to trade with another couple to sit side by side. (Personally, I prefer this because I don't like to watch people eat, you're closer to the other person, and it makes sharing food easier, but I understand why they make this rule since there's high customer turnover.) Bathrooms were clean, which is a good sign to me of the level of kitchen cleanliness.

We will definitely be coming back! Also plan to update my review once I've tried Iza Ramen and Marufuku for comparison.

tori paitan ramen.review:
The Tori Paitan Ramen (chicken broth) is amazing. Creamiest, thickest ramen broth I've had since being in Tokyo. Noodles were thick and chewy. Each topping had its own distinct flavor - no ingredient was a "filler." You could really taste the quality and care. Kitchen staff far outnumbered wait staff.

Not cheap - $16 before tax for Tori Paitan Ramen. Other options are cheaper. Shoyu (soy sauce) ramen is $14 before tax, Shio (salt) ramen is $9 before tax.

They do not yet have tsukemen and tonkotsu - those are coming in a couple months. So if you enjoy creamy ramen then Tori Paitan is your only option, but you won't regret trying it.

For seating, they only have communal high tables and a few bar seats.

Mensho Tokyo is well acclaimed in Tokyo and this is their first US location. The co-owner is from the Bay Area and is a ramen critic in Japan. He's the host and is super knowledgeable.

They do not have a waiting list, so you have to wait in line. I was in a party of 2 and we had to wait an hour after arriving at 8pm.

I hope the expand to the full menu soon. The choices on the wall (but not on the limited menu) like the ebi miso sound so good.

tori paitan ramen.author: Chen L.
tori paitan ramen.review:
Without a doubt the best ramen I've had in San Francisco.  I'll be coming back again.

Food
First, the Tori Paitan Ramen, with double chasu.  The broth was incredibly thick, almost gravy like!  An immense amount of flavor in each spoonful and incredibly satisfying in both flavor and fullness.  Both the duck and the pork chashu melt in the mouth; the slow cooking of the meats allows the flavor to concentrate it and it stands out despite the incredibly flavorful broth.  The noodles themselves are thick and take on the flavors of the other ingredients, all while having a firm but easy to eat consistency.

Second, the Shio Ramen.  Being a shio ramen, the broth is much lighter, but with a much more intense salty flavor.  The initial taste of the soup can definitely taste a bit *too* salty, but it quickly passes by eating more.  The noodles here are much thinner, but it definitely compliments the lighter but more flavorful soup.  The chashu is once again fantastic, and the flavors of the meat stands out in the broth.

The other vegetables were incredibly fresh, which really adds to the complexity to the overall dish.  It's incredible how they packed so many different flavors into a single dish!  And as a personal preference, I hate when food gets cold too quickly, but the choice of dishware and freshness of the food kept everything hot!

Environment
It's very intimate seating, so bring a party or a friend!  The food is the main attraction of the restaurant, not the decor! Clean, average loudness, and the service was fantastic.

In short, if you like ramen, you'll love Mensho Tokyo!

YUM - welcome Tokyo to SF!  Yes, this is the crazy thick broth ramen place that will change your life.  So do it.  Now I know you're going to order the tori paitan ramen which is their deservedly famous meaty dish with a chicken-ish broth, but let me also encourage you to order a couple other things:
- The vegan tantamen, which the chef recommended as his second choice, and which is an awesome, slightly nutty contrast with the tori paitan.  In fact, we kept alternating between the two because each one seemed to make the other one taste awesomer and each was awesome by itself.
- The oysters!  These had "shiyo oil" on them, which gave me flashback to the first time I had truffle oil: the first bite is a bit "unusual" or foreign, the second bite affirms that this foreign taste is actually good and fits in with other savory aromatic foods, and by the third bite you are ready to pay double the price just to have a little more.  Don't tell anyone but I actually licked the oil off the mini plate after the oysters were gone.  
- The Sansho beer, which is perhaps my favorite "herbal" beer ever - with a hint of Japanese peppercorn.  Disclosure: this beer is expensive as f*ck at over $1 per ounce.  Splurge and get two.

Out of curiosity we also ordered the $14 Shiyo ramen, which is listed on the receipt as "organic ramen."  OK to be honest, actually I wrote down "shiyo" based on phonetics but now that I look at their menu online, they have $14 "organic shoyu ramen" and $9 "shio ramen" so I'm not totally sure what we ordered.  Anyway, it was what thinner and what most people would probably recognize as "ramen."  Not as good as the others.  Still need to try the Shio... or Shoyu.

tori paitan ramen.review:
Came here on grand opening day and they have very few options of ramen to choose from. I'm a HUGE FAN of ramen. I hunt for ramen whenever I go travel. I've had ramen in Tokyo, NY, Hong Kong, and some other popular Bay Area ramen places, and I definitely will NOT say this is the best ramen place in even just SF. 

I got the Tori Paitan Ramen on this visit.
Broth:
The broth is favorable yet waayy too thick. it's prob the thickest broth I've had in my life. Don't get me wrong, I love thick broth in ramen but this one is just too much. It also left a strong residue on my throat, which made me drink tons of water afterwards. 

Noodle: 
I kind of felt like there's a sand-ish like texture on the ramen(probably due to the thickness of the broth). The noodle itself was too thick as well, feeling more like udon. 

Chashu:
I dont know if it's day 1 and they're unprepared, but the chashu I got is more than 70% fat. I like chashu with a bit of fat, but def not something like this. 

Overall, I would not go back again. 

Just as a reference, I love Ichiran Ramen the most. They're perfect in terms of broth, ramen, and chashu.

tori paitan ramen.author: Daniel H.
tori paitan ramen.review:
I was truly excited as I waited in line to try the ramen here, and got here with my friend a full 45 minutes to wait before the restaurant opened (we were not even the first party to arrive!). Luckily, we made the first seating though! 

Food: My rating for this place ultimately comes down to the food. I ordered the Tori Paitan ramen with double chashu. Long story short, I was just not impressed and this type of ramen is just not to my liking. The broth, while very flavorful, had an overly rich taste and was just a bit too salty to be enjoyable. It was also very opaque, so you couldn't quite see what else was in your bowl without having to fish around in it. The noodles though were actually tasty, and had a nice texture and bite...slightly reminiscent of an udon noodle, but not as thick. Overall, too much for me to handle after more than just a few bites. I was actually sad that they do not have to go boxes since this was way too much for me to handle in one sitting. 

Service: The people here are welcoming and friendly, especially since the location is quite small. I never found it difficult to let someone know if I needed anything like a water refill or the bill. The one issue that my party had was communicating with some of the people here when we had questions. I had a difficult time understanding them, so at some points I just nodded my head in agreement. 

Atmosphere: The restaurant is tiny on the inside and seating is done on communal tables (so you might not know who is across or to the left or right of you). I didn't mind so it was not too much of an issue. I do wish that there were other seating options besides stools, especially after waiting outside for so long. It would have been nice to have some back support to make the dining experience more comfortable (though I do understand the stools for aesthetic purposes). There are also baskets under each table for you to store your things, which are convenient too. This location also has just one bathroom, which had an unusual odor to it, but since it's located so close to the dining and kitchen area, there was not an opportunity to properly air it out. Better ventilation in the dining room would have also been appreciated because the aroma of the rich flavored food was a bit intense at times. 

If the hype ever dies down, I might come back here and try another noodle option, but based on my first experience I am in certainly no rush. I wish they took to-go orders (or at least a boxing option), but perhaps that's an area they can get into once their business starts to grow. I would also like to see them adopt a sign in system either manually or through an app instead of just having people wait in a long line. This would give people some mobility instead of having to wait outside until room clears up for dining.

I've been to most of the most highly regarded ramen places in the Bay Area and LA. This is easily one of the best ramen places I've ever been to. I tried the Tori Paitan Ramen and this broth is arguably the thickest, richest, creamiest non-tsukemen broth I've ever had. And it was delicious.

I also tried the Vegan Tantamen, which had so much rich flavor that I think it may have been the best Vegan food I've ever had. It was like a rainbow of flavor dancing around my taste buds. 

The only downside was they didn't have a tonkotsu ramen or tsukemen available yet. Waiting for that to happen. Oh, the line wasn't too bad when we got there, but I could see people waiting for a while. My fear is that this place gets too popular that the lines stretch forever. There isn't a lot of seating room.

excerpts: I would suggest getting the Tori Paitan ramen for first timers.
tori paitan ramen.author: Andrew W.
tori paitan ramen.review:
By far the best ramen shop in San Francisco. Absolutely worth the 1-2 hour wait; the trick is to go at opening or at closing for shorter wait times. I would suggest getting the Tori Paitan ramen for first timers. The soup is extremely rich and creamy, and the pork + duck slices are among the best I've had.

The head chef and owners are extremely knowledgeable about their ramen (one of them has been to over 1,500 different ramen shops in Japan as a professional ramen taster). In fact, they have even refused to add eggs to their ramen until they've found a perfect source in California. Just goes to show how much they care about their craftsmanship. I hope they eventually expand to other locations in the Bay!

excerpts: Organic shoyu ramen with double chasu - this was DELICIOUS.
I was opting for a less-rich broth so went with the shoyu.

organic shoyu.author: Karen H.
organic shoyu.review:
Gosh I feel bad I didn't brave the lines earlier for this place. I loved it. One of the best if not the best shoyu or paitan ramen in the SF area. 

We arrived at 8:30 Pm on a Friday night and the line was about 20 deep. Wait was around 40 minutes. Staff is super attentive collecting party numbers in the line and accommodated everyone on a first come first serve basis. We were waiting for a table for 4 and even as double seats showed up, and though smaller parties were behind us, they took care to seat us first.

The menu is clean and easy to read. We ordered:

Oysters in shoyu dare oil - doesn't look appetizing, tastes like canned oysters in oil (not a bad thing).

Organic shoyu ramen with double chasu - this was DELICIOUS. I was opting for a less-rich broth so went with the shoyu. Great choice. They double chasu is an extra slice, totally also worth it. The smoky flavor of the chasu pairs well with the clean shoyu based broth. The kale was so tender yet held texture in the bowl, and I adored the noodles. Tender, squiggly awesomeness. The duck chasu is new to me in ramen, and added depth to the bowl. 

Spicy tori paitan ramen with double chasu - spicy isn't too spicy, noodles were a little different than the shoyu ramen (closer to typical ramen noodles). Broth was super rich, creamy, heavy and delicious. Some with duck and pork chasu as well.

Although this ramen in general is much more rich than what I'm used to, it's GOOD. It's not exactly comparable but seems to me to stand In its own category - I've not had ramen like this before and it was so good.

Egg isn't included and it's a must add for $1. A whole egg, perfectly cooked. $1 is worth it.

Parking and neighborhood is kinda sketch... but I didn't feel unsafe dining here. The spoon provided is also way too large IMO, and made of heavy metal and my hand was tired after using it halfway through.

I'll be back!

organic shoyu.author: Vivienne K.
organic shoyu.review:
The American child of Tokyo's famed Mensho ramen bar, the minimalistic, no-frills joint serves up innovative spins on traditional thick tonkotsu broth - tasty and satisfying indeed, yet too hyped for my tastes. It is good, but not wait 1.5hours good. 

The decor is simple, modern, and scientific - the science of molecular ramen.  The space is cozy - sitting around 20 people in short segments of time. 

For the Macca Tori Paitan - The broth was too heavy for my palate.  The Macca powder dispersed on top the ramen was great for show, but did not add much to the culinary experience as I consumed chunks of Matcha powder here and there - it did not blend well in the soup.  The chewiness of the noodle was fine, but the noodle width was a bit on the thick side. 

For the Organic Shoyu Ramen - The broth was too salty. Again, the chewiness of noodles fine - the noodles were flat and thin like Chinese style Wonton noodles.  It was a good, but not an amazing bowl of ramen that dreams are made of. 

For the Vegan tantanmen, the broth was too salty for me to handle. The chef was incredibly liberal with the salt in this dish.  The dish was thick and lacked a balance of flavors. I appreciate the use of mame, pea shorts and cilantro, but the vegetables were very much overshadowed by the thickness and saltiness. 

For the Aburasoba, I was quite actually pleasantly surprised!  This was my favorite ramen dish here. Certainly not the signature thick tonkotsu broth, but most certainly more well balanced, with chewier noodles in a delectable lighter sauce with a mix of Chashu, menma, green onion, and daikon sporouts.

excerpts: I also had the Organic Shoyu, the broth was flavored just enough n much lighter that the others I've tried here.
organic shoyu.author: Mary R.
organic shoyu.review:
I've been here twice in one month, both times around opening on a weekday. I've been lucky enough to get the last few spots without waiting. The place is small and fills up quickly. Seating style is communal, so expect to sit closely and share long tables with fellow ramen lovers. 

The ramen here is different from any other ramen spot I've tried in San Francisco. The Tori Paitan was verrrrry thick and rich, almost like a gravy. I also had the Organic Shoyu, the broth was flavored just enough n much lighter that the others I've tried here. Both the Tori Paitan and Shoyu contained one piece of Chashu(option for double Chashu for 2$ more) and 2 slices of duck breast. The duck was soo tender and the Chashu was melt in your mouth. My friend had the Spicy Lamb...mmmm the lamb flavor was prominent and the combination of spices were just perfect. The noodles had a nice bite to 'em. Bouncy and cut on the thicker side, just how I like it.

Definitely worth the wait! Would recommend to give Mensho a try!

excerpts: I decided to order their organic shoyu ramen with double chasiu.
At first bite, the aroma of the broth was absolutely amazing.
Since I enjoy more of a lighter broth, I loved the warm, meaty taste of the clear shoyu broth.
The noodles were also very interesting, and they had a thick yet flattened texture.
The duck chasiu was also very tender and the chasiu was flavorful with a good amount of meat to fat ratio.
organic shoyu.author: Sandra S.
organic shoyu.review:
I've been dying to try this ramen place for the longest time, and the numerous number of rave reviews I have gotten from friends has definitely made the experience of trying Mensho Tokyo's ramen extra exciting. 

We came on a Thursday night at around 6pm, and the line was already fairly long. The restaurant holds only about 28 spots, so the lines and wait for ramen are crazy! We waited for about an hour, which I heard was better than most, since the average wait time is 1.5-2 hours. After getting seated on one of their bench seats, they had a place to hang coats and a cubby on the bottom of the table to hold purses. 

I decided to order their organic shoyu ramen with double chasiu. At first bite, the aroma of the broth was absolutely amazing. Since I enjoy more of a lighter broth, I loved the warm, meaty taste of the clear shoyu broth. The noodles were also very interesting, and they had a thick yet flattened texture. The duck chasiu was also very tender and the chasiu was flavorful with a good amount of meat to fat ratio. However, I do wish the chasiu was heated up, since it was cold on my plate. 

Overall, this is a great ramen place and I would love to come back (if I feel like waiting in that line again). This is definitely an experience that needs to be fulfilled when living in SF, and the aesthetics of each bowl will make the food all the more delicious.

excerpts: The organic Shoyu is more of the traditional broth Ramen with a twist of the noodles.
The mushroom cups are worth a try if one is fine with the fried foods.
organic shoyu.author: Simon N.
organic shoyu.review:
Get here at least by 4:15 to be one of the first to sit down. Otherwise, one will have to wait.  I am a person that prefers to wait ahead of time to be the first one inside rather than waiting while a line has formed after opening.  

Ambiance
This is a very small Ramen place that holds around 40 people. Once inside, the place has a modern Japanese feel to it.  They have places to hang my coat and put my book bag. The space is quite narrow for seating. 

Food 
There is a nice variety of Ramen and the usually toppings. The Paitan Ramen is pretty impressive with the creamy broth sticking to the noodle.  The organic Shoyu is more of the traditional broth Ramen with a twist of the noodles.  The mushroom cups are worth a try if one is fine with the fried foods. Really nice twist to a traditional mushroom. 


Service
After getting into the restaurant, I think the service is very fast once I ordered.  My Ramen came out before the appetizers since Ramen broth is made well in advance.  The wait staff is very attentive.

excerpts: The Organic Shoyu ramen ($14) was packed with flavor too.
If you're looking for something tasty, but less heavy, this is the ramen for you.
organic shoyu.author: Susan D.
organic shoyu.review:
Long lines ALL the time. There was a line when we got there at 9 pm and there was line there when we left around 11 pm. So, is it worth the hype and wait?! Yes, it's worth at least trying once. No, I probably wouldn't come back to stand in line unless I'm ok with the potential 1.5+ hour wait. It definitely seemed like other people didn't mind the wait since the line was always consistently long. Mensho is pretty small with 2 rows of communal tables for seating. 

By the time we were ordering a little after 10pm, they had already run out of their soft boiled eggs (both miso and soy). Come early if you want to try their eggs! The add ons seemed to be a little pricy like an extra $2 for fried garlic or green onions. If you want additional toppings, your bowl of ramen can easily be $20+. 

The Tori Paitan ramen ($16.50) has a rich and creamy chicken soup base. The broth was much thicker than your average tonkotsu broth - almost like a curry consistency. The duck chashu was glorious - so tender and flavorful! It was a little weird to have kale in my ramen, but hey it's SF, so why not. It was strange that they give you such a huge spoon for your soup. It was as big as a serving spoon or rice scooper. The Organic Shoyu ramen ($14) was packed with flavor too. If you're looking for something tasty, but less heavy, this is the ramen for you. The noodles were thinner than the Tori Paitan ramen which went well with the lighter broth.

They don't have to go boxes and you can't order to go, so make sure to slurp up all your delicious ramen before you leave!

organic shoyu.review:

Organic Shoyu Ramen: 3 stars

organic shoyu.author: Betty C.
organic shoyu.review:
Been meaning to try mensho but the line has always thwarted me from doing so. Fast forward to the hottest day in San Francisco to date at 9:30pm we
Finally had our first mensho experience.

Service: fantastic, our waitress was really nice and came back to fill our waters several times

Noodles: perfect el denote consistency

Broth: paitan=great! Perfect amount of flavor, rich, creamy, flavorful
Organic shoyu: both bland and too salty at the same time

Ambiance: cramped seating, we were seated in between two couples flanked on each side. You really also can't linger as there is still a line at 10:30pm!

Value: pricey. We paid about $50 for 2 bowls inc. tax and tip which seems expensive for noodle soup

Final tip:
Vegetarians finally a ramen place you can eat at. The vegan ramen looked deelish! If I come back that's what I'll be ordering.

excerpts: Organic Shoyu Ramen - $14.00
I'm a shoyu broth fanatic
so this was a must-try.
The broth had a strong smoky-bonito flavor which I loved.

Unfortunately they ran out of both miso & shoyu ajitamas 2 hours after opening, but I did get added bean sprouts and the included pork and duck chashu, bamboo, nori square and yucky kale, though the kale sprouts were good.
The noodles in this version were flat and wide, still cooked perfectly chewy and came out searing hot.
organic shoyu.author: Vince N.
organic shoyu.review:
We enjoyed our ramen so much that we had to go back and try more!

FOOD:
Enoki Mushroom Chips - $5.00 
Yum, like mushroom tempura!  The squeeze of lemon and sprinkling of a red spicy-looking salt really weren't needed. 

Organic Shoyu Ramen - $14.00
I'm a shoyu broth fanatic so this was a must-try.  The broth had a strong smoky-bonito flavor which I loved.  Unfortunately they ran out of both miso & shoyu ajitamas 2 hours after opening, but I did get added bean sprouts and the included pork and duck chashu, bamboo, nori square and yucky kale, though the kale sprouts were good.  The noodles in this version were flat and wide, still cooked perfectly chewy and came out searing hot.  This ranks right up there for me with the version at Momofuku. 

Spicy Lamb Ramen - $16.00 
If you think the Tori Paitan is thick and rich, this sucker is beats it.  It's a miso broth topped with ground lamb, pork chashu, nira (Chinese leeks) bamboo and green onions.  No egg for my spouse either as they ran out, but he did receive burdock shavings.  The spoonful of broth I tasted was intense and a bit like curry.  Personally, I'd stick to the paitan for a rich broth, but he absolutely loved it. 

SERVICE:
Our female server was so friendly and patient with our amateur ramen friends.  My spouse and I on the other hand are pretty profesh, lol. 

TIP:
No sodas are sold here.  

OVERALL:
A joint with two bomb versions of ramen for me?  That's saying A LOT!

The noodles were tasty and both was very light without feeling too greasy or filling.
I really liked the way everything tastes.
organic shoyu.author: Jenny K.
organic shoyu.review:
The kids wanted noodles and I found this place with decent reviews on Yelp. I was lucky to get here right after they opened but wow there was already a long line and a crowd of people outside the store! While waiting in line I checked the menu and saw they were a Michelin guide restaurant. 

After waiting probably a good 30-40 mins we finally got our seats. The menu is quite simple, mainly ramen dishes that either comes regular or with extra chasu. Some are with broth and some without. For appetizers there were only 2 to choose from. I decided to order the enoki chips to start. I really wasn't sure what to expect and was hoping it wasn't something I had to end up finishing on my own. When it came out it smelled wonderful and believe it or not it was SOOOO good!! One way to know something weird is good is having young kids try them. My 11 year old and 5 year old both loved it just as much.

I also ordered the organic shoyu ramen and shio ramen. The noodles were tasty and both was very light without feeling too greasy or filling. I really liked the way everything tastes. The soft boiled eggs were perfectly cooked which was an add on.

Overall everything was great here and the staff were very attentive and accommodating with kids. I will definitely will come back again next time I'm in town!

He said it was different from what he's usually used to eating

If you're ever in SF, give this place a try!

The first night we saw the line was almost a block down so we decided to try here another night. We made sure to get there early so we wouldn't have to wait in line as long. The wait was soooo worth it!!!
While in line I saw that the restaurant is Michelin rated and I perused the yelp photos and reviews on what would be the best thing to order.

excerpts: Organic Shoyu - Ramen with a pork and chicken clear broth, seasoned with shoyu and topped with pork and duck chasu.
The noodles were handmade, flat, thick and al dente.
organic shoyu.author: Helen C.
organic shoyu.review:
One of the best ramen in SF! I'm not a huge ramen fan, but definitely appreciated the dishes here. Given the high anticipation of the grand opening of its first location outside of Japan, we decided to wait a few months before coming here. Even so, it's very crowded and there's always a wait. We arrived at 4:15 on a Sunday, before they opened at 5. Our wait was considered "short" compared to others who arrived after us.

Oysters in Shoyu Dare Oil - This is 1 of 2 appetizers that they offered. The other appetizer was enoki chips, which I wasn't interested in. This dish may not look pretty, but it tasted great and paired well with the ramen. The oysters were cooked and tasted salty and meaty.

Organic Shoyu - Ramen with a pork and chicken clear broth, seasoned with shoyu and topped with pork and duck chasu. The noodles were handmade, flat, thick and al dente. Everything married so well together and the chasu was so tender and flavorful. 

There's about 28 seats and the tables are communal style. Service was fast and efficient and turned seems high here. We were in and out in 30 minutes. Our waitress looked stressed, but totally understand given how hectic is gets here.

excerpts: I ordered the organic shoyu, in my opinion, it was too salty and the noodles were mediocre.
I don't understand the hype.
The ramen was overpriced and wasn't worth the splurge.
Meh.
organic shoyu.author: Minji K.
organic shoyu.review: Ok, maybe it was an off night at Mensho but, I was so disappointed with my ramen and I am still dumbfounded. Came in on Wednesday night, it was super busy (in my mind, this is a great indicator that I am missing out on some good ramen) finally we were seated and I couldn't wait to try the ramen. I ordered the organic shoyu, in my opinion, it was too salty and the noodles were mediocre. I don't understand the hype. The ramen was overpriced and wasn't worth the splurge. Meh.

excerpts: In addition to the tori paitan broth, Mensho also offers organic shoyu, shio, and a vegan tantanmen.
The shoyu and shio broths are lighter and not as creamy, which might be good for those looking for something not as heavy.
(But why come all the way out here, wait in an excruciatingly long line, and not get the best?)
organic shoyu.author: Jean S.
organic shoyu.review:
Wow! Best Ramen I've had! Mensho's Tori Paitan Ramen (double chashu) ($18) was super amazing and full of delicious umami flavor! The broth was very rich and creamy, but the flavors were SO tasty, I could not stop drinking. The noodles were cooked to a perfect texture, the bamboo shoots and kale were a nice touch, but what was the crown on top was the EXTREMELY TENDER and flavorful chashu. Both the pork chashu and duck chashu were out-of-this-world amazing! Definitely the best I've had in any ramen bowl. I only wish there were more pieces.  

In addition to the tori paitan broth, Mensho also offers organic shoyu, shio, and a vegan tantanmen. The shoyu and shio broths are lighter and not as creamy, which might be good for those looking for something not as heavy. (But why come all the way out here, wait in an excruciatingly long line, and not get the best?) I also tried the oysters in shoyu dare oil ($5), which were not bad. The menu states 4 pieces...they gave us 6, but they were very small and not plated very nicely. 

Mensho Tokyo is one of Japan's most acclaimed ramen bars, and this very location in SF's Tenderloin district, is their first international shop outside of Japan. This location has been open for over a year now, but the long wait is still there. I came late Saturday evening (10:15pm) trying to avoid the long line, but it wasn't late enough. I still had to wait 45 minutes (only!?) and didn't get seated till just after 11:00pm. (They close at 11:30pm and there were people being seated all the way to the end.) I hate long waits, but the tori paitan ramen was well worth the travel out and 45 minute wait. On a positive side note, the restaurant was clean, the bathroom was clean, and their food safety score is 100.

excerpts: We got the tori paitan (with double chashu) and the organic shoyu ramen.
I liked the tori paitan better with the thick broth and rich flavor.
I'm not sure if the double chasui gets you more pork chasui or more of the duck chasui or both.
But I really liked the duck chasui - it's very unique.
The shoyu ramen had a thinner noodle than the paitan.
The broth was good but got really salty the more you kept drinking it.
Food came out quickly and service was fine, quick for the most part.
organic shoyu.author: Alison W.

The bf and I came around 5:40 on a weekday and still waited just under an hour to be seated. It's not a big place. They are actually pretty quick with the turnaround. Seats are not open for very long, which I appreciate as someone who's hungry and waiting for food. While in line, we were able to peruse the menu and decide beforehand so we were able to order right away. We got the tori paitan (with double chashu) and the organic shoyu ramen. I liked the tori paitan better with the thick broth and rich flavor. I'm not sure if the double chasui gets you more pork chasui or more of the duck chasui or both. But I really liked the duck chasui - it's very unique. The shoyu ramen had a thinner noodle than the paitan. The broth was good but got really salty the more you kept drinking it. Food came out quickly and service was fine, quick for the most part.

excerpts: I got the organic shoyu ramen.
It came with kale, duck chashu and pork chashu.
Surprisingly, I enjoyed the pork much more than the duck.
It was the most tender piece of pork I've ever had in ramen.
The noodles were also a stand out for me, since they were thicker than usual.
organic shoyu.author: Sara S.
organic shoyu.review:
The line is the reason I take away 2 stars from this place. Whyyy would anyone want to stand in a 2 hour line in the rain for a bowl of ramen? Could it possibly be worth 2 hours of your life (standing in the cold)? No. 

Nothing is worth that! Not even the best bowl of ramen in your life. Which, to be honest, this wasn't. I went very simple with my order, since this was my first time here. I got the organic shoyu ramen. It came with kale, duck chashu and pork chashu. Surprisingly, I enjoyed the pork much more than the duck. It was the most tender piece of pork I've ever had in ramen. The noodles were also a stand out for me, since they were thicker than usual. The kale was a nice addition as well.

However, I don't think this was the tastiest bowl of ramen I've had. It was clean, simple, and minimal. However, I was really missing the egg! For $14, I've gotten lobster broth, soft shell crab, and quail eggs at Ramen Parlor in San Mateo. I just don't think this $14 bowl of ramen here really compared. 

In addition, the vicinity is tiny, claustrophobic and not that comfortable. I was not a fan of the communal style tables and did not like how close I was to the people next to me. They also don't allow take out--so if you can't finish your ramen there, too bad. There's no way to take it home.

Maybe I would come back here one day, to try some of the more complex menu items. However, if I'm in the mood for ramen, I'll probably go somewhere else. There are plenty of great ramen spots in the bay area where you can skip the line, sit at your own table, and enjoy a variety of delicious menu options for a better price.

but I loved the rich and creamy soup way more,

organic shoyu.review:
Three words.... OMG! 

This place is like the best ramen I ever had in my life so far! I came here with my friend around 5:30pm and the line was crazy long. If your from San Francisco you know there's like a long line for every restaurant that's really delicious. Well I can tell you that this place is definitely worth the wait and price for the quality of the food.

I ordered the Organic Shoyu and my friend ordered Tori Paitan. Both of them were delicious but I loved the rich and creamy soup way more, and I know some of you are thinking, it's richer and creamy but more fat but hey majority of the best and delicious food are fat. You know what that means? Time to go gym and workout to lose all the fat and calories and eat more again! The ramen was honestly the best, I think it's handmade on the spot. And OMG their duck and chasu is litty! The organic shoyu was around $14 and the tori paitan was $16 just like it says on the menu on yelp. 

Overall it was a great experience just come early to avoid being the last one. And for those of you hesitating to come, just come or you miss out on the best ramen in San Francisco. Definitely one of those spots that I will be coming back again!

excerpts: My friend had ordered the organic shoyu ramen,  which tasted a lot lighter.
Probably the healthier alternative, if you're looking for one.
organic shoyu.author: Sarah L.
organic shoyu.review:
Like all other reviewers before me said, the wait is long! My friend and I came in around 7 on a Tuesday night, and got in approximately an hour later. We luckily managed to snag two spots at the bar, which was more personable than the other tables, and the place was small. Also asked the waitress if there was a time limit we could dine in and she said no. 

I ordered the Tori Paitan ramen. Now I've never, ever been too picky with my ramen. I would be perfectly content with instant noodles,  obviously preferring dine in when occasions rose for it. But I think this spot definitely changed my idea of what GREAT ramen is. The broth was thick, creamy, and rich. And all the elements combined made for an enriching experience, from the soft, chewy noodles to the tender chashu pork, to the burdock root which added a very nice texture. 

My friend had ordered the organic shoyu ramen,  which tasted a lot lighter. Probably the healthier alternative, if you're looking for one. Although we agreed all the elements of it didn't match as well as the Tori Paitan.

I was also very impressed by our appetizer, oysters in shoyu dare oil. The plate was small with only a few pieces. However, from the very first bite, your taste buds just get sent through the roof. I don't know how else to explain it, but I was hooked. 

The whole meal was very filling, the service was good, and I would happily wait in line again for this place.

excerpts: I got the organic shoyu ramen and my boyfriend got the tori paitan.
WOWWW
I loved the tori paitan more than the shoyu broth.
Probably because it's so thick, dense, and creamy.
One of the best broths I've ever tasted in my life!
I remember my shoyu ramen had pork chashu, duck chashu, kale, bamboo shoots, and some microgreens.
The pork chashu was soooo fatty it melted in my mouth.
I liked it
organic shoyu.author: Caroline B.
organic shoyu.review:
This is a very tiny restaurant, most likely only fits ~40 people. The wait is different from any other place. You and your entire party has to wait in line the entire time until you are called. The wait can be from 45 mins - more than an hour.

I got the organic shoyu ramen and my boyfriend got the tori paitan. WOWWW I loved the tori paitan more than the shoyu broth. Probably because it's so thick, dense, and creamy. One of the best broths I've ever tasted in my life! I remember my shoyu ramen had pork chashu, duck chashu, kale, bamboo shoots, and some microgreens. The pork chashu was soooo fatty it melted in my mouth. I liked it but, I prefer it to be more meaty. 

Overall, I thought it was delicious. I didn't mind how cramped it was but if you have major claustrophobia then maybe this isn't for you. Even though the ramen is pricey ($14-16) it's made with organic products.

excerpts: My friend ordered the organic shoyu, which I sort of wished I ordered instead because even without the spiciness or egg, it just looked more familiar as a soy-based broth.
organic shoyu.author: Stephanie Joyce D.
organic shoyu.review:
Literally what happens: "I'm craving ramen... Hm, maybe I'll pass by Mensho Tokyo... Nooope, ridiculously long line... Maybe next time." Repeat. Repeat. Repeat.

Finally I decided that on a Wednesday I was going to get there early to line up before they opened. Safest bet and smart move because my group of 3 waited no longer than 20 min after opening to get seated.

I ordered the tori paitan because it's what everyone's been raving about. It was unlike any bowl of ramen I've ever eaten before. The broth was thick and creamy, not to mention chicken based. The pork chasu was the most tender I've ever had in ramen, and I loved the flavorful addition of duck. The noodles were also handmade, unlike most ramen shops, which truly added to the uniqueness of the dish.

My problem? I've just been so used to ordering my ramen a specific way that it didn't entirely satisfy my ramen craving. I'm almost embarrassed to say this but my usual basic bitch order is spicy tonkatsu w/ soft-boiled EGG. OMG it was driving me crazy that I could not have the pornographic satisfaction of yolky egg in my ramen. I was also desperate for some heat, and was disappointed that none of the condiments on the table were spicy :( My friend ordered the organic shoyu, which I sort of wished I ordered instead because even without the spiciness or egg, it just looked more familiar as a soy-based broth. My intolerant thoughts aside, the tori paitan was nonetheless a delicious bowl of soup that I would order again if I have a specific hankering for it.

excerpts: the organic shoyu double chashu
and he loves it.
I got a taste of it
and it's phenomenal.
Thin noodles changed my life.
I know I sound over exaggerating it's just ramen is my favorite dish, food, choice to eat!
organic shoyu.author: Cindy H.
organic shoyu.review:
If ramen in Japan taste like this I cannot wait for my trip. Every ramen bowl should taste this good and nothing less. It's so simple and yet delicate. The broth is so delicious it makes you come back for more. Literally I had to pay 2 bridge tolls to eat this again! I got the Tori Paitan double chashu. It is amazing from the specific noodle chosen for the thick broth to the sides in the bowl that compliments it. And my boyfriend likes shoyu so he got the organic shoyu double chashu and he loves it. I got a taste of it and it's phenomenal. Thin noodles changed my life. I know I sound over exaggerating it's just ramen is my favorite dish, food, choice to eat! So I really appreciate Tomoharu Shono for letting us experience your food from home to us here, arigato!

P.S- the line looks intimidating but so worth it, the longest I waited was about an hour and we went for dinner at 7pm. So do always expect a line since they only open for dinner and it's a small shop but again WORTH

excerpts: Must try the Organic Shoyu.
organic shoyu.author: Owie N.
organic shoyu.review:
A few weeks ago I came here with my Bestest for dinner and I love it! I already want to come back to try their other noodles such as their soba! UMM YUM!!!

Some tips to know before coming here:

1) Come EARLY because there's a line...like everything else nowadays in SF...
2) Communal dining with high top tables and no back bar stool.
3) Ask to sit facing the kitchen because it's a better view AND you get a normal chair to lean against. 
4) Must get the TORI PAITAN. Rich, creamy and flavorful.
5) Must try the Organic Shoyu. Great broth texture. 

For about $16 for a bowl of ramen, my happy belly was satisfied. I hope you give this ramen place a try. Cheers!

excerpts: Organic Shoyu Ramen:
Clear Organic Chicken and Pork Soup, Shoyu Dare, Pork Chashu, Duck Chashu, Kale, Kale Sprouts,Chives, Menma, Nori ($16 double chashu)
organic shoyu.author: Elena N.
organic shoyu.review:
I've been wanting to try Mensho for some time, but the line always deterred me. Finally, on Thursday, July 28th, my group of three decided to brave the line around 10:30pm. It honestly didn't take too long. I think about 20 mins.

*Tori Paitan Ramen: Rich and Creamy Chicken Soup, Pork Chashu, Duck Chashu, Menma, Kale, Burdock, Katsuobushi Sauce ($18 double chashu)
*Organic Shoyu Ramen: Clear Organic Chicken and Pork Soup, Shoyu Dare, Pork Chashu, Duck Chashu, Kale, Kale Sprouts,Chives, Menma, Nori ($16 double chashu)
*Shio Ramen: Clear Chicken and Pork Soup, Shio Dare, Pork Chashu, Kale, Menma, Fried Garlic, Chives, Nori ($9)

My favorite, hands down, was the Tori Paitan. The noodles were the right consistency and the broth was rich and flavorful. I wasn't the one who ended up with this bowl, but I was wishing I had ordered it. My Shio ramen was okay. A light flavorful broth. But the noodles were the flat kind and I preferred the thicker noodles from the Tori Paitan better. They had a much better chew. I only tried a spoonful of the broth from the Shoyu Ramen which was fine.

We all know I can't have a meal without alcohol! Two of us got the Sapporo Premium: 355ml/12.0oz ($4.75) and one of us tried the Ozenoyukidoke IPA 12.75: 330ml/11.5oz ($12.75). Pricey for a beer, but a better choice if you like IPAs. I, myself prefer the lighter beers, so the sapporo was perfect for me.

Glad I was finally able to check Mensho Tokyo off my list. Was it worth the 20 min wait? Yes, I would say so. But if I had to wait 1+ hours in the SF cold, I don't know. I'm just happy I'll never have to find out.

excerpts: What I appreciate about Mensho is that they use real stock (including clam dashi...at least for the organic shoyu).
I had the organic shoyu ramen and it was packed with flavor.
organic shoyu.author: Lisa K.
organic shoyu.review:
What I appreciate about Mensho is that they use real stock (including clam dashi...at least for the organic shoyu). You can't call yourself a serious ramen maker without having a good soup base! 

That said, was a tiny bit disappointed to find out they still use MSG, but maybe that's an industry standard for this fast-paced, mass-consumption world. 

Was it worth the hour + wait? Maybe just once. 

I had the organic shoyu ramen and it was packed with flavor. The noodles were perfectly cooked and I appreciated the chewiness. 

Communal seating with high stools with baskets on the floor to store your bags. 

If you come alone, you'll get seated faster!

The friend I was with said she preferred Mensho to the ramen shop in Rockridge across the bay!

excerpts: We decided to try the Tori Paitan (single chashu) at $16 and the organic shoyu ramen (single chashu again) at $14, and enoki chips $5.

Wait time is about an hour to an hour and a half (pending) There is no reservations so prepare to have some time on your hands.

organic shoyu.author: Ed U.
organic shoyu.review:
The advance hype on this place was off the charts, and the breathless texting and taxing anticipation from the hipsterati of self-proclaimed ramen connoisseurs has been quite deafening. A two-plus-hour wait for an $18 bowl of ramen sounds like a Louis C.K. joke about San Francisco millennials with no punchline. I got exhausted thinking about the hoops I'd have to jump through to get a taste of the broth here. However, now that at least six weeks have elapsed since the grand opening in February, I had an opening that I couldn't bypass, the Thursday before Good Friday when I got off work early.

Everyone says to be there at 4PM even though they don't open until an hour later, and so I did. If you don't count the screeching homeless woman who kept sauntering by, no one else showed up until around 4:35PM. That's not to say the staff was indifferent to my presence as they thanked me for coming and waiting patiently. Eventually a line did start to form and rather quickly. I got seated at the front counter promptly at 5PM where I had a nice view of the kitchen where activity was bustling behind he coffee beakers with the broth at full boil and the pork and duck chashu being meticulously sliced. I was sitting with a Filipino family who could barely contain their enthusiasm over the forthcoming noodlefest.

I was feeling the same way and knew what to order since I had well over an hour to decide. I started with their one and only appetizer, the $5 Oysters in Shoyu Dare Oil. There were four of them completely shelled and marinated (photo: http://bit.ly/1Vp0sEV). Tasty freshness gone too soon, but the main event was about to occur. It was the $18 Tori Paitan Ramen with Double Pork Chashu, and I had them add an extra couple of Duck Chashu slices for $1.50 extra because why not go to town? The noodles were perfectly al dente, and the chashu was meaty without being overwhelming. Slices of menma, kale and burdock floated on top with a katsuobushi (bonito) sauce spooned on top (photo: http://bit.ly/224L6pv).

However, for all the fresh ingredients, it was that rich paitan chicken broth that lingers not only on the palate but in my sense-memory. Just the natural creaminess of it was amazing, and what really makes this bowl of ramen stand out against the others. There are three other ramen bowls on the menu - organic shoyu, shio, and vegan tantanmen, as well as a selection of mazesoba bowls. I was timid and just had a $4.75 bottle of Sapporo Premium to wash it all down (photo: http://bit.ly/1RTN9dq), but they have pricier Japanese artisan beers which they strongly recommended to me for the next time. And there will be a next time even as I saw the line go down the block as I departed.

FOOD - 5 stars...best paitan ramen broth ever, period
AMBIANCE - 4.5 stars...clean, white and you only wish it was triple the size to make the line move faster
SERVICE - 5 stars...lovely people work here
TOTAL - 5 stars...not just for self-proclaimed ramen connoisseurs...be patient or come near closing

excerpts: The short: organic shoyu ramen hits the spot
organic shoyu.author: Catherine W.
organic shoyu.review:
The short: organic shoyu ramen hits the spot

If you're not one of the first in line, be prepared to wait about an hour. This place seats about 30 people max, with 2 very long tables, and some seats facing the kitchen. Also be prepared for sitting at a communal table. Some people don't like this...? I don't mind, as long as I have elbow room and have good food!

While in line, we checked out the menu and had a face palm moment when I realized that the description described the items below. Basically, the items below the header start with the basic bowl, and increase in price for additional items. So the four categories are: tori paitan (most ordered based on pictures and reviews), shoyu (what I ordered), shio, and vegan tantanmen.

When the shoyu ramen arrived, I quickly dug in because I was so hungry. The duck chasu and pork chasu was tender, perfectly cooked, and enhanced the broth (wishing there were doubles of each!). Even the kale was an unusual, but nice addition. The broth was perfect, not salty or oily. And the noodles were chewy! At first, it doesn't look like there's a lot of noodles, but the bowl is shaped quite deeply at the bottom, so all the noodles are hidden there. There was so much I liked about this ramen. 

I couldn't figure out what the seasonings on the table were, though there was pink himalayan salt, and maybe some other seasonings to personally enhance the broth to the right taste. I didn't need to as I liked it the way it was.

The waiter was very kind and smiling, which is something I don't see too often. All the seating is on stools, and there are baskets on the ground for bags. The whole inside has a clean and modern aesthetic, with a living wall at the entrance, descriptions of the different types of ramen, and a view into the kitchen. So exciting!

One downside is that this isn't a place to sit and chat after you've eaten the food. Somebody will kindly let you know that there are other patrons outside who are waiting.

It's hard to say if I would wait in line for another hour, but I would come back to arrive right around opening so I don't have to wait so long. Thanks for the experience Mensho!

organic shoyu.review:
There's been a lot of large hype around this place, so the SO and I decided to finally investigate whether or not it was any good. We arrived around 8:30 pm on a Sunday evening, and the wait was most definitely real. It took us an hour to get into the restaurant, but only about ten minutes between getting seated and getting our bowl of delicious ramen served to us.

Anyways, while I wanted so badly to believe that Mensho was going to be the bomb.com, I found myself enjoying the bowl of ramen greatly, though unlikely to ever return back (well, maybe if the lines die down).

The current Mensho menu that everyone posts on the wall is actually an aspirational menu--we chatted with the waitresses and apparently they won't really be serving tsukemen until at least May/June. I was bummed out because the Bay Area has a real shortage of good tsukemen (besides Iza); they currently are serving a Vegan tsukemen if you're into that, but relative to their more popular dishes, I feel like most people are more inclined to try their more popular dishes. We got the following dishes -- I'll do broth and overall reviews and then noodle and content reviews since both bowls basically served the same thing:

Chicken paitan -- the must have for everyone who comes here. I really was not a fan of the chicken paitan. If you love your broths thick and creamy, this is the ramen for you. SO described it like a creamy chicken noodle soup -- flavor was rich, but not particularly nuanced or complex. Overall, easy to have a couple bites of, but you better have a high tolerance for creaminess, otherwise this dish is going to be hard to finish.

Organic shoyu -- I enjoyed this and actually found it be a good ramen. The broth is very light, perhaps salty, but I have a high tolerance for saltiness so I'm not a great judge of that. I thought the flavor was quite delicious, though the soup itself was definitely quite oily. Overall, I enjoyed it, and would have again. The noodles were interesting because they were flat noodles with speckles on it.... never seen that before, but they worked well with the soup.

Overall, noodles for both dishes were good -- they were appropriate complements to their soup base. The contents of the dish were interesting -- the chasu is good, but what I particularly enjoyed was the duck chasu, which I've never had before. I like duck to start with, so it was a nice textural shift to what people are normally used to in ramen. 

I was impressed with the careful attention to detail -- they served the chicken paitan with a wooden spoon and the organic shoyu with a flat metal one, perhaps because the flat metal one wouldn't have been quite as appropriate for the creamy paitan, but maybe we were overthinking it. 

Final price was $40, so definitely on the higher end, but given how expensive everything in the city is, I was pretty happy to have a $40 meal.

Overall, I found the ramen to be fairly good here, maybe not the best ever, but given the ridiculous wait times, it's hard to want to come back because it's not good enough to wait an hour for. Ippudo is also opening in Berkeley within the year, so will be interesting to see how these two big Japanese ramen stores do when they're all situated.

tldr; certainly good ramen with a higher price, but you will likely have to wait an hour for it -- I wouldn't do it again, but I did like the ramen. just didn't like it THAT much.

organic shoyu.review:
4.5 STARS

San Franciscans love shiny new places (and things). 

When it comes to the hottest new restaurant and food trends, many of us spare no expense with our paycheck (and time).

Last year, it was $8 for toast. Ok, not just "toast" but phuckin' bougie, tweezified toast. 

This year, it's $15 coffee (for one cup!) and $18 ramen.

Because, San Francisco! 

Next year, I'm bracing myself for $100 pizza. Oh wait, we already had that during the super bowl (well, I didn't but it was available at Tony's Pizza Napoletana). 

Seriously, what's next? 

Kindly let me know so I can start harvesting my eggs to sell! 

$18 ramen may sound crazy but people waited 3+ hours for this ramen on opening night! 

$18 for a taste of Tokyo? Why not! 

Mensho's first U.S. location is one of the most, if not the most highly anticipated restaurant opening this year in SF! 

Tip: Come at 4 pm (earlier on the weekends) or after 10 pm to avoid long wait times. 

Currently, Mensho has 4 ramen options available ($9-$18) with a single or double chashu option. When the owner returns from Japan in March, their menu will expand. No housemade noodles yet. They have a noodle machine but are awaiting permit(s) to use it (same for the tonkotsu equipment). Disappointingly no marinated soft boiled egg is available but maybe in the future? Beer only; no sake, soda, or juice.

My friend and I ordered three bowls of ramen to share:

(1) Tori Paitan: Rich, creamy chicken soup, pork chashu, duck chashu, menma, kale, burdock, katsuobushi sauce | double chashu $18
http://bit.ly/1XrzETT

Our favorite of the three, the kotteri broth was deliciously creamy (gravy-like) and richly satisfying. It had great depth of umami flavor but did get a bit gritty mid-way. The al-dente noodles were thick, springy, and had a fantastic toothsome chew. 

The chashu is sublime so pony up the extra $ and double up on it! The pork chashu is melt-in-your-mouth tender, like pork butter. It's so ridiculously tender, it falls apart when you pick it up. The duck chashu is silky smooth and chews effortlessly.

The only other ramen shop that offers Tori Paitan is Nojo Ramen Tavern (that I'm aware of). I tried Nojo's last night and there's absolutely no comparison. Mensho's is infinitely superior. 

(2) Organic Shoyu: Organic chicken + pork soup, shoyu dare, pork chashu, duck chashu, kale, kale sprouts, chives, menma, nori | double chashu $16
http://bit.ly/1QfmuKm

A much lighter assari broth but saltier with a slight sweetness since it's a soy sauce based. The duo of chashu were perfection just like in the Tori Paitan ramen. I didn't like the noodles which were overcooked, flat, and lacked chew. 

(3) Shio: Organic chicken + pork soup, shio dare, pork chashu, kale, menma, chives, fried garlic, nori | double chashu $11
http://bit.ly/1Loeijq

The most affordable bowl available, the shio ramen was simple and pure. The assari broth was light and salty but still had depth. Same delicious chashu as the other bowls but the noodles were disappointing like the shoyu ramen. In this bowl, not only were the noodles overcooked, there were two clumps. *sad pouty lip*

(4) Vegan Tantanmen | $18
I'm kicking myself for NOT ordering this too because I love nuts! The broth contains soy cream and 7 kinds of nuts, producing a creamy kotteri broth that looked similar to the Tori Paitan.

I washed everything down with a Sansho beer ($11.75): http://bit.ly/1Px6vnx. Beer usually tastes like carbonated piss to me but this one was refreshing with a gingery lemon spice. Loved it but not the price. 

Service is a work in progress which is understandable since this is Mensho's first foray in the U.S.. They only let 8 or so customers in at a time to not overwhelm the kitchen. They don't fire up orders by tickets, instead they prepare the ramen by type (they really should do the former). We received our order at different times and after people who ordered after us. If your companion(s) orders different ramen than yourself, be prepared to start eating first before the noodles get soggy. 

When I was line I met one of the restaurant partners, Abram aka Ramen Beast. He was uber nice and offered to answer any questions I had. Really cool guy! 

The space is small and only seats 28 - two communal tables and four seats at the counter. We choose to sit at the counter. There's more privacy (if you're on a date) and you can watch the chefs in action.

Read all signs before parking. Do NOT park on Geary from 4-6 pm (tow-away zone) on the weekdays, otherwise your $18 bowl of ramen will turn into a $618+ bowl of ramen. 

Because, San Francisco!

I freaking love ramen, so the second my husband mentioned this new place I was stoked! However walking up to the restaurant, all we could see was a big line out the door. We almost left, but the line was moving a little faster than we thought it would so we stayed and I'm so glad we did! We came on a Wednesday night around 7:30 PM and waited about 45 min before we were seated. But time went by very quickly. As you get closer to the door, an employee will hand you a menu so that you can figure out what you want while you are waiting in line.

Mensho Tokyo is very small. It reminded me of the ramen noodle stalls in Japan. Not a lot of space, but the service is very quick so people are constantly going in and out. All of the tables in the restaurant are communal, so you'll be sitting with other people. Since there isn't a lot of room for you to put your purse, backpack, jacket, etc. they place baskets underneath the tables for you to store your belongings. Thoughtful little touch! 

As soon as we sat down, we were greeted by our server who took our order right away. I ordered the Tori Paitan Ramen which was DELICIOUS! I noticed that everyone at our communal table was eating the same thing. If you like rich, creamy ramen, this is your dish! It was so rich that I couldn't finish it all, but that is definitely some of the best ramen I have ever head. It's very hearty, filling, with pork & duck chasu. The noodles were also pretty thick. Very yummy dish!

My husband got the Organic Shoyu which was served with a clear, organic chicken and pork broth. Also served with pork & duck chasu. Unfortunately he didn't like his dish and it's because it had a very fishy flavor. He asked me to try it and I could immediately smell the fish scent. Neither of us like fish but we didn't know this dish would have fish flavor since it didn't mention it anywhere in the entree description. My husband asked our server if there was fish in the ramen and she confirmed yes, and that a good way to indicate that is if you see Nori as one of the ingredients. We were glad she told us that little fun fact so that we could keep it in mind for future ordering! She was kind enough to take my husband's dish back and he ordered the Tori Paitan and ate the entire thing!

We left Mensho feeling very full and happy. This place is a genuine ramen restaurant that serves amazing food and quick service. Worth standing in line for!

My friend Bryan and I waited two full hours for three bowls of Ramen from Mensho Tokyo. Here's how it went down and read more to be convinced it is worth the wait.

Mensho Tokyo Ramen opened exactly three weeks ago, February 6, 2016. Mensho Tokyo is one of Japan's most popular ramen spots, and San Francisco is its first attempt in North America. I spoke to Abram during my visit, where he told me that the owner has a total of 8 ramen bars in Tokyo, and each of them has its unique menu including Mensho Tokyo so this is not your typical franchise. The two-hour wait was a bit long, but I occasionally chatted with ramen lovers in line, and kept myself occupied.

The hype for this ramen shop is not going to slow down anytime, because of the quality of the ramen it offers. After having lived in Vancouver for more than half my life, and have visited Tokyo and had authentic ramen, I can say that the Organic Shoyu flavour in Mensho Tokyo this is the best bowl of ramen I have ever had in the West Coast of North America.

What I recommend to order:
1) Organic Shoyu ramen
2) Tantan Vegan ramen, add chase
3) Tori Paitan ramen

organic shoyu.review:
Oh Mensho... so this is my #71 ramen review in my ramen list (can you believe that?!). Yes, I'm a bit obsessed with ramen and friends nicknamed me "Ramen Sheriff." Check out my ramen list attached :) 

So when the talk of the town was that Mensho was everyone's new favorite ramen spot, I had to try it for myself. I tried 2 of their bowls at 2 different occasions: 

[May 2016]
I ordered the Tori Paitan while my friend ordered the Shio. I got Tori Paitan because everyone raved about it - for me, it was very rich and flavorful, however too creamy and heavy for me. It didn't even taste like broth anymore, it was like a gravy sauce, which I was not a fan of. I was jealous of my friend's Shio because it was so flavorful and light. I gave my Tori Paitan 2.5 stars and he gave his 5. I do agree that the noodles are really good here though. Perfect texture and taste. 

[Oct 2016]
Decided to give Mensho another chance. This time I ordered the Shio and my friend ordered the Organic Shoyu. Shio was much better than the Tori Paitan I ordered before, but I thought my bowl was a little bit salty. I tried the Shoyu which tasted similar to the Shio but with a kick of light soy sauce. Noodles were great again, pork was not bad, but flawed in the broth again. I was hoping second time around would have me agree with everyone else, but with the amount of ramen bowls I've had, I can't help but compare.

OVERALL: Mensho has great texture and taste for their noodles and decent pork, however although their broths are unique and somewhat similar to Japan, it still does not quite hit the spot. If you really want authentic ramen, hit up Clint at Noodle in Haystack and reserve one of his pop up ramen dinners! It's the closest thing you'll get to Japan :)

Three stars for the noodles themselves. The soups I tried left much to be desired. Neither ramen that I tried would bring me back. I feel like I'm supposed to like this place because it's so hot right now. and new. and from tokyo. but, it's just okay. 

gomenaisai not gomenasai.

++1/2 Oysters in Shoyu Dare Oil. (3 pieces) $5

This was good; a nice, simple appetizer. the oysters aren't large, and seems like something that came out of a can, frankly, but still, I liked it and would order it again. It just works.

++ Tori Paitan Ramen (Double Chashu) $18
(Rich and Creamy Chicken Soup, Pork Chashu, Duck Chashu, Menma, Kale, Burdock, Katsuobushi Sauce)

Ahhh... I can't eat this. It sounds good, smells good, looks good as food porn, but it is SO RICH. It's just short of being a gravy. I ordered this on my first visit and made a mental note not to order it again. On my second visit, I didn't order it, but when I smelled it and saw it, I doubted my decision. Then I had a sip of the soup and I was like nope. The noodles are really chewy, and the soup flavor is good, but after the first few bites it already feels like too much. 


++ Organic Shoyu Ramen (Double Chashu) $16
(Clear Organic Chicken and Pork Soup, Shoyu Dare, Pork Chashu, Duck Chashu, Kale, Kale Sprouts,Chives, Menma, Nori)

The duck was okay; chashu was better but it was nice to have another meat choice in the ramen. I think it was hard to notice the chashu in the tori paitan, due to the decadence of the soup, but in the shoyu, the chashu is a fatty standout. probably the best chashu in a ramen that i've had. the noodles in the shoyu are good, but different - thinner and lighter than it's tori paitan counterpart. it paired well w/ the shoyu broth. The broth itself tasted like bonito more than shoyu. 


I would not come back for these two ramen dishes, but I still want to come back to try the other options. As for the wait, we waited about 30 minutes the first time, and maybe 20 minutes the second time. Not bad at all. Once you're in, though, the seats and ambiance are not intended to have patrons stay and shoot the shit. They want you in and out -- in that sense, it's a traditional ramen experience.

excerpts: i tried the broth for shio, organic shoyu, and tori paitan.
organic shoyu.author: Judy L.
organic shoyu.review:
the wait in the cold was not so fun. we were about 10 parties back in queue, and waited about 1 hour on a saturday evening around 9pm. it's communal tables with decently quick service. 

our party of 4 all got different dishes. my vegan tantanmen was DELECTABLE. super rich, peanut-y base, perfectly alkaline aldente ramen. i tried the broth for shio, organic shoyu, and tori paitan. all very good, but the vegan tantanmen was my favorite of the meal.

also try the oysters!!!

excerpts: Most of us ordered the Tori Paitan ($16 rich and creamy chicken soup, pork chashu, duck chashu, menma, kale, burdock, katsuobushi sauce) with one lone Organic Shoyu ($14 clear organic chicken and pork Soup, shoyu dare, pork chashu, duck chashu, kale, kale sprouts, chives, menma, nori).

The ramen came out piping hot
so I was unable to really slurp and go as intended.
The noodles were slightly thicker but not thick, and nice and chewy.
I didn't try the Shoyu but the friend who ordered it and his date tried both and declared the Tori Paitan much better.
organic shoyu.author: Jean K.
organic shoyu.review:
Came for dinner last night before seeing a play down the street. At 6pm on a Wed we only had to wait about 20 minutes for a table for 4 and an additional 10 minutes for the food to arrive after we ordered while waiting in line. 

Most of us ordered the Tori Paitan ($16 rich and creamy chicken soup, pork chashu, duck chashu, menma, kale, burdock, katsuobushi sauce) with one lone Organic Shoyu ($14 clear organic chicken and pork Soup, shoyu dare, pork chashu, duck chashu, kale, kale sprouts, chives, menma, nori).

The Tori Paitan was rich and creamy as described. The ramen came out piping hot so I was unable to really slurp and go as intended. The noodles were slightly thicker but not thick, and nice and chewy. The broth was a little too rich to drink on it's own but really good with noodles and meat and bits. 

I didn't try the Shoyu but the friend who ordered it and his date tried both and declared the Tori Paitan much better.

Not sure I would wait an hour but would make an effort to get in for an early dinner.

excerpts: I ate the Tori Paitan and my boyfriend had the Organic Shoyu.
organic shoyu.author: Samantha M.
organic shoyu.review:
Be ready to wait outside. But yes, completely worth it. I would go back and wait the line all over again.

I'm from Miami. My friend was here a few weeks back and came here with her husband to eat and told me exactly in these words "I don't care how long the line is or how cold you are, you get your butt in that line and wait."

I ate the Tori Paitan and my boyfriend had the Organic Shoyu. We shared the mushroom chips for the appetizer and had some sake and 2 Sapporos.

The staff is friendly and your food is served rather quick. The warm broth is the perfect comfort food for this San Fran weather. Especially us, since we're from Miami and FREEZING! Highly recommend!!!

excerpts: The organic shoyu ramen was too salty with strong a undercurrent of bonito and seaweed.
organic shoyu.author: Catherine C.
organic shoyu.review:
I hate waiting in lines, but like half of the Asian population in SF I just couldn't resist coming here to test my luck on a Saturday afternoon. I recommend coming 40 mins before opening in order to avoid a 1.5+ hour wait. We almost made it to the first round of seating by coming 20 mins before opening, but clearly there were people out there more determined than we were. The line only got worse after we were done eating around 7pm. 

Following the footsteps of fellow Yelpers, we each ordered the Double Chasu Tori Paitan Ramen at $18. I thought it was a little steep considering that the ramen didn't come with an egg, and double meat really just meant two thin slices of pork chasu and two thin slices of duck chasu. The duck was definitely the highlight of meal. The pork was on the salty side. Noodles were chewy and el dente just the way I like it. Broth was creamy but so loaded with chicken fat that it was deemed too unhealthy and rich to be drinkable by my friends...but I did it anyways! 

The organic shoyu ramen was too salty with strong a undercurrent of bonito and seaweed. The Tori Paitan was the clear winner here, but if you're not into thick broths, don't even bother coming here.

Customer service was efficient, and the greeter at the door was friendly. 

The restaurant seats around 25 people and is pretty tiny. Expect to squeeze with strangers at your table. Decor was clean and modern. I like that they have personal baskets below the table for you to store your purse and jacket. 

Overall worth a try for the duck chasu and delightfully chewy noodles, but not worth repeat visits because of the line.

excerpts: I had the opportunity to try the Tori Paitan Double Chashu and the Organic Shoyu Ramen Double Chasu.
Tori Paitan -
This isn't your typical ramen you'll get at Santouka or Orenchi; it is a must try.
The broth is thicker, heavier, and I would say a little bit creamy.
The noodles here are definitely hand made.
The broth stuck to the noodles so well that it was like eating soup and noodles at the same time!
It was a very harmonious dish.
Organic Shoyu -
The soup for this ramen isn't as heavy as the Tori Paitan.
It is lighter but came across super oily in my opinion.
Noodles in my Ramen were in the softer side.
So if you like stiff noodles, then don't expect that here.
Also the chashu is so soft, flavorful, and tender.
organic shoyu.author: Stefanie W.
organic shoyu.review:
This place is like a hidden gem. 

The shop itself is quite small so be prepared to wait to be seated. I arrived at the shop around 6ish and ended up waiting for an hour before we got seated. Luckily it was a nice warm day in San Francisco. 

Once you are seated, they are very prompt and quick with their service as their line is never ending. I had the opportunity to try the Tori Paitan Double Chashu and the Organic Shoyu Ramen Double Chasu.

Tori Paitan - This isn't your typical ramen you'll get at Santouka or Orenchi; it is a must try. The broth is thicker, heavier, and I would say a little bit creamy. The noodles here are definitely hand made. The broth stuck to the noodles so well that it was like eating soup and noodles at the same time! It was a very harmonious dish. If you're looking for something with a powerful flavor you should get this dish.

Organic Shoyu - The soup for this ramen isn't as heavy as the Tori Paitan. It is lighter but came across super oily in my opinion. Noodles in my Ramen were in the softer side. So if you like stiff noodles, then don't expect that here. Also the chashu is so soft, flavorful, and tender. It falls apart easily and makes it easy to eat. 

This place definitely has nailed the umami taste.

excerpts: Food: I got the organic shoyu ramen with no duck, just 2 pork charshu.
The broth was rich, but not too heavy or salty.
The noodles were thick - different from any other ramen I've had.
This was worth the wait.
organic shoyu.author: Shelley K.
organic shoyu.review:

Service: Food comes out very quickly, and the ladies are very helpful and quick even though they are so busy. We were in and out within 35 minutes! 

Food: I got the organic shoyu ramen with no duck, just 2 pork charshu. The broth was rich, but not too heavy or salty. The noodles were thick - different from any other ramen I've had. This was worth the wait.
