organic shoyu ramen.review:
Arrived around 4:45 and waited in line for them to open.
Not too fond of the crowded communion tables. The establishment is small, so they must make do. We were the last group seated and right at the edge of the table, so we were able to get their attention and order first. Lucky!
The Organic Shoyu Ramen ($14) was pretty good. Not sure if the oil was drizzled on or just part of the broth. The broth was tasty but not feeling the oil. The Tori Paitan ($16) was good. Our party member who ordered the Shio Ramen ($9) thought it was a bit bland and didn't finish it.
Glad we tried it but not a spot we would frequent.

excerpts: I ordered the Organic Shoyu Ramen and a draft Sapporo.
I only later saw that they had tsukemen which I will try next time.
The guy sitting across from me had it.
It wasn't like the tsukemen I get in Tokyo.
The noodles are served dry but there is no dip sauce.
Nevertheless, they looked good and the noodles were mixed with a large number of toppings.
organic shoyu ramen.author: Douglas E.
organic shoyu ramen.review:
Was walking around Westfield Mall on Market when I felt like ramen. Saw positive reviews and thought I would try Mensho. When I arrived at 7:10pm, there were about 20 people in line. As a single, I sat a little more quickly - in about twenty minutes.  The group of four immediately behind me sat down about twenty minutes after me (I just noticed that there sure we're a lot of twenties in this first paragraph) at which time I was finishing up my noodles and getting ready to pay. 

I ordered the Organic Shoyu Ramen and a draft Sapporo. I only later saw that they had tsukemen which I will try next time. The guy sitting across from me had it.  It wasn't like the tsukemen I get in Tokyo. The noodles are served dry but there is no dip sauce.  Nevertheless, they looked good and the noodles were mixed with a large number of toppings. The bowl of tsukemen looked like it had about twice the amount of noodles when compared to my ramen. 

My ramen took about 10 minutes to arrive.  The came with both duck and chashu. The noodles were flat as pictured by many in this review. The soup was clean and pretty tasty. The noodles were a little bit softer than I normally like but overall pretty good. Both the duck and the pork were cooked well and quite soft. There was a lot of fat with both which I appreciated.

Overall, the ramen was good. I would probably try to come earlier next time so that I might have a shorter line.

excerpts: I visited Mensho Tokyo with some friends, and had their organic shoyu ramen.
It was hands-down the best ramen I've had.
organic shoyu ramen.author: Robert M.
organic shoyu ramen.review:
I visited Mensho Tokyo with some friends, and had their organic shoyu ramen. It was hands-down the best ramen I've had. The broth was exceptionally balanced and the meat was super tender - the portion was quite large too. 

To improve, the restaurant could definitely offer better seating options; the highchairs are not that comfortable. I was fortunate to have friends bear the line for me (upwards of a 30+ minute wait, though I've heard it is commonly 45-1hr+), but it'd also seem worthwhile for them to offer reservations or a better line management system.

TLDR: The ramen is exceptional - the wait and seating options are not.

excerpts: I ordered the organic Shoyu ramen and my bf ordered the Tori Paitan ramen.
The Shoyu soup base tasted amazing but the noodles in the Tori Paitan were better.
I wish people would eat a little faster though, considering the fact that there is always a long line...
Eat like the people in Japan do!
organic shoyu ramen.author: Jamie T.
organic shoyu ramen.review:
My bf and I came here at around 930pm on a weekday and there was a line with 10-15 people. The wait was about 35-40 mins which wasn't too bad... We got seated by the glass window in front of the kitchen. The servers were super friendly and gave great customer service.

I ordered the organic Shoyu ramen and my bf ordered the Tori Paitan ramen. The Shoyu soup base tasted amazing but the noodles in the Tori Paitan were better. I wish people would eat a little faster though, considering the fact that there is always a long line... Eat like the people in Japan do!

excerpts: "  OK to be honest, actually I wrote down "shiyo" based on phonetics but now that I look at their menu online, they have $14 "organic shoyu ramen" and $9 "shio ramen
" so I'm not totally sure what we ordered.
Anyway, it was what thinner and what most people would probably recognize as "ramen."  Not as good as the others.
Still need to try the Shio... or Shoyu.
organic shoyu ramen.author: Aaron M.
organic shoyu ramen.review:
YUM - welcome Tokyo to SF!  Yes, this is the crazy thick broth ramen place that will change your life.  So do it.  Now I know you're going to order the tori paitan ramen which is their deservedly famous meaty dish with a chicken-ish broth, but let me also encourage you to order a couple other things:
- The vegan tantamen, which the chef recommended as his second choice, and which is an awesome, slightly nutty contrast with the tori paitan.  In fact, we kept alternating between the two because each one seemed to make the other one taste awesomer and each was awesome by itself.
- The oysters!  These had "shiyo oil" on them, which gave me flashback to the first time I had truffle oil: the first bite is a bit "unusual" or foreign, the second bite affirms that this foreign taste is actually good and fits in with other savory aromatic foods, and by the third bite you are ready to pay double the price just to have a little more.  Don't tell anyone but I actually licked the oil off the mini plate after the oysters were gone.  
- The Sansho beer, which is perhaps my favorite "herbal" beer ever - with a hint of Japanese peppercorn.  Disclosure: this beer is expensive as f*ck at over $1 per ounce.  Splurge and get two.

Out of curiosity we also ordered the $14 Shiyo ramen, which is listed on the receipt as "organic ramen."  OK to be honest, actually I wrote down "shiyo" based on phonetics but now that I look at their menu online, they have $14 "organic shoyu ramen" and $9 "shio ramen" so I'm not totally sure what we ordered.  Anyway, it was what thinner and what most people would probably recognize as "ramen."  Not as good as the others.  Still need to try the Shio... or Shoyu.

excerpts: Well, we waited almost 3 hours, I ordered organic shoyu ramen, but I really recommend tori paitan.
Seriously!
organic shoyu ramen.author: Tony S.
organic shoyu ramen.review: Well, we waited almost 3 hours, I ordered organic shoyu ramen, but I really recommend tori paitan. Seriously!

excerpts: I ordered the organic shoyu ramen; it was slightly lighter but just as flavorful.
organic shoyu ramen.author: Jules G.
organic shoyu ramen.review:
My friends and I were here on a misty Friday evening. We arrived before 5:30 pm and there was already a long line. Be ready for a really long wait! If you're super hungry, you may want to bring snacks. The group behind us left to buy snacks at some point. Our party of four were finally seated a little after 7:30 pm. Thankfully our bowls of deliciousness were quick to arrive after we'd ordered.

Was it worth the wait? It certainly was! Two friends ordered the tori paitan, which is their richest, creamiest option. One friend ordered the vegan tantanmen, which I loved and attempted to switch with my own bowl of ramen. I ordered the organic shoyu ramen; it was slightly lighter but just as flavorful. They're all good; it just depends on personal preferences.

They currently don't serve eggs in their ramen. We asked the staff and they mentioned they're carefully selecting a type of egg that is equivalent to those in Japan. It's nice to know they're so particular about their ingredients.

I would definitely return but I wouldn't wait over two hours again.

excerpts: Their Shio ramen looks great as well as the fried enoki mushroom appetizer.
Will def.
bring my dad here next time to try some other flavors.
shio.author: Spencer W.
shio.review:
4.4 Stars if I could give. Also, not going to review anything about waiting in line only to the food and service.  The third thing you'll notice are the outstanding ramen noodles, very chewing and thick.  The first thing being presentation and second you'll probably take a sip of the soup.   Although those noodles are the star of the show IMO.  There is quite a bit of difference in flavor & saltiness depending on which type of soup you choose.  Ramen bowls rated:

Spicy Tori Paitan - 5 stars, great flavor and seasoned appropriately
Vegan Tantanmen - 5 stars, also excellent flavor and seasoning. 
Matcha Tori Paitan - 3.5, flavor wasn't as deep as the other two bowls and needed more salt to the broth, although the broth was rich.  

The table does have a pink salt grinder sitting there for anyone that would like to add more salt to their soup.  Their Shio ramen looks great as well as the fried enoki mushroom appetizer.   Will def. bring my dad here next time to try some other flavors.

excerpts: My party ordered 2 orders of Orangic Shoyu Ramen ($14.5) , and 1 Shio Ramen ($12).
The Shoyu Ramen's broth tastes great at first, but after eating it for a while, it gets super salty, and makes you crave water.
Their broth has a soy sauce like taste to it, while the Shio has a Fish Oil taste to their broth.
shio.author: Jessica H.
shio.review:
I came to Mensho Tokyo after being heavily referred to it. We arrived around 5:21PM on a Saturday afternoon, and had to wait around an hour before we were seated. There seems to always be a line no matter what, because the place is super small, and only has two rows of seats. The service is pretty quick though. They're quick to take your order, and quick to get your food out, so I recommend looking at the menu before you head inside. 

My party ordered 2 orders of Orangic Shoyu Ramen ($14.5) , and 1 Shio Ramen ($12). The Shoyu Ramen's broth tastes great at first, but after eating it for a while, it gets super salty, and makes you crave water. Their broth has a soy sauce like taste to it, while the Shio has a Fish Oil taste to their broth. I wish I ordered their Tori Paitan Ramen, which seems to be the highlight of their shop! I'll try it next time I come. Noodles seem to be handmade (?) because of their difference in length. 

Mensho Tokyo will always have a line, so I recommend getting here as early as possible, and waiting before opening. Prices are decent, but eating here made me feel really rushed since I felt like I didn't really get to sit and enjoy the place before finishing my food and getting out. The vibe here is very hipster with their white walls being decorated with chemistry ramen facts, and Drake being played in the background. 

This is not the place to go for authentic, whole in the wall ramen, but a place to go if you want simplistic, nice ramen (looks great in pictures!) I prefer more Japanese authenticity in my ramen, and a shorter wait time if possible personally, but this seems to be the place to try, for the moment.

excerpts: In all honesty I was not a fan of Mensho after my first visit - that first time I tried the Tori Paiten Ramen, Specialty Maccha Ramen, and the Shio Ramen.
All of which were just A-OK in my opinion.
shio.author: Elaine N.
shio.review:
In all honesty I was not a fan of Mensho after my first visit - that first time I tried the Tori Paiten Ramen, Specialty Maccha Ramen, and the Shio Ramen. All of which were just A-OK in my opinion. After a mediocre first experience I was hesitant to wait in line and try this place again.

My friend invited me to try Mensho's 2nd Anniversary Specialty Ramen - A5 Wagyu Ramen and it was to. die. for. The wagyu was flown in from Miyasaki, Japan - fatty, flavorful and tender. Too bad it was only limited time and they only served 10 bowls/day over a span of a few days. 

Not only was the special bowl delicious, at this visit I also got a chance to try the Aburasoba which is a dry noodle served with pork chashu, green onion, menma, and the usual toppings. Top with as much chili oil and vinegar as your heart desires, and voila.... OISHI. I have officially had a change of heart regarding Mensho and I have to say that the Aburasoba makes the wait worth it.

excerpts: I got the Shio Ramen and it wasn't too salty nor was it too fatty.
The noodles are spirally and wide enough to soak up the broth.
shio.author: Jenny Q.
shio.review:
OH MY LAWD. This unassuming ramen shop is realllly tasty. I got the Shio Ramen and it wasn't too salty nor was it too fatty. The noodles are spirally and wide enough to soak up the broth. In the future, I'd want the noodles a little harder, but overall an amazing dish and a cute place where you're knocking elbows with your neighbors.

I want to try their fried mushrooms next time, it looked really tasty and not oily.

excerpts: I got shio char siu ramen with an egg and it was really good, but felt overhyped.
I got the egg as an extra and the egg was warm and had a strong soy-flavor.
shio.author: Lizzie S.
shio.review:
I DID MY WAITING. TWO HOURS OF IT. Not in Azkaban, but outside Mensho near the Tenderloin.

My friend raved about this place and said the wait would be one hour. Instead, it was two. And it was good, but not worth the two hour wait. 

I got shio char siu ramen with an egg and it was really good, but felt overhyped. I got the egg as an extra and the egg was warm and had a strong soy-flavor. The broth was rich, warm, and savory, and the noodles had a good consistency. 

The restaurant is cramped and small and tea is not included and ramen portions aren't as big as Santa Ramen/Ramen Dojo/Ramen Bar in San Mateo. They also don't offer takeout boxes.

excerpts: I tried their other ramen choices , such as shio and clam ramen - however, wasn't too impressed.
I think it's just personal preference/
taste thing though because my other friends liked the shio.
shio.author: Solongo B.
shio.review:
For some strange reason, I crave Mensho almost exclusively on Mondays...the only day I can't have Mensho. Then I go through the test of patience and suffering until Tuesday. 

Needless to say Mensho is my favorite ramen spot in the city because of my love for. Thick. Rich. Ramen. 

My go tos are the Tori Paitan and the Spicy Lamb. Tori Paitan never disappoints on cold SF evenings with its thick rich flavorful broth, but spicy lamb can be a little too salty sometimes. Let's just say the spicy lamb is burst with flavors - sometimes your mouth gets confused and overwhelmed in a good way.

Enoki mushrooms? I could go either way , but get it only if you are ordering a beer :P 

I tried their other ramen choices , such as shio and clam ramen - however, wasn't too impressed. I think it's just personal preference/taste thing though because my other friends liked the shio. FYI: clam butter ramen is limited to 10 each day, and takes longer to make than other ramen.

I dare you to point out a rich thick ramen spot that's better than Mensho in SF.

excerpts: - Shio: If you're into fishy flavors, this lighter ramen for under $10 fills a lighter meal than the above two items and has a deep umami flavor.
Not a fan of fishiness?
shio.author: Joanne Y.
shio.review:
I don't like ramen.

I don't like ramen.

I don't like ramen.

Oh wait, wtf... I do.

Mensho has shaped the way I think about ramen and completely turned me on to my obsessive search for good ramen everywhere. I've eaten practically every item on their menu now and still love it. The lines, yes, are still ridiculously long unless you get there just before 5pm or after 11pm, but it's worth the wait.

My favorites are:
- Vegan Ramen: I love meat, but this vegan ramen is quite something. The flavors are not as "heavy" as the other favorite, the Tori Paitan, but yet it's still a filling meal here. It feels a little healthier too!
- Tori Paitan: Creamy, rich, delicious pork broth; this one is a classic. It's mouth-watering savory!
- Shio: If you're into fishy flavors, this lighter ramen for under $10 fills a lighter meal than the above two items and has a deep umami flavor. Not a fan of fishiness? Probably shouldn't choose this or the shoyu.

The only bad ramen I've had here was the worst ramen I've ever had in my life, but it was a temporary summer chicken and corn special that isn't a menu staple. I've tried some of the dry ramens too which are good as well, but not exactly my cup of tea (or soup for that matter).

Why Mensho stands out:
- Ramen: has a lot of chew, and are thicker noodles to my liking.
- Broth: deep, deep umami flavor that gives it the complexity many ramen places miss.
- Meat: by far the BEST meat on ramen I've ever had. It's seasoned well, isn't dry at all, and they have both duck and pork options (both which are amazing).

Basically, Mensho's ramen stands out in all regards.

Note: They do not do takeout, they do not let you box home food, everyone who comes in has to order their own bowl of ramen, and sometimes they play very hyped up music which doesn't really make sense for the environment... but for the amazing ramen that hits the spot every time, I will deal with these minor inconveniences.

excerpts: Shio Chashu Ramen with egg - underwhelming, clear broth was lacking flavor.
shio.author: Jann B.
shio.review:
Not the best ramen spot, but good enough to visit at least once!  They do not accept reservations, so I would advise you to come early if you can.  

Shio Chashu Ramen with egg - underwhelming, clear broth was lacking flavor.  

Tori Paitan Ramen with egg - creamy and rich broth.  This bowl was full of flavors, my husband and I favored this one a hundred times more!  Noodles are served a little thicker than the previous bowl which complemented the soup just nicely.  Definitely something I would order again.

A few things to note, automatic 15% added to your bill for gratuity and they do not offer take out containers for you.  Their portion sizes are quite generous so if you know you wont be able to finish your bowl, you are allowed to bring your own.  Overall, delicious ramen but not delicious enough to wait 90 min in the cold delicious.  Would return again on the rare occasion that there isn't a line out the door.

excerpts:
3 stars

Shio: 3 stars
Broth tastes of fried garlic and fishy bonito flakes, a bit salty.
shio.author: Letitia L.
shio.review:
The line is always so long but it's worth the wait! Pretty different / original types of ramen, but quality wise it's a bit better than the San Francisco Ippudo in my opinion, and on par with Ippudo in Singapore.


---- RAMEN ----

Spicy Tori Paitan Ramen: 5 stars
Tori Paitan: 5 stars
The creamy "paitan" broth is to die for. It's like the most flavourful gravy ever.

Organic Shoyu Ramen: 3 stars

Shio: 3 stars
Broth tastes of fried garlic and fishy bonito flakes, a bit salty.

excerpts: My favorite is the Ume-Shio ramen, and the enoki chips.
You have to check this place out if you are visiting/living in SF.
Put it on your bucket-list.
shio.author: Amy C.
shio.review:
Yuuummmmm Mensho! My favorite ramen spot in SF! Ahhh the chef's dedicate their everything in the ramens here at Mensho! It's so good. It takes 30-1:30 min to get your ramen but hands down its so worth it. I've been here like 15 times. I'm a fan. I honestly don't remember having eaten so good ramen outside of Japan! My favorite is the Ume-Shio ramen, and the enoki chips. You have to check this place out if you are visiting/living in SF. Put it on your bucket-list. Tip: only go if you are going alone, or with one more person; you will get seated faster if the table is for one or two ;)

...

excerpts: Shio Ramen with Double Chashu - Broth is supposed to be pork and chicken based with fried garlic, but I thought it was underwhelming and lacked flavor (pretty must just tasted like salt and oil).
I thought the kale in ramen was a bit weird, it was bland and didn't do anything to enhance the ramen for me besides adding a bit of a crunchy texture which the menma is already supposed to do.
shio.author: Jenny L.
shio.review:
Got here when they opened, but the restaurant was already full and there was a line out the door. Ended up waiting an hour to get seated. 

Oysters in Shoyu Dare Oil - Looks like something you get out of a can. Smells and taste pungent but I liked it for some reason and goes pretty well with the ramen.

Shio Ramen with Double Chashu - Broth is supposed to be pork and chicken based with fried garlic, but I thought it was underwhelming and lacked flavor (pretty must just tasted like salt and oil). I thought the kale in ramen was a bit weird, it was bland and didn't do anything to enhance the ramen for me besides adding a bit of a crunchy texture which the menma is already supposed to do. Chashu was the only thing good, was flavorful, tender, fatty, and melt in your mouth.

Service was quick and prompt, but never felt rushed and 15% charge for gratuity is automatically added to your bill.

Maybe I chose the wrong broth or maybe they were having an off day, but I was not impressed. Cup noodles taste better.

excerpts: If you are like me, prefer something that is slightly lighter and go well with the noodles, I would suggest Shio or Shoyu, both made with clear soup base.
shio.author: Elaine H.
shio.review:
This bowl of ramen was total worth the hype! If you are wondering whether you should wait for at least an hour, or like me, stood outside thirty minute before they opened their door, you can stop wasting your time there and just line up.

This place was the first US outpost of that trendy Japanese ramen bar Mensho, so people get insane, I get it. Their menu was rather simple, if you enjoy a thick creamy broth that itself might serves as a standalone meal, go with the Tori Paitan, which was as fulfilling as you could imagine. If you are like me, prefer something that is slightly lighter and go well with the noodles, I would suggest Shio or Shoyu, both made with clear soup base. I went a step further by ordering the veggie Dandan ramen, which was recommended by the chef as their "best", while added the duck slices. 

Unfortunately they stopped supplying the soy-marinated eggs, and according to the chef, it was due to the concern of egg quality in US. Ok totally with him, I'd rather skip the whole thing if it was no good.

Lastly, noodles - this is the best part! Very different from the traditional instant noodle type, the noodles here were thick, chewy, and tasted hand-made! Felt to me that they had absorbed the broth so very flavorful as well! Heaven!

I guess starting from today I would ignore ramen in SF, as I have already experienced the best.

excerpts: I tried shio ramen.
The broth was made from meat so the soup was oily and too salty for me.
I could not drink most of the soup since it was too salty.
The noodles were great though.
It might have been better for me to have gotten the Tsukemen.
shio.author: Sarah C.
shio.review: The long line was not worth it for me. I tried shio ramen. The broth was made from meat so the soup was oily and too salty for me. I could not drink most of the soup since it was too salty. The noodles were great though. It might have been better for me to have gotten the Tsukemen.

excerpts: so I added ground lamb, the mushroom chips (So good) and the Shio with
a miso egg added.
shio.author: kennice g.
shio.review:
I'm glad I got the heads up about the line. We arrived 30 minutes before they opened and there were already around 14 people ahead of us. Luckily we got in with the first round (It's a very small place). We ordered the Vegan Ramen (there's only one) I'm not vegan so I added ground lamb, the mushroom chips (So good) and the Shio with a miso egg added. Everything was delicious, filling, the service was quick and attentive but I felt like it was hard to hear talking across the table. 

Don't go if you're starving but do try it out. Best Ramen I've ever had!

excerpts: I came for ramen -- the kind that comes with soup (miso, shoyu, shio, kombu...etc.) and noodles made from kansui (the yellow, wavy noodles that soup clings onto, not that white, flour/wheat noodle stuff).
shio.author: Mel L.
shio.review:
There was only one vegetarian option on the menu, which is the tan tan noodle.

While it started out really flavorful and delicious, it became far too rich and heavy halfway through the bowl. I also take offense to the fact that they can't seem to make a vegetarian broth, but can put in so much effort into this sesame sauce.

If I wanted saucy noodles, I'd just go to a better Chinese restaurant. I came for ramen -- the kind that comes with soup (miso, shoyu, shio, kombu...etc.) and noodles made from kansui (the yellow, wavy noodles that soup clings onto, not that white, flour/wheat noodle stuff).

excerpts: I knocked off 1 start from their perfect rating because tonight's Shio ramen my friend ordered was pretty much bad.
after trying my friend's Shio, Mensho dropped in ratings a bit.
I also found out that they don't have togo boxes.
My friend didn't finish the Shio but couldn't take it home.
There was tons of ramen left!
shio.author: Ticha B.
shio.review:
Mensho Tokyo is my must have when I come up to catch the Giants in San Francisco. Almost a tradition that I come in for dinner after an afternoon game. The area is sketchy, I hate that you have to stand in line with all the locals of the Tenderloin coming up to you and asking for change and food. 

I think Mensho has the best ramen around. I also understand that there will always be a wait since the restaurant itself is small (fire marshal notice says 49 or so). So that's not the problem. 

I knocked off 1 start from their perfect rating because tonight's Shio ramen my friend ordered was pretty much bad. I always go with the flavorful Tori Paitan which is delicious but after trying my friend's Shio, Mensho dropped in ratings a bit. I also found out that they don't have togo boxes. My friend didn't finish the Shio but couldn't take it home. There was tons of ramen left! :(

Sorry...you were rated too honors in my books for a couple of years until tonight. I'd definitely be back to stand in line again for your Tori Paitan!

excerpts: My boyfriend ordered the Shio Chashu Ramen which includes clear chicken and pork Soup, shio dare, pork chashu, kale, menma, fried garlic, chives, and nori.
We both enjoyed our ramen very much and left with happy full bellies!
shio.author: Annie L.
shio.review: This has been on my go-to list for awhile and I finally made the effort to wait in line for it! I got there around 4:30pm on a Saturday afternoon and there was a good amount of people in line already. As the doors opened at 5pm, they let people in and unfortunately, stopped at me and my boyfriend so we had to wait for the next batch to go in (they only have about 28 seats). By 5:30pm we were seated and I ordered the Spicy Lamb Chashu Ramen. It was a BURST of flavors in my mouth: the spicy, the lamb, the chashu and the thick broth. The ramen noodles was my favorite part as it was just perfect. It is the thicker ramen noodles, chewy with a bounce. My boyfriend ordered the Shio Chashu Ramen which includes clear chicken and pork Soup, shio dare, pork chashu, kale, menma, fried garlic, chives, and nori. We both enjoyed our ramen very much and left with happy full bellies!

excerpts: My two friends ordered the Shoyu ramen and I ordered the Shio ramen.
The food arrived fairly quickly and all came out at the same time.
SHIO RAMEN:
It came with bamboo shoots, chashu, noodles, and kale.
The kale was definitely an interesting addition to a bowl of ramen but none of the less, a great one because I like kale.
The clear broth was delicious, which was perfect for me since I like it light.
After one sip of the broth, I knew that it'd satisfy my ramen cravings.
The flavors in the broth were distinct and I instantly knew that waiting in the cold was worth it since the broth was one of the best I've ever had.
The noodles were interesting and different since it was kind of flat and thin.
One thing that was a bit disappointing was the chashu.
The chashu was barely warm and didn't complement the ramen since it wasn't the same temperature.
It would have been better if the meat was heated up more and if it had more flavor.
I also wish my bowl of ramen came with more broth because my bowl looked like it had less than my friends.
I slurped all the noodles, devoured the bamboo shoots and chasu, and gulped all the broth.
At the end, I was left staring at an empty white bowl hoping that more ramen would magically appear.
All in all, Mensho Tokyo is worth lining up in for.
I usually avoid restaurants that have long wait times since I tend to grow quite impatient, but I'm willing wait here again.
Hit up some friends (to make time past by faster), bring some small snacks (so you don't starve while waiting), and stand in this crazy line for a bowl of delicious ramen.
And yes, the hype is real!!
shio.author: Michelle F.
shio.review:
After hearing all my friends rave about this place, I had to go try it myself. Knowing that there was hardly any street parking and that the area around it was a little sketch, we decided to take an Uber there (good idea). 

Mensho Tokyo opened at 5pm, and we arrived there at 6pm on a Wednesday. Make sure to layer up, bring a warm coat, and be prepared to stand in the cold for an hour or two. The restaurant is very small and only seats 28 people. When we got there, the line (~50 people) was already extended two stores down from Mensho. I've never seen a line that long, but fortunately it moved more quickly than I expected. We were lucky that day and were seated after waiting for little more than an hour. I heard on some days, the wait time can be insane and can be 2+ hours. This gives you time to look over the menu and decide what you want to order ahead of time. When it was my turn to be seated, I walked inside, hung my coat up by the door, and made my way to the table. Seating is "communal style" so you'll most likely sit next to a stranger. The tables are high up and there are baskets underneath so you can temporarily store your personal belongings there. I also noticed they play fast paced music, such as EDM, but it didn't really suit the environment. It was odd, but after listening to the some Dillon Francis, I was even more excited to eat my ramen.

My two friends ordered the Shoyu ramen and I ordered the Shio ramen. The food arrived fairly quickly and all came out at the same time. 
SHIO RAMEN: It came with bamboo shoots, chashu, noodles, and kale. The kale was definitely an interesting addition to a bowl of ramen but none of the less, a great one because I like kale. The clear broth was delicious, which was perfect for me since I like it light. After one sip of the broth, I knew that it'd satisfy my ramen cravings. The flavors in the broth were distinct and I instantly knew that waiting in the cold was worth it since the broth was one of the best I've ever had. The noodles were interesting and different since it was kind of flat and thin. One thing that was a bit disappointing was the chashu. The chashu was barely warm and didn't complement the ramen since it wasn't the same temperature. It would have been better if the meat was heated up more and if it had more flavor. I also wish my bowl of ramen came with more broth because my bowl looked like it had less than my friends. I slurped all the noodles, devoured the bamboo shoots and chasu, and gulped all the broth. At the end, I was left staring at an empty white bowl hoping that more ramen would magically appear. 
All in all, Mensho Tokyo is worth lining up in for. I usually avoid restaurants that have long wait times since I tend to grow quite impatient, but I'm willing wait here again. Hit up some friends (to make time past by faster), bring some small snacks (so you don't starve while waiting), and stand in this crazy line for a bowl of delicious ramen. And yes, the hype is real!!

excerpts: Between the three of us, we got the clam butter ramen ($18), tori paitan ramen ($16), and the shio chashyu ($13).
Tori Paitan -
The pork was delicious, and the broth was slightly sweeter than I anticipated.
Shio Chashyu - This broth was fantastic.
It was thick, and rich, and everything I look for in ....
but it was so delicious.
shio.author: Gina L.
shio.review:
Most people complain about the wait time, but if you're not waiting before it opens, you're not dedicated enough!!!!! There's enough seating for about 30 people +/- a few (4) depending on how the party sizes work out and if you can extend to the ends of the table.

Between the three of us, we got the clam butter ramen ($18), tori paitan ramen ($16), and the shio chashyu ($13).

HOLY MOLY I had an out of body experience like I watching myself eat the ramen because simply eating it wouldn't do it justice.

Clam Butter - This was my favorite - the broth, the ramen, the swirl of pork, the clam, the butter 5/5 absolutely delicious. The only serve 10 of these a day, so be sure to get there early! We joked that we would just order 10 for the 3 of us in the future because that's how good it was.

Tori Paitan - The pork was delicious, and the broth was slightly sweeter than I anticipated. However, all good stuff!

Shio Chashyu - This broth was fantastic. It was thick, and rich, and everything I look for in .... but it was so delicious. It was like drinking liquid gold, and my mouth is watering just writing about it.

Bring your own container if you want to bring back leftovers!

excerpts: I also ordered the organic shoyu ramen and shio ramen.
The noodles were tasty and both was very light without feeling too greasy or filling.
I really liked the way everything tastes.
shio.author: Jenny K.
shio.review:
The kids wanted noodles and I found this place with decent reviews on Yelp. I was lucky to get here right after they opened but wow there was already a long line and a crowd of people outside the store! While waiting in line I checked the menu and saw they were a Michelin guide restaurant. 

After waiting probably a good 30-40 mins we finally got our seats. The menu is quite simple, mainly ramen dishes that either comes regular or with extra chasu. Some are with broth and some without. For appetizers there were only 2 to choose from. I decided to order the enoki chips to start. I really wasn't sure what to expect and was hoping it wasn't something I had to end up finishing on my own. When it came out it smelled wonderful and believe it or not it was SOOOO good!! One way to know something weird is good is having young kids try them. My 11 year old and 5 year old both loved it just as much.

I also ordered the organic shoyu ramen and shio ramen. The noodles were tasty and both was very light without feeling too greasy or filling. I really liked the way everything tastes. The soft boiled eggs were perfectly cooked which was an add on.

Overall everything was great here and the staff were very attentive and accommodating with kids. I will definitely will come back again next time I'm in town!

excerpts: I read from some reviews that they do have lighter broth like shio.
My other friend also suggested the vegan ramen and said it's the best thing he's ever had.
Probably next time, if I made my way to that area before 5pm.
shio.author: Connie C.
shio.review:
Woah... that's some thick and flavorful broth served at Mensho. I made it to the restaurant at 5:07, just missed the first round of seating, waited about 40 minutes to get seated as I was just party of 1, shouldn't be as bad even if you're with party of 2. I'm not sure if it's so good that I would wait an hour+ for this. half an hour is ok, 

If you're not comfortable with sharing tables with strangers where your elbows might touch, this place isn't really for you. If you're extremely claustrophobic, I think you should be looking for a plan B dinner spot. 

I kept on seeing people raving about Tori Paitan, so gave that a go, add on ajitama and make it double chashu. Boom, here comes my $20 bowl of ramen. Ok, my $20 bowl was extremely filling, lots of flavors going on: my egg was marinated in miso, my soup was mainly chicken, I have pork chashu and duck chashu, got some fried burdock root with some earthy taste. So much stuff going on, I can't even put it in words. Duck chashu was amazing, it was so tender. Pork chashu was just alright, I've had better ones at Ramen Shop, it was a bit tough here compared to Ramen Shop's. Their noodles are pretty chewy, fun to chew but not fun to slurp. I made a huge mess on myself so had to eat more ladylike. That soup though, it wasn't drying out my mouth but it was just so flavorful, I couldn't stop. By the time I should stop, I felt sick, guess my stomach wasn't used to the thick broth. 

I read from some reviews that they do have lighter broth like shio. My other friend also suggested the vegan ramen and said it's the best thing he's ever had. Probably next time, if I made my way to that area before 5pm.

excerpts: I tried my friend's shio broth and it was fantastic.
My other friend's vegan broth wasn't bad either!
shio.author: Emma W.
shio.review:
This was my first time back since they first opened and the lineup was unfortunately just as long! My friends and I got there at 6pm on a Wednesday and waited for 45 minutes for 3 people. 

I got the tori paitan ramen for $16 and it was as creamy and delicious as expected. What I love most about their ramen is their noodles though. They're thicker than typical ramen noodles and just have the best consistency. I'm dreaming about them as I write this review! 

I tried my friend's shio broth and it was fantastic. My other friend's vegan broth wasn't bad either!

excerpts:
Fine, but doesn't live up to the hype/price

Shio Chashu (3/5)
- Broth was flavorful without being
shio.author: Nathan M.
shio.review:
TLDR: Fine, but doesn't live up to the hype/price

Shio Chashu (3/5)
- Broth was flavorful without being too salty
- Noodles were a little thin and soft for my taste

Tori Paitan (3/5)
- I substituted the meat with 2 soft-boiled eggs; the soy egg was better than the miso
- Broth was extremely rich and creamy almost to a fault
- Very sweet undertones and not as salty as i expect Ramen to usually be
- Noodles were bomb, definitely the star of the dish; they seemed homemade and each of our ramen came with a different noodle
- It came with a good amount of veggies; tasty mushrooms and kale

Ambiance/Service (4/5)
- Expect a long wait during dinner time (30min to 90min)
- Seating is limited and only at communal tables
- Service was friendly and quick

excerpts: If I were to come back again, I would probably look to try the shio ramen.
shio.author: Megan C.
shio.review:
This is a pretty small place and I think it holds about 25 people at a time. Line started forming around 4:15pm and I would say there was about 40 people in line when it opened at 5pm. I got the tori paitan ramen because everyone seemed to like it on yelp and I prefer more creamy tonkatsu broths. I really liked the noodles and the flavor was good, but I think the broth was too thick. The consistency was much like melted ice cream and I don't know how I feel about that. 

If I were to come back again, I would probably look to try the shio ramen.

excerpts: In addition to the tori paitan broth, Mensho also offers organic shoyu, shio, and a vegan tantanmen.
The shoyu and shio broths are lighter and not as creamy, which might be good for those looking for something not as heavy.
(But why come all the way out here, wait in an excruciatingly long line, and not get the best?)
shio.author: Jean S.
shio.review:
Wow! Best Ramen I've had! Mensho's Tori Paitan Ramen (double chashu) ($18) was super amazing and full of delicious umami flavor! The broth was very rich and creamy, but the flavors were SO tasty, I could not stop drinking. The noodles were cooked to a perfect texture, the bamboo shoots and kale were a nice touch, but what was the crown on top was the EXTREMELY TENDER and flavorful chashu. Both the pork chashu and duck chashu were out-of-this-world amazing! Definitely the best I've had in any ramen bowl. I only wish there were more pieces.  

In addition to the tori paitan broth, Mensho also offers organic shoyu, shio, and a vegan tantanmen. The shoyu and shio broths are lighter and not as creamy, which might be good for those looking for something not as heavy. (But why come all the way out here, wait in an excruciatingly long line, and not get the best?) I also tried the oysters in shoyu dare oil ($5), which were not bad. The menu states 4 pieces...they gave us 6, but they were very small and not plated very nicely. 

Mensho Tokyo is one of Japan's most acclaimed ramen bars, and this very location in SF's Tenderloin district, is their first international shop outside of Japan. This location has been open for over a year now, but the long wait is still there. I came late Saturday evening (10:15pm) trying to avoid the long line, but it wasn't late enough. I still had to wait 45 minutes (only!?) and didn't get seated till just after 11:00pm. (They close at 11:30pm and there were people being seated all the way to the end.) I hate long waits, but the tori paitan ramen was well worth the travel out and 45 minute wait. On a positive side note, the restaurant was clean, the bathroom was clean, and their food safety score is 100.

excerpts: Will try shio ramen next time.
The oyster tasted like too much.
shio.author: Xiaoshi Y.
shio.review: Not as good as expected. Maybe Chicken Paitan is not for me. Will try shio ramen next time. The oyster tasted like too much.

excerpts: We got seated and decided to order four different ramens: Maccha Tori Paitan, Spicy Lamb, Shio, and Clam Butter Chashu Ramen.
We placed our order with our waitress and as she was about to walk away
I asked if they have Pepsi or Coke for my boyfriend.
Instead of being polite and professional, she gave my boyfriend
and I a snooty response, "UH NO".
Okay?!?!?!
Wouldn't be more professional to say something like,
"I apologize but our restaurant does not carry sodas"???
But how dare you respond to us in that tone, those words, and in such a disapproved expression?
Who are you to disapprove what he likes to drink?
If you don't have it, it's fine but don't disrespect us like that!
My boyfriend got the Shio and yes it came in a broth
but it was way too salty and again lack flavor!
Where are the chicken and pork flavors in this broth?
Was this just salt water with soy sauce for coloring???
And then guess what happened?
The same snooty waitress came by with a pitcher of water and asked to refill our waters.
She was pleasant when she filled my glass
but when she got to my boyfriend, she didn't say anything and just reach between my boyfriend's face and his ramen with her pitcher and dripped water into the ramen.
How rude can you be?
Didn't even acknowledged what she did and just went off.
I mean the water helped a little in diluting the broth but really?!?!
Anyway, my cousin got the Matcha and it was matcha flavored!
YAY!
But that was it!
The taste of Matcha powder sprinkled on the ramen!
My bestie got the Clam Butter Chashu ramen.
We all tasted the broth and we all agreed that the broth tasted the best out of ours.
It has a scoop of butter, we assumed, on top of the ramen but turns out my bestie said it tasted like sour cream.
She didn't think that will mix well with her ramen so she decided to remove it.
She did the right thing or her ramen will be ruined.
shio.author: kaY C.
shio.review:
My cousin recommended this place, said this place was better than many famous ramen restaurants. I was hyped about it as I loveeeeee ramen! I was warned to arrive early as this place always have a line out the door. But since my friend and my schedule didn't permit us to get there early, we got there around 5:30pm. Looking at the line, I thought to myself that this place must be good if all these people are willing to stand around in this neighborhood. As we got to the front of the line, we looked through the menu and saw a selection of different flavored ramen. Everything on the menu sounded interesting so we decided to each get a different flavor ramen to share. We also noticed a tip disclaimer by their menu posted outside that there is a 15% mandatory service fee added to each bill. 

We got seated and decided to order four different ramens: Maccha Tori Paitan, Spicy Lamb, Shio, and Clam Butter Chashu Ramen. We placed our order with our waitress and as she was about to walk away I asked if they have Pepsi or Coke for my boyfriend. Instead of being polite and professional, she gave my boyfriend and I a snooty response, "UH NO". Okay?!?!?! Wouldn't be more professional to say something like, "I apologize but our restaurant does not carry sodas"??? But how dare you respond to us in that tone, those words, and in such a disapproved expression? Who are you to disapprove what he likes to drink? If you don't have it, it's fine but don't disrespect us like that! Is this what your mandatory service fee includes, being rude???

Ramen arrived! Each bowl was presented beautifully! We were excited to dig in! We each took a spoonful of broth to try. I had the Spicy Lamb, OMG the broth is not broth, it's gravy! It's thicker than gravy and I cannot taste miso. Isn't this supposed to be MISO? The chashu was not bad, it was tender but lacks flavor. I do like the little kick in spiciness but I wish it was spicier. Overall, I would not recommend this ramen as I like broth type ramen with flavors! My boyfriend got the Shio and yes it came in a broth but it was way too salty and again lack flavor! Where are the chicken and pork flavors in this broth? Was this just salt water with soy sauce for coloring??? And then guess what happened? The same snooty waitress came by with a pitcher of water and asked to refill our waters. She was pleasant when she filled my glass but when she got to my boyfriend, she didn't say anything and just reach between my boyfriend's face and his ramen with her pitcher and dripped water into the ramen. How rude can you be? Didn't even acknowledged what she did and just went off. I mean the water helped a little in diluting the broth but really?!?! Anyway, my cousin got the Matcha and it was matcha flavored! YAY! But that was it! The taste of Matcha powder sprinkled on the ramen! My bestie got the Clam Butter Chashu ramen. We all tasted the broth and we all agreed that the broth tasted the best out of ours.  It has a scoop of butter, we assumed, on top of the ramen but turns out my bestie said it tasted like sour cream. She didn't think that will mix well with her ramen so she decided to remove it. She did the right thing or her ramen will be ruined. At lease she got the best one out of all the ones we ordered. 

Overall, I was not impressed this place and definitely not going there ever again. Every one has different preference in food so I'm not going to say don't try it as I'm sure this type of ramens suit other people's taste.

excerpts: The shio ramen is pretty good too.
shio.author: EJ A.
shio.review: Finally got around to trying Mensho now that the hype has kind of died down, and was not disappointed! Their signature dish is the tori Paitan with duck and pork chashu and is a must try for any ramen fan (just remember to order an egg separately). Got there around 6p on a Friday and the wait was about 30 min, not bad for SF. The shio ramen is pretty good too.

excerpts: If I come back, I'll probably do that, or try the shio.
Bottom line: if you've never had super rich ramen broth this is something to try, but shio may be a better option than the Tori Paitan.
shio.author: Kathy O.
shio.review:
We walked to this place after a thrilling escape room experience.  This place opens at 5pm and we got in line around 5:20pm. Parking, like most of SF, seemed about impossible so try to utilize a ride share company or public transit to get here. 

The restaurant is tiny and tables are kind of communal, so you'll be sitting at a table with other customers. We were lucky and sat next to a nice repeat customer. After our 30-45 min wait in line, we wanted to try the store's specialty, the Tori Paitan. 

The Tori Paitan was super rich, but I actually want to say it was too rich. This reminded me of Tsujita's tsukemen in LA, but as a broth rather than a tsukemen dipping sauce. It was rich, and almost greasy like a pasta sauce. Weird description, but I am not sure how else to describe it. The thing is, part way through, I started to have trouble finishing it. The noodles were a great texture, and the meat toppings were amazingly tender, but the soup really needed something to lighten it.

By the end, the soup itself also started to taste and feel gritty. I thought I was imagining it, but my friend agreed with me. Tsujita in LA provides a lime wedge with their tsukemen and it makes all the difference. The nice repeat customer sitting at our table suggested trying the soy sauce flavor ramen, as it is a less rich broth. If I come back, I'll probably do that, or try the shio.

Bottom line: if you've never had super rich ramen broth this is something to try, but shio may be a better option than the Tori Paitan. If the Tori Paitan was a tsukemen or had some acidity we could add to the broth, I'd give it 5 stars.

excerpts: My friend got the shio ramen and didn't feel it was any more special than other ramen places around.
We won't be making our way back considering the price, and the not so great area that it located in as well.
shio.author: Diana N.
shio.review:
I personally think this place is overrated. I guess the idea of this place is to be much like ramen shops in Japan. The plus was no tipping (which is offensive to do so in Japan), especially when it's is one of the more expensive ramen places in SF. 
I got the tori paitan ramen because it was the closest thing to my traditional creamy ramen I would always get in Tokyo. The broth was good, but a tad too salty for what I am used to. If you want your egg it is an up charge. The noodle was what ruined the experience. All the ramen place I had in Japan had this soft yet bouncy texture to their noodles which were all made from scratch. Here I got this thick and undercooked doughy noodle, nothing that reminded me of Japan. 
My friend got the shio ramen and didn't feel it was any more special than other ramen places around.
We won't be making our way back considering the price, and the not so great area that it located in as well.

excerpts: I've tried three of the ramens: tori paitan, shoyu, and shio.
If you like creamy go for the tori paitan if not the shoyu or shio will better suit you.
If you like creamy go for the tori paitan if not the shoyu or shio will better suit you.
I preferred the shoyu over the shio just based on the soup and would come back for the shoyu or the clam ramen
shio.author: Jenny E.
shio.review:
I really wanted to like this place but I just don't prefer it to others but keep in mind I don't have a very refined ramen palate. 

I've tried three of the ramens: tori paitan, shoyu, and shio. If you like creamy go for the tori paitan if not the shoyu or shio will better suit you. I preferred the shoyu over the shio just based on the soup and would come back for the shoyu or the clam ramen but that's never available when I get here anyways. 

The reason I don't like this place..... honestly there's a certain and smell and flavor to the ramen I just didn't like it kinda just reminded me of an Asian market but in my mouth... this could be just me but my boyfriend felt the same way. Just my two cents, still a nice place for ramen but definitely many worthy competitors out there!

excerpts: so if you like a lighter broth I would recommend the shio ramen.
Shio
Ramen-
the shio ramen was also really really really good!
shio.author: Mai Y.
shio.review:
This is my new favorite ramen restaurant in the bay area. I've heard the wait can be ridiculous so I came at night at 10 p.m. on a Saturday and waited only 10-15 minutes. It was also raining so there weren't very many people in line ahead of us.  

Tori Paitan- mmmm the broth is very rich and creamy and oh so delicious. It's very flavorful and fatty in all the good ways. It's a bit thick though so if you like a lighter broth I would recommend the shio ramen. The noodles were also cooked perfectly. 

Shio Ramen- the shio ramen was also really really really good! It's lighter but still super flavorful and yummy. 

By far the best ramen in the bay! I think it beats Ramen Dojo and Orenchi.

excerpts: This soup was definitely on the more oily side, if we were to compare the shio ramen.
It was so delicious
shio.author: Jana L.
shio.review:
This restaurant is DELICIOUS.  I can honestly say that this is probably the best ramen I've ever had (but I'm not as well-versed in the ramen scene as other Yelpers).  

My cousins and I were so lucky to get in line at around 4:30 pm on a Saturday!  There were only a couple of parties ahead of us, so we got seated during the "first round" - GO us!  The menu is pretty simple, with a couple of ramen choices and options if you want double chashu.  I got the Tori Paitan (I think that's he right spelling!), and the broth was so savory.  This soup was definitely on the more oily side, if we were to compare the shio ramen.  It was so delicious that I wouldn't even second guess my choice for getting it.

Our ramen was complimented with some quality green tea that the waitresses were so quick to refill.  I think this place would be nice for a date, but maybe not a first date.  The turn-around time is quick, since a majority of the time, there's a line outside.  But be warned, this restaurant is TINY!  There are like 3 total tables, two of which are large enough to fit maybe 8-10 people.  So, if you come with a party of two, you'd probably be seated next to random strangers (also an opportunity to make friends)! 

Overall, really great restaurant.  If this is what Japan's ramen tastes like, I'm going to book a flight to visit Japan next week!!!!  Definitely will return again, when the chance presents itself! :)

excerpts: I ordered the shio ramen.
I was really excited to taste the broth since it wasn't "creamy" like the other ramen on the menu
I found myself just eating the noodles and garnishes while trying my best to avoid the shio broth.
shio.author: Michael L.
shio.review:
My friend and I went here because we were told the ramen was amazing. On a Sunday evening the line outside the place was long since the establishment was relatively small.

After an hour of waiting, we finally got seated. I ordered the shio ramen. I was really excited to taste the broth since it wasn't "creamy" like the other ramen on the menu and so I was imagining it to be light and flavorful. 

With the first sip, my lips puckered, my toes curled and my kidneys screamed for water. The broth was soooo salty. Like painfully salty which was really unfortunate because ramen broth is always so tasty. I found myself just eating the noodles and garnishes while trying my best to avoid the shio broth. 

Service was also just okay. I downed my water so early on in dinner and no one ever came back to refill it. Luckily I had a hydro flask with me otherwise I would not have been okay. 

The interior of the restaurant was really nice and the quality of the ingredients was good it was just questionably salty.

excerpts: So when we saw that they have our favs (mine, shio; his shoyu), we had to come and try.
I got the shio with the duck chashu add on, and J got the shoyu (which includes the duck chashu).
The broth was just the way we like it, light but packed with umami (J finished his entire bowl of broth, which has only happened two other times at the Eat Feastly Noodle
In A Haystack ramen popup and at an award-winning ramen shop in Tokyo).
Duck chashu was tender and flavorful.
Also loved the kale in there, adds a very Californian touch.
Also, if you think miso, tonkatsu or paitan broths are too heavy, try this place's lighter shio or shoyu broths!
It might change what you think about ramen.
shio.author: Manki W.
shio.review:
My partner and I are both huge fans of lighter, dashi-based ramen broths. So when we saw that they have our favs (mine, shio; his shoyu), we had to come and try. 

We got in line on Saturday at 4:20 for the 5:00 open time. Already, there were 5 groups ahead of us (maybe 12-14 people total?). By 4:45, there were already more than enough people for the first seating. So protip: come here before 4:30 if you want to be part of the group that gets seated in the first round. 

We shared the fried enoki mushroom appetizer (it was ok). I got the shio with the duck chashu add on, and J got the shoyu (which includes the duck chashu). The broth was just the way we like it, light but packed with umami (J finished his entire bowl of broth, which has only happened two other times at the Eat Feastly Noodle In A Haystack ramen popup and at an award-winning ramen shop in Tokyo). Duck chashu was tender and flavorful. Also loved the kale in there, adds a very Californian touch. The only thing that would've made us even more happy was if the noodles were thicker and chewier. 

The paitan and butter clam options that our neighbors ordered looked interesting, but too heavy for my taste. 

Overall, we thought it was worth the wait, and we would come back to get our ramen fix when we can't afford the pricier Eat Feastly events. Also, if you think miso, tonkatsu or paitan broths are too heavy, try this place's lighter shio or shoyu broths! It might change what you think about ramen. :)

Last thing, be prepared to get comfortable sitting and slurping up noodles next to strangers (J mentioned feeling a little anxious when we got our ramen first and our neighbors were looking at our food and foodgasm faces, lol). All the seats are at communal tables, so might not be the best option for an intimate meal.

excerpts: and then I ordered the Shio Ramen with egg because I looove garlic.
shio.author: Leslie T.
shio.review:
Heard a lot about this place before visiting and waited 2 hours to get in (as many people have mentioned, very small space and limited seating). I was pretty hangry by the time we got seated (table of 5) so we ordered the oyster appetizer. 3 oysters for $5 and they were pretty overly salted and oily (very strong shoyu taste). I could feel my blood pressure go up.

4 out of 5 of us ordered the Tori Paitan with double Chashu (boys gotta eat!) and then I ordered the Shio Ramen with egg because I looove garlic. I waited an extra 10-15 minutes for my ramen while everyone else at my table got their Tori Paitan a little while after ordering and even had to ask the waitress to check on my food (politely of course). I was incredibly surprised when my ramen came and it was really watery broth~ I should've checked Yelp pictures before ordering because I definitely wanted a creamier thick broth... so let's just say you definitely get what you pay for. I ended up eating 1/4 of my boyfriend's Tori Paitan and mixing it with my garlic ramen (which tasted really good!) I think Mensho should expand and add more garlic into their creamy rich chicken broth - which by the way, is kind of unique because ramen usually has pork broth. One of my friends complained that the broth was too creamy and oily.. but he's going through a health phase. If you want to be that healthy, just stay in and eat food that you cook yourself ;) The ingredients were fresh and delicious but the prices are really unnecessarily steep. Maybe this is just San Francisco and the way it is but after tax/tip you're definitely paying $20+ if you order their staple ramen dish which is a lot more than other places like Ramen Parlor in San Mateo.

excerpts: Can't wait to try the Shio flavored broth!
shio.author: Jennifer W.
shio.review:
Mensho is incredibly good and NOT over-hyped! It is worth the wait. The wait is actually not bad at all if you show up, say, before 4:45. Then you're probably only waiting 15 minutes tops. They open at 5PM and you'd get in on the first seating. I got there a little after 4:50 and waited only(!) 45 minutes. I noticed that people tend to be eating pretty fast and leaving. Probably because the bright lights in there and tight spaces are not conducive to loitering around. The service is fast and friendly. They're efficient. 

The ramen is the best I've ever had. I tried the $16 Tori Paitan. Very creamy and rich broth. I also tried some of the Shoyu broth; the best Shoyu broth I've ever had. 

Definitely worth the wait, and I'd go back. Can't wait to try the Shio flavored broth!

excerpts: They also have small appetizers and other types of ramen including: no broth ramen, shio and shoyu and a vegan ramen!
shio.author: Samantha F.
shio.review:
Came here on a Thurs night around 530pm and there was a line forming already. Thank god, my friend got there earlier than me around 5ish and got a seat 5mins later. 

RAMEN:
We ordered: 
1) Tori Paitan (single chasu) $16: super creamy chicken and pork broth and really thick and chewy noodles with a pinch of cabbage and 2 duck chasus, No egg :( The broth was perfectly flavored and a little on the creamier side but not too oily or salty. 
2) Spicy Lamb $16: This was SO SALTY. It tasted like they dunk 10 packs of spicy msg ramen packs in the broth. There were bits of ground lamb and bean sprouts mixed in. I felt like the overly saltiness of the broth toke away the enjoyment of the ramen overall. 

Others:
They also have small appetizers and other types of ramen including: no broth ramen, shio and shoyu and a vegan ramen! No Tonkatsu (although I think Tori Paitan is closest to it but a bit more heavy). They advertise for Tsukemen (dipping) Ramen on their walls, but don't actually have it on their menu which is a little misleading. And for $16/bowl with no boiled egg was a little disappointing.

AMBIANCE:
Super small and packed interior. There are basically 3 long tables so be prepared to sit side-by-side with strangers. Cute decor though! 

SERVICE: 
Very fast and attentive! 

VERDICT:
For flavors and thick chewy noodles I give them a 5! However, for the lack of meat, boiled egg and overly salty lamb broth it drops to a 3. I can get the same ramen quality in Little Tokyo with more meat for less. Would I wait in line if it would have been longer? No.

excerpts: They have vegan ramen as well as shio, tonkotsu and organic soy.
shio.author: Yuko H.
shio.review:
One of the best ramen I had in North America. I haven't tried every places but since I really like ramen, I try as often as possible when traveling.

Tori Paitan ramen I had was so rich and creamy yet it wasn't overwhelming. Sometimes chicken base broth could be overwhelming but this felt light while maintaining rich and creamy texture.

I got lucky when I came. Arrived here on Thursday at 5:50pm, I only saw five people waiting outside. Since they were all together, she took me in before then. I was seated with almost no wait at all!  When I left after a nice bowl of ramen, I saw a very long queue (looked like about an hour wait). Must have came in such a perfect timing!

Service was good, just what you expect from any ramen shop in Japan. Fast and efficient.

Noodles were also prepared to perfection. Went well with tori Paitan broth.

They have vegan ramen as well as shio, tonkotsu and organic soy. I was really tempted to come back the next day as I enjoyed it so much. 

Next day I told several of my local contacts and they all knew about this place but unable to try yet due to long wait.  I was so glad I got to try here during my short visit to SF!

excerpts: We all ordered the same ramen: Shio Ramen!
Note: the Shio ramen has the flat noodles.
shio.author: Joey R.
shio.review:
From the reviews, the recommendation was to go as early as possible! So, we were there by 430PM and were one of the first in line. NOICE!

Mensho Tokyo is a tiny place with a cozy feel. Once the door opens, they sit you and your group in a very organized system. All of the dining tables are communal and you'll often find yourself next to a new face or two. When you are seated, know what you want because they will take your order right away! We all ordered the same ramen: Shio Ramen! Note: the Shio ramen has the flat noodles. If you want the round noodles, go for the Tori Paitan!

The broth was clear but had depth and was very flavorful. The noodles were cooked really well and had a nice chewy texture. We didn't speak much throughout the entire meal. The people sitting to my right had the Tori Paitan, Maze Soba (which looked amazing) and also had the Oyster dish. All the dishes looked gorgeous and were served within minutes after taking our orders. If you want very good ramen in San Francisco, you should give this place a try! :D

excerpts: We had 2 bottles of sake (among a group of 6) and 3 shio and 3 tori paitan all with extra chashu.
I wished we had ordered a shoyu ramen to try but maybe next time.
The broth of the tori paitan was rich and heavy but not too heavy.
It was delicious and I definitely would recommend this.
The noodles were cooked perfectly.
The shio ramen's broth was good
but I preferred the noodles used in the tori paitan ramen.
The shio noodles reminded me too much of korean kalguksu noodles rather than ramen noodles.
shio.author: Linda H.
shio.review:
We had ramen a few streets down on our first day in SF and was totally disappointed but this place is definitely worth the wait!

We were in line before they opened. They open at 5pm. We stood in line around 4:45pm and was seated around 6pm. There was a gentleman who came out and calculated the number of people in each party so he knew how to seat everyone. This made everything move faster. People who had a party of 2 were seated prior to us but since we had 6 our wait was a bit longer (but not too long). He even took our order before we were seated so the wait once we sat was not that long. 

We had 2 bottles of sake (among a group of 6) and 3 shio and 3 tori paitan all with extra chashu. I wished we had ordered a shoyu ramen to try but maybe next time. The broth of the tori paitan was rich and heavy but not too heavy. It was delicious and I definitely would recommend this. The noodles were cooked perfectly. The shio ramen's broth was good but I preferred the noodles used in the tori paitan ramen. The shio noodles reminded me too much of korean kalguksu noodles rather than ramen noodles. 

Other than that everything was great. Including the service.

excerpts: We got the ume shio chasu and double chasu and boy, was it salty.
I liked the texture of the noodles but just couldn't get past how salty the broth was.
When I got to the bottom of the bowl, it got even saltier and was so relieved I was done with it.
My friend said he liked the pork
I'll just have to come with lower standards and surely won't be going near the ume shio again.
shio.author: Ying Z.
shio.review:
In short: Food didn't live up to the hype. Highlights go to the speedy service, noodle texture, and unique interior. 

I was so excited to finally try this place because I heard it was popular. There is always a long line outside the place well before they open for dinner. We went on a Friday night and got in line around 5:15 and got seated an hour after, which I consider it to be a decent wait time. Seats are tight because it's basically family style on the four long tables inside. They have baskets on the ground for you to put your bags but since the seats are high, you'll have to get out of your stool to reach for your purse. The food came out fast and this is where the disappointment sets in. We got the ume shio chasu and double chasu and boy, was it salty. I liked the texture of the noodles but just couldn't get past how salty the broth was. When I got to the bottom of the bowl, it got even saltier and was so relieved I was done with it. My friend said he liked the pork but I didn't have any comment on that. 

This was such a letdown. I guess my expectations were too high having had ramen in Japan and orenchi in Santa Clara. But I would give it another chance and come to try something else on the menu. I'll just have to come with lower standards and surely won't be going near the ume shio again.

excerpts: Shio Ramen: Clear Chicken and Pork Soup, Shio Dare, Pork Chashu, Kale, Menma, Fried Garlic, Chives, Nori ($9)
My Shio ramen was okay.
A light flavorful broth.
But the noodles were the flat kind
shio.author: Elena N.
shio.review:
I've been wanting to try Mensho for some time, but the line always deterred me. Finally, on Thursday, July 28th, my group of three decided to brave the line around 10:30pm. It honestly didn't take too long. I think about 20 mins.

*Tori Paitan Ramen: Rich and Creamy Chicken Soup, Pork Chashu, Duck Chashu, Menma, Kale, Burdock, Katsuobushi Sauce ($18 double chashu)
*Organic Shoyu Ramen: Clear Organic Chicken and Pork Soup, Shoyu Dare, Pork Chashu, Duck Chashu, Kale, Kale Sprouts,Chives, Menma, Nori ($16 double chashu)
*Shio Ramen: Clear Chicken and Pork Soup, Shio Dare, Pork Chashu, Kale, Menma, Fried Garlic, Chives, Nori ($9)

My favorite, hands down, was the Tori Paitan. The noodles were the right consistency and the broth was rich and flavorful. I wasn't the one who ended up with this bowl, but I was wishing I had ordered it. My Shio ramen was okay. A light flavorful broth. But the noodles were the flat kind and I preferred the thicker noodles from the Tori Paitan better. They had a much better chew. I only tried a spoonful of the broth from the Shoyu Ramen which was fine.

We all know I can't have a meal without alcohol! Two of us got the Sapporo Premium: 355ml/12.0oz ($4.75) and one of us tried the Ozenoyukidoke IPA 12.75: 330ml/11.5oz ($12.75). Pricey for a beer, but a better choice if you like IPAs. I, myself prefer the lighter beers, so the sapporo was perfect for me.

Glad I was finally able to check Mensho Tokyo off my list. Was it worth the 20 min wait? Yes, I would say so. But if I had to wait 1+ hours in the SF cold, I don't know. I'm just happy I'll never have to find out.

excerpts: I got the Shio Ramen while my partner in crime got the Tori Paitan.
I was pretty disappointed.

Shio Ramen
 - broth was ok.

Nothing incredible about it
 - noodles were interesting but not amazing

- Chashu was pretty good but so thin
 - green onions were pretty bitter

Tori Paitan
 - broth was incredibly creamy and frothy.
shio.author: Jae C.
shio.review:
I wanted to come here for awhile after reading and hearing about this place since day one. Finally gave in and waited for 50 minutes in line. I got the Shio Ramen while my partner in crime got the Tori Paitan. I was pretty disappointed. 
Shio Ramen
 - broth was ok. Nothing incredible about it
 - noodles were interesting but not amazing
 - Chashu was pretty good but so thin
 - green onions were pretty bitter

Tori Paitan
 - broth was incredibly creamy and frothy. 
 - noodles were better

Overall, the experience was okay at best. At the very least I'm glad I tried it and don't understand the hype over it. My gf went to Japan recently and tried so many different ramen spots and according to her, it was far from authentic, it was a complete letdown. For SF ramen it is ok. When comparing this to the rest in the Bay Area, it doesn't even come close to Top 5. But compared to other Ramen in the LA or Japan it's like night and day.

excerpts: Ordered a shoyo and a shio.
A bit disappointed.
Ramen were good, but no where near "michillen guide" standard.
shio.author: David Z.
shio.review:
Ordered a shoyo and a shio. A bit disappointed. Ramen were good, but no where near "michillen guide" standard. Forget about Japan, any decent ramen joint in Vancouver, Toronto, or NYC is just going to be so much better. 

Hand pulled noodles were unique, but not sure it worked that well with the broth. And there's a mandatory 15% tip added to the bill when we barely got any service?

excerpts: I got the Ume Shio Ramen twice (was trying to get something else
but I really like Ume Shio, plus
you can't find this anywhere),
shio.author: Leslie C.
shio.review:
Mensho is by far my favorite ramen spot in San Francisco (my #1 used to be Orenchi in Santa Clara but I haven't been there for years). I've visited Mensho for 3 times and I had great dining experiences each time. The waiting time during weekdays is manageable, I waited 30 mins the most and got seated right after (around 7:30pm). Weekend is tricky, like other popular restaurants, at least an hour if you are lucky.

I got the Ume Shio Ramen twice (was trying to get something else but I really like Ume Shio, plus you can't find this anywhere), Tori Paitan Ramen once and they were both amazing. When a bowl ramen has the perfect cooked noodles and flavorful broth, it's hard not to come back for it. It's a bit pricy, but it's definitely worth it!

2017007

excerpts: I prefer the shio ramen more.
But the noodles were fantastic!
And the chasu meat was so good....very soft and flavorful.
Was not impressed with the options for the sides.
They did not have corn!!
So used to eating my ramen with corn..and no chili flakes either!
shio.author: Caitlin P.
shio.review:
This place truly does have good ramen. I had the tori paitan ramen. Soup was very rich in  flavors. It's kinda like a soy sauce based soup which is a bit too strong for me. I prefer the shio ramen more. But the noodles were fantastic! And the chasu meat was so good....very soft and flavorful. Was not impressed with the options for the sides. They did not have corn!! So used to eating my ramen with corn..and no chili flakes either! But I guess those ingredients would taken away the flavors of the broth. 

I also got the oysters in shoyu oil. It's 5 dollars for 4 pieces but they gave us 6 instead! Yes! We definitely came up with that so wooot! This was surpsingly very goood...it was oysters in soy sauce. Never had it that way before but it was amazing. Definitely worth the 5 bucks.

Update:
The vegan broth is so good. Think I'm gonna get vegan broth with a side of chasu next time I'm here. 

Come early if you  wanna eat here. Come an hour before it opens. We came at 4 last sat and to our surprise, some one was already in line when we got there. By the time it was 430, the line was  insanely long already !! Just do yourself a favor and come early. There's only enough seat for like 25 people there so wait can be long.

excerpts: Mensho Tokyo is a good place to have some Japanese flavor, I really love their noodles because the noodles are chewier and have a elasticity to them, the ramen at this place is just amazing starting from thr Maccha Tori Paitan, Spicy Lmb,Shio and Clam Butter.
Though the wait is long due to the busy nature and too many customers, the wait is worth it eventually since the services are amazing and food comes very fast compared to other restaurants around.
Every employee is super kind and very quick to respond.
Even with the large crowds, I was able to take as long as we needed to eat without ever feeling rushed.
