excerpts: There are three other ramen bowls on the menu - organic shoyu, shio, and vegan tantanmen, as well as a selection of mazesoba bowls.
shio.author: Ed U.
shio.review:
The advance hype on this place was off the charts, and the breathless texting and taxing anticipation from the hipsterati of self-proclaimed ramen connoisseurs has been quite deafening. A two-plus-hour wait for an $18 bowl of ramen sounds like a Louis C.K. joke about San Francisco millennials with no punchline. I got exhausted thinking about the hoops I'd have to jump through to get a taste of the broth here. However, now that at least six weeks have elapsed since the grand opening in February, I had an opening that I couldn't bypass, the Thursday before Good Friday when I got off work early.

Everyone says to be there at 4PM even though they don't open until an hour later, and so I did. If you don't count the screeching homeless woman who kept sauntering by, no one else showed up until around 4:35PM. That's not to say the staff was indifferent to my presence as they thanked me for coming and waiting patiently. Eventually a line did start to form and rather quickly. I got seated at the front counter promptly at 5PM where I had a nice view of the kitchen where activity was bustling behind he coffee beakers with the broth at full boil and the pork and duck chashu being meticulously sliced. I was sitting with a Filipino family who could barely contain their enthusiasm over the forthcoming noodlefest.

I was feeling the same way and knew what to order since I had well over an hour to decide. I started with their one and only appetizer, the $5 Oysters in Shoyu Dare Oil. There were four of them completely shelled and marinated (photo: http://bit.ly/1Vp0sEV). Tasty freshness gone too soon, but the main event was about to occur. It was the $18 Tori Paitan Ramen with Double Pork Chashu, and I had them add an extra couple of Duck Chashu slices for $1.50 extra because why not go to town? The noodles were perfectly al dente, and the chashu was meaty without being overwhelming. Slices of menma, kale and burdock floated on top with a katsuobushi (bonito) sauce spooned on top (photo: http://bit.ly/224L6pv).

However, for all the fresh ingredients, it was that rich paitan chicken broth that lingers not only on the palate but in my sense-memory. Just the natural creaminess of it was amazing, and what really makes this bowl of ramen stand out against the others. There are three other ramen bowls on the menu - organic shoyu, shio, and vegan tantanmen, as well as a selection of mazesoba bowls. I was timid and just had a $4.75 bottle of Sapporo Premium to wash it all down (photo: http://bit.ly/1RTN9dq), but they have pricier Japanese artisan beers which they strongly recommended to me for the next time. And there will be a next time even as I saw the line go down the block as I departed.

FOOD - 5 stars...best paitan ramen broth ever, period
AMBIANCE - 4.5 stars...clean, white and you only wish it was triple the size to make the line move faster
SERVICE - 5 stars...lovely people work here
TOTAL - 5 stars...not just for self-proclaimed ramen connoisseurs...be patient or come near closing

excerpts: We had the signature Torri and shio Ramen.
I added duck slices, ground lamb, bamboo shoots and hot spring egg.
The food almost overflowed out of the bowl  haha.
The soup was tasty and rich.
Pork and duck chasu tender and fresh.
shio.author: Andy Juzheng Z.
shio.review:
My friend and I were shopping at Union Square and craved for Japanese ramen. Went there at 7 and found a long line. When we were struggling to figure out whether to leave, the line only got longer.

Decided to stay on the line before we were seated one hour later. The ramen was definitely worth the wait. We had the signature Torri and shio Ramen. I added duck slices, ground lamb, bamboo shoots and hot spring egg. The food almost overflowed out of the bowl  haha. The soup was tasty and rich. Pork and duck chasu tender and fresh. I love the egg the most. 

Definitely a good choice for food in cold San Francisco evening!

excerpts: *SHIO RAMEN $11 - very clean, deep, clear.
The noodles were fettucine like.
shio.author: Earl G.
shio.review:
Not necessarily the best bowl of ramen I've ever had but the broth in their Tori Paitan (TP) ramen is INSANE. It's super thick, almost gravy like, yet still remains pretty light. I haven't had anything like it before. You can tell the broths quality with it's texture and deep flavor, definitely been cooking for HOURS.Add in some super tender chashu (both pork AND duck), menma, springy and squiggly noodles, kale, and some katsuoboshi (bonito shavings) and you got yourself their TP ramen. Hella flavor! 

Normally, it's $16 for a bowl but you only get one piece of meat so I'd recommend getting a double chashu for $18. Personally, I got the double and got an extra piece of chashu (since that's how I roll) and boom, baller bowl of ramen for $20. 

Perfect comfort food for those cold SF summer nights. I ain't spending hours making a ramen broth so it wasn't bad waiting an hour in line (Arrived on a Thursday @8:30pm, seated at 9:30pm). My tip - It's better to go later, wait times are shorter. 

Other bites. 
*SHIO RAMEN $11 - very clean, deep, clear. The noodles were fettucine like.
*OYSTERS IN SHOYU DARE OIL - 4 for $5. Like little chewy umami bombs. Reminded me of smoked oysters from the can. 

Can't wait to check out more flavors of ramen when they bring them over.

excerpts: So the four categories are: tori paitan (most ordered based on pictures and reviews), shoyu (what I ordered), shio, and vegan tantanmen.
shio.author: Catherine W.
shio.review:
The short: organic shoyu ramen hits the spot

If you're not one of the first in line, be prepared to wait about an hour. This place seats about 30 people max, with 2 very long tables, and some seats facing the kitchen. Also be prepared for sitting at a communal table. Some people don't like this...? I don't mind, as long as I have elbow room and have good food!

While in line, we checked out the menu and had a face palm moment when I realized that the description described the items below. Basically, the items below the header start with the basic bowl, and increase in price for additional items. So the four categories are: tori paitan (most ordered based on pictures and reviews), shoyu (what I ordered), shio, and vegan tantanmen.

When the shoyu ramen arrived, I quickly dug in because I was so hungry. The duck chasu and pork chasu was tender, perfectly cooked, and enhanced the broth (wishing there were doubles of each!). Even the kale was an unusual, but nice addition. The broth was perfect, not salty or oily. And the noodles were chewy! At first, it doesn't look like there's a lot of noodles, but the bowl is shaped quite deeply at the bottom, so all the noodles are hidden there. There was so much I liked about this ramen. 

I couldn't figure out what the seasonings on the table were, though there was pink himalayan salt, and maybe some other seasonings to personally enhance the broth to the right taste. I didn't need to as I liked it the way it was.

The waiter was very kind and smiling, which is something I don't see too often. All the seating is on stools, and there are baskets on the ground for bags. The whole inside has a clean and modern aesthetic, with a living wall at the entrance, descriptions of the different types of ramen, and a view into the kitchen. So exciting!

One downside is that this isn't a place to sit and chat after you've eaten the food. Somebody will kindly let you know that there are other patrons outside who are waiting.

It's hard to say if I would wait in line for another hour, but I would come back to arrive right around opening so I don't have to wait so long. Thanks for the experience Mensho!

excerpts: We ordered the Tori Paitan, Organic Shoyu and Shio.
Favorite of the three?
Tie between Tori Paitan and Shoyu.
They both have the DELICIOUS DUCK CHASHU but otherwise very different bowls of ramen.
Tori Paitan's rich creamy broth is hard to compare to the lightness of the shoyu.
Compared to other shoyu broths at other restaurants, Mensho's is definitely one of the better bowls.
Great noodles all around.
shio.author: Samantha L.
shio.review:
This line is only for the patient and determined. Got there 15 min before opening on a weekday and the wait was 80 minutes. Right in the "TenderNob", there were we a few beggars hassling the line but Mensho Tokyo was trying the best they could to ask them politely not bother the customers in line. I don't know if there's any way to really get around this with all the hype! 

Oysters: Tiny little oysters in shoyu dare oil. They were served cold and not quite appetizing. Dark brown in color from the oil ost likely, oddly very shriveled and almost chewy. Flavor was okay but not what i was hoping.

We ordered the Tori Paitan, Organic Shoyu and Shio. Favorite of the three? Tie between Tori Paitan and Shoyu. They both have the DELICIOUS DUCK CHASHU but otherwise very different bowls of ramen. Tori Paitan's rich creamy broth is hard to compare to the lightness of the shoyu. Compared to other shoyu broths at other restaurants, Mensho's is definitely one of the better bowls. Great noodles all around.

excerpts: You're probably better off with the lighter shoyu or shio ramen (both look delicious!).
shio.author: Tara A.
shio.review:
Authentic ramen from Japan? Count me in!!! 

My friends and I lined up at 4 pm and we were 2nd in line. By 4:30 pm, the line was growing. We only waited an hour compared to some of the crazy 3 hours that other people have waited. All 4 of us ordered the tori paitan ramen ($16), which was seemingly the most popular! We were all really excited especially just to be some of the first people in the restaurant. 

The tori paitan was incredibly flavorful, creamy, and THICK! Like others have said, the tori paitan broth has more of a sauce or gravy-like consistency rather than your normal thinner broth. If you don't like heavy meals... don't get the tori paitan. You're probably better off with the lighter shoyu or shio ramen (both look delicious!). The tori paitan broth got a bit too rich as I was finishing the bowl. However, I enjoyed it! I normally order tonkotsu at ramen places, so the chicken flavor was definitely something different to try out. 

The noodles are round and thicker than your average (think chow mein noodle size), but perfectly cooked and chewy. As for the toppings, the chasu was melt in your mouth delicious, but the duck was subpar for me. My friends and I also thought there should be a little more veggies just to lighten up the heavy bowl. I liked the bonito flakes, but the small amounts of kale and bamboo shoots did not cut it for us. But we did really like the toppings on the tables! The red salt was something we'd never seen before, and the other brown seasoning (smells like bonito flakes) was pretty tasty.

By the time we left at 6 pm, the line outside was crazy! If you don't like waiting, definitely don't come around that time. You're better off coming anywhere from 4-4:30 pm. The restaurant seats less than 30 people at one time, and it seems like there's a slow turnover rate. Mensho was good, but I probably wouldn't wait 2-3 hours for it.

excerpts: (3) Shio: Organic chicken + pork soup
, shio dare, pork chashu, kale, menma, chives, fried garlic, nori
The most affordable bowl available, the shio ramen was simple and pure.
The assari broth was light and salty but still had depth.
Same delicious chashu as the other bowls but the noodles were disappointing like the shoyu ramen.
In this bowl, not only were the noodles overcooked, there were two clumps.
shio.author: Cherylynn N.
shio.review:
4.5 STARS

San Franciscans love shiny new places (and things). 

When it comes to the hottest new restaurant and food trends, many of us spare no expense with our paycheck (and time).

Last year, it was $8 for toast. Ok, not just "toast" but phuckin' bougie, tweezified toast. 

This year, it's $15 coffee (for one cup!) and $18 ramen.

Because, San Francisco! 

Next year, I'm bracing myself for $100 pizza. Oh wait, we already had that during the super bowl (well, I didn't but it was available at Tony's Pizza Napoletana). 

Seriously, what's next? 

Kindly let me know so I can start harvesting my eggs to sell! 

$18 ramen may sound crazy but people waited 3+ hours for this ramen on opening night! 

$18 for a taste of Tokyo? Why not! 

Mensho's first U.S. location is one of the most, if not the most highly anticipated restaurant opening this year in SF! 

Tip: Come at 4 pm (earlier on the weekends) or after 10 pm to avoid long wait times. 

Currently, Mensho has 4 ramen options available ($9-$18) with a single or double chashu option. When the owner returns from Japan in March, their menu will expand. No housemade noodles yet. They have a noodle machine but are awaiting permit(s) to use it (same for the tonkotsu equipment). Disappointingly no marinated soft boiled egg is available but maybe in the future? Beer only; no sake, soda, or juice.

My friend and I ordered three bowls of ramen to share:

(1) Tori Paitan: Rich, creamy chicken soup, pork chashu, duck chashu, menma, kale, burdock, katsuobushi sauce | double chashu $18
http://bit.ly/1XrzETT

Our favorite of the three, the kotteri broth was deliciously creamy (gravy-like) and richly satisfying. It had great depth of umami flavor but did get a bit gritty mid-way. The al-dente noodles were thick, springy, and had a fantastic toothsome chew. 

The chashu is sublime so pony up the extra $ and double up on it! The pork chashu is melt-in-your-mouth tender, like pork butter. It's so ridiculously tender, it falls apart when you pick it up. The duck chashu is silky smooth and chews effortlessly.

The only other ramen shop that offers Tori Paitan is Nojo Ramen Tavern (that I'm aware of). I tried Nojo's last night and there's absolutely no comparison. Mensho's is infinitely superior. 

(2) Organic Shoyu: Organic chicken + pork soup, shoyu dare, pork chashu, duck chashu, kale, kale sprouts, chives, menma, nori | double chashu $16
http://bit.ly/1QfmuKm

A much lighter assari broth but saltier with a slight sweetness since it's a soy sauce based. The duo of chashu were perfection just like in the Tori Paitan ramen. I didn't like the noodles which were overcooked, flat, and lacked chew. 

(3) Shio: Organic chicken + pork soup, shio dare, pork chashu, kale, menma, chives, fried garlic, nori | double chashu $11
http://bit.ly/1Loeijq

The most affordable bowl available, the shio ramen was simple and pure. The assari broth was light and salty but still had depth. Same delicious chashu as the other bowls but the noodles were disappointing like the shoyu ramen. In this bowl, not only were the noodles overcooked, there were two clumps. *sad pouty lip*

(4) Vegan Tantanmen | $18
I'm kicking myself for NOT ordering this too because I love nuts! The broth contains soy cream and 7 kinds of nuts, producing a creamy kotteri broth that looked similar to the Tori Paitan.

I washed everything down with a Sansho beer ($11.75): http://bit.ly/1Px6vnx. Beer usually tastes like carbonated piss to me but this one was refreshing with a gingery lemon spice. Loved it but not the price. 

Service is a work in progress which is understandable since this is Mensho's first foray in the U.S.. They only let 8 or so customers in at a time to not overwhelm the kitchen. They don't fire up orders by tickets, instead they prepare the ramen by type (they really should do the former). We received our order at different times and after people who ordered after us. If your companion(s) orders different ramen than yourself, be prepared to start eating first before the noodles get soggy. 

When I was line I met one of the restaurant partners, Abram aka Ramen Beast. He was uber nice and offered to answer any questions I had. Really cool guy! 

The space is small and only seats 28 - two communal tables and four seats at the counter. We choose to sit at the counter. There's more privacy (if you're on a date) and you can watch the chefs in action.

Read all signs before parking. Do NOT park on Geary from 4-6 pm (tow-away zone) on the weekdays, otherwise your $18 bowl of ramen will turn into a $618+ bowl of ramen. 

Because, San Francisco!

excerpts: Since I had just burned through my wallet on drinks, I opted for the lower priced Shio Ramen w/ Chasiu ($9 something, ~$11 w/ tip and tax).
Food came out surprisingly fast.
I was kinda sad that there wasn't much in my bowl.
Everything was delicious
but I want a lot more for the price!
Everything definitely tasted top quality but when you only get one piece of meat, it kinda has you scratching your head.
Broth was great.
shio.author: Shanise M.
shio.review:
Our group had just finished up at Wilson & Wilson. After splurging on drinks there it was pretty difficult for me to dive right into some pricey ramen! But we were all ready for some drunchies.

We got here at 11 and asked for a seat for 4. Another customer came up behind us and said with a surprised tone, 'There's no line!?' I just told him that we're the line. I was confused too because I thought, why would there be? But now that I've actually seen the reviews and pictures... I now get it. Didn't realize this spot was THAT poppin' lol. I'm always wary about restaurants that have crazy lines - usually it doesn't meet the hype... not for me at least.

We were seated in no time. I love the communal tables! And I actually really like the small space haha, reminds me of a lot of shops I've been in throughout Asia.

Since I had just burned through my wallet on drinks, I opted for the lower priced Shio Ramen w/ Chasiu ($9 something, ~$11 w/ tip and tax). Food came out surprisingly fast. I was kinda sad that there wasn't much in my bowl. Everything was delicious but I want a lot more for the price! Everything definitely tasted top quality but when you only get one piece of meat, it kinda has you scratching your head. Broth was great. Looks like I should have gotten the Tori Paitan since everyone on here is raving about that one's broth.

I'll stick to my cheap, hefty ramen shops for now. I like quality and quantity - but, this was definitely a nice treat for one splurge-y night!

excerpts: The SHIO ($9 or $11 with DOUBLE Pork) tasted so clean
but I loved the chewy, al dente noodles.
The pork melted in my mouth and
I didn't even need to sink my teeth in the meat whatsoever.
shio.author: Veronica S.
shio.review:
SLURPILICIOUS !!!!!!!

Ramen - it's one of those comfort foods that anyone can appreciate!

Started getting hooked onto ramen a decade ago and my favorites include Santouka, Dojo, Santa, & Parlor. I've been following the Mensho opening for a few months and for the past few two months I've walked past it every week to monitor the progress of their construction/opening. Finally saw their plans to open up in February, but each time we thought about going, the lines were overwhelming so I made it a plan to come here on a weeknight 30 minutes before opening.

This is definitely one of the best ramens I've ever had - it's delicate but delicious and exploding in flavor. The SHIO ($9 or $11 with DOUBLE Pork) tasted so clean but I loved the chewy, al dente noodles. The pork melted in my mouth and I didn't even need to sink my teeth in the meat whatsoever. The Tori Paitan ($16 or $18 with DOUBLE Pork/Duck) is super frothy and tasty - the broth was super thick, almost  like a flavorful sauce. The DUCK was mind-blowingly good. I haven't had duck so tender in so long.

The restaurant is casual but comfortable. With the exception of the 4 seats at the "bar" (low seats), most of these tables are communal and you're obligated to share your place with others- so come here for a casual meal with close friends/loved ones - probably not the best location for a business meeting or something of that nature.

They do have a 1-hour limit BUT they serve beer so they ultimately let you enjoy your meal/drinks and don't rush you at all. It's not like in Japan where you sit, slurp slurp, and leave. I still felt like I had a really pleasant experience where I sat, drank, observed, ate, slurped, ate, drank some more, then left - completely satisfied.

Worth it!

excerpts: I would stop by again to try the Shio or the Shoyu one day when there isn't a ridiculously long wait.
shio.author: Annie Z.
shio.review:
I love ramen, I really do and Mensho is definitely an amazing ramen place. HOWEVER, I honestly would not wait in line for 30 minutes again or pay another $25 for mensho. While I thought the flavor was delicious and I enjoyed the chewy-ness of my noodles. I do not think it's mind-blowingly better than other options such as orenchi beyond, or shalala before they closed. This location is tiny and on a cold SF day, you're better off eating at a different ramen joint and not getting sick. the portions here are not huge but they're very very heavy given the amount of fat that's in the tori paitan. 

I would stop by again to try the Shio or the Shoyu one day when there isn't a ridiculously long wait.

excerpts: It was a little on the heavy side, so you prefer lighter soup, you should go for shio or shoyu.
shio.author: Hoyan L.
shio.review:
So happy to see SF finally expanding on its ramen scene! I have been waiting to give this place a try since the grand opening day on Saturday, but the mob of people on grand opening day was crazy! We left and came back on a weekday night around 8:30pm and the wait was only about 40 minutes, even shorter if you are a solo diner! 

I got the Tori Paitan ramen since they don't have tonkotsu on the soft opening menu yet. The soup was SUPER thick, rich, and creamy, almost like a chicken stew broth. It was rich but at just the right amount of salty. It was a little on the heavy side, so you prefer lighter soup, you should go for shio or shoyu. 

The noodles were cooked to perfect al dente, thicker than usual which gave a very nice chew. The duck chashu was luxurious and tender. The pork chashu was melt in your mouth good. Towards the later half of my ramen, I started tasting these little bits of grit or sandy like texture in the broth which threw me off a little bit (hence not perfect 5 stars) I'm not sure if that is how the broth should be? 

They are still working out the kinks (i.e., not giving me a pen to sign my credit card txn, forgot about refilling water, etc), but I am pretty excited about this new ramen place in SF and I can't wait to go back to try their tonkotsu and tsukemen when they become available! This place still hasn't won the Orenchi spot in my heart yet though, and also Tenderloin is sketchy at night.

I was debating if I should visit this place some more to try their other ramen before writing a yelp, but then I also want to be in their first 50th reviews list... :)

excerpts: I wasn't in the mood for their speciality, the heartier Tori Paitan, so I went with Shio Chashu and it tasted pretty clean.
I was afraid it might be a bit too salty and, while it hit the spot, I didn't love it?
I might just be more of a Hakata (Tonkotsu) ramen type of gal though.
The service was efficient and attentive.
One of my servers went out of her way to ask me what I thought of the food and that made an impression on me.
shio.author: Julia G.
shio.review:
Is it good? Yes. Is it worth the wait? Not sure. Is it "authentic"? Maybe, but you should probably ask a Japanese person that. I wasn't in the mood for their speciality, the heartier Tori Paitan, so I went with Shio Chashu and it tasted pretty clean. I was afraid it might be a bit too salty and, while it hit the spot, I didn't love it? I might just be more of a Hakata (Tonkotsu) ramen type of gal though. The service was efficient and attentive. One of my servers went out of her way to ask me what I thought of the food and that made an impression on me. I can't compare it to other ramen places in the Bay Area simply because I haven't been to any. 

I'd definitely go again though to try their specialty and the Tan Tan Men, which the couple behind me was markedly unimpressed with and complained was "SO spicy" lol

excerpts: They have vegan options and light broths like shio and even dipping ramens.
Definitely bringing friends here next time to try more!
Line fills up fast.. and you would think, a bowl of ramen should only take no more than 10 mins to slurp down in Japan... but be prepared to wait 45 mins to an hour or more!
It is delicious though!
shio.author: Linda T.
shio.review:
I recently just came back from Japan and my standards for ramen have definitely became more harsh.  Not a lot of ramen shops serve tori paitan so when I saw it here, I knew I wanted that.  I missed the first group of people being seated so waited about 45 minutes until a seat was ready for me.  They only have communal tables and everyone, no matter how big or small your group is, shares the table.
Got me my tori paitan which came out super hot, broth was thick, milky and flavorful.  Noodles were thick and al dente.  It comes with a slice of tender fatty cha sui and 2 slices of medium rare duck slices.  It was loaded with bamboo shoots and a few kale for some green.  
I can slurp this ramen everyday, especially this 60 degrees sf weather! 
They have vegan options and light broths like shio and even dipping ramens. 
Definitely bringing friends here next time to try more! 
Line fills up fast.. and you would think, a bowl of ramen should only take no more than 10 mins to slurp down in Japan... but be prepared to wait 45 mins to an hour or more!  It is delicious though!

excerpts: I ordered the shio chashu ramen and my bf ordered the tori paitan.
The tori paitan had a really thick broth, and was really rich and creamy.
The duck charsiu was also really tender and just melts in your mouth.
My shio chashu ramen was quite plain and felt like it lacked flavor.
I had to ask them for some chili oil to add some kick to it.
shio.author: Lisa H.
shio.review:
Came here on a Sunday around 6pm and there was a line outside the door. This was my first time here and I've heard that it was the new spot that was originally from Japan. The place was pretty small and their menu had a limited selection because it's still pretty new. The inside of the restaurant was pretty small so you will most likely be sharing a table with others. It took about an hour wait to finally get inside and sit down and eat. 

We quickly looked at the menu and they took our orders. I ordered the shio chashu ramen and my bf ordered the tori paitan. The tori paitan had a really thick broth, and was really rich and creamy. The duck charsiu was also really tender and just melts in your mouth. My shio chashu ramen was quite plain and felt like it lacked flavor. I had to ask them for some chili oil to add some kick to it. They also have very limited condiments that are on the table. 

Would I come back? Probably not. It's definitely overpriced for what they serve, and not worth the wait. It's also located in a sketchy area where bums would sometimes come inside the restaurant and ask for money. It's a cool place to try, but to be a fan of it, I think I will pass.

excerpts: I ordered the Tori Paitan while my friend ordered the Shio.
I got Tori Paitan because everyone raved about it - for me, it was very rich and flavorful, however too creamy and heavy for me.
It didn't even taste like broth anymore, it was like a gravy sauce, which I was not a fan of.
I was jealous of my friend's Shio because it was so flavorful and light.
I gave my Tori Paitan 2.5 stars and he gave his 5.
I do agree that the noodles are really good here though.
This time I ordered the Shio and my friend ordered the Organic Shoyu.
Shio was much better than the Tori Paitan I ordered before, but I thought my bowl was a little bit salty.
Shio was much better than the Tori Paitan I ordered before, but I thought my bowl was a little bit salty.
I tried the Shoyu which tasted similar to the Shio but with a kick of light soy sauce.
Noodles were great again, pork was not bad, but flawed in the broth again.
shio.author: Raquel Y.
shio.review:
Oh Mensho... so this is my #71 ramen review in my ramen list (can you believe that?!). Yes, I'm a bit obsessed with ramen and friends nicknamed me "Ramen Sheriff." Check out my ramen list attached :) 

So when the talk of the town was that Mensho was everyone's new favorite ramen spot, I had to try it for myself. I tried 2 of their bowls at 2 different occasions: 

[May 2016]
I ordered the Tori Paitan while my friend ordered the Shio. I got Tori Paitan because everyone raved about it - for me, it was very rich and flavorful, however too creamy and heavy for me. It didn't even taste like broth anymore, it was like a gravy sauce, which I was not a fan of. I was jealous of my friend's Shio because it was so flavorful and light. I gave my Tori Paitan 2.5 stars and he gave his 5. I do agree that the noodles are really good here though. Perfect texture and taste. 

[Oct 2016]
Decided to give Mensho another chance. This time I ordered the Shio and my friend ordered the Organic Shoyu. Shio was much better than the Tori Paitan I ordered before, but I thought my bowl was a little bit salty. I tried the Shoyu which tasted similar to the Shio but with a kick of light soy sauce. Noodles were great again, pork was not bad, but flawed in the broth again. I was hoping second time around would have me agree with everyone else, but with the amount of ramen bowls I've had, I can't help but compare.

OVERALL: Mensho has great texture and taste for their noodles and decent pork, however although their broths are unique and somewhat similar to Japan, it still does not quite hit the spot. If you really want authentic ramen, hit up Clint at Noodle in Haystack and reserve one of his pop up ramen dinners! It's the closest thing you'll get to Japan :)

excerpts: The creaminess was amazing with so much flavorful taste from the broth, we also had the most popular tori paitan with pork and chicken broth, which was also amazing very creamy though if you prefer less creamy go for the shio or shoyu.
Definetly expect to wait in line so the earlier you come to the better ;)
shio.author: Cheryl P.
shio.review:
We came on a sunday night around 9 & waited about 30 mins, the place Isnt very big so they definitely want you to eat fast because theres usually a long line outside of the place. They only have a few items on the menu but everything is pretty go id quality and taste great! 
The ingredients in the ramen overall here is some of the best, as they balance all the key components of ramen very well. I got the vegan tantamen ramen which was one of the best ramen ive ever had vegan or not. I love the ramen spots in so val like hakata sen gumi yen, kita kata, Kopan (Orange county) Tsujita and daikokuya in LA and MENSHO is up there with those places for me =D
The creaminess was amazing with so much flavorful taste from the broth, we also had the most popular tori paitan with pork and chicken broth, which was also amazing very creamy though if you prefer less creamy go for the shio or shoyu.
 Definetly expect to wait in line so the earlier you come to the better ;)

excerpts: I was able to try the oysters in shoyu dare oil, tori paitan,  and shio ramen.
The oysters were tasty, but nothing too special.
The tori paitan had a richer and thicker broth than any other ramen I've eaten.
The new consistency was initially overwhelming, but I loved the flavor and finished more of it than I should have by the end of the meal.
The shio was much lighter and more similar to ramen broth you can get at other Japanese restaurants.
shio.author: Sean W.
shio.review:
Came here on a Wednesday night around 6pm expecting a long wait. To my surprise, we only had to wait no more than 10 minutes for a party of 2! I have to agree with other reviews saying the fewer people you come with the better. My only complaint is the space is cramped and on the louder side, making it slightly difficult to have a conversation. 

I was able to try the oysters in shoyu dare oil, tori paitan,  and shio ramen. The oysters were tasty, but nothing too special. The tori paitan had a richer and thicker broth than any other ramen I've eaten. The new consistency was initially overwhelming, but I loved the flavor and finished more of it than I should have by the end of the meal. The shio was much lighter and more similar to ramen broth you can get at other Japanese restaurants. The meat was perfectly tender and the texture of the noodles were on point for both bowls. 

Mensho is a very unique ramen experience that you should definitely check out. Hopefully you will be as lucky with your wait time as I was!

excerpts: I got the Shio Ramen and Yuki Nigori Lychee Saki.
Both were better than I had imagined and honestly the best dish you may find in San Francisco for the price.
The duck was exquisite and the wait staff are attentive without making you feel in a rush.
shio.author: Jeremy B.
shio.review:
Yes. The wait is crazy long. I waited an hour, and the last 30 minutes was filled with me watching other people consume what I could only image to be the most amazing ramen dish ever poured into porcelain. Not to mention the big screen TV that also taunts you with recordings of others eating ramen at an alarming rate. 

Even with everything working against me, I continued to wait and it was worth it. I got the Shio Ramen and Yuki Nigori Lychee Saki. Both were better than I had imagined and honestly the best dish you may find in San Francisco for the price. The duck was exquisite and the wait staff are attentive without making you feel in a rush.

excerpts: The dishes here range from $13 for shio ramen, and up to around $18 for the extra spicy mazesoba.
shio.author: Eric W.
shio.review:
Went here last Saturday for the 3rd time and I'm pleased to report that the wait at 7pm for a party of 4 was only 25 mins! Now's your chance folks! 

This is the best ramen place in SF, the bay area, and most likely in California. The Tori Paitan ramen is on par wtih some of the NY greats like Ippudo and Totto, and the vegan ramen was a revelation for me. I came in really skeptical mumbling things about mouthfeel and "depth of flavor," but I actually ended up liking it more than the Tori Paitan. 

And on to the dish that makes me dream about this place -- the spicy mazesoba. It's a dry noodle dish kind of similar to Zha Jiang Mian (black bean noodles) that comes with bbq pork, chashu, and diced habanero. Yes, you read that right, HABANERO. It's hands down the best noodle dish I've ever had, I'm not even joking right now. I tried to order the extra spicy, but the waitress advised against it, as it contains a full 2 diced habanero. Next time! 

Finally, they have a super delicious IPA called Ozeno Yukidoke for $13 a bottle. Yes, that's super duper expensive for an ipa, but it's really really good and you should at least try it once if you're into IPAs. 

The dishes here range from $13 for shio ramen, and up to around $18 for the extra spicy mazesoba.

excerpts: i tried the broth for shio, organic shoyu, and tori paitan.
shio.author: Judy L.
shio.review:
the wait in the cold was not so fun. we were about 10 parties back in queue, and waited about 1 hour on a saturday evening around 9pm. it's communal tables with decently quick service. 

our party of 4 all got different dishes. my vegan tantanmen was DELECTABLE. super rich, peanut-y base, perfectly alkaline aldente ramen. i tried the broth for shio, organic shoyu, and tori paitan. all very good, but the vegan tantanmen was my favorite of the meal.

also try the oysters!!!

excerpts: If you tend to in general not really like chicken due to occasionally getting a "death"/fecal taste despite the chicken being cleaned very thouroughly then I would recommend you skip the tori-paitan and go for something like the shio ramen.
I ordered the tori-paitan despite my general dislike for chicken because I wanted to give it a try (I'm open the trying new things).
Despite not really liking the broth I wasn't mad at all at my order.
I'll definitely try out the shio ramen.
shio.author: E H.
shio.review:
Definitely get here early, someone wrote to get here around 4:15. We arrived at 5:10 and had to wait about 1 hour and 40 minutes to be seated. 

Tori-paitan is supposedly the famous/most popular dish here. If you tend to in general not really like chicken due to occasionally getting a "death"/fecal taste despite the chicken being cleaned very thouroughly then I would recommend you skip the tori-paitan and go for something like the shio ramen. I ordered the tori-paitan despite my general dislike for chicken because I wanted to give it a try (I'm open the trying new things). Despite not really liking the broth I wasn't mad at all at my order. I REALLY liked the fried gobo and the duck chashu is sooooo good!!!

If I get the chance to come back I'll definitely try out the shio ramen.

excerpts: I tried the Tori Paitan and Shio ramen.
The latter is more similar to the typical ramen around town where as the prior was unique with a thicker broth.
Every slurp took me to umami heaven.
Broth, texture of the ramen, charsu and vegetables were perfect.
I licked both bowls clean, down to the very last drop of broth.
It was that amazing.
It was also painful to move afterwards
but I got the full experience (pun intended).
Check it out.
shio.author: Amy J.
shio.review:
I devoured two bowls of ramen in a single visit.  One at 5:20 and another at 7:10.  The long and short of the hiccup is due a combination of hunger pains and anticipated lines and arrival time of friends.  

I tried the Tori Paitan and Shio ramen.  The latter is more similar to the typical ramen around town where as the prior was unique with a thicker broth.  Every slurp took me to umami heaven.  Broth, texture of the ramen, charsu and vegetables were perfect.  I licked both bowls clean, down to the very last drop of broth.  It was that amazing.  It was also painful to move afterwards but I got the full experience (pun intended).  Check it out.  The hype is real.  

Also, the service was unexpectedly good.  They bent over backwards in trying to accommodate my party of 1 which grew to 7.

excerpts: I have tried the shio ramen and the vegan tantanmen.
My favorite is definitely the vegan tantanmen, despite it costing double in price.
The soup is uber rich, and packs huge flavor.
I think most people would prefer the traditional soy sauce/ pork style broth, but I like this one more.
shio.author: Victor L.
shio.review:
Mensho is one of those places where there will always be a line.  However, the line is justified, as they are able to offer ramen that is quite delicious.  I have had the pleasure of being able to dine here several times.  I have tried the shio ramen and the vegan tantanmen.  My favorite is definitely the vegan tantanmen, despite it costing double in price.  The soup is uber rich, and packs huge flavor.  I think most people would prefer the traditional soy sauce/ pork style broth, but I like this one more.  Portions are generous, even though the ramen is quite pricey.  

There aren't any seats that are private, so be very aware that everyone will be eyeing you and your food.  Service is decent, but they do rush you to eat, pay, and leave.

excerpts: Their shio and vegetable tantanmwn rocks too.
The lamb is unique all though tasty and filling.
The broth is makes them unique.
And that's what makes this place different from the rest.
shio.author: Miguel Y.
shio.review: Very good Ramen. 4.7 stars different not your typical Ramen shop! Limited menu. Specialize on what they serve. Dashu oysters require an acquired taste. Their tori Paitan duck and pork chasu is their top biller. Highly recommend. Their shio and vegetable tantanmwn rocks too. The lamb is unique all though tasty and filling. The broth is makes them unique. And that's what makes this place different from the rest.

excerpts: I loved my Shio Ramen!
Really really tasty broth... light and not salty at all.
I slurped up every last bite!
I only wish they serve eggs here,, its not ramen without a poached egg!
Only gripe is they don't really have a system for the line outside.
You just line up and it could be an endless wait since the waitress is the one who comes out to get the next party.
You don't even check in, there's no texting, you just wait and wait and wait....
lol
I would definitely come back though, definitely one of the best ramen I've had!
shio.author: Irene C.
shio.review: I loved my Shio Ramen! Really really tasty broth... light and not salty at all. I slurped up every last bite! I only wish they serve eggs here,, its not ramen without a poached egg! Only gripe is they don't really have a system for the line outside. You just line up and it could be an endless wait since the waitress is the one who comes out to get the next party. You don't even check in, there's no texting, you just wait and wait and wait.... lol I would definitely come back though, definitely one of the best ramen I've had!

excerpts: so I opted for their shio ramen instead of the popular tori paitan, but it was underwhelming.
Just a word of caution, the shio broth is very fishy.
I was ok with that, but if you're not a fan of heavy bonito flavor, I'd skip on the shio.
The noodles were the crumply kind, but they weren't al dente but rather soft instead.
Toppings consisted of kale (how fitting...of SF?), nori, bamboo, green onions and one piece of chashu.
shio.author: Jen P.
shio.review:
Well, that was a letdown.

We arrived at 5:45 pm on a Friday and the wait was about an hour long. I don't really like creamy broths so I opted for their shio ramen instead of the popular tori paitan, but it was underwhelming. Just a word of caution, the shio broth is very fishy. I was ok with that, but if you're not a fan of heavy bonito flavor, I'd skip on the shio. The noodles were the crumply kind, but they weren't al dente but rather soft instead. Toppings consisted of kale (how fitting...of SF?), nori, bamboo, green onions and one piece of chashu. Comes with a giant silver spoon.

2 stars for the cute, wood minimalist interior with handy places to store your personal belongings, the friendly servers and relatively quick service once seated. As for the ramen itself, I'd look elsewhere.

If you aren't up for the long wait but want to try it out, just come as a solo diner! You'll get in much faster. There were open seats for "party of one" like 3 times over the course of our hour long wait.

excerpts: I also tried a bit of my friend's Shio broth which was nice and light with a really nice seaweed-y flavor to it.
shio.author: Quan N.
shio.review:
Waited an hour in line, totally worth it.

I got the single Tori Paitan which it seems this place is known for. The broth is really thick with a kind of foamy texture that I found pretty unique and very flavorful. Noodles were on the thicker side which I like, and the vegetables (kale and bamboo mostly) went really well with it. The highlight of the ramen was the two type of chashu (duck and pork) that came with it. Super tender and flavorful, especially the duck.

I also tried a bit of my friend's Shio broth which was nice and light with a really nice seaweed-y flavor to it. Very nice!

All in all, this place is 100% worth the wait, especially if it's your first time. The ramen tastes unlike any others I've had in the Bay Area. Highly recommend a visit!

excerpts:
I had shio ramen and it was just eating noodles dipped in oil.
No taste in the soup.
Kept adding salt but still no taste 
AT ALL.
Not Japanese quality at all!
So disappointing!!!!
日本人の恥だ
！！
shio.author: Mike C.
shio.review:
Horrible!!!!
If possible, I would like to give no star.
Doesn't even deserve a star.
Not sure why there is a long line for wait.
Not worth it.

I had shio ramen and it was just eating noodles dipped in oil.
No taste in the soup.
Kept adding salt but still no taste AT ALL.
Not Japanese quality at all!
So disappointing!!!!
日本人の恥だ！！

excerpts: Tried tori, vegan, and shio.
I like spicy
so vegan was my fav.
Tori and vegan noodles are delicious and crisper than the noodles in shio.
In shio they are more wavy.
shio.author: Allison W.
shio.review:
Tried tori, vegan, and shio. I like spicy so vegan was my fav. Tori and vegan noodles are delicious and crisper than the noodles in shio. In shio they are more wavy.

I heard the staff do a chant before they opened. I drink a lot of water and had to ask for refills everytime but the waitresses were nice enough. Service isn't the best but the vegan ramen is the best ramen I've had in my life. Broth is really thick in tori and vegan.

excerpts: If you want a lighter base, shio or shoyu.
shio.author: Chena N.
shio.review:
Imagine Wal-Mart during Black Friday, that's exactly what Mensho Tokyo was like. 
If you walk in the TL and see a long line out the door, it's most likely Mensho. 

Authentic ramen from JAPAN?! Count me in to join in on the hype! Gave it a couple days to let the crowd simmer down a bit... Not that it really has.... 

Did my research and realized that in order to get in first seating you have to be there around 4-4:20pm. On a Tuesday, my friend and I came at 4:10pm and were the 3rd ones in line. Around 4:20pm the line was pretty long. I hear that if you come at 5pm (their opening time it would be a TWO hr wait) anything after that is 3-4 hr. HELL NAH. Lol. 

::Parking/Service/Ambiance::
Parking. Ha. Don't even think about it especially after 6pm. Luckily we got there around 4pm and there was parking 5-6 blocks away from the restaurant. Paid $2.25/hr because it was meters. 
It's kind of ironic that a restaurant from Japan opened up in the most ghetto part of SF, in the tenderloins. I felt super scared at night, good thing I was with a guy. 
Service was amazing. While we were in line I think the manager of some sort came out and thanked us for waiting and asked if we have any questions at all. The staff were all friendly too from start to end. 
They fit about 28 people for max capacity says the manager. There were 3 separate benches: one long bench that fits 12, two short bench that fit 6 each, and 4 chairs near the chef window. The place was definitely small but very clean and simple. Below each table were cubbies that reminded me of elementary school where we could fit our small purses or jackets. 
Came at 4:10pm so we were seated immediately and got to order before the large groups came in. 

::BLACK FRIDAY DEALS::
If you want something creamy and thick, go with vegan tantanmen or tori paitan ramen. If you want a lighter base, shio or shoyu.

Tori Paitan ramen 16.00: thick creamy rich chicken soup with BOTH pork chashu and duck chashu topped with menma, kale, burdock, and katsuobushi sauce. The sauce was SO rich and creamy. It wasn't too salty despite the creaminess. However half way through it got too heavy for me. Nonetheless the meat were all melt in your mouth perfection and the noodles were thick and cooked to amazing "bounciness" level.

excerpts: For me, I had the Shio Double Chashu Ramen ($11), which had 2 slices of pork.
I was a little suurprised though as to how small the bowls were comparing to other ramen places that I've been to.
shio.author: Tito G.
shio.review:
I came here after a few drinks with my friends and we needed something to fill our bellies (well, I probably needed it more after 3 cocktails, hahahaha). Through the mighty power of Yelp, I found this place just a block away and it have a bunc++h of nice reviews. I figured, why not try this place out. Mensho was definitely smaller than I expected it to be and the place was pretty crowded. I learned through my friend that this place was actually a place where people would line up to eat at this place because it was really good. For us though, we waited around 5 min before we were seated.

Service here was really quick, as they gave us our ramen in a few minutes. For me, I had the Shio Double Chashu Ramen ($11), which had 2 slices of pork. I was a little suurprised though as to how small the bowls were comparing to other ramen places that I've been to. The food itself was pretty good and filled me up. 

Although the service was quick and the food was good, would I come back specifically to this place again for some ramen? Probably not. For the price, it was kinda expensive and I feel like you can get a better deal elsewhere. Maybe if I was drinking again and needed something in my stomach. Would I recommend this place? Sure! Just expect that you'll be paying a little more than usual for ramen.

excerpts:
My boyfriend's favorite of the 3.
- Shio Ramen ($9): The cheapest bowl and also my favorite.
Similar to Organic Ramen, but with a salt (not shoyu).
Simple fixings with pork chashu and some fried garlic bits.
I loved the clear broths of both the organic and shio ramen.
It was flavorfu and not overly salty.
Can really taste the complex flavors of seaweed and seafood notes.
I like the Shio Ramen just a bit more because of its simplicity, allowing the broth to shine.
The broth comes out HOT (the way it should be).
shio.author: Minh N.
shio.review:
Finally a worthy ramen shop in the Bay Area!

I happened to stumble upon Mensho Tokyo by pure coincidence on Instagram of all places. My plan of attack was to come straight here right after the halftime Super Bowl show. Line was about 30 people stacked already, but it took us only 45 minutes of waiting. Not bad, considering I overheard people waiting 2-3 hours grand opening night on Saturday. Plan worked! 

Totally digging the interior design and details of this place. There's coat hooks on the wall to hang your jacket, woven baskets underneath the table to stash your purse, and even a storage space under the table to keep your phone ready for some picture action. I totally geeked out on the molecular structures and science blurb of umami on the wall. Even the wooden spoon and chopsticks neatly laying on top of the ceramic plate was just perfect.

Me and boyfriend ended up sharing a total of 3 bowls:
- Tori Paitan ($18): The most decadent of them all, a creamy and rich chicken based broth with pork + duck chashu. The broth was good, however I couldn't get over the slight grittiness of the broth. That duck chashu though! Served with round thick chewy noodles.
- Oraganic Ramen ($14): A blend of chicken + pork clear broth seasoned with shoyu and comes with pork + duck chasu. Served with flat thick chewy noodles. My boyfriend's favorite of the 3.
- Shio Ramen ($9): The cheapest bowl and also my favorite. Similar to Organic Ramen, but with a salt (not shoyu). Simple fixings with pork chashu and some fried garlic bits. Served with flat thick chewy noodles.

I loved the clear broths of both the organic and shio ramen. It was flavorfu and not overly salty. Can really taste the complex flavors of seaweed and seafood notes. I like the Shio Ramen just a bit more because of its simplicity, allowing the broth to shine. The broth comes out HOT (the way it should be). I won't lie, I slurped that bowl clean!

The pork chashu was melt in your mouth delicious. Duck chashu was completely new to my tastebuds and is as amazing as it sounds. Their in-house made ramen noodles are the thicker kind and the shape depends on which bowl you get. The toppings were different, such as fried burdock, kale, or sprouts, but the novelty works.

There's 28 seats in this joint, but turn over seems fast. I dined in and out in 30 minutes.

Since they just opened, they have a very limited menu, hopefully to expand next month with tonkotsu and tsukemen. The vegan ramen sounds intriguing as well. Can't wait to try more!

The Tori Paitan is basically a chicken based Tonkotsu ramen and the Shio is salt based.
The Tori Paitan is basically a chicken based Tonkotsu ramen and the Shio is salt based.
The Tori Paitan was freaking amazing.
It was just packed with flavor.
The broth was thick and there was heaps of meat inside.
The chashu was very delicious and quite possibly the best chashu I had in a bowl of ramen.
Well, actually, this is probably the best ramen I've had in my life.
I've been to Japan and eaten plenty of too.
The Shio ramen was very light in comparison to the Tori Paitan.
It was very delicious as well.
It had a nice clean flavor and was very beautiful.
It was very very very good as well
The Shio ramen was very light in comparison to the Tori Paitan.
It was very delicious as well.

It was very very very good as well
, I just preferred the Tori Paitan because I'm a fan of thicker broths.
Tip, if you order two bowls of ramen start off with the lighter bowl first (not Tori Paitan) because once you go light to thick broth you can really taste and notice the difference of thickness.
shio.author: Allen C.
shio.review:
Came here on the grand opening on the first day and waited for LONG LONG time to get inside even though I was one of the first 20 people. 

The restaurant opened at 5PM, but I probably didn't get in until like 6:30PM. It was the first day on grand opening and it was superbowl weekend. It was pretty cool to see Chef Shono come out and greet everybody and also Abram AKA Ramen Beast. They took photos, some of us got interviewed. 

They didn't want to overwhelm the staff and chefs in the back so they only seated a few people at once. Everybody waiting in line was a little angry because we've been waiting for so long, but they just want to make sure everything goes well for the first day. 

Because me and my friend waited for so long we ordered 3 bowls of ramen. We got two orders of the Tori Paitan and one order of the Shio ramen. The Tori Paitan is basically a chicken based Tonkotsu ramen and the Shio is salt based. 

The Tori Paitan was freaking amazing. It was just packed with flavor. The broth was thick and there was heaps of meat inside. The chashu was very delicious and quite possibly the best chashu I had in a bowl of ramen. Well, actually, this is probably the best ramen I've had in my life. I've been to Japan and eaten plenty of too. This was definitely on that japan-level. 

The Shio ramen was very light in comparison to the Tori Paitan. It was very delicious as well. It had a nice clean flavor and was very beautiful. It was very very very good as well, I just preferred the Tori Paitan because I'm a fan of thicker broths. It was paired with flat noodles.

Tip, if you order two bowls of ramen start off with the lighter bowl first (not Tori Paitan) because once you go light to thick broth you can really taste and notice the difference of thickness. 

This is by far the best ramen shop in the Bay Area. The wait is incredibly long right now, so I'd advise you to wait till the hype dies down. Shono-san will be coming back to Mensho in March and will be added new items to the Menu. I cant wait!

excerpts: The shio was bland.
No flavor in the broth.
The mazesoba was good.
Better than the ramen.
Not exactly soba noodles.
shio.author: Karen N.
shio.review:
Meh.
Tried the shoyu ramen. A bit on the salty side for shoyu. Also the noodles, while obviously house made, were flat and not typical ramen noodles. The shio was bland. No flavor in the broth. The mazesoba was good. Better than the ramen. Not exactly soba noodles. Better! 

Probably wouldn't bother coming back. Not easy to park. About a 15 min wait. Not bad but not good enough to bring us back. So many other better ramen places.

excerpts: The shio ramen was better, though not by much.
The broth was light and flavorful.
For both dishes I didn't like the ramen noodles themselves, not your typical noodles
shio.author: Kent H.
shio.review:
Unfortunately I do not know what the buzz was about.  It's definitely on the pricey side, but it's SF.  

I felt the tori paitan's broth texture seemed a bit too powdery.  It's like when you cook broth and  the all that remained was the powdery portion.  The meats weren't bad.

The shio ramen was better, though not by much.  The broth was light and flavorful.  For both dishes I didn't like the ramen noodles themselves, not your typical noodles, they were of the flat wavy style.

We waited about 1 hr on a Thursday night.

excerpts: The Clam Butter Ramen was a little more of a miss, and we probably should have ordered something more traditional like the Shio or Shoyu Ramen.
The broth started off tasting light and delicious, but over time the taste of raw seafood ("like the ocean") permeated the entire bowl.
My boyfriend noted the noodles were not hot as in the Tori Paitain; perhaps that was to prevent overcooking of the clams and scallops in the dish?
shio.author: Amanda W.
shio.review:
Have you ever had ramen that was SO amazing, it absolutely ruins all other ramen for you?

Unfortunately, that was not my experience at Mensho Tokyo.  While the ramen is undeniably good and I am by no means a ramen connoisseur, I think I would have been similarly satisfied with a bowl at Waraku or Men Oh.  Maybe this was a dangerous product of high expectations combined with over-hype, but my meal last Friday night did not blow me away as much as I had hoped.

My boyfriend and I got in line at 4:40PM last Friday night, and we missed the first seating by 1 party of two.  The wait didn't feel too terrible--we were seated at 5:36PM--and I was excited to try the much raved-about $18 Tori Paitan (Double Chashu), as well as the $18 Clam Butter Ramen (currently limited to 10 bowls daily).  We also ordered the $5 Oysters in Shoyu Dare Oil for appetizer, as well as a $18.55 bottle of Kikusui "Perfect Snow" Sake.  Service was fast and we did not have to wait long for our food to come out.

The Tori Paitan was definitely the highlight of the night.  As many other reviews have noted, the broth is thick and almost gravy-like.  The noodles were hot and just the right amount of chewy, and the the only thing missing from the bowl was a soft-boiled egg.  It was my first time having duck chashu, and I LOVE duck, but I can't say I prefer it any more or less to the standard pork chashu.

The Clam Butter Ramen was a little more of a miss, and we probably should have ordered something more traditional like the Shio or Shoyu Ramen.  The broth started off tasting light and delicious, but over time the taste of raw seafood ("like the ocean") permeated the entire bowl.  My boyfriend noted the noodles were not hot as in the Tori Paitain; perhaps that was to prevent overcooking of the clams and scallops in the dish?  I was expecting the broth to taste a little more "cooked," so I would not recommend this dish if you are adverse to an overly "raw" seafood taste.

The Oysters in Shoyu Dare Oil were similarly raw tasting; I love oysters, but from the pictures I did not expect it to taste this much like the ocean.  Some pieces had sand/gravel in them, so at least you know it's fresh?

The waitresses are prompt in cleaning up your bowls after you are done, which I appreciated; however, they took away my napkin before I was done drinking my sake. :(

Overall, I am not in a rush to return, but on the off-chance I walk by and there is no line, I'd give this place another shot.  Finally, note that they do not offer to-go or take-out containers, but you won't be needing any since the portions run on the small side for the price.

excerpts: Bowls of ramen typically are more than $15 (except the shio ramen), so it's definitely on the higher end of the spectrum.
But despite the wait and cost, it's worth going at least once.
shio.author: Charlotte H.
shio.review:
Their vegan tantanmen is some of the best vegan alternatives I've had. They make a roasted nut based broth with chili oil, and it has a similar fat content and depth as their non-vegan broths. The vegan noodles were springy and thick and were similar in texture and taste as ramen noodles, despite not containing egg. 

We arrived at 5:20pm on a Thursday and waited about an hour before we got seated. Line seemed to move regularly, even though the restaurant could only seat around 20 people. Bowls of ramen typically are more than $15 (except the shio ramen), so it's definitely on the higher end of the spectrum. But despite the wait and cost, it's worth going at least once.

excerpts: I ordered the Shio Ramen and was very oily.
Besides the broth the pork was soft and tender.
They add a lot of bamboo to your ramen which I thought was a plus.
I really do not understand why this place has so much hype.
shio.author: Joey V.
shio.review:
stumbled upon this place on Yelp and arrived 10 minutes before they opened and there was a line of at least 6 groups ahead of me. So I thought, hey this place must be good. 

First off the place is very small. The placing of tables and chairs is cramped so much that the waiter kept bumping my back every time she had pass by. Very limited seating so if you come here with a group of 4 or more, good luck trying to get a seat. You will probably have to wait for hours until a table opens up. Since its so cramped here you can hear other peoples conversations so clearly. 

The customer service was little but there. The server who looked like the manager was too into getting customers in n out of the restaurant it felt like I was in a food competition where I had to eat as fast as I could. I felt so rushed I could barely enjoy what I was eating. I get that the place is very small and you have a line outside the door but if I am going to pay for over priced ramen I would want to enjoy it. Not only did I feel so rushed trying to finish my food the server denied a customer because they wanted to share a bowl of ramen. I thought this was ridiculous and honestly felt bad for the 2 people who had to leave. 

The food was mediocre at best. To be honest, I would not wait outside to eat at this place. I ordered the Shio Ramen and was very oily. Besides the broth the pork was soft and tender. They add a lot of bamboo to your ramen which I thought was a plus. I really do not understand why this place has so much hype. I have tried better ramen places around here in the bay area that had much more flavor and spices. 

I will not come here again.

excerpts: Probably one of the best ramen places I've ever been, the Shio Ramen is amazing.
BUT be sure to get the DOUBLE CHASHU trust me, the meat is soft and melts in your mouth, would even recommend adding more chashu from the menu.
shio.author: David Jonathan T.
shio.review: Probably one of the best ramen places I've ever been, the Shio Ramen is amazing. BUT be sure to get the DOUBLE CHASHU trust me, the meat is soft and melts in your mouth, would even recommend adding more chashu from the menu.

excerpts: Be aware that they are not currently serving Tonkotsu Ramen or White Truffle Shio ramen.
Our group tried the Tori Paitan, the Shoyu Ramen, and the Shio Ramen.
I had the Shoyu and it was super flavorful.
shio.author: Kelly L.
shio.review:
Best ramen in SF!

We tried our luck on Saturday to see if the hype was legit. Be warned: the restaurant only seats 28 people at a time and the line gets BANANAS. The wait for people end of the line at 5 pm (opening time) was about 2 hours. It was twice as long by the time we left. The host mentioned that 10 or 10:30pm was a good time to come if you didn't mind waiting until after the regular dinner rush.

Be aware that they are not currently serving Tonkotsu Ramen or White Truffle Shio ramen.

We shared two orders of the oysters in shoyu dare oil. They were good but nothing to really write home about. Definitely don't get them if you're planning on getting the shoyu ramen (unless you really, really like shoyu) because they taste pretty much the same. 

Our group tried the Tori Paitan, the Shoyu Ramen, and the Shio Ramen. I had the Shoyu and it was super flavorful. The broth was pretty strong on the bonito flavor, so if that's something you dislike you should try the Tori Paitan instead.

The chashu was A+ and practically fell apart when I picked it up. The noodles were excellent as well.

Service could have been better. I understand that they're working out the kinks and that the demand is super crazy, but with only 28 seats and a constant feeling of "we need to turn these tables over quickly" I don't think we should have needed to flag someone down for water and our check.

Overall, the food was pretty great and is definitely bringing the SF Ramen scene in the right direction. I'd love to come back later on when they have a fuller menu.

excerpts:
I have not yet tried the shio base yet, will try it next time.

over all very good, service may not be the best because they are not very good at English, but I am very happy with my visit.
shio.author: Zack Y.
shio.review:
I really wanna give this place a bad review and make people stop going, so I can skip the long wait at their door.

This place ain't gonna be a typical ramen shop that you may find near the bay, the ramen is close to a traditional Japanese ramen.

You should be there before they open, like 4:30 is a good time to be there, and sometimes that even won't make you in the top 3. If you be there at 5, expect at least half an hour wait. By 5:30, it is going to be at least 1.5 hour wait.

The place didn't even have a sign outside, and the address on Yelp is wrong(672 is the right one.) Inside is pretty small that only have around 30 settings. Interior is good, lets get to the food.

Tori Paitan Ramen has a full body and very dense broth. Very flavorful, every sip is a surprise, and it won't get me bored. Some people might found it a bit too oily or creamy, but I think it is thick yet not too much. The ramen noodle itself is one of the best noodle I had in the Bay. All other ingredients are pretty good. The Shoyu broth is very good, too. It is saltier than the Tori Paitan, which it should be. I have not yet tried the shio base yet, will try it next time.

over all very good, service may not be the best because they are not very good at English, but I am very happy with my visit.

excerpts: Tried the tori paitan, vegan tantan, and shio ramens -- LOVED ALL OF THEM.
You really can't go wrong with any of these.
Going in, I definitely had my usual pessimistic doubts about the place.
+ Tori Paitan - Richest broth of them all.
This was my top pick at the start.
Got through half the bowl and just couldn't do it anymore.
+ Vegan tantan
- Upon first taste, was a bit sweet but
a lovely complexity and spice/heat comes out as you eat it.
A bit of a creamy peanut-y taste.
I would probably get this over the tori paitan next time.
+ Shio - The true favorite.
A true broth rather than a creamy soup, it was rich in flavor profile.
Noodles are flatter in the shio.
shio.author: Jennifer M.
shio.review:
Lined up at 5:15pm on a Friday and waited about 2 hours. Tried the tori paitan, vegan tantan, and shio ramens -- LOVED ALL OF THEM. You really can't go wrong with any of these. Going in, I definitely had my usual pessimistic doubts about the place. Mensho is truly worth the wait though! 

+ Tori Paitan - Richest broth of them all. This was my top pick at the start. Got through half the bowl and just couldn't do it anymore.
+ Vegan tantan - Upon first taste, was a bit sweet but a lovely complexity and spice/heat comes out as you eat it. A bit of a creamy peanut-y taste. I would probably get this over the tori paitan next time.
+ Shio - The true favorite. A true broth rather than a creamy soup, it was rich in flavor profile. I could finish this whole bowl by myself, unlike with the other two.

Duck 'chashu' in ramen is new to me... but ended up being a good thing as I love duck and it is served at a perfect medium rare! Noodles are nicely chewy and pick up the soup perfectly. Noodles are flatter in the shio.

excerpts: As we were ordering the ramen they said they ran out of the 2 that we had just selected...sad panda...so we went with the Shio and Vegan Tantanmen.
We also ordered the enoki chips for apps and some sake.
GUYS...
the enoki chips were sooo good.
I'm a huge fan of mushrooms
so when I saw these were fried up?
That's a must for me.
Dip it in the spices that they give you and what a treat.
I wish I could talk to you about the Sake, but unfortunately the waitress never brought it to us.
The big disappointment was the Shio ramen.
It just wasn't anything special.
I feel like I could've went to the Korean market and picked up a pack of Shin ramen and it would've easily satisfied as well as this bowl did.
It didn't have any veggies ( you can order veggies to be added) and it was just so....plain.
shio.author: Richard C.
shio.review:
My wife and I landed in SF late last night, craving for some delicious ramen. We found Mensho to be the only thing open at the time. There was a little line outside, but only took like 20 mins to get through it. It's a pretty small restaurant and can only fit like 20 ppl at the max? We were sat down at the table nearest to the kitchen, so we're able to see the cooks working their magic.

As we were ordering the ramen they said they ran out of the 2 that we had just selected...sad panda...so we went with the Shio and Vegan Tantanmen. We also ordered the enoki chips for apps and some sake. GUYS...the enoki chips were sooo good. I'm a huge fan of mushrooms so when I saw these were fried up? That's a must for me. Dip it in the spices that they give you and what a treat. I wish I could talk to you about the Sake, but unfortunately the waitress never brought it to us. The service here was pretty bad (idk if it's because it was later in the night) as we had to ask them for utensils and no one came to refill our water. 

The waitress brought the ramen and we finally got to eat after a long flight from DC. First of all when I saw the Tantanmen, it looked like noodles in peanut butter broth haha. If you order it you'll know what I'm talking about, but nonetheless it was pretty good. The noodles were cooked great, but something was lacking in the bowl itself. Some bean sprouts or some crunch of something. We ordered some chili sauce to put into our ramen too, as we're both spicy food lovers! The big disappointment was the Shio ramen. It just wasn't anything special. I feel like I could've went to the Korean market and picked up a pack of Shin ramen and it would've easily satisfied as well as this bowl did. It didn't have any veggies ( you can order veggies to be added) and it was just so....plain. I guess I'm use to having some veggies in there or some other stuff in there besides the couple piieces of meat, noodles, and broth.

Overall...just a meh meal. Hope to try other ramen spots while in SF.

excerpts: The shoyu/shio ones are probably lighter.
Noodle's thick and cooked really well.
shio.author: Dana C.
shio.review:
Have to be mentally prepared to wait. Lined up at 5:30 on a Tues for 5 ppl and got seated 2 hrs later.

Ordered the tori paitan. First bite was heaven. Best ramen in SF imo. But because of the creamy broth, it does get pretty heavy by the end. The shoyu/shio ones are probably lighter. Noodle's thick and cooked really well.

excerpts: The Shio ramen was ok.
shio.author: Ali F.
shio.review:
Small restaurant on the border of downtown SF and tenderloin. I wouldn't recommend coming here with anymore more than 4 people; 2 is best. Their signature ramen, the tori paitan is excellent.; Very rich and flavorful broth with thicker textured noodles. The chasu melts in your mouth, but was quite a small piece. The Shio ramen was ok. The broth was good, but this noodle was flat and smooth, similar to egg noodles. 

The wait was one hour long on a Sat night. I'd say worth it to try once.

excerpts: Shio Ramen with duck is amazing!
shio.author: Nestor C.
shio.review: The waiting time varies so try and make it before it opens. Otherwise, the wait can be up to 45min, but is always worth it! Shio Ramen with duck is amazing!

excerpts: I got the shio broth which had excellent kombudashi flavor, with two slices of pork.
Wish there was an option to add an egg.
The noodles were chewy and the best part.
Tried some of their chicken paitan ramen but their broth was too rich and creamy that it was almost like tsukumen sauce.
The duck chashu was pretty amazing.
Like the flavor of the vegan broth ramen.
Overall high quality ramen but higher priced than your average ramen place.
shio.author: Ellin C.
shio.review: Mensho Tokyo takes ramen to another level. If you get there at 4 pm and wait you can probably make it in the first wave of diners. I got the shio broth which had excellent kombudashi flavor, with two slices of pork. Wish there was an option to add an egg. The noodles were chewy and the best part. Tried some of their chicken paitan ramen but their broth was too rich and creamy that it was almost like tsukumen sauce. The duck chashu was pretty amazing. Like the flavor of the vegan broth ramen. Overall high quality ramen but higher priced than your average ramen place.

excerpts: Tried the Shio Chashu Ramen after waiting in line for 30 minutes.
I read about the hype so was really excited until I tasted the bowl.
Not the most flavorful especially the broth.
It was underwheming.
shio.author: B H.
shio.review: Tried the Shio Chashu Ramen after waiting in line for 30 minutes. I read about the hype so was really excited until I tasted the bowl. Not the most flavorful especially the broth. It was underwheming.

excerpts: I got the tori paitan broth and my partner got the shio one.
Noodles are homemade and thicker/fatter than your normal ramen noodles.
They were still good and so were both of the broths.
I liked the thick, creamy tori paitan broth and was tempted to take it home for later (but resisted).
I was worried that the shio (salt) broth would be too salty but it wasn't, it surprisingly had a fish taste that I liked.
They said that they do not offer egg with their ramen because it detracts from the flavor.
shio.author: Diana B.
shio.review: I've been wanting to eat at Mensho since they've opened but was deterred by the long lines. I thought I'd try the Mensho in Tokyo but ended up trying other ramen shops there. Finally my partner and I happened to be in the area late on a weeknight and stopped by. There were about 6 people ahead of us in line. We saw a lot of parties finish their meals and leave, but we had to wait for the servers to seat everyone in line at once. They didn't have the tsukemen noodles today. They also don't have the tonkotsu broth yet which is what the shop in Tokyo is known for. I got the tori paitan broth and my partner got the shio one. Noodles are homemade and thicker/fatter than your normal ramen noodles. They were still good and so were both of the broths. I liked the thick, creamy tori paitan broth and was tempted to take it home for later (but resisted). I was worried that the shio (salt) broth would be too salty but it wasn't, it surprisingly had a fish taste that I liked. They said that they do not offer egg with their ramen because it detracts from the flavor.

shio.review:

excerpts: I had the shio ramen and was a bit disappointed by it after all of the hype I've heard.

shio.author: Mark S.
shio.review:
We went on a Wednesday evening and had to wait about 30 minutes.  When we got inside we were seated at the end of one of the long tables near the door so every time someone entered/exited you could feel a blast of cold air.  I had the shio ramen and was a bit disappointed by it after all of the hype I've heard. To me it was a bit salty and I wasn't able to distinguish it from other ramen that I've had before. 

Overall, I'm not sure the food here justifies the long wait to get seated. If you also need to use the restroom be prepared to wait as there is only one which is shared between the ~30 people in the restaurant (all of whom had had a long wait to get in) and the staff.

excerpts: We liked the shio ramen with plum paste, but not enough to return.

shio.author: Michael L.
shio.review:

excerpts: My boyfriend got the double charsu shio ramen and I got the shoyu ramen!

The other charsu pieces were well done as well!
