shio.author: Van N.
shio.review:
Pretty delicious ramen! Small space but clean and the line wasn't terribly long (Thursday night at like 9pm). 

My boyfriend got the double charsu shio ramen and I got the shoyu ramen! The duck charsu in my ramen was melt-in-your-mouth delicious! The other charsu pieces were well done as well! My broth was a wee bit salty towards the end so I might try another next time-but still tasty!

excerpts: The shio is my favorite so far, but I absolutely loved the vegan tantanmen too - it's distinctly rich and flavorful, you wouldn't believe it's vegan!
As for the long queues, go at night ~10-11pm.
shio.author: Grace C.
shio.review: There's a new ramen shop in town and it's already my favorite in the Bay Area. Ramen creator Shono Tomoharu is bringing authentic ramen culture to SF and I can't be more excited!! The dashi is made with two high quality kelps from Hokkaido and a specially sourced katsuobushi. The shio is my favorite so far, but I absolutely loved the vegan tantanmen too - it's distinctly rich and flavorful, you wouldn't believe it's vegan! As for the long queues, go at night ~10-11pm. :)

excerpts: Shio - Also for baseline.
Same as above, satisfyingly light.
Kale works well here.
shio.author: Richard C.
shio.review:
Fantastic addition to San Francisco. Grant them the operational roughness during the first week, and you'll have no disappointments. Recommended.

1-hour wait at 6:30pm on a Wednesday, 20 people in queue. Would not normally do this. Crowd thankfully knows to eat quickly, and turn the table for the next diners. Ramen is not food to linger over, folks.

4 kinds of noodles available at opening, ordered 3:

* Organic Shoyu - Excellent baseline. Good flavor extraction without excessive salt. Noodle bit on the soft side.
* Shio - Also for baseline. Same as above, satisfyingly light. Kale works well here.
* Vegan Tantanmen - Quite the standout, and I'm not regularly a tantanmen fan. Probably the most delicious vegan dish I've had in my life. Piping hot noodle, visually rich but each-to-eat soymilk base, many dimensions to flavor, all of the elements balanced well.

Our entire group finished the soups, to the last drop. It's a beautiful thing when this happens.

Suntory Premium Mait's not available. Boo-hoo!

Table check came out wrong (missing multiple items), sent back so we can properly pay for everything we ate.

The original Menya Shono (http://menya-shono.com/tokyo) in Shinjuku is a regular stop for me, and their Mensho Tokyo (http://menya-shono.com/tokyo/shop) overseas expansion pilot near Tokyo Dome has been reviewing well in Japan, with a wild range of noodles created. I'll vouch for the quality of the people behind this very welcome addition to San Francisco, I hope they continue to execute well!

excerpts: I tried both the shio and the shoyu ramen.
The broth for both are delicious.
May be on the salty side for some, but I love my ramen broth rich.
The meat is the perfect amount of tenderness.
The noodles weren't the best I've had, but still very good.
Portions leave you wanting a bit more.
shio.author: Tri N.
shio.review:
I tried both the shio and the shoyu ramen. The broth for both are delicious. May be on the salty side for some, but I love my ramen broth rich. The meat is the perfect amount of tenderness. The noodles weren't the best I've had, but still very good. Portions leave you wanting a bit more. I'd recommending splitting an appetizer and getting a bowl for yourself.

The restaurant is tiny, so if you are going with a group more than 2, expect to wait even longer. 

Overall, one of my favorite spots in the Bay Area. It's definitely not worth more than an hour wait though. I'd attempt to show up maybe 20 minutes before they open to avoid a 1.5+ hour wait.

excerpts: The shio ramen did look pretty good, but I don't know if I want to put in the time to try it.
shio.author: masa s.
shio.review:
A few sips of the Tori paitan, and I thought, Yum! After that, it was just the heaviest, thickest broth I'd ever had. The noodles clumped together. A good sign that it's store made, but that's not how you want to know it's not mass produced. The shoyu was really good, but I usually like lighter noodles with the lighter broth.

Waiting minimum 45 minutes for $18 ramen that is not the best that you've ever had (or even the best in SF) is just ludicrous.

The shio ramen did look pretty good, but I don't know if I want to put in the time to try it.

excerpts:
It's cold but a great burst of flavor if you love oysters and salty/sweet sauces
Shio Chashu Ramen - OMG...
The broth is clear and super flavorful for a clear broth.
I'm usually a tonkotsu kinda of gal.
The noodles are not your typical kind and the Korean kalguksu kind, so chewy and perfectly al dente.
The chashu just falls apart as you try to grab and eat...
Only sad thing is that they don't do marinated eggs :(
The noodles were different from the Shio
and I wasn't a huge fan of this dish, but the best part was the duck...
it was like pinkish and fatty but man.
shio.author: Jackie O.
shio.review:
Finally tried Mensho Tokyo ramen this weekend... I've been avoiding it like the plague because of the line BUT I was surprised at how fast the line went! The line was down the block but we only waited 40 mins max for 4 people.

Once you're seated the restaurant itself is tiny so please be respectful of the other waiting ramen lovers... just eat and go! Redford is across the street if you wanna drink and chit chat ;) 

As soon as we were in front and waiting to get seated the waitress took our order, then within 5 minutes we were seated. The tables are interestingly shaped they have these like slots for extra plating and napkins, then baskets underneath for your belongings. Stools so no leaning back and you'll most likely be sharing the table with other ramen goers. I loved the big ass spoons they give you... it's RIDICULOUSLY HUGE! :P

Probably another 5-10 minutes and our ramens came out! We got the following items:
Oysters in Shoyu Dare Oil - Livery texture and the Dare Oil is almost like a soy sauce/ponzu mixture. It's cold but a great burst of flavor if you love oysters and salty/sweet sauces
Shio Chashu Ramen - OMG... The broth is clear and super flavorful for a clear broth. I'm usually a tonkotsu kinda of gal. The noodles are not your typical kind and the Korean kalguksu kind, so chewy and perfectly al dente. The chashu just falls apart as you try to grab and eat... Only sad thing is that they don't do marinated eggs :(
Tori Paitan - The broth was more sweet than savory, but SUPER CREAMY! The noodles were different from the Shio and I wasn't a huge fan of this dish, but the best part was the duck... it was like pinkish and fatty but man. It melted in your mouth!

Service was phenomenal!

excerpts: The shio ramen at $9 is the single best value bowl of ramen I've had in the US: the shoyu just edges it out, but for those looking for something delicious that won't weigh you down, it's a proper shio ramen with a strong chicken flavor.
shio.author: Kevin L.
shio.review:
Reposting my prior review -- this was taken down by Yelp because it was posted prior to the restaurant opening, but after having revisited several times since, my opinion hasn't changed:

I was lucky enough to get a chance to taste the organic shoyu ramen before the grand opening, and I'm happy to report that Mensho Tokyo is as good as it gets for those of us that love our ramen as authentic as possible -- noodles with a good chew, a beautiful slick of fat ladled over the soup, and the whole thing served properly hot (temperature-wise). The soup was a great change of pace from the same old tepid, weak tonkotsu broth with curly pre-frozen noodles that you can get elsewhere in the area. The chashu was generous and delicious: a soft and fatty round of simmered pork, with two juicy slices of duck meat on the side. The tori paitan is thick and rich, for those of you who like a ramen with more body, and the noodles are appropriately matched. Agreed with others that the sprig of kale isn't much to my liking, and I miss having some of my Japanese ramen favorites (menma is a big one for me), but the fried gobo is excellent and adds a flavor that a lot of Americans aren't familiar with. The shio ramen at $9 is the single best value bowl of ramen I've had in the US: the shoyu just edges it out, but for those looking for something delicious that won't weigh you down, it's a proper shio ramen with a strong chicken flavor. The garlic tends to settle on the bottom, which leads to an interesting shift in flavor as you make your way through the bowl and the garlic sits longer in the remaining soup.

This feels like a shop transplanted from Tokyo (which it is), and beats out every one of the other 36 ramen shops I've tried across the US to take the title of #1. It competes handily with the best shops in Tokyo as well. The interior is beautifully appointed, clean, and modern, and I love that they've turned the entire restaurant into counter seating (albeit with the concession of counter-height tables for groups) for a more Japanese dining experience.

They're not launching with everything on the menu, and they're waiting on the go-ahead from the health department before they can start making their own noodles with the machine that they imported from Japan, but Mensho Tokyo is already far and away better than anything else available in the area. Can't wait until they finish sourcing ingredients and start serving additional items from the menu! When that happens, we'll finally be able to have proper tsukemen in the Bay Area. Crossing my fingers that the tori paitan gyokai will be reminiscent of Fuunji in Tokyo!

SF is in for a real treat. This place is worth the wait.

but I've been spoiled Hakodate's shio ramen as over there
the broth is clearer from cooking under low heat of bones and salt, but it's still better than any other shio broth in the bay area.
shio.author: Vien C.
shio.review:
Getting sick of all the tongotsu soup places in the bay area so finally a place with good shoyu Broth.  Having travelled through Japan the past two years, I miss the umami depth of good shoyu broth the likes that only until now that Tokyo and Asahikawa in my travels provided me.  Shoyu broth, seems simple but takes a master to create something deep and complex.  Missing an egg and maybe some scallions and fried shallots as Ramen Honda in tokyo does this and blew me away. But otherwise the noodles and were are perfect, and liked the kamo (duck) slices and burdoct shavings were a unique touch.

Also tried their shio (salt) which was good but I've been spoiled Hakodate's shio ramen as over there the broth is clearer from cooking under low heat of bones and salt, but it's still better than any other shio broth in the bay area. 

Finally, tried the tori paitain from my son.  It was good emulsified chicken stock goodness, but i like the clearer broth options.

Overall, we're lucky to have mensho open in SF.

**
Shio

shio.review:
Hoping to shorten the two hour wait that many yelpers have mentioned, I came here on Wednesday before the restaurant opened. Did I mention it was one of those days where SF hit the high 70s. I arrived at 4:28 being the third party in line with 4 people ahead. Although it was only a 32min wait, I was dying from the heat outside. I can't express how happy I was for those doors to open. 

Service **
Although we were the 3rd party to enter and order, our food did not come until 20-30 mins later. The ramen was made in about 7-8 mins, but I believe some kind of mistake was made by the chef or server. The first two parties ahead of us have already received their order, but the waitress did not notice that we did not have our ramen until 4-5 parties that ordered later was already half way done with their ramen. After asking about our ramen, the answer was oh you guys did not receive your ramen yet. 

*****
Tori Paitan 
This is definitely worth the wait. The broth is rich and flavorful, where you could taste the meats boiled for hours. I have to agree with what the customers across mentioned, "this broth is too good to waste." 

Thicker ramen is paired with this broth. 

***
Shio

Soft Ramen

Not too fond of the crowded communion tables. The establishment is small, so they must make do. We were the last group seated and right at the edge of the table, so we were able to get their attention and order first. Lucky!
The Organic Shoyu Ramen ($14) was pretty good. Not sure if the oil was drizzled on or just part of the broth. The broth was tasty but not feeling the oil. The Tori Paitan ($16) was good. Our party member who ordered the Shio Ramen ($9) thought it was a bit bland and didn't finish it.
Glad we tried it but not a spot we would frequent.

excerpts: I recommend the shio ramen with a side of duck chashu.
shio.author: Tracy Y.
shio.review: Hands down favorite ramen place in San Francisco- I recommend the shio ramen with a side of duck chashu.

excerpts: ramen is $14 before tax, Shio (salt)
shio.author: Jeffrey Z.
shio.review:
The Tori Paitan Ramen (chicken broth) is amazing. Creamiest, thickest ramen broth I've had since being in Tokyo. Noodles were thick and chewy. Each topping had its own distinct flavor - no ingredient was a "filler." You could really taste the quality and care. Kitchen staff far outnumbered wait staff.

Not cheap - $16 before tax for Tori Paitan Ramen. Other options are cheaper. Shoyu (soy sauce) ramen is $14 before tax, Shio (salt) ramen is $9 before tax.

They do not yet have tsukemen and tonkotsu - those are coming in a couple months. So if you enjoy creamy ramen then Tori Paitan is your only option, but you won't regret trying it.

For seating, they only have communal high tables and a few bar seats.

Mensho Tokyo is well acclaimed in Tokyo and this is their first US location. The co-owner is from the Bay Area and is a ramen critic in Japan. He's the host and is super knowledgeable.

They do not have a waiting list, so you have to wait in line. I was in a party of 2 and we had to wait an hour after arriving at 8pm.

excerpts: We decided to wait despite the fact that they had run out of the noodles for the Shio and Shoyu ramen.
I even went across the street to get Hot Cheetos because I was so hungry.
We entered the restaurant around 5:50 or so and sat at the "bar" which is really just 4 chairs looking into the kitchen.
I could tell that the ramen was really high quality, which is why I am giving 4 stars and perhaps if I would've tried the Shoyu or Shio
, I would give 5 stars.
I've had ramen at the best places in New York (Ippudo, Totto) so I have some idea of what good ramen should taste like.
shio.author: Adam G.
shio.review:
Arrived at 4:15pm on 2/14 with my girlfriend and we found ourselves at the 30+ mark in line. We decided to wait despite the fact that they had run out of the noodles for the Shio and Shoyu ramen. I even went across the street to get Hot Cheetos because I was so hungry. We entered the restaurant around 5:50 or so and sat at the "bar" which is really just 4 chairs looking into the kitchen. Given that our only options were the Tori Paitan, which is written about very favorably here, and the vegan ramen due to the limited menu during Mensho's early operations, we both went with the Paitan.

When the reviews say the Paitan is really creamy, they mean it. It is almost too overwhelming with meat flavor and we could not even finish our whole bowl because we got a bit grossed out. It was just a lot of the same flavor. If you've never had Paitan, think Tonkotsu, but WAY creamier. 

I could tell that the ramen was really high quality, which is why I am giving 4 stars and perhaps if I would've tried the Shoyu or Shio, I would give 5 stars. I've had ramen at the best places in New York (Ippudo, Totto) so I have some idea of what good ramen should taste like. There's just no way I see myself waiting that long again for ramen, especially in San Francisco, where there must be a dozen places to get at least a decent bowl without the hassle of waiting. 

For Mensho: You guys need to start recording people's cell phone numbers and texting them when their table is ready. There are two bars across the street I would have much rather sat at for 90 minutes. Also, the servers seemed confused about which seats they were covering, as I ordered with 3 different servers. I'm sure this kink will be worked out as the weeks go by, however. 

TL;DR - if the wait is over 1 hour, go somewhere else, especially in the first few months of the restaurant being open. They told me they are expanding the menu in the next 2 months. The ramen is really good but not worth the wait and countless people walking and driving by thinking you're crazy

excerpts: Second, the Shio Ramen.
Being a shio ramen, the broth is much lighter, but with a much more intense salty flavor.
The initial taste of the soup can definitely taste a bit *too* salty, but it quickly passes by eating more.
The noodles here are much thinner, but it definitely compliments the lighter but more flavorful soup.
shio.author: Chen L.
shio.review:
Without a doubt the best ramen I've had in San Francisco.  I'll be coming back again.

Food
First, the Tori Paitan Ramen, with double chasu.  The broth was incredibly thick, almost gravy like!  An immense amount of flavor in each spoonful and incredibly satisfying in both flavor and fullness.  Both the duck and the pork chashu melt in the mouth; the slow cooking of the meats allows the flavor to concentrate it and it stands out despite the incredibly flavorful broth.  The noodles themselves are thick and take on the flavors of the other ingredients, all while having a firm but easy to eat consistency.

Second, the Shio Ramen.  Being a shio ramen, the broth is much lighter, but with a much more intense salty flavor.  The initial taste of the soup can definitely taste a bit *too* salty, but it quickly passes by eating more.  The noodles here are much thinner, but it definitely compliments the lighter but more flavorful soup.  The chashu is once again fantastic, and the flavors of the meat stands out in the broth.

The other vegetables were incredibly fresh, which really adds to the complexity to the overall dish.  It's incredible how they packed so many different flavors into a single dish!  And as a personal preference, I hate when food gets cold too quickly, but the choice of dishware and freshness of the food kept everything hot!

Environment
It's very intimate seating, so bring a party or a friend!  The food is the main attraction of the restaurant, not the decor! Clean, average loudness, and the service was fantastic.

In short, if you like ramen, you'll love Mensho Tokyo!

excerpts: "  OK to be honest, actually I wrote down "shiyo" based on phonetics but now that I look at their menu online, they have $14 "organic shoyu ramen" and $9 "shio ramen
" so I'm not totally sure what we ordered.
Anyway, it was what thinner and what most people would probably recognize as "ramen."  Not as good as the others.

shio.author: Aaron M.
shio.review:
YUM - welcome Tokyo to SF!  Yes, this is the crazy thick broth ramen place that will change your life.  So do it.  Now I know you're going to order the tori paitan ramen which is their deservedly famous meaty dish with a chicken-ish broth, but let me also encourage you to order a couple other things:
- The vegan tantamen, which the chef recommended as his second choice, and which is an awesome, slightly nutty contrast with the tori paitan.  In fact, we kept alternating between the two because each one seemed to make the other one taste awesomer and each was awesome by itself.
- The oysters!  These had "shiyo oil" on them, which gave me flashback to the first time I had truffle oil: the first bite is a bit "unusual" or foreign, the second bite affirms that this foreign taste is actually good and fits in with other savory aromatic foods, and by the third bite you are ready to pay double the price just to have a little more.  Don't tell anyone but I actually licked the oil off the mini plate after the oysters were gone.  
- The Sansho beer, which is perhaps my favorite "herbal" beer ever - with a hint of Japanese peppercorn.  Disclosure: this beer is expensive as f*ck at over $1 per ounce.  Splurge and get two.

Out of curiosity we also ordered the $14 Shiyo ramen, which is listed on the receipt as "organic ramen."  OK to be honest, actually I wrote down "shiyo" based on phonetics but now that I look at their menu online, they have $14 "organic shoyu ramen" and $9 "shio ramen" so I'm not totally sure what we ordered.  Anyway, it was what thinner and what most people would probably recognize as "ramen."  Not as good as the others.  Still need to try the Shio... or Shoyu.

Definitely worth the weight in the end.

shio.author: Tori M.

It's a small restaurant that seats maybe 26 people inside. The ramen was good but not wait in line for two hours good. My boyfriend is Japanese and used to live in Japan and he said it tastes pretty similar to the ramen in Japan so that's good to know. I got the shio with double chasu and that went for $11. excerpts: The ramen was exquisite--I had the Tori Paitan, SO had the Shio.
She loved hers, the clear, flavorful broth won her over.
The Tori Paitan hit all the marks I have been reading about, creamy broth and excellent flavors.
Will be back.
shio.author: Colin S.
shio.review: Got lucky last night, after a Sketchfest event with Mike Judge and the King of the Hill cast at the Marines Memorial Theater, we walked over to check the line and it was only 2 parties deep.  Hopped in line, and before long we were seated.  Efficient service, we were slurping within ten minutes of sitting down.  The ramen was exquisite--I had the Tori Paitan, SO had the Shio.  She loved hers, the clear, flavorful broth won her over.  The Tori Paitan hit all the marks I have been reading about, creamy broth and excellent flavors.  Will be back.

excerpts: Not a fan of the little egg noodles they use in the shoyu and shio, and the Tori paitan broth  is way too much like gravy for me to slurp down to the last drop.
Vegan ramen all the way here.
shio.author: Michio F.
shio.review: I could see how people would not love the place on their first visit, but after three times.. I've got it down. Vegan tantanmen ramen with pork is the absolute best. Not a fan of the little egg noodles they use in the shoyu and shio, and the Tori paitan broth  is way too much like gravy for me to slurp down to the last drop. Vegan ramen all the way here.

excerpts: If you want a lighter soup, go for the Shio Ramen.
shio.author: Alex T.
shio.review:
I came here more than a dozen times already and I wanted to update my review.  

Their ramens, though expensive, is one of the best in the city.  Their soup base tends to be on the richer side, especially Tori Paitan.  If you want a lighter soup, go for the Shio Ramen.  Their noodles are pretty fresh and chewy, so no matter what you order, you can't go wrong.

Lines are usually pretty long especially during the weekends so the best time to go is before 7pm earlier during the work week where the lines tend to be the shortest.  If you are by yourself, your chances of jumping the lines are pretty high should they have a single spot open up.

Why 4 instead of 5 stars?  Sometimes service can be bad, but it has been steadily improving.  Also, $17.50-20+ is just a lot to pay for a ramen, even one as good as Mensho.

excerpts: Once seated we ordered the oysters, shio chashyu and tori paitan.
The oysters were good and helped ease our hunger pains while waiting for the ramen.
The ramen was amazing!
Shio was light and sharp with a flatter noodle.
The tori was creamy, rich and had a round thicker noodle.
They were both delicious and a nice compliment to each other.
shio.author: L L.
shio.review:
We arrived to a line and waited one hour. The shop is small, but the line moves pretty quick. Once seated we ordered the oysters, shio chashyu and tori paitan. The oysters were good and helped ease our hunger pains while waiting for the ramen. The ramen was amazing! Shio was light and sharp with a flatter noodle. The tori was creamy, rich and had a round thicker noodle. They were both delicious and a nice compliment to each other. I would recommend getting both if you come with a friend. 

We have had ramen from coast to coast in the US and this is hands down the best we've had so far! We will be back next time we are in the Bay Area.

excerpts: So next time I'll try the organic or shio ramen if muster enough patience to stand in line again.
shio.author: Yen T.
shio.review: We were second in line 50 minutes before opening time. Was it worth the wait? I think so. It is not like any other ramen I've tried. Pretty unique and I tried the creamy broth and it was super rich. So next time I'll try the organic or shio ramen if muster enough patience to stand in line again.

excerpts: Highly recommend the shio or shoyu.
The shio is very garlicky if you are into that because I totally am.
The paitan is good too but gets a little heavy after a few slurps.
shio.author: Michelle Y.
shio.review: A great ramen joint in SF, especially on a cold night.  We arrived on a Thursday at about 5:20pm and was seated by 6pm.  Not bad!  Highly recommend the shio or shoyu.  The shio is very garlicky if you are into that because I totally am.  The paitan is good too but gets a little heavy after a few slurps.

excerpts: The Shio Ramen was absolutely delicious.
The pork was unlike anything I've ever had.
One of the best meals in San Francisco without a doubt.
The line was worth the wait and the staff was super friendly.
I will definitely be back next time I'm in San Francisco.
shio.author: Lina M.
shio.review: The Shio Ramen was absolutely delicious. The pork was unlike anything I've ever had. One of the best meals in San Francisco without a doubt. The line was worth the wait and the staff was super friendly. I will definitely be back next time I'm in San Francisco.

excerpts: maybe I'll try the Shio next time.
shio.author: Fanny C.
shio.review: yum. Love ramen! Waited for about an hour for 2..  Got the Tori Paitan it is as described on the menu rich and creamy...the duck chashu was sooo juicy. The pork chashu just got lost in all the flavor. Wish there was a little more kale. All in all a good first impression just wish that the wait wasn't so long...maybe I'll try the Shio next time.

excerpts: After waiting over an hour in line on a beautiful sunday afternoon, I ordered 3 bowls of ramen: Tori Paitan, Organic Shoyu, and Shio, with extra duck in each.
The Tori was super rich and creamy.
It reminded me of my favorite ramen place in the world, Yume Wo Katare in MA Cambridge, except the bowl is way smaller, the soup less complex, and the noodle lacking in texture.
The organic shoyu was super one-dimensional and overwhelmingly salty.
If that is all I got after all this hype and wait, I'm disappointed.
The shio ramen was my favorite.
The flavor was there, not too salty with a hint a zest in the mix, but again, nothing stood out, no surprises, no kick, just a pretty girl with no personality.
I kept looking out the window looking at the beautiful sunset glow masking the dirty tenderloin street side, wishing I had made better use of my time.

excerpts: So if you're not really into rich broth, opt for the Shoyu or Shio ramen (Shoyu, imo, is less rich compared to Shio).
It was super delicious, comes with both duck and pork chashu
(my boyfriend opted to get double chashu), and the noodle is pretty thick with a nice chewiness.

I personally still like Orenchi and Ramen Dojo/Parlor better, but it's definitely in the top 5 (especially if the wait isn't as long and they have a more extensive menu).
I would come back again if the wait is under an hour, but overall, 5/5 in terms of food quality!
shio.author: Sharon L.
shio.review: After planning for weeks about the best time to come here, we finally decided to come here on a Tuesday evening at 5:15. There was (of course) already a line outside (presumably before they even opened). We waited around 45 minutes before being seated (party of 4), which was actually a lot faster than we expected. My boyfriend originally wanted to order Tonkotsu Ramen as it was one of the dish written on the wall, but apparently they're still doing a limited opening and Tonkotsu wasn't one of the dish we can order. We all opted to then get the Tori Paitan, which was what they're famous for. IMO the Tori Paitan is even more rich than Tonkotsu (it's basically a white thick chicken broth). So if you're not really into rich broth, opt for the Shoyu or Shio ramen (Shoyu, imo, is less rich compared to Shio). It was super delicious, comes with both duck and pork chashu (my boyfriend opted to get double chashu), and the noodle is pretty thick with a nice chewiness. One thing I hope they will add in the future would be an option for extra noodle. Is it the best ramen place in the bay? I personally still like Orenchi and Ramen Dojo/Parlor better, but it's definitely in the top 5 (especially if the wait isn't as long and they have a more extensive menu). I would come back again if the wait is under an hour, but overall, 5/5 in terms of food quality!

shio.author: Victoria S.
shio.review:
I like it. Do I love it? Nah.  We waited an hour in the line. I don't think this is worth a 2-3 hour wait. So for those of you thinking about it; just wait until the hype dies down and they've worked out the kinks. 

For two of us (we needed to make it worth our while to wait):

1.) tori paitan:  this was pretty tasty. Rich, without being too heavy. Garlic was yummy, but not overpowering. The pork and duck chasu were really good; not sure I would pay $2 or $1.50 for an small extra slice of either though. I liked the noodles in this one better than the other two.  I do think that overall, these aren't the best ramen noodles I've ever had. I like mine with more bite/chew to them. These noodles were maybe 1-2 mins too long. Also, towards the middle to the end of the bowl, I got a lot of residue/grit/something. I think they need to strain the broth a few more times to get rid of that stuff. It was a bad way to end the bowl. 

2.) shoyu: this was my favorite bowl of the three. It had a nice subtle sweetness and was flavorful. The soup gave my mouth a nice coat, but it wasn't fatty or greasy. But, as mentioned above, I didn't love the actual ramen noodles. Too soggy and they were different than the tori paitan noodles and not springy at all. 

3.) shio:  this was was also nice. Good, clean flavor. I like the garlic in this, also. I probably won't remember this one in a month. 

4.) oysters:  pass. I've had better smoked ones from Whole Foods. 

Service was good; they are trying really hard. 

I think they need to construct the table to be more stabilized. Every time some sat down and leaned on the table, it would knock the other end of the table. Could be hazardous with molten bowls of porky soup. 

The lines for this place tells me that SF is in dire need for some great, not good ramen.  Maybe we can send some of our good LA ramen juju up north.

excerpts: But their Shio-Chashu ramen was not what I expected.
The amount of katsuobushi (dried fish) in it was so great
I doubted whether they gave me the correct dish.
It was super-fishy, which isn't what I expect for the broth when it's supposed to be shio (salt).
I watched as the cooks were microwaving the noodles in the back.
Why?
The pork was refrigerated and not only cool, but it was COLD in my ramen.
The noodles themselves had very good mouthfeel.
But when the soup isn't correct, it's a big problem.
I walked by it the night before
and I believe the stories of greater than 1 hour wait.
I asked the people in line if they had been there before--not a single person had.
This may be emblematic for them.
I'm glad I went the next day near opening with no line.
This is my experience--I'm sure lots of other people had radically different experiences, but to say I was underwhelmed would be an understatement
and I ended up not eating more than half of it.
It wasn't bad, but it wasn't good, nor was it expected.
I don't know if there are better alternatives nearby, but I would have to assume there are.

shio.review: I lived in Japan for 5 years as a translator and have eaten good ramen. This would not be among them. I know my ramen and don't make the mistake of referring to one of their styles tonkatsu when it should be tonkotsu FWIW. Their front staff seem as though they all speak Japanese fluently or close to it, so that can be a good sign for a ramen restaurant. But their Shio-Chashu ramen was not what I expected. The amount of katsuobushi (dried fish) in it was so great I doubted whether they gave me the correct dish. It was super-fishy, which isn't what I expect for the broth when it's supposed to be shio (salt). I watched as the cooks were microwaving the noodles in the back. Why? The pork was refrigerated and not only cool, but it was COLD in my ramen. The noodles themselves had very good mouthfeel. But when the soup isn't correct, it's a big problem. I walked by it the night before and I believe the stories of greater than 1 hour wait. I asked the people in line if they had been there before--not a single person had. This may be emblematic for them. I'm glad I went the next day near opening with no line. This is my experience--I'm sure lots of other people had radically different experiences, but to say I was underwhelmed would be an understatement and I ended up not eating more than half of it. It wasn't bad, but it wasn't good, nor was it expected. I don't know if there are better alternatives nearby, but I would have to assume there are.

excerpts: The shio dashi was clean, with a perfect proportion of fat, and delicate noodles that were both toothsome and tender.
I look forward to the menu expansion and monthly specials to come.
Congratulations!!
shio.author: Irene T.
shio.review: GAME CHANGER!! Hands down, the best ramen ever. Food nirvana! The tori paiten dashi was umami on steroids, appropriately rich and flavorful. The shio dashi was clean, with a perfect proportion of fat, and delicate noodles that were both toothsome and tender. I look forward to the menu expansion and monthly specials to come. Congratulations!!

excerpts: We will definitely come back to try their shio and shoyu ramen.
By the way, the guy at the door, probably the owner and the staff were all very friendly and welcoming.
Good job!
shio.author: winnie l.
shio.review: We tried Mensho for the first time tonight, a week after they opened in SF.  We arrived at the restaurant around 4:30, half hour before they opened and we waited for about 2hrs before we got seated.  I thought it was crazy but it was worth it after we tried their ramen.  They only had two kinds of ramen tonight: Tori Paltanf and Vegan Tantanmen.  I appreciate them for trying to make sure everything is as good as it is in Japan and that's why they rather serve only 2 ramens tonight.  We tried both tonight and I love meat but to my surprise, I liked the vegan tantanmen better.  I thoughtful it was very flavorful and complex and the noodles were cooked perfectly with the right texture and chewiness.  The broth was very thick but it wasn't oily at all.  We will definitely come back to try their shio and shoyu ramen.  By the way, the guy at the door, probably the owner and the staff were all very friendly and welcoming.  Good job!

excerpts: They do have quite a few other options such as vegan tantanmen as well as some soupless noodles that I can't wait to try next time!
vegan tantanmen.author: Janice L.
vegan tantanmen.review:
Finally made it out to Mensho on a Wednesday evening and just missed the first wave to be seated.  The wait after that was about 40 minutes long as the restaurant is quite small. 

I ordered the tori paitan while my boyfriend ordered the shoyu. We also ordered the two appetizers: oysters and enoki chips. Both were tasty but the oysters were a bit too salty for me and so I enjoyed the enoki chips much more. I thought these were quite unique and tasted really good with a little lemon on top or even dipped into the ramen broth. As for the ramen, I found my tori paitan to be very flavorful and I loved the thick and toothsome noodles. While the frothy broth was interesting at first, I feel like this caused the ramen to cool down really quick, making it less tasty. My favorite part, however, was actually the duck chashu! Cooked perfectly- I wish I ordered more! The shoyu was quite good as well and I actually preferred the broth of the shoyu to the tori paitan. 

Overall it was a pretty good meal, a little pricey but not too extravagant. They do have quite a few other options such as vegan tantanmen as well as some soupless noodles that I can't wait to try next time!

excerpts:
Ramen bowls rated:

Spicy Tori Paitan - 5 stars, great flavor and seasoned appropriately
Vegan Tantanmen - 5 stars, also excellent flavor and seasoning. 
Matcha Tori Paitan - 3.5, flavor wasn't as deep as the other two bowls and needed more salt to the broth, although the broth was rich.
vegan tantanmen.author: Spencer W.
vegan tantanmen.review:
4.4 Stars if I could give. Also, not going to review anything about waiting in line only to the food and service.  The third thing you'll notice are the outstanding ramen noodles, very chewing and thick.  The first thing being presentation and second you'll probably take a sip of the soup.   Although those noodles are the star of the show IMO.  There is quite a bit of difference in flavor & saltiness depending on which type of soup you choose.  Ramen bowls rated:

Spicy Tori Paitan - 5 stars, great flavor and seasoned appropriately
Vegan Tantanmen - 5 stars, also excellent flavor and seasoning. 
Matcha Tori Paitan - 3.5, flavor wasn't as deep as the other two bowls and needed more salt to the broth, although the broth was rich.  

The table does have a pink salt grinder sitting there for anyone that would like to add more salt to their soup.  Their Shio ramen looks great as well as the fried enoki mushroom appetizer.   Will def. bring my dad here next time to try some other flavors.

excerpts: Others ordered the vegan tantanmen and the spicy tori paitan.
I added an egg to mine that honestly, you can probably skip.
vegan tantanmen.author: Lucy Z.
vegan tantanmen.review:
Overall, I'm very whatever about ramen. But that was before I met Mensho. I love Mensho. I don't love the cramped seating but if I'm gonna sweat while I eat, it might as well be over a bowl of Mensho ramen. 

Friends and I came at 5:45 on a Friday night and waited around 30-45 mins. Not too bad and the good company made the wait seem shorter ;) 

We each ordered a different bowl with me being basic and getting the tori paitan and someone getting the matcha. Others ordered the vegan tantanmen and the spicy tori paitan. I added an egg to mine that honestly, you can probably skip. But that's only because I didn't like a cold egg. 

The matcha was weird, not gonna lie. Mine was my favorite but the vegan one was also really really good. I'd just order that for the tantanmen and add chashu because you know, meat. 

All in all, totally worth the wait and I can't wait to revisit.

excerpts: All of my friends loved their dishes - the Tori Paitan Ramen,  the Vegan Tantanmen, Spicy Tori Paitan Ramen, Shoyu Ramen and A5 Wagyu.
vegan tantanmen.author: Katrine U.
vegan tantanmen.review:
Mensho Tokyo is my favorite ramen place in the bay area. That rich and creamy broth in their Tori Paitan is so delightful. I was instantly in love with their ramen, completely satisfied after finishing, and left wanting to come back for more! I have no more words to say but to try it for yourself! All of my friends loved their dishes - the Tori Paitan Ramen,  the Vegan Tantanmen, Spicy Tori Paitan Ramen, Shoyu Ramen and A5 Wagyu. Delicious!!!

Please come between 4:00-4:30, so that you're in the first group of 28 that is served at 5 PM!  It feels so much better getting seated and served first, so you get to skip having to wait in line and watch people eat their food. 

Thank you to Yoshi for the delectable food! I will always recommend this place and their great service.

excerpts: For the Vegan tantanmen, the broth was too salty for me to handle.
The chef was incredibly liberal with the salt in this dish.
The dish was thick and lacked a balance of flavors.
vegan tantanmen.author: Vivienne K.
vegan tantanmen.review:
The American child of Tokyo's famed Mensho ramen bar, the minimalistic, no-frills joint serves up innovative spins on traditional thick tonkotsu broth - tasty and satisfying indeed, yet too hyped for my tastes. It is good, but not wait 1.5hours good. 

The decor is simple, modern, and scientific - the science of molecular ramen.  The space is cozy - sitting around 20 people in short segments of time. 

For the Macca Tori Paitan - The broth was too heavy for my palate.  The Macca powder dispersed on top the ramen was great for show, but did not add much to the culinary experience as I consumed chunks of Matcha powder here and there - it did not blend well in the soup.  The chewiness of the noodle was fine, but the noodle width was a bit on the thick side. 

For the Organic Shoyu Ramen - The broth was too salty. Again, the chewiness of noodles fine - the noodles were flat and thin like Chinese style Wonton noodles.  It was a good, but not an amazing bowl of ramen that dreams are made of. 

For the Vegan tantanmen, the broth was too salty for me to handle. The chef was incredibly liberal with the salt in this dish.  The dish was thick and lacked a balance of flavors. I appreciate the use of mame, pea shorts and cilantro, but the vegetables were very much overshadowed by the thickness and saltiness. 

For the Aburasoba, I was quite actually pleasantly surprised!  This was my favorite ramen dish here. Certainly not the signature thick tonkotsu broth, but most certainly more well balanced, with chewier noodles in a delectable lighter sauce with a mix of Chashu, menma, green onion, and daikon sporouts.

excerpts: I knew I wanted to get the vegan tantanmen since I'm really a fan of really good vegetable ramen, and there are such few places that do a good job of bringing out the taste in vegan ramen.
The vegan tantanmen in my opinion is pretty rich in flavor, and the broth was very creamy.
I really enjoyed the seven herbs that they had in the dish, and the noodles were pretty good as well.
At the time of this writing, I would say that the vegan tantanmen here is the best ramen I've had in SF, and that isn't an exaggeration.
It appears that the vegan tantanmen is one of their top selling dishes, which honestly doesn't come as a surprise to me since it's pretty flavorful.
After tasting the ramen, I could see the reason why this place draws long lines even two years after it opened.
vegan tantanmen.author: Nelson X.
vegan tantanmen.review:
If I were to think about where I had the best ramen in SF, Mensho Tokyo would undoubtedly come up in my mind at the very top. It might even be more surprising that a vegetarian ramen convinced me that this was true. I came here with a friend on a Friday evening, waiting if I remember correctly at least an hour before we got to the front of the line. I knew I wanted to get the vegan tantanmen since I'm really a fan of really good vegetable ramen, and there are such few places that do a good job of bringing out the taste in vegan ramen.

The vegan tantanmen in my opinion is pretty rich in flavor, and the broth was very creamy. I really enjoyed the seven herbs that they had in the dish, and the noodles were pretty good as well. The dishes here are more expensive than your average SF ramen place, but if the prices reflect the quality of the ramen here, then the prices are well deserved.  

At the time of this writing, I would say that the vegan tantanmen here is the best ramen I've had in SF, and that isn't an exaggeration. It appears that the vegan tantanmen is one of their top selling dishes, which honestly doesn't come as a surprise to me since it's pretty flavorful. After tasting the ramen, I could see the reason why this place draws long lines even two years after it opened. What makes it even more amazing is that it's near the Tenderloin, and it's relatively out of the way for ramen. 

Mensho Tokyo is a solid five, and I hope they open up another store so there wouldn't be such long lines. I could see myself ordering the spicy lamb ramen or the clam ramen the next time I come back. Highly recommended to anyone who enjoys ramen and definitely worth the hour's wait in line.

excerpts: I got the Vegan Tantanmen and omg, the soup was amazing.
The right amount of sesame/peanuty flavor with the right amount of chili oil flavor.
I could not believe that this whole dish was vegan, it definitely made me feel a little better about putting on a couple pounds lol.
I would definitely go back again.
vegan tantanmen.author: Amanda C.
vegan tantanmen.review: I've heard about this place for a while and finally got to try it out. I got the Vegan Tantanmen and omg, the soup was amazing. The right amount of sesame/peanuty flavor with the right amount of chili oil flavor. I could not believe that this whole dish was vegan, it definitely made me feel a little better about putting on a couple pounds lol. I would definitely go back again.

excerpts: If you got vegan friends, say hello to their Vegan Tantanmen with made several types of mushrooms, nuts, chili oil, etc.
in premium Japanese soy cream.
You won't miss the real thing.
vegan tantanmen.author: Janice C.
vegan tantanmen.review:
Ramen it up.

People, the seasons have turned. We've said goodbye to our Indian summer in SF, so that means, pull out the chunky sweaters and scarves and head over to Mensho Tokyo in the 'Loin to warm up your soul with some incredibly rich ramen.

This is the first Japanese outpost outside of Tokyo and I loved that the owners chose SF. (why should NYC get all the cool places all the time?!) Years ago, I used to whine to my friends that I'll have to drive to San Mateo to get some fantastic ramen. But, now that we actually have choices, I can happily stay in SF and my friends don't have to hear my whining. 

First: YES. There is always a line. Come right when they open at 5pm or maybe closer to 11:30pm (but what if the soup runs out?) chances are, your wait will be less than an hour. There were 3 of us who waited around 530pm and got sat down in 20 mins. 

Second: it's all communal seating. Most are high tops where you will uncomfortably balance yourself. So, leave the kids with a babysitter and don't bring big groups. You will rub elbows with your neighbors. You won't have much space for your said purse/jacket/scarves, but there are baskets on the floor where you can store them, just like in Tokyo!

Third: get the Tori Paitan. Everyone talks about it, right? it's their signature bowl. At $16, you get rich and creamy chicken soup, pork chashu, duck chashu, menma, Kale, Burdock and katsuobushi sauce. I love duck and I love that they give you duck here. Double up and pay the extra $2 for another slice of MMMeat. If you got vegan friends, say hello to their Vegan Tantanmen with made several types of mushrooms, nuts, chili oil, etc. in premium Japanese soy cream. You won't miss the real thing. Trust. 

Fourth: the broth is like GRAVY. Is that groovy? if you think so (I think so!) then you'll love this place. If you prefer a lighter, cleaner taste, you won't like Mensho and you'll be pissed that you waited an hour in line for this sh*t. 

Fifth: just like in Tokyo, eat your ramen, don't linger and leave. People got things to see and places to go. Rye is next door and they make killer basil gimlets. You're welcome!

excerpts: Another friend ordered the vegan tantanmen as he is vegetarian, and he was blown away by how delicious and flavorful the ramen is.
vegan tantanmen.author: Dianna H.
vegan tantanmen.review:
Mensho's always a good time! Most recently, I came because I had heard about their new matcha tori paitan ramen and wanted to give that a shot.

I came right before they opened, around 4:45 on Wednesday, and there was only a handful of people in line. To be fair, it was a hot day--maybe 80 degrees--and only the most dedicated Mensho fans would even attempt ramen in that weather. The heat was definitely a barrier to enjoying the ramen; let's just say that I've been to Mensho many times but the lack of AC has never bothered me until this meal...

But was the matcha tori paitan worth it? YES it was! At $17 a bowl, it definitely doesn't come cheap, but I appreciated the subtle addition of the matcha to the already fabulous tori paitan ramen. Both my friend and I thought that the matcha flavor was very subtle and you had to stop and think about the flavors in your mouth to really taste it. Other than that, everything else about this dish is the same. The soup is still deliciously rich and creamy, the noodles thick and satisfying to chew, and the duck and pork chashu slices were perfectly tender. 

Also, I want to call out that they offer soft boiled eggs now! Unfortunately it's not included in the base ramen, so you have to fork out another $1.80 to add it, but it is completely worth it. I'm just really grateful that they've started offering it here, since for the longest time they didn't. I've had a lot of good ramen eggs before, but even then I think the one at Mensho is one of my favorites. It comes as a whole egg instead of sliced in half, and when you bite into it, you can see the perfectly partially cooked egg yolk inside. Plus it's marinated perfectly and that first bite of the marinated egg white and half cooked york is really memorable.

My friend and I also shared the poke soba ($18) as we were intrigued by the 10 bowl limit per day, but I would recommend skipping this. Because it was called poke soba, I thought all the proteins in the dish would be seafood, but for some reason there was also chashu in there. It ended up being a weird combination of warm and cold ingredients (the soba was also warm). Also we underestimated how full we'd be from the ramen. By the time we both finished with our tori paitan and were ready to start on the poke soba, we were already feeling pretty stuffed...

Another friend ordered the vegan tantanmen as he is vegetarian, and he was blown away by how delicious and flavorful the ramen is. I tried a sip and would highly recommend this even for non-vegetarians!

I know $17 for a bowl of ramen is really pricy, but I always end up coming back to Mensho time and time again for ramen. Definitely my fav spot in the bay area!

Lots of umami going on here.
Lots of toppings.
Certainly a good bowl of ramen

The broth was too creamy, too thick for my taste.
And I know it's weird to complain about spoons but quite honestly, their spoon was excessively large and made the eating experience a little difficult.
Imagine trying to eat soup but with a flat giant wooden paddle.
I'm sure it was more so for a
*wow/cool* factor.
Minor detail though.
I also wasn't feeling' the noodles either.
It made everything feel so thick.
However, I did think that both the pork and duck chashu were juicy, tender and generous in portion.

The soft egg was perfect.

Nice spicy kick to it.
I would actually recommend that over the Paitan, or if anything, perhaps the Spicy Tori Paitan would've been the better route.

We both ordered the vegan tantanmen which had a great thick broth that also had a crunch to it. It didn't seem very Japanese, but I wasn't really expecting it to be. I was surprised that it didn't really have many vegetables, but it's not the end of the world. We ordered enoki mushrooms chips that were mehhhhh. I feel like they're so skinny that you can't really taste the mushroom, and you're just eating breading. 

If I could change anything, I'd want to turn the music down a bit. Don't get me wrong - they were playing slappers and all my fav rap music from the 2000s, but I literally could not hear my boyfriend - and most of the two person seats are facing each other because of the communal style. vegan tantanmen.review: Definitely has a really good option for vegetarians! I ordered the Vegan Tantanmen with an egg. One of the richest soup base I've had in ramens but awesome to try! excerpts: I usually stay away from veggie bases, but I was surprised at how much I liked the Vegan Tantanmen!
The mushroom and kombu broth had so much umami, it was ridiculous.
The chili oil and nuts added a nice dimension.
This will be my next order if I revisit.
As for the meats, the pork chashu and duck chashu were tender, but forgettable for me.
I did like the hearty portion of ground lamb.
The noodles were good - nice chew and springy texture.
I enjoyed the Fried Enoki Mushroom appetizer.
It's a heavier amount of batter, but it crunches so pleasingly.
Enjoy with togarashi and lemon.
So was it worth the wait?
I thought so, though I'm not sure I would be so eager to wait again having experienced it once.
vegan tantanmen.author: Adrienne H.
vegan tantanmen.review:
Dinner with a lovely friend finally convinced me to wait out the 1+ hour line for Mensho Tokyo. We arrived at 7:45PM on a Wednesday and the line didn't look too bad, but the wait was still an hour. This line moves sloooow. Luckily I was with someone I enjoyed talking to past the time!
 
I tried three different broths - all in the creamy style. Mensho stands out for the thickness of their broth. It's not the thickest I've had - that was at Muteppou in Osaka (we are talking almost pudding), but it's the thickest I've tried in the states. 

I've come to realize thick broth is not my thing. I like rich flavors, but I don't want clam chowder texture when I'm eating noodles. Make sense?
 
Thickness aside, the broth flavors were great. My favorite was the Spicy Lamb, though it was way too salty and actually not that spicy. The flavor was unique for ramen - very peppery and heavily spiced.
 
The popular Tori Paitan was milder in flavor, with a very rich and creamy broth similar to Tonkatsu but not as 'meaty' in taste. If you like simplicity at its best, this is the way to go.
 
I usually stay away from veggie bases, but I was surprised at how much I liked the Vegan Tantanmen! The mushroom and kombu broth had so much umami, it was ridiculous. The chili oil and nuts added a nice dimension. This will be my next order if I revisit.
 
As for the meats, the pork chashu and duck chashu were tender, but forgettable for me. I did like the hearty portion of ground lamb. The noodles were good - nice chew and springy texture.
 
I enjoyed the Fried Enoki Mushroom appetizer. It's a heavier amount of batter, but it crunches so pleasingly. Enjoy with togarashi and lemon.
 
So was it worth the wait? I thought so, though I'm not sure I would be so eager to wait again having experienced it once.

vegan tantanmen.review:
TLDR: WORTH THE WAIT !!!!!!

IT'S DEFINITELY NOT JUST A HYPE!  Mensho Tokyo is by far the best ramen I've tasted anywhere.  No wonder they have a line out the door a hour before they even open.  Trust me, it's worth it though.

I haven't been to Japan yet but Mensho is a franchise that started in Tokyo so that counts for something.  This is their first location in San Francisco and their ramen is clearly on another level.  Their infamous tori paitan was absolutely breathtaking. I literally had to pause a second just to admire it for all its glory.  (Mind that, I'm usually one to devour my food in seconds)  I added duck meat and a soy sauce egg for toppings and I would highly recommend you to as well! 

Their vegan tantanmen and matcha ramen is next on my radar to try!  I'll probably need to strategically pick a day where I won't freeze waiting in line for a hour though.

excerpts: In addition to the tori paitan broth, Mensho also offers organic shoyu, shio, and a vegan tantanmen.

(But why come all the way out here, wait in an excruciatingly long line, and not get the best?)
vegan tantanmen.author: Jean S.
vegan tantanmen.review:
Wow! Best Ramen I've had! Mensho's Tori Paitan Ramen (double chashu) ($18) was super amazing and full of delicious umami flavor! The broth was very rich and creamy, but the flavors were SO tasty, I could not stop drinking. The noodles were cooked to a perfect texture, the bamboo shoots and kale were a nice touch, but what was the crown on top was the EXTREMELY TENDER and flavorful chashu. Both the pork chashu and duck chashu were out-of-this-world amazing! Definitely the best I've had in any ramen bowl. I only wish there were more pieces.  

In addition to the tori paitan broth, Mensho also offers organic shoyu, shio, and a vegan tantanmen. The shoyu and shio broths are lighter and not as creamy, which might be good for those looking for something not as heavy. (But why come all the way out here, wait in an excruciatingly long line, and not get the best?) I also tried the oysters in shoyu dare oil ($5), which were not bad. The menu states 4 pieces...they gave us 6, but they were very small and not plated very nicely. 

Mensho Tokyo is one of Japan's most acclaimed ramen bars, and this very location in SF's Tenderloin district, is their first international shop outside of Japan. This location has been open for over a year now, but the long wait is still there. I came late Saturday evening (10:15pm) trying to avoid the long line, but it wasn't late enough. I still had to wait 45 minutes (only!?) and didn't get seated till just after 11:00pm. (They close at 11:30pm and there were people being seated all the way to the end.) I hate long waits, but the tori paitan ramen was well worth the travel out and 45 minute wait. On a positive side note, the restaurant was clean, the bathroom was clean, and their food safety score is 100.

A creamy, rich edamame and soy-based ramen using several types of nuts in its broth delivered a FLAVOR bomb in my mouth!
vegan tantanmen.author: Rachel Ann C.
vegan tantanmen.review:
I'm not a big ramen person, nor am I a fan for waiting in line to be seated for the newest "hotspot," but as per my brothers' nagging me that Mensho Tokyo might turn my opinion on ramen around, I may have been convinced.

On a cold January night in San Francisco, as the night was ending and people were getting off of work, I decided to give this place my 30-45 minutes of time in line to try and see why people are loving this place. (I heard the wait can be up to an hour, but we got lucky by coming in around 8pm.)

The Vegan Tantanmen Ramen, as highly raved about and sounding DELICIOUS, immediately caught my eye. A creamy, rich edamame and soy-based ramen using several types of nuts in its broth delivered a FLAVOR bomb in my mouth! I've never had ramen so thick and creamy, with a slight spice to taste, and authentic preparation of noodles.

I love the concept of Mensho putting care into their dishes to produce quality-tasting ramen prepared in a very traditional way. The $18 price tag for a bowl is definitely worth a try (can be higher if you add extras to your dish) as the flavors are incredible. Consider this an upscale ramen spot giving you quality ramen and flavors. I could barely finish my bowl but I don't think I've ever had ramen taste that creamy or rich in my LIFE... Definitely something I can't have everyday or on the regular.

Service was prompt and friendly. Got our meals out in a reasonable time as they are very efficient at trying to seat you and rotate customers around. Mensho, I've gotta give it to you for providing thick, creamy, flavor bombs of ramen. You made this non-ramen fan actually appreciate ramen, and I think that says a lot!

vegan tantanmen.author: Nidhi M.
vegan tantanmen.review:
This was my second time at Mensho trying the Vegan Tantanmen. The wait on a Tuesday night was ~45 minutes, but totally worth the wait! This is definitely one of the best vegan ramen dishes I have tried. With an incredibly creamy broth and a blend of seven types of nuts, the flavor is unique to any other ramen I've had. Perfect level of spice to complement the richness of the soup. The toppings it came with were edamame, mushroom and bamboo shoots, which were delicious. The noodles soaked in the flavor of the soup well and were tastier than noodles of other vegan ramen dishes I've had. 

I also tried the fried mushroom chips which were delicious as well! Highly recommend to meat-lovers and vegetarians alike!

excerpts: The Vegan Tantanmen Ramen is indeed outstanding and every bit worth the wait and price of $18.
So creamy from the seven different types of nuts in the broth.
They sure do put deez to good use!
Great flavors come from the traditional techniques.
I did have to add some chili paste but it wasn't necessary.
Although I do wish there was a spicy option from the kitchen instead.
I finished my bowl and the rest of my wife's broth.
vegan tantanmen.author: John B.
vegan tantanmen.review:
I'm not normally the type to stand in line for an hour just to try the latest fad on the dining scene. Unless of course it's a hot new Vegan restaurant. That being said, SF Yelp Queen Cherylynn and new Vegan Eliteness Kelsey B. clued me into what just may be the city's best place to get a bowl of Vegan Ramen.

We came here around 8pm to celebrate our 5 monthiversary of gettin' hitched. We were plenty prepared for the wait since word is you need to get there early to avoid it.

One reason for the long wait is the food. The other is it's just not very big. The final reason are dickheads that sit around chatting it up and instafacesnapping for a long while after they finished their meal. Get on with it people!

The Vegan Tantanmen Ramen is indeed outstanding and every bit worth the wait and price of $18. So creamy from the seven different types of nuts in the broth. They sure do put deez to good use! Great flavors come from the traditional techniques. I did have to add some chili paste but it wasn't necessary. Although I do wish there was a spicy option from the kitchen instead. I finished my bowl and the rest of my wife's broth. I was considering putting this in our Contigo container to sip on the BART ride home, it was that good!

In fact their Vegan Ramen was so good that you don't even need to take my word for it. The entire group of people next to us ordered the same thing even though some of them added pork to it. The broth is just that delicious.

Our waitress was really sweet even though she was busy from table to table in this tiny restaurant.

While the line may be long, you don't have to worry about getting hungry. You might just lose your appetite watching a goat get skewered through the asshole along with whatever strange  and disgusting "cooking" shows they have showing on the TV. Aside from that and the inflated prices, this just may be the best Vegan Ramen in town. Then again, there isn't much competition.

excerpts: The only reason i really want to give it a 4/5 is their vegan tantanmen is very very good.
Otherwise if you are not vegetarian, it is not worth the hype or the money.
vegan tantanmen.author: Foodie A.
vegan tantanmen.review:
I would really love to give Mensho a 4 at least but

The tori paitan came with almost no meat! For $17!

Its not really a restaurant, it's a small room with two communal tables and you sit jam packed with strangers. Someone you sit across from strangers. Just not justifiable with the hefty price.

They do not allow to-go bowls? Why?? Each ramen bowl is at $16. I should have the freedom to do whatever I want with my food. I finished my meal but the stranger beside me barely ate hers and its goes straight to the trash. With the increasing amount of homeless people in SF, least one can do is pack up your food and offer it to someone graciously and respectfully. However Mensho does not even give its customers this possibility 

The only reason i really want to give it a 4/5 is their vegan tantanmen is very very good.
Otherwise if you are not vegetarian, it is not worth the hype or the money.

excerpts: I order the Vegan Tantanmen and enoki mushroom chips.
The mushroom chips were very greasy.
The vegan tantanmen has a medium spicy, smoky broth that was very thick.
The noodles were very chewy and nice, and they did add some vegetables, tofu, mushroom in the bowl, but the thickness of the broth was very overwhelming in taste.
I have friends who loves this type of ramen, but it's slightly too much for me.

vegan tantanmen.review:
Based on a friend's tip, we went there at 4:30 on a Sunday and waited for 30 minutes. I would definitely not go there by myself. Even though there is a crowd standing with you, it still doesn't feel super safe.

I order the Vegan Tantanmen and enoki mushroom chips. The mushroom chips were very greasy. It's what you would have expected, but it doesn't offer anything beyond "a bowl of fried mushrooms". 

The vegan tantanmen has a medium spicy, smoky broth that was very thick. The noodles were very chewy and nice, and they did add some vegetables, tofu, mushroom in the bowl, but the thickness of the broth was very overwhelming in taste. I have friends who loves this type of ramen, but it's slightly too much for me.

excerpts: If I do return, I would love to try the vegan tantanmen!
vegan tantanmen.author: Judy H.
vegan tantanmen.review:
After arriving at 5:15pm on a Saturday night, our group of 4 waited for 1 hr 20 min before being seated.  The space is super tight, but fortunately they have bamboo baskets beneath each table for bags (as many restaurants in Japan) 

We ordered the following:

Tori Paitan Classic- get this if it's your first time. The broth is super rich (you almost feel like you could start biting into it!) and flavorful.  The noodle was perfectly al dente.

Matcha Tori Paitan - basically the Classic version plus green tea powder on top.  You get a hint of green tea as a result - not overly so.  I do wonder if this might taste better if they used some kind of green tea noodle instead.   

clam ramen - this was probably our least favorite one.  It turned out to be some kind of seafood combo.  It wasn't bad.  It simple paled in comparison to the Tori Paitan Classic.

soy-marinated oysters - served cold.  I think I had expected a warm dish.  As a result, I was somewhat disappointed and thought this was just OK. 

This place deserves the hype.  However, I am not sure I would return again unless the wait is less than half an hour. If I do return, I would love to try the vegan tantanmen!

excerpts: While my mom ordered the vegan tantanmen (due to the "great" reviews about it).
My ramen was SUPER rich, almost painfully rich.
The broth is like a gravy, that's very deep in flavor; plus the duck and lamb meat adds to the richness.
I'm not use to a thick broth, so it was indeed an "experience" eating it.
You better be starving before you eat this ramen or you won't be able to finish it; or you might, who knows.
However, my mom was extremely disappointed with her ramen.
She said that the flavor was very bland and had a very odd taste to it.
Even though we are not vegans/vegetarians, some of our all time favorite restaurants are vegan.
After reading all the hype about this ramen, she wanted to give it a try; let's just say, we will be more skeptical about choosing items from yelp reviews.
Overall, it was descent at best; honestly I'd rather give this a 2.5 stars out of 5.
I will admit that the ramen is indeed unique but nothing amazing; nothing that will ever make me dream about it.
I don't think I'll ever come back here, just because the location is far
and I'm sure I can find better ramen places.
But I suppose if you live in the area, it might be worth to go back from time to time...maybe.
vegan tantanmen.author: Audriana S.
vegan tantanmen.review:
I was looking for a unique ramen place, since one of my favorites has been closed for awhile now. So I stumbled upon this place on yelp and decided to give it a try. Just like many others have mentioned, you do want to come at least 30 minutes early before opening. I came here with my mom and we were about the 10th person in line at 4:30pm. About 5 minutes later, the line extended so far!
I was not aware of how tight and uncomfortable the seating and environment was. The stools felt very unstable and you're pretty much shoulder to shoulder with those next to you. However, I do have to say that the waitresses are very kind and give you tips on how to eat your ramen and what drinks pair well with it. And since you are sitting so close to people, you tend to get comfortable and familiar with them; at least for me it felt like that.
In terms of drinks, we had 2 glasses of plum wine and that was probably the only good thing about the meal. On to the food, I ordered the spicy lamb chashu ramen that had duck and lamb, that was in a thick, rich lamb gravy. While my mom ordered the vegan tantanmen (due to the "great" reviews about it). My ramen was SUPER rich, almost painfully rich. The broth is like a gravy, that's very deep in flavor; plus the duck and lamb meat adds to the richness. I'm not use to a thick broth, so it was indeed an "experience" eating it. You better be starving before you eat this ramen or you won't be able to finish it; or you might, who knows. However, my mom was extremely disappointed with her ramen. She said that the flavor was very bland and had a very odd taste to it. Even though we are not vegans/vegetarians, some of our all time favorite restaurants are vegan. After reading all the hype about this ramen, she wanted to give it a try; let's just say, we will be more skeptical about choosing items from yelp reviews.
Overall, it was descent at best; honestly I'd rather give this a 2.5 stars out of 5. I will admit that the ramen is indeed unique but nothing amazing; nothing that will ever make me dream about it. I don't think I'll ever come back here, just because the location is far and I'm sure I can find better ramen places. But I suppose if you live in the area, it might be worth to go back from time to time...maybe.

excerpts: Vegan Tantanmen - Extremely creamy.
I'm not even exaggerating.
Extra rich, and flavorful.
Maybe a little too much for my taste
, it was just a little overpowering.
I wished it was spicier, but even with extra spice, the creaminess washed it out.
vegan tantanmen.author: Yannie S.
vegan tantanmen.review:
The line is ridiculous, even before opening! Luckily, the wait isn't all that bad if you're willing and really have time to kill. We got there before opening and started at the back of the time, probably wait about 30-45mins. My thought always has been that you should never have to wait that long for ramen. NEVER. However, it was a MUST for the group so I had to just believe the hype.

I was a little turned off when I saw that the vegetarian option was double the price of the regular pork. Yeah, it's pretty expensive being a non meater. It's pretty insane actually. I guess because it was the vegan afterall.

Vegan Tantanmen - Extremely creamy. I'm not even exaggerating. Extra rich, and flavorful. Maybe a little too much for my taste, it was just a little overpowering. I wished it was spicier, but even with extra spice, the creaminess washed it out. The noodles were cooked to perfection, there is no doubt their other options would have been enjoyable too.

I would definitely recommend this shop to any ramen lovers out there. I might be back but who knows!

excerpts: My wife got the vegan tantanmen and it was scrumptious.
vegan tantanmen.author: Jesse B.
vegan tantanmen.review: Holy moly. What a place. Hole in the wall with a line around the corner. Incredibly good ramen. Huge portions, excellent service and interesting communal seating. I ordered the matcha ramen and it was to die for.  My wife got the vegan tantanmen and it was scrumptious.

excerpts: Both servers working there suggested the Vegan Tantanmen!
Shocked but intrigued, I ordered it and added chashu.
It was amazing.
vegan tantanmen.author: Leana L.
vegan tantanmen.review:
After being at the bar across the street, birthday girl wanted Mensho ramen, so off to Mensho we went. We waited in line, and with a fun group, the line goes decently fast. We went in as groups of two to get seated faster and it just lucked out for us that we got to sit next to each other anyways!

Upon sitting down, we asked the server for recommendations. Both servers working there suggested the Vegan Tantanmen! Shocked but intrigued, I ordered it and added chashu. It was amazing. I tried a bit of the Tori Paitan (their signature dish), but it was too rich for me. I'm glad I got the vegan option!

excerpts: Mensho Tokyo delivers on both accounts with its vegan tantanmen.
Rich, deep flavors in the broth suit the noodles perfectly and offer vegetarians and vegans a substantial dish that can go up against its meat counterparts any day.
vegan tantanmen.author: Lakshmi M.
vegan tantanmen.review:
Being vegetarian, I feel like I'm almost on an endless quest to find good vegetarian broth that has both flavor and substance. Mensho Tokyo delivers on both accounts with its vegan tantanmen. Rich, deep flavors in the broth suit the noodles perfectly and offer vegetarians and vegans a substantial dish that can go up against its meat counterparts any day. I do have to admit that the vegan option is somewhat pricey, but considering I've been back roughly 5 times, I'd say that it's worth it.

The reviews about the lines are completely true. I would get there around 4:30 pm to line up if you want to avoid the dinner rush. If you don't mind a long wait (1-2 hrs) past 5:00 pm, you can definitely go later.

excerpts: I had Tori Paitan and my wife who is vegetarian l, had the Vegan Tantanmen.
Both were extremely good, very rich and flavorful broth, and tender pork chashu in the Paitan.
We waited for an hour in line, but forgot about that the moment we had the first taste of the ramen.
Definitely going back for my next Ramen craving :)
vegan tantanmen.author: Rohit N.
vegan tantanmen.review: Easily one of the best Ramens I have ever had; and this includes Ramen in Japan. I had Tori Paitan and my wife who is vegetarian l, had the Vegan Tantanmen. Both were extremely good, very rich and flavorful broth, and tender pork chashu in the Paitan. We waited for an hour in line, but forgot about that the moment we had the first taste of the ramen. Definitely going back for my next Ramen craving :)

excerpts: This is the first ramen place I have ever been to the vegan tantanmen albeit expensive is worth every penny.
If you are vegan, vegetarian or
even an
omnivore you will enjoy this dish.
Wait might be a bit long and there is always a line outside, service is good and fast.
The enoki mushroom chips are a must have!
Don't forget to squeeze the lemon juice on it (it makes a huge difference).
vegan tantanmen.author: Raymond H.
vegan tantanmen.review: This is the first ramen place I have ever been to the vegan tantanmen albeit expensive is worth every penny. If you are vegan, vegetarian or even an omnivore you will enjoy this dish. Wait might be a bit long and there is always a line outside, service is good and fast.
