excerpts: Anyway, had the Tori Paitan ramen and the Vegan Tantanmen.
-Tori
Paitan:
Deep chicken broth flavor.
Very creamy and filling.
I think I heard it described as a chicken soup for rich people.
I may be able to buy into this description.
For our patience in line, we got an extra chashu (which is not the best anyway).
Noodles were very enjoyable, al dente, and on point.
However, the broth just didn't do it for me.
-Vegan tantanmen:
Surprisingly, I will have to rate this above the tori paitan.
The flavor is fuller and more complex.
It has almost a nutty quality to it, so if you don't like nuts, would not suggest this one.
But it was always very creamy and filly of a broth.
vegan tantanmen.author: Edward L.
vegan tantanmen.review:
Had high hopes for this place. Maybe too high.

As with most ramen places, you expect to wait in line. You can either wait in line later, or you can wait in line before it opens. We chose the latter. We got there at 430pm, expecting to wait 30 minutes for the 5pm opening. Luckily, there was only 1 person ahead of us. Was able to walk down the street grab a cup of coffee from Starbucks and return without any problems.

Come 5 pm, window shades open. Pristine, small, clean dining room with the kitchen in the back. You could just anticipate a good ramen experience. Appeared it was well-staffed. Unfortunately, no one opened the door, as everyone just peered through the window, watching the staff working on the computer system.... Wait 5 minutes, nothing. Wait 10 minutes, nothing. Wait 30 minutes, finally, the head hostess comes out.

"Sorry, but our system is not accepting credit card. We can only accept cash. Please go to an ATM." Are you kidding me? I think cash-only establishments are OK, and I have no problem with this. But really? It took you 30 minutes to let us know this? Of course, all of us in line have been waiting and waiting, so we all make a dash to the nearest ATM. I think it makes more sense to let us know at the very beginning there was issues, so while we inevitably wait more in line, we can go get some cash......... amiright?

Further insult to injury. we didn't get seated for another 15 minutes... So really, 45 minutes after "opening." It doesn't make common sense.

Anyway, had the Tori Paitan ramen and the Vegan Tantanmen.
-Tori Paitan: Deep chicken broth flavor. Very creamy and filling. I think I heard it described as a chicken soup for rich people. I may be able to buy into this description. For our patience in line, we got an extra chashu (which is not the best anyway). Noodles were very enjoyable, al dente, and on point. However, the broth just didn't do it for me.
-Vegan tantanmen: Surprisingly, I will have to rate this above the tori paitan. The flavor is fuller and more complex. It has almost a nutty quality to it, so if you don't like nuts, would not suggest this one. But it was always very creamy and filly of a broth. Noodles the same. 

Unfortunately, given the late start and unreasonable wait without explanation (and even with an explanation, still does not explain make us wait beyond the opening time), I have to rate an overall 2 stars. Service while seated is great, but the compilation of average ramen and initial impression once we got there, has left a bad taste in my mouth.

excerpts: I ordered the vegan tantanmen, which seems like the most popular choice.
It was also the most expensive one too - $18.
The soup is made with many exotic ingredients and nuts.
I think the flavor was there but not the substance.
I felt like there were so many other things going on - with the konbu, mushrooms, kale sprouts, etc, etc, but not enough ramen!!
vegan tantanmen.author: Wendy F.
vegan tantanmen.review:
Tasty ramen and fast service (once you are inside), but in my opinion this place is overhyped! 

I've heard so many great things about this place, that it's one of the best ramen shops in SF.

I came with a friend on a Friday night around 5pm. We waited in line for 20 minutes, which was a short wait compare to how long my friends had to wait (about 1-1.5hr).

The shop is very small, and can seat 25 people MAX. There are 2 long tables, and you will have to share space with strangers. There is very little wiggle room, and with everyone talking, it's hard to hear each other even across the table. 

I ordered the vegan tantanmen, which seems like the most popular choice. It was also the most expensive one too - $18. The soup is made with many exotic ingredients and nuts. I think the flavor was there but not the substance. I felt like there were so many other things going on - with the konbu, mushrooms, kale sprouts, etc, etc, but not enough ramen!! It's suppose to be a ramen shop. 

Also again, with there being so little personal space and loud background noise, it was hard to really enjoy something tasty. I also think I paid too much for this.

excerpts: There are three other ramen bowls on the menu - organic shoyu, shio, and vegan tantanmen, as well as a selection of mazesoba bowls.
vegan tantanmen.author: Ed U.
vegan tantanmen.review:
The advance hype on this place was off the charts, and the breathless texting and taxing anticipation from the hipsterati of self-proclaimed ramen connoisseurs has been quite deafening. A two-plus-hour wait for an $18 bowl of ramen sounds like a Louis C.K. joke about San Francisco millennials with no punchline. I got exhausted thinking about the hoops I'd have to jump through to get a taste of the broth here. However, now that at least six weeks have elapsed since the grand opening in February, I had an opening that I couldn't bypass, the Thursday before Good Friday when I got off work early.

Everyone says to be there at 4PM even though they don't open until an hour later, and so I did. If you don't count the screeching homeless woman who kept sauntering by, no one else showed up until around 4:35PM. That's not to say the staff was indifferent to my presence as they thanked me for coming and waiting patiently. Eventually a line did start to form and rather quickly. I got seated at the front counter promptly at 5PM where I had a nice view of the kitchen where activity was bustling behind he coffee beakers with the broth at full boil and the pork and duck chashu being meticulously sliced. I was sitting with a Filipino family who could barely contain their enthusiasm over the forthcoming noodlefest.

I was feeling the same way and knew what to order since I had well over an hour to decide. I started with their one and only appetizer, the $5 Oysters in Shoyu Dare Oil. There were four of them completely shelled and marinated (photo: http://bit.ly/1Vp0sEV). Tasty freshness gone too soon, but the main event was about to occur. It was the $18 Tori Paitan Ramen with Double Pork Chashu, and I had them add an extra couple of Duck Chashu slices for $1.50 extra because why not go to town? The noodles were perfectly al dente, and the chashu was meaty without being overwhelming. Slices of menma, kale and burdock floated on top with a katsuobushi (bonito) sauce spooned on top (photo: http://bit.ly/224L6pv).

However, for all the fresh ingredients, it was that rich paitan chicken broth that lingers not only on the palate but in my sense-memory. Just the natural creaminess of it was amazing, and what really makes this bowl of ramen stand out against the others. There are three other ramen bowls on the menu - organic shoyu, shio, and vegan tantanmen, as well as a selection of mazesoba bowls. I was timid and just had a $4.75 bottle of Sapporo Premium to wash it all down (photo: http://bit.ly/1RTN9dq), but they have pricier Japanese artisan beers which they strongly recommended to me for the next time. And there will be a next time even as I saw the line go down the block as I departed.

FOOD - 5 stars...best paitan ramen broth ever, period
AMBIANCE - 4.5 stars...clean, white and you only wish it was triple the size to make the line move faster
SERVICE - 5 stars...lovely people work here
TOTAL - 5 stars...not just for self-proclaimed ramen connoisseurs...be patient or come near closing

excerpts: So the four categories are: tori paitan (most ordered based on pictures and reviews), shoyu (what I ordered), shio, and vegan tantanmen.
vegan tantanmen.author: Catherine W.
vegan tantanmen.review:
The short: organic shoyu ramen hits the spot

If you're not one of the first in line, be prepared to wait about an hour. This place seats about 30 people max, with 2 very long tables, and some seats facing the kitchen. Also be prepared for sitting at a communal table. Some people don't like this...? I don't mind, as long as I have elbow room and have good food!

While in line, we checked out the menu and had a face palm moment when I realized that the description described the items below. Basically, the items below the header start with the basic bowl, and increase in price for additional items. So the four categories are: tori paitan (most ordered based on pictures and reviews), shoyu (what I ordered), shio, and vegan tantanmen.

When the shoyu ramen arrived, I quickly dug in because I was so hungry. The duck chasu and pork chasu was tender, perfectly cooked, and enhanced the broth (wishing there were doubles of each!). Even the kale was an unusual, but nice addition. The broth was perfect, not salty or oily. And the noodles were chewy! At first, it doesn't look like there's a lot of noodles, but the bowl is shaped quite deeply at the bottom, so all the noodles are hidden there. There was so much I liked about this ramen. 

I couldn't figure out what the seasonings on the table were, though there was pink himalayan salt, and maybe some other seasonings to personally enhance the broth to the right taste. I didn't need to as I liked it the way it was.

The waiter was very kind and smiling, which is something I don't see too often. All the seating is on stools, and there are baskets on the ground for bags. The whole inside has a clean and modern aesthetic, with a living wall at the entrance, descriptions of the different types of ramen, and a view into the kitchen. So exciting!

One downside is that this isn't a place to sit and chat after you've eaten the food. Somebody will kindly let you know that there are other patrons outside who are waiting.

It's hard to say if I would wait in line for another hour, but I would come back to arrive right around opening so I don't have to wait so long. Thanks for the experience Mensho!

excerpts: I can't wait to try the vegan tantanmen,
vegan tantanmen.author: Caye Q.
vegan tantanmen.review:
As a Bay Area native I'm used to waiting in line for good food but lining up like you did in grade school, single file is another thing! The question is whether or not Mensho Tokyo is worth this process, well is it? The answer is YES. 

The long awaited Mesho Tokyo has lived up to the hype - the ramen is hella good. I ordered the Tori Paitan - rich, creamy chicken broth which is more like gravy. Thick, savory and packed with flavor. The noodles are thick and just the right texture. The chashu....ahhh, yes, PORK AND DUCK! So tender it melts in your mouth. Their ramen is a little bit hipster with substituting kale instead of seaweed which works but (insert sad face) NO EGG!! Nonetheless the ramen is one of the better joints in the Bay. I can't wait to try the vegan tantanmen, thats if I can ever find time to wait in that damn line.

ps Don't bother with the oyster appetizer, it was meh. Save your appetite for the ramen.

*sad pouty lip*

(4) Vegan Tantanmen
vegan tantanmen.author: Cherylynn N.
vegan tantanmen.review:
4.5 STARS

San Franciscans love shiny new places (and things). 

When it comes to the hottest new restaurant and food trends, many of us spare no expense with our paycheck (and time).

Last year, it was $8 for toast. Ok, not just "toast" but phuckin' bougie, tweezified toast. 

This year, it's $15 coffee (for one cup!) and $18 ramen.

Because, San Francisco! 

Next year, I'm bracing myself for $100 pizza. Oh wait, we already had that during the super bowl (well, I didn't but it was available at Tony's Pizza Napoletana). 

Seriously, what's next? 

Kindly let me know so I can start harvesting my eggs to sell! 

$18 ramen may sound crazy but people waited 3+ hours for this ramen on opening night! 

$18 for a taste of Tokyo? Why not! 

Mensho's first U.S. location is one of the most, if not the most highly anticipated restaurant opening this year in SF! 

Tip: Come at 4 pm (earlier on the weekends) or after 10 pm to avoid long wait times. 

Currently, Mensho has 4 ramen options available ($9-$18) with a single or double chashu option. When the owner returns from Japan in March, their menu will expand. No housemade noodles yet. They have a noodle machine but are awaiting permit(s) to use it (same for the tonkotsu equipment). Disappointingly no marinated soft boiled egg is available but maybe in the future? Beer only; no sake, soda, or juice.

My friend and I ordered three bowls of ramen to share:

(1) Tori Paitan: Rich, creamy chicken soup, pork chashu, duck chashu, menma, kale, burdock, katsuobushi sauce | double chashu $18
http://bit.ly/1XrzETT

Our favorite of the three, the kotteri broth was deliciously creamy (gravy-like) and richly satisfying. It had great depth of umami flavor but did get a bit gritty mid-way. The al-dente noodles were thick, springy, and had a fantastic toothsome chew. 

The chashu is sublime so pony up the extra $ and double up on it! The pork chashu is melt-in-your-mouth tender, like pork butter. It's so ridiculously tender, it falls apart when you pick it up. The duck chashu is silky smooth and chews effortlessly.

The only other ramen shop that offers Tori Paitan is Nojo Ramen Tavern (that I'm aware of). I tried Nojo's last night and there's absolutely no comparison. Mensho's is infinitely superior. 

(2) Organic Shoyu: Organic chicken + pork soup, shoyu dare, pork chashu, duck chashu, kale, kale sprouts, chives, menma, nori | double chashu $16
http://bit.ly/1QfmuKm

A much lighter assari broth but saltier with a slight sweetness since it's a soy sauce based. The duo of chashu were perfection just like in the Tori Paitan ramen. I didn't like the noodles which were overcooked, flat, and lacked chew. 

(3) Shio: Organic chicken + pork soup, shio dare, pork chashu, kale, menma, chives, fried garlic, nori | double chashu $11
http://bit.ly/1Loeijq

The most affordable bowl available, the shio ramen was simple and pure. The assari broth was light and salty but still had depth. Same delicious chashu as the other bowls but the noodles were disappointing like the shoyu ramen. In this bowl, not only were the noodles overcooked, there were two clumps. *sad pouty lip*

(4) Vegan Tantanmen | $18
I'm kicking myself for NOT ordering this too because I love nuts! The broth contains soy cream and 7 kinds of nuts, producing a creamy kotteri broth that looked similar to the Tori Paitan.

I washed everything down with a Sansho beer ($11.75): http://bit.ly/1Px6vnx. Beer usually tastes like carbonated piss to me but this one was refreshing with a gingery lemon spice. Loved it but not the price. 

Service is a work in progress which is understandable since this is Mensho's first foray in the U.S.. They only let 8 or so customers in at a time to not overwhelm the kitchen. They don't fire up orders by tickets, instead they prepare the ramen by type (they really should do the former). We received our order at different times and after people who ordered after us. If your companion(s) orders different ramen than yourself, be prepared to start eating first before the noodles get soggy. 

When I was line I met one of the restaurant partners, Abram aka Ramen Beast. He was uber nice and offered to answer any questions I had. Really cool guy! 

The space is small and only seats 28 - two communal tables and four seats at the counter. We choose to sit at the counter. There's more privacy (if you're on a date) and you can watch the chefs in action.

Read all signs before parking. Do NOT park on Geary from 4-6 pm (tow-away zone) on the weekdays, otherwise your $18 bowl of ramen will turn into a $618+ bowl of ramen. 

Because, San Francisco!

excerpts: Vegan Tantanmen - http://tinyurl.com/h29wb6x
vegan tantanmen.author: Lily L.
vegan tantanmen.review:
Unique and delicious ramen that is well worth the wait. I went here on a Thursday night around 10:00pm and was seated in about 1 hour (for a party of 2). When we left the restaurant, the line was just as long as when we first got there.  I liked the ramen here so much that I came back again the next day. 

Tori Paitan - http://tinyurl.com/zmhmezu
Amazingly thick and rich broth that has a strong chicken flavor. The first couple bites of this ramen is just heavenly. Then the richness gets to be a bit too much after a while. I could barely finish my bowl! The ramen came with two thin slices of pork chashu and duck chashu. The pork slices were very tender and the duck was cooked closer to medium than well - which is unusual for asian cuisine. The main flavor in both types of meat was the meat itself, not the typical chashu flavor. The burdock roots were thinly crispy and thinly sliced, which really added to the texture of the whole dish. The noodles were thick and average in terms of taste. I really liked this ramen as a whole. I felt kind of bad after finishing it because it was overwhelmingly rich and fatty. 

Vegan Tantanmen - http://tinyurl.com/h29wb6x
Overall, I liked this ramen more than the Tori Paitan. It still had a rich broth, but not so overwhelmingly rich that it made me feel bad after finishing it. The broth tasted like a combination of peanuts and sesame. There were a couple drops of spicy chili oil in the soup was only slightly spicy.

Oysters in Dare Shoyu Sauce - http://tinyurl.com/ztsb6kt
This is the only appetizer here. I don't eat oysters often and I've never had it cooked so this was a completely new dish to me. The order came with 6 pieces of oysters even though the menu says it's supposed to be 3 pieces. The oysters were well braised and topped with chives. (The 2nd time I came back, I saw an order of oysters topped with sprouts instead of chives so they probably change up the toppings). Taste wise, it kind of reminded me of chicken gizzard or heart. I wasn't super in love with this dish but I'm pretty sure that's just because I'm not a huge fan of oysters.

You can ask for a side of chili oil if you want to add some spice to your ramen. I really liked this place and will definitely come back again to try their new menu items!

excerpts: The Dish: I opted for the popular vegan tantanmen given that it's my first time.
The verdict....best tantanmen I've ever had in my life.
But it's definitely not the best bowl of ramen I've ever had in the states.
The best ones in the states are still NYC's Ippudo and SD's Menya Ultra
(an absolute must try if you're in SoCal).
vegan tantanmen.author: Audrey W.
vegan tantanmen.review:
The Line: Came here 15 minutes before opening on a Tuesday and got seated in the first seating. I sat at the bar facing the kitchen. On Tuesday's and Wednesday's, you can probably get here a little after 5 and still get seated right away if you come alone.

The Service: Not bad. Very attentive but not super pushy. They serve fast and give you the check when they see you're almost done. But I never felt pushed. With that said, the restaurant is cramped and hot that I wouldn't linger for too long anyway.

The Drink: I opted to pay $4.75 for a Sapporo bottled beer. Would I have ordered it on its own? Absolutely no. With ramen? Heck yah. Trust me, it'll help wash down the super rich soup.

The Dish: I opted for the popular vegan tantanmen given that it's my first time. The verdict....best tantanmen I've ever had in my life. But it's definitely not the best bowl of ramen I've ever had in the states. The best ones in the states are still NYC's Ippudo and SD's Menya Ultra (an absolute must try if you're in SoCal). I may come back and try their regular ramen Tori Paitan.

Finally, would I wait 1.5 hrs for this bowl of ramen? No. I'll wait max 15 minutes.

excerpts: She said the Tori Paitan and Vegan Tantanmen.
My friend and I decided to try both.
They were amazing!
The tori paitan was rich and delicious.
The Vegan tantanmen was spicy in all the right ways.
Everything about it was just right.
vegan tantanmen.author: Veronica L.
vegan tantanmen.review:
I've eaten a fair share of ramen in the bay area. I even waited in a relatively short (in comparison) two hour line at that crazy ramen festival.. and this is hands down the best ramen I've had. 

Yes i still had to wait in a line but still it was only about 30 minutes long and the weather was nice and I had great company so the line flew by.  It helps that Mensho is an organized and well run establishment. I appreciate their efficiency in getting people in and out without feeling overly rushed. 

The place is pretty small but they use every little bit of it with community seating. The menu is simple with few choices which I love. I assume their limited menu means they put a lot more thought into the few things they make. 

I asked the waitress what was most popular. She said the Tori Paitan and Vegan Tantanmen. My friend and I decided to try both. They were amazing! The tori paitan was rich and delicious. The Vegan tantanmen was spicy in all the right ways. Everything about it was just right. It even came with a giant spoon to make the event a little more delightful. 

I really want to go again but I also really don't want to stand in line.

excerpts: Vegan tantanmen had amazing depth of flavor, even better than the broth in the tori paitan.
Chashu in the tori paitan was probably some of the best I've ever had.
vegan tantanmen.author: Dinah V.
vegan tantanmen.review:
Four stars for the food but overall experience was closer to three stars. Came 25 minutes before open on Sunday, was the first batch of people seated, and received ramen around 5:30. Vegan tantanmen had amazing depth of flavor, even better than the broth in the tori paitan. Chashu in the tori paitan was probably some of the best I've ever had. Only critique is that the noodles are pretty thick and air on the side of being too dense/chewy. 

Cons: very loud edm made it hard to carry on a conversation, tall bar stools were uncomfortable to sit on, very very close proximity to other people so it was awkward getting food before them (in your peripheral they'd stare and watch you try it) and people waiting in line outside kept gazing around inside waiting to get seated 

Don't get me wrong, this is really solid ramen with excellent depth of flavor. But everything else made this experience very strange. I'm glad I tried it but I wouldn't go out of my way to eat here again.

excerpts: The food: I ordered the vegan tantanmen, and it was very spicy and delicious.
vegan tantanmen.author: Kylie B.
vegan tantanmen.review:
The food: I ordered the vegan tantanmen, and it was very spicy and delicious. I would have liked to have more than one vegan option (maybe a miso based one? :-)   ) , but I loved that my friend (not a vegan) and I were both able to eat something that we enjoyed! 

The service/venue: The service was pretty good. While we did have to wait in line for about an hour to sit down (the place is pretty small, can only fit about 20 customers at a time), the waitresses had an efficient seating process and we were able to order, get our food, and pay fairly quickly. Note: they do apply a 15% tip automatically, and there wasn't an option to tip more (at least when paying with a card).

I would definitely recommend eating here, though definitely show up early to wait in line.

excerpts: I got the signature ramen tori paitan and my friend ordered the vegan tantanmen.
The noodles were a great consistency but the broth was way too creamy and heavy for my palette.
It was also on the salty side.
The pork chashu was a highlight and melted in my mouth!
We also ordered the enoki chips which were fun but very greasy.
Overall fun experience and glad
we came but the ramen was just average and isn't justified by the long wait.
vegan tantanmen.author: Yin H.
vegan tantanmen.review: Mensho was good but didn't live up to my expectations and the hype. We got here around 6 on a cold Friday night. The line didn't look long at all but then we realized the restaurant was tiny!! We waited about 45 min before being seated. The waitress had already taken our orders while we were in line. Our orders came out pretty quickly. I got the signature ramen tori paitan and my friend ordered the vegan tantanmen. The noodles were a great consistency but the broth was way too creamy and heavy for my palette. It was also on the salty side. The pork chashu was a highlight and melted in my mouth! We also ordered the enoki chips which were fun but very greasy. Overall fun experience and glad we came but the ramen was just average and isn't justified by the long wait.

excerpts: I got the vegan tantanmen and my boyfriend got the tori paitan.
The tantanmen was very good!
Hearty and creamy.
Flavorful broth and you won't miss the meat.
The tori paitan was very heavy.
Very creamy.
I can't imagine finishing the whole bowl
and I am a person who loves creamy stuff.
4 stars for the tantanmen and 3 stars for the tori paitan.
vegan tantanmen.author: Rae C.
vegan tantanmen.review:
Sunday night lined up at 445pm, got seated after an hour. 

Gratuity free but 15% service fee is included in every bill. 

Service was good, they were nice and attentive. Ramen came out quickly. 

I got the vegan tantanmen and my boyfriend got the tori paitan. The tantanmen was very good! Hearty and creamy. Flavorful broth and you won't miss the meat. The tori paitan was very heavy. Very creamy. I can't imagine finishing the whole bowl and I am a person who loves creamy stuff. Broth was good and was very chickeny, the pork was good too.

4 stars for the tantanmen and 3 stars for the tori paitan. Rounded down to 3 stars because of the wait and price point. 

All in all, good experience and I'm glad I came. But I still prefer Ichiran and Ippudo.

excerpts: The Vegan Tantanmen is an exceptional journey into comfortable textures, tasty broth, and happiness!!
Also love the concept of no leftover packaging or to-go orders, an environmentally responsible measure that minimizes and reduces waste.
Perfectly portioned, the meal left me well nourished and very satisfied!!
vegan tantanmen.author: Milton W.
vegan tantanmen.review: After passing by a line of waiting people numerous times and hearing a raving recommendation (especially about the vegan option) from a friend, I had to try Mensho Tokyo. And yes, the wait was for about an hour but the communal dining and view of the kitchen team in action made it worthwhile. The Vegan Tantanmen is an exceptional journey into comfortable textures, tasty broth, and happiness!! Also love the concept of no leftover packaging or to-go orders, an environmentally responsible measure that minimizes and reduces waste. Perfectly portioned, the meal left me well nourished and very satisfied!!

excerpts: my vegan tantanmen was DELECTABLE.
super rich, peanut-y base, perfectly alkaline aldente ramen.
all very good, but the vegan tantanmen was my favorite of the meal.
vegan tantanmen.author: Judy L.
vegan tantanmen.review:
the wait in the cold was not so fun. we were about 10 parties back in queue, and waited about 1 hour on a saturday evening around 9pm. it's communal tables with decently quick service. 

our party of 4 all got different dishes. my vegan tantanmen was DELECTABLE. super rich, peanut-y base, perfectly alkaline aldente ramen. i tried the broth for shio, organic shoyu, and tori paitan. all very good, but the vegan tantanmen was my favorite of the meal.

also try the oysters!!!

excerpts: I have tried the shio ramen and the vegan tantanmen.
My favorite is definitely the vegan tantanmen, despite it costing double in price.
The soup is uber rich, and packs huge flavor.
I think most people would prefer the traditional soy sauce/ pork style broth, but I like this one more.
vegan tantanmen.author: Victor L.
vegan tantanmen.review:
Mensho is one of those places where there will always be a line.  However, the line is justified, as they are able to offer ramen that is quite delicious.  I have had the pleasure of being able to dine here several times.  I have tried the shio ramen and the vegan tantanmen.  My favorite is definitely the vegan tantanmen, despite it costing double in price.  The soup is uber rich, and packs huge flavor.  I think most people would prefer the traditional soy sauce/ pork style broth, but I like this one more.  Portions are generous, even though the ramen is quite pricey.  

There aren't any seats that are private, so be very aware that everyone will be eyeing you and your food.  Service is decent, but they do rush you to eat, pay, and leave.

excerpts: the Tori Paitan and my friend had the vegan Tantanmen.
The Tori Paitan was very interesting.
The broth was VERY creamy and rich, almost like a sauce instead of a broth.
If tonkotsu had a creamier poultry-based broth cousin, it would be this.
You could definitely taste the katsuo in the broth, which I normally don't like
but it was okay here.
The slices of duck were SO tender, it was quite amazing.
The noodles aren't the traditional ramen noodles, but a bit more thick, wide and flat.
I found it odd that there was kale in my ramen
o_o
The limited menu is a turn-off, since I don't see myself coming back for the Tantanmen or the Tori Paitan one again anytime soon.
Oh, and the price tag.
$18, not including tax and tip, for ramen?
Yikes.
I'd def pay $23 for Ichiran or Ippudo, but Mensho?
Eeeeeh.
vegan tantanmen.author: Doris K.
vegan tantanmen.review:
Closer to a 3.5-star rating, but I'll give it the bump.

After all the hype (aka ridiculous long lines) died down, I finally decided to give Mensho a try with my friend. Gone are the mile-long lines - I arrived around 6 and there were about 5 people in line. By 6:30-7, there was still no significant line (maybe 30 minute wait max?). 

The menu is short and sweet. I had the Tori Paitan and my friend had the vegan Tantanmen. As soon as you sit down, they come and take your order so better decide while you're waiting in line!

***First thing to note***: This is nothing close to the ramen I had in Japan. I don't know if Mensho is authentic or not, but it's definitely not the same as stuff you hear about like Ichiran, Ippudo, etc. I think my hopes of Mensho being legit ramen from Japan killed it a bit for me =X Or maybe I just didn't run into any ramen shops that served ramen like this? *shrugs*

The Tori Paitan was very interesting. The broth was VERY creamy and rich, almost like a sauce instead of a broth. If tonkotsu had a creamier poultry-based broth cousin, it would be this. You could definitely taste the katsuo in the broth, which I normally don't like but it was okay here. The slices of duck were SO tender, it was quite amazing. The noodles aren't the traditional ramen noodles, but a bit more thick, wide and flat. I found it odd that there was kale in my ramen o_o But overall, I enjoyed it. 

I had a sip of my friends Tantanmen, and I think it was good? Haha

While I don't think Mensho lives up to ramen in Japan, it's pretty good. The limited menu is a turn-off, since I don't see myself coming back for the Tantanmen or the Tori Paitan one again anytime soon. Oh, and the price tag. $18, not including tax and tip, for ramen? Yikes. I'd def pay $23 for Ichiran or Ippudo, but Mensho? Eeeeeh.

excerpts: so I just ordered the Vegan tantanmen which was amazing.
It was the best vegetarian ramen I have ever had.
The ingredients were so fresh and the broth was to die for.
In addition to the amazing ramen, they also had a small selection of different Japanese beers which included a Japanese IPA that was pretty good.
5 stars for authenticity and best vegan ramen!!!
vegan tantanmen.author: Cynthia L.
vegan tantanmen.review: I came here in the beginning of April and arrived around 7:30ish and the wait was about 30 minutes which was not bad considering the wait for this place is usually longer. The service is pretty fast once you're seated. They have a pretty simple menu and only one vegetarian option  so I just ordered the Vegan tantanmen which was amazing. It was the best vegetarian ramen I have ever had. The ingredients were so fresh and the broth was to die for. In addition to the amazing ramen, they also had a small selection of different Japanese beers which included a Japanese IPA that was pretty good. 5 stars for authenticity and best vegan ramen!!!

excerpts: My friend who had been there before said that her favorite is vegan tantanmen, and we are both partial to spicy ramen.
However, they ran out by the time we got there.
At least that's what our server said - but I think she must have gotten false information from the kitchen.
The dude next to us who came after got a bowl, which made us very sad.
Note that if you get more food than you can eat, they do NOT do to-go orders.
Meaning they won't give you a to-go box.
I'm not sure I like this policy.
You shouldn't make delicious food and then not let people bring it home with them to enjoy if they can't finish it all.
(3) Spicy Mazesoba: Originally, we were going to get the vegan tantanmen as our third bowl but they ran out.
Then we wanted to get the tsukemen, but they said they run out at 7p.
So we decided on the spicy mazesoba.
I have never had this before, so I had no idea what it is.
Basically, it's like noodles with sauce but no soup.
It comes in a bowl (see attached pic) with an egg yolk and various toppings.
Note that the spicy one also comes with a side of what I think are habanero peppers, but not super sure.
We thought these were carrots and put the entire thing in
- it was wayyyyy too spicy this way - like wasabi style spicy.
Do not do what we did!
I think this noodle dish would have been really yummy to try and share if we didn't accidentally make it so darn spicy, it came with thick and chewy delicious noodles.
I will definitely be back to try to get my hands on bowls of tsukemen and the vegan tantanmen!
vegan tantanmen.author: Lin Z.
vegan tantanmen.review:
First of all, the line for this place is insane. You want a tip on when to come? Probably even at weird times, the line is better but it's still long. We came on a Thursday night around 9:15p. Maybe it was because of the NBA finals, with a game that just recently ended and people still at the bar, or maybe it was just because we caught the lull in between the dinner rush and the late dinner crowd. We ended up waiting for about 20 minutes. I would also recommend you come in a smaller group of like 2 people. You are likely to get seated faster with a small party because the shop is very small. Bigger parties just have to wait for more tables to open up. 

Ok, on to the ramen. You want to know if it's worth the wait? I don't think any food is really worth a two-hour wait, so that's where I'm coming from. But it is very good ramen. We got three bowls to share between the two of us so that we could try more things.  My friend who had been there before said that her favorite is vegan tantanmen, and we are both partial to spicy ramen. However, they ran out by the time we got there. At least that's what our server said - but I think she must have gotten false information from the kitchen.  The dude next to us who came after got a bowl, which made us very sad. Note that if you get more food than you can eat, they do NOT do to-go orders. Meaning they won't give you a to-go box. I'm not sure I like this policy. You shouldn't make delicious food and then not let people bring it home with them to enjoy if they can't finish it all. I will also say that I still like Ramen Dojo better than this place because I'm partial to spicy broth and they didn't have the spicy one when we were here. 

So here are the bowls of ramen we tried: 

(1) Tori Paitan: I think this is their specialty. I don't really like chicken broth ramen, but this place has the best chicken ramen I've ever had. The broth is frothy and creamy and satisfying. Also the noodles here are some of the best ramen noodles I've ever had. They're thicker than normal and really yummy. Still, I love spicy ramen and this was delicious but a little too bland for me. The toppings are good too - duck chashu and pork chashu are both yummy. 

(2) Shoyu: If you like shoyu ramen, this is probably the best one I've ever had. If you like lighter broths this is the one for you. I'm not as big a fan of lighter broths, but I could tell this ramen was done really well. The noodles are really good in this one too, still chewy but a little thinner than the ones that come in the tori paitan. 

(3) Spicy Mazesoba: Originally, we were going to get the vegan tantanmen as our third bowl but they ran out. Then we wanted to get the tsukemen, but they said they run out at 7p. So we decided on the spicy mazesoba. I have never had this before, so I had no idea what it is. Basically, it's like noodles with sauce but no soup. It comes in a bowl (see attached pic) with an egg yolk and various toppings. Note that the spicy one also comes with a side of what I think are habanero peppers, but not super sure. We thought these were carrots and put the entire thing in - it was wayyyyy too spicy this way - like wasabi style spicy. Do not do what we did! I think this noodle dish would have been really yummy to try and share if we didn't accidentally make it so darn spicy, it came with thick and chewy delicious noodles. Good alternative to the soup ramens, and interesting to try if you come with a group. 

All in all, I'd give this place five stars for the food. But docking it one star because of the to-go policy and because they didn't explain how to eat the mazesoba to us. It's not really intuitive! Just don't go in expecting great service either because it's a little too crowded and busy to give great service. 

I will definitely be back to try to get my hands on bowls of tsukemen and the vegan tantanmen!

excerpts: The vegan tantanmen was so delicious.
I highly recommend ordering this dish, even if you're not vegan!
vegan tantanmen.author: Kirsten M.
vegan tantanmen.review: The vegan tantanmen was so delicious. I highly recommend ordering this dish, even if you're not vegan!

excerpts: If you want something creamy and thick, go with vegan tantanmen or tori paitan ramen.
Tori Paitan ramen 16.00: thick creamy rich chicken soup with BOTH pork chashu and duck chashu topped with menma, kale, burdock, and katsuobushi sauce.
The sauce was SO rich and creamy.
It wasn't too salty despite the creaminess.
However half way through it got too heavy for me.
Nonetheless the meat were all melt in your mouth perfection and the noodles were thick and cooked to amazing "bounciness" level.
Tori Paitan ramen 16.00: thick creamy rich chicken soup with BOTH pork chashu and duck chashu topped with menma, kale, burdock, and katsuobushi sauce.
The sauce was SO rich and creamy.
It wasn't too salty despite the creaminess.
However half way through it got too heavy for me.

vegan tantanmen.author: Chena N.
vegan tantanmen.review:
Imagine Wal-Mart during Black Friday, that's exactly what Mensho Tokyo was like. 
If you walk in the TL and see a long line out the door, it's most likely Mensho. 

Authentic ramen from JAPAN?! Count me in to join in on the hype! Gave it a couple days to let the crowd simmer down a bit... Not that it really has.... 

Did my research and realized that in order to get in first seating you have to be there around 4-4:20pm. On a Tuesday, my friend and I came at 4:10pm and were the 3rd ones in line. Around 4:20pm the line was pretty long. I hear that if you come at 5pm (their opening time it would be a TWO hr wait) anything after that is 3-4 hr. HELL NAH. Lol. 

::Parking/Service/Ambiance::
Parking. Ha. Don't even think about it especially after 6pm. Luckily we got there around 4pm and there was parking 5-6 blocks away from the restaurant. Paid $2.25/hr because it was meters. 
It's kind of ironic that a restaurant from Japan opened up in the most ghetto part of SF, in the tenderloins. I felt super scared at night, good thing I was with a guy. 
Service was amazing. While we were in line I think the manager of some sort came out and thanked us for waiting and asked if we have any questions at all. The staff were all friendly too from start to end. 
They fit about 28 people for max capacity says the manager. There were 3 separate benches: one long bench that fits 12, two short bench that fit 6 each, and 4 chairs near the chef window. The place was definitely small but very clean and simple. Below each table were cubbies that reminded me of elementary school where we could fit our small purses or jackets. 
Came at 4:10pm so we were seated immediately and got to order before the large groups came in. 

::BLACK FRIDAY DEALS::
If you want something creamy and thick, go with vegan tantanmen or tori paitan ramen. If you want a lighter base, shio or shoyu.

Tori Paitan ramen 16.00: thick creamy rich chicken soup with BOTH pork chashu and duck chashu topped with menma, kale, burdock, and katsuobushi sauce. The sauce was SO rich and creamy. It wasn't too salty despite the creaminess. However half way through it got too heavy for me. Nonetheless the meat were all melt in your mouth perfection and the noodles were thick and cooked to amazing "bounciness" level.

excerpts: Their vegan tantanmen is some of the best vegan alternatives I've had.
They make a roasted nut based broth with chili oil, and it has a similar fat content and depth as their non-vegan broths.
vegan tantanmen.author: Charlotte H.
vegan tantanmen.review:
Their vegan tantanmen is some of the best vegan alternatives I've had. They make a roasted nut based broth with chili oil, and it has a similar fat content and depth as their non-vegan broths. The vegan noodles were springy and thick and were similar in texture and taste as ramen noodles, despite not containing egg. 

We arrived at 5:20pm on a Thursday and waited about an hour before we got seated. Line seemed to move regularly, even though the restaurant could only seat around 20 people. Bowls of ramen typically are more than $15 (except the shio ramen), so it's definitely on the higher end of the spectrum. But despite the wait and cost, it's worth going at least once.

excerpts: The Vegan Tantanmen is shockingly savory and meat-like for a dish that is meat-free -
I know some of you are likely skeptical of this one
vegan tantanmen.author: Matt M.
vegan tantanmen.review:
If you haven't lived in San Francisco you'll probably make the assumption that there are a lot of great ramen places there - it's a major city after all. Sadly the locals will disappoint you immediately by dissuading you of this myth and telling you to trek south to the far remote lands of San Mateo and San Jose to seek what you crave. If you're like me and the thought of ever leaving downtown is off the table you've just kind of accepted that you'll never have ramen quite as good as you would in Tokyo or even Los Angeles.

And then, Mensho Tokyo opened its doors. Since that day it's been really clear that the inhabitants of San Francisco are suffering from a severe ramen shortage because the lines to eat at this tiny place haven't let up. Part of the reason is that there are only around twenty spots to eat in this place but still, I would have expected the demand to let up a bit after a few months; your best bet is to show up around 4:30pm before the restaurant opens if you want to be seated in less than an hour.

There is good reason for the demand: the ramen is unquestionably the best in the city. The Tori Paitan has one of the most flavorful broths I've ever tasted and every sip is like having pure concentrated chicken. The Vegan Tantanmen is shockingly savory and meat-like for a dish that is meat-free - I know some of you are likely skeptical of this one but I guarantee you will not be disappointed and go out on a limb here.

I would say that despite how good everything I've eaten here has been I still wouldn't put it up there with my favorite ramens. For truly satisfying comfort food ecstasy you're still going to have to heed the advice of your local friends and travel south on the peninsula to the likes of Ramen Dojo and Santouka.

Since it was my first time I decided to go with the 'tori

Very nutty, rich broth and excellent balance of flavors.
vegan tantanmen.author: Dustin H.
vegan tantanmen.review:
Arrived at 5PM on a Saturday and waited 50m for a table for 2.

+ The chicken paitan broth is delicious. Suuuuper creamy soup but not overwhelming
+ Noodles are perfect. Great texture and chew
~ Chashu is solid, but you're really here for the soup and noodles
+ The vegan tantanmen was also great. Very nutty, rich broth and excellent balance of flavors.

excerpts: Vegan Tantanmen - despite the consensus
vegan tantanmen.author: Whan T.
vegan tantanmen.review:
When I arrived at the restaurant (9.30 on a Friday night), the line was pretty long so I was kind of skeptical if it was worth the wait. Surprisingly, the wait was only 30 minutes and I only had to wait 10 minutes for the food. The overview of the food:

Tori Paitan - the broth was very good the first few bites but the broth became too overwhelming and creamy for my taste (I don't favor creamy food so if you enjoy creamy food then you would probably like this). The chashu pork was delicious, though!

Vegan Tantanmen - despite the consensus, I prefer this one over the Tori Paitan. The broth was a little spicy but it wasn't too creamy. For those who think that the Tori Paitan might be too creamy should try this one! It kind of reminds me of a Thai dish called Kao Soi (which is also delicious). 

Oysters - this is not your typical oyster in a shell which I expected but turns out to be oyster dipped in shoyu. The taste wasn't bad but I was hoping for something else.

The overall experience was good. I would definitely come again if I didn't have to wait in line.

excerpts: As we were ordering the ramen they said they ran out of the 2 that we had just selected...sad panda...so we went with the Shio and Vegan Tantanmen.
We also ordered the enoki chips for apps and some sake.
GUYS...
the enoki chips were sooo good.
I'm a huge fan of mushrooms
so when I saw these were fried up?
That's a must for me.
Dip it in the spices that they give you and what a treat.
I wish I could talk to you about the Sake, but unfortunately the waitress never brought it to us.
The big disappointment was the Shio ramen.
It just wasn't anything special.
I feel like I could've went to the Korean market and picked up a pack of Shin ramen and it would've easily satisfied as well as this bowl did.
It didn't have any veggies ( you can order veggies to be added) and it was just so....plain.
vegan tantanmen.author: Richard C.
vegan tantanmen.review:
My wife and I landed in SF late last night, craving for some delicious ramen. We found Mensho to be the only thing open at the time. There was a little line outside, but only took like 20 mins to get through it. It's a pretty small restaurant and can only fit like 20 ppl at the max? We were sat down at the table nearest to the kitchen, so we're able to see the cooks working their magic.

As we were ordering the ramen they said they ran out of the 2 that we had just selected...sad panda...so we went with the Shio and Vegan Tantanmen. We also ordered the enoki chips for apps and some sake. GUYS...the enoki chips were sooo good. I'm a huge fan of mushrooms so when I saw these were fried up? That's a must for me. Dip it in the spices that they give you and what a treat. I wish I could talk to you about the Sake, but unfortunately the waitress never brought it to us. The service here was pretty bad (idk if it's because it was later in the night) as we had to ask them for utensils and no one came to refill our water. 

The waitress brought the ramen and we finally got to eat after a long flight from DC. First of all when I saw the Tantanmen, it looked like noodles in peanut butter broth haha. If you order it you'll know what I'm talking about, but nonetheless it was pretty good. The noodles were cooked great, but something was lacking in the bowl itself. Some bean sprouts or some crunch of something. We ordered some chili sauce to put into our ramen too, as we're both spicy food lovers! The big disappointment was the Shio ramen. It just wasn't anything special. I feel like I could've went to the Korean market and picked up a pack of Shin ramen and it would've easily satisfied as well as this bowl did. It didn't have any veggies ( you can order veggies to be added) and it was just so....plain. I guess I'm use to having some veggies in there or some other stuff in there besides the couple piieces of meat, noodles, and broth.

Overall...just a meh meal. Hope to try other ramen spots while in SF.

excerpts: I want to try the Vegan Tantanmen.
OH, just a suggestion, if you want to get in quick, come alone, there were some lucky ducks who got to skip the line for that.
vegan tantanmen.author: Jenny Y.
vegan tantanmen.review:
Things you can do while you wait for a seat at Mensho Tokyo:
- Tailgate: The people behind us may or may not have been brown bagging. We were told that there have been people who will break out six packs cause they DGAF.
- Get yur hur did: leave a designated wait person and get a haircut from across the street. Trust me, you have enough time.
- Meditate: You probably won't do this, but I'm not going to lie, my hangryness was taking over my body real quick. If every crevice of SF wasn't covered in piss, I'd be sitting in a corner collecting myself.

So we arrived at about 5:15 on a Sunday and had to wait for a good 2 hours before we were able to enter the door. Abram was really nice and thanked us for waiting. We shared an oyster appetizer, SO ordered the Shoyu Ramen, I ordered the Tori Paitan.

The oysters were nice but forgettable. I wouldn't order them again. The Tori Paitan ramen on the other hand, was delicious. The chashu and duck melted in your mouth, the noodles were perfect, and the broth was so very rich and creamy. Sadly, the Shoyu Ramen was too salty. Each bite was followed by a gulp of water.

I can't wait for the rest of the menu to come, we'll definitely be back. I want to try the Vegan Tantanmen. OH, just a suggestion, if you want to get in quick, come alone, there were some lucky ducks who got to skip the line for that.

excerpts: Vegan Tantanmen, $18 [http://bit.ly/22xt7tY]
Vegetable soup with konbu and mushrooms, Japanese soy cream, sesame, cilantro, chili oil, green onion, menma, etc.
---My friend ordered this one
but I was able to try some of the broth and noodles.
The broth was very creamy as well - think tonkotsu without meat.
vegan tantanmen.author: Jasmin H.
vegan tantanmen.review:
Finally had a chance to check out what the hype was about and the verdict was - yes, totally worth the wait!

Wait time: 2 hrs on a Friday night (arrived at 6:05pm, got in at 8)

Space: Roughly 24 seats. Easier to get seated right away if you go by yourself or as a couple than parties of 3+. They let my friend and I come in before two large groups ahead of us.

What we ordered:

Tori Paitan double chashu ramen, $16 + $2 for the chashu [http://bit.ly/1VsPPBt]
Rich, creamy chicken soup, pork chashu, duck chashu, menma (condiment made from dried bamboo shoots), kale, etc.
---The server gave me the option of single or double chashu, but **ORDER DOUBLE CHASHU!!!!**  ...trust me one won't be enough!! All my friends who made the mistake of ordering just one walked out the door day dreaming about that other chashu... Also, about the broth, as many Yelpers say here, it is definitely on the thicker side but has a flavorful and creamy twist. Noodles were chewy and perfectly cooked.

Vegan Tantanmen, $18 [http://bit.ly/22xt7tY]
Vegetable soup with konbu and mushrooms, Japanese soy cream, sesame, cilantro, chili oil, green onion, menma, etc.
---My friend ordered this one but I was able to try some of the broth and noodles. The broth was very creamy as well - think tonkotsu without meat. It's sprinkled with seven kinds of nuts and a bit spicy because of the chili oil. 

Bill ended up to be $39.15 sans tip.

No doubt, if you're craving authentic ramen from Japan, you cannot go wrong with this one!

excerpts: but I ordered the vegan tantanmen and  honestly, you wouldn't be able to tell it's vegan!
The broth is so rich and creamy, but doesn't leave you feeling heavy or greasy.
It has so much depth of flavor and a good spicy kick.
Also the nuts added a nice texture and crunch.
vegan tantanmen.author: Karissa Y.
vegan tantanmen.review:
Ramen is oh so good.

I was so excited to finally try this place! I came here with 3 other friends on a Saturday night at 4:30 and we were able to get seated the first round.

I'm definitely not vegan but I ordered the vegan tantanmen and  honestly, you wouldn't be able to tell it's vegan! The broth is so rich and creamy, but doesn't leave you feeling heavy or greasy. It has so much depth of flavor and a good spicy kick. Also the nuts added a nice texture and crunch. The ramen noodles are thicker than your typical ramen noodle, but are perfectly al dente. 

Overall, the waits are long and the prices are pretty steep for ramen, but worth it once in a while for their unique and delicious ramen.

excerpts: Eating ramen is hard to do for a vegetarian, but the vegan tantanmen does not disappoint.
Creamy, spicy, and served at an amazingly perfect temperature, this broth was everything.
The noodles were also perfectly cooked - just a little al dente and very flavorful.
Worth the wait and a gem of a find for vegetarians looking for ramen!
vegan tantanmen.author: Vina C.
vegan tantanmen.review: Standing in line is worth it for this ramen. Perfectly cooked, delicious broth, and add-ons to customize it to your taste. No take out containers provided as they are purists about their ramen consumption experience, but for good reason. Eating ramen is hard to do for a vegetarian, but the vegan tantanmen does not disappoint. Creamy, spicy, and served at an amazingly perfect temperature, this broth was everything. The noodles were also perfectly cooked - just a little al dente and very flavorful. Worth the wait and a gem of a find for vegetarians looking for ramen!

excerpts: I had the vegan tantanmen (the vegetarian ramen on the menu).
It was very flavorful - the broth was spicy but nice; the cilantro and chili oil were a great touch.
The noodles were thicker than usual and was quite filling.
We went on a Friday night and there was a 20 minute wait outside
but once we were in, service was quick.
Seating seemed limited with space for about 16 people (2 tables with 8 chairs each).
vegan tantanmen.author: Roshan H.
vegan tantanmen.review: One of the best ramen places I have been to! I had the vegan tantanmen (the vegetarian ramen on the menu). It was very flavorful - the broth was spicy but nice; the cilantro and chili oil were a great touch. The noodles were thicker than usual and was quite filling. We went on a Friday night and there was a 20 minute wait outside but once we were in, service was quick. Seating seemed limited with space for about 16 people (2 tables with 8 chairs each).

excerpts: Vegan Tantanmen:
Nutty, chili oil deliciousness.
vegan tantanmen.author: Britt M.
vegan tantanmen.review:
Tori Paintan: Bouncy noodles with tender, tender duck + pork in a rich and creamy broth. Solid bowl of ramen. Add chili oil to this and it would be *slightly* better than the vegan option.

Vegan Tantanmen: Nutty, chili oil deliciousness. Rivals Izakaya Goku's vegan ramen... which is saying a lot.

Since it's so small, I love how they crank you out. Super efficient and great service. Worth noting because of the tight space and quick turn around, not a great date spot.

excerpts: The Vegan Tantanmen has the perfect balance of creaminess and heat with ingredients I don't usually see in ramen.
vegan tantanmen.author: Cora A.
vegan tantanmen.review:
In town for business and wanted to find something near my hotel. Boy, did I hit the jackpot. It a little pricey but SO worth it. The Vegan Tantanmen has the perfect balance of creaminess and heat with ingredients I don't usually see in ramen. 

If you want a soft drink, the Ramune is fun (you have to pop a marble into the bottle to drink it) but I'd skip it if you're don't like the taste of Juicy Fruit gum. 

There will definitely be a line but it moves faster than you think and the food is worth the wait.

excerpts: Our server was very friendly and helpful when it came to ordering; she actually recommended the Vegan Tantanmen, but said that the Tori Paitan was the most popular item.
We ordered one of each, although surprisingly I ended up preferring the vegan ramen.
It truly was some of the best ramen I've EVER had (and I've had quite a lot in my lifetime).
Everything was perfect, from the al dente noodles, to the level of spice in the broth.
There's no way you could tell it's vegan, and the broth had a great earthy, nutty flavor.
Even the chopsticks and spoon were fantastic (you'll see what I mean what you go there).
The chicken ramen was unlike anything I had tried before - super creamy but also light at the same time.
It was such a delicious culinary experience, and while I would not wait over an hour for it, I am SO happy I had the chance to try it.
The ramen is so good that perhaps I might even start walking by after work just to see if there happens to be a short line...
vegan tantanmen.author: Regina L.
vegan tantanmen.review:
My friend and I decided to take advantage of the Warriors game being on and hit up Mensho Tokyo. We figured that with the game being on, the line would at least be slightly shorter than their infamous 1.5+ hour-long lines. Thankfully it was a lovely evening out and we only waited about 35 minutes before we were sat. They run a VERY tight ship; seats are turned incredibly quickly and efficiently. We were sat at the bar, which allowed us to look into the kitchen. The kitchen, along with the dining space, looked incredibly clean and everyone was operating very efficiently. The dining area, although packed quite tight, doesn't feel too crowded, and I thought I had a lot of personal space at the bar. 

Our server was very friendly and helpful when it came to ordering; she actually recommended the Vegan Tantanmen, but said that the Tori Paitan was the most popular item. We ordered one of each, although surprisingly I ended up preferring the vegan ramen. It truly was some of the best ramen I've EVER had (and I've had quite a lot in my lifetime). Everything was perfect, from the al dente noodles, to the level of spice in the broth. There's no way you could tell it's vegan, and the broth had a great earthy, nutty flavor. Even the chopsticks and spoon were fantastic (you'll see what I mean what you go there). The chicken ramen was unlike anything I had tried before - super creamy but also light at the same time. It was such a delicious culinary experience, and while I would not wait over an hour for it, I am SO happy I had the chance to try it. The ramen is so good that perhaps I might even start walking by after work just to see if there happens to be a short line...

excerpts: The vegan tantanmen was a close second favorite.
vegan tantanmen.author: Sally C.
vegan tantanmen.review:
Sigh, what crazy people would wait outside a ramen shop at 10pm on a Tuesday night? Yes, me. And many others apparently... because this wait still took 45 min!

Totally worth it. I've had ramen up and down California and with all the hype going around, Mensho reigns supreme (next to Orenchi). How do you make a pork broth taste so thick yet light at the same time?! Noodles were actually al dente. A lot of ramen places claim to have good noodles but theirs were perfectly chewy. The vegan tantanmen was a close second favorite. I think I almost enjoyed the broth more.

I would love to come back for the tsukemen and oysters.

excerpts: This was not just the case with the chicken paitan, but my friend who had the vegan tantanmen also said hers was really salty too.

You could definitely tell that the chicken broth was cooked for a long time because the natural flavors of the chicken were prominent, but I thought the broth was too heavy, salty and creamy in a bad way.
I drank SO much water
while eating the bowl of ramen, and 3 hours later, I'm still thirsty and my mouth is super dry.
I appreciated the innovation of incorporating different ingredients that aren't traditionally seen in ramen such as kale.
I am willing to accept kale because it offered a change in texture within the different types of vegetables, but I was NOT a fan of the duck.
I thought that having a chicken broth with pork and duck chashu was WAY too much.
3 different types of meat in one dish
and it felt like all the flavors were clashing.
I liked the pork chashu though; it just melted in your mouth.
The noodles were also cooked al dente and chewy.
My friends and I were disappointed that there wasn't even a soft boiled egg in a bowl of ramen that costed $18.
There were a lot of noodles
and I was full, but I definitely will not be back.
vegan tantanmen.author: Sharon C.
vegan tantanmen.review:
The wait is SO NOT worth it. 

My friends and I (party of 5) came to try the hype and because it's pretty unusual for a ramen place to have vegetarian or vegan options since the broth is usually made with meat. We came here around 7:15pm and stood about 5 feet from the Alcatraz theatre sign. A waitress came to take down our name, and we asked how long the wait was. She said from the sign, it would be about an hour. We decided to wait, but her estimate was far from what the actual wait turned out to be. It took us almost an hour to get to the sign, and in total, we waited 2.5 hours. 

What turned my friends off the most was the service. Their seating system is the most inefficient that we have ever seen. It was baffling. Granted, our party is on the bigger side, and there are only 4 tables and a bar to sit at so approximately 35 seats in the restaurant. Their seating system really puts people with more than 2 or 3 people at a disadvantage because they won't seat you unless a party with the same number of people leaves. Once we reached the front and there were only 2 more parties in front of us, the waitress told us that we would take the table of the group of 5 that just sat down even though there was a group of 3 that was leaving. We asked if we could split up because the people next to the group of 3 on their way out would probably finish within 15 minutes. She said no because then the time of serving the food to our party would be  vary and that's not allowed. We were so confused as to why that should be a problem if we were okay with it. And if that were really a problem, since the party next to the group of 3 was close to done, it would have been practical for her to save those three seats until the other party finished so that we would all be seated at the same time. Instead, she gave it to another party behind us and multiple parties behind us went before we even got in. In total, it was a 2.5 hour wait. By the end of the wait, we were fuming at the inefficiency because it was extremely unfair that we couldn't be seated even if we agreed to split up. As we were making our way out, the same waitress, an older woman who seemed to be the manager, stopped my friend and yelled at her for not giving enough tip and demanded more. We were all in shock because we have never been put in a situation like this before. My friend said no because she explained her to how she thought the seating system was inefficient and the wait wasn't worth it. The lady then proceeded to tell her, "If you don't want to wait, don't come back." We waited because we thought it would only be an hour because that's what we were told, and a lot of people would be seated faster and the line would move faster had their system been more efficient. She has our WORD that we will not be returning. 

Finally, onto the food. I ordered the chicken paitan ramen because that's what everyone was raving about. Upon being seated, they took our order pretty quickly and the food came pretty fast (~10-15min). Upon tasting the soup, my friends and I looked at each other with furrowed eyebrows, and said, "it's so salty." This was not just the case with the chicken paitan, but my friend who had the vegan tantanmen also said hers was really salty too. You could definitely tell that the chicken broth was cooked for a long time because the natural flavors of the chicken were prominent, but I thought the broth was too heavy, salty and creamy in a bad way. I drank SO much water while eating the bowl of ramen, and 3 hours later, I'm still thirsty and my mouth is super dry. I appreciated the innovation of incorporating different ingredients that aren't traditionally seen in ramen such as kale. I am willing to accept kale because it offered a change in texture within the different types of vegetables, but I was NOT a fan of the duck. I thought that having a chicken broth with pork and duck chashu was WAY too much. 3 different types of meat in one dish and it felt like all the flavors were clashing. I liked the pork chashu though; it just melted in your mouth. The noodles were also cooked al dente and chewy. My friends and I were disappointed that there wasn't even a soft boiled egg in a bowl of ramen that costed $18. There were a lot of noodles and I was full, but I definitely will not be back.

Expect long lines.
Service is quick b/c they want u in and outta there.
Even the omnivores around me wanted the vegan ramen I had.
Get in line at 4:25 b4 they open at 5 or go after 6:30 pm.

The broth and noodles were so good with so much flavor.
The kale sprouts and mushroom tasted good.
The last time I was here
vegan tantanmen.author: Allie L.
vegan tantanmen.review: We waited 10 minutes in the rain, but well worth the wait as we were treated to a delicious bowl of ramen. I ordered the Vegan Tantanmen and my friend ordered the Shoyu ramen. The broth and noodles were so good with so much flavor. The kale sprouts and mushroom tasted good. The last time I was here I had their Organic Shoyu ramen with Chashu and that was equally tasty! The staff is friendly, but they also remind you to move along as there others waiting for your seat. It's not a bad thing if you're waiting.

excerpts: The shio is my favorite so far, but I absolutely loved the vegan tantanmen too - it's distinctly rich and flavorful, you wouldn't believe it's vegan!
As for the long queues, go at night ~10-11pm.
vegan tantanmen.author: Grace C.
vegan tantanmen.review: There's a new ramen shop in town and it's already my favorite in the Bay Area. Ramen creator Shono Tomoharu is bringing authentic ramen culture to SF and I can't be more excited!! The dashi is made with two high quality kelps from Hokkaido and a specially sourced katsuobushi. The shio is my favorite so far, but I absolutely loved the vegan tantanmen too - it's distinctly rich and flavorful, you wouldn't believe it's vegan! As for the long queues, go at night ~10-11pm. :)

excerpts: Vegan Tantanmen - Quite the standout, and
I'm not regularly a tantanmen fan.
Probably the most delicious vegan dish I've had in my life.
vegan tantanmen.author: Richard C.
vegan tantanmen.review:
Fantastic addition to San Francisco. Grant them the operational roughness during the first week, and you'll have no disappointments. Recommended.

1-hour wait at 6:30pm on a Wednesday, 20 people in queue. Would not normally do this. Crowd thankfully knows to eat quickly, and turn the table for the next diners. Ramen is not food to linger over, folks.

4 kinds of noodles available at opening, ordered 3:

* Organic Shoyu - Excellent baseline. Good flavor extraction without excessive salt. Noodle bit on the soft side.
* Shio - Also for baseline. Same as above, satisfyingly light. Kale works well here.
* Vegan Tantanmen - Quite the standout, and I'm not regularly a tantanmen fan. Probably the most delicious vegan dish I've had in my life. Piping hot noodle, visually rich but each-to-eat soymilk base, many dimensions to flavor, all of the elements balanced well.

Our entire group finished the soups, to the last drop. It's a beautiful thing when this happens.

Suntory Premium Mait's not available. Boo-hoo!

Table check came out wrong (missing multiple items), sent back so we can properly pay for everything we ate.

The original Menya Shono (http://menya-shono.com/tokyo) in Shinjuku is a regular stop for me, and their Mensho Tokyo (http://menya-shono.com/tokyo/shop) overseas expansion pilot near Tokyo Dome has been reviewing well in Japan, with a wild range of noodles created. I'll vouch for the quality of the people behind this very welcome addition to San Francisco, I hope they continue to execute well!

excerpts: For this visit I had the Vegan Tantanmen and there isn't anything I would change about this dish.
Also I would recommend trying the crispy, fried mushrooms appetizer with a little lemon on top for a pleasant intro to your meal.
vegan tantanmen.author: Lauren S.
vegan tantanmen.review: At this point it looks like I have found my favorite Bay Area' Ramen house. The line is what it is so if you intend on making a wise decision by enjoying the wonderment of Mensho Tokyo come prepared. I did not find the line to be too terrible - it is no different than what you can to get for an average Sunday brunch wait. For this visit I had the Vegan Tantanmen and there isn't anything I would change about this dish. Also I would recommend trying the crispy, fried mushrooms appetizer with a little lemon on top for a pleasant intro to your meal.

excerpts: so I tried Vegan Tantanmen which was soooo good and one hour
waiting outside in cold weather was worth it!
I would love to go again when we return to SF.
vegan tantanmen.author: YM E.
vegan tantanmen.review: Omg!! The best ramen ever!! I'm not a vegan but it sounded good so I tried Vegan Tantanmen which was soooo good and one hour waiting outside in cold weather was worth it! I would love to go again when we return to SF.

excerpts: Vegan tantanmen ramen with pork is the absolute best.
vegan tantanmen.author: Michio F.
vegan tantanmen.review: I could see how people would not love the place on their first visit, but after three times.. I've got it down. Vegan tantanmen ramen with pork is the absolute best. Not a fan of the little egg noodles they use in the shoyu and shio, and the Tori paitan broth  is way too much like gravy for me to slurp down to the last drop. Vegan ramen all the way here.

excerpts: I got the vegan tantanmen and she got the tori paitan.
Both were amazing!
The noodles had the right amount of density and chew  and the broth was rich and layered with flavor.
I particularly loved my vegan broth, which had some nice peanut and spicy notes.
The only warning I have is to come hungry so that you can finish the entire bowl.
The type I got was pretty rich and filling.
I can't wait to come back and try some of the other broths.
vegan tantanmen.author: Bethany D.
vegan tantanmen.review: Mensho serves some of the best ramen I've had in the Bay. My friend and I arrived around 10 on a Saturday, and the line actually moved pretty quickly. Once we got in, we were not disappointed. I got the vegan tantanmen and she got the tori paitan. Both were amazing! The noodles had the right amount of density and chew  and the broth was rich and layered with flavor. I particularly loved my vegan broth, which had some nice peanut and spicy notes. The only warning I have is to come hungry so that you can finish the entire bowl. The type I got was pretty rich and filling. I can't wait to come back and try some of the other broths.

excerpts: We ordered vegan tantanmen and the clam butter, enoki chips.
My vegetarian friend really likes the tantanmen.
I liked the think ramen noodle in tantanmen and the way it is cooked
but it's too salty for my taste.
the clam butter uses a thinner and flatter noodle, which works well with the lighter and clearer soup.
the clam and scallop are both fresh and tasty, the lemon slice helps by giving it a fresher taste and also adds variation to the bowl.
We are happy with the enoki chips.
I had enoki tempura before but these are different.
They don't seem to be using any flour batter  (at least I didn't taste any in our batch), which makes it very flaky and less greasy than enoki tempura.
vegan tantanmen.author: s c.
vegan tantanmen.review:
We ordered vegan tantanmen and the clam butter, enoki chips. My vegetarian friend really likes the tantanmen. I liked the think ramen noodle in tantanmen and the way it is cooked but it's too salty for my taste. the clam butter uses a thinner and flatter noodle, which works well with the lighter and clearer soup. the clam and scallop are both fresh and tasty, the lemon slice helps by giving it a fresher taste and also adds variation to the bowl. We are happy with the enoki chips. I had enoki tempura before but these are different. They don't seem to be using any flour batter  (at least I didn't taste any in our batch), which makes it very flaky and less greasy than enoki tempura. Definitely give it a try if you like enoki like we do.

Overall we enjoyed the food quite a lot. But we probably won't be back when the line is long. The food is good but not worth an hour of wait. 

I do think the restaurant could serve their customers better with some lining policies

We went there on a friday evening around 5:50. There were about 28 ppl in front of us. There are also about 28 seats in the restaurant so we decided to stay. After 15 minutes, we didn't move forward too much, mostly because ppl lining in front of us had friends joining them - one person even had 5 people joining him! I would like to think restaurants line their customers up not just to give themselves good advertisement but also to help people decide if they are dining there based on the length of the line. Allowing too many people to cut into the line because they have sent a friend waiting does a disservice for that purpose. If the restaurant lets people line up before the whole group is there, It is better to also keep a written waiting list of names with the number in each party, so that people would not have the wrong expectation regarding the waiting time. 

I also noticed that mensho does not seem to seat smaller groups first. They left 4 empty seats open for sometime until 2 more people at that table left so that they can accommodate the 6-ppl group. To be honest, that's a nice thing for the restaurant to do, and I would prefer going to that kind of restaurant when I have a larger party. But it sucks if 5 people of that party cut into the line in front of you and you ended up having to wait 10-15 minutes longer.

excerpts: I had the vegan tantanmen, which was one of the most flavorful vegan broths I've ever had.
Made out of seven kinds of nuts, it had a hearty flavor and thick texture that was coated on each noodle just perfectly.
The noodles themselves were some of the best I've had, both chewy and thick.
I loved the additional toppings, from the menma to the edamame.
vegan tantanmen.author: Ashley T.
vegan tantanmen.review: Mensho Tokyo is the newest ramen shop in SF, with lines out the door at least an hour before opening almost every night. My boyfriend and I got in line at around 4:45 PM on a Saturday, and waited almost an hour and half to get into the restaurant. We learned the story behind the store while talking to the owner, who is a Bay Area native and well-known ramen critic in Japan. For now, they only have a couple of their ramens on the menu and a oyster appetizer. I had the vegan tantanmen, which was one of the most flavorful vegan broths I've ever had. Made out of seven kinds of nuts, it had a hearty flavor and thick texture that was coated on each noodle just perfectly. The noodles themselves were some of the best I've had, both chewy and thick. I loved the additional toppings, from the menma to the edamame. My boyfriend had the tori paitan, their specialty ramen, which comes with both pork and duck chashu. Again, the broth had such well-developed flavor. I'm hoping the lines start to dissipate because I'm dying to go back for the ramen here as it's definitely some of the best you can find in San Francisco!

vegan tantanmen.author: flashegirl e.
vegan tantanmen.review:
Go! Now! Stand in Line and stay there until you get in and eat! It's worth the wait.
Had the Tori Paitan Ramen. The creamy chicken broth is magical, the ramen is think. It's filling but I ate all of it. I noticed people around me didn't finish their broth because they were either full or out of ramen. 
my friends had the other ramen dishes with clear chicken and pork broth and thinner ramen noodles, it didn't compare with the Tori Paitan Ramen. I'm still giving them five stars.

so go, stand in line! Visit the web site, watch the videos about Mensho Tokyo while you're in line. http://mensho.tokyo/

excerpts: My bf got the Tori Paitan Ramen and I got the Vegan Tantanmen.

It was the best tasting broth I've ever had.
Absolutely DIVINE.
And the noodles were cooked so perfect.
I'm honestly at a loss for words right now because the ramen was THAT good.
I can't wait to come back again and again.

so you are seated very close to everyone else at the same communal table.
I'm talking bumping elbows close to strangers
but it's worth it.

Come early because this place gets packed.

However, the service is very fast so the turn out on table space is quick.
We waited less than 10 minutes.
Definitely check this place out next time you're having a ramen craving.
It's the best in SF!!
