excerpts: One friend ordered the vegan tantanmen, which I loved and attempted to switch with my own bowl of ramen.
vegan tantanmen.author: Jules G.
vegan tantanmen.review:
My friends and I were here on a misty Friday evening. We arrived before 5:30 pm and there was already a long line. Be ready for a really long wait! If you're super hungry, you may want to bring snacks. The group behind us left to buy snacks at some point. Our party of four were finally seated a little after 7:30 pm. Thankfully our bowls of deliciousness were quick to arrive after we'd ordered.

Was it worth the wait? It certainly was! Two friends ordered the tori paitan, which is their richest, creamiest option. One friend ordered the vegan tantanmen, which I loved and attempted to switch with my own bowl of ramen. I ordered the organic shoyu ramen; it was slightly lighter but just as flavorful. They're all good; it just depends on personal preferences.

They currently don't serve eggs in their ramen. We asked the staff and they mentioned they're carefully selecting a type of egg that is equivalent to those in Japan. It's nice to know they're so particular about their ingredients.

I would definitely return but I wouldn't wait over two hours again.

excerpts: I had the vegan tantanmen and I liked it!
vegan tantanmen.author: Sri S.
vegan tantanmen.review: After Ramen Underground got rid of their tomato ramen, this is my new favorite! It's much better - creamier broth and thick noodles. I had the vegan tantanmen and I liked it! Also tried the tori paitan ramen and highly recommend! Took us an hour to get seated on a Friday at 6:15 pm.

excerpts: I had the Vegan Tantanmen and it was a whole new experience.
vegan tantanmen.author: Marco G.
vegan tantanmen.review: Admittedly this was one of my first times having ramen, but it was so good, I'm still thinking about it a week later.  I had the Vegan Tantanmen and it was a whole new experience.

excerpts: The vegan tantanmen does taste good and for that they get at least one star.
Did i mention our server and manager fought that day
and i think she was fired and that caused all the miscommunication.
vegan tantanmen.author: Paul C.
vegan tantanmen.review: The line is long, once inside it took 10 minutes to get our order taken , then another 30 minutes to get our ramen because one guy cooks while the other 3 stands and watches. Lastly the ramen doesn't even arrive together i finished my ramen by the time my friends arrived. Now I understand why the wait is long, what a failure or a restaurant... The vegan tantanmen does taste good and for that they get at least one star. Did i mention our server and manager fought that day and i think she was fired and that caused all the miscommunication.

excerpts: Decided to try the vegan tantanmen.
Noodles: 5/5.
Broth: 5/5 (creamier than I'm used to, but super great), ingredient choices: 4/5.
Absolutely recommend giving this a try if you can stomach the long lines.
I'll definitely be back.
vegan tantanmen.author: Zach S.
vegan tantanmen.review: Best ramen I've ever had.  What more can I say?  I've been on a mission to come here since they opened several weeks ago, but the line is always far too long.  I lucked out last night and ended up on a short line.  Decided to try the vegan tantanmen.  Noodles: 5/5.  Broth: 5/5 (creamier than I'm used to, but super great), ingredient choices: 4/5.  Absolutely recommend giving this a try if you can stomach the long lines.  I'll definitely be back.

excerpts: They only had two kinds of ramen tonight: Tori Paltanf and Vegan Tantanmen.
I appreciate them for trying to make sure everything is as good as it is in Japan and that's why they rather serve only 2 ramens tonight.
We tried both tonight
and I love meat
but to my surprise, I liked the vegan tantanmen better.
I thoughtful it was very flavorful and complex and the noodles were cooked perfectly with the right texture and chewiness.
The broth was very thick but it wasn't oily at all.
vegan tantanmen.author: winnie l.
vegan tantanmen.review: We tried Mensho for the first time tonight, a week after they opened in SF.  We arrived at the restaurant around 4:30, half hour before they opened and we waited for about 2hrs before we got seated.  I thought it was crazy but it was worth it after we tried their ramen.  They only had two kinds of ramen tonight: Tori Paltanf and Vegan Tantanmen.  I appreciate them for trying to make sure everything is as good as it is in Japan and that's why they rather serve only 2 ramens tonight.  We tried both tonight and I love meat but to my surprise, I liked the vegan tantanmen better.  I thoughtful it was very flavorful and complex and the noodles were cooked perfectly with the right texture and chewiness.  The broth was very thick but it wasn't oily at all.  We will definitely come back to try their shio and shoyu ramen.  By the way, the guy at the door, probably the owner and the staff were all very friendly and welcoming.  Good job!

excerpts:
We ordered:

Oysters in shoyu dare oil - doesn't look appetizing, tastes like canned oysters in oil (not a bad thing).
oysters in shoyu dare oil.author: Karen H.
oysters in shoyu dare oil.review:
Gosh I feel bad I didn't brave the lines earlier for this place. I loved it. One of the best if not the best shoyu or paitan ramen in the SF area. 

We arrived at 8:30 Pm on a Friday night and the line was about 20 deep. Wait was around 40 minutes. Staff is super attentive collecting party numbers in the line and accommodated everyone on a first come first serve basis. We were waiting for a table for 4 and even as double seats showed up, and though smaller parties were behind us, they took care to seat us first.

The menu is clean and easy to read. We ordered:

Oysters in shoyu dare oil - doesn't look appetizing, tastes like canned oysters in oil (not a bad thing).

Organic shoyu ramen with double chasu - this was DELICIOUS. I was opting for a less-rich broth so went with the shoyu. Great choice. They double chasu is an extra slice, totally also worth it. The smoky flavor of the chasu pairs well with the clean shoyu based broth. The kale was so tender yet held texture in the bowl, and I adored the noodles. Tender, squiggly awesomeness. The duck chasu is new to me in ramen, and added depth to the bowl. 

Spicy tori paitan ramen with double chasu - spicy isn't too spicy, noodles were a little different than the shoyu ramen (closer to typical ramen noodles). Broth was super rich, creamy, heavy and delicious. Some with duck and pork chasu as well.

Although this ramen in general is much more rich than what I'm used to, it's GOOD. It's not exactly comparable but seems to me to stand In its own category - I've not had ramen like this before and it was so good.

Egg isn't included and it's a must add for $1. A whole egg, perfectly cooked. $1 is worth it.

Parking and neighborhood is kinda sketch... but I didn't feel unsafe dining here. The spoon provided is also way too large IMO, and made of heavy metal and my hand was tired after using it halfway through.

I'll be back!

excerpts: We also had the oysters in shoyu dare oil to share, and those were incredible; highly recommend to order that to start off.
oysters in shoyu dare oil.author: Kevin C.
oysters in shoyu dare oil.review:
Man...the thickest and heaviest broth I've ever had.  I've heard so much good things about this place, but the long wait times always scared me and I never explicitly sought to come.  But things always work out and just happened to be in the neighborhood and a group of 6 of us decided to give it a try.  

Even an hour before opening, the line was packed and we had to wait about 40 minutes before getting seated.  I can see why the wait so darn long; they only have 15-20 seats inside!  The setting is mostly community format, so unless you have a large party, you're more than likely to be seated with other die-hard ramen lovers.  

I recall that on this particular day, I wasn't really hungry but ended up getting Tori Paitan (Double Chashu).  I know I know...no shame!  First sip of the broth....wow is it filling, rich, and creamy.  I don't know if I'm in the minority here, but wasn't that big a fan of the thickness of the broth.  The chashu however, was some of the best I've had compared to other ramen establishments.  I loved the texture of the noodles though!  We also had the oysters in shoyu dare oil to share, and those were incredible; highly recommend to order that to start off.

Maybe I'll come back and try this for a second go round in the near future, but my initial experience has me questioning if the richness of the broth is really my style or if I just didn't have the best appetite on my visit.

excerpts: Oysters in Shoyu Dare Oil - Looks like something you get out of a can.
Smells and taste pungent
oysters in shoyu dare oil.author: Jenny L.
oysters in shoyu dare oil.review:
Got here when they opened, but the restaurant was already full and there was a line out the door. Ended up waiting an hour to get seated. 

Oysters in Shoyu Dare Oil - Looks like something you get out of a can. Smells and taste pungent but I liked it for some reason and goes pretty well with the ramen.

Shio Ramen with Double Chashu - Broth is supposed to be pork and chicken based with fried garlic, but I thought it was underwhelming and lacked flavor (pretty must just tasted like salt and oil). I thought the kale in ramen was a bit weird, it was bland and didn't do anything to enhance the ramen for me besides adding a bit of a crunchy texture which the menma is already supposed to do. Chashu was the only thing good, was flavorful, tender, fatty, and melt in your mouth.

Service was quick and prompt, but never felt rushed and 15% charge for gratuity is automatically added to your bill.

Maybe I chose the wrong broth or maybe they were having an off day, but I was not impressed. Cup noodles taste better.

excerpts: I had the chance to try the spicy tori paitan and the oysters in shoyu dare oil and the mushroom chip appetizers.
The spicy tori paitan came with pork chashu (yum!), spicy jalapeno miso, cabbage, burdock, and green onion.
The oysters were a bit herbal tasting to me
and I didn't like it.
The mushrooms were good if you like fried food.
It was greasy and oily.
My ramen was good, rich, and very pungent tasting.
The soup base was very creamy
but it went well with the thick noodles.
It was not as spicy as I thought it would be.
Additionally, I tried the tori paitan (pork chashu, duck chashu, kale, burdock, and katsuobushi sauce) and it was flavorful, pungent and savory as well.
Note that although one was spicy and one was not, there were differences in ingredients.
I would come back here
oysters in shoyu dare oil.author: Kristy L.
oysters in shoyu dare oil.review:
Features:
-After waiting nearly one hour on a weekend, we were finally seated inside.  I had the chance to try the spicy tori paitan and the oysters in shoyu dare oil and the mushroom chip appetizers.  The spicy tori paitan came with pork chashu (yum!), spicy jalapeno miso, cabbage, burdock, and green onion.  The oysters were a bit herbal tasting to me and I didn't like it.  The mushrooms were good if you like fried food.  It was greasy and oily.  My ramen was good, rich, and very pungent tasting.  The soup base was very creamy but it went well with the thick noodles. It was not as spicy as I thought it would be.  Additionally, I tried the tori paitan (pork chashu, duck chashu, kale, burdock, and katsuobushi sauce) and it was flavorful, pungent and savory as well.  Note that although one was spicy and one was not, there were differences in ingredients.  I would come back here but I would not wait an hour again. 
-Good and fast customer service, you could place your belongings in a basket below the table. 

Tips:
-Come early so you don't have to wait so long, I would recommend coming half an hour before they open.
-Each table sits up to six so if you have a bigger party, the wait may be longer.  
-Credit Cards and Cash accepted.

excerpts: I ordered oysters in shoyu dare oil as an appetizer, the tori paitan ramen, and the bf ordered the organic shoyu ramen.
First off, the oysters were already de-shelled, and on the drier side.
But soooo good!
I would definitely order these again and again!
My tori paitan had such a rich and delicious broth.
And besides the usual pork chashu, they also had duck chashu.
Okay, I actually enjoyed the duck way more than the pork!
Everything was so appealing to the eyes and stomach!
The bf also enjoyed his organic shoyu ramen.
He said it was different from what he's usually used to eating
but it was still good.
I saw some reviews stating this was the best ramen ever, but that they've never been to Japan.
I would say, for the category of atypical Japanese ramen, it's definitely very good.
But it definitely cannot compare to traditional Japanese ramen in Japan.
If you're ever in SF, give this place a try!
But be sure to get there early!

oysters in shoyu dare oil.author: Cara Y.
oysters in shoyu dare oil.review:
Thank you Yelp for being my go-to when I'm traveling and looking for places to eat! This ramen place we visited during our SF trip definitely did not disappoint!
The first night we saw the line was almost a block down so we decided to try here another night. We made sure to get there early so we wouldn't have to wait in line as long. The wait was soooo worth it!!!
While in line I saw that the restaurant is Michelin rated and I perused the yelp photos and reviews on what would be the best thing to order.
I ordered oysters in shoyu dare oil as an appetizer, the tori paitan ramen, and the bf ordered the organic shoyu ramen.
First off, the oysters were already de-shelled, and on the drier side. But soooo good! I would definitely order these again and again! My tori paitan had such a rich and delicious broth. And besides the usual pork chashu, they also had duck chashu. Okay, I actually enjoyed the duck way more than the pork! Everything was so appealing to the eyes and stomach!
The bf also enjoyed his organic shoyu ramen. He said it was different from what he's usually used to eating but it was still good. I saw some reviews stating this was the best ramen ever, but that they've never been to Japan. I would say, for the category of atypical Japanese ramen, it's definitely very good. But it definitely cannot compare to traditional Japanese ramen in Japan.
If you're ever in SF, give this place a try! But be sure to get there early!

excerpts: Oysters in Shoyu Dare Oil - This is 1 of 2 appetizers that they offered.
The other appetizer was enoki chips, which I wasn't interested in.
This dish may not look pretty, but it tasted great and paired well with the ramen.
oysters in shoyu dare oil.author: Helen C.
oysters in shoyu dare oil.review:
One of the best ramen in SF! I'm not a huge ramen fan, but definitely appreciated the dishes here. Given the high anticipation of the grand opening of its first location outside of Japan, we decided to wait a few months before coming here. Even so, it's very crowded and there's always a wait. We arrived at 4:15 on a Sunday, before they opened at 5. Our wait was considered "short" compared to others who arrived after us.

Oysters in Shoyu Dare Oil - This is 1 of 2 appetizers that they offered. The other appetizer was enoki chips, which I wasn't interested in. This dish may not look pretty, but it tasted great and paired well with the ramen. The oysters were cooked and tasted salty and meaty.

Organic Shoyu - Ramen with a pork and chicken clear broth, seasoned with shoyu and topped with pork and duck chasu. The noodles were handmade, flat, thick and al dente. Everything married so well together and the chasu was so tender and flavorful. 

There's about 28 seats and the tables are communal style. Service was fast and efficient and turned seems high here. We were in and out in 30 minutes. Our waitress looked stressed, but totally understand given how hectic is gets here.

excerpts: My friend and I ordered the Oysters in Shoyu Dare Oil, Tori Paiten Ramen With Double Chasu(Duck and pork chasu), and the Matcha Tori Paiten Ramen (Tori Paiten Ramen with Matcha all over).
The Oysters in Shoyu Dare Oil was unexpectedly very delicious.
There was different layers of flavor but every flavor was deep and tasty.
The price might have been a little much for this appetizer, but it is something that I can definitely recommend to others.
The Tori Paiten Ramen with Double Chasu was certainly an experience.
In my opinion, they really try to showcase the chicken broth.
The chicken broth to me was a turn off.
It was certainly very rich and creamy, but maybe too much so.
It was too rich, creamy, and frankly heavy & salty.
I've had my fair share of rich and creamy broths, but this one felt a little excessive.
The toppings were rather generic besides the duck chasu which I thought was very delicious.
I've never had duck chasu before so
when I had it here, it was a tasty surprise.
Overall, I can understand why some people would enjoy this broth, but to me, it's a bit much.
The Matcha Paiten Ramen was really no different.
I don't believe the Matcha added any type of flavor difference and
it fact
, if I had to choose whether or not it made the ramen better or worse, I think it made the ramen worse.
oysters in shoyu dare oil.author: Anthony Y.
oysters in shoyu dare oil.review:
One of San Franciso's premier ramen restaurants.

Mensho Tokyo ever since it's establishment has placed itself upon one of the more famous ramen restaurants in San Francisco. Known for its Tori Paiten(Chicken Stock Ramen), there is almost always a line at any given moment.

My friend and I came at around 6pm on a Thursday night. We expected the line to be a bit shorter since it wasn't the weekend, but lo and behold there was a line. We waited around 20-30 minutes for a table for two. Something to note here is that this restaurant is extremely small. There aren't very many tables, and the long tables often have parties unrelated sitting next to each other.

One note of the service here at this point: The waitress who served us would keep coming by asking if we were ready to order yet. I understand if it was every minute or so, but the waitress came so often it felt incessant, as if we needed to order as quickly as possible so we can leave as quickly as possible.

My friend and I ordered the Oysters in Shoyu Dare Oil, Tori Paiten Ramen With Double Chasu(Duck and pork chasu), and the Matcha Tori Paiten Ramen (Tori Paiten Ramen with Matcha all over).

The Oysters in Shoyu Dare Oil was unexpectedly very delicious. There was different layers of flavor but every flavor was deep and tasty. The price might have been a little much for this appetizer, but it is something that I can definitely recommend to others.
The Tori Paiten Ramen with Double Chasu was certainly an experience. In my opinion, they really try to showcase the chicken broth. The chicken broth to me was a turn off. It was certainly very rich and creamy, but maybe too much so. It was too rich, creamy, and frankly heavy & salty. I've had my fair share of rich and creamy broths, but this one felt a little excessive. The toppings were rather generic besides the duck chasu which I thought was very delicious. I've never had duck chasu before so when I had it here, it was a tasty surprise. Overall, I can understand why some people would enjoy this broth, but to me, it's a bit much.
The Matcha Paiten Ramen was really no different. I don't believe the Matcha added any type of flavor difference and it fact, if I had to choose whether or not it made the ramen better or worse, I think it made the ramen worse. The matcha certainly made the ramen look very novel however.

Overall I find myself difficult going to Mensho Tokyo again. The prices are pretty outrageous and if you're coming here to try the tori paiten ramen and you aren't a fan of heavy or thick broths, then this place is not the place to be. If you simply want to be part of the hype, then by all means, but I'd rather take my ramen hopes elsewhere.

excerpts:
-- OYSTERS in Shoyu Dare Oil (3 Pieces)...$5
(https://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/mensho-tokyo-san-francisco-2?select=dl2NqklWfTa36XWtThxdTw)
It may not have been the prettiest oyster dish to look at, but it tasted pretty good!
Being that it wasn't a raw dish, there wasn't much freshness or sweetness to the oysters.
However, I liked how the saltiness of the sauce complemented the oyster's meatiness so well.
oysters in shoyu dare oil.author: Mike L.
oysters in shoyu dare oil.review:
Considering how so many people rushed to check out Mensho when they first opened, this review is pretty late.  However, as much as I wanted to be part of that initial wave to check them out, I can't say I was willing to wait two and a half hours for that to happen.  My social calendar may not be as packed these days, but that's not exactly how I want to spend my time either!

Although the initial craze has died down a bit, the wait at Mensho can still approach two hours during peak times.  Thankfully, we were able to beat the rush and only had to wait about 25-30 minutes at 6:00pm on a Friday, but the line was pretty long by the time we left.  Sadly, our group was also forced to split in half, but it was understandable - with just a handful of communal tables and some counter seating, they can't easily accommodate large groups.

-- OYSTERS in Shoyu Dare Oil (3 Pieces)...$5
(https://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/mensho-tokyo-san-francisco-2?select=dl2NqklWfTa36XWtThxdTw)
It may not have been the prettiest oyster dish to look at, but it tasted pretty good!  Being that it wasn't a raw dish, there wasn't much freshness or sweetness to the oysters.  However, I liked how the saltiness of the sauce complemented the oyster's meatiness so well.  Yum!

-- TORI PAITEN RAMEN (with Double Chashu) - Rich and Creamy Chicken Soup, Pork Chashu, Duck Chashu, Menma, Kale, Burdock, Katsuobushi Sauce...$18
(https://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/mensho-tokyo-san-francisco-2?select=6oCdgfNJO79TLqfYAku5jQ)
While I still wish they had their tonkotsu ramen on the menu, this was great!  The kale was kind of odd, but I liked how well the noodles were cooked, how tasty the pork chashu was, and how tender the duck one was.  The broth was the star though - as advertised, it was super rich, creamy, deep, and very flavorful.

Beyond how good the food was, the service was just as awesome.  Orders came out very quickly and the workers were all super friendly, which was especially notable given how hectic this place can get.  If you want to avoid said lines, you can also try coming in for a late bite (they're open until 11:30pm, or so).  That is, if you're willing to gamble a bit, as they can run out of broths (and will shut down earlier than posted if they are completely out).

Though I'd certainly come back for the Tori Paiten Ramen again, I'd especially like to return to check out the additions they've made to their menu in the time since I came here (like their lamb ramen, which sounds very interesting).  Four stars for now (it's great, but $18 is still a little pricey), but I love how Mensho, Nojo Ramen Tavern, Marufuku, Hinodeya, and the upcoming Ippudo are making SF's ramen scene just that much better!

excerpts: I also tried the oysters in shoyu dare oil ($5), which were not bad.
oysters in shoyu dare oil.author: Jean S.
oysters in shoyu dare oil.review:
Wow! Best Ramen I've had! Mensho's Tori Paitan Ramen (double chashu) ($18) was super amazing and full of delicious umami flavor! The broth was very rich and creamy, but the flavors were SO tasty, I could not stop drinking. The noodles were cooked to a perfect texture, the bamboo shoots and kale were a nice touch, but what was the crown on top was the EXTREMELY TENDER and flavorful chashu. Both the pork chashu and duck chashu were out-of-this-world amazing! Definitely the best I've had in any ramen bowl. I only wish there were more pieces.  

In addition to the tori paitan broth, Mensho also offers organic shoyu, shio, and a vegan tantanmen. The shoyu and shio broths are lighter and not as creamy, which might be good for those looking for something not as heavy. (But why come all the way out here, wait in an excruciatingly long line, and not get the best?) I also tried the oysters in shoyu dare oil ($5), which were not bad. The menu states 4 pieces...they gave us 6, but they were very small and not plated very nicely. 

Mensho Tokyo is one of Japan's most acclaimed ramen bars, and this very location in SF's Tenderloin district, is their first international shop outside of Japan. This location has been open for over a year now, but the long wait is still there. I came late Saturday evening (10:15pm) trying to avoid the long line, but it wasn't late enough. I still had to wait 45 minutes (only!?) and didn't get seated till just after 11:00pm. (They close at 11:30pm and there were people being seated all the way to the end.) I hate long waits, but the tori paitan ramen was well worth the travel out and 45 minute wait. On a positive side note, the restaurant was clean, the bathroom was clean, and their food safety score is 100.

excerpts: I was also very impressed by our appetizer, oysters in shoyu dare oil.
The plate was small with only a few pieces.
However, from the very first bite, your taste buds just get sent through the roof.
oysters in shoyu dare oil.author: Sarah L.
oysters in shoyu dare oil.review:
Like all other reviewers before me said, the wait is long! My friend and I came in around 7 on a Tuesday night, and got in approximately an hour later. We luckily managed to snag two spots at the bar, which was more personable than the other tables, and the place was small. Also asked the waitress if there was a time limit we could dine in and she said no. 

I ordered the Tori Paitan ramen. Now I've never, ever been too picky with my ramen. I would be perfectly content with instant noodles,  obviously preferring dine in when occasions rose for it. But I think this spot definitely changed my idea of what GREAT ramen is. The broth was thick, creamy, and rich. And all the elements combined made for an enriching experience, from the soft, chewy noodles to the tender chashu pork, to the burdock root which added a very nice texture. 

My friend had ordered the organic shoyu ramen,  which tasted a lot lighter. Probably the healthier alternative, if you're looking for one. Although we agreed all the elements of it didn't match as well as the Tori Paitan.

I was also very impressed by our appetizer, oysters in shoyu dare oil. The plate was small with only a few pieces. However, from the very first bite, your taste buds just get sent through the roof. I don't know how else to explain it, but I was hooked. 

The whole meal was very filling, the service was good, and I would happily wait in line again for this place.

excerpts: We ordered the following: special of the night lobster ramen, the tori paitan double chashu ramen, vegan ramen, enoki mushroom chips, and oysters in shoyu dare oil.
oysters in shoyu dare oil.author: K S.
oysters in shoyu dare oil.review:
Worth. The. Wait. Walked up to the restaurant at opening. There was already a line of 25 people. The place only sits about 20 or so. Brace yourself (and maybe bring a warm jacket.) The wait will be long. On the upside, there is a liquor store across the street. I recommend bagging a cold one and sipping in line. (Do what you gotta do for ramen.) 

After one hour and forty minutes, we got in! We ordered the following: special of the night lobster ramen, the tori paitan double chashu ramen, vegan ramen, enoki mushroom chips, and oysters in shoyu dare oil. 

Bomb. Bomb. And more bomb. I would highly recommend ordering the special of the night. Even my devout vegan friend wanted to break the rules and eat the lobster ramen.

You might want to take some to go. But, don't forget your tupperware! (But seriously, bring your tupperware because they do not offer to-go containers. BYOT, baby.)

In the name of all his holy noodleness... Ramen!

excerpts: I had the oysters in shoyu dare oil and while these weren't quite what I was expecting, I enjoyed them.
oysters in shoyu dare oil.author: Maya S.
oysters in shoyu dare oil.review:
We got in line at 4:35pm on a Wednesday with 8 ppl ahead of us.

The staff starting seating customers just after 5pm.

Seating was communal and extra cozy. There are baskets on the floor to place your belongings inside.

Service was courteous and the staff stay on top of everything. Upon getting seated, we placed our order pretty quickly. We wanted to try the Ozenoyukidoke IPA but our waitress said they didn't have it. While waiting for our order, I counted 24 seats in the restaurant. 

I had the oysters in shoyu dare oil and while these weren't quite what I was expecting, I enjoyed them. The oysters were flavorful and firm with a texture similar to liver.

I also had the Tori Paitan ramen with double chashu. I tasted the broth first and immediately picked up on its intense chicken flavor and richness. When I cook chicken thighs in a pan, and that skin is browning and the fat renders, I could smell the same aroma in the Tori Paitan broth. It was very delicious and for sure unlike any ramen broth I've had before. I loved the thick springy noodles and the tender chashu. The pork was excellent but the standout for me was the duck which had a really nice floral flavor. I have to say I didn't enjoy the menma as they didn't taste like they had enough TLC since they still had that mustiness. I did find that as I finished up the broth, it began to feel grainy and my body was feeling that salt so water was much needed.

We were out the door by 5:52pm.

excerpts: and I were feeling adventurous so we went ahead and ordered the Oysters in Shoyu Dare Oil
oysters in shoyu dare oil.author: Sam K.
oysters in shoyu dare oil.review:
Pretty amazing I must say, although the bill didn't look too appealing for two people. Went a little overboard with one of my buds and we spent more than we had anticipated for two bowls of ramen, oysters, beer and sake (woops!). Money well spent at the end of the day (to justify the hole in my wallet).

Was in the mood for ramen and just so happened to be in the area as well... hey... why not give Mensho a shot? Line was not too long and table for two was seated in 45 minutes (it was 10:00 pm on Friday at the time though). This place is also very tiny, so not such a good place to dine at if you're with a party larger than 4 folks.

My bud and I were feeling adventurous so we went ahead and ordered the Oysters in Shoyu Dare Oil and I think our experience would have been better off if we didn't order it (personal preference of ours, it might be amazing to someone else). 

Japanese IPA and Sake made for an awesome double-fist combo as we downed the oysters.

I tried their Tori Paitan Ramen with double ChaShu - after my first bite, I knew I was in for something special for the entire meal. Broth was loaded with flavor, very thick and creamy and it was nothing I have ever tried before... definitely the highlight of Mensho.

Overall lovely experience, it is a shame that this place is so small. I'd love to keep coming back, but the wait is absurdly long during peak hours. You'd have to start lining up for at least 30 minutes before they open in order to dodge the epic-long wait.

excerpts: We ordered the Oysters in Shoyu Dare Oil, which was really yummy.
oysters in shoyu dare oil.author: Connie C.
oysters in shoyu dare oil.review:
There's so many ramen joints around the Bay Area and they're all good in their own way but none has ever stood out to me until I came to Mensho. Prior to trying Mensho, Ippudo Ramen in NY was my favorite ramen spot ever. Unfortunately Mensho has stolen Ippudo's spotlight and is seriously the best ramen that I've ever had.

Had an impromptu day with some friends in the city and kinda winged it as to where to get food. My friend was browsing through Yelp for awhile and he picked very wisely. He asked if we were down for some ramen and off we went. Luckily when we got there, the line was starting to form so it wasn't too bad. We got in line while my friend tried to find parking. We waited in line for about 1.5 hour which honestly isn't that bad since Mensho is pretty small inside. So keep in mind it's not friendly for groups. As the line started to move once their doors opened and people were filling up the tables, my friends and I were so close to getting in and we were close to making the cut.

While anxiously waiting we browsed through their menu and as people were leaving, we asked what they got which made the decision process a lot easier. Finally we got seated by this counter seating which was fine. We got to see the chefs in action and it was interesting to see the process of it all. I had ordered the Clam Butter Chashu Ramen since I've never seen anywhere serve clams with ramen. My friends got the Tori Paitan Ramen with Duck Chashu and the Spicy Lamb Chashu Ramen. We ordered the Oysters in Shoyu Dare Oil, which was really yummy. There was enough pieces for the 3 of us to try and to hold off our appetite as we patiently waited for our ramen.

Once our ramen had arrived, we tried each other's broths. The ones that my friends ordered had a creamy broth and it was so savory and delicious. My broth was lighter but still delicious. At first when I tried the broth for my ramen, it had a strong seafood taste but after mixing that whipped butter and all the other ingredients in my bowl together, there was a huge shift in the taste of my broth. It was much more flavorful and that strong seafood taste was masked...probably by the butter but I'm not complaining. The noodles in my ramen were a bit different from my friends but they were so fresh and tasty. So delicious!

The service was alright. Had to flag down a server a few times to get more water. They were busy and it was packed so I understand. The decor was very simple and minimal.

When my friend had told me it was Michelin star rated I wasn't sure how I felt but after trying the food, it definitely proved me wrong. The quality of the ingredients was amazing. As mentioned earlier, it's one of the best ramen that I've ever had. I was craving for more the next day because it was so good. We had met some tourists in line and they told us it was their second time going during their trip in SF. That speaks volume.

Highly suggest trying this place and try to come as early as possible to wait in line. There was already a line at 4PM and they don't open until 5PM. Be patient and you'll have some of the best ramen ever!

excerpts: I started with their one and only appetizer, the $5 Oysters in Shoyu Dare Oil.
There were four of them completely shelled and marinated (photo: http://bit.ly/1Vp0sEV).
Tasty freshness gone too soon, but the main event was about to occur.
oysters in shoyu dare oil.author: Ed U.
oysters in shoyu dare oil.review:
The advance hype on this place was off the charts, and the breathless texting and taxing anticipation from the hipsterati of self-proclaimed ramen connoisseurs has been quite deafening. A two-plus-hour wait for an $18 bowl of ramen sounds like a Louis C.K. joke about San Francisco millennials with no punchline. I got exhausted thinking about the hoops I'd have to jump through to get a taste of the broth here. However, now that at least six weeks have elapsed since the grand opening in February, I had an opening that I couldn't bypass, the Thursday before Good Friday when I got off work early.

Everyone says to be there at 4PM even though they don't open until an hour later, and so I did. If you don't count the screeching homeless woman who kept sauntering by, no one else showed up until around 4:35PM. That's not to say the staff was indifferent to my presence as they thanked me for coming and waiting patiently. Eventually a line did start to form and rather quickly. I got seated at the front counter promptly at 5PM where I had a nice view of the kitchen where activity was bustling behind he coffee beakers with the broth at full boil and the pork and duck chashu being meticulously sliced. I was sitting with a Filipino family who could barely contain their enthusiasm over the forthcoming noodlefest.

I was feeling the same way and knew what to order since I had well over an hour to decide. I started with their one and only appetizer, the $5 Oysters in Shoyu Dare Oil. There were four of them completely shelled and marinated (photo: http://bit.ly/1Vp0sEV). Tasty freshness gone too soon, but the main event was about to occur. It was the $18 Tori Paitan Ramen with Double Pork Chashu, and I had them add an extra couple of Duck Chashu slices for $1.50 extra because why not go to town? The noodles were perfectly al dente, and the chashu was meaty without being overwhelming. Slices of menma, kale and burdock floated on top with a katsuobushi (bonito) sauce spooned on top (photo: http://bit.ly/224L6pv).

However, for all the fresh ingredients, it was that rich paitan chicken broth that lingers not only on the palate but in my sense-memory. Just the natural creaminess of it was amazing, and what really makes this bowl of ramen stand out against the others. There are three other ramen bowls on the menu - organic shoyu, shio, and vegan tantanmen, as well as a selection of mazesoba bowls. I was timid and just had a $4.75 bottle of Sapporo Premium to wash it all down (photo: http://bit.ly/1RTN9dq), but they have pricier Japanese artisan beers which they strongly recommended to me for the next time. And there will be a next time even as I saw the line go down the block as I departed.

FOOD - 5 stars...best paitan ramen broth ever, period
AMBIANCE - 4.5 stars...clean, white and you only wish it was triple the size to make the line move faster
SERVICE - 5 stars...lovely people work here
TOTAL - 5 stars...not just for self-proclaimed ramen connoisseurs...be patient or come near closing

excerpts: OYSTERS IN SHOYU DARE OIL - 4 for $5.
Like little chewy umami bombs.
oysters in shoyu dare oil.author: Earl G.
oysters in shoyu dare oil.review:
Not necessarily the best bowl of ramen I've ever had but the broth in their Tori Paitan (TP) ramen is INSANE. It's super thick, almost gravy like, yet still remains pretty light. I haven't had anything like it before. You can tell the broths quality with it's texture and deep flavor, definitely been cooking for HOURS.Add in some super tender chashu (both pork AND duck), menma, springy and squiggly noodles, kale, and some katsuoboshi (bonito shavings) and you got yourself their TP ramen. Hella flavor! 

Normally, it's $16 for a bowl but you only get one piece of meat so I'd recommend getting a double chashu for $18. Personally, I got the double and got an extra piece of chashu (since that's how I roll) and boom, baller bowl of ramen for $20. 

Perfect comfort food for those cold SF summer nights. I ain't spending hours making a ramen broth so it wasn't bad waiting an hour in line (Arrived on a Thursday @8:30pm, seated at 9:30pm). My tip - It's better to go later, wait times are shorter. 

Other bites. 
*SHIO RAMEN $11 - very clean, deep, clear. The noodles were fettucine like.
*OYSTERS IN SHOYU DARE OIL - 4 for $5. Like little chewy umami bombs. Reminded me of smoked oysters from the can. 

Can't wait to check out more flavors of ramen when they bring them over.

excerpts: We ordered oysters in shoyu dare oil for appetizers, and it was tasty.
4-5 pieces for $5 so not a bad deal.
oysters in shoyu dare oil.author: Kevin S.
oysters in shoyu dare oil.review:
Mensho is so worth the wait!

I've heard from many people that this place is like THE best ramen ever. That's impossible right? Well, I'm not easy to please in terms of ramen, but the fact that I actually drank the entire chicken broth is saying something! The restaurant opens at 5pm, but a huge line already started forming before it even opened. My friends got a spot in line at about 4:45pm, and I met up with them 30 minutes later. Total wait for us was about 1.5 hours, but I heard people have waited at least 2 hours for this. There is no sign up sheet for waiting, just an old fashioned wait your turn in line kinda deal. There's also not a lot of seating inside, so the wait makes more sense. Once you're inside, you still have to wait about 30 minutes from being seated to having your ramen come out.

TIP: If you're comfortable and brave enough to eat alone, single seats are most likely available for you to skip the line if there are groups with odd numbers.

Parking in this area is kind of difficult, especially with all the one way streets and meter parking. If you wait till about 5:45pm on weekdays, rush over to take the parking right across the street. Parking is free and allowed at 6pm along this part of Geary. 

The menu is pretty simple too, with your choice of Ramen, Tsukemen, and Mazesoba. The most popular one is the Tori Paitan Ramen, but I hear the Tsukemen is bomb as well (chilled ramen separated from the broth). There's not too many choices for additional toppings like soft boiled eggs or corn, but hey if the ramen tastes amazing by itself, who needs it? Just kidding I still want my soft boiled egg and corn.

We ordered oysters in shoyu dare oil for appetizers, and it was tasty. 4-5 pieces for $5 so not a bad deal. Once my Tori Paitan Double Chashu ($18) came out, I just stared at my ramen for a good 10 seconds. IT LOOKS SO GOOD. Okay looks are one thing, but let's taste the broth. DROOLS. A rich, thick, & creamy broth packed with a lot of flavor. It doesn't taste overly saturated with sodium at all. Double Chashu is so worth. Most of the flavors from the ramen came from the pork, and the chashu just melts in your mouth. The duck was good too, but it had a subtle lemon taste to it. Crispy bamboo shoots were a nice touch.

The hype couldn't be more real.

excerpts: We ordered the oysters in shoyu dare oil to share and for myself, I got the tori paitan ramen with double chashu (because dammit, I waited too long in line to limit myself).

oysters in shoyu dare oil.review:
Pencil in an hour or two of waiting. But it's worth it. 

Mensho Tokyo opens at 5pm and so my friend and I came here at exactly 5pm. There was already a long line waiting outside the restaurant. Were they there since 4pm or just five minutes ago? I have no clue but 5 minutes later, half of the line went in so my heart skipped a beat at the possibility of having my wait time reduced in half. Even then, we waited for at least another hour and 15 minutes until we were finally seated. At reaching the top of the line, there was still a good thirty people behind us. 

There is no wait list to put your name down or reservations. You do it the good old fashioned stand and wait your turn. Finding parking in this area can be a hassle but there is parking across the street that is free and available after 6pm assuming you can snag the spot (it is a no stopping zone before 6pm). The restaurant is quite small and there's two rows of tables. The front row was one long table and the back row near the windows was sectioned off into two separate tables. It's communal seating so you may be sitting with other parties if you are a small group. I was sitting in the back row near the windows and our table seated 7 so our party of 3 was seated with two other parties of 2. If you're eating by yourself, you may be lucky enough to move up in line since you can sit with the odd number groups. 

We ordered the oysters in shoyu dare oil to share and for myself, I got the tori paitan ramen with double chashu (because dammit, I waited too long in line to limit myself). 

Oysters: For $5, you get four pieces although I counted five unless one oyster cloned itself. They're really tiny pieces and the Yelp photos are a lie when you see the close-up and think it's bigger than it really is (so sorry, my photo is now a lie). It's a little salty but still kind of tasty if you're into oysters. I'm definitely used to raw oysters with the lemon and marinara so it was a bit strange to taste cooked oysters in soy sauce. A good starting appetizer as you wait for your ramen. 

Tori Paitan Ramen (Double Chashu) $18: WOW! The chicken broth was so rich and creamy. I would expect it to be salty judging from the look of it but it wasn't although it was SUPER FLAVORFUL. In fact, most of the salty taste came from the pork chashu. The pork chashu broke apart easily with my chopsticks and melts in my mouth with each bite. Duck chashu was interesting since it had a slight lemon-y flavor. I definitely enjoyed the pork more. The noodles were thick (chow mein thick) and chewy. You get a big silver ladle spoon so you can spoon up both the delicious broth along with your thick noodles.

Be prepared to open up your wallet and drop almost $20 a person. With three bowls of ramen and oysters, we paid about $75 with tax and tips. Thankfully it's not cash only and they do take card. To the side of the restaurant, they have a single unisex bathroom that is quite spacious for such a small restaurant.

excerpts: Tiny little oysters in shoyu dare oil.
They were served cold and not quite appetizing.
Dark brown in color from the oil ost likely, oddly very shriveled and almost chewy.
Flavor was okay
oysters in shoyu dare oil.author: Samantha L.
oysters in shoyu dare oil.review:
This line is only for the patient and determined. Got there 15 min before opening on a weekday and the wait was 80 minutes. Right in the "TenderNob", there were we a few beggars hassling the line but Mensho Tokyo was trying the best they could to ask them politely not bother the customers in line. I don't know if there's any way to really get around this with all the hype! 

Oysters: Tiny little oysters in shoyu dare oil. They were served cold and not quite appetizing. Dark brown in color from the oil ost likely, oddly very shriveled and almost chewy. Flavor was okay but not what i was hoping.

We ordered the Tori Paitan, Organic Shoyu and Shio. Favorite of the three? Tie between Tori Paitan and Shoyu. They both have the DELICIOUS DUCK CHASHU but otherwise very different bowls of ramen. Tori Paitan's rich creamy broth is hard to compare to the lightness of the shoyu. Compared to other shoyu broths at other restaurants, Mensho's is definitely one of the better bowls. Great noodles all around.

excerpts: Finally, we tried the appetizer oysters in shoyu dare oil because it was option one of two.
oysters in shoyu dare oil.author: Corey H.
oysters in shoyu dare oil.review:
I braved the 1.5 hour wait on Saturday evening to see if this place would live up to the hype. My thoughts are mixed. I really wanted to like it but I'm not 100% sold.

On to the review, the service was excellent and once we were in the restaurant we were seated and given menus but not rushed even though it was jam packed.

The menu is spartan and focuses on the ramen. I would love to return here once they have some more of what I consider necessary side staples such as karaage or takowasa. 

First, we had the tori paitan with extra chashu. The broth is very hearty and fatty (creamy taste always equals high fat content). The ramen was firm and held up well. However, where was my ajitsuke tamari!? This is Japanese for soft boiled egg and I am not sure why they don't also serve this as an option. My guess is this will be added later but it was sorely missed.

Second, we had shoyu ramen. I actually liked this better than the first bowl because the broth was lighter. Now, I did know what I was getting into by trying the fattier broth; however, if you are watching your figure or want something light stick to shoyu.

Finally, we tried the appetizer oysters in shoyu dare oil because it was option one of two. The oysters were ok to me not bad but not amazing.

In sum, I was a bit disappointed because things that I consider fundamental to a good ramen experience and ramen dining experience were missing. Admittedly, the appetizers do not make the ramen but the ajitsuke surely does.

I will have to return and give this place another after they introduce the full menu. 頑張ってね！

excerpts: +1/2 Oysters in Shoyu Dare Oil.
oysters in shoyu dare oil.author: Erika C.
oysters in shoyu dare oil.review:
Three stars for the noodles themselves. The soups I tried left much to be desired. Neither ramen that I tried would bring me back. I feel like I'm supposed to like this place because it's so hot right now. and new. and from tokyo. but, it's just okay. 

gomenaisai not gomenasai.

++1/2 Oysters in Shoyu Dare Oil. (3 pieces) $5

This was good; a nice, simple appetizer. the oysters aren't large, and seems like something that came out of a can, frankly, but still, I liked it and would order it again. It just works.

++ Tori Paitan Ramen (Double Chashu) $18
(Rich and Creamy Chicken Soup, Pork Chashu, Duck Chashu, Menma, Kale, Burdock, Katsuobushi Sauce)

Ahhh... I can't eat this. It sounds good, smells good, looks good as food porn, but it is SO RICH. It's just short of being a gravy. I ordered this on my first visit and made a mental note not to order it again. On my second visit, I didn't order it, but when I smelled it and saw it, I doubted my decision. Then I had a sip of the soup and I was like nope. The noodles are really chewy, and the soup flavor is good, but after the first few bites it already feels like too much. 


++ Organic Shoyu Ramen (Double Chashu) $16
(Clear Organic Chicken and Pork Soup, Shoyu Dare, Pork Chashu, Duck Chashu, Kale, Kale Sprouts,Chives, Menma, Nori)

The duck was okay; chashu was better but it was nice to have another meat choice in the ramen. I think it was hard to notice the chashu in the tori paitan, due to the decadence of the soup, but in the shoyu, the chashu is a fatty standout. probably the best chashu in a ramen that i've had. the noodles in the shoyu are good, but different - thinner and lighter than it's tori paitan counterpart. it paired well w/ the shoyu broth. The broth itself tasted like bonito more than shoyu. 


I would not come back for these two ramen dishes, but I still want to come back to try the other options. As for the wait, we waited about 30 minutes the first time, and maybe 20 minutes the second time. Not bad at all. Once you're in, though, the seats and ambiance are not intended to have patrons stay and shoot the shit. They want you in and out -- in that sense, it's a traditional ramen experience.

excerpts: I was able to try the oysters in shoyu dare oil, tori paitan,  and shio ramen.
The oysters were tasty, but nothing too special.
The tori paitan had a richer and thicker broth than any other ramen I've eaten.
The new consistency was initially overwhelming, but I loved the flavor and finished more of it than I should have by the end of the meal.
The shio was much lighter and more similar to ramen broth you can get at other Japanese restaurants.
oysters in shoyu dare oil.author: Sean W.
oysters in shoyu dare oil.review:
Came here on a Wednesday night around 6pm expecting a long wait. To my surprise, we only had to wait no more than 10 minutes for a party of 2! I have to agree with other reviews saying the fewer people you come with the better. My only complaint is the space is cramped and on the louder side, making it slightly difficult to have a conversation. 

I was able to try the oysters in shoyu dare oil, tori paitan,  and shio ramen. The oysters were tasty, but nothing too special. The tori paitan had a richer and thicker broth than any other ramen I've eaten. The new consistency was initially overwhelming, but I loved the flavor and finished more of it than I should have by the end of the meal. The shio was much lighter and more similar to ramen broth you can get at other Japanese restaurants. The meat was perfectly tender and the texture of the noodles were on point for both bowls. 

Mensho is a very unique ramen experience that you should definitely check out. Hopefully you will be as lucky with your wait time as I was!

excerpts: We also ordered the $5 Oysters in Shoyu Dare Oil for appetizer, as well as a $18.55 bottle of Kikusui "Perfect Snow" Sake.
The Oysters in Shoyu Dare Oil were similarly raw tasting; I love oysters, but from the pictures I did not expect it to taste this much like the ocean.
oysters in shoyu dare oil.author: Amanda W.
oysters in shoyu dare oil.review:
Have you ever had ramen that was SO amazing, it absolutely ruins all other ramen for you?

Unfortunately, that was not my experience at Mensho Tokyo.  While the ramen is undeniably good and I am by no means a ramen connoisseur, I think I would have been similarly satisfied with a bowl at Waraku or Men Oh.  Maybe this was a dangerous product of high expectations combined with over-hype, but my meal last Friday night did not blow me away as much as I had hoped.

My boyfriend and I got in line at 4:40PM last Friday night, and we missed the first seating by 1 party of two.  The wait didn't feel too terrible--we were seated at 5:36PM--and I was excited to try the much raved-about $18 Tori Paitan (Double Chashu), as well as the $18 Clam Butter Ramen (currently limited to 10 bowls daily).  We also ordered the $5 Oysters in Shoyu Dare Oil for appetizer, as well as a $18.55 bottle of Kikusui "Perfect Snow" Sake.  Service was fast and we did not have to wait long for our food to come out.

The Tori Paitan was definitely the highlight of the night.  As many other reviews have noted, the broth is thick and almost gravy-like.  The noodles were hot and just the right amount of chewy, and the the only thing missing from the bowl was a soft-boiled egg.  It was my first time having duck chashu, and I LOVE duck, but I can't say I prefer it any more or less to the standard pork chashu.

The Clam Butter Ramen was a little more of a miss, and we probably should have ordered something more traditional like the Shio or Shoyu Ramen.  The broth started off tasting light and delicious, but over time the taste of raw seafood ("like the ocean") permeated the entire bowl.  My boyfriend noted the noodles were not hot as in the Tori Paitain; perhaps that was to prevent overcooking of the clams and scallops in the dish?  I was expecting the broth to taste a little more "cooked," so I would not recommend this dish if you are adverse to an overly "raw" seafood taste.

The Oysters in Shoyu Dare Oil were similarly raw tasting; I love oysters, but from the pictures I did not expect it to taste this much like the ocean.  Some pieces had sand/gravel in them, so at least you know it's fresh?

The waitresses are prompt in cleaning up your bowls after you are done, which I appreciated; however, they took away my napkin before I was done drinking my sake. :(

Overall, I am not in a rush to return, but on the off-chance I walk by and there is no line, I'd give this place another shot.  Finally, note that they do not offer to-go or take-out containers, but you won't be needing any since the portions run on the small side for the price.

excerpts: We shared two orders of the oysters in shoyu dare oil.
They were good but nothing to really write home about.
oysters in shoyu dare oil.author: Kelly L.
oysters in shoyu dare oil.review:
Best ramen in SF!

We tried our luck on Saturday to see if the hype was legit. Be warned: the restaurant only seats 28 people at a time and the line gets BANANAS. The wait for people end of the line at 5 pm (opening time) was about 2 hours. It was twice as long by the time we left. The host mentioned that 10 or 10:30pm was a good time to come if you didn't mind waiting until after the regular dinner rush.

Be aware that they are not currently serving Tonkotsu Ramen or White Truffle Shio ramen.

We shared two orders of the oysters in shoyu dare oil. They were good but nothing to really write home about. Definitely don't get them if you're planning on getting the shoyu ramen (unless you really, really like shoyu) because they taste pretty much the same. 

Our group tried the Tori Paitan, the Shoyu Ramen, and the Shio Ramen. I had the Shoyu and it was super flavorful. The broth was pretty strong on the bonito flavor, so if that's something you dislike you should try the Tori Paitan instead.

The chashu was A+ and practically fell apart when I picked it up. The noodles were excellent as well.

Service could have been better. I understand that they're working out the kinks and that the demand is super crazy, but with only 28 seats and a constant feeling of "we need to turn these tables over quickly" I don't think we should have needed to flag someone down for water and our check.

Overall, the food was pretty great and is definitely bringing the SF Ramen scene in the right direction. I'd love to come back later on when they have a fuller menu.

excerpts: Oysters in shoyu dare oil
oysters in shoyu dare oil.author: Vince L.
oysters in shoyu dare oil.review:
I've been hearing all this hype about Mensho from a few friends so decided to check it out. Come early because the wait is pretty long. Waited a little over an hour for a party of 5. 

What we ordered:

Appetizer: Oysters in shoyu dare oil

This reminded me of the Chinese canned dace you would have for breakfast with congee. Texture and saltiness were about the same. Would've never guessed it was oysters. 

The Ramen:

When I arrived at Mensho, I saw signs everywhere that said Tsukemen. I was extremely happy and anxious because not a lot of places serves it. I've been on a search of Tsukemen for quite awhile after my trip to Tokyo in 2011. We I saw their menu, no Tsukemen . It's plastered everywhere on their wall but no go. So I opted for their Tori Paitan double order of chashu. 

Interesting take on ramen. Their broth is extremely thick and one note. Noodles were cooked perfectly and had the right amount of chewiness and texture. Duck chashu was pretty good but their pork chashu was the highlight of the dish. 

Overall, nothing impressive about their ramen. I'm just glad it wasn't bland. Their shoyu ramen may be the better option.

excerpts: We also ordered the oysters in shoyu dare oil appetizer.
They were just OK.
oysters in shoyu dare oil.author: David C.
oysters in shoyu dare oil.review:
I was told Mensho was the place to go while visiting SF.
I waited 30 minutes outside on a chilly day in SF before being seated by the kitchen. The restaurant is quite small but it didn't bother me. However, I do wish there was more than communal seating. I've had ramen in Japan and throughout the states and I do prefer a thick pork based soup. 

I ordered the Tori Paitan and something just seemed to be off about the flavors. I'd definitely say the flavors are Americanized. It's not a bad thing but it's not what I like to eat. There was kale used for the veggies which was kind of a letdown. The duck chasu however was pleasantly delicious. Chashu was mediocre. We also ordered the oysters in shoyu dare oil appetizer. They were just OK. Think pickled oysters. 

You leave with sticky lips which I love after eating ramen but the flavor profile isn't your traditional flavor so just know that going in. Service was excellent but you do feel rushed when there are 20 pairs of eyes watching you slurp through the big window. 

I wouldn't go back a second time but if you want something slightly different from your ramen you can give it a shot.

excerpts: I also ordered the Oysters in Shoyu Dare Oil.

Tasted like oysters from a can drenched in soy sauce.
I wasn't a fan.
Also, I wanted to try a spicy ramen
but they didn't have it yet.
oysters in shoyu dare oil.author: Julie S.
oysters in shoyu dare oil.review:
I came here solo and still waited like 20 minutes. I'd recommend coming 30 minutes before they open. Would I wait more than an hour for this place? Probably not. If I am with friends who are fun and willing to wait, probably yes. I'm all about the foodie adventure! 

Compared to other ramen places, the broth is what made this place stand out. I got the Tori Paitan. The broth is rich and creamy. I loved the duck cashu. I've never had that before and it went very well with the broth. The noodles are thick the way I like. Everything just meshed together. I just wish you could add a marinated soft boiled egg.

 I also ordered the Oysters in Shoyu Dare Oil. They were interesting... not what you expect when you think of oysters. Tasted like oysters from a can drenched in soy sauce. I wasn't a fan. Also, I wanted to try a spicy ramen but they didn't have it yet. It was on the wall menu but I'd like to come back and try it.

This place is super small and you will probably end up at a communal table. Interesting fact I learned from someone I met at my communal table: the ramen broth making process in Japan would not meet food safety requirements here in the US. And I heard the owner is an expert Ramen creator from Japan, I trust that this could be the closest we can get to authentic Japanese ramen!

excerpts:
We got the following items:
Oysters in Shoyu Dare Oil - Livery texture and the Dare Oil is almost like a soy sauce/ponzu mixture.
oysters in shoyu dare oil.author: Jackie O.
oysters in shoyu dare oil.review:
Finally tried Mensho Tokyo ramen this weekend... I've been avoiding it like the plague because of the line BUT I was surprised at how fast the line went! The line was down the block but we only waited 40 mins max for 4 people.

Once you're seated the restaurant itself is tiny so please be respectful of the other waiting ramen lovers... just eat and go! Redford is across the street if you wanna drink and chit chat ;) 

As soon as we were in front and waiting to get seated the waitress took our order, then within 5 minutes we were seated. The tables are interestingly shaped they have these like slots for extra plating and napkins, then baskets underneath for your belongings. Stools so no leaning back and you'll most likely be sharing the table with other ramen goers. I loved the big ass spoons they give you... it's RIDICULOUSLY HUGE! :P

Probably another 5-10 minutes and our ramens came out! We got the following items:
Oysters in Shoyu Dare Oil - Livery texture and the Dare Oil is almost like a soy sauce/ponzu mixture. It's cold but a great burst of flavor if you love oysters and salty/sweet sauces
Shio Chashu Ramen - OMG... The broth is clear and super flavorful for a clear broth. I'm usually a tonkotsu kinda of gal. The noodles are not your typical kind and the Korean kalguksu kind, so chewy and perfectly al dente. The chashu just falls apart as you try to grab and eat... Only sad thing is that they don't do marinated eggs :(
Tori Paitan - The broth was more sweet than savory, but SUPER CREAMY! The noodles were different from the Shio and I wasn't a huge fan of this dish, but the best part was the duck... it was like pinkish and fatty but man. It melted in your mouth!

Service was phenomenal!

excerpts: He also ordered the Oysters in Shoyu Dare Oil.
oysters in shoyu dare oil.author: Cat G.
oysters in shoyu dare oil.review:
Waited 45 minutes in line yesterday evening for dinner and it was worth it. NOM. We both ordered the Tori Paitan - which had Rich and Creamy Chicken Soup, Pork Chashu, Duck Chashu, Menma, Kale, Burdock, Katsuobushi Sauce. I requested a spicy broth, - they didn't have it but they did have some hot chili oil / paste that she gave me and I dumped the entire thing into my ramen - so good. 

He also ordered the Oysters in Shoyu Dare Oil. (3 pieces) $5 - really good and super tasty. 

My favorite part: the NOODLES... omg. So good. Definitely recommend coming by for ramen. Staff is super friendly and tables turn pretty fast.

excerpts: Two of us got the Sapporo Premium:
sapporo premium.author: Elena N.
sapporo premium.review:
I've been wanting to try Mensho for some time, but the line always deterred me. Finally, on Thursday, July 28th, my group of three decided to brave the line around 10:30pm. It honestly didn't take too long. I think about 20 mins.

*Tori Paitan Ramen: Rich and Creamy Chicken Soup, Pork Chashu, Duck Chashu, Menma, Kale, Burdock, Katsuobushi Sauce ($18 double chashu)
*Organic Shoyu Ramen: Clear Organic Chicken and Pork Soup, Shoyu Dare, Pork Chashu, Duck Chashu, Kale, Kale Sprouts,Chives, Menma, Nori ($16 double chashu)
*Shio Ramen: Clear Chicken and Pork Soup, Shio Dare, Pork Chashu, Kale, Menma, Fried Garlic, Chives, Nori ($9)

My favorite, hands down, was the Tori Paitan. The noodles were the right consistency and the broth was rich and flavorful. I wasn't the one who ended up with this bowl, but I was wishing I had ordered it. My Shio ramen was okay. A light flavorful broth. But the noodles were the flat kind and I preferred the thicker noodles from the Tori Paitan better. They had a much better chew. I only tried a spoonful of the broth from the Shoyu Ramen which was fine.

We all know I can't have a meal without alcohol! Two of us got the Sapporo Premium: 355ml/12.0oz ($4.75) and one of us tried the Ozenoyukidoke IPA 12.75: 330ml/11.5oz ($12.75). Pricey for a beer, but a better choice if you like IPAs. I, myself prefer the lighter beers, so the sapporo was perfect for me.

Glad I was finally able to check Mensho Tokyo off my list. Was it worth the 20 min wait? Yes, I would say so. But if I had to wait 1+ hours in the SF cold, I don't know. I'm just happy I'll never have to find out.

excerpts: I was timid and just had a $4.75 bottle of Sapporo Premium to wash it all down
(photo: http://bit.ly/1RTN9dq), but they have pricier Japanese artisan beers which they strongly recommended to me for the next time.
sapporo premium.author: Ed U.
sapporo premium.review:
The advance hype on this place was off the charts, and the breathless texting and taxing anticipation from the hipsterati of self-proclaimed ramen connoisseurs has been quite deafening. A two-plus-hour wait for an $18 bowl of ramen sounds like a Louis C.K. joke about San Francisco millennials with no punchline. I got exhausted thinking about the hoops I'd have to jump through to get a taste of the broth here. However, now that at least six weeks have elapsed since the grand opening in February, I had an opening that I couldn't bypass, the Thursday before Good Friday when I got off work early.

Everyone says to be there at 4PM even though they don't open until an hour later, and so I did. If you don't count the screeching homeless woman who kept sauntering by, no one else showed up until around 4:35PM. That's not to say the staff was indifferent to my presence as they thanked me for coming and waiting patiently. Eventually a line did start to form and rather quickly. I got seated at the front counter promptly at 5PM where I had a nice view of the kitchen where activity was bustling behind he coffee beakers with the broth at full boil and the pork and duck chashu being meticulously sliced. I was sitting with a Filipino family who could barely contain their enthusiasm over the forthcoming noodlefest.

I was feeling the same way and knew what to order since I had well over an hour to decide. I started with their one and only appetizer, the $5 Oysters in Shoyu Dare Oil. There were four of them completely shelled and marinated (photo: http://bit.ly/1Vp0sEV). Tasty freshness gone too soon, but the main event was about to occur. It was the $18 Tori Paitan Ramen with Double Pork Chashu, and I had them add an extra couple of Duck Chashu slices for $1.50 extra because why not go to town? The noodles were perfectly al dente, and the chashu was meaty without being overwhelming. Slices of menma, kale and burdock floated on top with a katsuobushi (bonito) sauce spooned on top (photo: http://bit.ly/224L6pv).

However, for all the fresh ingredients, it was that rich paitan chicken broth that lingers not only on the palate but in my sense-memory. Just the natural creaminess of it was amazing, and what really makes this bowl of ramen stand out against the others. There are three other ramen bowls on the menu - organic shoyu, shio, and vegan tantanmen, as well as a selection of mazesoba bowls. I was timid and just had a $4.75 bottle of Sapporo Premium to wash it all down (photo: http://bit.ly/1RTN9dq), but they have pricier Japanese artisan beers which they strongly recommended to me for the next time. And there will be a next time even as I saw the line go down the block as I departed.

FOOD - 5 stars...best paitan ramen broth ever, period
AMBIANCE - 4.5 stars...clean, white and you only wish it was triple the size to make the line move faster
SERVICE - 5 stars...lovely people work here
TOTAL - 5 stars...not just for self-proclaimed ramen connoisseurs...be patient or come near closing
