ozenoyukidoke ipa.author: Maya S.
ozenoyukidoke ipa.review:
We got in line at 4:35pm on a Wednesday with 8 ppl ahead of us.

The staff starting seating customers just after 5pm.

Seating was communal and extra cozy. There are baskets on the floor to place your belongings inside.

Service was courteous and the staff stay on top of everything. Upon getting seated, we placed our order pretty quickly. We wanted to try the Ozenoyukidoke IPA but our waitress said they didn't have it. While waiting for our order, I counted 24 seats in the restaurant. 

I had the oysters in shoyu dare oil and while these weren't quite what I was expecting, I enjoyed them. The oysters were flavorful and firm with a texture similar to liver.

I also had the Tori Paitan ramen with double chashu. I tasted the broth first and immediately picked up on its intense chicken flavor and richness. When I cook chicken thighs in a pan, and that skin is browning and the fat renders, I could smell the same aroma in the Tori Paitan broth. It was very delicious and for sure unlike any ramen broth I've had before. I loved the thick springy noodles and the tender chashu. The pork was excellent but the standout for me was the duck which had a really nice floral flavor. I have to say I didn't enjoy the menma as they didn't taste like they had enough TLC since they still had that mustiness. I did find that as I finished up the broth, it began to feel grainy and my body was feeling that salt so water was much needed.

We were out the door by 5:52pm.

excerpts: I washed everything down with a Sansho beer ($11.75):
http://bit.ly/1Px6vnx.
Beer usually tastes like carbonated piss to me but this one was refreshing with a gingery lemon spice.
sansho beer.author: Cherylynn N.
sansho beer.review:
4.5 STARS

San Franciscans love shiny new places (and things). 

When it comes to the hottest new restaurant and food trends, many of us spare no expense with our paycheck (and time).

Last year, it was $8 for toast. Ok, not just "toast" but phuckin' bougie, tweezified toast. 

This year, it's $15 coffee (for one cup!) and $18 ramen.

Because, San Francisco! 

Next year, I'm bracing myself for $100 pizza. Oh wait, we already had that during the super bowl (well, I didn't but it was available at Tony's Pizza Napoletana). 

Seriously, what's next? 

Kindly let me know so I can start harvesting my eggs to sell! 

$18 ramen may sound crazy but people waited 3+ hours for this ramen on opening night! 

$18 for a taste of Tokyo? Why not! 

Mensho's first U.S. location is one of the most, if not the most highly anticipated restaurant opening this year in SF! 

Tip: Come at 4 pm (earlier on the weekends) or after 10 pm to avoid long wait times. 

Currently, Mensho has 4 ramen options available ($9-$18) with a single or double chashu option. When the owner returns from Japan in March, their menu will expand. No housemade noodles yet. They have a noodle machine but are awaiting permit(s) to use it (same for the tonkotsu equipment). Disappointingly no marinated soft boiled egg is available but maybe in the future? Beer only; no sake, soda, or juice.

My friend and I ordered three bowls of ramen to share:

(1) Tori Paitan: Rich, creamy chicken soup, pork chashu, duck chashu, menma, kale, burdock, katsuobushi sauce | double chashu $18
http://bit.ly/1XrzETT

Our favorite of the three, the kotteri broth was deliciously creamy (gravy-like) and richly satisfying. It had great depth of umami flavor but did get a bit gritty mid-way. The al-dente noodles were thick, springy, and had a fantastic toothsome chew. 

The chashu is sublime so pony up the extra $ and double up on it! The pork chashu is melt-in-your-mouth tender, like pork butter. It's so ridiculously tender, it falls apart when you pick it up. The duck chashu is silky smooth and chews effortlessly.

The only other ramen shop that offers Tori Paitan is Nojo Ramen Tavern (that I'm aware of). I tried Nojo's last night and there's absolutely no comparison. Mensho's is infinitely superior. 

(2) Organic Shoyu: Organic chicken + pork soup, shoyu dare, pork chashu, duck chashu, kale, kale sprouts, chives, menma, nori | double chashu $16
http://bit.ly/1QfmuKm

A much lighter assari broth but saltier with a slight sweetness since it's a soy sauce based. The duo of chashu were perfection just like in the Tori Paitan ramen. I didn't like the noodles which were overcooked, flat, and lacked chew. 

(3) Shio: Organic chicken + pork soup, shio dare, pork chashu, kale, menma, chives, fried garlic, nori | double chashu $11
http://bit.ly/1Loeijq

The most affordable bowl available, the shio ramen was simple and pure. The assari broth was light and salty but still had depth. Same delicious chashu as the other bowls but the noodles were disappointing like the shoyu ramen. In this bowl, not only were the noodles overcooked, there were two clumps. *sad pouty lip*

(4) Vegan Tantanmen | $18
I'm kicking myself for NOT ordering this too because I love nuts! The broth contains soy cream and 7 kinds of nuts, producing a creamy kotteri broth that looked similar to the Tori Paitan.

I washed everything down with a Sansho beer ($11.75): http://bit.ly/1Px6vnx. Beer usually tastes like carbonated piss to me but this one was refreshing with a gingery lemon spice. Loved it but not the price. 

Service is a work in progress which is understandable since this is Mensho's first foray in the U.S.. They only let 8 or so customers in at a time to not overwhelm the kitchen. They don't fire up orders by tickets, instead they prepare the ramen by type (they really should do the former). We received our order at different times and after people who ordered after us. If your companion(s) orders different ramen than yourself, be prepared to start eating first before the noodles get soggy. 

When I was line I met one of the restaurant partners, Abram aka Ramen Beast. He was uber nice and offered to answer any questions I had. Really cool guy! 

The space is small and only seats 28 - two communal tables and four seats at the counter. We choose to sit at the counter. There's more privacy (if you're on a date) and you can watch the chefs in action.

Read all signs before parking. Do NOT park on Geary from 4-6 pm (tow-away zone) on the weekdays, otherwise your $18 bowl of ramen will turn into a $618+ bowl of ramen. 

Because, San Francisco!

excerpts: Sansho Beer:
Yes, I did order that $11.75/11.5oz beer.
How could a beer be so expensive I was thinking.

Well, it did have its own unique flavor - it's an interesting combination of herbs, peppercorn into a beer, and it did go well with the thick ramen soup in a way that it flushed out the soup taste from the last bite so that every next bite was new and refreshing.
sansho beer.author: Simon C.
sansho beer.review:
After reading the raving reviews of this place I had been wanting to try this place so badly. On a weekend night I was done with gym close by and got pretty hungry, so I decided to just forget my workout and gain all my calories back...!

* * * EXPERIENCE * * *
Pros:
- Friendly staff (even though the place was always full and they were working nonstop)
- Simple and neat decorations and furnitures
- TV which was showing an interview with the founder/owner of this place explaining the uniqueness of their food (for ramen enthusiast)
- Food came fairly quickly

Cons:
- Looooooong wait outside the restaurant: Thursday night, started lining up at 8:30pm, waited for 1 whole hour
- Kind of pricey
- Cramped interior (almost elbow to elbow)

* * * FOOD * * *
Tori Paitan Ramen: A+.
Oh boy that soup base.... it was the thickest/creamiest ramen soup I have ever tasted. I almost  regard that as a paste. The taste was super rich and flavorful yet non-oily nor too salty. After weeks I still remember how the soup tasted like. It came with both pork and duck chashu; pork was tender as expected but the duck was surprisingly juicy as well. The noodle was also one of the thickest I have tried with spongy texture. The whole presentation definitely makes this the best ramen I have ever tried in the US without a doubt. With double chashu this ramen cost $18, SF price on the high side.

Sansho Beer: B+.
Yes, I did order that $11.75/11.5oz beer. How could a beer be so expensive I was thinking. Well, it did have its own unique flavor - it's an interesting combination of herbs, peppercorn into a beer, and it did go well with the thick ramen soup in a way that it flushed out the soup taste from the last bite so that every next bite was new and refreshing. But after all, I still have to say this beer is VERY expensive.

I absolutely cannot wait to go back either to get the same ramen again, or the Tantanmen looks very interesting to me too.

excerpts: We ordered (1) enoki chips (2) tori paitan chashu ramen (3) organic shoyu double chashu ramen (3) sansho beer.
We received the organic shoyu ramen first which was slightly fishy and caught me off guard.
It wasn't bad just very different.
The noodle were also flat noodles, which was also different from other ramen places I've tried.
Next we receive the tori pain tan which came with noodles similar to chow mein.
We both preferred the tori paitan broth.
It was much richer and, for lack of a better word, the texture of the soup was "fluffy.
We then received our appetizer, which was fried enoki.
sansho beer.author: Remus L.
sansho beer.review:
I finally got off work early on a Friday and was driving in the area with my partner in crime at 5:10pm. I told him I've been wanting to try this ramen restaurant that makes their noodles in house. So what do we do? We drove by to see how bad the line was. We saw two people in line, which meant we would catch the second seating.

I dropped the hubby off to stand in line while I circled for parking, which was atrocious at the time. Make sure you don't park in a spot that's a tow away zone from 4-6pm! When I finally got parking, hubby was 5th in line. Not too bad. We were seated within 20 minutes of my dropping him off.

When we were at the front of the line, the server asked us what we wanted to order. This way our food would be served to us shortly after we were seated. As others have mentioned, this is communal type seating in a small space. I couldn't quite carry a conversation with my husband because it was so loud.

We ordered (1) enoki chips (2) tori paitan chashu ramen (3) organic shoyu double chashu ramen (3) sansho beer. We received the organic shoyu ramen first which was slightly fishy and caught me off guard. It wasn't bad just very different. The noodle were also flat noodles, which was also different from other ramen places I've tried. Next we receive the tori pain tan which came with noodles similar to chow mein. We both preferred the tori paitan broth. It was much richer and, for lack of a better word, the texture of the soup was "fluffy." We then received our appetizer, which was fried enoki. We never had a dish like it and would order it again.

Service at the establishment needs work. The communal tables have these weird cubbies that the workers place setting in them. Without an excuse me, the workers would reach into the cubbies and startle patrons. I would never expect for someone to reach for something in front of my stomach. They should either (1) learn to say excuse me (2) place these setting elsewhere. I'm not one that dings an establishment for service but more of an FYI.

Would I go back? Only if the wait didn't exceed the one we experienced. Considering the price point (our tab was over $60 with tip), I can't justify waiting 1+ hours for ramen with mediocre service. Was it good? Hard to say but it was definitely different.

excerpts: On the bright side, the bottled sansho beer they have on the menu is amazing.
No one should pay $11 for it though.
Find it elsewhere.
sansho beer.author: Tracy S.
sansho beer.review:
Pretty good. Not really worth the 1.5 hours in line we spent though. I had mazesoba in Japan and was excited it was on the menu here. It's similar in the sense that they're both noodles, but miles away from the wonderfulness I tasted in Japan. 
I guess I can't expect the exact same taste, but at least serve the vinegar pourer together with the dish. The first girl I asked about vinegar wasn't surprised and immediately brought it out. The soup (more like a sauce in the case of mazesoba) was extremely rich and way too heavy, so I needed more vinegar. The second girl I asked was so confused and kept making sure that I was asking for vinegar lol. If you're going to serve mazesoba, please be familiar with it.
I pushed myself to finish everything because I waited 1.5 hours, but as soon as I was done, I regretted it. I felt like throwing up.
On the bright side, the bottled sansho beer they have on the menu is amazing. No one should pay $11 for it though. Find it elsewhere.

excerpts: The Sansho beer, which is perhaps my favorite "herbal" beer ever - with a hint of Japanese peppercorn.
Disclosure: this beer is expensive as f*ck at over $1 per ounce.
sansho beer.author: Aaron M.
sansho beer.review:
YUM - welcome Tokyo to SF!  Yes, this is the crazy thick broth ramen place that will change your life.  So do it.  Now I know you're going to order the tori paitan ramen which is their deservedly famous meaty dish with a chicken-ish broth, but let me also encourage you to order a couple other things:
- The vegan tantamen, which the chef recommended as his second choice, and which is an awesome, slightly nutty contrast with the tori paitan.  In fact, we kept alternating between the two because each one seemed to make the other one taste awesomer and each was awesome by itself.
- The oysters!  These had "shiyo oil" on them, which gave me flashback to the first time I had truffle oil: the first bite is a bit "unusual" or foreign, the second bite affirms that this foreign taste is actually good and fits in with other savory aromatic foods, and by the third bite you are ready to pay double the price just to have a little more.  Don't tell anyone but I actually licked the oil off the mini plate after the oysters were gone.  
- The Sansho beer, which is perhaps my favorite "herbal" beer ever - with a hint of Japanese peppercorn.  Disclosure: this beer is expensive as f*ck at over $1 per ounce.  Splurge and get two.

Out of curiosity we also ordered the $14 Shiyo ramen, which is listed on the receipt as "organic ramen."  OK to be honest, actually I wrote down "shiyo" based on phonetics but now that I look at their menu online, they have $14 "organic shoyu ramen" and $9 "shio ramen" so I'm not totally sure what we ordered.  Anyway, it was what thinner and what most people would probably recognize as "ramen."  Not as good as the others.  Still need to try the Shio... or Shoyu.

excerpts: I got the Shio Ramen and Yuki Nigori Lychee Saki.
Both were better than I had imagined and honestly the best dish you may find in San Francisco for the price.
The duck was exquisite and the wait staff are attentive without making you feel in a rush.
yuki nigori lychee.author: Jeremy B.
yuki nigori lychee.review:
Yes. The wait is crazy long. I waited an hour, and the last 30 minutes was filled with me watching other people consume what I could only image to be the most amazing ramen dish ever poured into porcelain. Not to mention the big screen TV that also taunts you with recordings of others eating ramen at an alarming rate. 

Even with everything working against me, I continued to wait and it was worth it. I got the Shio Ramen and Yuki Nigori Lychee Saki. Both were better than I had imagined and honestly the best dish you may find in San Francisco for the price. The duck was exquisite and the wait staff are attentive without making you feel in a rush.
